Overall, I desperately wanted to tell people that I enjoyed the film and that I fully recommended it. But alas my expressionless face said otherwise. Like Harry Potter films before, Narnia left me feeling tired and disappointed and desperately hoping for better book adaptations ahead. Go Memoirs of a Geisha!

title: Not as good as it thinks it is
review:
I'm not going to go over the ground so many of the other comments have made, although several of the comments frankly baffle me. Tilda Swinton was great as the ice-cold Machiavellian ruler, but fell far short believably beguiling Edmund. Why he should have considered trusting such an obviously ill-intentioned character was incomprehensible, and I put this down to her simply not understanding what her character was up to. I read the book the best part of 30 years ago and recall her being sweet and enticing rather than simply ordering him to betray his siblings. (Surely, being just a little older than myself, she read the books as a child? They were all the rage in the late 60s with younger kids, as LOTR was with older ones.) My other big gripe is with the SFX. Did I really see the same film as the one those who praised the CGI, the landscapes and the animals? A significant amount of the blue/green screen work looked cheap and unfinished - it may have passed muster 10 years ago, but not today! I've never been a fan of anthropomorphous animals (except for the occasional cartoon), but with the possible exception of the beavers, the sounds being made did not believably emanate from the animals' mouths. I found this particularly weird given Adamson's experience with CGI animation.

Of course, many of the reviews here (and elsewhere) have compared this movie to the LOTR trilogy or the Potter franchise: Disney probably doesn't discourage such comparisons, if they're favourable. Regrettably, in my mind, such favourable comparisons are misplaced: LOTR's scope and geography beats Narnia into a cocked hat, and the mass battles of Jackson's trilogy have set a very high benchmark; Narnia doesn't come close with its battle, which I couldn't even call "eye candy". Potter is a very different animal, the continuing storyline being its main attraction, and characterisation built over the series as the trainee witches and wizards mature. Attempting to show such growth in the limited running time of a single movie was always going to be difficult, and given even my foggy recollection of the book, much development was lost at the expense of under-whelming visuals.

A fairly crude measure of my enjoyment of a film is how long into it I am desperate for a break and how often I need to check my watch, and by that measure, this film fails rather spectacularly, as I lasted no more than half an hour before my attention wavered. LOTR and all but the first Potter movie came off admirably in comparison, but even that did better than this piece of over-hyped bandwagon-jumping.

title: Disappointing: Narnia doesn't come across as convincingly real
review:
A short advance review  I saw the film last night and I won't bother with a summary here: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is disappointing from the moment the child-actors enter Narnia, and it becomes outright bad after Father Christmas passes by on his sledge. Unlike The Lord of the Rings'"Middle-Earth, this fantasy-land never quite comes across as real. The reasons for this are four:

1.) The Special Effects are very mixed: some work, others don't. While the wolves are impressive and Aslan seems hyper-realistic, if somewhat like a giant talking toy-animal, many of the other creatures are lifeless or rather, soulless. Worse, the wintry landscapes recreated on sound-stages are plainly artificial, and the matte paintings in some scenes are simply awful, as is the breaking ice on the CGI-river. Then there's the lack of attention to detail. Why on earth do Mr. Tumnus' ears never move? They seem like nothing so much as fur-covered rubber-attachments, which in fact they are. (Otherwise Mr. Tumnus, played by James McAvoy is one of the film's few highlights.)

2.) More importantly, the child actors are obviously out of their depths when it comes to acting in front of a blue-screen. A lot of "The Lord of the Rings" works because the actors convincingly interact with each other as well as with the fantastic environment . In this film, that doesn't happen. The children are also hopelessly foundering when asked to portray the admittedly difficult process of turning into kings and queens. It's not enough to dress them up with some live action role playing costumes and hand them a sword for them to have them overcome their apparent awkwardness when faced with their roles.

3.) Some of the above may be due to the fact that director Andrew Adamson doesn't have much experience with live action movies, but comes from a Special Effects background. One example: When Edmund  incidentally the only child whose acting was impressive (but then, unlike the others, he had some character-development to portray)  stumbles into Narnia and falls backwards into the snow, he doesn't even bother to shake off the wet stuff that must have entered his clothes at the neckline. Anyone ever went skiing and fell? Or got hit by a snowball? See what I mean?

4.) Then of course some of the problems lie with Lewis'book. An amalgamate of fairy-creatures from all the myths in the world that don't really have any important dramatic justification just isn't to everybody's taste (it certainly wasn't to Tolkien's, a fact which caused their friendship to cool considerably). While such a miscellaneous fairy-world may work in print, i.e. in children's minds, it certainly is difficult to portray on screen without going heavy on the cliché-side.

Thus the tag of a Lord of the Rings"-for-kids used to describe this film is misleading. It marks perhaps the aspirations of the filmmakers, but not the final product, rather underlining once more the unique achievement of Peter Jackson (whose LotR-films, I haste to say, I didn't wholly like either; see my reviews). It also draws attention to some obvious parallels: The monsters, the final battle, the way Jadis walks up to and fights Edmund  this last very reminiscent of Lurtz fighting Boromir, who was also a traitor, and Aragorn, who was also a king.

The one thing I liked about this movie was Jadis as the Evil White Witch, played superbly by Tilda Swanson. I also thought that the costume-designers/make up artists did a nice job when they endowed her with a neat black and white imagery that underlined the black-and-white-opposition of good and evil that Lewis' plot is based on: The evil witch is white as ice, but her eyes never light up. The Faun opposing her is dark and rugged, but his eyes shine.

Thus in the end, with Jadis, Edmund and Mr. Tumnus respectively standing out, if not redeeming this film, The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is another instance of the fact well known since Dante's Hell and Milton's Paradise Lost, i.e. that it is always a lot easier to portray the absolute evil than it is to portray the absolute good.

title: Overly sophisticated acting on the part of the children
review: My wife and I were very disappointed with the Narnia movie.During the first 45 minutes particularly it was very labored.Throughout the movie the children acted in an overly polite speaking style, which bordered on the robotic. The two oldest children appeared to have a physical age of 15-16 years, yet they spoke and acted like children of a considerably younger age. The youngest girl appeared to have a physical age of 7-8 years,but she spoke like a sophisticated 12 year old. When the children tramped about in the snow they exhibited little discomfort from the cold temperature despite only wearing flimsy clothing. The highlight of the movie proved to be the lion and the witch and the costumes of the other various characters, all of whom prevented this movie from being a total disappointment for my wife and I.

title: The Lion, the Witch, and the annoying beavers.
review:
This was not a great movie. Its tone shifts severely from serious drama to near slap-stick comedy. Mr. and Mrs. Beaver, otherwise "straight" characters in the book, function in this movie as comic relief, throwing out "witty" one-liners every scene--scenes that were (and are!) serious within the confines of the story.

Beyond that change (which, and I can't stress this enough, really ruins the entire movie. Certain parts feel like Shrek; it's almost as though the director didn't trust the material enough to play it straight, to keep it Romantic, so instead makes it so we have to laugh at the characters; the book is Dr. No while the movie is Die Another Day), the other bad parts are largely expected for a Hollywood movie. The children's escape from the beavers is now filled with harrowing adventure (including a fancy escape on a floating iceberg down the river), entirely absent from the novel. The movie, obviously a product of its times, mentions "the War" (World War II) about a dozen times (it is mentioned once in the novel, in its opening sentence, and never again; the Nazi's London bombing raid is the reason the kids leave their parents), including a five-minute opening scene of the air raids.

The worst part is the battle scene. In the novel, the last battle is largely unimportant (in fact, it lasts about 5 pages); once Aslan is resurrected, we know who's going to win. However, in this movie, we get a huge, 20-minute spectacle of giant computer-generated armies clashing with each other (scenes inspired, in no doubt, by Lord of the Rings and Troy). Perhaps I'm just jaded, but I'm quite frankly sick of these scenes, as they are always the same. This movie's contribution has one good addition (the director doesn't include a score, a welcome change) and one bad addition (the movie is rated PG, so when characters maim each other with swords, no blood is shed; plus, we get some crazy editing to keep some violent parts off-screen).

As for the Christianity... I actually felt the movie expressed them better than the novel. The story is still the same (Aslan still sacrifices himself and is miraculously resurrected), but the director shoots certain scenes to more directly make the Biblical connections, particularly the scene in which Aslan is beginning to make his walk to the witch to end his life. The novel is very vague, but the film actually shows Aslan wrestling with his thoughts in a garden, obviously referencing Gethsemane. This movie also includes some curious Biblical dialogue. After binding Aslan, the White Witch declares to the crowd "Behold the Great Lion," echoing Pilate's "Behold the man ('Ecce Homo')" in John 19:5. Also, at the end of the battle scene, Aslan magnanimously says to no one in particular, "It is finished." (John 19:30) However, it was still entirely possible to just enjoy the movie; the Christian themes aren't overwhelming.

However, even on a purely cinematic level, it failed. I can't find the right words for it, but... none of the scenes were "magical." Nothing I saw in the film will stick in my head, while dozens of scenes from the novel will. It is just... any time the director could do something great with a scene, something fresh, something memorable--he just takes the easy way out. It just wasn't memorable. I just felt like I'd seen everything before, except executed much better in much better movies.

4 out of 10. Please no sequel.

title: I easily recommend it to all ages
review:
As quoted in the press notes...

"And then she saw that there was a light ahead of her; not a few inches away from where the back of the wardrobe ought to have been, but a long way off...she found that she was standing in the middle of a wood at night-time with snow under her feet and snowflakes falling through the air..." With that, C.S. Lewis sends young Lucy Pevensie into the magical world of Narnia. Likewise, once the big screen version of the wardrobe materializes, moviegoers follow Lucy into this alternate universe.

That's the true beauty of Narnia - it isn't portrayed as just a figment of the children's imagination; it's a completely believable, imaginary world. C.S. Lewis never told the reader how he was supposed to perceive it; Lewis was content to leave a lot to the imagination. Even the final battle for Narnia is described in fewer than two pages.

And that's the true beauty of the film - it takes the source material and fills in the blanks that had previously been left to the reader's mind. Visualizing in your head the fight between Aslan's army and the witch's minions is a joy for the creative, but watching a massive battle involving centaurs, minotaurs, dwarfs, giants, and a wide variety of other mythical creatures is truly a sight to behold.

C.S. Lewis theorized that if a book is worth reading when you're five, then it needs to be equally worth reading when you're 50. The same holds for the movie - I gladly recommend this regardless of whether you're five or 50 or anywhere over, under, and in between.

What makes The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe so accessible is its focus on topics that we can all relate to in some form - betrayal, forgiveness, selfless sacrifice, family, and loyalty. For Christians, the allegory behind the story certainly gives the film more meaning as Aslan, the Christ figure, battles the Devil's representative - the witch. But those who aren't as spiritually inclined will find this to be a great epic story of a battle between good and evil. The spiritual parallels are easy to recognize, but they're never heavy-handed.

Fans of the book will notice that the movie has implemented some minor changes, and you may be puzzled by some curious exclusions (why was there no Giant Rumblebuffin?), but overall this is a faithful adaptation that should live up to and probably exceed your expectations. What is there not to like? The actors are great (particularly Tilda Swinton as the witch and the adorable Georgie Henley as Lucy), the CGI is remarkably impressive (Aslan looks very real!), the battle is genuinely exciting, the world of Narnia feels real, the creatures are given life without ever becoming cartoonish, and the moviegoer is treated to a two-hour vacation from whatever stress or hardships he or she may be enduring.

There aren't a whole lot of movies these days that completely suck me into their world and force me to concentrate on the characters and the story rather than on the actors that I'm watching. Tom Cruise will always be Tom Cruise, and Angelina Jolie will always be Angelina Jolie. But for two hours Tilda Swinton is the evil witch, Georgie Henley is a little girl whose reactions feel real and sincere, and Aslan feels like more than just an impressive piece of CGI.

This is exactly the kind of movie I want to see more of. Go see it. If you think you're too grown up to enjoy this and can't let your imagination get the best of you then perhaps it's time for you to, in the words of Todd Snider, grow back down.

title: even the beaver had a suit of armour
review: I have never read the books. I really looked forward to seeing this film. I cannot say enough how horribly disappointed I was. A talking lion. Talking beavers. More CGI than I have ever seen in any one film. And absolutely at it's core, no story whatsoever. Pretentious and sanctimonious prattle. Completely unbelievable. I would have given twenty minutes -- any twenty minutes -- from any of the LOTR films then The Chronicles of Narnia. This is clearly Disney's attempt to cash in on what began with the Harry Potter films -- their foray into epic children's stories and the cash cow that they have generated. Brought to you by the man that gave the world "Shrek" and "Shrek 2", no less, who sat in a dark theatre watching LOTR and drooling over Peter Jackson's masterpiece and thought in all his naiveté, in all his conceit, "I can do that too."

title: Fantasy Failure
review:
In an era where fantasy books can be satisfyingly transferred into film, it was to be expected that the C.S. Lewis's classic "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" would be brought to life too. And it was. But without justice.

"The Lord of the Rings" trilogy and the "Harry Potter" heptalogy were as successful as possible. "Narnia", on the other hand, didn't seemed to put forth as much effort as the others. The technology used in the film didn't create the same magic as the other fantasy-stories did. As the film progressed, it became abundantly clear that "Narnia" was nothing more than a competition to "Lord" and "Harry" (with an obviously smaller budget).

Many people impressed with the film can argue that it was entertaining and enjoyable. This is all fine and dandy. However, it is mere fact that the film's creators didn't go about the project with the love and passion for the story like those of "Lord" and "Harry". The campy special effects, the underdeveloped characters, and the fact that the "Narnia" film-series is going to be abridged by four book leads to the conclusion that this is done for nothing more than profit.

For those who are bored and looking for something to do, you may enjoy this lazy excuse for a film. But for those who want to be impressed as they were with "Lord" and/or "Harry", wish to see a wonderful classic brought to life on screen, or just like seeing special-effects, you will be greatly disappointed.

title: Too much hype.
review:
When I first heard about a film based on the books by C.S. Lewis, I was hoping something as good as LOTR by Tolkien. Those two ere good friends and thus maybe the films about their books would be in the same category of great movies. Not by a long shot The setup and imagery of the film are very good. Loads of well detailed places that can leave you in awe. The castle of the witch is nicely detailed and I thought the wolf guards were well done.

However, the flow of everything else is lukewarm. The characters of the children are OK, but they are missing with those outside the children. Nor does the film explain a lot about the children, at least not in the beginning.

Plus, the fights and battles certainly don't inspire much out of a person who loved LOTR. Instead, they were disappointing and mildly funny in a bad way.

Overall, this is average. And for so much hype, that is not good. "C"

title: I encourage all children to read the book and throw the movie in the fire...
review:
Everyone who has read the book will agree with me, the movie is rubbish: There is no magic, Aslan is 'just' a lion. The books have a lot of room for your own imagination: anthropomorphic animals and especially Aslan are just things you can't film. And if you can, you're one hell of a Filmer, this one just couldn't.

I quote C.S. Lewis himself in a letter from him to producer Lance Sieveking: 'But I am absolutely opposed  adamant isn't in it!  to a TV version. Anthropomorphic animals, when taken out of narrative into actual visibility, always turn into buffoonery or nightmare. At least, with photography. Cartoons (if only Disney did not combine so much vulgarity with his genius!) would be another matter. A human, pantomime, Aslan would be to me blasphemy'

Nowadays, because of technology, animals don't turn into buffoonery like C.S. Lewis says, but he is still right about Aslan.

There is no spirit in this movie!

title: A big shiny package with nothing inside
review: I have never read the C. S. Lewis novel from which this film originates so I am going in cold and judging the film on its own merits and have no idea how closely it adheres to its source. The film starts off quite well with a lot of potential, but somewhere along the way misses its footing and ends up delivering a rather empty viewing experience. The end result fails to achieve the emotional depth or scope of Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings trilogy (films it appears to want to emulate), the imagination of the Harry Potter films, or even the ambition of the more recent The Golden Compass. The opening is fascinating and sets the stage nicely, taking the four central characters - two brothers and two sisters - from war-torn London to a more pastoral setting. The youngest child, played by the adorable Georgie Henley, stumbles onto a wardrobe that opens into another realm filled with talking animals, ice queens and epic battles of good vs. evil. Naturally, she compels her siblings to return with her and aid the forces of good - embodied by a wise, noble lion voiced by Liam Neeson - against the forces of evil, led by Tilda Swinton's queen. Unfortunately, it is around this point that the film begins to falter and lose its initial impact. The visuals range from good to merely adequate, with the battle scenes particularly smacking of CGI phoniness. Purportedly there is some pro-Christian agenda at work in Lewis' novel, but one really has to stretch to find it in the film as it just never seems that deep - in fact, it is amazing how quickly the film evaporates from the mind after it concludes. Swinton is suitably malevolent as the queen, but despite that none of the characters ever truly seem to be at great risk from her, which results in a veritable dearth of suspense. By contrast, Neeson appears to have become entombed in the role of wise mentor and desperately needs to stretch himself. He has become a veritable cliché. James McAvoy is charming as an impish faun who befriends young Henley, but then he is off-screen for far too long. The biggest problem lies with the central characters. The film works well when the emphasis is on young Henley, who is the most appealing and accessible of the siblings. Unfortunately, the second half punts her into a supporting role in favor of Skander Keynes, as her conflicted brother and the younger of the boys. Keynes's role requires some degree of acting prowess to carry one over the contortions his character is forced to go through during the running time, but he seems to only have two reactions - very surly and slightly less surly, which confounds any evolution. The older siblings have it even rougher. Blond pretty-boy William Moseley seems on hand only to appeal to the teenyboppers in the bland hero role and the film/story never seems to know what to do with the older sister, played by Anna Popplewell, so she instead just seems...there, like a prop. And therein lies the film's problem as a whole. It ends up performing the same function as a Christmas gift box wrapped in sparkling paper that holds nothing inside. It is lovely to look at for a short time, but then one is ready to move on to something with substance.

title: Not absolutely terrible, but nowhere close to good.
review:
While I loved the work of C.S. Lewis, I was not expecting a masterpiece out of this movie seeing as though it garnered much pop-culture hype, Burger King endorsements, etc. But I still thought it would, or perhaps more aptly, could very much be a good film considering the original material they were working with. It saddens me to say that I was wrong. Well it doesn't sadden me that much. Just that one of the great stories of modern literature was so terribly adapted. But I'll get back to that.

For starters, I feel the filmmakers did an extremely poor job of accentuating the emotional mountains and valleys that take place in Lewis' original work; The discovery of Narnia, the death of Aslan, the resurrection of Aslan, etc. I could go on and on. All of these, terribly executed. We see Susan and Lucy absolutely weeping over Aslan when they've known him for, what, two scenes? Also, how is the audience even supposed to care by then, especially if strangers to the story? And the discovery of Narnia. When the children all discover Narnia for their respective first times, their on-screen action basically says,(in bland monotone) "Oh. Wow. Looook. A maagicall land called Narrniaaa..." Where is the wonder, awe, excitement? In the films, it is nowhere. It seems at almost every major turn of plot, plot clichés and digestible drama is used instead of bringing out the full power of the situations.

I won't do a big section on dialogue, but I'll just say that I'm glad I rented this movie and wasn't in the theaters because, on multiple occasions, I could just not hold back explosions of laughter. Again, clichés and digestible, "I've heard this line 1000 times in 1000 movies" lines seemed to dominate this film.

GRANTED, this film does not absolutely fail. Tilda Swinton did great. And, while some may disagree, the overall acting wasn't bad at all. It was as good as the script allowed it to be. Well almost. But you know what I mean. Anyways, like I was saying, this film does not fail completely because of ONE thing, and one thing only: The story. Like I said before, Lewis' original work is just simply classic. Heck, even a comic flip book based on The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe couldn't be TOO bad.

All in all, I was extremely disappointed in this adaptation. I know some people get sick of LOTR comparisons, but there's no way you can not compare the two. The LOTR films captured the heart of Tokien's writings, with drama, intellectuality, AND accessibility. TLTWATW just seemed to capture the heart of the box office. Nothing more.

title: I love this movie!!
review: I loved every minute of this movie and cried several times. I think it captured the book so well and was true to every detail. I would suggest that everyone read the books first not only because C.S. Lewis wrote such an incredible set of books, but it will allow you truly appreciate the movie and get over the whole talking animals bit. I thought all the images in movie looked so real and the makers of this film captured the greatness and majesty of Aslan perfectly. All the actors did a great job playing their roles, especially those playing Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy. I remember watching a play of The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe when I was child and I loved it; to watch it again on DVD as an adult makes me feel like a little girl again. I truly hope they make movies out of the rest of the books. I think this movie is right up there with Lord of the Rings!

title: One of the best films of 2005!
review:
It's a portrait of cinematographic excellence!

Four children are sent to live in the countryside for the duration of a war, in order to keep safe. While at the estate of their caretaker, the youngest child discovers a wardrobe that leads into an alternate world in which a prophecy holds that she and the rest of her siblings are destined to come and save the people of Narnia from the rule of an evil white witch who calls herself the queen of Narnia (and is played to perfection by the icy Tilda Swinton). Many elements in the film are very similar to Christian belief, for instance the Lion can be thought to be representative of Jesus Christ if you look within the context.

The soundtrack is especially exquisite, especially that one song by Alanis Morrissette and that 'I can't take it all in' song.

Jim Broadbent and Liam Neeson co-star.

title: Well done, kept the integrity of the book nicely
review:
Having grown up reading the Chronicles of Narnia, from The Magician's Nefew through to The Last Battle, I was quite pleasantly surprised with this film.

I have an issue with making good books into bad movies. That did not happen this time. I understand that sometimes the books are just too full of characters, or sub-plots to be able to make a 2 hour movie without loosing something. I was quite happy to see that this did not happen with this movie.

"Gone With The Wind" is a perfect example of what I meant. The book was so powerful that they did the whole book on film. Then proceeded to cut/edit about 4 hours worth of the story, possibly more. The end result was still over 5 hours long. Fortunately, they managed to keep the flow of the story without damaging the integrity of it.

Then you take "Flowers in the Attic". They not only trimmed the original book, they mushed all four of the books into a very poorly produced 1 3/4 hour movie.

I was very happy to see that not only did they keep the integrity of "The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe", I was able to anticipate scenes. Scenes which were important to the story in the novel.

I understand that C.S.Lewis was a Minister, and had attempted to use these books as a way of teaching Christian Morales. Having read all 7 books repeatedly since I was 6 yr old, I honestly do not recall any attempts to teach me better Christian beliefs or morales.

The movie dos not have the feel of being anything more than a really well done Fantasy. If you are boycotting this film simply for religious reasons, perhaps you should watch it before you judge it.

I am eagerly awaiting the next installment in this well written and so far, well produced, series.

title: glossy, shiny, empty adaption of a 'for children only' novel
review:
I went into the film with mixed expectations - a friend of mine was enthused about it, another claimed it to be a total waste of time.

Itis a waste of time. The book by Lewis is a classic, which doesn't automatically make it good, filmable, or even relevant to todays society, morals, people, or just the individual viewer.

The acting by the kids is substandard, and that is relative to a standard set by child actors, who for the most part only succeed in being kids. Which they are supposed to be, during the first few minutes of the movie, at that point doing fine, therefore. Afterwards, when they're supposed to be heroes and villains, they simply fail. The costumes are outrageously bad. The white witch seems to protrude from some kind of portable xxl mix of victorian dress, refrigerator and michelin-man, the garb of the kids looks like cheap halloween costumes, the plate armour shows that the creator has at least seen lotr, but sadly also admits that he hasn't understood what was so great about the armour there. The cgi is not good. it's not bad either, but it fails to take you to fantastic places, meeting fantastic creatures;

some plot elements are awful, or awfully acted out: ------ the transition to traitor comes in a blink; ------ all kids, including the nearly grownup ones hide in a closet? ------ the girl is always chided for its seemingly extraordinary 'logicalness' whilst being only marginally more coherent than the rest. ------ is aslan a sadist, or why doesn't he tell the girls in advance he'll survive? ------ what, exactly, have the white witch and her secret police been doing these last 100 years, if the revolutionary army can peacefully assemble in a valley full of banners and brightly coloured tents? ------ the chase scene is as bad as any in 'knight rider' ever was; ------ the wolves, secret police of the evil witch, are incredibly inept; ------ the alpha-wolf, right hand to the evil witch, big bad evil overlord himself, attacks a kid with a sword - by jumping right into the point?? ------ no place in narnia is farther than an hours walk away, seemingly; ------ the whole ice-floe-waterfall thingy is plain dumb and the (cgi?)water oozes Caribbean warmth; ----- hiding under an outcropping while thunder of hooves is nearing (very lotr by the way) is fine, but in untouched snow? with the only traces leading directly there? (the traces-in-snow issue is completely left out throughout the film, presumably because all of it was edited in later, thanks, again, to cgi); ------ nothing relevant the children do has to be done by them or even any human children ------ why the fuss?. their sheer existence seems to provide the solution to all ill; ------ the white witch has not the voice needed to whip up three henchmen, bar thousands of them; ------ the battles (lotr-esque, again) are bloodless and pathetic. if that's for the sake of the children in the audience, so be it, but then as a consequence the battle ought have been a less integral part of the storytelling. ------ no props or buildings in narnia that weren't either bad, cgi, or bad cgi.

summary: avoid it, or take your kids <10 (the 12yo behind me noticed a major logical flaw(not mentioned above, trying to find it helps against the urge to sleep through the movie))

title: Unenlightening
review:
I went to see this movie, expecting to be uplifted and for the film makers to live up to all the hype I have read about this film. I also went to view the film to fulfill my hopes of producing an entertaining and moving version of one of my favorite childhood stories. Sadly, it failed to do so. The film was boring and slow in many parts and I felt the cartoon version when I was 12 was a lot more enthralling. Either it is because I lost the spirit for talking animal films, or because it is difficult for some people to relive their childhood favorites.

The only saving graces were those of the Beaver family which I thought were rather cute and sometimes funny, and I thought little Lucy was cute. Also the music at the beginning was well done and inspiring and the opening scene was clever.

title: I liked Georgie Henley. Otherwise, an Ordinary Movie.
review:
We watched The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe. How was it? Let's just say that the first half was good. I liked the mood created by the music, which was really nice and consisted of smooth woodwind noises.

But then the movie just got bad. I really didn't like some of the messages of the film. I didn't like it how the professor says that it is "logical" to trust in your family. What if your dad sexually abuses you?. Genetic relatedness means nothing. The kindest person in the world may be someone with completely different genes to you and the most evil person in the world may be your brother, sister, or father. Saying, "Trust in your father. He knows what is good," may sound nice, but what if you were giving this advice to Adolf Hitler's hypothetical children? The way Edmond all of a sudden changes I thought was weird. Still it all seemed unrealistic. The worst part about the movie would be the battle scene. It's the same old thing we've seen in The Phantom Menace, Lord of the Rings, Troy, Alexandra, and maybe more movies. When some concept is popular, the media executives really milk it, don't they? Whether it's martial arts wire-fu or reality TV, surely people must get sick of the same thing over and over again. I was yawning throughout the whole battle scene. We've seen it all before. Some other people are saying this movie was more incoherent and sanitized, and yes I suppose these are fair concerns.

I should also add that Georgie Henley, the girl who played Lucy, was strangely realistic in her acting. She was also a very likable character.

title: Technically perfect, the soul is missing
review:
Yes, it is quite perfect from a technical point of view. The animations are very well done, especially the beavers faces have inspired a great deal of respect to the makers of this movie. Also the voices of the animated actors are very well chosen and fit the faces like a glove.

But the story... I will now write spoilers, so maybe you shouldn't' continue to read.

Maybe I am just too stupid for this one. I love adventure movies where the hero gets into trouble or is helped out of it by pure and utter chance, this so unlike that in normal life the hero would have died long ago. I really mean chance, not some special skill the hero had or some gadget (like in most Bond-movies). But in this movie, it is often pure chance that ensures the heroes survival. Luck at its best. Okay, that fits the quite hectic change of camera positions, or unexplained changes of scene, apparently quite a bad attempt at portraying simultaneously happening scenes.

I also don't get some of the plot, the white witch (nicely played by Tilda Swinton) is the overpowerful master of narnia, some children appear, they are told that they would help to defeat her. One of them she tried to corrupt, but at his first visit she reveals her plan, losing all control over the child, instead of drawing him closer to her, although he would have been the perfect solution to her plan, since there had to be FOUR of them, as will be stressed enough later on in the story.

When they arrived, it was deep winter, since the white witch controlled the land. These children at first do nothing of any significance, and they are told that Aslan will try to defeat Her Majesty. So... up until the final battle, she is the ruler of Narnia, she is the reason for winter... But, also she hasn't suffered the smallest blow yet, nobody had stood up to her, everybody is just fleeing, suddenly the winter is over and spring breaks out. So they only had to arrive... Strange, especially when you look at the end of The Battle, aslan had to rescue the children and defeat the white witch; he is the only one she is afraid of, not the children or the hordes of enemies, she has enough soldiers herself. So, the children were useless, all in all, more a hindrance. I don't get it, maybe the original from 1988 was more easy to follow.

title: Fantasy for infants
review:
One of the great things about fantasy as a genre is that it can be used to satirise aspects of our own world that we find repugnant. However, the trap of all fantasy films is that a certain grounding in reality has to take place. When a plot device is used, its function must be explained. When a character is able to perform a great feat, the reasons and means must be laid out. Before I go on, I should point out that one video critic laid out a series of rules for judging motion pictures by their titles. One such rule is that the longer the title, the worse the film will be. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a very, very long title. And in spite of having a special effects budget that would have had C.S. Lewis salivating, it becomes a very average, ordinary film. Then again, Lewis only gets it as bad as his more famous contemporary, relatively speaking.

There is another saying in creative work that when you adapt something into a new medium, you inherit the source material's flaws. Lion inherits quite a few of them, not least of which is Lewis' childish conception of a fantasy world and how it works. Characters are repeatedly killed, turned to stone, or otherwise unpleasantly dealt with. Prophecy, magic, and general plot devices are used to undo all these events. Gee, a world where there is no conflict, no death, and no consequence. You can keep this world, mister Lewis, because it sounds like the same thing as being dead to me. Admittedly, it has been a while since I read the novel on which this extended Play School was based, but I do remember a serious problem with being able to deal with consequence or change there, too. I know this will come as a shock after I have talked about how fantasy epics such as The Lord Of The Rings suffered from the director's wholesale mauling, but this is one case where a big difference from the source material would have helped.

Another amusing moment comes when a Santa Claus figure, riding a sleigh into the edge of a forest, hands three of the four children tools for their quest. He tells us that MoneyMas has not been celebrated in Narnia for a century, since the oh-so-evil White Witch came to dominate this land. The audience they are quite obviously aiming this film at might be too young to appreciate this, but as films like Bad Santa helped us appreciate, MoneyMas is only a celebration when you have succumbed to the brainwashing. So Jadis does not celebrate MoneyMas? Okay, get a fantasy creature army going on me, because I do not celebrate it, either. One more amusement is when Dwarrow are shown in the film as simply being diminutive Humans (and yet the presence of regular-sized Human children and adolescents seems so significant). Granted, this is Lewis' fantasy world and not necessarily meant to make physiological sense, but sending such creatures into battle does not tend to strike me as a good tactic.

Unfortunately, it is the battles of the film that let it down the worst. After years of viewing such delightful films as RoboCop, violence without consequence easily equals boring to me. And as I indicated earlier, consequence does not seem to have been a word in Lewis' vocabulary. There is no situation from which our characters cannot be given a reset button. Nor, it seems, is there any blood when a five hundred pound lion leaps on a woman who has to weigh a hundred and seventy pounds, tops. And therein lies the fatal flaw that has killed every fantasy film of the past ten years. Lion tries so hard to appeal to that mythical audience of all ages, and winds up appealing to nobody. Tilda Swinton does her best to appear menacing, and she does a decent job in some sequences, to give her credit, but the script literally undercuts her at every turn. It would have been interesting to see how Lion and the next Harry Potty film would have clashed together at the box office, because heaven knows they are made with the same mindset.

Words fail me when I try to describe the positives of this exercise in driving in the middle of the road. The film is slower than dragging a dead lion across a yard up to the end, when it suddenly attempts to give the sleeping adults in the audience some positive memories by staging a very ordinary battle sequence. To the credit of the director, he manages to resist the urge to shake the camera about, but the framing of shots is still nonsensical from the point of view of anyone who wants to see anything. To be fair, the film also manages to give viewers a sense of the chaos and suffering that drives the children into rural England in order to set up the action. It is rather amusing to hear Roger Ebert, a man who has been criticising films for several decades, describe Lion as a film sitting on the line between traditional family fare and some new kind of action-oriented family fare. To me, this is symptomatic of the MPAA's utter inability to recognise that there are adults in the audience, and they also have a right, as one expects when they pay obscene amounts of money, to be entertained.

I gave Lion a four out of ten. I was gnashing my teeth over whether to give it a five as I gave Jackson's abysmal attempt to put half of The Return Of The King on the silver screen. I even said to another audience member that Lion was a better film, as it certainly had a better sense of pace and flow. However, I lowered the score to four when I realised that so too do most test patterns.

title: Loved it! Never read books.
review:
I never read these books and neither had my 7-year old daughter. But, she has the complete set of books now! She even got one of the "How the movie was made" books. Note - she reads at a 6th grade level even though she is technically only 1st grade age.

We thoroughly enjoyed the entire film and story. We took it just for what it was and did no comparisons to anything else - previous movies, other stories, the books. The acting and special effects were completely wonderful. We had no complaints for any of the graphics. It was all very believable.

We did think it was a tiny bit slow in a couple of points and overall, a tiny bit long, but since it isn't really a story or movie for very young audiences (5 and younger), this was okay.

title: Could have been better
review: I was very excited when I saw the trailer for Narnia, mainly cause this is one of my favorite books and it looked like it was very well done. The first half of the movie or where they were at the proffesor's house was according to the book and the actors they chose for the kids were very good all of them believable, Lucy was the innocent, Edmund was the bully, Susan was the sensible one and last but not at all least was Peter the heroic one. However Liam Neeson was not believable as Aslan and I don't understand why they didn't get somebody like Anthony Hopskins to talk for him. Jadis was not believable as the charming evil witch in the beginning and I feel that they didn't give her a good enough introduction. The biggest mistake were the relationships. Peter and Edmund didn't seem to have as much hatred towards each other as in the books, and there was way too much hugging and crying, in fact I felt like they were concentrating more on making this a blockbuster then making this a good movie. There was no playfulness in Aslan as there is in the book and they didn't make Aslan as respectable and fun as they could have, again I felt like he didn't get a decent introduction and therefore when the whitch killed him I wasn't sad at all. The part where the girls were crying over his death was long and I got sick of it. Jadis looked ridiculous in those clothes which seem to be cut from an 80's magazine. I definitely think that they should have spent more time on the script and less time on making this a Hollywood movie, I don't know if it is the producer or the directors or even just because this was a Disney film. So to sum up this movie left me lukewarm like annegirl8 said and this could have been a much better movie if they wouldn't have made it so lame. Kids movie not for the adult fans.

title: You have a lion, a witch and a wardrobe... What more would a movie need?
review:
This film could only have been made in the past five years or so. The sequences were visually eloquent and intense. Certainly a "must see"for fans of both this film's genre and the book from whence it came!

The children that are playing the roles of the four children that find the wardrobe and inevitably free Narnia from the cruelty of the White Witch, were intense in their portrayals.

Of course, the veteran actors (such as Kate Blanchette) turned in their typical flawless performances. (If you are a martial arts fan, you might also want to take a look at the final seen with the White Witch. VERY COMPETENT SWORD WORK BY MS. BLANCHETTE!!)

I took my three-year-old to see this film with his slightly older brothers. I was amazed that this film kept him engaged for its entire run (and awake in spite of the fact that we had attended the 7 o'clock showing)!

If you have the opportunity to see this film in digital, please do. The effects are greatly enhanced and brought to life with a crispness not available with the standard movie theater setting.

title: Good Movie, but don't watch if you don't like fantasy!
review:
Hi,

I'm from Germany and I just saw "The Chronicles of Narnia-The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe" and I was impressed by the movie. The movie is nearly a complete adaption of the book written by C.S. Lewis in the Fifties of the last century. Although, I have to mention that there are some elements of the story which I personally missed but maybe it is because I saw "Narnia" from an adult perspective. For example the criticism of using drugs. However, the movie was impressive but if you do not like speaking beavers and several other animals you know of the world of fantasy like a lion, which is the king of the world of Narnia you won't get satisfied with the movie. Furthermore it is noteworthy that it was written for children this is why the story isn't of that complexity compared to the one of the "Lord of the Rings". Well, the story begins in WW-II and four children are being evacuated from the city to the countryside of the Kingdom of England, to prevent that the nation will have to face a lack of procreation after the war. The children get to the house of an old professor by train. At first sight it seemed to them like a boring place and they don't know what to do there but as the youngest of them finds a mysterious wardrobe as a hiding place in which she finds another world, called Narnia. Boredom is over and the adventures begins. It is an adventure, on the one hand containing betrayal and evil but on the other hand love and the good. The destination of the four children is to to break the spell of an 100 year lasting winter in Narnia spoken by the evil white which.If they are able to confirm their dangerous quest or fail I won't tell...

In conclusion I want to say, why I didn't gave the movie 10 out of 10. To my mind Andrew Adamson played a "bit" to much with bytes! You'll sometimes get the feeling that they have a photographic wallpaper put behind the scene declared as a background. In my opinion nowadays technology of SFX is that advanced, as we saw in the lord of the rings that one is able to make it look more realistic than it was in this movie. For example the beavers would perfectly fit into ice age 2 but not into Narnia. Another important thing to mention is that it wasn't such a bad movie but people who aren't interested in the world of fantasy shouldn't spent their hard earned money for Narnia because I aren't willing to listen to your cant that the movie sucked. Most of those people should read the book before watching the movie to get another perspective to it!

After all it is not easy to make a quick judgment. There are only little aspects being mentioned and I have to tell so much more...

And finally don't forget that Narnia is not Middle earth!

title: Bad, very bad
review: This movie is an absolute waste of money and time. It was boring (not only for me but for my 11 yo nephew) from the beginning to the end. All actors, excepting the queen, are really bad. Even if the rest were fine (that is not the case), they would spoil the movie just by themselves. I wonder what was the casting director doing while that maniac was doing his work. The movie is slow, very very slow, and never really tells anything. The main important questions in the story remain unexplained in the end. It's just images and cgis appearing one after the other for 2 hours. The cgis were very nice to look at, though. And finally, leaving the Christian issue aside, it's a story full of clichés, and tries to perpetuate the most traditional roles. It's two couples of kids and in each couple the elder kid is a boy (woman dependency on man). There is an obvious reference to grow up(sex) and how kids should avoid it and remain pure. "Sex is bad" and "Women depend on men" aren't the ideas I want to teach my kids.

title: This movie is SO SO .... SO SO SO ... LAME ...! ( read it its not flaming )
review:
... The lights go out ... Andrew Adamson (director) is also there ... And the picture starts ...

Night, dark sky. Nazis all around ... Nazis start London bombing ... A hose. The HORROR of the bombing, the noble and stupid disobedience of stupid brother a.k.a future traitor, is in the beginning of the scandal with future king a.k.a Bigger brother. Symbols. The kids get on a train to go far away from the mean Nazis invading england. On the background of the speeding train goes the title - "The Chronicles of Narnia"

The audience: - Phuuuh, we thought we got the wrong movie!

Railroad station. Behind the corner a carriage comes up.

The audience: - Gandalf?

NOP, its just me the strict butler (not to forget we are in england)

Half and hour screen time goes by, and a kid finds its self in front of a wardrobe, she is so excited to find it that she nearly grows wings! So the kid finds a wardrobe filled with fur coats ( probably of killed Narnia beasts, probably symbols) the kid goes Through the wardrobe and finds it self in the the snowed up forest of Narnia.

Forest. And in the middle of the picture, a gas lamp. SYMBOL.

The audience: ( gets the idea) - This must be some kind of a symbol.

After a few boring minutes the conflict in the family is all "good to go" for the movie...

Then we meet Tilda Swinton ( with her shocking beauty she played an angel as well as a witch)

Andrew - director bursts : -THE WHITE WITCH!!! NOT THE SNOW QUEEN!!! THE WHITE WITCH!!! STOP IT!!

The audience: -But Andrew, nobody said anything, it kinda looks like her, not to say it kinda the same thing ...

Tilda Swinton - THE WHITE WITCH!!!NOT THE SNOW QUEEN : -Young SON OF ADAM, have some Turkish delight, have some, have some, drink up your tea, do you want some pie ?

And it goes on, the young kids find out that all decedents of Adam and Eve are wanted criminals for been a part of some prophecy, and they all so get the SHOCKING news that Narnia didn't have Xmas in a 100 years!!!

The audience: -Did they say Xmas ? So they have Jisus in Narnia? So they have the Roman empire, which means the got the Jews too, so are we waiting for the Nazis to start bombing Narnia!?? What about everything else! What is going on here!? How does Narnia know about Adam and Eve? Do the creatures there read the bible? Or this is another SYMBOL ? You naughty boy Lewis (author), this is probably some "modern" style ...

In the mean time the conflict between the children is so hot that they are ready to start bitch slapping each other...

Stupid brother a.k.a The traitor

Screw you all!, ill sell you out for a lump of sugar!

The kids find a family of beavers which help them get away from the gestapo wolves which chase them because the kids got reported by STUPID BROTHER a.k.a THE TRAITOR! Yet the gestapo wolves don't give up, and the escape goes along with the arguing - "Whos the leader", "where are we running to", "whos fault is it". Its the fox's turn to help.

The hardcore fantasy fans : Whats with the zoo? When do the ORCS show up?!

Andrew (director): You probably dint get it, there are no ORCS!

The hardcore fantasy fans : Xa!, even kids know that there is no fantasy with no ORCS LOL.

Andrew (director): Ah, well there is fantasy... and fantasy ...

The gestapo wolves find the tracks of the two girls and bigger brother a.k.a future king, since they were again reported by stupid brother a.k.a THE TRAITOR!

STUPID BROTHER a.k.a THE TRAITOR : -I've done so much don't i get a Snikers or something, apple pie better!

Gestapo wolves, beavers, fox and kids all run around, hide, jump, swim and WALLA they find Santa!

Then he starts with the gifts;

  • For you little girl a dagger!, to cut enemy throats in the night.. - For you bigger girl, a bow and some arrows, nail em between the eyes! - And for you DUDE it The sword to cut the skulls open of whatever stands in your way... - And for the other guy ? Aaah he is a lowlife nothing for him. - Merry Xmas kids, wish you many killing sprees ...


The audience: -Santa is preparing kids for a massacre? -Oooh, we probably missed something between word or frames. -There gotta be some UBER DEEP THOUGHT and SYMBOLS YEAH MHM! Well we should be happy he didn't give them adult videos.

After some boring and stupid adventures, never giving the sword a brake, they arrive in the headquarters of the good forces. And out of the main tent comes the guarantee of and happy ending The LION!

The lion: Grrrr!(and then goes on to English official language of all Narnia creatures) - Why are you only 3 ?

Future King a.k.a Bigger bother : - Well our brother turned out to be a dumb bitch, sold as out of some Turkish delight...

Lion: -Dont be so harsh on him, he probably has a GOOD reason for it.

The audience: -Is that lion stupid!? They already told him of the Turkish delight!

Lion & Co go rescuing Stupid Brother a.k.a The traitor. Later... A short private talk with the lion, stupid brother a.k.a the traitor is been forgiven everything and the love between the kids starts on.

title: 180,000,000 $ spent on nothing much...
review:
IMDb gives the above number as the budget of this film. I'm wondering where all that money went to: The acting is of the worst kind, the story unbelievably laughable, the dialogue is tiring, CGI and effects look awful, there's no kind of storytelling whatsoever, etc. etc.

Here's some of the (dozens of) questions that came up and were left unanswered during this movie:

Why are humans so important in that world? Why are pigs and cattle 'bad' animals and others (beaver, fox) 'good'? Why is everybody eager to give their life for some children that never have proved themselves worthy for it? Why doesn't Mr. Tumnus fall over when standing still - I mean, he's only got two hooves and according to physics and gravity he has to fall over unless he scuttles. What did the professor give the children at the end of the movie? Why is the white witch able to put a whole country under snow, but isn't able to kill some inept children? Why does everybody in this movie have to speak in such a momentous and meaningful voice - all of the time? Did anybody ever think about what this raw blend of racism, violence and salvation myths does to the suggestible minds of children (i.e. the target audience)?

I guess the idea behind all that was just to make tons of money from people wanting to see some pseudo-Christian-and-fantasy-themed movie. So they spent 1.50 $ on screenplay, actors, effects and direction respectively and the rest of all those millions went into advertising to trick people into paying money for this thing. It's the only way I can understand how such a piece (that would get the worst grade at every writing and directing school) could make it onto screen.

Go for the 1989 version instead - at least it had no budget to go along with no story, lame acting and even worse effects. Or simply wait till it's on free-TV - don't support something like that with your hard earned money.

title: Lord of the Rings for Kids and not as entertaining.
review:
I saw this at a midnight showing and I couldn't stop checking my watch every 20 or 30 minutes.

***Some SPOILERS present*** (not that there's really any surprises to spoil) While Tilda Swinton is as awesome as ever as the White Witch, everyone else is as dull as the clichéd storyline and special effects. Nothing about this film was believable. Thing such as Peter being able to fight off the witch, who obviously knows what she's doing, with a sword only with a couple of days of sword training, Santa popping out of nowhere to give the children gifts which happen to solve all their problems, everyone that died coming back to life at the end just by the Lion breathing on them, things like this caused my eyes to roll numerous times. Of course the battle scenes, nothing is shown, just some off screen animal cries and jagged camera-work that makes you care even less what is happening.

By the end, I was not caring anything about any of the characters in this film and was only truly enjoying the scenes where the White Witch was present. This is yet another franchise that will probably make tons at the box office, but mostly due to the religious masses who will go to see the Aslan "Jesus" figure and the other numerous biblical undertones.

All in all, a forgettable, strictly by the numbers, bland film and I can only hope that they don't make films from the other books in the series.

title: More wooden British kids and wordy magic adults
review:
I haven't read the books. My wife had, whom I accompanied to this movie. I like fiction, however.

But this movie was a waste of time. Another 2005 dose of British kids in a stuffy old mansion and a stern housekeeper. Oh no, they can't play like proper British kids! Oh no, the little one is bored and sad! (OK, so maybe that was in the book, but couldn't they tone it down a bit?) Then Narnia is discovered, a soundstage with some rocks. Next, a cute British kid's interaction with a goat-boy. Later, a queen on the same soundstage. Then when they all come, more soundstage action and a CGI house. And the requisite funny small furries, which are always so appropriate when millions of lives are at stake.

Then there's a Q-branch scene out of Bond where the kids get gadgets from Santa Claus (??). Then the kids go lead an army which has somehow assembled under a Queen's nose without her knowledge, despite having the forest creatures on her side (she needs to get off that soundstage and survey her land a little bit). Somehow no professional in the grand army cares that inexperienced CHILDREN are leading thousands into battle.

Then the lion dies. And is resurrected - in the sloppiest plot "fuhgeddaboutit" since the latest episode of DragonBall Z. So the queen just forgot to read the fine print? Jeez, weren't the Queen and Aslan in the tent debating this for like, a long time? So the battle happens. It's more like a big schoolyard slapfest. No divisions, no regimented forces. Hills on both sides remain unoccupied. Flanking & maneuvering are ignored by this professional army with generals and officers, despite the gobs of gold obviously spent on Windex and nice tents. Cavalry is thrown pell-mell into the fray with the infantry. The flying rock-dropping Griffins glide blindly into a curtain of arrows. Couldn't they use the air power to soften the enemy at night? Did CS Lewis pay attention to the war raging around him? In all, I was astonished by the characters' lack of accountability. Pure imagination without regard for consequence. Lazy, lazy, lazy storytelling. And at the end, the entire movie cancels ITSELF out by kicking the kids out of Narnia. Somehow, the kids don't care. Their loyal subjects, which were promised these rulers by prophecy, have now lost them. And these four little British brats simply dust themselves off and continue their childhoods. None of them cry out for their lost kingdoms. I hope the people of Narnia die of sheer stupidity.

title: I am PAINED by the potential this Movie misses out
review:
My heart aflutter, I settled in the seat for what promised to be, well, a modern classic. The movie does have its moments - the special effects are terrific, the overall "environment" created splendid and the "feel" of the film is technically excellent. The music is enjoyable.

But frankly, thats where the accolades end. I am pained that a film with such tremendous potential could fall so flat that finally it was an exercise in patience to sit through the whole 140 mins. Having said as much, it is worth a see ~ but with MUCH lowered expectations than what the studios and marketing drones in Hollywood would have us collectively believe the delights the film holds.

I found in Tilda Swinton's portrayal of the Evil White Queen absolutely excellent ! She was interesting, and a character who though evil, one could not help silently rooting for at some level. A brilliant actress indeed.

The 4 children, who were the key players in the plot, should all be sent to the Prisons of Askaban - where perhaps they might pick up some acting tips from the excellent cast of the Harry Potter films. I have seldom seen such a pathetic and uninspiring performance as from the two boys who were supposed to carry the film. The little Poppelwell girl did a half decent job, but she ain't no Dakota Fanning. Frankly I found the animated characters far better at acting real than the children in fulfilling the roles allotted to them.

All in all I would recommend this film as it is well made technically and well, because i am a fantasy movie buff. But please watch it with a nice big tub of popcorn and a large coke - you'll need them to get through the more dragging parts.

title: Worth a yawn
review: General thoughts were that it was poor. The casting was terrible, at one point Georgie Henley was supposed to be upset and crying and she looked like she was laughing. I know she's a child actor but take Dakota Fanning for example who CAN actually act! Effects at times were brilliant, but in others absolutely poor (eg. the mountains that shook when there were closeups of characters because of bad green-screening). In terms of story telling it was average, i often thought that at moments the tension could have been heightened by having better directing. It did not seem to me to have the fantasy element that it deserved, it just 'seemed like another film' and not as mythological or as grand as the book portrays. Worth a rent when it comes out on DVD, but halfway through you may decide to fast forward as it gets a little B-O-R-I-N-G. The battle scene its good, but you soon realise that the White Witches army must be pretty terrible as both Edmund and Peter half-heartedly kill a few soldiers which seem to stand there and wait for the sword to tap them dead. THIS FILM COULD HAVE BEEN DONE SO MUCH BETTER!

title: Half-assed CGI and dopey Disney style fighting
review:
The original CS lewis books listed great battles but Disney serves us up a very watered down and bloodless version of the CS Lewis epic tale. This is most watchable film interpretation to date but it doesn't follow the book properly. I was disappointed with the battle scenes and the unimaginative swordplay that always "killed" without ever drawing blood. LAME.

For little kids who are ignorant of the original books this movie is a fine outing for them. For adults who haven't read the books it will be OK. And for those of us who are literate in CS Lewis we will always hold the books far above this fart of a movie. This rendition of the tale makes simply makes the books even that much more inviting.

THE BATTLE SCENES: Some of them were duplicates of footage from the video game Age of Mythology, along with the characters(Minotaurs to name just one) and their armor styles. I think someone saved a few dollars by re-hashing some footage??

title: So many good reviews... Why?
review:
I don't know guys... I'm reading a lot of these positive reviews, and I think its neat you liked the books and were entertained but when you take a step back and just examine the film on it's own merits, it really is just mediocre. I don't mean to be an elitist either, I went into the movie wanting to like it. I was just stunned by the standard looking CGI, unimaginative lighting and visual theme, wooden acting and general feeling of "Is this thing almost over?". It also, unfortunately, had to conform to the trappings of what is considered a "family" movie. That runs the risk of causing unintentional laughs. The filmmakers had a choice: 1. A smaller, quirkier film focusing on the more magical and charming elements to the story 2. A big bloated "epic" (even though that word is reserved exclusively now for films of LOTR caliber)with an unneeded battle scene and very little in the way of character development.

Given all the positive reviews and the box office returns, they made the right choice for the consumers.

title: It was boring.
review:
I've never read the books, whenever I picked them up, I always found the synopsis on the backs too childish to read (when I was 10).

I think young children would enjoy this movie 7-10.

I certainly didn't. At several points in the movie, I got the distinct impression that the movie was made to be translated - the characters spent so little time actually speaking. I guess I've been spoiled by LoTR.

I found myself frustrated with the characters. How does someone get really good with a sword/bow/knife/etc so quickly? The battle scene was poor, terrible tactics, poor use of cavalry. The whole resurrection thing was the most hackneyed piece of religious claptrap invented.

I found myself very interested in Edmund and his growing up, but we never saw it happen. I guess that would have been too much of a change from the book.

title: Brilliant Faithful Adaptation
review: I saw the film on the day it came out as I love the books and was quite looking forward to it, and boy I was not disappointed. The cast, special effects and direction were spot one of the best films of the year. The stand out moments would have to be Tilda Swinton as the white witch giving a performance which is the epitome of evil and of course Aslan whoever thought of casting Liam Neeson as Aslan needs to be given a medal. Lastly Rupert Everett as the fox expanded from the book but still a great character. All in all a great film for all ages even though not for the really young however. Still released at precisely the right time (christmas, should be destined to become a classic in years to come and quite right too.

title: Take a trip into a truly magical world
review:
Gosh that film was fab, not sure if my eyes stopped watering all the way through and was trying so hard not to sob when Aslan died and then during the war etc, even though I remember the story and knew what was coming. What a fantastically done movie.

Was coming home and nearly took a heart attack as a wolf jumped out at the side of the road, then I realised it was actually just a husky..on a lead.. Ah well! Can't get over how amazing everything and everyone was. Lucy wasn't nearly as annoying as in the BBC version. I completely loved Mr Tumnus, and then the beavers and then Aslan. Was just amazing and all the wee details like the badgers that scurried past at one point. Crickey I could go on all night! Go see it now!!

title: Exceeded my expectations
review:
The feelings leading up to watching this movie was a mixture of skepticism and anticipation - I read The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe a million times as a kid and I reread it in my most recent years since my cousin gave me the series two Christmases ago (God bless her).

But now after watching the movie I have to say ... well, I don't really know what to say first because I can't say enough good things about it!

Superbly cast, excellently acted, wonderful cinematography and special effects... and most importantly, it followed the book to the T. This is how movie remakes of books should be like - for once, Hollywood executives didn't leave anything out and instead added their own little bits and pieces where they felt needed a boost.. yet they still maintained all the important elements of the story AND made it flow correctly. Not an easy task and very well done. I mean, it is a blockbuster movie, so I'm sure they had to spice it up a bit, but I love how the story just picked right back up at the precise moments mentioned in the book after the extra elements were added... you didn't miss anything.

For kids no older than 18 years of age, these actors can convey such great emotion in their eyes and faces that it's not even imperative to have words leave their mouths to explain what they're feeling. Another daunting task, but well executed.

And finally, the Pevensie kids are exactly how I pictured them. Peter as the tall, handsome looking and righteous boy, that really plays out his elderly brother role (how about that final scene with Edmund, huh? Amazing). Susan as the pretty, logical, matter-of-fact girl - tall like her brother, brave enough to do anything. Edmund as the black sheep, the shorter, dark haired kid, always looking scruffy and having that look of mischief in his eyes. And Lucy, with the brown bob haircut and the adorable buck teeth when she smiles.

I could go on and on about this movie. But I'll let the others handles the rest. Can't wait for the rest of the series. C.S. Lewis, you are my hero.

title: A triumph. Even better than 'Rings' and miles better than 'Goblet'
review: Who could ever have believed Disney would do it? Make a faithful, magical, complex, touching, funny and exciting screen version of Lewis's children's classic. But they have. What is so terrific about this film is that the children--all portrayed with remarkable unfaked authenticity--beautifully portray the tensions and problems of any siblings. We feel their difficulties, their rivalries, their problems--not manufactured movie-type problems but the usual conflicts apparent in any family. And the tensions between them mirror the split in the magical world in which they find themselves. I never dreamed that one of the very greatest children's books could make it to the screen in such a consummate way. Tilda Swinton is superb as the White Witch and the story, built around a great human myth that is not necessarily or exclusively Christian, is simpler and finally more satisfying on a human level than 'Rings;. Oh and Harry Potter' pales by comparison. This is a hundred times more enjoyable and more original than 'Goblet'.

title: Disney shouldn't make anymore of the Chronicles
review:
This movie was way, way, way below my expectations and was a pathetic final product for the amount of money spent on its production. It seemed like I was watching a wildlife preserve rather than a magical kingdom with all the animals randomly appearing throughout the movie in the corners of the screen. The CGI was crap. It was so unrealistic, they could have used stop-motion techniques like in the Nightmare Before Christmas and it would have been 10 times better. There was also a shortage of dialogue. I suppose the actors and actresses had a difficult time remembering their lines. Most of the scenes that involved character interaction were nothing more than people staring at each other, then crying or smiling, then hugging. The fight choreography was embarrassing. If you can fight the way Peter and Edmond did to win the fight for Narnia, then you're probably fighting in the land of pansies.

There was absolutely no character development whatsoever and there was not a decent introduction to the story. Without at least a little background or plot outline, nobody cares about what will transpire for the next two hours! Which creatures are on whose side? How did the White Witch come to power? Why are the children staying with a professor that appears to do nothing but smoke a pipe and lock himself in his room all day? It seemed like whoever edited the movie went back and re-spliced additional footage from scenes that went too long and placed it into the original version of the film to break up the action, causing the flow of the movie to suffer terribly. I read the books a long time ago as a kid and thought that they would eventually make great movies someday. But Mr. Adamson was definitely the wrong choice to helm this project.

Spielberg could have made this movie a blockbuster with one hand holding onto ET. Narnia's fantasy characters were also crap. Seriously, they must have hired 1st year makeup students from liberal arts colleges to design the creatures with spray paint, play dough, hot glue guns and heads from dead animals. And Liam Neeson as Aslan? Sorry, it just doesn't work. He doesn't have a voice with a lot of forcefulness. Get somebody like Sean Connery for crying out loud! If you haven't read the books, you'll just plod along with the movie and you probably won't care at all for Lucy, Susan, Peter or Edmond, or even Aslan when he gets sacrificed, or what happens to Narnia for that matter. The producers were obviously trying very hard to make this movie feel exactly like the Lord of the Rings trilogy. The castle designs, panoramic shots of the battlefield and camps, and the camera work are such a rip off from Peter Jackson that its nauseating. To top it all off, people in the audience were laughing at how comical the acting was, especially when Susan kills the White Witch's henchman (talk about a dwarf with an attitude problem). It was one of the worst action scenes I have ever seen that involved saving someones life in the nick of time. This was a huge waste of $15 for my wife and I. Don't see this movie unless you take something to enhance your movie going experience before entering the theater.

title: very colorful... very what-the-public-likes... very empty... very American
review:
I've been looking out for this film for some time, and was anxious to see it. Now i've seen it... and i've seldomly seen a worse book to film translation. Taking into consideration this is an incredibly good fantasy story.

The film itself looks great. Visual effects were cleaner then ever and everything was vibrant and full. Sure this is needed for this big a story. 3 CG companies worked on it, and it show's. They did their part perfectly... bravo, another step forward in CGI.

The story on the other hand - lacked almost everything that makes the book what it is. The book has a grand depth which makes these big fantasy stories work. It's not about the talking animals, but why they talk... it's not about the fact the 'god' is a lion, but it's about why he's a lion. This is what makes the book work on so many levels. The movie only worked on the shallow end. Aslan was far to weak compared to the book's character. The BBC version of narnia portrayed aslan as a being to be feared and loved at the same time - that is Aslan - incredibly powerful. In this movie he lacks the huge wisdom on one hand and the power on the other. A tame Aslan. Disney's Mufasa from the Lion King was twice as strong as this Aslan, and Aslan from the book is much more then Mufasa's character.

The audience had to laugh about the adult peter at the end of the movie - and that's about the worst thing that can happen to a story like narnia's. He resembles 'prince charming' from Shrek 2 - who was portrayed as a self-absorbed egotistic figure. Incredibly big flaw...

These are a couple of the bigger faults - but the whole movie is desaturated in the same way. If you read the book and find this film satisfying in comparison, please read the book again, because the book is meant to tell much much more then this movie does. This film ended up in the McDonalds-commercial category. Very sweet... very colorful... very smartly adapted to what-the-public-likes... very empty... no vitamins, just a short lasting good taste.

There were some good parts. The Lucy character was nicely done, and really made an imprint. The other 3 didn't... i couldn't describe their personalities if i was asked now. Which negates Lucy's quality.

I've seen about a zillion stars for this film, but i really, really don't understand. Maybe the big posters and the visuals indeed are enough. The quality of Peter Jackson's Lord of The Rings must be very much underestimated if this movie gets this high a rating. Hope Disney chooses another director, because Narnia requires someone deeper... and less American.

Walt would never approve.

title: Underwhelming
review:
After the huge success of "The Lord of the Rings", studio money seems to flow rather easy for films of the fantasy genre. Money alone however does not make a good film, and "The Chronicles of Narnia" is a sad example for this.

In this movie, really nothing is as it should be. First, at over 40 minutes the exposition is way too long and provides little in terms of establishing characters: OK, Edmund is seemingly not that nice and Lucy willingly accompanies half-naked beings she meets in the forest to their home, but that's about it.

Secondly (and this is what hurts most): Narnia doesn't live, in fact, it looks like (and probably is) an indoor studio environment. The snow looks fake, except in very few scenes at the end there is absolutely no wind, the skin color of the characters doesn't look like it's cold and there is no icy breath to been seen. Actually, after getting bathed in a river that was frozen minutes ago, instead of shaking the characters look like they've just left a hot tub. Additionally, in the first 2/3 of the movie, we don't get to see anybody but characters with talking roles, which contributes to the feeling that there isn't a Narnia outside the main storyline we follow. All in all (and given a budget of 180 million USD) regarding atmosphere, this movie is a huge disappointment.

Thirdly, the story is much too simple (having never read the novel, I don't know if it's the screenplay's or Lewis' fault): 4 children enter a new world, which they are destined to save according to some prophecy, and there is an evil witch, who is, well, evil. That's about it. And at the end you can't even tell, what these children actually did to save Narnia and why they were needed. For reason unknown, they get crowned as kings and queens of Narnia anyway.

Furthermore, the movie does everything to prevent creating tension or being taken seriously, which comes down to three big mistakes:
