I also felt the lion should have been the king of Narnia not a bunch of outside kids, and if there needed to be more than one throne occupied then make them be the lion, the faun, and the two beavers. Maybe they should make that five thrones, and include the brave fox.

Although the fox is killed I would assume he could be brought back since everybody else good that got killed or frozen could.

title: Deep Magic!
review:
While the dark recesses of many wardrobes are a mystery containing untold treasures and/or horrors, there is a particular wardrobe in a spare room that leads to the magical land of Narnia. A land where the White Witch (evil) has reigned for 100 years, but Aslan the Lion (good) is on the move. This is such a vast and beautiful world that an epic clash between good and evil is inevitable.

Set during World War II, the four Pevensie children are sent away from blitz-bombed London to the safety of Professor Kirke's country mansion. Peter and Susan are the elder children and stoically sensible and responsible. The youngest child, Lucy, is sunny and engaging. It is Edmund, desperately missing his father and smarting against the assumed authority of his older siblings, who has some hard lessons to learn about temptation and treachery.

Isolated and bored in the sprawling house, the children resort to playing hide and seek. Lucy hides in a wardrobe and stumbles into Narnia, a land frozen in the grip of winter and the evil Witch. This seemingly random event begins the fulfillment of a prophecy of biblical proportions. And the biblical themes that run through these Chronicles are undeniable.

The essence of Narnia is Deep Magic. Mythical creatures such as unicorns and griffins, mermaids and centaurs and even Santa Claus mingle with more modest birds, beavers, badgers and wolves. All these animals can talk and even the trees are listening. So who can be trusted? Definitely not the White Witch, with her guilty gifts of Turkish Delight. She is the epitome of evil, breathtakingly icy and chillingly ruthless. As for her followers, fortunately it does seem to be true that evil disfigures and deforms as they are the foulest collection of genetic mishaps we have ever seen.

On the other hand, Aslan the Lion is molten gold goodness, with a lion's courage and a true heart. His voice resonates with warmth and it can only be summer in his presence. His followers are a host of the most dazzling beings in Narnia, as well as a myriad of sharp-witted forest animals.

The Chronicles of Narnia incorporate CGI at its most seamless. Though for all the awesome scale, its beauty is in the details. Only four of the heroes are human and it is set in a vast, magical land, but this fantasy is warmly familiar. Following his first meeting with Lucy, Mr Tumnus the Faun says that she "made me feel warmer than I've felt in 100 years". This is how we felt about our first trip to Narnia and we can't wait to return.

title: Disney at its best
review: Disney has made plenty of good live action and animated movies in the past (Mulan, Beauty and the Beast, 102 Dalmations, Monsters Inc.) But none like this. This movie has its own unique style. It features great actors (Georgie Henley and William Mosely being the best)a great director and a great screenplay. After seeing Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire I realized they left a lot out of stuff. But this movie fetures almost every last detail. The make-up artists did a fantastic job bringing C.S. Lewis' creatures to life. No wonder they won an Academy Award! I also think Tilda Swinton makes the perfect White Witch. All the voice talents were great as well. The only flaw in this film is that some of the backgrounds look fake. Other than that the film is perfect. Two thumbs way up Disney!!!

title: Pleasantly surprising.
review: My initial reaction when I first heard that the director of the Shrek films would be directing/writing "The Lion, the Witch, & the Wardrobe" was, "What?! That won't work!" I am not an avid book fan that curses at the screen at every add-in or change. I find the Chronicles a bit dry & hurried, but my expectations of the transfer from book to movie rose. Until I heard the director's name. However, despite my recurring fears that in it's stead, a horrid mutant of the the original story would appear, the rumors that I began to hear shortly after the film's release were all favorable. I started to think that perhaps this adaptation of the novels would be better than BBC's whole-hearted, but cheap, attempt at the series many years ago. So, I accompanied my family to the theater, & was sucked into Narnia instantly. The scenery was amazing; the children looked exactly how my mind had imagined them when it received absolutely no prompt from the book. The acting was believable; all the missing components of the book were, amazingly, in the movie. We own the special-edition DVD & watch it over & over, highly anticipating the release of "Prince Caspian." Andrew Adamson pleasantly surprised me, bringing a quality family film to the screen, & leaving me begging for more.

title: Awesome Movie.
review: This is the best version of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" I have ever seen. The cast is great; the special effects are amazing, and the scenery is beautiful. It's no wonder that Andrew Adamson did a very good job of directing the movie since he did Shrek and Shrek 2. The other versions of this story are not as good. Peter was my favorite character. He reminded me of Harry Potter because of his courage and Ron Weasley because of his sense of humor. They probably shouldn't have made Susan a little stuck up because she wasn't like the that in the books. In the last book, they say she stops believing in Narnia. They made that to obvious. The girl who played Lucy did a great job, and the boy who played Edmund portrayed his character very well. The BBC version wasn't good because it had poor special effects and scenery. The animated movie was all right, but it wasn't really exciting.

title: Better Than Harry Potter, Worse Than LOTR
review: I feel this movie gets a bad wrap. I mean, if you read the books you would realize the pacing of the books is so fast and isn't paced evenly throughout the book. I thought Lucy did an amazing job, her scenes with Mr. Tumnus were amazing, Edwin had his moments, but the other too gave very weak performances. To be fair though, they had the least dialogue to work with and what they did have wasn't very good, they weren't well-developed characters and it shows. The two most memorable sequences were the sequences between Lucy and Mr. Tumnus and the sacrifical sequences. If the rest of the film had been treated with such care it would have been a spectacular film, perhaps rivaling the LOTR films. The much touted CGI characters also shine, the voices perfectly match the character and their animation in terms of emotion is great. Unfortunately, the film is marred by pacing issues, some uneven CGI effects, some poor dialogue, and some uneventful action sequences. On the whole, I thought this was a step in the right direction and am looking forward to future films in the series. Definitely a film your kids will enjoy.

title: Near perfect film for children, but really great for all ages!!!
review:
When I rented this movie I had already heard so much about the movie and was skeptical as I generally don't end up enjoying movies with to much hype.Also I had missed the movie in the theaters and was really excited when i got this DVD almost the next day after it released.

This movie will be one of the rare movies where you expect the world and end up getting it. Everything about the movie is great and save for a one or 2 I cannot see any flaws in it.

The acting is excellent and I'm not to sure whether the plastic expressions of Edmund were intentional or because he is a bad actor but the fit perfectly with the mood he should have been throughout the film.

The setting of the film is in fantasy and even though some scenes reek of LOTR and New Zealand the fantasy world of Narnia has been masterfully created.

A special winner is the background score of the film which was brilliant and was further enhanced with some great mixing on the home-theater enhanced sound on the DVD.

The old fashioned values that are taught in this film (sacrifice, family bonding, hope) are endearing to people of all ages and are far better than the stupid cartoons that are being dished out today(spongebob , squarepants ).

The only thing that annoyed me was the quality of the action towards the end of the film which could have been much better considering the pg-13 certificate (i can never understand why they freak out in fight scenes when whats really disturbs the children are the sexual themes in movies even with pg-13, i mean we watched cartoons where people fought and killed every time and were no homicidal maniacs).

Save for that this film is a perfect family potboiler with loads of hope, scary scenes, funny scenes , inspiring scenes etc etc etc.

A must watch for all ages and a far better film for children then say a Harry Potter.

You have to watch this film.

title: Made me feel like a child again
review:
Growing up, my favorite films tended to involve ordinary people thrust into unordinary situations. Part of the fun was the hope that someday, somehow I would become one of those people and explore places that were deemed impossible to exist. As I got older and became an adult, I accepted the harsh realities of the real world and that I would never end up like the heroes that I cheered on screen. The innocence and the warm feelings of my youth became extinct.

The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe brought those feelings back, if just for the two and a half hours of the film's running time. This is the best fantasy film released since 1984's The Neverending Story. Any relation to the real world and the logic we have all become accustomed to should be discarded upon viewing, because that's not what the film is about. The audience is in the shoes of the four main heroes of the film as they explore and discover all the wonders of this new world and its strange mysteries for themselves.

The story is often hailed as a representation of the Christian belief and is well-acclaimed by its followers. However, there is no reason for Atheists to discard this film, by any means. It is not a retelling or adaptation of the story of the life of Jesus Christ. It merely makes references and borrows ideas from the bible to help develop their own characters. And it all works. By the time the film ends, the audience will care deeply for the heroes and cheer for them all the way through the many exciting turns and situations they encounter.

Terrific film. Highly recommended.

title: Absolutely stunning
review:
I grew up reading the Narnia books since second grade. I've remembered my teachers reading to me "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe." I'll have to admit, that book was pretty darn good, and I ended up reading most from the series except for book 1. Now this movie came along for the winter, probably the nicest treat a child can get.

Narnia was simply a classical tale full of knights, magic, and animals. Hell, it was almost ALMOST like the kid's version of Lord of the Rings. (I mean, the two authors were good friends) This movie had everything coming as expected, unlike how other movies are these days. I don't understand, all the kid's flick these days include some of the most awful films ever. Now here was a classic tale that a kid would enjoy, despite his age and size.

I was actually amazed at how much I underrated this film. The actors and actresses all pounded their roles, but I have to admit, Tilda Swanton as the White Witch stole it all. She was amazing as the White Witch. Changing faces from that kind, generous queen to that cruel, arrogant witch made me realize how much of a powerful actress she was. Maybe it was all that makeup she probably had, but the White Witch clearly depicted the villain I had expected her to be. Liam Neeson's powerful voice also matched that of how I would imagine Aslan would be. The clear beauty of the landscape and the epic battle that takes place in a wide terrain made Narnia ever so beautiful and bold. The simple children's story that I held and read came vividly and alive. The special effects had it all, as well.

I have to admit, Narnia was one of the best kid's movie I have seen in years. Convincing performances, stylish landscapes, and the beautiful dialogue made this film the most classical experience I have ever felt.

title: A Fantasy Well Grounded in Reality
review:
CS Lewis' The Chronicles of Narnia may very well have been a book intended for children but it was also the result of a life through the Great Wars and the effects those wars had one the individual. Gratefully in Andrew Adamson's directorial hands that part of the story that lends the need for the fantasy is preserved.

The concept of separating children from their parents during the Blitz in London in WW II is now showing up in many novels. Lewis was one of the first to address the trauma these separations had on children. Adamson opens his film with some fine footage of the aerial German blitz and the terror of the Londoners running for bomb shelters. The family in focus is the Pevensie family - Lucy (Georgie Henley), Edmund (Skandar Keynes), Peter (William Moseley), and Susan (Anna Popplewell) - and these four children are sent off to a safe mansion owned by the Professor (Jim Broadbent). The mansion has a wardrobe that begins the fantasy, Lucy being the first to enter the kingdom of Narnia through the back of the wardrobe. Soon the four children are all together in the snowy place and encounter first a faun, then the Queen of Narnia/White Witch (Tilda Swinton) and there begins the struggle for domination and secrets that gradually resolve the mystery of Narnia, that mystery carefully paralleling Christianity through the forces of the kind Lion Aslan (Liam Neeson).

The children are wonderful, especially Georgie Henley, and while the story deals with human creatures it is strong. As the various CGI animals enter (fine though they may be as creations) the tale for this viewer weakens a bit, but that is a personal response. In general with work like that from Tilda Swinton and Jim Broadbent along with the children, the movie form of Narnia is convincing and enchanting. Quibbles aside, it is a charming film. Grady Harp

title: its a pity that a story like this was missed by a very bad movie
review: The thing that I didn't like about the movie is that its a long story which they tried to put in a short movie - This movie was supposed to be like " Lord of the ring " - Two or three movies at least . Its seems that everything is happening too fast in this movie . Like for example Peter who just ten minutes ago was playing hide and seek with his brother and sisters is now given a sword and after killing one miserable wolf he is granted the title of " Knight of narnia " - Give me a break - What did he do to deserve it ? In lord of the ring you get to know the character , they are fighting ten great wars before you come to respect them as true warriors . And then on top of that after being a knight , not a day goes by and Peter is forced to go to war to save Narnia and all the country comes for the aid of the kid who half hour ago didn't even know what Narnia is . So , for conclusion , it could have been a much better film . Give it to Peter Jackson and I bet it will look a lot different .

title: Where is the magic?
review:
First up, I know the Narnia stories. I read them first in primary school, and I read them to my children when they were young. I have also read much of Lewis' other writings, as well as Tolkien's and know about their gentle rivalry. The upshot is that Peter Jackson did a better job with Lord of the Rings than Adamson has done with the first of the Narnia chronicle, and I think it's because Lewis' writings were simpler - naive even - whereas Tolkien created an entire world, languages included.

But the lack of spark transcends Lewis' material. There is no magic. Everything seems to proceed in an almost nonchalant way. I went with my daughters, and we were all a little underwhelmed. It didn't excite us, it didn't get our pulses racing, and we shed not a tear at the scenes that were clearly intended to do so. Yes we know the stories well, but we knew the LoTR story even better, and it grabbed us.

Finally, some of the scenes may not be appropriate for the intended younger audience.

All in all, an OK adaptation, but as one daughter commented, the BBC adaptation was less technically sophisticated but ultimately better.

title: Magical Fun!
review:
Narnia can be summarized by two words: magical fun! As a kids movie, it was nearly perfect (if I were a decade or two younger ), but as a complete movie that stirs the soul, I can only give it an 8 (which is a very good score in my book!). Before I say anything, Tilda Swinton was simply BREATHTAKING (no pun intended) as the Witch in this movie! Her every move, every look, every gesture was pure art, grace, and *evil*! She literally stole the show and carried the movie, both at the same time.

Otherwise, the story was fun if you watch it from a child's point of view. The special effects were done quite well (except for maybe a couple scenes here and there where you can tell it's a blue/green screen), and the child actors weren't too bad either. The little girl was definitely my favorite out of the 4 kids. Of course, there are many comparisons to Lord of the Rings, and I find myself thinking "Gandalf!" when I saw Santa Claus, or "Galadriel" when seeing the witch... Also, for fellow RPG geeks out there, my friend and I thought that Peter must have walked around in the same place to "level up" so that he went from not knowing how to use a sword to killing minotaurs...

There were some concerns about heavy handed religious overtones in the movie, but that wasn't a problem at all. It was handled quite well and fit the story.

All in all, great movie! Allow yourself to live your childhood again and you'll be immersed in the wonderful world of Narnia.

title: Narnia is our childhood world
review: It reminds me of my childhood, when I started to believe in miracles and we were little and inoffensive and we were playing all kind of silly games. About the film: The story is very good implemented and the scenes are without useless addings. Oh..., and we must note the good animal-characters animations. At the battle scene was place for better performings. Also, this scene is without any kind of nonsense actions, like we are seeing in many movies. I won't give examples here. The sound ambiance is nice but not very good. I don't now how the casting for this movie was made, but there are some future actors playing around in this movie. ;) I expect to see them in other movies too. Per total, is worthing that 8. So people, go and see this movie!

title: Beautiful, warm, lovely movie bringing back the child in you
review:
Based on reviews I read in advance, didn't expect much from this movie at all. In fact, I was expecting to sleep through part of the movie. But boy, was I wrong! There are these kind of movies, where after the first few shots you know you are going to love the rest of it. This was precisely the case. The parting of children from their mother in London was shot just beautiful, full of rich emotion, yet steering clear of being pathetic.

This remains the case for the rest of the film. Were it set into different background, I would probably sneeze at it, calling it pathetic and emotionally overcharged. But in conjunction with the beautiful tender story of small children living out their fantasies, it just all seems to work.

Performances by the child actors are very satisfactory with some and exceptional with others. While I didn't like both of the boy's acting as much, I found the young girls brilliant. Lucy in particular, being the youngest child, is basically driving the whole atmosphere of the movie and should have been maybe given even bigger space.

Overall, the movie left a very warm and cosy feeling in me, it made me sit at the edge of the seat and feel like a small child again. Very, very recommended.

title: Faithful to the Spirit of the Book
review:
I was very pleased that Disney didn't fool around with the basic themes of the book. I had not read the Chronicles in a few years and that helped me not to keep thinking "where is this part or that part of the book." It was fresh and very real for me.

I hope that Tilda Swinton doesn't suffer the same fate the Margaret Hamilton was rumored to have dealt with. It is said that Ms. Hamilton's portrayal of the Wicked Witch of the West left such a mark upon young viewers that when they saw her in real life they would get quite frightened. Tilda brought that depth of believability to this role.

The reason I give this magnificent film an 8: I am deducting 2 points for the over-wrought final battle sequence - too long and too involved - it didn't match the pace and balance of the rest of the movie.

That said I would heartily recommend this movie to anyone about 8 years old and up.

title: Pleased!
review:
I was very pleased with the Chronicles of Narnia, The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe. Since the technology now exists to bring C.S. Lewis' creation to life on the big screen I was really pleased with the efforts made by the filmmakers to draw you in to Narnia. There aren't too many special effects like you will see in some more recent movies (sorry George Lucas!). Although the scene with the 4 children and the Beavers at the waterfall wasn't in the book, one can see where Peter is forced to make a decision and isn't ready to make it yet, which is in the book. If you see this movie in the theatre be prepared to hear Aslans roar as it was intended to be heard in the book. The only parts my 3 year old was scared slightly by were the ones with the wolves, other than that even she enjoyed it. My husband, my 13 year old son who also had read the book enjoyed it.

My son especially appreciated the scene where the Phoenix bird lays down a strip of Napalm (SP?) type effect with the aid of a lit arrow from Edmonds archers. The white witch definitely gets her share in the end in a brilliant scene of Aslan flying to the rescue in all his roaring lionly glory to save King Peter.

When I had read the books as a child I never knew that C.S. Lewis was writing an analogy of the life of Jesus in his stories but now that I know it does make sense. For Christians and non-Christians alike, I think this is a Theatre must see!

title: Good Movie. (period/full stop) Not Harry Potter. (period/full stop) No comparisons, please.
review:
I beg to differ with Ms. Catherine Jones but this is not a "better movie than Harry Potter" - it is a DIFFERENT movie than Harry Potter. (It's also different than LOTR but there are some similarities.) Obviously, as the 6th or 7th sequel to Narnia comes out the lines will be less firmly drawn but this is simply a different movie about a different book. All three (HP, Narnia, and LOTR) are adaptations of VERY popular book series and, as such, must remain as faithful as possible to the original story to retain fans of the books. But they are distinctly different movies (books) which happen to touch on overlapping themes at times.

I have read all of the HP books at least once and the same for LOTR. This is not true about Narnia. However, I have read other C.S. Lewis and, perhaps most importantly, a primordial version of Narnia (not called that but many of the ideas came from there) which Clive wrote with his brother when he was 8 or 9 years old. What IS similar about the three authors, and hence the three movies to some extent, is the ability to build a fantasy world peopled with very real characters who exhibit some very real human traits and situations (in spite of the fact of their fantastic or non-human form).

I would not/did not/could not judge this movie in comparison to HP or LOTR because I would have to find it lacking. I would recommend judging it on it's own merits. It is a good move. The series may some day become a great series. But Peter Jackson's LOTR was a feat like none other and stands on it's own. The same is true of the HP series but in a different vein - this is a collection of film adaptations made by a number of different directors yet hearkens to and keeps us connected to the series of books which is still evolving within our lifetime - there is a connectedness between the evolution of the books, the characters, and the films that has it's own appeal - not unlike the serializations of Charles Dickens or Arthur Conan Doyle. But enough of those other series - I said that I dost not compare this movie to they.

This first of the Narnia stories was a good movie. By comparison to all lesser movies (common Hollywood drek) it may even be a very, very good movie. But comparing it to HP or LOTR can only reduce it's appeal.

The CG was a little less perfect than it could have been. The child actors were outstanding and the adults did not get in the way. (I do think that I will go back and watch some of Ms. Swindon's earlier films such as "Female Perversions" ...)

I do recommend it and, especially for the holidays, it is an excellent family movie.

title: Waste of time
review: Throughout the entire movie I was left unamused and annoyed. The story was not believable (it's not supposed to be), although, I was hoping it would take me on a wild adventure, it did the complete opposite. It did nothing of the sort. I was constantly checking my watch and making cynical remarks. The movie was a blockbuster disappointment. Sadly, at certain serious points, I was left laughing. I do not recommend seeing this movie, the children in the movie gave it their best but it was a cinematic disaster. The only decent part was the last scene, the battle scene, but even then, it was hard to believe these 7 year olds doing much with a huge sword.

title: bad no matter the religious content
review: This is the first movie where I BADLY wanted to leave the showing despite the fact that I had paid money for it. I didn't because I feel that that would have upset the kids actually liking the movie. Narnia is full of Christian mythology, and that is appalling on many levels, but the reason for why it is awful is the poorly told story. The best part of the movie is truly the beginning. The reference to WWII was suspenseful and eye catching. In those scenes you could see the harsh reality of the children's daily life and pity them. The rest of the movie is boring and badly told and frankly pointless. Where does Aslan come from and why would he return because those four kids had walked into Narnia?? How did the white witch come into power and how come she could make the world cold and harsh? What is her motif? What is the point of this movie?? I left being upset that for once I hadn't believed the reviewers saying that the use of special effects was overdone, but they are right. The story would probably have been better if some thought had gone into the plot rather than the effects!

title: Are you kidding me?
review: Who is writing these reviews???? Did Disney tell it's executives to take Friday off and write Glowing reviews of this horrible movie? Where is Narnia? Has the professor been there? Why is the Queen so mad? What's her story? Why did the Lion leave at the end? What's the deal with the broken slab? These are a fraction of the unanswered questions that will leave you hanging. No backstory, no depth, this movie does not even deserve to mentioned in the same breath as LOTR, although it is obvious that the director sat through Peter Jackson 101 and thought that was enough. A "climactic" scene late in the film was probably meant to make the audience cheer with conviction...instead, everyone laughed at the horrible unconvincing acting. I want two hours of my life back!!!

title: worst movie EVER!
review:
This movie is a total disgrace and made me sick! the story seems good but, well still don't go see this movie (read the book). it will haunt you for ever, the techniques used seem to out date my year of birth by at least 20 years and are very, very, very annoying if you ever have seen any special effects in other movies ( the caveman will probably love it: "*points finger* ohh beaver moving on my wall! W00T!!!" ). if you like these special effects like in the lord of the rings or starwars well then better take a sleeping pill or keep a loaded gun ready. not to shoot oneself, but to shoot the directors. those ppl don't deserve to live a happy life anymore and should be deeply ashamed of themselves. as for the actors, if the had seen some of the wardrobe they should have resined. its better to live on the streets and beg for food and money then to play in this movie. in my honest opinion this movie qualifies for all raspberries ever given away or that will be given away in the future.

ps I wished all the ppl in this movie were Japanese. the Japanese have the decency to commit suicide after they disgraced themselves an their country and suicide seems about the only way out, this movie is just inexcusable....

PPS only explanation for ppl not rating this movie a clear 1 is that they must be either drunk, stoned or insane. no sane person can like this one unless its his or her first and only experience with a movie.

take care, I'm gonna drink some and pray to God I wont have nightmares of narnia... if Hell exists it is narnia.

title: Disappointing
review:
This movie is absolutely for kids. The scenario has many weak spots that only kids can not notice. 4 babies suddenly become super heroes. Very bad acting also... Visual effects are not so cool. All we see is animated characters in narrow scenes.

Aslan dies,2 girls stay with his body for hours. Cry for him. But they don't even know him yet! They know nothing about the universe they have entered but they go on a war. They can't even hold a sword but they kill dozens of huge beasts.

Nearly zero violence is another thing that shows this movie is for kids. We know that they are fighting,we see them fighting but we do not ever see any of them hitting another one clearly.

title: Jeeesus, awful!
review: This is by far one of the biggest waste of times I spent in a cinema. The effects were bad, the acting so so, but worst of all, I did not get the story at all. Is 'Narnia' famous in the states? Like as a fairy tale I mean? In Europe it is not known at all, so I am not sure about the perception of the movie here. Some Americans told me, it was something like Lord of the Rings, so my expectations were way too high.... It uses partially the story of Hans Christian Andersen's Snow Queen (little boy falls for the bad snow queen, little sister saves him), but then turns into a very weird mixture of all kinds of fantasy stuff... The Lion was more funny than impressive. Some of the creatures were done quite nicely, but in comparison with Lord of the rings for example, quite bad. I would be happy if somebody could update me about this movie, like what it should be in general....

title: That's not The Lord of the Rings!
review: My big mistake was to buy my ticket thinking I'd watch something like The Lord of the Rings. You can't blame me for that since that's what Disney is trying to sell us. But if you watch this movie with that in mind, you'll surely leave the theater as disappointed as I left. Actually that's a childish flick where even Santa Claus shows up. But I think Narnia sucks by its own mistakes anyway. A funny thing is that despite of that prophecy that the "two sons of Adam and two daughters of Eve" would kick the witch's ass, the four kids didn't do anything of relevant to beat her. I guess the only effect they had in the war (oh gosh, I miss LOTR so much...) at all was a placebo: the queen of Narnia got so preoccupied with their arrival that her fear made her lose. About Aslam's resurrection, he offered his blood to pay for Ed's (I'm not quite sure his name in the original version is Ed, in Brazilian version the boy was called Edmundo) betrayal, but when he comes to life again he says that if an innocent was killed in the holy table he would resurrect. But, well, IMHO, if the lion tricked the witch with this, he's not innocent at all, he betrayed her confidence.

title: A must see film!
review:
I saw the Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (TLWW) last night with my father (opening night in Britain) and I have to say I am impressed. While I am a devoted Harry Potter fan I say this: TLWW is MUCH better than the recent Harry Potter film and maybe once I have read the Chronicles, a much better series of books. Better acting for one thing.

As for the anti-Christian comments: unless you *are* a Christain or know about our faith in depth then you will not see - well, understand -any Christain symbolism.

There is only one scene which can be taken as a directly Christain reference/symbolism, otherwise the good morals portrayed are what you find in other faiths and what is (hopefully) taught in our schools: honour, love, forgiveness, self-sacrifice etc. Surely these are not bad things?

So don't let any preconceived notions prevent you from seeing the film!

title: Comparisons comparisons
review:
The problem with this movie is that it ends up like little bits of pieces of scenes gathered from various similarly-themed movies. This movie ruined the beauty of C.S. Lewis delicately written imagery by resorting to a badly written book-to-movie script and "seen that, what else is new?" special effects.

So basically, that is what really disappointed me when watching the film. It's amazing that FINALLY they bought the book to life... And yet only to watch it go down the toilet drain. Aslan (Liam Neeson) was a great asset to the film, but somehow along the middle it seemed like I was watching a Sesame Street movie.

The movie is a mess, it failed to capture the real series. What a disappointed. Watch it if you're a fan of the book but be prepared for the havoc that awaits.

1/10

title: The bloating
review:
I was really surprised at how seriously awful this movie is. The early scenes are fine enough, and Lucy's entry into Narnia is nice. But ultimately "Lion, Witch and the Wardrobe" seems to exist to transport audiences back to a time 30 years ago, when grotesque, over-produced, over-extended children's fare was the norm, because understanding children was a very low priority.

Where to begin...? If your story culminates in a protracted, climactic war, you've made a war movie; this isn't exactly a genre kids are screaming for. That, and it takes the form of a long, lifeless sermon... another format that doesn't make children stampede to theaters. Every single moment of the movie is unengaging. The script sucks and lazy, hierarchical thinking insures that every moment has been scrutinized for maximum staleness; everything is done the way someone did it before. The film-makers find a sluggish way to mount every scene, and continually find ways to bring the movie to a complete standstill with characters spouting yet another boring pronouncement. It moves at the pace of a funeral dirge, and after maybe half an hour it has all the excitement of a diagram. Specificity vanishes to make room for more setpieces. Both Liam Neeson and Tilda Swinton give performances that some committee of drones approved.

If your kid likes this, you've got yourselves a dud. Only pasty, anemic indoors-oriented Brit brats pining for a lordship could tolerate even twenty minutes of this. Sadly it's over two hours long. This movie is D.O.A..

title: Well-made and enjoyable....but.....
review: Technically speaking, this was an excellent film. Up until very recently, doing a competent live-action version of THE LION, THE WITCH AND THE WARDROBE was really impossible because the special effects were technically impossible to do and still make them look real. Now, thanks to computers and incredible software, it is possible to get the look right of the book and Disney did a great job. And, having read the books, I was impressed that they got the story right. The problem for me, though, was that although everything seemed to fit just fine, the story itself didn't fully engage me. Perhaps I'm just getting old, but after this eye-candy was over, I just felt a great sense of "is that all there is?". The biggest problem related to this were that the LORD OF THE RING movies were so great, so grand and so wonderful that this left this film in the category of "also ran". You just can't help but compare the films and when this occurs, the depth and complexity of the Peter Jackson films is apparent.

title: Horror
review:
First time i saw the preview i had the opinion of seeing something like Lord of the Rings, but now i know this thoughts were a terrible mistake. Rarely i've seen such a pushed film that disappointed me so heavy. Why ?

Because of the schematic characters and their bad play. As Lion i would kill the little girl instead of the witch.

Logical errors that can't be tolerated. (children who can fight after some training)

cheap tricks or they seems to be.

The whole story bored my wife and me, both of us wished that the film has to end as fast as possible.

Another example of a pushed film with nothing inside.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The music was good!
review: I have no idea what made this movie as big as it is today!? The director had every hand out to him. The story was there already, and these kinds of movies are a big hit right now. But how in the world could he make a movie like that, and why was it shown in cinemas? It would been perfect to show this movie at the HALLMARK CHANNEL over the Christmas, I've would have turned on the Television and not expected a well done movie, but a movie filled with computer animated effects that didn't really look real, but fun! Instead I had to dress up, go out and sit beside a stranger, staring angry at the screen trying and wanting to join the stranger playing with his popcorn! In one scene, where the little girl Lucy, (Georgie Henley) saw here friend turned into stone, she just stood there smiling, but then start's sounding like she's crying and I got confused! We also had these "Peter Jackson, over the hill, camera flying move" but we had it to many times, four times if I remember it right! They should had hired a good makeup artist instead of a bed costume designer! But the music was fantastic; you could hear that the director knew that the music was the only good thing as he tuned it up a lot! IF you haven't seen this movie, then don't! MuggZ

title: Truly a Disappointment
review:
When I went into the theater, I had very high expectations- especially after reading the books- but when I came out of the theater, I was shaking my head and regretting spending 7 bucks on this movie. By far one of the worst I've seen. It seemed the only thing interesting in the theater was my popcorn that I was eating.

I thought that the special effects were fine, but there was a matter of the storyline and actually bringing the heart of the story to the big screen. It didn't catch my interest as the books did. The actors also did an OK job, but I thought the movie was quite horrible compared to what reviews I'd read.

title: Unfortunately - Unbelievably poor
review:
First off - like many others who have rated this film - I really wanted to like it. I loved the books as a child and the trailer looked very entertaining.

Perhaps whoever edited the trailer should have done the same for the movie. It was poorly put together. An amazing potential for a film that probably will make enough money to propagate a second installment - hopefully that one won't disappoint.

If you're worried about them straying from the book too far - don't be. The director didn't take any artistic license what-so-ever. I wish he had. The pace is slow, the actions scenes don't have action and it just isn't "Fun". After all, that's what movies are supposed to be.

I've read many other comments and I feel that there are probably 2 types of reviewers - those who watch movies and those who only watch movies that they are told it's OK to watch. The latter will enjoy this film, the former knows good from bad.

If you enjoyed this film it's probably because you have nothing better to compare it to.

If you're group won't allow you to watch Harry Potter, please break away and see what you're missing. Those movies are entertaining. I suppose a good comparison would be that this installment is much like Star Wars Episode I - great potential - but not very good.

title: Missing the magic
review:
I was rather underwhelmed by my experience of seeing Narnia for a few reasons. Some of the main problems arise from miscasting of the characters:

Mr Tumnus: he somehow manages to come across looking like some guy you would meet at a fancy-dress party, or in a bar, albeit in an excessively elaborate costume.

Jadis: this character is the most important of the movie and should have been played by a stunningly beautiful actress with a much more powerful screen presence, both in terms of her compelling and admirable (yes) intellect, and her sheer size. She is described in 'The Magician's Nephew' as one of the most beautiful women in the entire world. Tilda Swinton simply has no appeal, and comes across rather meek and albino/alien-esquire. As a result, it is very difficult to conceive the magnetic attraction that Edmund was supposed to have had to the White Witch. Andrew Adamson has said that he wanted to avoid the usual cliché of the "evil stepmother and the cackling witch" that has been seen too many times over the years. He said he wanted to "create a more sophisticated type of evil". While the usual stereotype has been avoided (which is good), its replacement fails to arouse much emotion at all. She could point her wand at me any day and I wouldn't bat an eyelid.

The children: Peter's actor seems the least likable. His strong leadership from the book comes across as joyless sanctimoniousness and is off-putting. Susan seems to suffer the worst from the CGI, especially scenes involving wind which doesn't seem to move hair very much. The actress playing Lucy tries desperately to be cute and show wonderment at the unbelievable world around her. Any scenes involving extreme emotion (for example, crying) were the most disappointing. Edmund was actually pretty good.

The beavers, and Aslan: The voices, provided by celebrities, did not blend into their scenes. They were simply too loud and too clear. The beavers were the best part of the movie and their lines were met with approving murmurs from the audience around me. Liam Neeson's Irish accent, while slightly modified, seemed odd.

Regarding the rest of the movie, I just have a few remarks: The most crucial part of the plot from the book that is left out is the fact that the Turkish Delight given to Edmund is in fact enchanted! The book says "anyone who had once tasted it would want more and more of it, and would even, if they were allowed, go on eating it till they had killed themselves." There are many instances in the movie where either critical information required for the story (such as above), or descriptive narrative, is left out, and the movie loses a huge amount of texture as a result. My solution would have been to include a narrator, making sure that they did not speak in a patronizingly slow manner. Father Christmas is depicted in the movie without his usual, hackneyed red outfit. I considered this to be rather refreshing. However, what Susan says a few scenes later doesn't really fit in as a result - "just because some fellow in a red coat gives you a sword doesn't make you a hero". I noticed that while leopards are featured in the book, the rosetted felines starring in the movie appeared to have cheetah heads, with prominent black 'tear' marks that leopards do not have. The bodies were clearly those of leopards. CS Lewis wrote in a letter: "Anthropomorphic animals, when taken out of narrative into actual visibility, always turn into buffoonery or nightmare -- at least with photography." This unfortunately rang true. I found myself many times thinking how clever the WETA graphics team was, and other times thinking that more work should have been put into the project. My objection to this is that I really don't think I should have been thinking about the WETA team at all.

title: I'm getting too old for that...
review:
OK, so i've sat through the movie. And the end credits. I was definitely impressed by the work that went into the effects, the sets, the animation, etc. etc.

Other than that, i'm feeling rather empty after two hours and twenty minutes. It seems like the film doesn't really know what to do with the story. Sure, we have that battle at the end. Sure, some of the creatures (and their movements) are really impressive. Would you just look at that incredible fur animation? Woah. And we see a lot of people (and animals) fight each other, because, well, it's good vs. evil, and of course, it's a long hard fight, and good wins because it's able to hit evil where it hurts, etc. etc. but in the end, i really didn't care for any of the characters, no matter how often the camera returns to the dramatic face close-ups of kids staring into the lens with possibly important meaning. The more the SFX become believable (talking animals, fantasy creatures etc.), the less believable the whole world they're supposed to create becomes. Narnia (in the movie) is the most detached environment possible: on one hand, all the weapons look like they're going to really, *really* hurt if applied, on the other hand, they must have non-sticky coating or all these creatures are just filled with straw... at least for me, the realistic violence and its obvious non-consequential nature in the movie just don't mix. Give me the cheap background projections, the wires, the unbelievable boss-fighting move or stop-motion trick, any kind of honest fake that says "hey, we're telling you an original story, so just imagine/believe us that this isn't the cardboard the leading character's wig came in, but imagine it IS the shrine of the sword of weird-sounding-name" over that polished fake of this Disney Narnia any time...

The whole film conjures so many other memorable moments in film history that it was more like a two-and-a-half hour collection of "whoa, just like Lord of the Rings" or "my, doesn't she just look like Andersen's Snow Queen? Just not really that evil..." or, worst, "yeah, who didn't see that coming from a mile away / now who wrote that dialog?"

If it's supposed to be a kid's movie, then it's far too "pseudoreal" in its scenes of violence - and for grown-ups it's even less real, it's utterly fake. Aslan biting the evil queen's head off (off-screen, we're doing family-friendly Christmas entertainment after all...) and then turning around without even a single stain? I know cats are cleanly, but c'mon... on the other hand, maybe witches don't bleed. Don't know, don't really care, too... though she had some nice swordplay a few scenes earlier, i'll give her that. Now *that* was really cool... :)

And seeing analogies to the bible in this film, in my opinion, tells more about yourself than it does of the story. Feel free to disagree with me, but remember that in about every other fantasy novel, someone's back from the dead on a regular basis. Mighty popular these days, keeping the leading character around because he/she/it knows how to have the local magic/technology/midichlorians at hand... but, sorry to break this to you, that does not make them Jesus, or a symbol for him. Could as well be Atréju of the Neverending Story, or Gandalf the Grey/White, etc. etc.

Oh well, i'll catch the other parts on cable TV some year or other just for the awesome scenery and CGI animation, but this won't lure me into the cinema come next Christmas...

P.S.: No, i've not yet read the book, and after that film, i doubt that i will...

title: Yawn
review:
Yeah i just came out of the theater after watching this one and i had to get on here to warn people. Unless you're 10 years old or younger, avoid this movie and save your money. This movie can be best described as a made for TV movie with a bigger budget. Or perhaps it could be seen as a watered down kid's version of Lord of the Rings.

The first 3/4 of the movie was a total yawn. Character development is non existent as we are not given any insight about the personalities of the children at all, all we know is that they're children running away from the Nazis. Furthermore, what we do realize about these children are that they are quite the little runts. With exception to the the youngest child, Lucy, the rest are a bunch of malcontent, annoying, complaining, unworthy rodents. Edmond in particular is an obvious pain and i would not be misty eyed at all to see this little brat's existence come to thankful end. The older sister is annoying as well and there are several times during the movie where she was so annoying that you wished you could reach into the movie screen to ring her neck. I was not made to feel any sympathy for these two. The oldest boy, Peter was a bit easier to tolerate however still not worth a care. How could the viewer enjoy this movie if they didn't care for the main character's well beings? A very good question...

The story is seriously flawed and also share painful parallels to the triumphant Lord of the Rings movies. For example the death of their leader, who later is resurrected by questionable, and head scratching means. The big battle that seemed to be lost, suddenly saved by a last minute addition of troops. A character that does not wish to take their role as leader but afterwards taking up his sword and marching into battle... Please give me some credit... please give viewers credit... we are not morons, don't treat us like we are.

The inhabitants in Narnia also do no make much sense as they do not seem to be able to follow footprints. The White Witch (aka female Saruman) is all powerful, able to freeze anyone with a motion of her staff however fails to be able to dispose of a child who just picked up a sword 2 days ago for the first time. She forgets about all her powers and tries to swat him with swords. Which brings me to another point... how could children who were given weapons by Santa Claus and have had not previous training be able to battle in a war, be better able to lead an army into battle better then any soldier already in the army? Overall this movie was a real disappointment and falls short on many many levels.

4 out of 10

title: Santa?
review:
Overall, a very well made movie. Yes, lots of good vs evil, but I enjoyed it...a LOTR, on the lighter side...

Sure, some killings....no blood and gore though....nice battle scenes though...

OK, now...the old man..on the sleigh...giving out the bow/arrows, sword, healing potion....

His name, I don't think was ever spoken but the little girl does look at her sister and comments that he was indeed real....

That WAS supposed to be Santa, yes? I have not read the book, but was this character in it and was it Santa?

title: One war for another...
review:
You can sum up this movie as children escaping one war only to find themselves in another and then striving to do their duty in the face of evil hordes who prefer winter to warmth.

As a movie it has its flaws - not least is a little too much chasing and event-skipping plus a feeling some of it was shot in a studio - but overall it is a delight mostly because of talking beavers, Tilda Swinton, Tumnus the faun and little Lucy Pevensie.

Don't worry too much about allegations of Christian undercurrents: the symbolism is there for those who want to see it but for anyone else, it's a good old unlikely-heroes-fighting-for-good epic.

title: Exceeded my best hopes
review:
Let's face it, we all have hopes and expectations about books that we read as children and young adults. A lot of times, you might feel disappointed and let down by such, or, in the case of "Starship Troopers" you might even feel betrayed by its translation. This is not going to be one of those movies! I watched it last night and I am still in awe of the magic that they pulled off.

For it was truly magical. I felt young again as I watched the interaction between the Pevensie children, especially in their games and politics. I felt that the casting was perfect, especially for Lucy. The teasing and betrayal of Lucy by her older brother Edmund seemed very realistic. The dismissal of Lucy's "fantasy" of finding Narnia within the wardrobe was played well by her older "boring" sister Susan. But when they all find their way into Narnia together, it is a magical moment. Another such moment is when they first lay their eyes upon Aslan the lion, played by the voice of Liam Neeson.

The development of the characters was well done as well, from Peter's lack of self-confidence to his early development as a leader of the army, to Edmund's growth from a bratty, betraying boy into his role as a noble prince and hero.

The special effects were wonderful. At first you are awed by the talking animals and incredible scenery, but as time goes on you forget that they are special effects and just accept them as characters in the movie. This is one of the first special-effects-laden movies that I have seen in the last couple of years, in which the producers and director understand that lots of special effects do not take the place of a good plot or good acting.

Seeing this movie for the first time strongly pointed out to me a lot of the Christian parallels that CS Lewis wrote in, that perhaps were not as easily seen on the surface of the story as written in the book. The simple view is that Aslan, an innocent, decides to sacrifice himself to save a person who is not innocent. But Aslan's interaction with the children, particularly when Lucy and Susan (paralleling Mary and Martha) accompany him on his journey towards his death, Aslan's treatment (being beaten, humiliated, and shorn of his mane) before his death, Lucy and Susan's actions after his death, and his resurrection were more clearly spelled out in the movie than in the book. The only thing that was different was that they didn't go into much depth as to *why* he was resurrected (deeper magic, the Emperor Over The Sea, etc.) I felt that that could have been explored and explained in more depth.

I sincerely hope that they decide to make all of the "Narnia" series into movies. Quite frankly, even though TLTWaTW is the most important book in the series, it is not my favorite by far. I look forward to seeing "The Magician's Nephew", "Voyage of the Dawn Treader" and "The Last Battle"! But if they release them one movie per year, it will be 2012 before the series is complete.

It's not as though he is a *tame* lion, after all.

title: Excellent Movie
review:
It is rare that I enjoy a movie so thoroughly. CS Lewis' writings were a staple of my childhood. Any time the original BBC productions would come on PBS, I would be very much glued to the TV screen.

I am also an avid fan of Tolkien's works. I found that I was disappointed after going to see Jackson's movies. I did not feel the same way at all after seeing this movie.

The movie retained much of the emotional weight that I think the LOTR's was lacking in. All of the moral lessons that were core to the book were also present in the movie without being preachy. The fact that the movie has "a point" other than just trying to tell a story makes it better than the great majority of movies released in Hollywood these days.

The story and the acting were excellent. I look at some of the Harry Potter movies (even the most recent ones) and I can't understand why those kids can't live up to the standard of acting set in Narnia.

There are few obvious faults to be found. The compression of the books' story line did not have a detrimental impact at all. The progression was natural and smooth and there were few changes that felt abrupt.

I look forward to reading through the papers on Monday to see the box-office earnings to try and discern if the other books will be made into movies (I hope so).

title: Perfectly done!
review:
I remember first reading the Narnia books when I was 7 and I have been waiting for Decades to see a live action film adaptation. I was hoping against hope that this film would do it right and all I can say is thank God for Andrew Adamnson and his team! I know art is all subjective and what one person likes another may hate but from a personal level I have not found a film quite this engaging for a very long time.

It can't be an easy book to adapt to film; It's full of talking animals, the main characters are children and half the cast aren't human. It must have seemed so daunting to try and do it right, but thankfully they have achieved just that.

The children playing the four leads were convincing and emotive; child actors should not be so talented. I really felt like I was watching four completely unique characters rather than four children. Tilda Swinton's White Witch has gone into my list of greatest cinematic villains of all time. A perfect balance between the beautiful and the evil. So menacing and scarily sinister. Aslan felt authentic (even though he was predominantly CGI) and I was moved to tears by some of the more emotional scenes.

Visually it was breathtaking, both in terms of the way it was filmed & edited and in the production design. It was immersing, engaging and wholly magical.

I have even more respect for Adamson and co. for daring to do this after the world of the fantasy epic has been over-shadowed by LOTR. How brave of them to tackle fantasy and battle sequences and how impressive to pull them off so magnificently. Also hats off for finally making a film that uses CGI responsibly (the way it used to be done five years ago) rather than in every shot.

I felt the film was rich in character and ideas but at the same time completely faithful to the book by C.S. Lewis. Although I don't generally like to compare book to film I know many do and rest assured this is a meticulous adaptation.

Ultimately it was everything I wanted it to be and more. It was an ideal bit of escapism that made me laugh and cry. Maybe I was just in with a very responsive audience but they were laughing along with me and cheering throughout the battle as well as giving the film a lengthy applause at the end (this is in a chain cinema remember). So feel free to disagree with me but I thought it was a 10/10 five star film and if it's the same team doing the other six films then I can rest assured they shall be just as magnificent.

title: This incredible film brought the book to life in a way I couldn't have imagined!
review:
I admit I was torn before seeing this film. LWW was my favorite book as a young girl, and I was thrilled to share the book with my son, who loved it too. When I saw that a film version was in the works, I was excited but nervous...how could anyone do this book justice? I was afraid that the film would never be able to capture the essence of the book, and I thought it was impossible for the images on the big screen to compare to the book's life created in my imagination. These fears coupled with the immense amount of media attention made me leery - usually movies can't life up to this kind of hype.

I'm happy to say I was wrong to worry. The film was pure magic - every moment of it. Just the right amount of emotion and humor combined to send me back to my childhood when first I visited Narnia. To experience this with my son was truly special - his excitement eclipsed my own. As we lived these adventures right along with the Pevensies, my son would reach over and grab my hand or tap my arm and smile as though we were experiencing a secret world that no one else in the theater could possibly understand. (Here comes a little spoiler for those who don't know the story...) What struck me most about the power of this film was the scene at the Stone Table and Aslan's death. I knew it was coming, I knew what happened afterwards, but still I found tears running down my cheeks as it played out. Incredible.

In two and a half hours, this film captured the essence of Lewis' Narnia without taking very much away from the original story. The additions made by the filmmakers enhanced the story without giving that obvious "that's not what happened" feeling that usually comes with adaptations. Go see this film...it's the first in a long time I can say is worth the price of admission.

title: Shock and Awful
review:
It doesn't cease to amaze me how Walden continues to bring down great directors.

Holes, while I had never read the books, had the same stilted hollowness that they managed to infuse into the Narnia tales (and that's WITH Disney helping) and that film was directed by the same director as the Fugitive! (Around the World in 80 Days was a travesty against the original work, but it kind of worked since Jackie Chan became the main character) How does Walden do it? How do they manage to wreck such great material? Despite having Mr. Gresham on board, the writer/director/maybe even some of the actors miss the feel of the book. Maybe it's not possible to replicate that on-screen: ever. But they should have at least tried for a more serious treatment. This was way too kiddish: like it was made for the Chicken Little crowd. I was hoping for something much better, much more sobering.

As far as acting goes, Georgia Henley is the best. She was the life of the movie. But as a result, everyone else (especially Susan) came off looking a little stiff. It never seems that the characters get to change much. They start off as one might expect, but by the end it doesn't seem like they're much different except for those crown things on their heads.

The music was terrible. Pop-ballads done with a symphony sounds cheap. Where was the theme music?

The editing was terrible: unless you're just advertising to sell an extended version of the DVD. (Hey audience: if you feel unsatisfied, buy the real movie next year!)

The children should have gotten lost like they did in the book so we didn't have to waste time having Peter and Susan whining about going home the entire film (oh bother, we have to rescue Edmund first...)

Very little build up to Aslan. No build up to the war. Trying to be Lord of the Rings, but Narnia isn't Middle Earth and they should never have tried to make it that way.

The witch's wolves have American accents: why?

The worst thing was the loss of the intangible feeling of discovery and wonder of a world within a world. I don't know how hard it would be to create it (in some respects the BBC version still had this feeling), but if you're going to spend $120 million, you sure shouldn't leave it behind.

I think this comes down to bad writing and too many corporate milk-toast spines having influence. All you needed was a real screenplay (one that they apparently weren't willing to pay for since they went with the cheap just of school writer) and someone who was passionate about the story and the BE ALLOWED to tell it. With only three or four lines of dialog being from the original book, I almost doubted whether Walden had actually optioned the material from the CS Lewis Estate! Watching the film did give me hope for one thing: it may still be possible for me to remake it some day. True, I'm American and I'm overly critical, and it will be 30 years before anyone will even care to see it again: but after seeing this film: I want to try. I think that's what having British people write/direct this British work does. They can't feel the book, because the book is nearly everyday English life and they can't see how that's interesting. (Remember the book didn't do that well in England, the US is where Lewis got his child readers) But there's a whole feeling that as an American I get from the book that is essentially idealised English family life, something that many Brits can't stand anymore. There's nothing for them to do than try to update and "modernize" it away: but when, as an American, that's a large part of what I enjoyed.

Solution: have an American write and direct the movie, and don't let a single American have a voice on screen!

title: 4 children venture into a wardrobe
review: I thought that this movie was fantastic, the characters were well played especially, Lucy, she was the best.The other children were swell too the captured their characters and the emotions which run through the whole movie. The effects are dazzling as you see each and everyone of C.S. lewis's creature come to life. Thsi movie, which i thought wouldn't be all that great because it was made by Disney, but yet it was awesome. I give this movie two thumbs up, and i urge everyone to see it. I urge everyone to see this movie so they will be exposed to the great mind of Cs, lewis and so that they can venture with these four children into the land of Narnia. go see the Chronicles of Narnia I assure you you will enjoy it.

title: Enormously entertaining...
review:
The long-awaited film version of C.S. Lewis's 'The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe' has arrived, and I'm largely impressed. The material has become more nuanced and compelling in it's transition from book to film, the action is very good, and Narnia is perfectly realized. The film, while enormously entertaining, is not perfect.

One of the main problems with the film is the spotty direction of the child actors. Georgie Henley is magnificent as Lucy, and Skandar Keynes brings some depth to Edmund (watch his face harden when he tells the others, "I've seen what the Witch can do."). Peter (William Moseley) and Susan (Anna Popplewell), alas, do not fare as well; they are stiff, awkward, and wooden compared to their siblings. Fortunately, this is only a minor problem.

What I'm really impressed by are the inhabitants of Narnia. Aslan (voiced terrifically by Liam Neeson) looks great, as do the Beavers, the Fox (Rupert Everett), and the assorted animals and fantasy creature. But especially the Beavers. They add greatly to the enjoyment of the film, and Ray Winstone and Dawn French are clearly having fun as the voices. Tilda Swinton is awesome as the White Witch, and she relishes getting a chance to play a figure of pure evil.

Director Andrew Adamson (both the 'Shrek' films) handles all this material nicely, even if the kids get a little annoying once in a while. 'Narnia' is no 'Lord of the Rings' or 'Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'; it's clearly intended for family audiences. This doesn't hurt the film, though, and it's a highly enjoyable fantasy adventure.

title: Lewis would have been pleased...
review: I have read a lot of C.S. Lewis' work (most recently, sadly enough, his Chronicles of Narnia) and I am going to go out on a limb to say that Lewis would have been pleased with this representation. I think this film was able to capture the brilliance of Lewis' masterpiece better than the Lord of the Rings Trilogy was able to capture the brilliance of Tolkien's masterpiece. They are both highly deserving of great films made from them. I was highly impressed with LOTR when I saw them...but now that I have seen The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe, I only wished that Peter Jackson could have done a little bit better...even if each movie had to be 4 or 5 hours long instead of 3. All of the elements of the story were there (and I mean just about EVERY element), the acting was wonderful, the cinematography was excellent, the special effects were superb and the music topped it all off. Up until this film, Walk The Line had my vote for the best film of 2005, but there is no way I can deny Narnia of that title now.

title: The Best Film in Disney History
review: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe has been highly reviewed by top critics and especially by Christians alike. Walt Disney and Walden Media has depicted how a Christian should and should not live through the entire movie. The Wardrobe represents the door to each of our lives, The Lion (Aslan) represents Christ reigning in our lives, and The Witch represents everything the world (Satan) wants us to be, and Narnia represents the Kingdom that we will live in with Christ. These comments are not for the faint-hearted. These comments are for those who wish to read them and accept them. If Walt and Roy Disney were alive today, they would praise these comments and praise this movie as being the best and most inspiring movie of all time. Siskel and Ebert may give it two thumbs up, but Christians around the world that watched this movie today, give it roaring applause because it is within our own hearts that our Lord does reign within us. We may live in perilous times now but wait until we actually see the Narnia that we will go to. It is beyond comparison and beautiful. Andrew Adamson depicts in the movie of what that is at the end of the movie. It is beyond words and it is beyond comprehension. The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe will go down in Disney and Bible History as one of the GREATEST STORIES EVER TOLD.

title: Everything I hoped and waited for since I first read the series.
review:
I first read the Chronicles of Narnia when I was around 11. Since that time (many, many years ago), I have hoped for a big-budget version of this wonderful story. I am sure this great achievement couldn't have happened much sooner as the quality of the special effects needed to do the story justice simply didn't exist until recently.

The movie was well worth the wait. I was captivated from minute one and was so excited to see some of the scenes that I actually found tears in my eyes. Reliving the story, watching the characters, meeting the creatures, it was all like coming home.

The casting was great and was done by someone who obviously had read the books and knew the characters as well as serious fans know them. Tilda Swinton was fabulous as the White Witch and made the transition from the nice "queen" who "snowed" Edmund to the terrifying war waging witch perfectly. The children played their roles flawlessly, going from scared war "orphans" to mature royals saving their kingdom. I was amazed to see them at their coronation, seeming so grown up and seeming so wise.

The special effects were just amazing. The variety of creatures in the book were shown in such a real manner. I particularly enjoyed the method used to portray the tree spirits. None of the mythical beings were unbelievable and Aslan was simply magnificent, although I pictured him a bit larger. I did not pick up on Aslan's voice being Liam Neeson's, I merely knew the voice was familiar and his was a perfect voice for Aslan.

The battle scenes and some of the "dark" creatures may be too intense for younger children but this is a children's movie based on a children's story. However, most adults should find it enjoyable. It may be helpful for adults to be familiar with the series to really appreciate the movie. I recommend this movie for everyone with an open mind to fantasy and the age-old, good winning out over evil tale.

P.S. Do not leave the theater when the credits start rolling.

title: Highly flawed.
review:
The good parts:

The character of Lucy was likable, and well acted(mostly). Dawn french is always a pleasure to hear.

The bad parts: The rest of the kids were a bit rubbish, truth be told. Most of the acting in this film was sub-par. I even thought Liam Neeson's voice acting was a tad forced.

Maybe it wasn't bad acting, maybe the actors were just given the worst dialogue in the history of the world. Yeah, that was probably it.

OK, it wasn't the worst dialogue in the world, but it was the worst dialogue of any film that i've ever seen. Whoever wrote the screenplay for this should rethink their career. it sounded like something an illiterate teenager would rite(sic).

The cinematography was appalling... all the time. It even tried (unsuccessfully) to copy Lord of The Rings in places. Especially a bit when the kids and the two beavers are hiding under a big rock. The way this was filmed mimics the scene in The Fellowship of the Ring where the hobbits are hiding under the big tree root from the ringwraith. It is almost shameful to watch. thankfully, poor acting and a total lack of intelligent cinematography makes the scene devoid of tension.

Visually, the entire film (the bit in narnia, anyway) reeks of LOTR. But this is probably due to the similar themes that the two books shared. Yet, even when taking their inspiration from such great works, the people responsible for the style of the film miserably failed. It sometimes felt like this film had an extremely low budget.

The sets were poor. Watching LOTR, i barely ever thought to myself "that scenery doesn't look real", but in pretty much every shot of this film(again, while the kids were in narnia), i noticed how blatant it was that they were on a film set.

The cgi is mostly pants. Aslan was pretty damn impressive, but the beavers, the fox, the wolves... all the other creatures were unbelievable(in a bad way).

Speaking of the wolves, as the main antagonists for part of the film, they weren't scary at all. Even the ice queen wasn't scary. Mostly due to her inane dialogue.

The "funny" moments were about as funny as the rest of the moments in the film(meaning they weren't funny).

Children will no doubt enjoy the film regardless of (and oblivious to) the above observations. And that's fine. But if you are looking for something that will captivate and immerse the viewer like the LOTR trilogy did, keep looking. I've heard that new harry potter movie is quite good.

title: Enough to Pull In Old and New Fans Alike, of All Age Groups
review:
'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' is a truly outstanding fantasy adventure. Based on the beloved children's book written by C.S. Lewis in 1950, it has enough to pull in old and new fans alike, of all age groups. While the film has been kept to a PG rating in the U.S. to remain children friendly, it is by no means meant to be purely for children. The book has seen three other adaptations: a television series, an animated film and a live-action made-for-television movie; this is the first adaptation to be released in theaters.

For anyone who may not know the story of 'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,' here is a brief overview: Peter, Susan, Edmure and Lucy Pevensie are sent away from London during World War II, and come to live at the house of Professor Digory. Lucy, the youngest, finds a mystical wardrobe which leads her to another world, which the others don't believe her about at first. But soon all four come to the land called Narnia, and find that it is being ruled by an evil White Witch, Jadis, who has declared it shall be forever winter but never Christmas. To defeat her, they must join forces with Aslan the lion, true King of Narnia, and lead an army in a great battle between good and evil.

Andrew Adamson, who co-directed the first two 'Shrek' films, steps up for his first feature-length film and does not disappoint. The start of the movie is dark and moody, much like the attitudes the four children have. It isn't until Lucy's first visit into Narnia that coloring truly starts to lighten, helping Narnia to truly seem like another world. Adamson creates scenes that are beautiful and sweeping, and scenes that are disturbing and dark. And while he used enough action to make the film slightly more appealing to audiences, he never strays too far from the heart of the novel.

The acting is also superb in this film. Tilda Swinton as Jadis the White Witch is a wonderful villain. She has proved before that she is a great actress, but she is truly at the top of her game here. She becomes the role, and makes Jadis so evil that you can not help but hate her. The four children, three of whom have never made feature-length films before this, are all outstanding in their roles as well. They make the characters believable, and display their faults just as well as their virtues. And the voice acting, especially Liam Neeson as Aslan, is very well done, making you believe these animals can truly speak.

The visual effects are very nicely done for the film. While some animals, such as the Beavers, are obviously done with computer animation, they still come off believable within their landscape. The work done for Aslan is especially astounding, having combined shots of a live lion with computer animation to create a truly magnificent talking lion. Richard Taylor's work, featured in 'The Lord of the Rings' as well, is obvious throughout the film with beasts hideous and beautiful, and magnificent armor and weapons. The score for the film is wonderfully composed and utilized especially well in the battle sequences.

There is one point I should address. The film is not obvious Christian propaganda, as some would paint it to be. Yes, it's true that the story has ties to Christian beliefs. But those story points are never pointed out as being Christian in origin. The religious context is no more than other epic fantasies like 'Star Wars' and 'The Lord of the Rings' contain, it just has slightly more bearing on the main focus of the story. Yes, you're bound to see Christian themes in the film, but they are themes that run in many stories, some predating the Christian belief system. Please do not let talk of religious themes affect whether you would see this film.

'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' is one of the first films to have an obvious influence from Peter Jackson's 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy. While the idea of making an updated film version of the book has been floating around for several years, it was the popularity of Jackson's films that prompted this movie to be made. After Tolkien's books-turned-movies hit theaters, Walden Media opted to adapt all seven of C.S. Lewis' 'Narnia Chronicles' in feature-length film version. While 'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' is the only book optioned so far, it seems likely that Disney will at least make a trilogy of movies, if not adapting all seven books.

I look forward to see what else they do with the series. This film, while perhaps not quite reaching the epic status of 'The Lord of the Rings,' is a great movie to see. Beautifully done, with great action, adventure and drama, it truly is a fantasy film for all ages. While it may not be the best fantasy adventure to date, I can't imagine it possibly being better adapted than it is. For that, I gladly give the film 9 stars, and recommend it as a must-see this holiday season.

title: A Superb Film!
review: I just put this film together for the Friday opening and what a treat it was to watch. Almost right away, you will be whisked into this incredible fantasy world with some of the best scenery and graphics sense "Lord of the Rings". The soundtrack accompanies the film well adding a great depth to this magical land. The acting and voice talents of many characters were also done exceptionally well in my opinion. With all those elements added together you get a wonderful film you will be engrossed in from start to finish. However, It maybe a little too much for really young kids to follow. The screenplay seemed to follow C.S. Lewis's masterpiece nicely. A very moral and uplifting story about good triumphing over evil with a biblical twist.
