So if you're between 8 and 108 check it out; I don't think you will be disappointed!

title: absolutely terrible
review:
this movie is supposed to be for children, yet it still is highly religiously biased! It uses verses from the bible as regular film dialog.

Take it from a 12 year old, i saw the movie with a friend and i had to keep getting up and going to the bathroom because i was so bored. i wanted to sleep in the theater, but it was so boring i couldn't.

I am Jewish and I am not discriminatory against other religions but this movie really offended me!!! the movie was terrible and if there was anything lower than a 1 i would definitely choose it but there isn't so i give it a 1.

title: Waste of money.
review:
$180m ???? god, what a waste, what the hell were they spending it on? Turkish delights for Edmund? Well, from watching the film, all i can say about the production values, is that you're definitely not getting $180m worth.

Sure, the visual effects are great, especially the wardrobe.

Aslan just cracked me up when he first spoke, the horses and all the other animals too. They just look ridiculous talking.

As for the direction, it was terrible. The film did not have any suspenseful moments nor any funny moments.

1/10 KING KONG IS WAY BETTER!

title: Burn it
review:
First lets get one thing across. 'Epic' movies are not created by great effects alone. It takes a great story and flow to create a good movie. This had neither, considering what it had to work with.

Now, I've seen the BBC version of this movie, and if you can stomach the effects of the time (and budget) you'll understand why it's a way better movie. They took the time to go through and develop the story properly, the 2005 edition is nothing more than a jazzed up movie trailer; you get the point, but for the most part its not a full story.

The movie jumps around from action scene to action scene, the way i'd expect bad boys II to do, but no flow to it whatsoever. I mean, how can you take a teenage boy who can barely wield a sword and accidentally kills a wolf to being commander of an army of 5,000 or so going up against an army of 50,000 and still not die? It wasn't believable in the slightest and I say BURN IT!

title: very good realisation of a splendid book
review:
17 years after the first attempt to translate The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe into a live action film comes this big screen treat from Andrew Adamson, previously best known for Shrek.

CS Lewis' book deals with four children, evacuated during WWII to the home of Professor Kirke (Jim Broadbent), who find a magical world inside a wardrobe in a stately home. This new world is populated by mythical creatures (fauns, centaurs, satyrs, and dwarfs) and talking animals, and is ruled by Aslan, a Christ-like figure in the person of a talking lion.

Narnia is in the grip of the White Witch, the self-styled Queen Jadis (played by Tilda Swinton). Curiously if all 7 books are to be filmed the story of how Jadis came to be in Narnia has been missed out (this is told in book 1, The Magician's Nephew, although The Lion... was written first). It is always winter and never Christmas, and there is a mysterious prophecy that states that the White Witch will lose her power when two boys and two girls sit on the thrones of Cair Pavarel.

Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy are the quartet who find themselves placed to fulfil this prophecy. As such they have to carry the film, and are not bad in doing so. Little Georgie Henley as Lucy and William Moseley as Peter are very good indeed; Anna Popplewell as Susan and Skander Keynes as Edmund less so - but watching four children could easily tire the patience of an adult viewer and they were pleasing enough to watch.

CGI is employed to produce the battle sequences and the talking animals. Aslan, voiced by Liam Neeson, is an impressive creation, but others - the beavers and the fox - are obviously fake. None of the other animals or creatures (save the centaurs) are sufficiently magical in the way characters in the Lord of the Rings series were; although the film more or less keeps to the story Lewis wrote, and James McAvoy puts in an appearance as an impressive Mr Tumnus.

The screenplay does contain some howlers ('Gee up horsey' 'My name is Philip') but is basically very good. The soundtrack is largely modern, save an Andrews Sisters number early on (just to remind us we are in wartime no doubt). Thankfully someone resisted the temptation to follow the lead of the stage show which turned the book into a musical! What Adamson does well is to show us how the children develop to their new lives in a strange land. They meet the demands of battle and learn to cope with new friends and new dangers - the police are vicious wolves, Father Christmas stops to give them weapons of war, the Wicked Witch turns her enemies into statues; and there is the ritual sacrifice on the Table of Stone.

A promising start then. I look forward to seeing other instalments in the series and hope this film is a success.

title: Horrible Storyline and Film
review:
Unlike many of the people who have reviewed this movie, I have not read the book. In fact I was unaware of the book. So I'm speaking from an average movie goer perspective. I thought this movie was horrible and long. The storyline was basically a rip-off of several scenes depicted in the bible. How people say that it isn't a Christian allegory is beyond me. Very simple. Edmund is the Judas of the family. The White Witch Jantis the Devil. Aslan was supposed to be Jesus Christ.

According to the bible, as I know it, when Jesus is crucified, he was first humiliated (i.e. crown of thorns), then stabbed by a spear. Afterwhich the ground broke in two and a momentous storm took place. (i.e. God showing his displeasure). This is paralleled in the movie when Aslan sacrifices himself to Jantis to save the life of Edmund. Before she sacrifices him on an alter, she humiliates him by cutting his mane. (i.e. The lions crown, showing his right as king). Then she and her demons laugh as they throw the mane around for the fun of it. She then kills him w/her dagger.

This scene is then followed by the two girls crying over Aslan (i.e. Mary and Miriam I believe, crying over Jesus). He resurrects himself in front of them first. (same as bible) then proceeds to resurrect the dead that Jantis kills. He then has the final kill on her.

I could go on and on but this story doesn't impress me....its a ripoff of the bible over and over again.

Besides that the movie is slow and boring. I had to catch my self from nodding off numerous times. The cinematography is horrible. Like the scene where the kids are riding on the horse or something (cant remember) and you can tell they shot the scene in front of some kind of background. The lighting on the kids hair didn't match the scene they were in.

I also found it amusing that the faun is a "friend" in this movie. Kind of a twisted joke for normally the faun represents the Devil.

Most of the movie is very dark. And is a clear ripoff of LOTR. The Orks are everywhere under Jantis crew. The battle scenes boring and monotonous.

The storyline didn't make sense. It just seemed to jump around a lot to me. Not to mention this is not a kids movie. I took an 8 year old with me and I'm just hoping she doesn't have nightmares after this one.

You've demonic characters flying around and ritualistic sacrifices taking place. How this was not at least PG13 is beyond me.

Don't waste your money!

title: Shockingly Bad
review:
This is the worse movie I've seen in a while. I was hyped up to see it and really looking forward to it but it was just so bad i had to walk out and this is the first movie I've ever walked out on. Things that were wrong with this movie :- *Shockingly bad child actors that are precocious beyond humour *Ridiculous over-emphasis on the boring elements of the plot - everyone knows that they walk through a wardrobe, why did it take 60 minutes for them to do so? *Completely transparent special effects - you can quite blatantly see that the first horse-man was just a man with brown trousers on. *Enormous portions of the movie where there was no music and the kids were just talking crap.

Where's Peter Jackson when you need him? :( I cant put into words how bad this movie is compared to what it could have been.

Hats off to Tilda Swinton (White Witch) - she was up to scratch and had a go at saving this farce but it just wasn't enough. Unfortunately Liam Neeson (Aslam) just sounded like a wise nanny.

Expect to be bored stiff & expect young children to cry with boredom.

title: Where to start?
review:
This movie is probably better suited for someone who did not see the original TV series or read the books, or someone who is simply far younger than myself.

Right from the start, the young actors playing the leading roles (maybe with the exception of the youngest one), seem stringent in their performances and are unable to deliver the dialog in anything close to a believable manner. It all really feels like you're watching an elementary school play that happens to be better than the average school play, but it just doesn't cut for a film. In the case of "Peter" and "Susan", I believe it's a downright case of bad casting. There are plenty of kids out there that can act better, and certainly fit these roles better in terms of looks and demeanor. The fact that the whole movie theater broke into laughter when "older Peter" showed up at the end of the film looking like Ted McGinley in the 80s, may give you an idea of casting problems.

Then there is the director. Where to start? First of all; he doesn't take his time. He just doesn't let the story develop in a natural pace throughout the piece. He lets it breathe for a good half-hour to forty five minutes, and from there it's a race to the end. The characters develop skills and attitudes at such an incredible pace that the story implodes on itself. You're left with questions and confusion. You never see "Peter" grow to the task of becoming a king. It is mentioned to him at one point, and suddenly he is a king and a warrior!? And by this point you are bombarded with over-sentimental moments when you in fact have not been able to develop any kind of feel for the characters. The director, whoever he is, has a couple of things to learn about story-telling.

And of course there are the endless effects and CGI created characters. And I have to say I'm impressed by some of the characters. I only wish there was a little more time spent of attention to detail. There's a ridiculous amount of shots of the characters talking in front of a green-screen (with some grand landscape inserted), and it just doesn't look convincing at all. Why haven't directors figured this out yet. DON'T shoot close-ups on a green-screen with a landscape backing. And while I'm at it, what is with these constant close-ups and generally awkward shooting. Use your close-ups sparsely! And where is the darkness? Where is the fright and contrast between good and evil? Where is the excitement? And where is the enchantment that the book and the TV series leaves you with? God help us if Shrek-man is to direct the follow-up....

I could go on for hours, but let me summarize: For the greater second half of this movie I had one thought in my head: Why didn't Peter Jackson direct this? He would have made it what it should have been. It's a fantastic story that I have a great deal of affection for and Jackson should have been the one to tell it.

title: Another lackluster Christian fairytale.
review:
I had the misfortune of being able to see this film yesterday and not knowing anything about this film going in, I walked out wondering if I had just came from a church play of some sort. Wow, and after I researched a bit online it became clear that my instincts were accurate in that 'churchy' feeling that I had felt coming from the screening. This is definitely the religious worlds attempted counter of 'Harry Potter'. I heard they are wanting to make 7 of these Sunday morning church plays. I can only hope that is untrue. Please, by all means may this have ill fortune at the box office so we won't have to endure a 7 year brain washing escapade.

The special effects were decent in this film, however the character design is severely lacking any creativity. I mean.....never-mind I won't go on, but let me say it almost embarrassed me. The direction and editing of this film were also average, nothing to praise. They did their job as the director of a soap opera or or lifetime show does, by the book. The children's acting....well, it is children's acting so no valid complaints there.

If you want to numb your child's brain for a couple hours then by all means take them to this. I am sure they will enjoy seeing the MGM lion prance around, or a Buffalo looking Minotaur stumble about in front of children acting in front of a blue-screen. However, if you want to enhance your child's mind with any sort of creativity, then take some time out with them and read a book.

title: Sadly Disappointed
review:
I went into this film as an avid fan of the book and having read some very promising reviews, I had high expectations. Unfortunately, these expectations were dashed by the film which pushed the biblical allegory a little hard in your face and fell short of providing visuals equal to the Lord of The Rings trilogy, to which so many comparisons could be made.

Character-wise Tilda Swinton was absolutely fantastic as the white witch. She came across so intensely and so mysteriously that you couldn't help but get drawn to her, and her eyes were so deep and hypnotic! For me, she swept the floor with the Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson) who throughout never really convinced me that his was necessarily the right side to fight for...

The children in the 4 main roles all performed better than I had expected them too: The pick of the bunch was undoubtedly Georgie Henley, who's eyes captured Narnia's magic and it's fascination for children. I was a little disappointed with William Moseley as Peter, who didn't have as much physicality about him as i had imagined him to have, and at times seemed a little weak.

For me the films main failing was that for it's budget some things seemed to be rather strapped for cash. Costumes for example, there were several occasions where i cringed at the awfulness of what the children were wearing. And another example was that sitting side by side with some fantastic special effects, were some shoddy bits of costume and make up: This was most obvious amidst the white witch's army towards the end, who seemed to be more a bunch of misshapen plastic headed humans than mythical beasts.

And despite of some subtle and classy moments of humour, that pleasantly surprised me, although i should have known better seeing as Adamson was the director of Shrek (!) Adamson failed to deliver the scenic grandeur of Narnia that was so impressive in Peter Jackson's vision of Middle Earth and which set the benchmark of what to expect from a fantasy epic.

Undoubtedly I'm sure most people will love it, it's faithful to the book, the characters are in the most part believable and amiable, and children will love the sheer magic and imagination, and the talking animals; but for me it lacked some of the style and panache of Lord of The Rings, and it lacked the atmosphere I had imagined Narnia to have...

title: Awful
review:
This is one of the worst films I have ever seen. The previous TV edition is much better, much closer to the book, and much more believable.

Why is it so bad? Here's a few reasons: The CGI is terrible. The worst I've seen in years. I wouldn't have been surprised if I saw some polygons! The lighting normally seemed to be wrong for the CGI creatures, and the expressions were not done well.

The Queen was lame. She had no presence about her, was ugly and had dreads. Her face looked like it was made from plastic. A poor performance.

The children did not act well. They didn't fit the characters they were playing.

The story felt as if it was constantly being cut short. I didn't contain some of the important scenes from the book. It just failed.

The film is not worth seeing. Watch the TV edition instead.

title: Absolutely AWFUL
review:
DIRE!!!

Embarrassingly bad special effects, terrible acting (surprisingly awful (hammy) acting from Tilda Swinton.. didn't expect that). Absolutely NO pace whatsoever and no magic. There was no character development - the children didn't seem to connect with each other, and had clearly not had much acting ability.

The CGI creatures were mix and match - i didn't get the impression all these animals came from the same world. They were hotch potch and the armour looked like it had been made out of plastic. The special effects make-up was appalling and there were some shockingly obvious blue screen moments.

I'd like to add that I am a HUGE movie fan and will watch almost anything - but this didn't even mildly entertain me. Although there was an amusing joke with a horse called Philip.

This wasn't even a good bad film. They could have done so much better. DO NOT waste your money on this!!

title: Better to say: Snoozefest of Narnia
review:
this was the most boring film i have ever seen, the first hour is was all excited for what "was to come" but nothing came!!! a lame story, special effects that reminded me of king kong, but the one from 19 34 oder so... the thing on that "stone bridge" from further away it looked cool, but the close scenes.. PAH.. I can do better with my cam on my cell phone... total crap... that's what this movie is *spoiler* i think i still have to say, that SOME scenes were great like the big battle at the end.. i was very overwhelmed... but if i had a choice 8 which i do) i'd rather see harry potter and the goblet of fire for the third time...

and what i don't get is, that the horseguy at the beginning doesn't know the earth.. but the narnia people know Turkish delight... and that santa clause is in that movie... HE DOES KNOW THE EARTH?!?! .. i don't even get the fact, that santa's in that stupid boring dull movie

title: Disappointing
review:
I suppose that loving the books at 7 years of age does not mean you are going to like the film as an adult.

There are a lot of aspects of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe that I found very disappointing, not the least being Aslan. From his first appearance the computer generated aspects seem obvious - something odd about the way he moves. Also, they did not manage to solve the problem of how to make him speak and his mouth was quite distorted. I did not like the voice either, myself, though others may love it. Was the film made on the cheap, or was it simply made 20 years too soon?

A number of "enhancements" hindered rather than helped the story. When the children emerge from the Wardrobe, the expressions on their faces and the photography suggest that they have come out into some kind of wintry wonderland, which is overdoing it a bit, as the winter is supposed to be associated with evil. It is not obvious who the old man in the sledge is, as, unlike in the book, he is not wearing a red coat. The crowning at the end owed more to Star Wars than C.S. Lewis. And why did they decide to have Susan moaning about going home all the way through?

Putting in the air raid at the beginning gave some useful background, although the several reminders of the war back home were another innovation, presumably intended to draw a parallel in terms of the fight against evil. Maybe it was also intended to draw a parallel with the fight for oil in Iraq (the airplanes attacking the good guys, the ugly faces of the enemy, who deserve no quarter ...). Hmm, don't go there.

Dawn French gave an excellent voice to Mrs Badger.

I am reviewing this as an adult. I would recommend the film for children under 10 (though I am suddenly a bit worried about its propaganda intentions) but certainly not for grownups.

title: What a crap
review: Who wants this film to satisfy? For parents the story is far too naive, but even children won't take the lies and false editing. Every single drop of blood was cut out, even in the huge battles. I mean, o.k. its a movie for children, and I admit that Potter 4 was far too cruel for children under 12, but come on, every child did already hurt itself once and do know that people bleed. What do they want to make the kids believe, that even if you get a sword rammed inside your body, you just hold it, as if you have bellyache. And, warning spoiler, the Santa Claus gives the children weapons on Christmas for war!!! Great! But the best was still the image of the unicorn used as a horse for battle. This movie was from beginning filled with such idiotic images, which I hope even kids will see through. I still give three points for the amazing landscapes in winter and some exciting and funny moments with the speaking animals. Some are very well animated. But for the rest, it's hard to bear.

title: Music really killed it - if had known, I would have paid not to watch it
review:
Apart from many things I could mention (bad acting, no action, no development of the characters), it's the music that really killed it. It's simply too modern and midi-like. In the first scene everything goes smoothly, but right from the moment Lucy goes into the world of Narnia... everything fails. The characters, the story, even the world itself are unbelievable and completely artificial. And it's no even about the CGI (which is quite OK). It's about the believability of the story.

What struck me the most was the artificiality of behaviour of the kids - Lucy tapping the faun like she was what? 30? 40? Completely unbelievable for me, sorry.

So don't waste your money on this one - go check on BBC's series instead: maybe the FX is silly in comparison, but at least there's what I call MAGIC.

title: Misanthropic take
review: I saw this movie and let me just say, I am stunned. Stunned that ANYONE, let alone so many people, could possibly ever give this movie a good review. Lacking in any form of subtlety, grace, or anything resembling acting, I literally found myself watching the film through my fingers at times in sheer disgust and disbelief. The theater broke out in laughter often, although not at any point where the film attempted to be funny. I am truly amazed that this low-rent, thinly-veiled bible regurgitation made it into theaters. I can't believe I didn't walk out. Every single actor was awful, and as for the special effects being good in any way--that is the most ridiculous thing i've ever heard. The blue screens were so bad at times as to provoke aforementioned theater laughter. A complete piece of garbage that should only have been shown late night on the Disney channel. My hate of this film occupied my conversations for days.

title: How to convert kids to Christianity
review: Obvious attempt by Disney to cash in on the sudden popularity of the fantasy genre in the wake of the fantastic Lord of the Rings movie trilogy. The trick seemed simple: take a book from a well known fantasy series and adapt it into a sweeping epic of a film, and build an easily exploitable franchise around it. Granted, this first Narnia film did pretty well at the box office, but remains maligned by critics the world over and is an altogether feeble movie based on the classic book by C.S. Lewis. During WW II, the four Pevensie children are sent to live at a big mansion on the English countryside, where they discover a wardrobe that turns out to be a doorway to the fantasy world of Narnia. However, this realm is in the grip of a severe ice age because the evil White Witch (Tilda Swinton doing a good job at playing a ruthless villain) rules the land. The coming of four human children means the dawn of a return to peace and prosperity under the benign rule of the lion god Aslan (voice by Liam Neeson), but the White Witch doesn't surrender her regime so easily and a grand battle for the freedom of Narnia erupts, with the Pevensies at the heart of it (fortunately Father Christmas equips them with the necessary deadly tools to kill their opponents: good job, giving weapons to kids!). Laced with extremely obnoxious Christian overtones (including the annoying parallels between a certain carpenter/magician and Aslan, who dies for the sins of another but is resurrected), this movie at many turns feels like it means to convert us to Christianity, while it's also a poorly acted - especially those pesky kids and a vast array of irritating digital talking animals - and humorless piece of work that takes its fantasy concepts a little too serious, which seems an odd move for director Adamson, who previously delivered two superb Shrek films. The audience, apart from Christian fanatics who obviously loved it, quickly grew tired of it as they demonstrated by making the sequel Prince Caspian do quite poorly at the box office, after which Disney swiftly abandoned the franchise, selling the rights to Fox, where its right wing religious overtones were more at home. Still, general interest in the franchise remains low.

title: This was really pretty bad
review:
As a general rule of thumb, it's best not to try to take a timeless classic novel and try to convert it to the big screen (unless you happen to be named Peter Jackson.) Last time I checked, Andrew Adamson wasn't Peter Jackson. I liked Shrek and all, but the book that, admittedly, really funny movie was based on was by no means a timeless beloved classic. While I do not believe that Narnia books are nearly as brilliant as they commonly made out to be, I still have to give C.S. Lewis credit for making books as a segue into fantasy for the children too young to read the actual classic fantasy series The Lord of the Rings. So while I do feel that Narnia books are very over-rated, I can still see their worth in introducing 4 and 5 year olds to the genre (and seriously, 4-5 is about the age level these books seem to be written for.)

However, the movie adaptation takes the books' unengaging, repetitive nature, and then goes on to disregard all the values that made the books at least worth the paper they're printed on. The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe adaptation attempts to be a poor man's Lord of the Ring. It keeps true to the books for the most part, but Adamson interprets what is not specifically specified in the book and tries to recreate the epic battle sequences found in both the Tolkien and the Jackson "Rings" trilogies. For example, in the novel version of "The Lion, etc." the final battle lasts somewhere around a page and a half. Along came the movie, and WHAM! 25 minute battle scene, anyone?

The fact the book was made into a movie at all was also a bad decision. The book is very slow, and takes it's sweet time in causing anything to happen. With only the two Shrek movies under his belt (and stuff was continuously occurring in those. Shrek is the definition of never a dull moment) Adamson has no real experience making anything with long slow bits of dialog that seems written by George Lucas (and no, that's not a compliment.)

The acting in the film wasn't horrible. It was a darned sight better than in that cinematic piece of crap called Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen. Now there's a film that makes a Uwe Boll movie look like manna from Heaven. Comparatively, simply because the acting was completely atrocious, this film seems about on par with one of his. I'm not saying the acting was genius or deserves any special awards. On the contrary, it was quite forgettable. But therein lies the key. Bad performances, as well as brilliant ones, can be remembered for long periods of time. I guarantee that whatever you've heard about this movie, good OR bad, the conversation probably did not revolve around William Mosely or Georgie Henley, or any of the other actors. They are not memorable in the slightest.

So on the plus side, this movie didn't have me debating the merits of destroying a movie with nuclear weapons simply so future audiences don't have to sit through it and current audiences are put out of their misery. However, this came about as close as you can get to the point. Actually, Im being unfair. This movie is the perfect sleep aid. If you know any insomniacs, and Lunesta doesn't work, they may have found their perfect sleep aid. I know I did. And then, unfortunately, after the good night's sleep I was granted, I had to watch "This film that involves something to do with a gigantic carnivorous cat, a warlock, and a big closet" again. I did not fall asleep this team, and I was able to come to terms with how much of a cinematic turd this really is. It's just not the worst turd in existence. And that's a back-handed compliment if ever I saw one.

title: Too much contradiction
review: The fighting and overall theme was good, but the plot was bad, I think. "I can't think of any way to give these kids any kind of power, so I'm just gonna have Santa Clause come along and give them a bow and arrow and a sword that's not even magical and that they hardly ever use. Oh, and all the creatures are going to be from either Greek or Roman mythology, nothing is going to be of my own creation except for this big field with a few mountains called NARNIA." Yeah, I thought it was kinda lame. CS Lewis could have been more creative. The book is only like 80 pages long. Clearly, CS Lewis wanted to write it as fast as he could and not take his time to make it great. The loop-holes in the plot are as big as the solar system. He gives absolutely no reason for all that's happening other than a prophecy being fulfilled. Okay. But, as far as the battles go, I liked it.

title: Terrible.
review:
If you read the book when you were a child and loved it, I suggest you avoid this film. (Especially if you are British, as it will annoy you intensely.) It's nice-looking, and the animals are fabulously done; if you like to marvel at how good CGI is these days, it might be worth seeing some clips. But as a rendition of the story, it's just soulless and not very much fun. As far as I can see, the only reason to watch this would be to poke fun at it afterwards, and even that's not massively entertaining. Ten reasons to avoid it:

*(minor spoilers)*

1) The music, which sounds like it came from a cheap library disc of the school of bad sub-Clannad pseudo-Celtica. I see many bargain bins in its future.

2) The tragically wooden child actors, with the exception of Skandar Keyes, who did a fairly good job with Edmund. Hate to say it of someone so young, but the actress playing Lucy had only two facial expressions - a grimace which supplied both happiness and tearfulness, and a sort of smirk for practically everything else. Susan appeared to have come out of the cupboard in which Hollywood keeps a constant supply of zombie child actors with huge, overly lipglossed mouths, and was infinitely forgettable. Peter was slightly less generic but snoresomely bland, and why on earth was he holding his sword like a gun?

3) The tacked-on opening scene, which was yawnsomely clichÃ©d and probably responsible for killing the music budget. It also caused me several minutes of stress while I thought we'd paid for the wrong film.

4) The tacked-on window-breaking scene - which sorry, soooo wouldn't have happened. These are nice, well-brought-up, polite, honourable 1940s children. They would have stood their ground and owned up immediately. Lucy and Peter, especially.

5) The American WOLF. Argh, argh, argh, there just aren't enough arghs in the world for this one. It pretty much killed the whole thing for me, and has probably caused small tornados in the vicinity of poor Lewis's grave.

6) The tacked-on waterfall scene. Utterly pointless and annoying. Bored now.

7) Father Christmas. Not dressed as Father Christmas. If you hadn't read the book, you'd probably have had no idea who he was; he appeared to be some random old bloke who liked giving out presents.

8) Liam Neeson: why?!! Star Wars buffs in the casting department? Only big name available at the time? Who knows. Aslan spoke, and everyone in the room immediately said 'Oh, that's Liam Neeson.' Spellbound by the majesty of the great Lion, not. There are probably hordes of unemployed Shakespearean actors who would have done a far better job for half the price. And if they really felt a desperate need to make Aslan Irish, they should have gone the whole hog and used Ardal O'Hanlon in full Father Ted mode. At least I'd have got a giggle out of it.

9) Tilda's hair. Oh dear. Jadis, Empress of the Western Lands, as New Age crusty? I think not. Can't decide whether wardrobe had been watching the Matrix sequel, or old Slits videos. As for the battle-scene hair, which appeared to be reconditioned from Jareth's in Labyrinth; it actually looked quite awesome, but I was really disappointed when the expected blast of death metal never happened. I like Tilda, but alas, only her hair was scary. And Jadis, you know: meant to be scary.

10) In short: it's basically before-the-watershed-MTV Narnia. Might make nice wallpaper if you turn the sound down. :)

title: beautiful to look at but boring to watch
review:
During the height of the London blitz, four young children are sent off to an estate in the countryside to wait out the war in safety. Ironically, they soon find themselves caught up in a quite different war, one that takes place in a world not their own. For while staying at the house of an eccentric professor, the youngsters discover a magic wardrobe that leads them to a mystical land of centaurs, fauns and a whole host of anthropomorphic creatures - a snow-covered land called Narnia. The kingdom is ruled over by a wicked witch who declared herself queen after she usurped the throne from a benevolent lion king named Aslan, who is amassing a rebel army to help him reclaim it. The children become a part of this epic battle since it has been prophesied that four young humans will arrive some day to bring about the liberation of this benighted kingdom.

Based, of course, on the beloved C. S. Lewis novel of the same name, "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" does pretty well in its setting-up stage as the youngest of the four discovers the strange land inside the wardrobe and tries to convince the others of its existence, but once the children become firmly entrenched in the Narnian action, the movie begins to feel too much like a warmed-over "Lord of the Rings" with a lot less action and far less interesting characters. Aslan, in particular, is so drippy and sappy, so full of bromides and platitudes, that we have a hard time getting misty-eyed even when he's heading up the stairs to perform his act of ultimate sacrifice. Speaking of which, the Christian allegory at this point is so heavy-handed and obvious that it ceases to function as allegory and just becomes slavish imitation. And the scene with Santa Claus passing out weaponry and ammunition to barely pubescent children - how is that an acceptable image in a movie meant for youngsters? The film has a beautiful look and design, although some of the special effects shots look surprisingly amateurish and unconvincing for a film of this size and budget. The acting by the children is passable at best, although Georgie Henley, as the youngest child, and James McAvoy as the faun, Mr. Tumnus, do establish something of a rapport in their scenes together. Tilda Swinton as the Big Bad Witch does little but harrumph around the countryside, glaring and snarling.

I realize that both the book and the movie have legions of devoted followers and any attack on either is bound to elicit cries of "sacrilege" and "blasphemy" from the faithful. But, the truth be told, "The Chronicles of Narnia" is a pretty mediocre movie, pleasant to look at but boring to sit through.

title: Not what i was hoping for.
review:
I have just finished watching this film and i have to say i am somewhat bemused by some of the comments i have read. I found the film entertaining but only just, it was slow starting and never really picked up any kind of tempo, the battle scene was disappointing, special effects were OK but nothing special and at one point, a scene were the queen is seen sledding across a frozen lake, this was quite false looking. It is in my opinion poorly directed, the scene with Aslam dying on the sacrificial slab with Susan and Lucy looking on was a prime example of this, more should have been put into this scene and the two girls would have been far more traumatised to see what was happening. This is not comparable to the Lord Of the Rings trilogy in any way. Peter Jackson would have made a far better job of directing this classic tale, lets hope for better on the next instalment, although i do not hold out any hopes.

6/10 and i feel i am being generous.

title: Extremely entertaining....powerful story.
review:
I typically do not prefer to watch fantasy or sci-fi films, but out of respect for C.S. Lewis, I saw this one right when it came out. It was above my expectations. A movie can never be as good as the book because of the limitations on a movie that our human mind does not have. Nonetheless, it captured my attention while telling me a positive story that is enjoyable for nearly all ages.

The 1,000+ people who rated this film as awful (1 out of 10) probably cannot accept such a powerfully positive message considering the majority of today's films are so dark and negative. For a real mind-opener, I would challenge any of you nay-sayers to read CS Lewis' "Mere Christianity" for a dose of truth.

title: The movie was AWESOME. It was so well directed..
review: The movie was fantastic. I look forward to seeing it again and buying the movie. It was directed well, and the actors and actresses did outstanding. It was so well directed that I actually cried during the movie.. I never cry during movies. After seeing the movie, I couldn't stop thinking about it, and how great it was. This movie will definitely be winning a lot of rewards. I'm looking forward to the rest of the movies, even though I haven't read the books. It was possibly one of my favorite movies. It actually made it seem like you were in the it. I definitely recommend that if you haven't already, go see this movie!I give The Chronicles of Narnia, The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe, Two thumbs up!

title: kid version of PAssion Of The Christ ? (No offense)
review: This movie is not good, it's too long and boring. The only good things from the movie is just the, cool special effects, Weird but cool creature, and Genius Idea of creating the Character. and i guess it's just another version of Jesus movie (or Another version of Passion of the Christ?). I said that because, well there is one part Where Aslan(the Lion) were killed, and then the next day he raise again. its just like Jesus. he sacrifice himself for people's sin, then after a few days he raise again from death. well there is nothing wrong with it, but its just that the story suppose to be short.the Director just try to stretch it as long as possible, i don't Know for whatever reason. i guess this movie is not worth to watch it in Movie theater,just wait for the DVD. probably some people like it, but not me.

title: In a word...it's all about "nostalgia"
review:
...For me, anyway, experiencing this movie on the big screen, was a matter of reliving a piece of childhood nostalgia...and, that was the only real driving force, behind my resolve to see it.

To that extent, it did not disappoint.

Visually, this is a beautiful movie, which had no trouble holding my attention, on those grounds alone.

Story wise, is where I started recognizing, that not all beloved books are well suited, to be made into movies, which are strictly faithful to the original storyline.

There are things about the C.O.N. novels, which make it hard for any movie to gloss over (or just ignore), without leaving you (or at least me) with the sense that there are substantial holes in the plot and story.

There seems to be a trend amongst some, trying to spread this notion that you can either watch it from a religious standpoint and it works great, or you can watch it from a non-religious standpoint and it works just as great. Personally, I could not disagree with this notion more staunchly, if I wanted to. I strongly disagree.

It's not that the religious tones are overbearing, or that they are not kept well enough out of the limelight...It's that, if you are not reading them into the story, then you are left with the sense that there should be more there...that the story should be better fleshed out, than it is.

...and, this is a good lead in to the flow of the movie...which was great, during the first half or so of the movie, but, then degenerates into this experience, where you are simply having ill explained scenes hurled in front of you.

If you know the basic story from the book (I do), then it may not be such an issue to you...but, if you are walking into the theater thinking, "I'm leaving any preconceptions at the door...I simply want to be treated to a good story", then this simply does not work well.

The pacing of this movie is badly uneven, and it suffers for this.

The acting is passable. Nobody will win an Oscar, I'm sure, but, nobody was abysmal to watch, either. The two younger children, are quite cute, and delightful to watch.

As to the general viewing experience, I found myself genuinely sucked in, and enjoying it...but, I was constantly enjoying it by, "in the moment", bits and pieces...not so much so, as a larger, connected story.

...In fact, it is the "connected" aspect, that is such an issue to me...This movie feels disjointed, from one scene to the next, in a fair amount of it. I feel like I connected with some of the scenes, remembering and anticipating what was about to happen, but once the scene ended, it was like being plucked out of one world, and plopped down into another world...to enjoy that scene for what it was, and plucked away again.

It just did not work, as an over all story...Something is missing, and you can tell.

The movie feels epic, in some regards, but fails to fully flesh out an epic tale.

Children of all ages may quite enjoy this movie, regardless...It's a matter of taste, preference and forgivability.

Personally, being someone who has experienced this story from both the religious and the atheist perspective, in both book and movie form, I find myself in the awkward position of knowing and understanding the religion influence, accepting that it is there, yet still wishing it were different, and seeing this is an ultimate downfall of the movie.

...and the awkward thing, is that I still enjoyed it, and would likely recommend it to others, who are fans of the books. The movie has good nostalgia value, in my opinion.

title: Wasted time and money
review:
Hi all, I went yesterday with my girlfriend to see Narnia. I can tell you now without any doubt : it is a piece of s@#$%!!! The acting was very poor (except maybe for the white witch and .... Mr Beaver!). The blond dude looked very dumb and it was pathetic in his appearances with the sword - which sword looked very much like tin to me. The little girl was king of cute, a little better acting in here, but nothing spectacular.

The decorations and details were done like in some television show; see the snow which looked like polyester to me - and that is what it was! I liked the black frozen guys though... I can agree with a guy that said before that this is a very poor copy of LOTR. The woman who picked up the children from the station also looked a lot like the teacher of Harry Potter. Maybe this movie is nice for young children (not very smart ones), but for grownups which enjoy fantasy I sincerely believe it's a waste of time and money!!!

title: Best Family Film of 2005...
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia blends a wonderful story with beautiful scenery, good acting, superb visual effects, & top notch CG & puppetry. Four English children, moved to the country during WWII, stumble upon a secret wardrobe closet which opens a door to a fantastic but troubled world of Narnia. The White Witch (villian) & the lion Messiah Asland (hero) prepare to battle for supremacy of Narnia. The White Witch knows of a prophecy of four children who will tip the balance of power to the good creatures of Narnia, and wants to get rid of the kids for good. The White Witch desires to keep most of Narnia in a frozen landscape for all time.

When the Witch calls for the life of the youngest boy, Asland makes a deal sacrificing his life to save Narnia. Asland is humiliated & murdered and all seems lost. The majestic & powerful lion returns from the dead because of his true heart to join his people & new found friends in battle against the White Witch & her evil minions. Asland & company win the great battle & save Narnia from a cold, desolate wasteland of ice. The children are crowned rulers of Narnia, presiding over different areas.

A great movie for all ages, if you enjoy fantasy films. The battle scenes are not terribly violent & are over as fast as they begin. This is one to sit with your children & watch for family time. If you liked Lord of the Rings & Jumanji, you'll fall in love with The Chronicles of Narnia.

title: Wonderful Movie
review: Growing up, I loved reading the Chronicles of Narnia series, and I was worried that Disney would ruin the central religious allegory aspect of the book. However, I didn't know that C.S. Lewis'stepson was one of the producers, and he ensured that this movie stays true to the book. Tilda Swinton is the perfect White Witch, the scenery is stunning, Liam Neeson is great as Aslan's voice, and the children are just as I imagined they would be. I thought Mr. Tumnus would be older than what he is portrayed to be in the movie, but other than that, the movie was great. The opening scene with the bombers attacking London almost made me cry, and that only happens when I see a great movie. You can hardly even tell that the animals are digitally animated! The special effects add a dimension of fantasy to the movie that I haven't seen since "The Neverending Story" came out in the mid-1980's. Overall, "Narnia" is a motion picture masterpiece that will entertain and enthrall both children and adults alike. However,I would recommend that children under the age of 10 be accompanied by a parent, because some scenes may be a little mature for them. In addition, I recommend reading C.S. Lewis' novel before you see the movie, because otherwise you may not completely understand the story.

title: Chronicles a fantastic adaptation!
review: Because the book "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is such a short novel, the director had an excellent opportunity to include all the details from the book. In the two hours of the movie we get everything from the actual book including a couple of areas of "fleshing out," like a little bit of back story of the Pevencies and some reasoning for Edward's bratty behaviors. Aslan is truly realistic in the way the CG teams make his features emote, just as he would in our minds' eye when we read the book. His roar is, fierce, his sensitivity is touching. In his face the audience knows what he is trying to convey. All in all the movie brings to life a story so full of adventure and beauty, only before seen in our imaginations. I loved it as much as the book!

title: A ticket to a magical land
review: You could compare Narnia to Lord Of The Rings in detail and richness. The movie moves in quite of a fast pace and there are no dull moments. Like with King Kong the CGI has reached a new level. The animals look and move in a life like way. The child actors do a very good job especially the little Georgie Henley as Lucy Pevensie. The other star of the show is Tilda Swinton as the white witch. I can't remember seeing a better bad guy/gal on the silver screen recently. Sometimes the obvious Christian undertones bothered me but you have to remember when the books were written. Otherwise the story is pure class. What made me gasp in awe were the battle scenes at the end of the movie. All the details, camera tricks and sword fight choreography made it something wonderful. I can't wait for the other Narnia movies to come out.

title: Disappointing compared with the made for TV version
review:
I thought a big budget and more sophisticated techniques would make this better than the 1988 British TV version of the story. But it doesn't. While the digital lion, beavers etc are fabulous creations, they're no more believable than the (very sophisticated) puppetry and costuming used in the earlier films.

It looks too much like "The Lord of the Rings" and some elements are just ludicrous (Gandalf the extraordinary wizard riding a horse at speed without saddle or bridle is believable; a London schoolboy doing it in full armour is just silly).

I don't want to include any spoilers, so won't say any more. If you've seen (and loved) the previous films, I think you may share my disappointment.

If you haven't seen the earlier one, the story makes this version worth seeing.

title: Why does this movie make me squirm?
review: I never read the Narnia books as a child. Maybe that would have helped. I respect author C. S. Lewis as an imaginative Christian writer - his slim volume The Great Divorce is a tour-de-force of theological speculation. But this movie - yuk. Most of our UK atheist reviewers of the film tore into it for daring to slip a Christian message into the cinema. As a Catholic Christian, I would have welcomed that but in fact, it wasn't there. Instead there is a strangely mawkish, sickly-sweet analogy for the Redemption that made me feel quite uncomfortable. To me - the Christ Event of the Gospel is challenging enough without these layers of colouring-book story-weaving. I hope children will enjoy it though. I've gotta remind myself it's for them.

title: If you enjoyed the books, save yourself the torture, and read it again
review:
I grew up having read the famous book, undoubtedly someone would one day try and convey this story upon the silver screen, it's actually a miracle it took them this long! Where do I start, its always hard taking someone's else imagination, work, story and moulding it into your own piece but people have done good jobs of this in the past "Charlie & The Chocolate Factory", "The Lord of the Rings Trilogy" & "Jurassic Park" to name a few books successfully turned into good movies. Also with such a entertaining book with detailed characters & good action scenes everything is in place for a good translation into a movie, unfortunately Andrew Adamson who directs this movie maybe thinks he can follow in his countrymen's footsteps (Peter Jackson also a famous Kiwi director) and although he did good with the Shrek Movies, it seems Mr. Adamson's skills lie in the animated movie industry as this film is diabolical from start to finish. Most of you will already know the story and premise of this famous story, 4 young children during World War II are evacuated to the countryside in rural England, from here the children stumble upon a cupboard in a strange professors huge house, upon entering the cupboard they arrive into a strange world, NARNIA. Their adventures in Narnia centre on saving the people from the evil rule of the White Witch who has plunged all of Narnia into eternal winter, with the help of Aslan the talking Lion they set about freeing Narnia. The problem with this movie is it seems VERY, VERY, VERY Rushed, where as LOTR spent years trying to recapture Tolkiens world of Middle earth, Narnia seems to have taken the blurb you get on the back of the book and created the film off that! The story is told at a frenetic pace and at 140 minutes long that's quite a feat, but even if they had made the movie longer and told the story better with these pathetic child actors in charge little could have been done to save this film. Peter the eldest and supposedly smartest of the bunch is totally unconvincing and his fight scenes are almost comedic, Little Lucy is just plain annoying rather then endearing & cute, Susan is very pompous more so then her character in the book and the one person who has the most material and characterization to play with fails miserably as a weedy unconvincing troubled young boy, Edmund, but at least he plays the cowardly part right. Liam Neeson provides the voice for Aslan and does his wise old man routine seen so successfully in Star Wars & more recently Batman, Mr. Tumnus played by James McAvoy from "Shameless" fame does well but the relationship between him & Lucy seems a bit too false, where as in the book it was well written. Tilda Swinton plays the White Witch the "bad guy" so to speak in this movie, and she does OK, but I think anyone could play this character as she has to look quite monotone & emotionless, almost wooden in her performance to pull it off, so stick a wig on Keanu Reeves and you'd get the right effect! The Beavers are by far the most entertaining characters along with the wolves but don't get nearly enough screen time, instead we're left looking at Peter holding a sword in an attack position looking like a complete donut for half the movie. My biggest gripe with this movie isn't how he hasn't made a good interpretation of the book, its the poor makeup & costume of some of the characters, the visual effects are excellent, CGI and all is good, but some of the creatures like the half horse half men, the Minotaur's (bull heads) and other creatures look like they are straight out of a TV serial that got cut after the first episode, just imagine watching the making of LOTR and seeing all the Orcs, Goblins, Uru-Kai's, Dwarfs & Elves masks made up by the crew that went horribly wrong and were thrown into the scrap heap, its almost like the Narnia crew snuck into this scrap heap and took what they could !

If you enjoyed the books, save yourself the torture, and read it again, or watch the old cartoon or old BBC TV series, this is so bad how Disney hopes to have started off a Lord of The Rings or Star Wars legacy is beyond me, this is more the start of something like Police Academy then anything else!

title: OK, but that's all.
review:
Narnia is a OK movie and it will entertain children from ages of about 10-15.

However what must be remembered is CS Lewis was a good friend of Tolkien, the man whose books were recreated masterfully by Peter Jackson. One gets the nagging feeling that Lewis wanted a different interpretation than the syrupy tripe that Disney manages to offer.

Firstly, the two eldest children are not even endearing for 2/3 of the movie and it makes the idea of empathy and being brought along this world with them all the more difficult. The character development is thin, with the idea of Peter suddenly becoming the hero that he is, isn't really explored.

Secondly there is the idea of casting. Tilda Swinton doesn't seem all there as the White Witch and doesn't seem as menacing or masterful as Voldermort, nor as drunk with power as Saruman, and it is somewhat difficult to see how she got the power in the first place. However, the animals are good and Jim Broadbent though underused, is good as the Professor.

Finally there is the Americanised tripe that Disney seemed to plow in just to please. This comes in the form of Santa Claus, who turns up to give the children presents ( in the form of weapons ). There are more scenes like this one and it truly takes away from what could have been a great film, but instead seems to trip over itself.

This is no Harry Potter or Lord of the Rings, and nor should it have been seen as such, but while these two movie franchises had intricate plots, great casts and memorable dialogue as well as Spectacular, but not OTT effects Narnia drowns the audience in syrup and it only half comes off as it at the expense of characters and plot. A shame , as this could have so much more...

title: Disney Cashing in and Then Some.
review: Peter Jackson's Masterful Lord of the Rings trilogy opened a flood gate of fantasy ripoffs and wannabes. Disney's Narnia is no exception. When the storyline is not paralleling a biblical narrative it glosses over any attempt at fleshing out any of the characters, who are two-dimensional at best. The only exception is Tilda Swinton's White Witch character. One of the best scenes is the Pagan sacrifice ritual, where I was able to feel something other than the movie's sugarcoating on my teeth. The movie is beautiful to watch. And given a chance, the remaining cast seem capable of creating memorable characters. I like the beavers, too; the female beaver's voice is none other than the enjoyable and funny Dawn French from the Vicar of Dibley and French and Saunders. Otherwise this film's main achievement is to help boost Disney's revenue at the end of a lackluster year for the film industry. I dread to think that there will be six more of these Disney interpretations of C.S. Lewis' Narnia Series.

title: Great for kids, but not for a serious film buff.
review:
First of all, I was amazed at the number of reviews that praise this film as one of the greatest of the year, and even though I am highly outnumbered, and my opinions may not be popular, I feel they must be stated as a contrary to what everyone else is saying.

This movie is not a literal interpretation of the beloved C.S. Lewis book, and while he was a devout Christian, C.S. Lewis denied that the similarities to the story of Jesus in the Chronicles were intentional. Douglas Gresham, artistic and creative director of the C.S. Lewis Co, and C.S. Lewis' stepson has said "If you want to, you can find Christian symbolism in a McDonald's hamburger," (http://www.azcentral.com/ent/movies/articles/1105narnia1105.html).

This movie takes advantage of the subtle Christian symbolism the book offered, and has brought it to the forefront, often adding in its own twists, such as the visual of the "Footprints in the Sand" poem at the end of the film. There is no problem with this, and Walden Media can do as they wish, as they have the rights to the film adaption, but I felt this is something that is often ignored in peoples reviews of this film.

Here are some quotes from other reviewers.

"The acting was excellent and the special effects set a new standard for Hollywood" The acting is decent, but in no way excellent. It appeared to me to have been over direction of the children on the part of the director. Perhaps, he is not comfortable working with children. They did a decent job mind you, but every action, and emotion they conveyed seemed forced. It just seemed obvious to me that they were being walked through each scene by the director. I was also disturbed by the lack of worry for their brother "Edmund the Afterthought" throughout the movie, but especially when they are told of his, and their potential fate.

With the advancements in CGI over the past couple of years, this movie was a huge letdown. The glaringly obvious moments were during the standoff with the wolves. Watch as they jump down the hill. They seem to have forgotten to shade the characters all together. Azlan was the exception to this for obvious reasons, he was very well done. It also would have been nice if they added some cold air effects coming from the mouths of the children when they're in the snowy winter of Narnia. Due to the acting inconsistencies, I just never believed that it was actually cold outside.

"The musical score is appropriately stirring and moody." I am a fan of Harry Gregson-Williams, but felt the music was inappropriate, and out of place. If I listened to this on its own, I think I would really like it, but I felt it just didn't fit. The song at the beginning of the movie was WAY out of place, and almost laughable. You can always count on Disney to try and add a pop-culture touch to the film.

Overall, this is a great movie for families and for kids. Children, who typically could care less about special effects flaws, and bad direction, will be in awe of this film. It is worthwhile to check out this movie, but it would probably be more enjoyable if you brought some kids along.

title: Lavish adaptation---ALMOST great.
review:
Here you have just more than HALF of what it takes to make a great and enduring fantasy film. Great look and sound--but an unfortunately lacking script, and dull acting. Great children's entertainment, but without the adult element that would deepen it. (Only Tilda Swinton plays her role at an engagingly adult level that also works for the kids.) Lewis's original books worked, as Roald Dahl's books work, because they don't talk down to the kids, who recognize B.S. better than anyone.

Quality of script and acting are more important than lavish sets and effects--films like Neverending Story and Princess Bride proved this. When the most intriguing screen presence is the villain (Tilda Swinton's toned-down but unnervingly creepy White Witch), the balance of the story is in trouble. Just think how much you could root for emotionally engaging heroes like Atreyu, or the eccentric gang from Princess Bride, or that motley gang of kids with real personalities in Spielberg's The Goonies.

So, they got half of it right. Really right. Unfortunately, it's the less important half.

* * *

Script problems include leaving out crucial details that give the plot events meaning, a general dumbing down (in the book, for example, Lucy protests reasonably enough that they have to stay in Narnia because "it's on my account that Mr. Tumnus is in trouble"; the film dumbs it down to a four-year-old wide-eyed "But we HAVE to help MR. TUMNUS," without explanation; et cetera). The Father Christmas episode, which has rightly been called off-putting in the film version, was less awkward in the book because Santa provided a merry meal as well as murderous weapons, plus a sewing machine for Mrs. Beaver, and it all seemed less abrupt.

Pacing problems include dialogue that stretches out with hypnotic languor even while leaving out helpful details; you'll be left begging for another implausible action sequence.

Acting problems include the general blandness of the main characters, despite the sweet screen presence of Lucy, (you'd think even well-bred British children would exhibit some astonishment at entering another dimension; their indifference works in the book, but not on film), and a general failure of actors to inhabit their roles. Even James McAvoy, one of the better actors as Mr. Tumnus, could have avoided the uneasy "molestor" dynamic by playing the faun as eccentric and slightly blithering, as in the book, as opposed to the quiet, wry intensity he brings to the role here.

And on and on. The main problem is a lack of characters we really identify with or care about.

Unlike many viewers, I enjoyed the build-up to the Wardrobe; the air-raid sequences and the leaving of home were emotionally engaging (Mrs. Macready was an entertainingly sharp presence), and the sarcastic dynamic between the bored children actually made for some believable interaction and characterization.

title: am I missing something? "minor spoilers"
review:
There must be something I am missing about the movie. It makes very little sense to me and maybe things are explained better in the book. I have no problem accepting a magical world through a doorway, a noble lion that rules a kingdom and such, but please don't tell me a evil witch/queen who knows of a prophecy of her demise involving 4 "children of Adam and eve" does not have the sense to kill one as soon as she had the opportunity. And the "idiot Queen" had multiple chances to save herself by killing one of the children. This so called Queen then proceeds to miss read some fine print on an old law and can't even do a proper killing. Not to mention under her employment is the most useless pack of wolves in existence. They couldn't even injure two defenseless girls in what seems like 30 minutes of time?! The leader of the pack then falls on a sword and kills himself?! And about these "kids", they falls in a frozen river and shakes it off like it was a dip in a tub? they'd turn into ice cubes,and not the rapper/fake actor either. Then with what seems like an afternoon of sword training, these "kids" are out and hacking about on a battlefield?! Are you kidding me?! at least give me the "he ate the battle skill apple" or something. The list go on and on with these stupid happenings that make no sense to me. I know this is a children's story, I know it is fantasy. But please have some basic logic and realism. I am sure the ice is still cold in Narnia, I am sure the Queen dosen't want to die. Then please act like it. That my rant on this so called epic movie. I hope the book was better.

so turn your brain off and prepare to get retarded when entering this picture.

title: Wonderful fantasy adventure, yet there are some flaws
review:
I have never read the original artwork by C.S. Lewis, so my review can by no means assess how true the movie actually is to the original.

The movie itself does have some weaknesses, fair enough. I am used to rating movies due to their logical coherence and substantial quality, and both is to be criticized here. Yet the actual transformation is only one aspect. I approve of the underlying themes and the messages that are conveyed, and this makes me award Narnia with a solid 7.

The story is simply outstanding and inspirational by all means. This is of course due to the books and not something that can be credited to the movie's producers. The fantasy and the power of magic that pervades the story might make any child's eyes gleam in admiration and amazement. This needs to be appreciated and makes Narnia a nice Christmas movie.

The characters are somewhat indifferent, save for little Lucy played by Georgie Henley. The two male actors in particular seem a bit overcharged with the movie's scope. They act decently in a way that would definitely suffice for a movie of lesser dimension, but they lack to vitalize their characters with the emotional depth and convincing authenticity that would be absolutely necessary for the audience to establish some sort of relationship to them as characters. This is probably due to a lack of sophistication in terms of the kids' acting skills. Maybe the casting department should have chosen more experienced actors instead of utter newcomers.

Okay, having criticized this aspect I have to say some good things about the visual accomplishments. The movie is an eye-catcher in terms of wonderful visualizations. I think it is fair to say that the visual outfit does justice to Lewis' perception of Narnia. The creatures are wonderfully designed and seem so vivid as they could have possibly been.

The real reproach of my review is the coherence of the storyline though. I do concede that it is a challenge to process something as huge as Lewis' Narnia, but the story lacked considerable logic sometimes and was sort of elusive. It seems to me that the producers wanted to jam as much input into the story as possible, which hampered the natural development of the plot. How can you expect the two boys being good at fighting with their swords in a huge battle? Why are the main characters rejuvenated when they re-enter the wardrobe? In addition some scenes were indeed very corny and too stereotyped for my taste - even young kids can expect a bit more. The deep emotions were not really convincingly conveyed, which brings me back to the unexperienced actors.

The reason for giving Narnia a 7 is the magic of the whole movie. Talking animals, magnificent landscapes, funny dialogs, themes of redemption and courage - this is something to be appreciated, as it might inspire children and adults alike. The whole movie might have been a bit too childish, okay, but it is not that bad as a whole.

Still, there would have been many ways to make Narnia better. It is a pity that both the cast and the producers were not really able to live up to the scope and the possibilities this unique story provides.

title: Always a King
review:
First, Tilda Swinton was extraordinary as Jadis. She was terrifying yet gorgeous in a way that reminded me a bit of Alice Krige as the Borg Queen. She is an actor with magnificent screen presence which was well-exploited by Adamson. The young talents were all quite good too. Georgie Henley (Lucy) was adorable and William Moseley (Peter) was very strong too.

The photography is terrific. I had to look up Donald McAlpine but I wasn't surprised to find that he also shot Peter Pan and Moulin Rouge which both looked amazing to me. It was just mythic, epic and magical enough to be perfect for the subject matter. I'd very much like to review the BBC's 1988 version because I have a vague idea that Adamson and McAlpine borrowed a couple of shots directly from it which is kind of cool.

I think C.S. Lewis would have been happy with the creature designs and the CG animal characters. They certainly capture the spirit of the words he wrote. It's all about the titanic struggle between the forces of good and evil and in good Christian-fashion, most of what's evil is ugly. Though it's rather obvious what is CG and what isn't they did a good job at making the creatures fit into the world with the actors. Hair and fur are one of the most difficult things to replicate and they had tonnes of it to do here. I think it turned out rather well. A few of the CG shots could have been replaced by puppets or animatronics to give a more realistic look but overall, I was happy with the balance.

The Chronicles of Narnia inspire me. They are collectively one of the greatest volumes ever written in English or any other language and I am thrilled that they are being brought to the silver screen in such a grand fashion. For Andrew Adamson's first live action film this is an incredible achievement. I can't say I loved Shrek but Adamson was clearly as inspired as I by Lewis' writing. It shows in the filmic tribute he has created. Well done.

One final note, the music in the film is wonderful. There seem to have been a few composers involved and they all deserve congratulations. Also, the credits feature a couple of beautiful songs by Imogen Heap and Alanis Morrisette. In a time when I've more or less stopped buying CDs, I can't wait to get my hands on this one.

title: Good attempt to give a much-loved Narnia story the "epic" treatment.
review:
The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe had already been filmed twice prior to this 2005 version, once as a rather mediocre cartoon in 1979 and once as a modest-budget BBC mini-series in 1988. It had never been done on a grand cinematic scale though, possibly because of the phenomenal expense and technology needed to bring it to life in a manner true to the essence of C.S Lewis' book. The catalyst for this latest attempt to tell the story was probably Peter Jackson's LOTR trilogy. Having seen in Jackson's films what could be done - what monsters could be put on screen, how epic battles could be realised, how fantastical worlds could be visualised, and so forth - the folks at Disney decided that the time was right to have another go at this Narnia favourite, only this time they've thrown a mega amount of money at it, as well as every type of visual trickery under the sun. The result is certainly a stirring and well-made piece of entertainment, and easily the strongest adaptation of the story thusfar.

During WWII, four children are evacuated from bombed-out London to an old mansion in the countryside. They are Peter (William Moseley), Susan (Anna Popplewell), Edmund (Skandar Keynes) and Lucy (Georgia Hanley). The mansion belongs to an old professor, and the children are warned by his crusty maid that they must behave perfectly whilst in the house. Pretty soon boredom sets in, and the children decide to play hid-and-seek to pass the time. Young Lucy chooses to hide in a wardrobe, but she gets quite a surprise when she finds that the wardrobe is actually a magical entrance to a fantasy kingdom called Narnia. One by one, all the children find their way into Narnia via the wardrobe, and they discover it to be a kingdom locked in a permanent state of winter by the evil magic of a powerful witch (Tilda Swinton). The witch has long ruled over Narnia, turning all who oppose her to stone. However, she has always feared the words of an age-old prophecy that states her reign of terror will come to an end with the arrival of four humans in her kingdom. Afraid that the children are the four humans of the prophecy, the witch deceitfully lures one of them - Edmund - onto her side and tries to turn him against the others. Meanwhile, Peter, Susan and Lucy travel across Narnia, evading the witch's wolves every step of the way, and eventually meet the mythical lion Aslan (voice of Liam Neeson) who prepares them for the final battle against the witch and her monstrous army.

At 2.5 hours, The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe is a well-rounded and well-developed film, though perhaps a bit too long for very young audiences. The special effects work is pretty impressive on the whole, with a convincing gallery of beasts and some magical sets that really capture the child-like wonder of Lewis' stories. Some of the CGI effects in the battle scenes are a little obvious and detract slightly from the spectacle. The performances are good on the whole, particularly the four young actors and Swinton as the despicable witch, plus James McAvoy as the faun Mr Tumnus. One thing, however, that I found really unconvincing was the way that novice swordsmen like Peter and Edmund managed to cope so well on the battlefield.... surely the witch's army would have despatched with the pair of them quite comfortably if they'd fought so inexpertly?? It is an enchanting tale which has stood the test of time, and thankfully the scripters have stuck to the story faithfully in most aspects. On the whole, The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe is a good, solid family film and a long overdue effort to do a version that is worthy of the source novel.

title: Lives up to every positive review
review:
I headed to the late showing tonight and was pleased to find this movie lived up to every positive review I've seen or read.

There is reason to compare Adamson and Peter Jackson, they have a rare ability to deliver on faithful re-creation of the literary into the cinematic.

The movie delivers on the allegory, and yet again the New Zealand landscape shows fantasy can be real.

For all those anti-Christian, Santa hating folk out there...go see it, let Aslan breathe on you.

"Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is a simple children's story, that didn't leave a single adult eye dry in the house tonight.

title: Disney ruined a great book
review: Leave it to Disney to ruin a great book/ story/ movie. C.S Lewis' genius was reduced to a barney movie. Instead of all the expensive cheesy effects, green screen and bad animation they should have paid for a better director and script. All the meaningful moments were glossed over and none of the characters were believable. The fight/ action scenes were like a bad video game, none of it seemed important. In the book you see the characters evolve and you believe these kids when they transform over time into kings and queens, fighting minitars and such. Leave it to Disney to not have faith in the kids in the audience and us and dumb everything down. When did our society completely loose faith in the intelligence and depth of our kids? Seeing children's movies like these makes me want to vomit because of the trash we are feeding our kids minds. What happened to the jungle books, lord of the flies, the Narnias, the wrinkle in times, and lord of the rings Etc.? Stories and productions meant for kids but not dumbed down for 2 year olds. The book is so incredibly better than this film; it's embarrassing. Lord of the Rings hit it on the nail, this missed it by a football field. to bad Warner Bros didn't do it. the director should be shot and the mouse should be hanged. i was very much hoping this would be great and unfortunately it was a huge disappointment. this was more of a Disney TV movie of the week instead of a major motion picture. i wanted an Oscar movie i got a movie that wouldn't even get nominated for an emmy.

title: good for younger kids and fans
review:
I just saw the cut down version (age 6, cut down from age 12) and was somewhat disappointed. Thats mostly because from the trailers I expected a fantasy movie and not a movie for children with fantasy elements.

It is said the movie is true to the books, which are intended for a younger audience. So thats it. But being true to a book should never be a factor in judging a movie. If one wants a true adaption, thats like having an audio book with pictures - better read the book in the first place.

So I will only rate the movie, and not being a kid (or a fan), the movie could not quite live up to my expectations of an entertaining evening.

I am sure if I had seen this as a 7 year old I would have been swooped into the story, but as an adult I just see a lengthy non fantasy prelude with character development of the 4 young and unwilling heroes, a well made first contact scene between fantasy creature and normal girl, again some lengthy zig-zag till the story seems to get a direction which turns out to be a not-to-bad-for-a-kids-movie battle scene. Not to forget the obligatory reward scene and the return to normality scene.

For (young) kids this should be a great fantasy film to begin with. For older audience it's a little more difficult. Just because you liked other kids movies this does not mean Narnia is the right kind of movie for you.

title: A good surprise
review: . When I saw the first trailers of this movie, I really thought that it would be a strange one, I couldn't see this getting much of a success. I actually was expecting it to be just another simple fantasy movie for kids. Yesterday I watched it and I had a big surprise. It's just a wonderful movie !!! I see many people will be comparing it with LOTR, mainly because the same company was responsible for all visual effects in both movies, but while LOTR exceeds a bit over Narnia, it has its own original charm and mood. Many people may dismiss this movie due its obvious Christian references, moved by their prejudice against Christian values and culture. The movie may get some bad reviews due to this particular feature, but it's a big mistake. Apart of that, this is a beautifully-told, engaging and interesting fairytale history, with amazing visual effects and good characterization. I was pleased to see this movie, it totally beats my expectations. No one should miss it.

title: Did justice to a wonderful book
review: I went to this movie very worried that I would be given a lot of P.C. Hollywood junk, especially since this is a Walt Disney Movie. However, I came out of the theater over joyed with how they stuck to the books original messages and themes. Aslan still lays down his own life and is resurrected, not healed or magically fixed as I feared would happen. Anyone who has read the books will also be happy to know that a lot of the dialog comes directly from the books. All of the actors are tremendous, and fit what I have always pictured them to look like. The only character I found flawed was Mr. Tumnus, the actor was very good but I fear he just looked to young and should have had a more grandfatherly feel.
