I wonder if they'll make movies out of the rest of the series.

title: shameful remake
review: This would have to be one of the absolutely worst most terrible unfaithful Movie made out of a novel I've ever seen. As a child or a younger child I really loved the chronicles of narnia, especially horse and his boy, the last battle, silver chair and voyage of the dawn treader OK they were all good. But when I saw this I just found the ambiance and feel way different from the book. First off it was made by Disney and made as an 'action adventure movie'and it was Just really unfaithful to the book for instance In the novel peter stabs and attacking wolf guard with his sword and this this is a sign of him growing up and becoming a man but in the Disney version to escape the wolf guards Peter stabs his sword into a frozen waterfall unleashing a torrent of water, washing the wolves away whilst he escapes clinging on to a floating block of ice. None of this was included in the book and i think it was just an excuse for Disney to blow a couple of million dollars on some phony baloney graphics. The movie left me feeling empty and violated.

title: I loved the movie!
review:
I must say, I completely enjoyed this movie.

When I first heard that Disney and Walden Media were making the beloved book into a film, I was excited, but also worried about the fact that they might not live up to the amazing story C.S. Lewis created. How very wrong I was.

Disney and Walden Media were obviously the best choice to make on who would make the film, because they made the movie so incredible. The actors, who literally came out of nowhere, were a hit. I do hope we'll see more of these actors in films apart from Narnia. The special effects, music, costumes, and everything else came together so perfectly to make this a spectacular movie, one that I could watch again and again (which I do).

I can't wait for the sequel, and I can only hope that they will continue throughout the remaining Chronicles.

title: Could have been much better
review:
I saw the ads and couldn't wait to see it!! I rented it and watched it today and was I disappointed! I FF through quite a bit of the movie. The only good thing about this movie was the special effects. I loved those!

The writer COULD have spent some quality time on, say, the plot. Never having read the book, I don't know how true to it the movie is, but writers and developers take poetic license all the time and they should have done so with this movie!

Anymore, it seems like the trailers that we see on TV are the best part of most movies. I'm usually let down.

title: Mediocre Performance, Mediocre Storytelling
review:
I got this DVD a short while ago, and I was very disappointed. I realize why they would have made this movie first, because it is the most popular, but I'm afraid that if they tried to make the actual first book in the series, people would turn away from it. Though it was the first book published, it still is not the beginning of the story. The book was almost too magical to be turned into a movie. The acting was a bit mediocre; some of it was downright annoying. They changed scenes too much from the books, and Aslan....Aslan was not nearly as magnificent as he could have been. "Fills the screen, and your heart," one review says, but watching it I only got angry as they turned it farther and farther away from what this story is supposed to be.

I'm trying to stop comparing it to the book, but that's what originally made me fall in love with the whole "children's magic" scene.

And also, everyone could be saved from anything!Any "death" scene was awful! If someone was dead, it would be: die (cry,cry,cry) be saved (laugh) Why laugh?

Overall, I just really thought this movie was one mediocre job done.

title: the chronicles of Narnia and harry potter movies
review: i gave it a 8 out of ten because although its a very heart warming Christmas movie, kids of that age shouldn't fight with such creatures, even if it is just imagination... anyway, even though many many people have turned against the harry potter movies, i don't think we should talk ugly or sloppy about them. my personal opinion is that the harry potters are much more magical, but both movies ,or in this case series of movies should be appreciated as such. so, my advise is that every person who is interested in the comparison of the two pieces of art should first see the movies, and after that reading through the comments of them.

title: An enjoyable fantasy film
review:
I haven't read the Narnia books so I didn't know what to expect about the movie. Surprisingly, The Witch, The Lion and The Wardrobe was an enjoyable and lovely picture. It was not the best fantasy film I have seen but I liked it very much.

The story was very typical but well-made and compelling. There were some very impressive and touching scenes although some of them were too scary for kids. It's same with Potter movies: they're meant for children but sometimes, at their scariest moments, you start to think if they're really suitable for kids. Or maybe I just overreact. Anyway, this movie really made a huge impact to me.

Especially I liked the warmth of the story. It was visually stunning and good-looking but it also had a heart and a soul. I really cared the characters and felt sadness and joy when they felt it too. That's something that you don't find the Potter movies. Also the world of Narnia was charming and full of the sense of wonder. It was very easy to me to be wrapped up in this magical land of miracles.

Kids were good in their roles. Also Tilda Swinton was excellent as the White Witch. I liked the way she played the role: no shouting or exaggerating looks but unassuming and well-balanced performance which made her character very scary. Instead, Jim Broadbent was just the annoying professor.

However, the movie was not perfect. I think it was quite over-long. Especially in the middle of the movie story didn't seem to move on. Also some of the funny lines were unnecessary and even stupid. I was not satisfied the ending. It was too over the top. (Okay, this is the fantasy movie but still it was too silly, even for fantasy!)

Some of viewers have criticized The Witch,etc. because its Christianity. Well, I'm not a devout Christian and I don't like too religious movies. Still, I didn't feel Narnia's Christianity irritating or too preaching. I think it was well integrated to the story and filmmakers didn't underline it too much. Besides, the movie can be watched even without thinking its Christian message.

Conclusion: The Witch, The Lion and The Wardrobe is better than most of Potter movies but cannot match the LOTR -trilogy.

title: Disappointed
review: I was eagerly awaiting this film. Sadly, it disappointed me. The special effects were wishy-washy. Sometimes they would epic(Aslan, the battle) sometimes they were less than believable(The fox and the beavers mostly). The acting was good,Edmund and Lucy were phenomenal(I still don't believe that Georgie Henly had never acted a day in her life before this). Peter was good, but you can only act so good to a sub-par script. Susan annoyed me, she wasn't that annoying until later books. The witch was a good actress, but the way they made her look is ridiculous. Tumnus reminded me of a child molester, the way he looked at Lucy creeped me out. Aslan was wonderfully voiced by Liam Neeson, he lifted the entire movie. Oreius was a good addition to cast as well. The costumes were like the special effects, Great(The entire Narnian army)and terrible(The Witch's dresses, enough said.). Overall, Narnia is a hard movie to judge. With signs of being great, and signs of being terrible. The battle at the end was a good action scene, it lifted the movie along with Aslan. Crossing my fingers for Prince Caspian.

title: A Complete Trainwreck
review: This movie is a real disappointment. It is boring, lackluster, and missing something. Every moment is a moment of agony, as the movie never delivers that special element that captivates you like masterpieces such as Saving Private Ryan and Lord of the Rings deliver. The movie overall pleases the simple-minded. For those of you who cannot think for yourselves, this is the movie for you. Generally, throughout the whole story, the movie tells you how to think and what to feel about each situation. This overall hold-your-hand approach to the story line leaves intelligent viewers bored and pleading for that something that will redeem this abysmal flick. Not only does it walk you through everything, but it tries to shove epic sequences down your throat every other minute of the movie. These frequent catastrophes just don't work at all. Each of these just leaves you with a more bitter taste than before and a growing opinion that Chronicles of Narnia is a movie that tries to be something it's not. It's no epic and it's nothing to stand up and cheer on any army for. In addition, the character development is so erratic that it never feels like any character are actually evolving, but instead assuming roles. I have to admit I only paid one dollar for the movie but I wish I had spent the money on four gumballs. I would have gotten tenfold more enjoyment out of those four gumballs than I got from this disaster of a movie.

title: Biblical Symbolism
review:
The movie was absolutely amazing, it was truly moving, with a wonderful score and true essence. I was rather disappointed of the comments people have made on this movie here at IMDb, since many missed the whole Biblical Symbolism that the movie wanted to represent. C.S. Lewis was a Christian Author, and the symbolism is very present in the movie, for example Christ Crucifixion, Death, Resurrection and Assention by Aslam being killed, then he was resurrected, and left at the end of the movie with the promise we will see him again. Also the stone table being cracked, same as in the Bible but it was not a stone table. Jesus is also represented in the Bilbe as a Lion from the Tribe of Judah. Or how about a girl out of curiosity opening up the wardrobe, which has a tree on it, and opening up another world (same in the Bible, Eve eating from the tree of good and evil and opening up this world to a new one, a sinful world). There are many more as well, but for now this will do. The whole point of the movie or the novel is to teach an important lesson, and I hate it that it is always compared to LOTR or Harry Potter, which have absolutely nothing good for our kids to teach morally except to entertain them to death.

The movie I give 10/10, it is truly remarkable and can't wait till the next Narnia movie will come out in 2007.

God bless.

title: Fantastic movie
review: I just love this movie. I saw it yesterday, and I am glad i did it. The animation is just sick. Aslan look gorgeous, and the battle is very amazing. The actors did a great job when they played in the movie. I will recommend this movie to everybody. I am a big fan of this movie, because of the great story and special effects. The animators did a really amazing job with the creatures and battle scenes in this movie, and Aslan is even better than a real lion :P I am really looking forward to more Narnia movies, and I will buy them at all cost:P It is sad that the computer game is so bad compared with the movie. The minotaurs in the movie are also very cool, but Aslan is the coolest and best character. This is a very, very great movie. Hail Aslan, king of the movies!!!! :)

title: "...Narnia..." Is a Moving Must-See!
review:
Fans of "The Chronicles of Narnia" will not be disappointed by this magical adaptation of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe."

When four children enter a magical land full of fantastic creatures--and evil villains--there is sure to be adventure. And adventure there is! "...Narnia..." is packed full of all the best elements of comedy, drama, action, and (of course) fantasy.

The costuming is stunning, the scenery is lush, the acting is genuine, the soundtrack is moving, and the story is...well...it's Lewis' best!

Anyone interested in remembering how it feels to believe in something will find in this film a meaningful and moving testimony to the power of hope, family, and faith. Bring your imagination and your sense of wonder--and prepare to enter the wardrobe!

title: Excellent Movie for all ages (and Christians)
review: WARNING: SOME CONTENT HAS A SPOILER!!!!!!!!!! This is an amazing movie! The music is wonderful! All the actors are wonderful! Georgie Henley(Lucy) was a great success! And, also my religion wasn't slammed in my face for no one likes my religion. Aslan stands for Jesus and when he died and rose from the dead that stands for Jesus dieing and rising from the dead. THIS MOVIE IS AWESOME! When Lucy first got into Narnia, I was convinced that this was her first time seeing the set. James McAvoy (Mr. Tumnus) was also amazing. He is such a good actor. Anna Popplewell (Susan)....... words can't describe the care and beauty. Skander Keynes (Edmund) HA...such a troublemaker. He is one of a handful of people in the world. William Mosely (Peter) one of the people with the bravery and elegance. I hope that people will like this movie!

title: Perfect
review: There is nothing like seeing one timeless classic morph into a film, where characters are more real to you then ever before. The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe is the first of several films to be produced by Mark Johnson based on C.S. Lewis's wonderful series. The acting in this film was nothing but amazing, as the young actors played their parts with brilliance. The film is a perfect blend of action, anticipation, sorrow and joy all fit into a wonderfully complete plot line, topped off with a heart felt ending. It captivates its audiences from beginning to end. The adaptation was wonderful, and this film will forever be immortal.

title: Very long and flawed.
review: I haven't read the books, and my only relationship with Narnia is from the old BBC series. And upon viewing the movie, I had fair expectations for it. Sadly, Naria comes as a disappointment. First off, Naria is long. It drags in many places, and IMO it could easily be edited down half a hour or so without loosing any value. I'm not usually for trimming down the running time in favor for action and pace. But here I thought the running time ruined the experience for me. Secondly, the cast. I didn't care much for the four siblings. OK, Lucy was adoring, but that was about it. Aside from poor performances, I was never convinced that the fate of Narnia rested upon two skimpy boys and their sisters. Perhaps I'm missing the point, but the movie never gave me a good explanation of it either. It just seems hollow, like it cues up events from the books without proper care or meaning. And story aside, the movie is not that much of an excitement. Its visual, even with its impressive cgi characters and make up is too saturated and bright for my taste. Overall Narnia comes as an disappointment, with its running time as its biggest flaw

title: great movie.
review: Great movie in all, if that's all you needed to here than go see it. But if you want a better review than that I got some stuff for ya. Great battle scenes, great characters,great creativity, great fun! This movie combines big ol rhinoceros action and wonderful acting. But besides all the fighting there is also good humor and pretty cute animals. I think you need to have read the book to really appreciate the film though. Thouh even though this movie was great in my eyes this movie is not for every one. I think those who like any common action movie and like to have a warm feeling in there gut, this is the one for you.

title: Surprised....in a very good way
review: I heard a lot of praise about this movie and I'm into special effects and movies like this such as King Kong. I didn't think to see this in theaters because i thought it was a childish movie. To some extent it is a movie really built for a younger age group and one thing i wished to see was some more realism when some soldiers got killed but at the same time i didn't mind too much since the action had me hooked. I went into this movie expecting to be mildly entertained and i didn't think it could compare to King Kong or Harry Potter. Well I'll be the first to admit how wrong i was. The movie was just stunning in every aspect. The Visual effects were second only to King Kong but this movie didn't really stress Visual effects as much as King Kong did. The music i thought fit right into the Movie and especially in the scene before the big battle. The Action was good and every character was interesting and vital to making this movie the success that it is, from the Beavers to the children. The one character that stood out was Aslin the lion because he stole every scene he was in. C.S. Lewis made a great choice when he chose the lion because it signifies a majestic and honorable animal and by the end of the movie you won't see him as an animal but as a character just like the children. In the end, not every one will like this movie, not if your all into blood and gore or if you don't like a little childhood aspects to your movie, but at the same time if you like movies like this you would only hurt yourself by missing it. This was one of the best movies of last year. 9/10

title: Just buy the toys...
review:
Watching the Lord of the Rings movies, the problem I always had was I could never tell who anyone was exactly or what was happening exactly  all I knew is that there were hordes of demon baddies trying to bust down the castle door to get to some women and babies, so I rooted for the guys trying to stop that. With Narnia I had the opposite problem  everything that was happening was made obviously clear, but what was revealed was a story and world so fraught with logic questions, I was left as baffled as I was leaving Lord of the Rings.

And what fundamental questions they are, like what is Narnia exactly and who lives in it  without knowing that, what's at stake when it's threatened? We never see any towns or "normal" inhabitants, only mythic-styled warriors who never do any real talking. What was it like before the White Witch arrived (other than not frozen)? Who is the White Witch and where did she come from  was she good before and turned bad? Who is Aslan the Lion? Was he a king or something before? I get that the White Witch is evil, because she sneers, and I get that Aslan is good because he has Liam Neeson's slow Scottish brogue and talks elliptically, but come on. There is a prophecy of course  as there always has to be in these movies, from Mannequin Skywalker (sorry, but Hayden Christiansen's performance reminded me of the "Life of Brian" catchphrase "He's not the messiah - he's just a very naughty boy") to KeaNeo Reeves in Da Matrix  but here in Narnia you have four children stumbling into a huge war-like situation they (and therefore we) have no understanding of whatsoever, and all the battle hardened warriors allow these untrained, unmotivated and confused CHILDREN to lead them into ACTUAL battle? With swords where they actually fight hand-to-hand and people actually die? Because of a prophecy? I dunno while maybe there's an Iraq allegory in there somewhere, with a major Christian right spin perhaps, this movie had me totally lost  and bored.

And one final question - the most incongruous of all  what on earth is Santa Claus doing in this Narnia world, and why is he handing out WEAPONS to children? I know this is a post 9-11 world, but since when does Santa give weapons? And while we're at it, why does the White Witch use the exact same sleigh/reindeer transport as Santa? None of this is explained. It's like why not toss in the Pillsbury dough boy, Bigfoot and the Easter bunny into the big battle? Honestly, why not?

I feel sorry for kids today, growing up watching sanctimonious ultra-violent junk like the Matrix trilogy, plot less I-own-a-visual-FX-company junk like the LOTR trilogy, numbing/dumbing action figure commercial junk like the Star Wars prequel trilogy, and now this.... Whew  okay, now I'll be good boy and go buy the Narnia toys and Taco Bell tie-ins and get really excited about Narnia II and III.

title: costumes and creatures of Narnia, and the colorful things about it
review: First off giving credit to the WETA workshop and the others that helped and worked on the costumes and creatures of the Narnia movie. Although the costumes and creatures and such were good, everything always seemed to be much too shiny and colorful. If they were in such terrible times, why all the passionate colors and amazing sunlight on the days? Perhaps it's because The Chronicles of Narnia is much like The Lord of the Rings...for toddlers, that is. Not a very big fan of the acting, either. After all, it was William Moseley's second or third movie, same for Georgie Henley, same for Skandar Keynes...but that's really no excuse. All in all, I suppose it's just too much bright color, sunshine, pretty animals, and shiny stuff for one movie.

title: Does Justice To C.S. Lewis' Christian Fantasy Novel
review: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe (2005): Starring Judi McIntosh, Georgie Henley, James McAvoy, William Moseley, Skandar Keynes, Anna Popplewell, Tilda Swinton, Jim Broadbent, James Cosmo, Ray Winstone, Dawn French, Rupert Everett...Director Andrew Adamson, Screenplay Ann Peacock The rights to a film project for C.S. Lewis' classic Christian fantasy about four British siblings who wander into an enchanted realm and of a boys' redemption through the sacrifice of a noble lion had been long contested prior to this film. Disney had always intended to produce this fantasy film but never did. Finally, in 2005 Walden Media Productions and director Andrew Adamson released this terrific and awe-inspiring movie, which, unlike many book-to-film adaptations, is faithful and stunning. Georgie Henley, William Moseley, Skandar Keynes and Anna Popplewell star as the Pevensie children Edmund, Lucy, Peter and Susan who during the 1940 Blitzkrieg over London are temporarily secluded in eccentric and affluent Professor Kirke's (Jim Broadbent) sprawling mansion. Lucy discovers a winter wonderland behind a closet/wardrobe and soon Peter discovers the same thing. But this enchanted world is under a dark spell.."It's always winter, but never Christmas". The wicked White Witch (Tilda Swinton) is contesting the right to rule the world and fighting a battle against the rightful king, the good lion Aslan. True to the novel in every aspect, this film is enjoyable as a fantasy for adults and for children. It is a long film and in fact December of '05 saw many long films including Harry Potter and King Kong. But you hardly feel the time go by as we journey into the heart of Narnia with the children. Peter learns a valuable lesson in love and sacrifice as Aslan offers to die in his place for his betrayal. Now, everyone who is deeply familiar with C.S. Lewis'works understand that this is a Christian allegory/fantasy. Lewis, a born-again Christian, created a Christ-like figure in Aslan, a sort of haphazard Judas in Peter, and a pagan Devil-Goddess in the WhiteWitch, though some would have it that he was attacking what we call the Goddess today. The children carry the film for the most part, despite the fact that this film relies heavily on computer-generated characters such as the Witch's wolves and the helpful beavers and other good-natured animals. The scenery is gorgeous. This film was shot in various location- the UK and New Zealand and studios. Some of what we see is pure computer animation, though by today's sophisticated standards, one hardly notices it and takes it for reality. The film wraps up nicely but mind you, the Narnia novels are a long series and there is already a sequel under way- Prince Caspian, said to be released in 2007.

title: Great movie and WONDERFUL for children.
review:
Really fantastic. There are a few scenes I wish they would have done differently and a couple I wish they would have added (like the humorous scene between Aslan and the lion who is released from the White Witch's castle). I was a little disappointed with Aslan's voice....I don't think Liam Neeson's voice is quite majestic enough for the way I pictured Aslan. This was quickly overlooked though by the general presence of the movie.

I'm sure someone could nitpick every portion of the film if they had a mind to, but overall, WELL worth the wait. And so close to the book, I was amazed. This is one movie that lives up to it's publicity hype. I can't wait for Prince Caspian!

title: Easter's Cancelled, We Found The Body...
review:
This movie was great --- These evangelical neocons need to check their own backyards before thinking they know whats best for everyone else... This is still America and we still like our freedom when Gorge Butch isn't running up our collective national debt and selling Americans to the highest bidder.

Maybe more supposed "Christians" should see this film it might keep them from turning out like Tom Delay or maybe even keep our future vice presidents from shooting people in the faces.

As an Atheist --- This film was wonderful and full of imagination. Hats off to the KNB F/X Company on their Oscar's for their fine work in the film.

may peace be with you---

title: A Bland Retelling of A Great Book
review:
I found this to be a trite by the numbers re-telling of a book I enjoyed greatly as a kid. Both the 70's cartoon and BBC mini-series captured the feel of the book much better.

The acting was stiff and unconvincing, the continuity was bad, often people were looking in completely the wrong direction while supposedly talking to each other or to the CGI creatures. And there were huge parts of the plot missing that were never explained.

Example: It was never explained that the winter was ending because the humans were in Narnia and it was never explained why the White Witch wanted to keep it winter in Narnia or how she made it that way in the first place.

As a child I imagined Narnia as a much more unique and interesting looking place, this movie managed to make it into a bland un-exceptional landscape that will be easily digestible for those that buy the DVD at Target or Wal-Mart...

title: With Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter, Narnia Is Adventure-Lite.
review:
Four children walk through a wardrobe and discover a land of mystery and enchantment. After the youngest learns that her friend from the land of Narnia has been kidnapped, she pleads for her brothers and sister to help rescue him. Once meeting the creatures that live in Narnia the siblings soon discover that they are some kind of prophecy written heroes. The Kings and Queens of Narnia that are said to rid the Witch of her evil reign with the help of Aslan, the lion.

Narnia seemed like the perfect film of the year that had adventure, excitement, and fantasy all rolled into one entertaining film. Based on the books, which are loved by millions, Narnia had a huge step to overcome in pleasing it's devoted fans. It's too bad that in a world with Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter, Narnia is adventure-lite. It's scope seems bigger then what it's reality is. Even when judging it against another book turned film, Series of Unfortunate Events, Narnia seems to be lagging behind in last place.

To begin with, the children are not likable at all. The little one who is suppose to be cute is annoying, the younger brother is a pain in the ass, the older sister has too little screen time to make any kind of connection, while the oldest is just too dumb. Not to mention that all the actors playing them were annoying to listen to. Other then the main characters, who we are stuck with no matter what. The supporting cast, the witch, the Faun and the deep and perfect voice of Aslan, Liam Neeson make up, a little bit, for what the children actors lack.

Nothing really exciting happen in the film. When you have a fantasy film such as this, that promises an adventure, you would expect something a little bit more then what the result is. It takes thirty some odd minutes for all the children to finally get into Narnia, after that they encounter a beaver and learn what the place is and who they supposedly are. After a quick run in with some wolves, and the younger brother in the hands of the witch, nothing else happens, save for the final battle. The kids are safe in their "terrirtory" where the heroes of the film train for the final battle. Then the final battle occurs, which is something right out of a card game Magic: The Gathering.

There's not too much of an emotional attachment to any of the characters, so when one is near death, we can't seem to care. This installment is a weak first entry to something that could be a successful series. Narnia does contain beautiful images, ranging from snowy mountain tops, to green valleys. It's a beautiful film, with great special effects, costume designs and set pieces. They have created a wonderful world where these creatures live in. Go into Narnia expecting a wild adventurous time, then you will be disappointed. Hoping to expect to see a massive battle scene, skip it, it can't hold a candle to anything that Jackson served us. See this, for beautiful images or if you're a fan of the material, whether you will be satisfied or not is up for debate, as I've never read the books.

title: Just Magical ! - An Excellent Rendition Of The Novel
review:
I have got to say that this movie is very enjoyable.As a child i had watched the VHS version made in the 80's and the animated feature but without the excellent special effects they are just mediocre compared to this.The battle scene is phenomenal and it is just an excellent rendition of the novel.

We start in London in the height of the blitz which i'm happy to see they added in.The four children are sent to the countryside to stay with a charitable professor in his grand country manor.As the children grow tired of boring games invented by their caring but know it all sister they decide to play hide and seek.In the search for a good hiding place, Lucy(the youngest) stumbles across an ancient wardrobe which she decides will be a perfect hiding place.All is not as it seems as Lucy stumbles to the back of the wardrobe she finds herself in a mysterious snow blanketed forest in the middle of Narnia an enchanted land where it is always winter but never Christmas and it has been that way for almost one hundred years under the terrible rule of the evil white witch.Lucy meets Mr.Tummus a fawn who befriends her, when Lucy returns to the house she is surprised that no time has passed even though she was with Mr.Tummus for many hours.Of course her brothers and sister don't believe her at first until Edmund the dishonest sneaky brother of Lucy stumbles into the land of Narnia and befriends the White witch. When the two other siblings of Lucy, Peter and Susan discover that Lucy is indeed telling the truth they find themselves caught up in a battle for good and evil helping Aslan a wise lion overcome the terrible white witch and bring Narnia back to normal.Although Edmund has other ideas and selfishly chooses to join the white witch unaware of her evil intentions to kill the children and raze the prophecy,the prophecy that says two sons of Adam and two daughters of eve will overthrow the witch and rule Narnia with Aslan.

This is a very entertaining movie with excellent special effects and a sweeping soundtrack.The beavers are excellent characters with hilarious cockney accents,Liam Neeson is excellent in bringing life to the mighty lion as the voice of Aslan and Tilda Swinton is a wonderful White Witch as she brings the harsh and brutal style of her character.This would be almost perfect if it weren't so rushed, great flick though definitely worth a look.

8/10

title: No more than adequate
review: I suppose I was spoilt after the recent crop of high class fantasy films. This was disappointing. A tale for children told at a child's level. I was hoping Disney might have grown up (temporarily) in order to make this important film but we still had cutsie bickering beavers hopping across the snow making unfunny comments and an Aslan that failed to evoke sympathy. That said, the acting of the humans was good, especially Georgie Henly as Lucy who really seemed to live the fantasy she was experiencing and the performance of Tilda Swinton as the Witch was memorable. However, it needs to toughen up in future films to bring out the extra dimension needed to raise the series from the mundane and to sustain interest if a full series of "The Chronicles" is to be made.

title: A Family Film in Every Sense
review:
As a parent, I deeply admire this film for adhering to a PG rating. It could have gone over the top in the battle scenes and with gore and completely ruined itself. Its jaw-dropping box office success was due to the fact that is was the best family film of 2005 and one of the better ones in many years.

Narnia's story is well known. Four young English children trying to escape World War II are sent to a large country home. There, they stumble upon an old wardrobe which leads them to the mythical land of Narnia, where strange and friendly creatures live. Narnia is cursed to a permanent winter while it is under the rule of the icy White Witch, devilishly played by Tilda Swinton. The four siblings soon find themselves in a battle for their own lives and for the very freedom of Narnia itself.

The parallels to LOTR are many, but Narnia comes across as LOTR-Lite. The battle scene at the end is exciting, not scary and Andrew Adamson has perfect sense in when to cut a scene and how far to take things. Yes, its frightening, but just enough.

And, as an allegory of the life of Jesus, it has a strong moral message that allows for some great conversation with your kids after the film.

Well made, wonderfully acted, good (but not great) FX, this is a film worth owning if you have kids, and maybe even if you don't. ***1/2 out of ****.

title: quite good
review: I have been a fan of C.S. Lewis for a long time, especially his 'Chronicles of Narnia'. So when I heard that Disney was going to make 'The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe' into a movie, I got excited. There had been previous cartoons and live action movies made, but with the new technology we have developed since then, I was anticipating this one being even better. I will admit that they changed certain scenes in comparison to the book and that was kind of a shame, but they did still do a pretty good job and the changes were not too bad. Over all I think the movie still turned out great, and I would definitely buy it and watch it again. Unlike some 'family' movies this one really is appropriate, so long as you do not have very small children. (there is fighting after all). Definitely worth seeing.

title: Heavy in prophecy, light on intensity
review:
It could be that Narnia has had to follow up two fantasy hits such as Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter, it could be that the book lacked in fire power, or it could be that the movie just wasn't done that well; but in any case Narnia fell short of expectations. Recently it seems to be en vogue to have children or teenagers playing the leads in fantasy movies (ala Frodo and Harry Potter), but what Narnia failed to do is make these children believable.

There was no transition from these kids' innocence and ignorance into courageous warriors and saviors. In Lord of the Rings, Frodo and Sam were never sure of themselves and they constantly exhibited inexperience throughout their goal to save middle earth. Harry Potter was always in need of help and he was not even the best magician in his class. But in the prophecy rich Narnia in which four humans were foretold to save the land, it seems all of the prognostication forced itself upon the somewhat unwilling heroes. First the siblings are bumbling around Narnia trying to stay alive as anyone would do in a foreign land, and then seemingly overnight the older brother is leading a major battle, the other brother is an integral part of that battle, while the two girls develop fearlessness of the foreign woods they are in.

The movie lacked intensity, there were never any white knuckle moments or hair raising events. The dialog was very generic and far from profound though one can infer that it was supposed to be, and the drama was mild even with the fate of an entire mythical land being in the hands of children. This was a kids movie dressed up as an adult one nothing more.

title: Very good in many ways, but.....
review:
Much like LOTR, the whole film is somewhat less that the sum of its parts.

There where too many trims to the final production, too many little bits and pieces that I just wanted to see, having vivid, yet thirty year old memories of the books, leading to (in my eyes) less than adequate character development of many important characters and or scenes.

Its almost like speed-reading the books, a little detail is lost here and there that reduces its over-all value.

Having said all of that however, if you are not over familiar with the books, its an excellent movie, the CGI surely sets new standards, the scenery is superb, and even the young actors do a very good job.

Had it been a little longer, it might have been close to perfection.

Worth a rental, your kids will adore it, and probably get more out of the books as a result.

title: Bad directing, mediocre acting, okay story, great potential
review:
Narnia is one of the most amazing film-phenomenas of the last years. For me. The hype, the amazing number of good ratings...

I had very high expectations and thought Narnia to have the quality of the Lord of the Rings. Well, it has certainly not and probably the only one to blame is: Me! For having high expectations.

When you approach Narna (book or film) you should never forget: It's a story FOR CHILDREN. Nothing more, nothing less. It is not a story compatible for anyone looking for an intellectual challenge.

If you keep this in mind (and you are a kid or someone at this level) you're going to enjoy this. If not, don't bother to watch it.

title: What a great adaptation
review:
It is so hard to do justice to books in films and so many people are too keen to just try and put the first thing they can up on screen but not this film. I have been a fan of the books for many years and when my children are slightly older I will read them again with them.

So what did I like about the film? I thought it looked beautiful, clearly New Zealand is the place to go to get a perfect setting nowadays. However I also felt that the acting was wonderful. There balance was perfect between all of the brothers and sisters although how they are going to do the next one is a puzzle to me as they all look like they will age very quickly!

I can't really say too much about the film that has not already not said in the comments and reviews but I would definitely suggest going to see this version as at last the producers have done the book proud.

title: Have your kids read the books when they're 10 instead...
review:
Finally got around to renting this. My thoughts, not necessarily in order:

The Good

Great production values, beautiful scenery, effects. The acting is, by and large, fabulous. The kids hit all the right notes, Liam is perfect as Aslan, Mike Madsen is perfect as a wolf as well. Very good adaptation, very true to the novel.

The Bad

The soundtrack is awful. Couldn't they have come up with something better than that terrible moaning at inappropriate moments? It's actually really jarring in places. Possibly because of the novel, the pacing is horrible. It really is a boring movie in some parts.

The Disappointing

I remember reading these books lovingly as a ten year old kid. Watching them on the screen as an adult sadly disappoints I think, in part, because the sense of wonder is drowned by the heavy handedness of the material that a ten year old would likely not pick up (or ignore in favor of Lewis' wonderful sense of imagination). When Aslan said "It is finished," I nearly fell out of my chair laughing.

The movie also suffers in comparison to the "Lord of the Rings." Once you've seen an army of Uruk-Hai and goblins, armies of minotaurs and tigers just look, well, silly.

Bottom line: Rent it. It's worth seeing once for the kid actors and the spectacle but don't expect it to re-create the sense of wonder you felt as a kid.

title: Narnia
review: Well, what is there to say about this movie? It won an academy award for make up. It did better than Harry Potter in the box offices and in my opinion, it was better too. I loved all the characters and the special effects. My favorite character performances were Edmund (Skander Keynes) and Mr. Tumnus (James McAvoy). Even though they were all great. The voice was perfect for Aslan and they did a good job creating him. It was actually somewhat humorous too whenever the White Witches dwarf was in the scene. They did great with the animation. I actually thought the legs of Mr. Tumnus were real until I saw the bloopers and he was wearing those green pants. The setting was incredible too! I loved the snow scenes in the beginning but during the battle, that was a great location too. The stone table scene was frighting and it made you just want to take that knife and hurt the White Witch And the music was incredible! They did a really good job with that. I look forward to the next Chronicles of Narnia movie, but something tells me its not going to be as good as the original. So overall, this has to be my current favorite movie. If you don't have the DVD, go out and buy it as soon as possible!

title: Enchanting Book = Enchanting Movie.
review: I have many fond memories growing up of reading the seven books that make up the "Chronicles of Narnia" series. So when I heard that they were making the first book into a film, I greatly anticipated its release. THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE LION, THE WITCH, AND THE WARDROBE is the first of C.S Lewis's beloved books to be released on the big screen. With a great deal of reverence, and a very large budget, Disney and Walden Media magnificently bring the classic novel to life. The enchanting story opens with the four Pevensie siblings  Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy  being sent from London during the bombing raids by the Nazis during World War II, to a country estate to stay with an old professor, safe from the war. On a boring, rainy day they play a game of hide-and-seek in which Lucy (the youngest child) stumbles onto an old wardrobe she chooses to hide in. Backing deeper and deeper into it, much to her surprise, between the furry coats, she hits snow covered pine needles! Wandering out of the wardrobe, she discovers a lamp post aflame in the midst of these wintry woods. She meets there a faun, Mr. Tumnus, who explains to her a bit about this world called Narnia. Narnia is ruled by the cruel White Witch, and has been in a 100 year winter, with no Christmas. Eventually, all four children venture into the wardrobe doorway to Narnia, and Edmund is taken hostage by the self-entitled "Queen of Narnia", the White Witch. Her plan is to kill all four kids, because of the prophecy which tells that sons of Adam and daughters of Eve (humans) will arrive to challenge and end her reign. Pursued by her army, the children are aided by a couple of kindly beavers, who can talk of course. The four siblings are to take their rightful place on the throne to rule Narnia. So they go to meet the lion Aslan, the real King of Narnia, and assemble a large army to fight the White Witch and her grotesque minions. Great morals are in this film, such as courage, loyalty, and sacrifice. The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe was Oscar nominated three times this year, including Best Visual Effects. You will be excited to hear they are making the second book, Prince Caspian, into a full-length feature, due out in 2007. This perfect adventure movie for both adults and children is rated PG. *Note: read the books too!

title: Non-emotional except for....
review:
Narnia can leave one feeling aloof and as cold as it's snow topped mountains. It doesn't have any real tears, it doesn't have any real belly laughs, it doesn't even make one angst or fearful. The battle doesn't even make on cry "onward soldiers, hooray".

The characters seem just like characters, and you never feel really touched by their actions or deeds. They seem more animated then the animation.

I never spoke aloud, not a word to any character.

I remember screaming to Frodo to "watch out, oh! turn around" And I remember detesting Darth Vader with vocal jeers.

I even cry when I watch ET.

The only glorious most attractive and attentive quality in this movie was the deepest most sincere wish to REACH OUT AND GRAB SOME FUR.

The animals made this film a great film, the irony is they weren't even real.

title: One of the best movies I've ever seen
review: When I first read the books as a child I thought, wow, no one will ever be able to make a movie from these books and be able to please me and keep Narnia alive. But Andrew Adamson and the entire cast and crew of Narnia have done exactly that. As soon as I saw the opening scene of the movie, chills literally ran down my spine. Never before have I been able to watch a movie over and over again and have the magic just as real as it was the first time. Like lots of people I was very nervous about people making a movie of this greatness but I was 100% pleased. For all kids and kids at heart, please watch this movie, it's sure to make your heart warm and your smile wide. (Corny I know, but watch it it's good.)

title: Better than I ever imagined.
review:
I absolutely LOVED this movie- I have not been able to say that in a long while. As soon as it started, the environment, music- everything about it easily lulled me into a deep nostalgic peace. My favorite character was little Lucy. Georgie Henley acted absolutely brilliantly, and so did Skander Keynes (Edmund).

Sometimes the Christian undertones of the movie are a little more evident in some places than others, but to avoid spoilers in this review I will not expand on that thought. (though, griffins and phoenixes definitely wouldn't be Christian symbols- at least I doubt it) The only reason this movie escaped a 10, was because of what I considered some moments of cheesiness/choppiness within the main battle. It seemed to go slowly sometimes and it seemed there should've been more attack directed on the main characters (you would need to see the film to understand).

Aside from that, this movie is perfect, both for the young and the young at heart.

Having seen both the Lord of the Rings and Narnia, I'm going to say that LOTR is probably a more "serious" or "mature" film. Both, however, do have a central theme of the main character(s) having to take up a burden that at many times seems too heavy. The similarity, however, ends right there, and any comparisons to battles, plot, etc., are unfair to make.

title: Excellent Family Entertainment!
review:
This is, simply put, a very entertaining movie (what I've always thought movies are supposed to be)! The story is intriguing, compelling, has its lighter moments and some darker ones, and is just a visual treat to watch. There exists no hidden agenda, only the allegory to the salvation story of Jesus Christ  a perfect opportunity to share the story with younger viewers (and some not-so-young . . .).

I am not interested in discussing the production values, special effects, plot holes, goofs or other trivialities that generally crop up in movie reviews  this is a joy to watch, and well worth the price of owning.

The best part of all is that this well-made piece of work was not rammed down my throat by the Hollywood elitists as an "end-all" movie that must be seen. It figures that the trash they promote wouldn't be nearly as enjoyable a experience as "The Chronicles of Narnia." As the Dylan song muses, "When will they ever learn?"

title: true to the story i suppose
review:
Well if you liked the book you will love this I never did so i didn't rush to the cinema to see it but have done so since it's release on DVD. The performances were very good tilda swanton was the stand out performance but my problem is simple it's a story about 4 children 3 of whom arn't particularly likable (the characters not the actors) who blunder into a fantastical land and by merit of being human set of a chain of events that cause the leader of the good forces to sacrifice himself to save everyone and rise from the grave in a jesusesque fashion. I just don't relate to the characters except maybe Lucy and find the story uninspiring, more down to CS Lewis than to anyone involved with the film which I think is pretty true to the story That said it had some fine scenes, good CGI and convincing sets.

I gave it a five which is probably about as good as i was ever going to give a film of this book.

title: Somebody please e-mail me!!
review:
What is great or even good about this film? I never read the books and am a 26 year old male. But I was lost after Santa Clause came into the picture. This is terrible, even from a simple story POV. It's too convenient, the plot is too convenient, the characters are too convenient and on and on! I am open to children's movies, I love good movies! I even LOVED KING KONG and LORD OF THE RINGS and the DARK CRYSTAL. This movie is terrible! Although the lead girl (Georgie Henley) was cute, the acting of the children was terrible. Tilda Swinton is awesome as the the "Queen", but one character is not enough to make this film worth watching. It's beautiful to look at, but even that is not enough because this movie fails on so many other levels. The best way to sum up my feelings about this "film" are to say,"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, COME ON!"

*1/2 out of ****

title: One of those films that the majority can enjoy and not completely hate.
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is an entertaining film for both kids and adults  something we rarely find in a world of either Brokeback Mountain or Daddy Day Care. In this lovely adaptation from the classic novel from C.S. Lewis, director Andrew Adamson takes the book into a new level if not better. Other than being a well-told story, some of the scenes look breathtaking and adds more eye candy to the solid-traditional novel. In other words, Adamson is able to do the impossible: Make the film better than the book.

Narnia is quite a popular story and I don't think there is any reason for me to really explain it in a coherent fashion. It is simply about four children (Anna Popplewell, William Moseley, Skandar Keynes, Georgie Henley) who lives in a time of WWII and moves to the home a professor  and they happen to discover the world of Narnia through a wardrobe in the professor's home when the youngest child Lucy (Henley) was trying to find a place to hide during a game of hide-and-seek. As beautiful Narnia seem to be with its snowflakes on the ground, we find out that it is not all it seems to be. Narnia has been having its winter for about 100 years when the White Witch (Tilda Swinton) took over. The Witch happens to be looking for four children who are going to arrive in Narnia and fight alongside Aslan, the "lion king" to make more sense (voiced by Liam Neeson). The Witch wants to trap the children, as the children tries to escape from her with help from the creatures in the woods.

The film has its sparks, with a good cast and nice entertaining bits here and there. The four children in the film actually seem like relatives so that is a huge plus right there. Tilda Swinton, whom I have never really seen in anything else before is absolutely fabulous here: She plays a villain that strikes with just a stare with her cold, blank eyes. There are also some good supporting players, including James McAvoy's Mr. Tumnus, the Faun that saves Lucy from harm of the White Witch. There is also Jim Broadbent as the professor that we actually come to love in the little scenes he is in.

There are a few problems I had with this film. Even though CGI isn't at tops right now, Aslan's fur looked so artificially fake to me that I thought I was going to prefer that dragon from Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire. There is also the corny dialogue that you won't notice unless you're older than the age of twelve  but that is another matter. There is also Edmund (Keynes), which I swear is the "other" version of Fredo in The Godfather: Part II, only nobody kills him and he turns out okay in the end.

Many knew Lewis was a Christian, and in a society where we have to say "Happy Holidays" in schools, I was glad to see that the film kept the Christian allegories that Lewis intended for his original novel. (You see, Aslan is Jesus.) I try to wonder if younger children in our society that are not raised in such a culture of religion (I have friends who don't even know what I'm referring to when I talk about a man putting bunch of animals in a ark) would really understand this story. There are a few scenes where some of the creatures in Narnia ask, "Are you the son of Adam?" "Are you the daughter of Eve?" But still, this tiny problem would not turn away audiences  I assure you that kids will still enjoy it because it still maintains its kid-friendly action-entertainment.

I really liked this movie  it was entertaining, it was nice, it was a film that I think I can watch with anyone in the world, it had nice performances (kudos to Swinton), and it was better than the book, something that is rarely achieved in cinema. This film also makes for really good eye-candy, with the lovely snow from Narnia, the sleigh of Santa Claus even made Santa to a knight in shiny armor, and everything from the makeup to the costumes  it was all really well done. Adamson surprised me with all the success of Narnia, considering the only films on his director resume are the Shrek franchise. Overall, this is a good film, despite the corniness of some of scenes, but after all, Narnia is aimed at children and people who absolutely loved the book. I am none of those, but I still recommend families check it out for family movie night  there is a huge chance you might enjoy it.

title: Glossy Dross
review:
I approached this film with an open mind. I had read the books as a kid and had seen the UK TV adaptation, but I was never what you would call a major fan. Narnia was never going to be sacred to me. After all, it's just stuff.

Even so, Disney's approach to this film grated. It starts of well enough, and I enjoyed some of the special effects in the exposition, but once we get to Narnia proper, it goes down hill rapidly.

In my view the film has poor pacing, relies too heavily on visual effects and has the kind of sickly sweet sentimentality that could give anyone diabetes. Frequently I was bored. Jim Broadbent did his stock eccentric professor performance. Ray Winston did his stock cockney sparrow performance. What was Tilda Swinton playing at? She is far more capable than her paint by number performance as the White Witch. And as for cute child performers

'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' seems to veer wildly through its course; from trying to emulate all the better parts of Lord of the Rings in terms of scale and action, to desperately trying to distance itself in terms of plagiarised imagery. It fails on both counts. It kept reminding me of LOTR, and in doing so fails miserably as a comparison.

It was just so insipid and uninspired.

An overlong film with sloppy sentimentality, clumsily stitched to some big set pieces and liberally sprinkled with sugar.

On the positive side, the CGI lion was superb. Breath taking in fact! The scenery fantastic, and Judy McIntosh excels. Paramount fodder for young children, as it is intended I'm sure, but a real pain for accompanying parents.

title: A Wonderful Film
review:
I thought that the Chronicles of Narnia was a great film. It was a bit shaky at times (you could tell that this was Andrew's first live action film), however I found this added to the story and made it more realistic. The music is wonderful and inspiring. The actors/ actresses were more or less how I pictured them in the book.

The only actress that seemed out of place was Tilda Swinton (the white witch), simply because I always pictured the character of Jadis as having dark brown hair and green eyes. This is kind of a stereotype, so I am kind of glad that they decided to give her dreads and blonde hair instead.

All of the weapons, costume designs, props and computer generated characters were on par with Lord of the Rings. The wardrobe was simply beautiful. A true Narnia fan (like me) could pick out all of the little details and be nerdy about it. For example; the wardrobe tells the story of the first book, through the images that are carved into it. Look for this the next time you watch the film. Also...all of the books shown in Mr. Tumnus' study were the exact ones mentioned in the book. Check for this too. Little details like this are scattered throughout the film. They are fun to look out for. It's good stuff. ^_- The Chronicles of Narnia did not quite live up to my expectations. I almost walked out on this film when I went to see it. But I gave it another chance. I rented it and watched it through with a cup of hot cocoa in my hands. I found that it warmed my heart and even emotionally touched me when I let go of my personal interpretation of the book and chose to view it with Andrew's "realistic" vision. After watching it a second time it became a favorite. I think Andrew took it in the right direction by making it more "real." Making it too magical might have made the story seem cheesy...and just another Disney Stereotype.

(Of course Disney is not on my "nice" list right now. It keeps making crappy sequels. One day, just for that, I shall buy out the Disney "Empire" and return it to its former glory. But that is beside the point.) I felt that the Chronicles of Narnia has more heart and spunk then the first Lord of the Rings movie. And Peter Jackson had prior experience with live action. This was Andrew's first. So give him a break. I bet the first time you made a drawing in art class the teacher had to keep themselves from laughing. Had I been Andrew's teacher I would have been staring at the screen with my mouth agape. This film was pretty damn good for a first time live action. So I give it ten stars.

OK...so they added a few scenes. I'll admit that they skimped a bit on the character development. And they did cut some things from the book. But if this is what you are all complaining about...take a look at the Fellowship. They didn't even add Tom!! Or Goldberry! Where was the "magical" element in that? So all these people who say it's a Lord of the Rings reject...heh. I suggest going back and watching the first movie again. The Chronicles of Narnia surpassed it by far. Even in music.

My advice to the hard core fan (like myself) is to give the movie another chance. Go back and watch it a couple times. Appreciate all of the extra things they put in the film (for the hard core fans to notice ^_-) and marvel in the fact that they actually took the time to make this movie. Then think of the future. If this is the way they started the series...then I bet it will finish with bang. Look at the Fellowship. It was long, didn't have much of a plot, and the characters were dull if anything else. But by the time the Return of the King rolled around, I was balling my eye out. The next two became quick favorites. I was the first person in line to buy copies of the "two towers" and "return of the King" midnight when they were both released. Jackson restored himself and became one of my favorite directions from then on.

Andrew just needs some time to warm up. Once he makes the next movie, people will take back all of the bad things they've said about the first one. Even me. So I am giving him the benefit of the doubt. At least he included all of the characters. And Aslan was great! I cried when they killed him on the stone table. It was a powerful and memorable scene. Overall, I give this movie ten stars. It wasn't perfect, but it was enough to rekindle the hope of Narnia fans everywhere that there beloved book series would be produced with the care they deserve. So because of this, the series had my support and Andrew has my complete faith. Well done Andrew. Can't wait to see the next one. Keep up the good work and thank you for restoring my hope in cinema.

P.S. If you think this version in bad, you ought to see the original BBC version. The beavers are people in furry suits...with painted faces. This is a MAJOR step up from that. So appreciate the artistic quality of this film and stop griping. If your fans, support the cause! And that's all I have to say.

title: Good movie, needs better lighting
review: This is a really good movie. However, a lot of it occurs at night. There is almost 30 minutes where the screen is either entirely black or only has one or two reflected images on it. It was really hard to tell what was going on at these times. This is unfortunate, as the rest of the movie was really good. The scenes, especially the battle scenes, were almost too clean. There was no dirt on anyone, even in the middle of battle. Also no blood. Of course, the movie is aimed at kids, so this is sorta expected. The special effects for the various creatures were very well done, though. It's a very good family movie, but should also be good for normal viewing.

title: Perfect but Shallow
review:
This movie contains everything I like since my childhood. The Music is excellent, the effects great and fantasy rules the world. Still: "Narnia" stays soulless and shallow. Don't ask me why. It just didn't get me. The Characters are poorly developed, Kids who fight like heroes without even touching a sword before? Come On! Okay,usually stuff like that does not disturb me in other movies. Why here? I seriously don't know. I tried to like it so bad! For 2 1/2 Hours or so I really tried to convince myself that it has everything I love. It didn't work out! Is it because I'm 40? Well, there is more childish stuff that I really love and the last Harry Potter? Was Great! As was "The Lord of the Rings", which you can not really compare to "The Chronicles"...

Maybe I try to watch it again around Christmas-Time. But actually I don't think that it would change anything. Btw.: I love the Winter-Landscape...the evil White Which...well, she was good for the first time, then Swanton used the same facial expression all the time. Just the costumes changed. Lovely was the little Girl, she brought a little life-spark with her acting into this perfect but cold fantasy-world. And the Christian Message? Okay, I could live with that because as much as Christianity was present, there was symbolism and thinking of "the old pagan path". I liked that ;-) Much said and then nothing with this review. Its probably like the movie itself. So much going on with so less emotions. But as I said before: I promise! I will watch it again, and maybe...just maybe...I like it better then. I will try ;-)

PS: Maybe it will be like Harry Potter: getting better with every sequel

title: Great children's movie, also appealing to adults!
review:
Some months ago, there were Narnia commercials everywhere, I remember taking my kids to McDonalds, they went crazy because McDonalds was selling Narnia toys.

Every time the name Narnia was mentioned on TV or we passed another poster of it, they both begged me to let them see it. I got tired of it and eventually let them see the movie.

It was surprisingly well done and the story was well adapted to the screen. It wasn't just a great movie for children, but for adults as well.

The actors were good. The casting was great. The sets were wonderful. It was a great adventure on screen.

It's worth spending your time and money on.

title: Narnia is Amazing
review:
This film is an excellent adaptation of C.S. Lewis's series, The Chronicles of Narnia. The film is attractive to young and old, those interested in good plot/drama or amazing special effects(fantastic battle sequences may I add)and for those just wondering what movie they'd like to see (or rent since it is coming on DVD tomorrow) this weekend. I loved the fact that I did not know any of the actors/actresses involved in the movie (except for Liam Neeson who is the voice of aslan). If I don't know the actor, it helps me concentrate on their performance given, and that it is something fresh to watch. The children who played the 4 Pevensie children did an outstanding job. Those who love the books wild have no complaints about the adaptation (if you do, i'm sorry). If you liked the 3 Lord of the Rings films (which I absolutely love) but dread sitting in your living room for three or more hours, NO Fear, this movie is only approximately 2 hours and goes by at a very good pace. This movie will hopefully solidify itself as one of the best fantasy films of all time. I hope they make the sequel just as well.

If you have seen this movie and enjoyed it, here are some of my recommendations: KING KONG, Indiana Jones Trilogy, The Lord of the Rings Trilogy, Star Wars Saga, Pirates of the Caribbean

I also recommend that you read the books which are fabulous.

title: Excellent! C.S. Lewis has a wonderful imagination!
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe/2005/****

Main Stars: Georgie Henley Skandar Keynes William Moseley Anna Popplewell Tilda Swinton Liam Neeson

Being a big budget film, the makers of the film sure put a lot of effort into this. I respect them for putting a lot of effort in and I loved the film! It was worth the money definitely! From the very beginning to the very end were non-stop, well-acted great thrills, some humor (love it), creepy moments, dramatic moments, great music, and perfect storyline! I respect C.S. Lewis's imagination for creating the wonderful fantasy world of Narnia consisting of a witch (Tilda Swinton), and a lion (Liam Neeson). Then there is Mr. Tumnus (being one of the mystical creatures), and a few beavers, wolves and other creatures/animals that can actually talk. The witch pretty much symbolizes Satan and the lion symbolizes Jesus Christ. This did seem to remind me of "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy a bit (which I refuse to review) because of the battles of good versus evil (Gandalf versus Saruman from "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring"). Now, in this film, hide and seek is a main thing because that's what starts it all. When their mother sends them far away from home after a catastrophic bombing attack, the four kids are sent to an enormous home. The home houses the four of them, a professor (who owns the place), and a housekeeper of some sort. The four of them are extremely bored and decide to play hide and seek and that's what starts it all. The little one of the four, Lucy Pevensie (Georgie Henley), is a curious child and finds the world of Narnia by herself while searching for a hiding place. Her two brothers, Edmund (Skandar Keynes) and Peter (William Moseley), don't believe in her and her fussy, annoying, picky older sister Susan (Anna Popplewell) doesn't believe in her either. The three of them apologize to Lucy in an unconvincing way of course after they discover the wonderful world of Narnia too. There was one really well done battle scene in this film consisting of Aslan (the lion, voice by Liam Neeson) and the satanic witch. What was good about the battle was the music, special effects, and the acting. This battle was extremely long though but very, very entertaining! The whole movie was entertaining! Being all British actors (minus maybe a few), I could understand what they were saying for once. But I've seen many British films so I'm used to their foreign way of speaking. This film is a remake of a televised production called "The Lion, the Witch, & the Wardrobe" and had the same story based on C.S. Lewis's famous novel. I think they should continue the C.S. Lewis "The Chronicles of Narnia" series until they have turned all seven books into seven films but who knows if they'll keep making the series. It depends on if they get enough money (I don't doubt it) from this one. And if they do continue making the series, how long will it take? Movie directed by Andrew Adamson.

title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen
review: I saw this with high expectations. The films commercials where more entertaining than the movie itself.That is probably the first time a movies trailers are more exciting than the movie itself. I found myself dozing off after 20 or so minutes of the movie. I roughed it out and saw the whole thing but it was still horrible. Don't see it buy it, unless you're having trouble sleeping. If your parents looking for another harry potter or another lord of the rings, this isn't the movie for you. Even then don't waste your money on buying it. The books are a better form of entertainment then the movie. Go buy the book instead. Hopefully the next installment of the series will turn out better.

title: "Much ado about nothing"
review: The film had nice graphics, good voice-character presentation but somehow could not keep up with the expectations it gradually built in the viewer's mind. Some correlation/connection was expected with the real world, their mother, the ongoing war, the professor and the warden they were living with..something somehow was amiss in the story, which I believe was a very big drawback of the movie, which could have succeeded given the talents that have gone in. Everybody's question when we came out of the theater was "what is the big deal about the witch, lion and wardrobe?" A big hype was created with nothing to substantiate.

title: Computer graphics aren't spectacular, but it is true to the book
review:
The Chroncles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe

The great series written by C.S. Lewis were momentous occasions to a first time reader. Anyone could let their imagination run wild to create Aslan, the great lion and King of Narnia, or the humble Mr. and Mrs. Beaver. The movie, however, lays it all out straight for you, and it doesn't do a good job. The visual effects look incredibly fake at times, but, all that aside, it is a movie you should take your kids to.

Mr. Tumnus' character is one of the few I think was depicted perfectly. He is the first Naninian Lucy sees, and they both shriek in fright when they see each other. Aslan, however, fails to emit the great amount of power which the character possesses. The lion looks like what he really is: computer generated.

The screenplay is well written and doesn't leave gaping holes in the plot, nor does it cut out small details to leave room for the big picture (unlike the enormous Harry Potter novels, C.S. Lewis' tales were only about 200 pages long). The movie does have a sense of reality mixed in with all of its fantasy, which makes the length of 2 and ½ hours easy to sit through for most.

When you are watching, a word of caution: do not stop as soon as the credits roll, the movie isn't over yet. There is a short scene between the Proffesur and Lucy that you wouldn't want to miss.

title: Flawed Kid's Movie
review: 'The Chronicles of Narnia' tells a rather straightforward fairy tale about a hidden magical land, where a group of children from war-ridden London experience a series of adventures. The story is very simple and should be very easy to follow for even smaller children. Older kids and adults might be easily bored by the overlong movie, however. Director Adamson, who previously made the rather entertaining Shrek movie, does a reasonable job making engaging CGI creatures, but does not really get adequate performances out of the child actors. He directs without much flair and his style is visually underwhelming. The editing also leaves a lot to be desired, pacing often slow and some scenes are awkwardly put together. The whole film has a rushed and unpolished feel to it as if made on a tight schedule. The CGI is not the best, but certainly adequate for this type of movie. Finally, the much talked about Christian aspects of 'Narnia' do feel a little clumsy, but they should not distract/offend people who do not like overtly religious topics in movies. I rate this film 3/10, the kids liked it slightly better but were also quite glad when it finally was over.

title: Stunning Movie!
review: I can't even begin to describe the feeling I got when I was sitting in my movie theater seat, and I saw the Walden logo go across the screen. From the first picture that you see, you just know that you're about to be taken on a magical journey. I went to a midnight screening, and the place was packed. We barely got a seat. I've seen the movie 4 times, and I noticed something new every time. It was just a great movie. The visual effects are great, and all of the actors do a wonderful job of portraying their characters just like I imagined them while reading the book. If you haven't already seen it, by it on DVD and I promise you won't be disappointed. I know I wasn't!

title: One of the movies you must see.
review:
I cannot stress enough how much this movie is great. I went to the movie theater expecting a kid's movie with a simple plot, childish, one-dimensional characters and a cheesy ending...

My expectations were not even close to the actual standard that this movie proudly declares.

The visual effects are breathtaking; it makes Aslan seem as a true character of the movie and not like a computerized comptraption.

The timing is just right. not too slow nor fast; one can say that it was almost real-time.

Adamson has lived up to his SHREK fame as he directed this masterful masterpiece of English Literature; he did not watered down the intention, the feelings, the emotion, the dimentionality of the characters,etc. It is about 99.99% exact to the way C.S. Lewis imagined it as he placed it on paper.

For Christians, it is a movie that will treasure dearly; a movie that gives meaning to calling Jesus by the title "His Majesty".

In short, everyone must see this movie; as it is a novel that creates the fiction world of Narnia...and transports you there.

title: Chronicle of Narnia
review:
The way the whole movie was done graphically was just really brilliant. How the setting and the animals were brought to life. The four characters Lucy, Edmund, Peter and Susan were really into their characters. Especially Susan, I thought that she did a brilliant job. Though, she was the youngest her character to me was the strongest and she really moved me. The second character that really touched my heart was the lion. In most movies and novels the Lion is portrayed as a bad guy or like a arrogant animal but in the movie it was portrayed as a loving and gentle animal. I was really nice. I recommend this movie for all ages. I think this movie brings out the child in you and wants you to believe that their is a mystical land where there is magic. The scenery was great, characters were adorable and the plot was remarkable.

I recommend this movie to all ages young and old!

title: CoN: The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe
review: This is the best movie since LoTR! Everyone, stop right now and go see it! (Spoiler) It's about four children, evacuated from London during the Blitz to live at the home of a professor. The smallest, while playing hide and seek, hides in a wardrobe. There, she discovers that it is the door to a world called Narnia, and thus begins the adventure. Weta does the SE's, and they always do good. I've never been a fan of A. A., but this movie certainly is good. The actors and actresses are great! The snow looks real. The battle is awesome! Everything is flawless. This picture won for makeup and it deserves more! The costumes are realistic and the props are REAL!

title: NARNIA : Great Children's Epic That Embraces The Original Book's Depth & Ambition...
review:
CHRONICLES OF NARNIA : THE LION, THE WITCH, & THE WARDROBE

Back when NARNIA first came out at the beginning of the winter I saw it in the theater and was underwhelmed. I labeled it LOTR:LIGHT for a long time and was always bitter over the fact that NARNIA was beating my beloved KING KONG at the box office. If I remember correctly, I stated the film was good... but not remarkable... with slightly hollow special effects and performances (except for Tilda Swinton) and I gave the film an indifferent grade of B.

However, I put in a bootleg DVD yesterday to watch it with some friends who hadn't seen it and I realized I was unfairly rough on what is actually a very well produced children's epic.

On first viewing, I don't think I appreciated all the undertones featured in some of the performances, particularly James McAvoy as Mr. Tumnus. I found his performance to be empty but that's because I didn't realize the darker shadings of his character that McAvoy uses from the very start. I still find the child stars to be slightly underwhelming at parts... but it's unfair to expect such young children to carry a film of this size on their shoulders flawlessly. And Tilda Swinton is still incredible.

Upon second viewing, I realized the film seems slightly slower with less flashy special effects b/c in the end it doesn't need them in the same way KING KONG and LOTR did. The film emphasizes the tension of oncoming doom more so then actual confrontation and battle. I got a grander sense of the Pevensie children's destiny and found the film to be all the more engrossing because of that.

Overall, I found the film to be highly entertaining and creatively brought to life... though still not remarkable (KING KONG and LOTR are still vastly superior films). This time around I didn't notice as many flaws in NARNIA. Instead I sat back and enjoyed it for what it was... a different movie aimed at an entirely different audience.

It is disappointing to me that my beloved KING KONG was defeated at the Box Office by this, but even so NARNIA is one of the better "big-budget franchise films" to come out in a long time... and so it shouldn't be faulted simply b/c it beat my favorite movie at the box office. I am definitely anxious to see CHRONICLES OF NARNIA : PRINCE CASPIAN and seeing where this franchise grows.

Upon first viewing I gave the film an indifferent B... but upon second viewing, I gave the film a much more enthusiastic:

... B+ ...

title: My fears were unjustified
review:
Let me tell you some of the fears that I had concerning this movie before watching it. Firstly, it would undo all the great work that Lord of the Rings had done for the fantasy genre. I felt that this would be a hit and run attempt to cash in on the recent interest in fantasy based movies. Secondly, it would be too childish and lack interest for adults. Thirdly, having seen the children in trailers I was convinced that I was going to find the children annoying and would want to give them a good slap.

I can tell you that my fears were totally unjustified. The film took me back to my childhood,wishing for a magical adventure with an opportunity to show my valour and courage. This was no mere attempt to cash in on the work of the Lord of the Rings. This film was thoughtfully made and an extremely faithful adaptation of the book.

The film was enchanting and made excellent family viewing. Although the interest for children is obvious,I believe that the film had enough going for it to interest adults as well.
