The scenery and the characters are very interesting and cool you would think that you are there with them. Overall this movie is awesome, interesting, exciting and pulls you in a lot. I would give this movie an A+.

This movie is the greatest!! You've got to see it or you are crazy. Although it isn't completely the same as the book, it's still awesome. There are some things that are different from the book which makes the movie a whole lot better. There is also a PS2 game that goes with it and it is extremely similar to the book and the movie. Everyone in the movie was very with there character, for example the White Witch didn't smile once and Edmund (the youngest boy) was a good lair. Either than that, the movie was fantastic! So if you haven't seen it you have to see it, unless you aren't into action and some fantasy, movies.

title: Nz All The Way
review:
Cool movie, better than the TV series. New Zealand director too good. New Zealands on a role rite now with this and King Kong.

Academy awards get ready.......... Stuff golden globes. Nah they just chose the wrong movies to get the awards.

Everything was good especially the war. The beavers were cool and the faun. But the character i didn't like was.............EDMUND!!!!

Anyway Andrew Adamson did a great job on it, actors as well. The graphics were alright and the music was good. The view of New Zealand was awesome ,if it was New Zealand. Anyway this movie was the best movie I've seen this year. New Zealand too good. Well i guess you know New Zealand is getting more powerful in the movie business.

And this is just the BEGINNING.

title: This was one of the best movies I've ever seen!
review:
I loved this movie. The Chronicles of Narnia have always been my favorite books, and my little brother got the whole series on CD for his birthday last year. We have always enjoyed sitting down and reading the books together, so watching the movie was so much fun! Again, my little brother asked long and hard to see the movie, and he finally saw it the day after Christmas, 2005. We all loved it, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for something for all the family.

I personally was worried that the movies wouldn't hold true to the books and my imagination, but this was the best movie to go with an imagination! C.S. Lewis did a good job of describing things, and Andrew Adamson did a good job of portraying those descriptions. Awesome job, everyone!

title: Crossroads of the Fantasy and Spiritual Worlds
review: "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is based on the famed fantasy novel by C.S. Lewis. It's a story much in the vein of J.R.R. Tolkien's "Lord of the Rings" trilogy. In this story, the four Pevensie children must leave wartime London as the Germans attack, for the safety of a country house. There, they encounter a magical wardrobe that leads them to a land inhabited by talking animals and legendary creatures. The good leader is the divine lion, Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson), who must battle Jadis, the White Witch (played by Tilda Swinton). The story is fascinating, even with the underlying Christian message. The visuals are amazing and eye-catching. In the end, you'll eagerly await more of Narnia's lore.

title: A very simple fantasy story made into a very simple movie with spectacular results
review:
The box office record of USA does make sense when comparing the Narnia movie to King Kong. Although the latter is a better movie in my book, there are a sizeable few who didn't like it. But Narnia is a movie that everyone can like & enjoy - from Kids to Parents, Guys & Girls.

The movie starts off with an introduction of the Pevensie children in the middle of an Air Raid during World War II. Promptly, their mom packs them away to the country house of an Elderly uncle where soon they discover a wardrobe that opens into the Magical Land of Narnia. A once peaceful and serene land of talking beasts is now taken over by the Evil Witch Jadis, plummeting the world into a perpetual winter. The children are there as a part of a prophecy that the witch would be defeated, and warmth will shine on Narnia again.

Adam Anderson successfully makes a movie that, unlike the Harry Potter series, never tries too hard to be grand. And for the same reason it becomes a wonderfully grand piece. Here is again a director who really knows his subject well, and you can sense his understanding of the world from the creative liberty he takes with the story. The extended opening scene, the prep & actual battle are not in the book at all. Yet he unfolds it like it were from the mind of C S Lewis himself. He also presents the movie from a beautiful eye, which more than helps to make this a lock for the home-video market. Although the CGI of the movie is at its best it is not unlike the best that we have already seen. That makes it less noticeable and more awe-worthy. This combined with good voice-work, the talking animals come across with all authenticity and no corniness. The children themselves do a good job of acting in the company of these imaginary creatures, with the best turn coming from the second youngest: Edmund, mainly because of the dilemma he faces.

At the end, it all works because it is a very simple fantasy story made into a very simple movie with spectacular results.

My Rating ---> 4/5

title: Entertaining and generally worth the watch
review:
Having not read the book, I cannot comment on how true to it this motion picture version is. Being that The Chronicles Of Narnia are regarded as literature classics much in the same esteem as The Lord Of The Rings and such like, I would estimate that there have been some changes to the narrative as it didn't grip me as much as The Lord Of The Rings did and thus as much as I was expecting.

With regards to this, I found how Edmund's initial betrayal of his brothers and sisters a little inconceivable. I was expecting it to transpire that he was brain washed or under some spell from the Witch. Alas in the film, this wasn't the case and the motives for his treachery weren't revealed, save from the fact that he was picked on by his brothers and sisters and the promise of Turkish Delights.

Many of the interactive dialogue sequences between the 4 children became noticeably unnatural on several occasions. Party aided by some slightly wooden acting, if I may be so bold as to suggest. If these lines are true to the book, it would seem that C.S. Lewis didn't have a knack for inventing natural interaction of siblings. But that is perhaps for me to find out should I ever read the book from which this film is based.

How 4 children can blossom into swash buckling heroes, willing to lay down their lives and become rulers of a land they know little about, disregarding their home world and origins in the space of a few days (as the time line is not established) was also a little difficult to comprehend, even in a fantasy setting.

But none the less, I am not going to harp on about the things that a feel were bad about this film as the vast majority of it was excellent. It is very entertaining boasting fantastic performances from Tilda Swinton portraying the Evil White Witch and Georgie Henley as a very adorable Lucy. The video and audio effects are incredible and the battle scene is very intense and reminiscent of the Pelennor fields battle from The Return Of The King though no way as gruesome.

I enjoyed it very much and recommend it for anyone that has a pallet for fantasy movies and stories.

title: Great but it didn't move me
review: Having read the book, made a Mr Tumnus' house collage at school and watched the BBC series I was looking forward to this movie a lot. I must say, and I apologize if Sophie Wilcox reads this, that the Lucy in this film is a lot better looking than the girl in the BBC version - no buck teeth and bowl cut for a start. The whole movie was very beautiful, the effects, scenery and costumes were great. However, despite all of its great attributes, I didn't emotionally connect with this film as much as I thought I would. Aslan's death was rather scary, and sad, yet it did not cry. I am not sure if it was because, subconsciously I knew he would rise again or not. I'd like to think that is the case. The White Witch was a departure from the usual "snow queen" image. While she did have an icy crown of sorts she wasn't swathed in furs and, for once, did not have dark hair. She had blond dreadlocks and dead looking eyes. Very effective. Mr Tumnus was younger than I usually pictured him but still very cool. He wasn't as treacherous as I remembered either, though it has been more than 10 years since I read/saw Narnia last. Edmund was a little weasel and the boy who played him - Skyander Keynes (interesting name) did a great job. The beavers added some comedy and were very well animated. I thought through the whole movie that Aslan was voiced by Patrick "And-I've-seen-everything" Stewart, but it was Liam Neeson instead. I am not sure why I don't rate this film higher, I can't think of anything wrong with it, I just didn't come away thinking it was spectacular. A great film though, one that will no doubt spur on a revival of C.S Lewis' works.

title: Good fairy tale
review:
This movie is a good fairy tale. I saw it in the cinema yesterday and probably because of that found some of the nature scenes very impressive. Honestly there weren't as much good special effects as I expected, but the play of the actors compensates for that. As far as I remember the TV version I saw few years ago was at least as good as that new version, trough the beginning of The Chronicles of Narnia was interesting.

Before watching the movie I have heard some comments that the plot unfolds too slowly, but I did not notice such a thing while watching. There was some humor in the dialogs, but aside of that they weren't really that good.

title: Excellent Start
review:
Ignore the critiques who want to dis this movie with their technical complaints...I challenge the technical critiques to show me just one movie that failed at the box office...but could have succeeded if it was more technically adept...Cause it ain't the techniques...it's the story. Why the big movie company's waited so long to bring a story to the big screen that has been a proved winner for decades...who can tell....In the mean time...200+ million dollars and counting in the US alone...I'd say this movie is a hit...and just think, we got six more to go...all of which in my opinion, except The Prince and His Chair is as good a story or better than this one.

Lucy is the best child actress I've ever seen...She just stole the show...She has a sophistication and genuineness I have never seen in a child actress...and I've been watching since Shirley Temple's rerun's in the early 60's.

I had never like Mr. Tumnus' character...but this fellow really brought him alive and gave him a very charming and mischievous personality.

This movie kept my attention and could have been longer to develop the characters more...Susan started to grow on me...but Peter and Edmund didn't capture my heart.

I loved Susan's line, "He's a Beava, he shouldn't be talking." I was disappointed by the witch...Her appearance didn't match her description in The Magician's Nephew. In my opinion, she was neither a woman who the audience would look at and say, "this is the most beautiful woman I've ever seen"...but then was also wicked beyond description.

The great part of this movie is that I don't have to worry about my son watching this flick. The battle scene kept my attention and was most suitable for children and old men like me who don't like the gratuitous blood and gore.

I am looking forward to seeing The Boy And His Horse...And now that Hollywood has discovered CS Lewis, maybe it won't be long before we see a rendition of his Space Trilogy as well. Of course, it will take a excellent writing effort to script those.

title: A touched story...
review:
It is a well adapted movie from the fantasy novel. One day, the Nania story would be shown on the big screen. I always knew that. Though it's not quite the four children in my mind, I saw another cutie Lucy, rigid Susan, brave Peter and the most lovely of all, the veritable Edmund! Besides them I totally attracted by the poor and gentle Faun and the cool White Witch! Two great actors! Tilda, ahhh, I always considered her the most beautiful woman in the world, just like a Hellenistic goddess come out from a Greek myth book. The adaption of the four growing up children in Nania one day finding the way back to the wardrobe is a great gleam of imagination. It is this part that show the power of magical film. With worming and grumbling in the forest and then the fur coats, young peoples turn back to the childhood. When the door opened again after so many years they fall off the wardrobe and find themselves are still the four little kids evading the tough housekeeper...

Hope you enjoying it... At last the Prof. give us more space for imagining the history of this wardrobe and the story of himself, the eccentric old man...

title: A sweet and faithful adaptation
review: I've not read the Narnia books since early adulthood (over a quarter-century ago), but this adaptation has inspired me to do so. The young actors are superb, and the cinematography seamless and sound. I sincerely hope they continue to be faithful to Lewis' incomparable stories. Oh ... and LOTR fans should, of course, refuse to make comparisons. Lewis and Tolkein, though friends, wrote from very different points of view and with very different audiences and intentions. Other than the facts that both stories are fantasies, and both deal with (on some level or another) Christian themes, there is little to compare. Rather, the Narnia books and the LOTR stories are wondrous bookends to the vast field of allegorical fantasy. Enjoy each for what they are. I'm looking forward to the next installment of Narnia, and (hopefully) Peter Jackson will soon turn to making "The Hobbit."

title: Wow!!!!!!!!
review:
Yes, this is a movie!!! The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe was nothing like I expected. I thought I would be falling asleep, but no. More or less, I was on the tip of my seat, eyes stuck on the screen. This wicked movie is about an innocent hide-and-seek game led to a hiding spot that Lucy Pevensie (Georgie Henley) least expected. A new world, full of wonder and magic. Full of friends, happiness, and an evil witch, these four children didn't expect what was coming next. For what would soon happen would not only shock these four children, but so will it shock the audience.

This movie was based on the C.S. Lewis novel, and also a remake of a previous The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. This family movie should be the next movie on your list to see.

title: Oscars Anyone?
review:
I loved the film! Although the screen version didn't follow the book as closely as I would have liked, I understand why the changes were made and enjoyed the new plot twists.

I have heard a rumor that Georgie Henley (Lucy) is being promoted for an Academy Award nomination. Has anyone else heard that? I hope she does at least get nominated! She was my favorite character! If she was nominated and/or won an Oscar, would she become the youngest actress to receive that kind of recognition? (I do not know very much about the history of the awards).

I have also heard that an extended edition of the film will be produced by the same people who worked on the LOTR Special Extended Editions. I can't wait to see the extra scenes they chose to include because it may follow the book more closely. The extended edition may also clear up any plot holes that may have been created from the cutting of scenes for the shortened screen version.

title: Lewis Will be more than Proud
review:
Although there is a particular draw to the Narnia adventures because of the long and extensive fan-base, it would be a lie to say that is the only reason why the film has done as well as it has. Non-readers will enjoy the film just as much as the loyal readers, if not more (simply for the lack of knowledge concerning the plot) because of the intense care that Disney took to stay loyal to Lewis' vision.

We begin in a time of war in England where siblings Lucy, Edmund, Susan, and Peter take off to the country to live with a mysterious professor they have no past relationship with. With a small dose of curiosity from the youngest of the four, and a little faith from the rest, we are thrown into a well-interpreted, wonderfully-performed, adventure with a family of youngsters just trying to keep their family together.

The battle sequences were gripping and action-packed and the tender moments brought tears. The wonderful evil White Witch (Tilda Swinton) makes us want to throw our popcorn at the screen in fury and the wise and mysterious Aslan brought the audience to tears and applause. Once again, Disney has shown they can make more than just kid movies with viewers anywhere from three to late sixties. The particularly charming Mr. Tumnus (James McAvoy) was a breath of fresh air and a beloved character audiences welcomed with open arms.

All in all, wonderfully interpreted and made. Beautiful performances by the four children as well as the White Whitch. Rally points go out to the cinematography team as well as the CG animators. Most touching and authentic, leaving audiences teary-eyed and breathless.

title: What I Think
review:
This is my #1 favorite movie of all time. It had a good story, a good plot, and good actors =). William, Skandar, Anna, Georgie, Liam, and Tilda, you're all good actors and William I find you hot =P sorry but it's true. The other cast and crew you guys are great too. Family channel was right to interview A lot of you. The movie was just amazing, the wolves, the war, Father Christmas, when Aslan dies and comes back to life and so many more good scenes. Just the entire movie was great. I love it I give it a 10, 10 gold stars, the blue ribbon, whatever you want to call it you get perfect.

Congradgulations on a great movie. From: Natalie Allaire.

title: a beautifully made movie that's worth seeing
review: It's a movie that's wonderfully made. All the acting is great. I was impressed by the children, Tilda is superb, and the various animal/creature voices are a perfect match. The special effects are well done, with a few exceptions. The cinematography is beautiful. The story sticks close to the book. The music supports the movie well, although it's not very memorable. My only complaint is that I watched the film without much emotion, which surprised me since it's one of my favorite books from childhood. I can't pinpoint the reason why, maybe I know the story too well. But nevertheless it's very enjoyable and worth seeing, I've already seen it twice, and I'm planning to see it again.

title: Narnia = Amazing
review:
Looking for fantasy but not something too digitalized? Although Narnia does use a lot of special effects (I'd guess), they only add to the adventure.

If you go into the theater sort of skeptical, like I was, you'll probably get totally owned by this movie. Even for people who haven't read the books, or maybe haven't ever heard of it before, it's something to get excited about. For me, it was one of those movies you can't stop thinking about after you see it. The the set was done and how the actors were dressed really made this whole other world, and I spent most of the time in awe.

Basically, if you're pretty open-minded you'll most likely find something you love about this movie. It's fun to pretend for a couple hours that all these creatures and places could exist, to really get into the journey the kids go on. I thought this movie was going to be kind of childish, but it was so much more that I expected. From what I've heard, the books are just as great, or even better.

title: ...pretty good film....
review:
Chronicles of Narnia is pretty good film. It does seems to loosen up a bit in the second act, but overall the tale and its execution does manage, at times, to amaze. All the kids played their parts well, and I especially liked the performance that James McAvoy gave as the faun; one can tell that he is an exceptional stage actor immediately.

The only other faults that I found with the film were that the editing could have been more generous at times, holding on a shot or two for an extra beat here and there to further the effect of the image and the pacing. And the backgrounds, especially toward the end of the film, all have strange saturation with odd artificial hues. I don't know if this is usually done with the theory of making it more appealing to kids, but my eyes didn't like it. They were either over saturated with the wrong values, or were the wrong mixtures of reds, blues and greens.

In light of excellence, one has to consider a few other things. Like why didn't the battle climax scene, which was pretty good, elevate the film to the level of true spectacle? And as another reviewer wrote, as soon as the prophesy of the destiny of the children becomes known, they loose any sense of self-determination and events happen to them not because of them. There are answers to these questions, but perhaps they demand a larger forum than a capsule review. Suffice is to say, I think, that the film holds together despite these imperfections, and, as a third reviewer wrote, "Bring on Prince Caspian."

title: Enchanting Tale for the Ages!
review:
I loved The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe. It was enchanting to see great CGI effects on the fantasy aspects of the movie: the mythical creatures, palaces, etc.

The cast makes this a great epic. Set in War Time Great Britain, four children are sent to live with a perfect stranger and unveil the wardrobe that leads them into a land of mystery and oddities. They face a choice between what is easy and what is right. You'll be surprised how it plays out from character to character.

I believe it is great for all ages and hopefully we will see the rest of series made into movies...the books to the screen share the true image of C.S. Lewis's masterpiece that is The Chronicles of Narnia!

title: Well worth it
review:
My sister and I have been waiting for a movie that could do this story justice for some time. As kids, we used to watch a cartoon version that was bland and pretty much boring. My mom taped a real life version off of TV that was a lot more entertaining than the cartoon and we watched that one instead for a while. We recently rewatched it, and I realized that most of the magical creatures (except Aslan, the fauns, and the centaurs) were added in with animation- really bad 2D animation- which pretty much ruined it for me. So I knew that any version that came out now would have to be convincing in its special effects or face my wrath on the IMDb voting polls.

Then this came out. And I knew I didn't have to worry.

Every creature looks real. Even if you can tell it's CGI, it's brilliant CGI and lets you sink into the world of Narnia without worrying about the fact that it's a movie. I was particularly worried about the Beavers, because in the TV version they were played by people in beaver costumes, and I don't care how young you are, you know they're people in beaver costumes. However, the beavers in this are wonderfully played by computer animation, made to look very real while still enabling them to talk, and given some of the best lines in the movie. Aslan, who I wasn't really worried about because they just HAD to get Aslan right, is a great piece of art and his eyes are as expressive as any human's. Liam Neeson is charming and soothing as his voice, completing the picture. The evil creatures are just as convincing as the good, if not as nice-looking. The landscapes are just as incredible as the magical animals, and it's no surprise that the same effects team that worked on Lord of the Rings did this movie too.

The movie's effects aren't the only good thing about it either, thankfully. The screenplay stays true to the book for the most part, throwing in a couple of extra scenes that seem unneeded but provide for some good action and a backstory for the Pevensie family. The movie starts out with an effective air raid scene that is not in the book, and at first I was kind of annoyed, but as the movie progressed I realized that it was necessary, in a way, not to the story but to the movie. In the scene, Mrs. Pevensie is ushering her children to the bomb shelter when Edmund (Skandar Keynes) suddenly runs back to save a picture of his father, who is fighting in World War II. Peter (William Moseley) tries to stop him and when he brings him back to the bomb shelter he yells, "Why can't you just do what your told?" Peter asks him the same thing again when Edmund is hurt trying to save Peter's life near the end.

The cast probably was the most risky part of this movie for its director, Andrew Adamson. Finding convincing child actors who are capable of doing a dramatic film like this one yet actually look their age is tough in this day and age where children are usually the stars of bad screwball comedies. However, the four leads are definitely capable, especially Georgie Henley, who plays Lucy, and Keynes. Both of them are able to show a wide range of emotions, often in the same scene, and Keynes makes the transformation that Edmund goes through after being rescued from the queen perfectly evident through his wonderfully expressive face. Tilda Swinton was not the queen I was expecting after the TV version, but she grew on me, and by the end I had forgotten she was an actress and was riveted in the queen's evilness.

This movie is worth the money if only for the effects, but luckily, your money is spent on a good cast and worthy screenplay. I don't think this will be up for any Oscars other than Best Visual Effects, but if it's up for Best Picture, I'll certainly be cheering it on.

title: OK. Ruined by unnecessary deviation from the storyline
review:
Generally I though the film was very good for telling the story, and captured the spirit of the book pretty well. Having grown up reading the books and watching the cartoon, I got to know the story pretty well, without ever noticing any of the religious allegory, so this aspect of the film didn't bother me, but one thing did.

*Spoiler here* My favourite part of this story was always leaving the Beavers home, hoping that they could reach the secret Beaver hide out before the wolves caught up with them. This part of the book had more suspense than any other, sneaking around in the dark, hoping they don't get caught. Why the director/script writer chose to mutilate this part of the story is beyond me. Whether they were trying to make this part a little more their own, like their signature, I don't know, but I felt this ruined the film. I hate when script writers do this.

title: Chronicles of Narnia
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe By: Tanner Phillips

The Nazi Blitzkrieg rages over London and the Pevensie children  Lucy (Georgie Henley), Edmund (Skandar Keynes), Peter (William Moseley) and Susan (Anna Popplewell)  like many, are being shipped to the country for safety. The kids arrive at the manor of solitary Professor Kirk (Jim Broadbent), an old bachelor under the attentive care of his housekeeper, Mrs. MacReady (Elizabeth Hawthorne). Bad weather keeps the children inside, bored, and Lucy convinces her older brothers and sister to play a game of hide and seek. She finds a near empty room with an old wardrobe at one end and decides to hide there. This begins the magic of "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"

I was excited to see this movie from the time I saw the preview about 4 months ago. I was literally giddy every time I thought about it. I had the ultimate expectations for this film and couldn't believe I had to wait such a long time to finally see it. I had seen the old cartoon about 100 times and remember loving it very much. I have never read the books but I figured the cartoon movie would suffice.

I think that might be why I was a bit let down as the end credits rolled past. I had expected so much and I felt as though I had been a little bit misled. The previews made the movie look fantastic, but the end product made the movie simply mediocre. I am not saying I didn't enjoy the movie at all. I enjoyed it very much. I thought it was cleverly done with some very good CGI, and some brilliantly mastered makeup/costume design. The same makeup artists that did Lord of the Rings were called in for this extravagant feature film. The hefty production cost just didn't seem to go that far for such a film. I thought to myself that they must have spent a lot less on this movie than they did on LOTR. However, I was surprised to find out that they in fact spent more on this production than they did on LOTR. I could be mistaken, and please feel free to correct me if that is not correct. It just didn't seem that way. As much time as they spent on building up to the story, I felt like they still didn't do an excellent job of actually building the character audience relationship. I wasn't connected to the characters as you usually can become with movies such as this. I think this is not the case however with all the characters. For example the beavers that help the Pevensies are an absolute hoot throughout the movie. You are instantly connected to them, and you love them from moment one. Mrs. Beaver is always concerned with how she looks, as her husband complains about her cooking while giving her compliments and expressions of love and affection. I think the beavers were excellently done, and a huge part in the enjoyment I felt while watching the movie.

Another one of my favorite parts of the movie were the Christian symbolisms that were so clearly included. I have always considered C.S. Lewis to be one of the greatest Christian authors that has ever lived. He was a brilliant man with a creative mind full of ideas and spirituality for all to partake of. It is not hard to catch the symbolisms all over the place in the movie, and I love that. It goes far beyond having Aslan the great Lion come back to life in an obvious symbolism of resurrection. It goes as far as small comments made throughout the entire movie. Such as, "Why won't you just do as you're told?" and "What has happened is in the past." I enjoyed this side of the movie very much and I wish there were more movies like it. I thought that the symbolisms in this movie were far more apparent than in Lord of The Rings. I'm glad that the director was true to the books of C.S. Lewis and was able to honor his symbolic idea's that lye within his own little world of Narnia.

All in all, I thought the movie was well worth my time and money. I am critical yes, only because that's my job to be. However, if you were to ask me if I liked Narnia, I would say "Yes, I liked it." I don't know that I can say I loved it though. Who says we have to love every movie anyway? I would even see this movie again. It was great, and I think everyone should see it, regardless of the shortcomings that it might have. Because all in all, they aren't large enough to draw away from the fact that if anything, it will entertain you for a few hours. It might even touch your spiritual senses a bit. See it.

Author is an official Critic for: Myspace Movie Fiends @ http://groups.myspace.com/moviefiends

title: Animals Made This Film
review:
The animals in this film were the absolute standout achievement, even given the excellent casting of the children. I was so worried they would be fakey and crap like in Stuart Little, Cats & Dogs etc. but this was exceptional. Aslan brought a lump to my throat as soon as he appeared and I loved every second he was on screen. The sacrifice scene, the armies, the battle, the variety of animals was great and my kids, being lovers of big cats adored it all.

Can't wait for the DVD as I'm dying to see how it was all done. Does anyone know? Three cheers for the director who brought it all to life. He knows how to give animals personality in spades, something he did with Shrek's Puss in Boots. I am actually not a fan of most kids films because of the current trend in unendearing characters (Chicken Little) and have them be rude and smartarsed. While other people see comparisons with Lord of the Rings, for entertainment this is superior in my view. LOTR was overlong, over complicated, just like the book. I actually fell asleep during one installment.

The message from this film just as in the book was loud and clear and left me feeling great about the world. Note to children's authors and film makers: you should set the standard and guide children like the Narnia books do, not reflect the poor behaviour and attitudes of today.

title: Awesome.
review: this movie was the best that i have seen in a long time, it captured the book to the word, even down to the fly on the window sill. It really gave me the shivers in the battle scene when the enemy is charging and the narnia army appears to not be moving and all of a sudden these flying creatures come over the hills dropping rocks on the enemy (remeber the scene at the beginning of the movie where the planes were flying overhead dropping bombs?...this is what it what it looked like) , while the rest of the narnia crew don't move a muscle. the movie was great and i'm a huge fan of c.s. lewis books...i hope that they make the other six books in the narnia series into movies. btw...i loved tumnus.

title: Magnificentin its making and storyline, but disappointing in its acting by the kids
review:
For five years, since I've read this book, I've been waiting to see this film. Finally, after five eager years, it has arrived with an almost smashing success.

The story is unforgettable and childlike; the plot is simple, four kids are sent away to an old man's mansion, and shortly after arriving there, they find a wardrobe, and when they step into it, they enter a fantasy world called Narnia, filled with awesome locations and talking creatures, both the good and the bad. The story goes on about a wicked Witch who turns everything into winter and ice has ruled the world for the last hundred years. But hope arrives with Aslan, a giant and computerized, but fabulous looking, giant lion, with the aid of the talented and tame voice of Liam Neeson. Together, they must defeat the witch, before the world is destoryed by evil.

So, almost everything was great in this film, from the stunning visuals that are in a comparison of King Kong and Star Wars, the uplifting score from Harry Gregson-Willams (Kingdom of Heaven), the settings, costumes, make-up, and storyline. But the acting from the four kids almsot made me laugh.

Why? First of all, the girl who played Lucy reminded me of an annoying little sister that had the look of Chucky. Then, the teenage girl who played Susan, was dry, boring, and an overall pain throughout the film, and the kid who played Peter, was just as equally as dry as Susan. However, the kid who played Edmund was great, and seemed not rehearsed like the others (if they were). The actress who played Witch was probably the best cast member, because she was so evil, that she is good comparison to a female and fair version of Darth Vader. And ironically, her servant was an evil Humpa Lumpa with a beard.

My bottom line is that the good guys were grand, and the villains were very evil and wicked. I honestly have to say that this film should not have been PG, instead, it should have been a PG-13, due to its scary images. Anyway, it's hard to do good battle sequences with a PG rating, not that I mean the film should've been violent like Alexander or Gladiator, but needed, in my opinion to at least have some intensity like The Lord of the Rings films in terms of violence, to have more feling, and making them more intense and realistic.

I enjoyed this film, that's the truth. About buying it? I probably won't because it's not an everyday movie, except for children. So, my rating is a ****1/2 out of *****

Parents, if you wnat your kids to see it, watch the film first, for some material is a bit disturbing for young kids.

title: Well done.
review: This movie could have gone wrong, horribly wrong. It didn't. The only oddzo bit was Santa showing up handing out medieval weapons. I mean if Santa is going to show up in Narnia and start arming the natives like some covert CIA operative - he should have been handing out ak47s and semi-automatics. You would have sure needed them for Jadis and her army of most-wanted werewolves and beasty-thingeys. This was in the book so I guess it's entirely kosher - but it was a sequence where the movie seemed warped and hard to take. Wicked white witch - very good. Child actors - outstanding. Other than the already mentioned arms for children Santa-gate, this movie was very good all around. I hope they make more.

title: I expected a childish story from C.S.Lewis
review:
OK, I didn't read the book and I didn't see the 1988 TV adaptation. Shame on me! However, I did watch this film and I was averagely impressed by it.

First of all, the special effects. There are not so many, but they are subtle. The movie has a lot of animals and they all look like animals (for the first time ever) and there are some clever computer light manipulation and actor physiognomy mapping to make it seem natural.

The story. It is a children's tale. Don't expect much from it. It doesn't explain things and it has a lot of "lucky strikes" typical of a story that is not meant to scare or excite, but to make a point. It has children that fate has put in a very important position and they are more or less forced to act it out, learning a lot about themselves, family and building character. It has a lot of inconsistencies and it fails to keep you into the tale. I found myself shouting "Use the bloody bottle! Shoot the damn bow already!", though, so I guess it all depends on how far you are willing to go.

The actors. Tilda Swinton again plays a powerful creature with mental issues. She does it well. Actually, the movie would have been bad without her. It does make sense in a movie with four or more main positive characters and only one villain. The children... are OK. The big sister is terribly annoying, but maybe that's just me. The others in the cast are either animals (like the beavers from the Milka commercials :) ) or have secondary parts.

The conclusion: a book intended to be a Christian allegory for little children is transformed into a movie. The audience is little Christian children. There isn't much else to be said. Maybe even old Arabs will enjoy it as long as they understand it is a simple tale with lots of inspirational music.

title: Disappointed...
review: My whole life I've always been a huge fan of the Chronicals of Narnia. I grew up reading the books and watching the original movie. In High School I adapted The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe to the stage for our high school drama team. In doing this I became even more attached to the story. When I watched the movie I must say that I was a little disappointed in it. The plot was basically the same, but there were several aspects that the movie left out that I thought were very important. Several lines were cut that were my favorite. As a Christian I've always turned to the Narnia series as a source of inspiration, and I felt that this movie DRASTICALLY left out the Christian aspect. I felt that CS Lewis would have wanted the movie to stay true to his Christian parallels, and I felt that it really did not. I was very sad to find that. I thought everything else was good. The acting and costumes and such.But as for the Christian parallels I was very disappointed and irritated.

title: Been twice and will go again
review:
Okay, here is how I'm gonna do this simply put  THE GOOD and THE BAD. I am a Narnia Purist and had my expectations. Some were met, some were not.

Here goes

THE GOOD Lucy  Perfect. Just as I imagined her. Gets my vote for an award. Mr. Tumnus  Near Perfect. Just wish the crying would have been more blubbering. Edmund  Near Perfect. More earnestness for Turkish Delight would have been nice. Father Christmas  Near Perfect. Nice touch running across the lake. Susan  Not Bad. Too much cautiousness. Peter  Not Bad. Kind of a sissy pants in the beginning. Aslan  Okay. I wanted to hear Aslan, not Liam. Digital was perfect Jadis  Fair. I wanted a reason to not like her. Should have been taller. Landscape  Beautiful and majestic.

THE BAD Why oh why add pointless scenes that detract, and delete scenes that enhance?

The river scene P.U. I would have much more enjoyed watching the Pevensies experience the thaw of Narnia than the river scene (and it would have cost them a lot less to do!). An obvious add-in for the game. I've played it; it's in there.

The Beavers meal. When you read the book you actually get hungry waiting for the children to eat. In the film, Lucy almost turns her nose up to what is offered her.

Aslan in the Witches Castle. This scene is very important as Aslan moves from statue to statue, breathing life into them. It becomes a celebration, a reunion, a joyous moment of rebirth for the Narnians and totally skipped in the film. A missed opportunity to give the viewers an opportunity to cheer for Aslan and Narnia. Oh, and where is Giant Rumblebuffin?

The Stone Table. Already mentioned in previous reviews, but where was the play after Aslan resurrects? Another crucial point, showing Aslan meeting the girls at their level by healing their mourning. Had that been included, the viewer would have been more drawn to Aslan.

In all, the movie was very, very good to great. Apart from Lewis excellent writing, it still stands strong as an entertaining film.

title: The family film we've been waiting for since The Neverending Story!
review:
The film is absolutely fabulous in pretty much every way! My four and five year-old kids really loved it, particularly my daughter, and they weren't at all scared.

The only problem with the film is that director Andrew Adamson didn't really do a great job of letting the viewer understand the power and majesty of Aslan before his death. Sure, he growls menacingly, but otherwise you don't really understand "what the big deal is" about this lion. (I don't think it was a conscious "dumbing down" of Aslan, as much as a simple failing of the director -- it's really his first major live-action film, and so one can't reasonably expect everything to be "perfect.")

But that is a minor complaint, and I still rate the film a 10. Like Peter Jackson's "Lord of the Rings" films, I feel myself truly blessed to have seen such faithful adaptations of such beloved classics during my lifetime. (Fingers still crossed for Tolkien's "The Hobbit" and C.S. Lewis' "Space Trilogy"...!)

title: Great movie, a must see for all
review:
First of all, GREAT movie, i really enjoined the movie, actually i did go and see him twice ;) I was surprised how good (excellent) the movie is, it is just as good as the book an the film is actually the same as the book, that thing made me look surprised. C.S. Lewis's Chronicals are very enjoining to read and different stories not like LOTR or Harry Potter, an very Important, Narnia has a special massage, probably you heard it more often but for those who didn't = Aslan is Jesus how is rising from the death, and the witch is the devil who will be defeated at last, and in that way the movie (or book) is similar to the Bible. And LOTR isn't not at all about the bible! And the actor's did a very good job except for Lucy, she is playing great except for one scene, Aslan is dead and she is almost LAUGHING instead of crying (that's how i saw it ;)) but the rest is very good acted from the little Lucy.

And the filming again Excellent !! so it's a must see for all and don't miss it !

title: Fine, Enjoyable Film
review:
This is a very good family film, and I would say that it compares favorably with Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings, to which it is inevitably compared. The films are of course as different from each other as the novels are, and each takes certain inevitable liberties with their originals. Both films wind up a bit overblown in spots (too much emphasis on battle, particularly in LotR), and both have minor weaknesses, but provide satisfying entertainment.

Lewis' story is too well known to require more than a brief overview. Lucy, a young English girl, magically stumbles into a land where animals talk and magic is real. Her siblings disbelieve her and she is betrayed by her young brother Edmund: out of pride and greed he has succumbed to the blandishments of Narnia's evil tyrant, the White Witch. The Witch is on the lookout because of a prophecy that her reign will end when 2 pairs of humans appear in Narnia. Lucy's other brother and sister eventually discover Narnia and, evading the White Witch's wolf-henchmen, they meet Aslan, a mysterious lion who represents justice and freedom. Unfortunately Edmund's treason has given the Witch rights of him that only Aslan's sacrifice can redeem: without Edmund, the prophecy will not come true.

Lucy (Georgie Henley) is naturally the star of the story and so it is a delightful surprise to see the brilliance of scriptwriter Ann Peacock's enriched treatment of Edmund, superbly played by Skandar Keynes. Henley also does a fine job although William Moseley and Anna Popplewell have little to work with as the older siblings. The supporting characters are also wonderful, particularly James McAvoy as faun Mr. Tumnus. Frankly, I think Liam Neeson had a far more challenging role than Tilda Swinton as the White Witch, and he does a VERY creditable job.

The story carried me along too well to notice any problems with the CGI. I had uncomfortable memories of the BBC's TV version of the talking beavers  they are well-handled here as are all the animals (with an amused nod to the talking horse!)

The film's real weakness is that it tries too hard to be a children's adventure and fails to put the appropriate emphasis on the story's big themes: good and evil, destiny and free will, betrayal and redemption, sacrifice and reward. The book has a slightly stylized fairy-tale nature that makes it easy, for example, to accept the appearance of Santa Claus. Despite all its mythological elements, the film fails to capture this.

title: Another fantastic fantasy film!
review:
"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe" follows the LotR Trillogy and the Harry Potter movies as another fantastic fantasy film. More family-friendly then the other franchises, the film stays true to C.S. Lewis' children's tale, and brings a believable yet equally fantastic world to life on screen. The acting is strong, the CG holds up well, and the design "feel" of the film is it's own; not just a LotR copy. The Queen and the waring armies deserve special mention. This obviously wasn't just another film with an overinflated budget and little depth: the filmmakers have created an entertaining and absorbing world to enjoy.

Family friendly but with more then enough to grab any audience, "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe" will be a favourite for years to come.

title: Superbly done, true to the book through and through
review: I'm not a fan of knights and battles in movies, but I did read these books many times as a young adult and consider the series among my all my favorites. I was truly impressed with the way they managed to convey the story so closely to my young imaginations version of it. There was not a sour note to found here, and the casting was amazing! All four of the main characters were perfect, and even down to Aslan the lion, who was even better then I imagined! The music is perfect and adds tremendously to the movie. Back to the " knights and battles". Wow.... how awesome was that? Great job. The computer team on this should win some awards for sure, oh and I can't finish without commenting on the actress who played the White Witch, I thought she was very good, ( wow she has some real arm muscles there in the final battle)but it took me awhile to get over seeing the borg queen,( she played that part too) it felt so similar! Great Movie

title: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review:
This is an awesome movie! I love Peter, Susan, Lucy and Edmund. I think the casting for them is awesome! All of them are perfect for the roles! I like this movie because it is action-filled all the way through.

The White Witch is super creepy and Tumnus' faun legs are awesome! All of the faun legs are cool! The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe really sticks close to the book. It's hard converting books to movies and Andrew Adamson and all the producers and script writers manage that!

Even though Edmund betrays them all and then gets hurt in the battle, its an awesome story! I loved how all of the kids sort of grew up in this movie- in the beginning they were little English kids and in the end they were the kings and queens of Narnia.

THIS IS THE BEST MOVIE EVER!

title: One amazing film, with some fantastic actors!
review:
I went to see it yesterday, and it is amazing!!! At first, I thought the acting was pretty poor. Then Tilda Swinton came along!!! If I was a Director, she my friends, would be auditioned immediately!!! If anybody says another actress could have done a better job, they need to watch the film more carefully. The character is evil, but what an actress! She should be damn rewarded!!! The others weren't bad, I just picked a favourite!! The film on a whole, did kind of drag, but it kept you watching. Action was in place the whole time, and worked immensely! IU did, however, at first, think that the start was a little rushed, and then I watched it until the end, realising the length. The director mush have been really good, I have never heard of him, but he is a pro!

I saw the older version, but can't really remember it, as I was about 6. But I want to see it again. I think the difference would be fantastic, actors wise. Again, the White Witch, I believe, should have been played by Tilda Swinton all along.

The skills in her acting came across when I realised she was evil. Because at first, when she spoke to Edmond, I thought she was a nice character, because I couldn't remember her in the old film. Then she killed the helpful fox!!!!!! Thank god he came back to life!!!!

Film overview:

Susan, the youngest child, hides in a wardrobe whilst playing hides in a wardrobe (THE wardrobe) whilst playing Hide and Seek with her brothers and sisters, and enters the magical land of Narnia. She meets the Faun, Mr. Tumnus, and leaves. Not realising that time stops whilst in Narnia.

None of her brothers, or sisters however, believe her. One night, she decides to visit Faun, whilst Edmond follows her. He loses track of her in Narnia, and comes across the Witch. Edmond drops Mr. Tumnus in it by telling the witch that his sister has been visiting him. This is not allowed. The witch captures Mr. Tumnus, when all 4 children, after being persuaded, on the run from the housekeeper of the house they are staying at, visit Narnia, and discover that Mr. Tumnus has been taken. They spend time with Beavers, searching for him, and on the run from the White Witch, whilst Edmond betrays them and goes up to the White Witch! She is angry that Edmond hasn't fetched all relatives (for her to kill, Edmond no knowing this), and decides to keep him with her. He realises the things she can do, in all evilness, and is extremely frightened! Whilst on the run from the White Witch, the other three children come across dangerous, and strange creatures, that can talk. They then meet Aslan, King of the nice part of Narnia. Edmond is returned to his brother and sisters (who are now known as the two son's of Adam, and the two daughters of Eve), and Aslan meets with the White Witch, both teams present. Aslan speaks with the White Witch in privacy, and realises that Edmond must be killed, as he committed a serious betrayal. Aslan sacrifices himself for Edmond, by being killed and all Narnia owned by the White Witch. The two sisters watch Aslan be shaved, and killed on the giant stone. All of the evil side of Narnia watches this. Later, when deserted Aslan lay alone, the two sisters appear at his side and sob over him whilst devastated of his death. They turn their backs, and the stone cracks, Aslan is back alive, and Aslan explains this whole thing. A giant battle is on the go, meanwhile.

Aslan runs to the rescue, carrying the two sisters. He kills the White Witch, and all Narnia is owned by Aslan. The two queens (the two sisters) and the two kings (the two brothers). The children then return out of the wardrobe, and the professor of the house walks in with the ball. The film ends.

One mistake I noticed was at the end. The children entered Narnia, whilst the Professor be downstairs, and the Housekeeper chasing them. Time is supposed to stop. When the children finally re-enter the house, the professor walks in and hands them the ball. Not in suitable time to walk upstairs, find the ball, and reach the children to return it, after all, time is supposed to stop.

Hope it helps, overall, a FANTASTIC film. 9/10.

title: Enjoyable and true to the original stories with a few exceptions
review: I enjoyed the film a lot but for me there were two glaring weaknesses. The first was the way Aslan was portrayed. There was very little of the glory and majesty of the Aslan of C.S. Lewis' books. This is a major weakness, although perhaps one that never can be conquered on film. It was for this reason that Lewis himself was vehemently opposed to the stories being filmed. The second weakness was not so important but still disturbed me. The first time Lucy sees the wardrobe it stands out as being something special. Although this may be along the lines of other fantasy films, it is not in keeping with what Lewis wanted to portray. The wardrobe was a perfectly normal wardrobe with no magical qualities whatsoever.

title: Thoroughly enjoyable.
review: I went to see this film with a mixture of trepidation and anticipation as The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe was a favourite childhood book. I am pleased to say it did not disappoint as it certainly caught the flavour and spirit of childhood memories. The child actors were on the whole excellent and not irritating as I feared they may be. The animated/CGI animals were also very good and the casting of Ray Winstone and Dawn French as the beaver voices was inspired. All in all a thoroughly enjoyable film, and I can not wait for the next instalment of the Narnia chronicles. One point I would add is that at the showing I went to there were a number of young children as young as 5 or 6 in my opinion it is not really suitable for such young children.

title: Magnificent but a bit cliché'd
review: Very good movie, and i think it follows the story in a much more comprehensible way so the whole family can enjoy and understand it. although some of the combat scenes closely resemble the classic style of many other 'tryhard' 'lord of the rings' battles. but other than that its a superb film which is worth watching! The youth acting is above average and i think that the children suited all of their characters very well. Obviously the 'White Witch' affectively captures the cold impious character which she is renound for. The voice of the lion is also very affective. Conclusively this film really captures the story in all its glory.

review: I like this movie, even when I see the episode of it~ I am new here, and I am a Chinese, I don't know I should write 10 lines! So I am saying some nonsense. Is it enough? title: The Chronicles of Narnia
review: I think the Chronicles of Narnia is the best movie ever. It has plenty of action and excitement for all ages or groups of people. It is one of the only movies that is actually rated correctly too. The entire movie kept me on the edge of my seat and I wouldn't get up for anything. The characters really bring the movie to life before your very eyes. Where it was filmed was an awesome spot because it really sets the tone of the movie. I hope they keep making movies like this one and continue with the series. If they do, it will be a real money maker and definitely impress the audience. I think the Chronicles of Narinia is worth taking everyone you know to see because it is the best movie ever!!!!!!! I loved the movie and I hope everyone who saw it loved it as much as I did. This is the movie to see if you haven't.

title: Narnia Rocks!
review: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe was amazingly accurate of the children's book by C.S. Lewis. Georgie Henley is perfectly adorable as Lucy Pevensie. Anna Popplewell, William Moseley, and Skandar Keynes are equally fit to play Susan, Peter, and Edmund respectively. Although it is fairly obvious that they do not have a lot of acting experience, they do well in spite of the fact. They portray siblings extremely realistically. You find yourself reminded of your own brothers and sisters as you watch them bicker and make up. One of the only problems I had with this movie, is that Liam Neeson does not have a deep enough voice. Therefore Aslan was not as commanding as he should have been. Overall I was very pleased with this movie.

title: Never read the books and loved it
review: Since I've never read the books I can simply comment on the movie as a stand-alone work of art. It was a fantastic film full of great effects and wonderful scenery. The CG effects were top notch and the story was quite good. The good versus evil story has been told millions of times over but this is one that needs to be seen. If you enjoy fantasy movies of any kind this should be on your "must see" list. I do have friends who have read the books and seen the film and they were very pleased with the film as well. This is one movie that I will definitely add to my collection when it comes out on DVD. I took my kids to see it (they're 7 and 5 (twins) ) and they enjoyed it and were quiet throughout as their attention was riveted to the screen.

title: Very Well Done
review:
Overall, I was very impressed with this film. It was well done. The computer-generated effects were very crisp and enjoyable.

I have to say, it did not have the same epic feeling as the Lord of the Rings, however, having read the original books, I don't think the Chronicles of Narnia was intended to have the same feel as Lord of the Rings. Though both Christians, C.S. Lewis was more of a theologian, while Tolkien was more of a storyteller. One has to remember that when seeing the movie.

The movie was good and I definitely recommend it, however, I can't help but feel the movie was missing something... Perhaps this was due to the fact that I had read the books and listened to an audio dramatization as a kid -- It seems that the imagination still can do a better job at picturing this story, though the movie is definitely worth seeing and hopefully the other books will follow.

title: good adaptation...not enough depth
review:
i read the book (and was obsessed with it for many months) when i was 5 years old and have to commend the director for staying true to the original story.

where adamson fails is in his attempt to create an epic film. you could tell that he tried - using cinematographic elements you'd see in true epics like the lord of the rings (sweeping vistas, dramatic music, etc). he unfortunately did not succeed in this attempt.

with so many characters and so little time one never really gets an opportunity to really know any of the protagonists which left me lacking a strong connection to any of the good guys. we spent a lot of time with the white witch, though, and she is by far my favourite character.

in a truly epic film most, if not all, of the actors need to do a stunning job. in narnia, quality varied from actor to actor. the performances of the actors playing the four sibling protagonists are mediocre at best. tilda swinton (the white witch) and james mcavoy (mr. tumnus) are notably good performances. then again, the fabulous tilda swinton gets to play an evil bitch...? what better role could there be for her? i've read many comments about the special effects/cgi and how great it is. and it is indeed so on all the main characters (the beavers, the lion). i found the work on some of the more fantastical creatures to be lacking, however. the best example of this is with the general of the white witch's army. a few times it looked like they were using live actors in second-rate costumes instead of high quality cgi.

finally, the book is loved by kids and grownups worldwide but, because of some violent content, the movie is most certainly not meant for young children. so you've got a movie that doesn't have the substance/depth to appease adults but isn't suitable for children either. while it's mainstream and religious appeal will likely make this movie a commercial success, from a creative/artistic perspective it's clearly stuck in a strange twilight zone.

title: mesmerising and beautiful
review:
As a child, I liked the "idea" formed by the CS Lewis books more than the books themselves. This is a case where the movie has vastly improved on the original book. A big plus, is that the clunky, almost preachy Christianity of the books has been smoothed out and toned down. Aslan now "could" be a Christ figure as much as he "could" be an Osiris figure or any one of a number of mytho-religio figures who have triumphed over death. The pagan atmosphere has been ratcheted up a bit. This is just simply "The Other World".

I watched this on a gigantamoose. floor to ceiling screen with state of the art projection. The imagery and color schemes were so powerful that at times I was sure I had entered a Dream.

Strangely, as the film began with the London war scenes, as the faun played panpipes to the tea-sipping Lucy, as Father Christmas doled out his "tools not toys", and in many other places I wept inexplicably.

Tilda Swinton's albino viper/Snow Queen of a White Witch struck terror into my heart at EVERY appearance. One's never sure where she'll strike (waaaay beyond the book's characterisation) And Aslan . . . was fur ever furrier? Didn't I want to run my hands through his marvelous mane and hug his leonine neck for protection? Sometimes, the film "lapses" but these are "breathing spaces" rather than "faults" A children's film? No. A learned child will "appreciate" it but only a 50 year old child (like the author of this review) will know what it takes to "love" it: Passing Time's bittersweet loss and the cost extracted for passage through a magic wardrobe.

Kudos to all involved --- Ya' done Good!

title: Excellent Film
review: I'm a big fan of the book series, and a Christian so this film appealed to me on many fronts. I loved this film adaption of C.S. Lewis classic, and I think older children unfamiliar with the original stories will find the allegorical exploration of the Atonement of Jesus Christ contained within it to be a very accessible and helpful vehicle for spawning conversations at home about what the sacrifice of the Savior means. But even if you're not Christian, I think you'll find the film to be great family entertainment and very moving. They were true to the story on all the key points and of course added in the requisite Lord-of-the- Rings-esquire battle sequences (hey, that's Hollywood folks). The cast was well selected and I am continually amazed at what they are able to accomplish with CGI technologies these days (Aslan was just as I pictured him from Lewis' description in the book, and they were able to convey all of the warmth of character and power in his countenance that Lewis intended). Don't miss this film! One aside: I would caution parents of younger children (say under 7 years old), that there are some scary moments and some emotionally tough moments that may be troubling for younger kids.

title: "What were you children doing in the wardrobe?"
review: This movie joins the legion of films based on books I was supposed to read as a younger kid, The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a solid adaptation of the CS Lewis novel. For this uninitiated viewer, I found aspects of other fantasy movies sprinkled in the story, with some elements of greater theology thrown in there for good measure. Tilda Swinton plays the evil White Witch (though we never find out how she becomes so powerful or how she recruits her followers) who proclaims herself the ruler of Narnia. The kingdom resides in the back of a wardrobe in an English countryside home where four children flee to during World War II's Battle of Britain bombardment of London. While trying to hide from the housekeeper, the children enter Narnia where they become entangled in the war between the white witch and animals of Narnia, lead by a lion named Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson). The kids, Peter (William Moseley), Susan (Anna Popplewell), Edmund (Skandar Keynes), and Lucy (Georgie Henley) are used by the Witch to proclaim war against Aslan's forces, setting up a battle sequence right out of Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings movies. The prodding by the White Witch reminded me of Darth Vader in the Star Wars movies, perhaps shedding light on the source material for George Lucas and his mythology. There is also an undeniable religious slant to the pivotal Aslan scenes, as the parallels between Aslan and Christ cannot be overlooked. It's not a bad thing, and critical viewing of this movie could be used to discuss stories of the Bible without overtly discussing potentially dicey topics. Overall, the movie is entertaining, though a tad long, I thought some scenes could have been trimmed, allowing the story to flow better. The beavers (voiced by Ray Winstone and Dawn French) are not only funny and bring some levity to an otherwise heavy movie, but the animation is top-notch, producing believable beaver tour guides for the characters and viewers. Lovers of the book will like this movie, while other viewers may be entertained in the levels of mythology featured in the movie and their relations to theology.

title: Re: Professors final scene of the movie
review:
I took my kids to see Narnia Saturday and loved it! It was terrific. My only negative comment is that when the movie appeared to be over, the theater lights came on and we were all walking down the stairs thinking we had seen the whole movie. Then, we saw the Professor come back on and deliver a probably very moving few last words....the theater was so loud we could not hear what was said.

Could anyone tell me what he said???? I would really appreciate it.

Though I am sure we will purchase the movie when it comes out on DVD and we will begin the C of N book set my son got for Christmas, I don't want to wait that long to hear the end of the movie!

title: All in all, good movie
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia is a beloved fantasy series of novels for children and adults. I'm glad to see the first movie translation was done well. Although, there are several parts to this movie that are lacking, special effects not always the best, overall it is very enjoyable. I hope for better efforts for the subsequent novels, but the first outing is admirable. Coming from Disney, however, makes me question whether they can improve or even maintain the quality seen in the first film.

This is a great family film, although the action might be too intense for real small children. Some of the characters are simply delightful, and Georgie Henley, as Lucy, impressed me with her young acting chops. The cinematography is very stunning throughout. I was glad for the open, sunny feel of it that helped point this towards being a children and family film rather than a darker, young adult version.

I think Disney may have stumbled upon a winner series if it keeps those behind the creation of The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe. I can only cross my fingers and hope for a continuation and improvement on this great start.

title: Good Family Movie
review: The Chronicles of Narnia:The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is the best family movie offered in this Christmas season. Director Andrew Adamson really didn't leave any stones unturned. The special effects are extremely well done and the animals in the movie are as real as human beings in the movie. The final battle scene is well edited and it can be used to compare with the battle scene in Lord of the Rings movies. Of course, the battle scenes in Lord of the Rings movies are better than the battle scene in this movie, but this movie is for children and showing any bloody battle scenes would not be wise. And the special effects are not the main point of the movie that make me love this movie. The family and the emotions between Lucy, Edmund, Susan and Peter are the main points of this movie. The four main characters are well cast and they really make this movie works. Another area of the movie that really elevates this movie is the score. Harry Gregson-Williams is the composer of all the scores in this movie and they are not only appropriate for this movie, but they are actually increase the entertainment values of the movie. To me, I think the scores are even better done than Lord of the Rings movies. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is perfect for family to enjoy. Director Andrew Adamson and the casts have brought a classic story to the big screen with satisfying results.

title: Orrite, but went very fast
review:
What struck me about this one was how *fast* things seemed to happen... I think you can tell that this was a book that made the transition to a movie. It's one of those movies where "bits" are missing. Sometimes it seems like a highlights package for the full movie... Or maybe for the book. Mind you I've never read the book, so maybe I'm talking nonsense. (c: The start was well paced. It introduced everything very well... There just seems a point where everything went *too* fast.

Mind you the movie certainly has its moments. The effects are glorious - if you can fool yourself into believing the CGI effects. Somehow I have trouble with that... I mean, an effect is an effect, but for some reason the CGI ones are less believable than the "human-generated" ones. Odd.

Most people I went with loved this movie, so maybe you will too. For me, I'm off to read the book! The movie whetted my appetite a little... Now I want to "see" the rest of it. (c:

title: Best film (I've seen) of the year!
review:
And I'm not kidding. There have been a number of movies I was interested in, and looking forward to this year. This really was not one of them, at first. Logic holds that it would be my absolute favourite.

I have rarely ever seen a book-to-movie adaptation that rivals this one. I say rarely, but possibly EVER. It was incredibly faithful to the Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, but that in and of itself doesn't make a great movie. This was faithful, and amazingly well done. It's almost hard to describe. The adaptation is quite possibly the best I have ever seen done. With exceptions, I think few people who have read and loved the first book of the series could be disappointed in this movie.

What else can I say? I love Disney for making this movie. That I can remember, the last Disney movie I really liked was Pirates of the Caribbean. I'm not a huge Disney fan, in general.

This film was beautiful, magical, childlike and yet adult. The most perfect children's story, come to life. The acting was great. I loved everyone... my favourite (of course) was little Lucy. I frickin' adored that little girl. But the whole cast was fabulous.

I've already seen it twice in the theatre, and I would see it again in a heartbeat. Of the several movies I've seen in the theatre this year, this is one of only two I've watched more than once. I have *no* doubt that I will buy the DVD when it comes out.

I gave it 9 out of 10. This is just a perfect Christmas movie.

title: A disappointment, but an entertaining one
review:
I have been looking forward to seeing this film since I first found out it was being made. I'm a huge fan of fantasy literature and the Narnia books are some of my favorites. That being said I was hugely disappointed in this film. I felt that much of the CGI in the film looked forced and horrible fake. The performances of the young actors was one dimensional, and the ending, the four siblings as grown Narnian kings and queens hunting the white stag and then finding their way home to England, a beautiful and funny passage in the original novel, was clumsily handled and not well explained. It did not show that many years in Narnia passed and yet when the children returned to England they were still just that, children. The character of Aslan seemed to me not to be the central figure of this film, as he is in the novel. The film's focus is much more on the children, less on Aslan. Their relationship with the great lion is shown, although it is hard to show on film with the necessary detail the feeling the children are supposed to get from Aslan.

With these criticisms aside, I have to say that The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe is an extremely enjoyable film. Although badly animated the animal characters, especially a fox who lays down his life for the safety of the Pevnsie children, and the beavers who escort them to Aslan, are extremely likable and fun. Also I enjoyed the performance of Tilda Swinton as the White Witch. Early on in the film she sugar coats a sweetness to entice Edmund to her side, and you see why he is attracted to her, although we as an audience already know she is evil. When she becomes entirely evil I found myself getting chills. And although I felt that the three older children gave dull performances I did enjoy the youngest Georgie Henley, as Lucy Pevnsie. She was adorable and perfect as the innocent little girl who finds the magical land, and introduces her skeptical siblings to it.

This is far from a perfect adaptation of LWW, but it is enjoyable, and the story has so much heart and beauty in it, it is almost impossible to hate. I recommend seeing this film, but be warned of its pitfalls.

title: Very good movie
review: As a long-time fan of "Narnia" I was thrilled to understand that there'll be a new "Narnia" movie and in the same way I was weary - it's like this when you expect a movie, based on a fave book. Fortunately, the new "Narnia" movie is terrific. The movie has vision, wonderful actors - from the kids to the fascinating White Which, terrific battles, excellent visual effects and which is most important - it has the magic atmosphere of the books. I might even go as far as saying that the movie is no inferior, even superior to the book. It has the feel of wonder from the books, but the kids are definitely cooler in the movie and some wonderful combat scenes are added. Overall, third best movie of 2005 (after Episode III and Harry Potter IV).

title: Exquisite start to a long-awaited Chronicle!
review:
I grew up on the books and cartoon version of The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe. So, when i heard that they were making a live-action version of the film, I was very excited. I went to see the movie and was not disappointed. The costumes, special effects, acting, directing, casting, and screenplay all come together to make a phenomenal and exquisite start to one of the greatest Fantasy Chronicles ever written.

My only complaints are that Disney's family-friendly no-blood approach to the otherwise well done battle scenes takes away from the realism of the movie. although I follow their logic (wanting to make it family friendly and all) I can't help but think that Professor Lewis would be screaming "They're not bloody bleedin'!" if he saw the film. Furthermore I didn't find Queen Jadis to be nearly as terrifying as I found her to be when reading the books. I mean, she killed an entire world!! (The Magician's Nephew)

title: The best movie of the year, I must say.
review:
This movie, by far, blows the rest out of the water. Being an individual who dissects movies, and one who compares movies to their written counterparts, this movie just awed me. There were only two scenes that were in the movie, that weren't in the book (the confrontation between Peter and the wolves on the river, and Edmund and Mr. Tummus talking in the Witch's Palace), but other than that, the book was followed almost exactly. I was especially pleased that they kept the part in the movie where the mice chew off the cords binding Aslan on the stone table.

The casting was suburb. Each of the Pevensie children matched their counterparts in the books, exactly as I imagined them. Peter as the one who is trying to be strong for his family, in light of the times trying to rip them apart; Susan as the forward individual, acting as the voice of reason, even when reason isn't warranted; Edmund as the selfish brat at first, transitioning to a chastised boy; and Lucy as the innocent, lovable little girl.

Tilda Swinton as Jadis added a level of cruelty and malice, combined with subtlety, that the movie needed. Liam Neeson as the voice of Aslan was a perfect match-he portrays a regal, compassionate, yet strong, calm, and otherwise amazing level to Aslan.

The music added the mystical touch that Lewis' books portrayed throughout. The computer graphics were spectacular, especially considering the amount that was required, what with the multitude of mythical beasts, and special effects.

All in all, this was my favorite movie of the year-it parallels The Lord of the Rings, and various others. If you haven't seen it, I suggest that you do. It is well worth anything.

title: excellent movie to watch again and again
review: the best movie to watch with your family. when i went to it in theaters (by myself, which was't the best idea), the second i came out i bought another ticket and watched it again. the bad thing was that it was only the second day out and so it was in the biggest theater room there and was packed. phones were going off, people were laughing at something completely NOT funny, yet when something was actually funny you hearing crickets chirping (literally), and there were kids with those necklaces that light up in the dark and they also had lasers so they kind of ruined it for me, but overall i still enjoyed it. anyway, the second the movie comes out on DVD i am so buying it, so i can watch it my way with my family. i think almost anyone will enjoy this movie.

title: Fabulous, Faithful Retelling
review:
Welcome to Narnia. Prepare to be lost. If you don't wander around blindly in the forest, prepare to be "lost" on this virtually flawless film. Unlike other movies made from books, this film never strays from the novel. Like the fourth Harry Potter movie, this one does suffer from a feeling of scenes that are far too brief and rushed. The music is quite ordinary. Aslan's angry roar could use work. But that is all. The film gives us the ability to see C.S. Lewis' fabulous allegorical tale enacted on the screen, with incredible results. The story represents Christ's unending love for us, carried so far as to die on the cross at Calvary. Look for ways this movie, and the story, represent the different aspects of Jesus' story.

Don't miss the movie. As a bonus, Peter is REALLY CUTE!!!

title: True to Author and Audience Alike
