review: I know that the movie (Narnia) made an impression on me when after seeing it I find myself still thinking about it the next day. In the 1960s, I felt that Lewis was just making his own version after reading his friend Tolkien's trilogy, but Narnia is very rich, and truly does stand on its own, admittedly interpreting Lewis' real life view of good and evil, Godlike and ungodly. While Tolkien's trilogy better remains read and not over-interpreted as a violent movie, Narnia works well as filmed, and I expect would be appealing to Lewis. Pacing is excellent, the mix of humor, fear, hope and emotion are fine, leaving one not wondering when the long picture will be over, but rather, with "oh, what's next??!!?"

title: A true classic
review: When I first found out about Chrpnicles of Narnia being made into a movie, I was filled w/ a sense of extreme excitement and at the same time apprehension. After all, there had been several times before that they had tried to create these films and failed. All of my friends continued to assure me that it was good, and I went into it w/ a hopeful feeling... and came out feeling so thrilled and fulfilled that I was in a slight sense of shock. The acting was excellent, the shots were superb and the overall feel of the movie was perfect. I've now seen it twice and I can't wait to see it again. It was just so perfect in all it's particulars. It definitely deserves best film of the year, and I'm sure it would have won if Hollywood wasn't so screwed up by nominating the stupidest movies of all (not to name any names- BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN!) I loved this movie and would recommend it to anyone and everyone. See the movie. You'll be happy you did.

title: Narnia is Magnificent
review: The movie was excellent form beginning to end. The beginning though where you watch their hometown get destroyed was unnecessary. Chrildren will find it fascinating and awesome. However the movie did have moments where you might think it would lose some of the audience. These include a scene with Santa,Skandar Keynes's(Edmund) acting capabilities, and the major scene where good and evil once again clash. The movie was produced by Disney who in desperate attempts to remain a titan in the film industry is grasping at any ideas that may hit big. Some include Cars and Casanova. Disney has such a small amount of films to be released that there are only two trailers before the film. It begins in Germany during World War two and you watch as a whole town is bombarded with explosives. The children are sent to live in a safer place with a mysterious "Professor" and Mrs.Macready. Lucy Pevensie the youngest hides in a wardrobe during a game of hide and seek and enters Narnia. She then meets a Faun named Mr. Tumnus. She proceeds to have tea with him until he reveals he is kidnapping her. She goes back in the wardrobe in her world to find time hasn't passed since she entered Narnia. She tells her siblings Edmund, Peter, and Susan. Naturally they don't believe her. She goes back though at night followed by Edmund who unknowingly tells the White Witch the whereabouts of his sister and who's been hiding her. When Edmund and Lucy leave he lies and tells the others there is no Narnia to the dismay of Lucy. Later when they break a window they end up in Narnia after hiding in the wardrobe together. They find Mr.Tumnus's place destroyed and meet the badgers who lead them to Aslan the rightful ruler of Narnia. Meanwhile Edmund goes to the White Witch who finally reveals her true colors and send wolves to kill the others and locks Edmund in a prison. The White Witch holds Edmund hostage as they travel across Narnia to capture the others. When Edmund is saved Aslan sacrifices his life for Edmunds. A war between those who want freedom and those who want power ensues. Good vs. Evil. The acting in this movie is incredible (excluding Edmund) and the plot really catches your attention. The special affects dazzle you and the beauty of Narnia is astounding. However because its a Disney production at times the battles don't seem realistic and greatly appear similar to the original. The movie however does not have music that goes with the scenes and that gives you mixed ideas. However Narnia is much better than the latest Harry Potter movies and is enjoyable for those of all ages!

title: Surprisingly fresh
review:
I expected a recycled version of some kids adventure I'd never seen before. Something along the lines of Masterpiece Theatre or Dr. Who kind of "wonder". Wow, was I surprised.

The acting in the film is very very good, from Mr. Tumnus to Lucy to the White Witch. They were able to instill the right feeling of wonder at the right places, as well as at other times indignation, anger, and great sorrow.

The animals in the film were the best seamless blend of, well, animals and other types of characters. I truly believed the gryphons could exist as they did in the film, as well as the cheetahs. There were some 'CG' moments, and the appearance of a rather well-known folk figure was the longest stretch. But even then the role that was there and how it was presented was masterfully done. Not leaning too hard either way.

The educated, serious film watcher will complain and nitpick about silly details (army tactics, inexperienced swordsmen against masters), but relent that the story is the main thing, and it is very very good.

Very much looking forward to more in the series, if they can keep up with the masterful screen writing.

title: Very good movie, better than I expected
review:
I had read the book of The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe and the story was so good that I wanted to see how they adapted into a movie.

Now with the actual technology for create fictional characters generated by computer, they did a very good job with all the animals that required to appear according to the book. And the movie is very faithful to the book even when they eliminated some parts that were on the book that I won't mention cuz were so strong that it would have been rated PG-13 like Pirates Of The Caribbean: The Curse Of The Black Pearl.

Anyway, the movie is watchable and beautiful. The cast was great, my greetings to Tilda Swinton, she did an excellent acting as the main villain and made her character more villainous than the book.

I expect the sequel The Prince Caspian, a follow up to The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe.

I give this 9 stars out of 10.

title: A wonderful adaptation of the first book in the best fantasy series EVER!!!
review:
"The Lord of the Rings" was good, but soooo drawn out. "Harry Potter" was just good. What sets "The Chronicles of Narnia" apart is the fact that the story is just all around more interesting, along with the symbolism.

In this film, four kids find a magical world in a large wardrobe. The world is under the reign of a false ruler. A witch. When the four kids arrive, so does a lion, and things begin to change.

The symbolism in this movie is obvious. The White Witch is Satan. Aslan is Jesus. Come on, I mean The White Witch kills him and he comes back and when he kills her, he says: "It is finished", the same three words Jesus said on the cross.

Tilda Swinton was a better White Witch than the old one because when she pretended to be nice to Edmund, it was convincing. The four kids, particularly Georgie Henley, were really great too.

This movie is a great family movie or anyone just big on epics.

10/10

title: Very entertaining viewing
review:
I've never read the Narnia Chronicles (gasp!) so I came to this movie with very few preconceptions. And I have to say the film was a pleasant enough diversion for a couple of hours.

As one might expect, the movie is heavily dependent upon CGI effects for its realisation, but it would be a terrible inaccuracy to say that it depended on them for its entertainment. True, the animal inhabitants and fantastic beasts of Narnia are all the better for the CGI treatment, but its the actors (and voices) that really make the movie worthwhile. In particular, the young stars of the film playing the Pevensey children are outstanding and I'm sure we'll be seeing more of them in the future.

It's rare also that I spot something particularly well done amongst the omnipresent CGI effects these days - usually its quite the reverse, but I did here. In the large final battle feline warriors of both sides charge and leap at each other. The way the cats meet each other and twist in the air will be immediately familiar to anyone who has owned cats, particularly kittens, and watched them fighting. These brief scenes are exceptionally well-done and hats off to the CGI artists for this.

The animals are not overtly anthropomorphised either, which is nice. They speak, and make head gestures rather nicely like a human might. But the features aren't too "altered", if you know what I mean.

As for the story, you are either familiar with it (having read the books) or ignorant of it (like me) but the basic plot is instantly familiar and recognisable. Good vs. Evil etc. and the ending is exactly as you might expect it to turn out.

That said, the film is enjoyable thanks to the cast and effects and I'm sure we'll be seeing more of Narnia in the future.

title: Spectacular Story and Incredible Scenery!!!
review: This was an excellent movie! I was amazed that Disney did such a great job adapting the book into a feature film. The cinematography was incredible. This is a must see on a Big Screen, as the big screen allows you to see all of the amazing scenery and it's beauty up close. The casting for this film was absolutely perfect. The four children, being basically unknowns in the business, did a perfect job portraying each of the characters. Each of them is likely headed into wonderful acting careers. When I went to see the film, I wasn't sure what to expect, but I was very pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed the entire experience. I was familiar with the book, but wasn't sure how well it would adapt to the screen. I was more than impressed with it and feel that there is something in this for everyone! Christian or not, this movie can be enjoyed by all and has a wonderful heartfelt message. I highly recommend it and look forward to it coming out on DVD so we can add it to our movie collection. It is sure to be a classic.

title: Excellent Story!
review: I LOVE storys that are battles between Good and Evil. This one hits the mark! I appreciate that they made this movie without any real "Star Power". Goes to show you that you don't need Tom Cruise, Colin Ferrel, etc... to make a movie GREAT! The setting is magnificent, the wardorbe excellent, the casting superb. As someone who has never read C.S. Lewis, this movie convinced me that I should give his books a chance. Having read all of the Harry Potter books, I can see where C.S. Lewis was way ahead of his time! My 9 year old son wants to read them now. Any movie that will get a 9 year old interested in reading is fine by me!

title: A beautiful movie
review:
I was reading The Cronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe about 8 years ago (I'm now 18 years old), and I didn't read it to the end ever, because I didn't like the book. It was too confusing for me (and I was a bad reader) and that's why I considered pretty long whether I should even see this movie. Now I can only say that this movie was worth of paying.

Probably the best thing in the movie was the magnificent visualization and the great sound: the landscapes of Narnia are incredibly beautiful and the voice of Aslan is still shouting through my ears and it isn't caused by the speakers of the cinema. No, the great battle in the end is something I haven't seen since Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings trilogy and the mighty background music was about to blow me away.

One other thing that really surprised me was the animating, which is the most beautiful I've ever seen in any film. All the animals looks almost real and the dubbing couldn't have been done any better. Even the eye of Aslan have been done very well. Unbelievable!!!

Then why I gave only 8 to this movie? I think the only bad thing in this movie was the story: it isn't just my type. I prefer to more mature fantasy stories like The Lord of the Rings. Of course I know this is a movie for children and that is why it doesn't contain any blood or raw scenes, but I think fantasy movies aren't perfect without them. Even so, I can say that the movie was very exciting and that is one reason why I liked it.

The actors in the movie were kind of OK. Most of the main actors were in their perfect roles, but one actor didn't fit very well to her role: Tilda Swinton is in my opinion a good actor, but her appearance didn't fit very well to White Witch, whereas Lian Neeson's voice was just perfect to Aslan.

Anyway, after seeing this movie I've decided to read the whole Chronicles of Narnia series when I have enough time. I hope there will become more Narnia movies in future. This one is definitely worth of seeing for everybody.

title: Truly charming
review: To me, this was an 'old-fashioned' story given the modern movie treatment - and what a triumph it turned out to be. Wonderful acting from the children involved, sumptuous cinematography and truly elegant characterisation all add up to a visual treat. Not being overly familiar with the books (read them too long ago!), the story came as something of a surprise but was beautifully handled and almost effortlessly moved along with its own pace and style. Cannot praise the young cast highly enough, but director Andrew Adamson also deserves special credit for helming a film that is captivating for adults without being childishly simplistic - a rare feat for a PG film. The ultimate accolade I can give it is that 'Narnia' creates the magnificent visual impression of much of 'Fellowship of the Ring,' which, to me, is the peak of modern film-making. Is there something in the New Zealand air.....?

title: True to the spirit of fantasy and Christianity
review:
This movie is superb. Period. Aslan is noble, powerful, regal and benevolent, just as in the story. There is nothing that kills a story like this more than a movie portrayal of a story that depicts the villain(s) being unconvincing, or a character that is supposed to be great and powerful (like Aslan) turning out to be wimpy. This movie hits the jackpot.

And I must admit, the movie is full of color and imaginativeness, all the magic and wonder of a fantasy world like Narnia. So, what's not to like about that? Sure, those people with keener sensitivities as to beauty and aesthetics may enjoy it more than most, but its a definite plus. It is truly amazing what technology can do these days. (The beavers are so adorable!)

The acting is so-so to really quite convincing. Georgie Henley is such a cute little girl! :) She'll melt your heart. She's really quite the actor for her age. The other three kids/teens aren't bad either.

title: Great adaptation
review:
I went into this movie expecting it to be somewhat overdone and slave to special effects, but was pleasantly surprised.

It wasn't quite how I imagined it when I read it as a child, for example, the professor's extravagant house has a life of its own in this movie (you would expect an eccentric British professor to live in something more modest or shabby).

Aslan doesn't let us down and his "sacrifice" for Edmund is just how I remembered it.

Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy do a superb job. The girl who plays Lucy is one of the most naturally gifted young actresses to have come along in a long time.

Hope they do as well with the next book.

title: Narnia was breathtaking!
review:
Narnia was breathtaking! I think my husband and I have been waiting to see this movie since the first time we read the books as children  and this portrayal was everything we've waited for! The scenery was beautiful, and the children did an incredible job  especially since they don't have much prior acting experience (or any experience in Henley's case). Henley made an absolutely adorable Lucy! My children (age 4 & 7) also were spellbound the entire movie. It's only December and my 4 year old is already convinced she's going to be Queen Lucy for Halloween!

Our only real criticism was that the female characters didn't have roles that were as active as they were in the book. They seemed more peripheral in the movie than they were originally written, but Henley and Popplewell did a wonderful job of portraying Lucy and Susan anyway.

The Lion, the Witch & the Wardrobe has easily been added to our list of favorite movies. We hope Disney continues the rest of the Narnia series!

title: Pretty interesting, but...
review:
Harry Potter, LOTR, Harry Potter, LOTR, ... Well, those were the sentences I heard from people who watched this movie before me, so I decided to watch it myself. First of all movie is very interesting, reminds me on my childhood when I have started to create fantasy world, fantasy heroes, characters, etc. so it was kind of fun to watch it. Second, the story itself is amazing but it is based on clichés from other fantasy movies, so you can easily predict what will happen. But to put these two things aside, my grade for this remake shall be 7,5-8

So it all starts in GB during war and four kids from Pevensie family take trip to a safer place, country side. During one session of hide & seek game, from clear curiosity, Pevensies discover magical wardrobe that gives you enter to fantasy world of Narnia ruled by White Witch. Narnia is a world full of imaginary creatures, talking animals, and superpowers. By some prophecy these four kids, sons of Adam and daughters of Eve, are meant to be new kings and queens of Narnia, but before that all good living in this world must face White Witch's army and destroy the dark side. As in every movie good always wins so this one is not exception, kids become honored new rulers of Narnia and live their lives happily, but... Did they forget how the Narnia is entered, well a kind of yes, by magical wardrobe, and so they come back to the real world to find themselves not the minute older and confused by magical things they experienced. (Not a best review but what the hell)

title: Amazing, no other word describes it.
review: I first saw previews for this movie, thinking "Why is everyone making such a big fuss about it, it seemed very childish, and uninteresting to me." So i decided nothing of it. Opening night my brother went and saw it, he said it was "awesome", and i've noticed his taste in movies is fairly decent, so I'm thinking "Maybe it won't be that bad, I mean all my friends thought it was something special, and the box office is making a big deal with it and all, i might as well give it a try." And am I happy that i did? Of course the movie was as my brother said "awesome." It was exciting, and I even had tears in my eyes quite a few times, but i guess i kind of am a wimp when I come to think of it, I've cried in a fair few movies. Well anyways this movie was extraordinary, and not a dull moment. Most of the characters were very likable, except for the White Witch, all of her followers, and at times I wasn't too fond of little Edmund, but Aslan, Tumnis, Lucy, Susan, Peter, and all of the centars, and such were very likable, even lovable (not sure about the spelling on all of the names, I guessed on most.) So overall the movie was magnificent, the characters were very well developed, and lovable, the plot exciting, everything perfect! 9/10

title: Just a copy?
review: This film was a comprehensive, monumental coinage which include dozens of picaresque novels and fantasy films' features. For example The lord of the rings, Harry Potter and the Snowqueen,(Undermentions are my favorite films and books)but these creations are more gripping and memorable. The Narnia is just a copy of these masterpieces or not? I think it's true but this is a little bit more than just a duplicate: this story transmits some standard human intrinsic value like heroism, honest,bravery, sanity and of course love. So it' s a good film, but not more than just a banal tale. Despite of that: Don' t miss the chance to see this film!

title: it has every thing you would want in a movie from its Christ like story to great action to a big heart
review: this is without a doubt the best of 05 star wars was great but lacked hope king Kong was good but lacked great acting potter was good but lacked to stay true to its child like past movies war of the worlds lacked a good ending broke back mountain was about a gay cowboy need i say more this goes to show that you need more than just big effects or a sappy love story to hit the top narnia will be the grand champ of 05 because what this movie is were it came from an its authenticity an if thats not enough proof for you Kong fans and potter fans and star fans than look at the box office numbers not for one week but for the whole run narnia owns Kong and is catching potter and has began its climb towards star wars too so congrats to this years best picture the chronicles of narnia the lion the witch and the wardrobe not just from me or the critics but by the people the box office is the key i give it 10 out of 10 5 out of 5 it owns 05 an deserves it

title: Great Effort. Bring on the sequels!
review:
Overall I thought this movie adaptation was fantastic and it's only recently that the computer technology could catch up with the imagination of CS Lewis. I would heed the warning that young children might find some of the scenes dealing with death a bit disturbing but rest assure there is a happy ending.

Not having read the books, my main introduction to the world of Narnia was actually from the BBC TV series that I enjoyed watching as a kid. What I remembered from it was the gentle, majestic score at the beginning and end of each segment. The BBC did set the bar high for this and while for the most part the score in this Disney movie is competent I don't understand why in certain scene there were synthesised drum machines. It just gave those scenes as extremely cheap, tacky feel to it. The Lord of the Rings managed to avoid this, how hard could it have been.

The little girl who plays Lucy is just brilliant, I was absolutely enchanted by her. The older children's acting was slightly wooden in the beginning of the movie but as it progressed they manage to pull off a good effort.

I thought the casting of the white witch was great as well. It reminded me a lot of the demonic figure in Passion of the Chirst where evil has a tempting look. It's actually weird that as a kid watching the BBC TV series I never cottoned onto the fact the story had Christian overtones to it apart from the reference to the Sons and Daughters of Adam and Eve.

title: fabulous (seen it six times)
review: I couldn't believe my eyes. Since when does a 42-year-old see a movie like this six times--twice in one day? The whole thing is outstanding. The only piece I could do without was the Santa Claus figure (I guess "Father Christmas," since it's British through-and-through except for Oreius the centaur)--it was just too smarmy. Then again, they certainly needed the not-so-peaceable "gifts" he provided. But everything else was wonderful. And never mind Georgie Henley--for my money, Skandar Keynes can out-act anyone three times his age. I predict four Oscars: male lead (Keynes), music, costumes, and effects. Also, I was just a tad disappointed that Aslan just came back to life with little or no attempt at explanation other than "Had the witch truly understood the meaning of sacrifice she might have interpreted the deep magic differently." I did not once get the idea that the witch was an imbecile! And she CERTAINLY could handle swords--who the heck trained her? Two at once against a guy with a shield?? Oh, and her chariot pulled by two polar bears was a cute touch . . . Several viewings later, it just keeps getting better and better. I can't imagine how some people find it "boring" when it's so chock-full of thrilling chases and hairbreadth escapes. Make sure you see it with an evening crowd so that they'll laugh heartily at the wisecracking of the Cockney beaver and the interplay between Maugrim and the fox ("Greetings, gents: lost something, have we?" "Don't patronize me; I know where your allegiance lies. We're looking for some humans," and so forth). I didn't even mind the obvious inconsistencies, e.g., the witch slaps Edmund on the right cheek but he develops a black eye on the _left_ side of his face. But I'm sure you can find Web sites offering far more "inconsistencies" than this obvious one, if that's how people choose to devote their energies.

title: Narnia Reigns... film goes far beyond expectations...
review: As Lewis intended the Biblical themes in this film are blatant but not overbearing for the non-Christian. In short, this film proves to be relevant to everyone. The only issue that I have with this film is that it could have been just a bit longer. While I was emotionally moved by Aslan's sacrifice for the betrayal committed by Edmond, it would have been nice to get to know Aslan better. Some of the complaints about Edmond and Lucy's pre-occupation with Tumnus are overplayed and usually brought up by those who didn't bother reading the books first. Disney does a freakishly good job of shaking it's own stereotype of being "kiddy". This film depicts evil almost on par with the Lord Of The Rings and the effects are nothing short of astounding. One of the films crowning achievements is the epic battle scene between the White Witch and Aslan's army which is by far the best battle sequence ever filmed. Never before have we seen realistic talking animals (polar bears, tigers, rhino's), matador's, griffins, giants etc. in all out war. After having just re-watched the Lord Of The Rings series one thing that stood out about Narnia was that the battle scenes all took place in the day. This challenge for director Andrew Adamson meant that there was not room for errors which could have been hidden in scenes shot against a darker set. Anna Popplewell who plays Susan is perfect for the part and William Moseley was very well cast as Peter who has to come to full maturity as a warrior to protect his family and help save Narnia. Aslan is everything we needed him to be and more carrying as much power as The Lion King and as much authority as Darth Vader, but in a good way. This is a must see film. For Christmas movie fans King Kong pales in comparison. Narnia is not only King at the box-office, it truly is one of the best films you will ever see. Smart people will stay away from pitting this film against Lord Of The Rings much because the films are both brilliant and carry a vital message a faith, hope, a messiah and perseverance which are cornerstones of the Christian faith. They are also proof, that Christianity is not only not boring, it gives creative freedom to depict good and evil with blurring lines and wondering about so called gray areas. I give this film a 7 out of 10. I can't wait to own this on DVD.

title: Great movie, lived to expectation
review: i gotta be quite honest , i went to this movie fearing the worse , after all this story is my all time favorite, i guess i read it 10 times and i was fearing that it will be done as bad as King Kong, but boy was i wrong. the movie was not a masterpiece but it did show all the depth of the story , it times it moved slowly but the pace was reasonable , and i didn't need to check my watch at any point in the movie, the first time since i watched hitchhikers guide to the galaxy. the directing was amazing although the graphics seemed cartonish at times expected due to the HUGE amount of graphics that needs to be generated. the director did well by making the movie less violent than the original story to make it more suitable for kids. the only pick on that movie is that it was made for people who have actually read the story, anyone who haven't would struggle to catch up at some points or just end up feeling it's a lame kids movie, but for people like me who loved the story the movie was absolutely sensational. if you love the lion the witch and the wardrobe go to the move and you will not be disappointed that's my advice. it certainly was some sort of a refund after the huge KING KONG size disappointment in KING KONG. i will certainly go see this movie again.

title: Amazingly done the best Book Adaption yet
review: Not having read the book for quite sometime, I wasn't quite sure what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised the book adapts to the screen well, part of that is C.S. Lewis and his writing. Details and events are described very well. One problem I have noticed with book to screen adaption is that if the novel is long[200pgs+ if 1 page = 1min of film] key events or elements get glossed over or cut out entirely. This film proves that if done correctly and with care everything that needs to be said can be said. The Actors/Actress performances portray the characters to a "T" Caring, sharp and dramatic. The youngest is able to hold a commanding presence at times which I found very good. I'll end it there in case I give something away, Loved it gives 'Goblet of fire' a run for it's money and then some.

title: Narnia and Watchful Dragons
review:
I saw the Chronicles of Narnia today with my 2 nephews and a couple of friends. Wow! It is as good as the hype makes it out to be. If you haven't seen it yet, I encourage you to do so.

When he wrote Chronicles of Narnia, C. S. Lewis wanted the story to get past the "watchful dragons" of young minds trained by an increasingly secular British culture to help the readers understand the good news of Jesus Christ. In this well told story, he does so. In a letter written to a child in March, 1961, C. S. Lewis said,

"The whole Narnian story is about Christ. That is to say, I asked myself 'Supposing that there really was a world like Narnia and supposing it had (like our world) gone wrong and supposing Christ wanted to go into that world and save it (as He did ours) what might have happened?' The stories are my answers. Since Narnia is a world of Talking Beasts, I thought He would become a Talking Beast there, as He became a man here."

I had a great time talking with my junior high age nephews after the movie, slipping by the watchful dragons that often guard our hearts, protecting them from "truth". We chatted about the meaning of the movie and the symbolism of Aslan and the witch. Then came a harder question, whom did Edmund symbolize? Unless one can look in a mirror and say, I ... I am Edmund, one will never be able to grasp the true meaning of Narnia, Aslan, and His redemptive work on the stone table. Are the dragons still guarding your heart?

title: Rare and wonderful movie
review:
Chronicles has accomplished the difficult task of preserving the original author's material and fully incorporating the possibilities of the screen. I was delighted when I heard that C.S. Lewis's stepson, Douglas Gresham, is co-producer of Chronicles; I felt comfortable with the integrity of the movie's plot even before I saw it. My expectations of the animatronics and special effects were not only met, but surpassed. I don't think the story of Narnia could have been told on the screen until now.

You can enjoy this movie and walk out smiling (although I used a couple of tissues, too.) If you are a Christian, you can follow the parable for the story of Jesus. This movie brings a new meaning to "something for everyone".

title: Best movie of 2005
review:
This movie is excellent. The acting is amazing. All four children are innocent and fun to watch, and each has a unique personality. Lucy is wide-eyed and imaginative, Edmund is endearingly conflicted, Susan is prim and intelligent, and Peter is brave. Lucy's facial expressions are particularly good. Jadis, the white witch, is appropriately evil, and Aslan, the lion king of Narnia, is dignified and majestic.

The special effects are also excellent. The animals, including Aslan, are realistic, and the battles are exciting. The music is beautiful, and the pacing is fine. Although the movie feels slightly rushed on very few occasions, I appreciate the fact that the beginning is not rushed. The scenery is beautiful, and the lighting works well in both the scenes that take place at night and those that take place during the day. Additionally, the cinematography perfectly captures the majesty of Narnia. The close-ups are particularly excellent, as they capture the actors' wonderful facial expressions. The costumes, both those of Narnia and of World War II-era England, are glorious and suit the characters well.

"The Chronicles of Narnia" possesses an innocent, glorious beauty similar to that of "The Polar Express" and the first two Harry Potter movies. It surpasses "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" in acting, pacing, visual effects, cinematography, and costumes. Out of the thousands of movies that have been made throughout history, most are mediocre, and some possess true magic. "Narnia" is one of the latter.

title: My whole family just loved it!
review: This book has been a favorite of mine since grade school. When I first heard it was going to be made into a movie, I was both excited and nervous. I believed it would either be great, or be a great disappointment. We chose to take our four children (ages 4, 5, 5, & 8) to see this movie as part of hour Christmas treats. All of them sat still, glued to the screen in awe. The characters had the whole theater alive with laughter, gasps, and cheering. Our children clapped at several parts and they have raved about favorite parts since leaving the theater. It was our 4 year old's first time seeing a movie at a theater, and she now has a very enjoyable experience to remember. I was very happy with this movie.

title: A Fantastic Movie
review: This movie was incredible!! Where do you start when just about everything in this movie was done perfectly! This entertaining movie really should get some points for making the audience actually feel the magic and be entertained, when the movie is based on a children's classic series. Each actor/actress played their part perfectly, and really brought their character to life. However, I must add that one of the actresses, Georgie Henley, played her role as the adorable Lucy Pevensie very, very well. She was able to show rare amounts of emotion for her part, and she didn't make her character wear out the audience with boredom. In this movie, each scene was put together so well, and went together so smoothly, it was quite amazing. The only flaw I think this movie had, was that it started getting boring in the middle. Later on in the movie though, the movie begins to get very interesting, emotional, and exciting. Narnia was an excellent movie, that will keep the most difficult audience to deal with to be asking for more.

title: Enchanting
review:
There quite a few films that can actually enchant, like if you catch the golden bells' ringing and a warm smell that is suddenly filling up your childish mind with gentle memories. It's a kind of magic, of a kind magic.

Having the book read before, I am quite satisfied with the movie, while I wasn't with the Peter Jackson's LOTR. May be because "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" was directed by a man who really loves that lovely book? The only thing that have disappointed me is that the Christian context has been nearly wholly removed, for it was the firmament of the Lewis' books. Aslan is Christ, his incarnation in the world of Narnia. Those who did never read the books will never make it from the movie, and this makes the film rather meaningless.

Nevertheless it's a great adventure for all big and small who has a bit of imagination: masterfully directed, without clichés, amazingly shot, with the great CGI and absolutely wonderfully acted (especially I liked James McAvoy as Mr. Tumnus and of course, Georgie Henley). Superb movie, though the spiritual context would be able to complete the gem.

title: Greatest film
review: One of the best films I have ever seen. I read the book when I was a boy and it was great to relive the story through this film. This is, I believe, quite faithful to the book, and true to C.S. Lewis's thoughts. I loved this film. I won't say too much, as I really think you just have to go and watch it, rather than be told in advance what it is all about. And if you read the book, you should see the film. The special effects are done really well, they add to the enjoyment of the film, without being overdone. Some films are all about special effects. But as this was originally released as a book in 1950, the storyline was already in place a long time ago, and by following that, we have a great story in the film, which holds the attention throughout. Not one boring part at all. And great music.

title: Wonderful!!!
review: This movie is awesome!!! I love the books, and I was thrilled as to how accurate the movie was to the book. The scenes were just as I imagined them! My only complaint is that they didn't come out with the actual first book in the series: "The Magician's Nephew." "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" was the first book written, but "The Magician's Nephew" is the creation of Narnia, and it explains many things that are often understood in the other books, such as why there is a lamppost in the middle of the forest, why this particular wardrobe was the one through which they found Narnia, how the Professor knows so much about Narnia, and the list goes on. Anyway, back to the movie. It is the best movie I have ever seen. It is the only movie I think I could watch over and over again. I love it!!! Part of the reason I love it so much is because there are so many symbols of the story of Christ throughout the story. C.S. Lewis was a Christian writer, and he purposely put those symbols there. Aslan (Christ) created Narnia (the World) and serves the Emperer Beyond the Seas (God). The three ropes that Aslan is tied with represent the three nails that held Christ up on the cross. The Stone table represents the cross. Susan and Lucy are Aslan's disciples. They kept him company on the night before his death, just as the disciples of Christ kept him company in the Garden of Gethsemene. The earthquake after Aslan's death represents the earthquake after the death of Christ. The broken Stone Table represents the torn curtain of the temple. After the earthquake, Susan and Lucy represent the two Marys that return to the tomb of Christ after he is risen. The risen Aslan represents the risen Christ. The prophesy that Aslan will return represents the many prophesies in the Bible that Christ was to come. It is said that Aslan will one day return to his people, as Christ will one day return to us. The Battle at the end of the story represents the Battle of Good and Evil. There is so much more represented in the movie that I haven't mentioned here, but the point is that this is the best movie I have ever seen, and I can't wait until it comes out on video! I love this movie!!!

title: Heartstopping, energetic, the truly amazing epic of 2005
review: I have always been a huge fan of C.S. Lweis's novel's of the Cronicles of Narnia, so I was a bit hesitant to go see this movie since I was sure I would be disappointed. How wrong I was. My eyes were glued to the screen the entire time, everything from the music, the animation of the talking animals, the costumes, the makeup and effects of the fauns, even the slide transitions were absolutely amazing. I can truthfully say (and I don not say this lightly) this might be the best , most moving movie that I have ever seen in my life. I would recommend this movie to anyone and everyone, young and old. Everyone can find something in this movie. It brought me back to my childhood where I used to play Narnia with my brothers and sister, where I was Susan, and it make you want to route for the good guys, where on other movies you're like, good guys are no fun. It is the best movie I have ever seen, placing it with movies like the Colour Purple, Imaginary Hero's, even Oscar winning the Lord of the Rings. I would change nothing about this movie, and I guarantee that you can see it again, and again, and never get tired of it.

title: Perfect
review:
Among about 4000 movies I have seen in my life, this one is really special. It somehow combines my favourite genres, and in such a good style! Battle episodes, fairytale, even some suspense... And excellent, really excellent cast! Not to mention the special effects which are unbelievable.

I did like the Hurry Potter, but this movie is definitely my new most favourite fairytale! When I had left the cinema, I spent few minutes to understand where I was and what should I do. Aha, I came to my bicycle locked near - and again got stuck: forgot what to do? Why bicycle, why not a griffin or lion?? And that cat near the corner - will it tell me something??

title: A great and inspiring movie!
review: Saw it yesterday and I was really impressed, it gave me inspiration to life. It's such a wonderful story that just fills u up with hope. The characters are great and they are believable. Aslan is the mighty power of goodness and hope and the witch is just as evil as she should be. They contrast each other so beautifully. The only things that could have been left out are some stupid "supposed to be fun-comments" that pop up here and there. Luckily they are not many. They could also have cut back on the computer animations. But still, I think ILM has done a good job on this one. On a whole it is a masterpiece, portraying evil and good in the most fantastic way. WOW WHAT A MOVIE!

title: The best Disney movie ever!!!
review: From the beginning I know that this movie was going to blow me away, but it did more then that. The Chronicals of Narnia is a must see movie. The special effects, and fantasy battle puts Lord of the Rings to shame, heck it beats it with a metal bat. The C.G. animals are amazingly life-like, and the voice actors couldn't be more perfect. I really enjoyed the wolf character, as well as the fox. Warning though, this movie is a tear jerker so if you or your loved ones are sensitive to animal violence then stay away because some of this stuff gets pretty brutal, but it not like its over the top Kill Bill blood and guts flying everywhere kind'a thing, in fact there is only one scene I can remember seeing any blood, but that doesn't take away the fact that it still makes a great movie for both kids and adults. This is the finest movie I have seen created by Disney in a long time. It seems to me that when it comes to making epic movies Disney is really on the ball.

title: Better than Potter and lotr put together
review: All of the elements of theater are excellently used to create a film that is every bit as enchanting as the novel. From the moment the movie started to the second it ended, I sat on the edge if my seat. The casting was amazing. All of the children showed great skill. The kids all looked the part, and their acting was equally fitting. The effects were great I barley noticed that they were effects at all. When Lucy walked through the wardrobe I saw the image of Narnia that had been in my head since childhood. I felt like I was really there. I hated the witch, loved Aslan, was afraid for the kids, hopeful for Narnia's future, and sad that it ended so soon. If you see ONE movie this holiday season make it The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe. If you see two movies, watch it again. I will be the first in line to see the sequel, and I will see this one many times before then.

title: Great Movie for the WHOLE family
review: The movie was beautifully filmed and great to watch for the whole family. In a day and age where we are so immersed into violence on film (in order to make a film great)... it is great to see a family film which is safe to watch with the kids. My kids loved the movie and my wife and I loved it more. Its exciting from beginning to end. The acting is superb, and the cinematography is a must to watch on the big screen. Don't miss this one. We brought the whole family ages 4 and up. The 4yr old held my hand a little tight some moments... but they all loved it. Parents should be aware with what their kids watch on film... for those parents who care...This is by far a great movie for the family - you will love to experience this adventure together... plus makes great family discussion afterward.

title: Outstanding fantasy tale brought to the movie screen
review: I have read many comments on The Chronicles of Narnia discussing that the movie made contained to many mistakes and the director was the wrong choice for the movie. I have also read that the relationship in the movie built between Lucy and Mr. Tummus was inappropriate. I have to say i think anyone who questions this movie is off base. Narnia is a wonderfully made movie with great acting from all angles. Lucy gives one of the best child performances I have seen in a movie. The story is outstanding and the action mixed with the storyline give us as an audience more than enough excitement to cover the entire movie. Narnia gives us a movie that is similar to the Lord of the Rings in the end. All of us enjoyed the Lord of the Rings as it is ranked in the top ten of the IMDb database, but somehow Narnia will not be put in that class. In the end this is an amazing movie and anyone who loves great acting combined with action and adventure should spend their money and watch this movie.

title: Childhood fantasy come to life
review:
Who amongst us had not dreamed of being a King or Queen of Narnia as we breathlessly plowed through its mystical world? As a child I could not imagine that one day I would see it come to life on the big screen, told with remarkable accuracy. What a stupendous moment.

And yet, like the old world that the children leave in The Last Battle, the film, despite its remarkable special effects, is not quite as vibrant and deep as the Narnia I had created in my head. Is it because, as Movie Guy Blogs Com suggests in his review, some of the actors didn't show their character's true mettle (I agree Tilda Swinton could have done better - maybe she should have read the book first)? Or is it because, no matter how clever the special effects are, they cannot replicate the verdant fertility of the imagination?

Either way it was a trifling disappointment to bear in the face of what is a wonderful representation of the mastery of C.S Lewis. Bring on Prince Caspian!

title: Magical, fabulous, and wonderfully old fashioned
review: I can only recommend it to those young, and the young-at-heart. If you like classic Fantasy - from the likes of Tolkien, Lloyd Alexander or the very Mr. C. S. Lewis - you must not miss it. Not only is it quite true to the book's words, but it is IMHO also true to it's spirit. There are two or three minor changes, but they really are so minor they do not affect the story or your viewing pleasure. The cast is very good, the FX are precisely there when they are needed - and only then. The dialog seems at times a little bit modernized, but not so much as to spoil the 1940's/1950's feel. Without spoilers, I cannot say much more. See for yourselves.

title: Excellent movie!!
review: I don't want to write any spoilers, so I'll keep this short. I read the whole series when I was younger and I've always loved all the books in it. I didn't really expect the movie to be as good as it was because until the last few years (with the making of movies like The Lord of the Rings trilogy and the Harry Potter series), movies based on books have largely been let-downs. But that was definitely not the case with this movie!! I was amazed that they fit so much from the book into the movie; it seems like almost nothing was left out, certainly nothing important. I am so happy to finally see one of my all-time favorite books visually rendered so well. I am very excited at the prospect of seeing the rest of the series come to life on screen as beautifully as this one has. This movie is absolutely worth full ticket price, hands down.

title: We're not heroes - we're from Finchley!
review:
This is a wonderful film for the entire family. The effects are staggering, and the story is faithful to the original story - The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe.

Two sons of Adam and two daughters of Eve C.S. Lewis was a great storyteller and a great theologian. He was able to weave together elements from fairly orthodox Christian belief into metaphoric stories that show a classic battle between good and evil in ways that transcend the purely Christian context. Elements such as the innocence and wonderment expressed by children, the power of nature and natural elements, the struggle between good and bad - these are things that have been shown in mythological and cultural stories from the most ancient of times up to the modern day television serials. They are brought to a strong pitch here in this film, hopefully the first of several installments of the rest of the Chronicles of Narnia.

One needn't be Christian to enjoy these tales, nor must one subscribe to any particular theology to find them accessible - this really isn't evangelism as it is known via 'televangelism' today.

The director Andrew Adamson and writers Ann Peacock, Christopher Markus, and Stephen McFeely worked with the estate of C.S. Lewis to strive to remain faithful to Lewis' original vision in terms of story and characters, but also to allow for the developments of technological expression that permit fuller visualisation than Lewis could give. This also occurs in the acting - the four leading roles of children are played by relative newcomers: Georgie Henley plays Lucy, Skandar Keynes plays Edmund, William Moseley plays Peter, and Anna Popplewell plays Susan - the four Pevensie children exiled from London during the war, thrust into an austere and severe household in the country that is full of real-life mystery apart from the wardrobe that holds the portal to Narnia. The film is very faithful to the spirit of Lewis' work, as well as much of the detail of the stories. This makes this a good companion to encourage reading.

Narnia is presented not as a fantasy or dream (a la Peter Pan or Wizard of Oz), but rather as a real place; comparisons will be made with the Lord of the Rings trilogy in many respects (including the incredible scenery from New Zealand mountainous regions), but one primary difference here is that the connection to the real world here is very real indeed. The White Witch, portrayed by Tilda Swinton, is played in a very realistic way - she represents what children fear the most, not as much bloody violence and evil as much as a cold detachment and lack of caring and compassion (something that children in all eras find frightening). Just as the place is real, the children are real, and the situations in the real world are just as harrowing as those in Narnia. However, in Narnia (unlike the real world) it is the children who have the real power.

The CGI effects are astounding, but the voices bring the real life to the characters. Actors such as Liam Neeson (Aslan), Rupert Everett (Fox) and Dawn French (Mrs. Beaver) add their unique personalities to the characterisations of the animal roles. Things are done in a truly wonderful way.

This is a film for all ages, and all sorts of people who love a good story.

title: Good
review: Though starting of at a very slow pace, Narnia gradually gets interesting. Defects are numerous, the music standard, and the acting is sometimes poor, but, on the other hand, the special effects were convincing, especially for the animated characters, such as the lion (which was surprisingly believable), some wolves, and other various beasts. Many scenes, throughout the film, are very "clichÃ©" and some have a slightly odd look, due to inadequate color balance between actors/landscape/effects. Costumes, Items, Weapons could have had better designs, or at least some cultural/esthetic signs. The monsters were also a touch uninventive, and looked more like toys rather than beasts. Anyway, the story remains a nice one, which makes this movie good and definitely entertaining.

title: The version every fan of the book has waited for
review: As someone who grew up with the C.S. Lewis Narnia books this version of 'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' is the one I have long waited for. Prior to this we had the 1978 animated movie and a rather low-budget BBC series, and while both were adequate neither really managed to truly capture the imagination as completely as the book has for generations of readers. Thankfully the success of the LOTR movies gave Buena Vista the courage to attempt this excursion into the fantasy realm and the result is a truly remarkable movie filled with wonder and spectacle. It really has to be seen to be believed and certainly on the big screen where all its majesty can be effectively conveyed.

title: Narnia
review:
The movie The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe is the best movie I've seen in two years. All of the things in the movie that were computer animized (like making the wolves talk) was really good i couldn't even tell. I love this move and am buying it as soon as it comes out on DVD. I have seen a lot of movies and this is one of the best. The plot of the movie goes almost exactly with the book which is good because a lot of movies that are based on books don't follow the plot, but this ones is very good at that. I am a big fan of this book and was hoping that the movie would be a lot like the book because it is good enough already and doesn't need to be changed. I was very surprised by the fact that the directer and screenplay writers did a good job on making the movie an almost exact replica of the book

Thank You for this amazing, and entertaining movie

title: Chronicles of Narnia 10x better than Kong, Brokeback Mtn. etc
review: I and my grandchildren absolutely loved this movie! We saw it twice now. They are also seeing it with their classes. And I will be taking my Sunday School class to it. I've never done that before! It far exceeded my expectations. We even bought all the snacks and large containers of popcorn to show our support to the cinema for showing it. I have personally recommended it to my entire church friends and family and am endorsing it to anyone who inquires what they should go see this weekend. Keep these movies coming Hollywood, you did really well this time. It's about time that family movies with substance and moral values make a comeback in America, I can't speak for anyone else out there but as for myself, my grandkids and I are starving for thoughtful and meaningful movies with no sex, or foul language or even excessive violence. This movie was able to capture our imagination and attention for the duration of the film and my grand-daughter always has to go to the bathroom 1/2 thru any movie, not this one. Kudos!!!

title: Excellent Rendition of Classic Favorite
review: I've loved this allegorical series by C.S. Lewis since I was a small child, and have seen it performed in many styles from Broadway to cartoon. The BBS version sits beside Star Wars, Harry Potter and LOTR in my collection, though I must confess of these the Narnia series is my favorite. I looked forward to seeing the Disney magic (and money) put to making a version that included modern technological wizardry. I was not disappointed. The children selected for the movie did an admirable job and closely matched my mental image of the characters. The action was fast-paced, and the animated characters were believable and smooth. Fenris Olf will give you shivers, and Aslan is inspirational. The story was true to the book, and very few parts were skipped (which made for a long movie). If you are taking small children, consider previewing the piece because the battle scenes are quite realistic and the bad guys are truly scary. The attack on Aslan was vivid and the creatures as dark as depicted in the book.

title: Simply phenomenal...
review:
This movie was simply magical and wonderful.

The timeless classic story by C.S. Lewis has been faithfully and well adapted to the movie screen.

All the cast members were well cast with each of the Pevensie kids really filling their respective roles just how they were written in the books. Edmund and Lucy especially I think were the two challenging roles that Skander Keynes and Georgie Henley did an absolute wonderful job in. From the sibling jealousy and bitterness felt by Edmund in the beginning to his sincere feelings of remorse and guilt in the last half to Lucy's accurate and realistic portrayal of child-like joy and sorrow, the kids nailed their parts.

And who can forget the performance by Swinton as the White Witch? I honestly believe she deserves an Oscar nod. As a devout fan of the book I had real doubt in her ability to pull off the White Witch and even when she first appeared in the movie I thought she was miscast. But by the last half of the movie she sheds all doubts as she portrays Jadis the White Witch in all her icy, fierce, terrifying ways. When she first appears on the climactic battlefield with her cold eyes intently gazing as she's being drawn by her chariot I was blown away. Swinton was simply amazing.

There are two things about this movie I think that is leading to the negative reviews and opinions of this movie.

The first is the fact that this movie comes after the success of similar veined movies so that one cannot help drawing comparisons to others such as the wonderful Lord of the Rings trilogy. As a PG-rated movie, this movie shows no blood and the fighting is less violent (though certainly not disappointing). But while the Lord of the Rings series (both the movies and the books) were geared towards a more older audience, the Chronicles of Narnia was geared towards an audience of all ages. Hence the slower pace and more simple themes. The movie, like the book, is for an audience of all ages and demographics. The central theme of bravery, love, justice, forgiveness is not watered down and yet it is not too complex so that even a child can understand the messages behind it.

The second is the fact that this movie is so faithful to the book. While certain minor details (such as the witch having been said to be extremely tall in the book) may be different, no major act or scene is cut out. So for viewers of this movie who have not read the book before, they may find the movie drawn out or slow at times but if they had read the book, they would realize that the speed and sequence of events are for a reason. For example, they give a glimpse of the personality of the Pevensie children and some of the reasons why they are that way.

But bottom line, this movie will appeal to the kids, the kids in the adult's hearts, and anyone else in between. I've seen quite a few number of movies and I had goosebumps the entire last 30 minutes of the movie. But don't let my words hype it up for you. Go see for yourself and read the book if you have not yet. As wonderful as the movie is, the book is in a league of its own.

I sincerely hope that they continue making movies of the rest of the series. Not to replace the books of course but to hopefully draw other viewers to the original magnificence of the books themselves.

title: The movie won over this skeptic
review:
I should start by saying that I LOVE the books. They are among my favorite books of all time and I still re-read them as an adult. I've worn out copies of some of them. So, when I say I was skeptical, it was not of the story, but of the ability to translate it onto film and do it justice. I was terrified that Aslan would end up being silly - and the story doesn't work if Aslan comes off as silly. I was worried that they would make so many story changes that I would no longer recognize it and would spend the entire movie comparing and contrasting the book and the movie. On the flip side, I was worried that it might just not work on film for people who didn't know the books. But, my doubts are cleared up.

This is truly a masterpiece. There are some flaws. And some differences between the movies and the books. But there is nothing that guts the characters or the story or the world of Narnia. Well, there is one thing. It is in some ways a minor thing. But, in C.S. Lewis's Narnia, NO ONE would EVER ride a Talking Horse except in an emergency (the battle would qualify, the later scene would not) and if they did, said horse would not be wearing a bridle. The Talking Beasts of Narnia are free creatures just like all of us - the implication that Phil becomes "Edumund's" horse is just flat out contrary to the rules Lewis established for the way Narnia works. It sounds like a small thing, but to those who really love the books, it is no small thing - it is a very big thing, actually. That said, big thing or not to the world of Narnia, it is a very small part of the movie, so I can overlook it. The rest of the movie was magnificent.

My only other nitpick is that they didn't give the White Witch blood red lips - the one descriptive piece Lewis gave about her - and he gave it several times. I also found it difficult to believe that Edmund would be deceived by her beauty and apparent kindness, as he was in the books, given the way they played her. But, that aside, the performance was outstanding.

The children were absolutely wonderful. I thought the effects were terrific. There were some logic inconsistencies - like why the White Witch doesn't just kill Edmund so there are no longer four to sit in the thrones ... but that's an inconsistency that is never explained in the books, either, so I must fault Mr. Lewis for that one.

Some of the changes are for the better. For example, Lewis's blatant sexism is gone, much to my relief (I always had to overlook that in my enjoyment of the books - rather like his blatant racism in the books that address Calormene). Some changes, I suspect, were for pacing reasons. Some were to explain plot points without a narrator (like showing the air raid and bomb shelter sequence). None of them cut the heart of the story or of any of the characters, however and almost none of them were inconsistent with the work of C.S. Lewis. And THAT is what I was really worried about.

I love the nods to book fans - the little details that people who hadn't read and re-read the books would miss - Lucy leaving the wardrobe door open, and Edumund shutting it ... "he's not a tame lion".

My only other comment, and it has nothing to do with the movie really, is that someone really needs to teach Alanis Morrisette (I think it was her) how to pronounce "wunder kind" - she butchered it repeatedly and it was distracting.

In the end, I walked out of the theater relieved - and planning to see it again, and buy the DVD and hoping that they would make the rest of them. So, yes, it was a big hit with me! And Alan Lee did another superb job designing a magnificent movie!

title: Well directed, acted and graphics are very well done
review: I went to this movie not sure what to expect. My wife wanted to see it so I tagged along. I was pleasantly surprised at many elements of the movie. One of the most dangerous failures I find in movies like this is obnoxious child actors. Very few films actually get kids that don't grate on my nerves. I felt all these kids did incredibly well with their parts and interacted well with the CGA's that were in this movie. From what my wife says the story was pretty true to the book. Unlike the Harry Potter movies (I can fall asleep, and usually do, and wake up and feel like I didn't miss anything)this movie was well paced and kept my interest the entire time. I definitely recommend this movie to those who would like a well produced fantasy movie that puts emphasis on the importance of family.

title: this film is fantastic!
review: this film was excellent, i have never heard the story before, have not watched the old version/s, or read the books to this film and i absolutely love this film. i would recommend going to see it because it's brilliant! The lion effects in the film were fantastic and it actually looked real, everything in the film looked real, i went in and i saw it from everybody's point of view, it was like a fairytale. This film did not have much violence in it, which is good for the little ones if you want to go along with your kids, and they will absolutely love it! And you will love the film too! You will come away and you will want to see it over and over again!

title: Beaver for Parliament!
review:
I liked the Narnia books as a child, and I really enjoyed this movie. It is simply amazing what can be done with computer imaging these days. The creatures in Narnia were all completely believable.

Now as to the real stars of the show (as far as I'm concerned): Mr. and Mrs. Beaver. These two working-class heroes of Narnia really deserve a film or perhaps a television series of their own. I would love to go to their home for a nice cuppa and chat about the state of the world and things in general. Perhaps they could have a news show or something on the BBC and offer commentary. Barbara Walters should do an interview.

Better yet, Mr. Beaver should stand for Parliament! I want to see him challenging Tony Blair on television! More policemen and hospitals for Narnia!

Excellent movie, overall.

title: Absolutely faithful to C. S. Lewis's vision.
review: This film perfectly realized the book "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" (The Chronicles of Narnia: the first chronicle). Even though I know the book by heart and know the mythology, history, and philosophy on which it is based, the film grasped me from the first moment and never let me go. After some time, perhaps the first half-hour, the tears were streaming down my face continually. The book is, of course, an allegory of the Christian myth. All the details were allegorized perfectly. Passages from the sacred scriptures of the Christians, and moments from the entire history of the Christian faith and culture, came continually into my mind as I watched the film. Here is an instance. When Peter is given his shield, the armorial bearing blazoned thereon is an emblem of Aslan. The emblem is red. Immediately into my mind leapt "In hoc signo vinces." The accompaniment of Aslan by Lucy and Susan, until he must go on alone, resonates beautifully with the versions of the story of the Garden of Gethsemane. Aslan's progression to the altar of sacrifice, his progressive stripping and humiliation, and the Witch's triumphant shout, "Behold the great cat," echoes perfectly "Ecce homo."

title: In my opinion not so bad, but no so good too (may contain spoilers)
review:
I know that many people will hate me for what i'm going to say, but in my opinion the first two hours of narnia definitely are not good, they take so much time to get to the action, the performance of the actors was good (except for the annoying girl that plays lucy's role, i hope she do a better performance in the next movies), definitely the actress for the white witch made a great great performance and the role suits with her ;) (specially in the last battle scene with the carriage and the polars bears) the last battle was impressive and the effects in all the movie were incredible in all senses. well nothing more to say, only that narnia is a good movie but with some extra touches could be even better than LOTR

L.

title: Narnia packs us with all the characters of Harry Potter, and all the style of Lord of the Rings, but most of all-it's great fun for Christmas
review:
--Only tiny spoilers through-out-- Yes, this is it! The Chronicles of Narnia is the next big fantasy hit, along with Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter. It is not only up there with them, but packs all the characters of Harry Potter and all the style of Lord of the Rings.

I will start from the beginning. In the first scene, an English family is being bombed by Nazi planes. So, the family runs off, and the children are sent away on a train to go live with "The Professor." (I guess it is no coincidence that English children being sent away to live with relatives also happened in Harry Potter.) They think that it is going to be an exciting journey, but they were wrong. To entertain themselves, the four children play hide-and-seek. While trying to find a hiding spot, Lucy (one of the children) stumbles upon a covered wardrobe. Of course, we all know what this means. After seeing it happen before in many other stories and movies, we know that Lucy found a portal to another world. There, she meets Mr. Tumnus, a cheerful fantasy creature who actually plans to kidnap her. (I remember somebody like that in Harry Potter.) Of course, more adventures happen, and when the children finally all gather into Narnia (this scene does take a while to get to) they go on different adventures and meet different characters, such as talking animals (just like the talking books in Harry Potter) and even, (just in time) Santa Clause! (Keep in mind that Santa gives away weapons in this film.)

Okay, so far we have talked about the characters in Harry Potter. So, what about the style of Lord of the Rings? Well, the audience is treated to wonderful music (part of which creates the fantasy environment in Lord of the Rings) and some of the most wonderful detail. What am I talking about? I am talking about the amazing effects of the castle, the weapons, the creatures and the special effects. (especially when people turn to stone) Not to mention, the war scene isn't as breath-taking as the one in Lord of the Rings: Return of the King, but it sure comes close! Plus, the camera angles of the griffins dropping rocks on the army resemble that of Legolas killing the elephants. They both show lots of detail of the war beneath them.

This was an excellent film! The world of Narnia is full of fun and creativity. It just didn't blow us away as much as Harry Potter or Lord of the Rings. Either way, it still ranks among them.

8/10

Feel free to send me a Private Message regarding this comment.

title: Good film, great dialogue, liked a lot.
review: Having seen this film twice I have felt that it definitely warrants more than one viewing. The opening scenes are good and whilst they are not vital to the story they set up a running theme throughout the film which works well. This film is brilliant from a personal perspective due to the way in which it sticks closely to the books. The children are on the whole good, Lucy is very adorable, peter suitably unsure of how best to protect the others and Susan and Edmund are suitably sullen in places, whilst when they do open up they become charming characters. The voices are done well and on the whole the animation is well done. A few problems with to much CG and a lack of dialogue ruin some of the battle moments however the battle itself is well done and suitably different enough from Lord of the Rings not to have me sitting their looking for elves and the armies of Mordor. Generally well done and, considering the certificate, a very well done film.

title: Wow this was a great movie
review: I really enjoyed this action pact movie. It was able to take you into the world of narnia and make you feel for the characters. I have never read the books so this film was completely new for me. The film began with a lot of info about time frame and setting as well as introducing the main characters, This was done very well as i did not get bored hearng the history of the situation. I even feel that this information part could have had more to it explaining more indepthly the relationships of the characters in the story. After this though, the movie jumped into even more intense explanations. The Characters of Narnia had to be explained as well what had happened in Narnia. This part moved too slowly and in fact caused me to be somewhat frustrated( when you see the movie you will see why). After this explanation the story begins to unfold showing the audience the realm of Narnia and its inhabitance. The one thing that I found to be done less than perfect was the animation. Some of the animation looked almost cartoon like when it was meant to be real life, and often the use of color was over played and almost looked corny. I did enjoy this movie and encourage all to see it also

title: To Narnia!
review:
I just saw this movie, and I really must say that it is at least in my top 3 favorite movies of all time. The acting was wonderful, the cast was great, the special effects were extraordinarily believable, and the movie did not demolish the book. I was swept away by how wonderfully it was made and performed, and would HIGHLY recommend it to anyone who has even the slightest interest in seeing it.

There were definite improvements to the book, however. First of all, I did not imagine Edmund to be as evil-looking as he did in the movie (this is a good thing). Skandar Keynes did a great job of portraying the greed and evilness of the character, then again with his apologetic and "Crap. I really messed up." looks. William Moseley did a fantastic job of playing Peter, and his acting was exceptional. He really showed at least me up at how believable his sword-fighting and charisma can be. Anna Popplewell was also great in being the motherly figure, and was very funny in some of her lines. Lastly, Georgie Henley was soo cute as Lucy, and did a great job playing her. Basically, congratulations to the WHOLE cast!!!

Overall, I give The Chronicles of Narnia 10 out of 10 stars, for every reason imaginable. TO NARNIA!!!

title: One viewing is never enough
review:
I just came back from my second viewing of "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"--unlike the four Pevensie children, we lucky young-at-heart can use the wardrobe over and over! As so many have said before, Almost nothing is left out, and what little is added does not detract from CS Lewis' wonderful story. At first I wondered if I could accept different looks from my firmly entrenched views on the "look" of Narnia (i.e, the original illustrations by Pauline Baynes), but no fear--and Tilda Swinton's splendidly malevolent White Witch was the only character (here seen with blondish dreadlocks, heavy white gown and an icicle crown) who appeared different. Actually her performance was, I think, an improvement on the somewhat stilted original character, what with her icy (no pun intended) manner, drop-dead eyes and Samurai-like way with a wand.

The plot, once again, is a model of faithfulness to Lewis, with an added prologue reminding us WHY the children are being sent out of London. I suppose though, that it is a little jarring to suddenly see the four children matured into adulthood as rulers of Narnia--just one of those things you accept when reading a book, but find odd in a feature length film.

The technical aspects of the film were very well done--better than "Lord of the Rings", where I could tell differences between real actors and CG "extras". At one point, I actually stopped thinking of the friendly beavers (and Mr. Tumnus' hooves) as CGI. And anyway, shouldn't good film-making help you to suspend disbelief? The acting was wonderful too. In addition to the afore-mentioned Ms. Swinton, four exceptional youngsters more than hold their own--they make you believe in them as a family. I particularly liked the bond of affection between Peter & Lucy, well shown as she cajoles them into a game of hide-and-seek; with a perfect look of weary big-brother kindness, he starts counting "one, two,three..." and Lucy unexpectedly stumbles on the wondrous land of Narnia in her hiding-place.

This can (and should) be enjoyed by anybody regardless of their world view (The Narnia books' Christian symbolism was never a problem for me, it actually brought me closer to God). There is nothing to offend here and everything to delight and warm the heart. I'm off to investigate my walk-in closet.....

title: Amazing story, special effects
review:
awesome sums up my experience. Long movie!, it flies by as the film is very engaging and the filming is beautiful. I always dread a Disney production that is not animated because I don't think they do as well, but this is absolutely fabulous. Yes there is some violent parts in the battle, but no blood is seen and it is clear cut between good and evil.The theater was filled with children and as I would normally be annoyed by the noise the kids make, in this theater they were extremely quiet which means to me, that the movie has what it takes to keep their attention. Hooray for another excellent film.

A must see on the big screen for all ages.

title: Chronicles of Narnia (One of the best movies)
review: I thought the movie was the best movie i have seen in years. The plot and effect and costume design and everything about the movie was perfect. The cast and crew is what made this movie the way it was. If you want to argue against me then go ahead take a shot. i thought it was flawless 2 thumbs up.. I hope they make more movies from the other books that were sequels to the movie. I loved the ending because they go back out of the wardrobe and are children again. What happens when they enter it later will they go back to Narnia as adults or start over as children. There are so many questions left to be answered i hope they make some kind of sequels.

title: Great Adaptation
review:
I just read The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe for the first time and I only had one regret. I wish I had discovered Narnina when I was still a child. It was a wonderful book, but I bet there is something magical in reading it as a child, but I was determined to read it before I saw the movie and I was determined to see the movie because there are so few movies with strong moral story lines being released today.

So, last night, I went to see the movie. I have never seen a better adaptation of a book into a movie. There were no significant changes to the basic plot. Those differences that existed were there to tell things that the narrator was able to explain in the book.

I was pleased with the job the young actors did in their parts. They were all able to carry the innocence and be endearing without being overbearingly cute (with the exception of Georgie Henley as Lucy, but I think that's just because she's at the age where her teeth are too big for her mouth). I think James McAvoy stole the show as the conflicted Mr. Tumnus. He said a lot with his facial expressions. I can't say as much about Tilda Swinton in the role of the White Witch. She was too mechanical in her role. The White Witch should have been much more passionate in her hatred. Swinton seemed robotic.

To touch on the deeper meaning of the story, the parallel with the Christian gospel, I was much more moved by Aslan's sacrifice than the entire movie "The Passion of the Christ." At the same time, I appreciated the cinematography involved in his sacrifice, though I do warn that there are a few scenes that might be difficult for small or sensitive children.

My only problem came with some of the CGI effects. Oh, I thought Aslan was well done and I was quite fascinated to watch the faun's legs move. The sloppy animation came when the humans were obviously against a blue screen. The backgrounds were not as seamless as similar movies.

Of course, to go back to my statement at the beginning that I wished I had discovered Narnina when I was a child, I was just as excited during the trailers when I saw the preview for the next Pirates of the Carribbean. Is it me, or does this one not look as good as the first? Whatever your age, discover Narnina today.
