title: Good but not great
review:
As a movie it is a good. As a representation of the book it is mediocre. Most of the wonderful words and dialogue from the books are dumbed down in the movie. The beavers, wolves, and Ginarrbrik are especially awful (corny dialogue, badly animated, etc). It seemed like the people who made the movie were not huge fans of the book (they may have liked it, but you could tell that they did not love it).

Visually it was pretty nice (besides some of the animations), but basically, whoever wrote the script needs to be replaced before the next movie comes out. C.S Lewis would have never written some of the crap the actors were made to say in the movie.

Certain small details I enjoyed (never closing the wardrobe door, as is stressed several times in the book...the white stag...etc). The final battle was well done, but the fight between Peter and Maugrim was very anticlimactic. It was well cast...the children and the witch were very well done...though I thought the professor could have been better (he was a bit too goofy).

It definitely could have been better...hopefully in the next one they will get someone who can better interpret the book to a screenplay and ditch the corny dialogue...especially when the original dialogue from the book is so wonderful and strong! The average viewer will most probably like it. Lovers of the book, however, may find some bits lacking...

title: Narnia !
review: I went and saw Narnia on opening weekend and it was the coolest thing i had ever seen. I have been waiting rather impatiently to see this movie as I am a very big fan of the Chronicles of Narnia. The first half an hour was dead on to the actual book, Which I was thrilled about. From there however the story line suffered a few add ins which was a tad disappointing considering it was extremely accurate to begin with. But as we all know everything goes Hollywood at some point, but I was really hoping this would stay true. The special effects were not half bad. And all the actors and actresses did a wonderful job. Not to mention that Liam Neeson is a perfect pic for the voice of Aslan. Lets not forget Tilda Swinton. Good gracious. All in all I give it an 8. Way to go guys.

title: good vs evil?
review: This movie was good if your trying to go to a "family" film but i wasn't i wanted to lord of the rings type good vs evil battle for the world but this wasn't! The point where Aslan comes back to life was the MOST IMPORTANT part of the book and it was treated as nothing in the movie! Plus the white witch was obviously evil but Aslan was not obviously good. This was not a obvious good vs evil thing. This was not supposed to be a "family" film. This book was showing a Biblical metaphor for Jesus (Aslan)counqering death and saving the world. I think that the whole movie should be redone and raise the rating to pg-13 and show a battle between good and evil. Over all i wouldn't buy this movie but it was worth (barly) five dollars to see it

title: Really Good Movie
review: This movie was really good. It was very bright and heroic, and it really captured me. In my opinion, it is one of the best Disney movies. Some parts are a little violent, but you don't bring a five year old kid to a PG movie. The scenes were so well done, they looked really real. And it was funny at some points too. I also like how they picked no names for the characters, it really gave it a sense of realism, and it made the movie even more enjoyable. It also had a good story to it. And all the fighting scenes were more bright, which gave them a happier, heroic feeling. Movies like the lord of the rings are darker, but this is a great movie. I recommend it for the whole family, just don't bring really young children. A must see this Christmas.

title: Wonderful! Works can hardly say how I feel!!!!!!
review:
I just saw this movie, fearing of story changes, bad acting, and a push on Religion! I left feeling a feeling I haven't felt from a movie in quite some time! The whole story, in my opinion, is true to the book and then some. It has everything I could ask for and more. It's true that there is a religious tone given to us from C.S. Lewis, but while you watch the movie (unless you're looking for it) only enough to set the mood shines through and you are left with a compelling story.

Every actor, big and small, did absolutely fabulous! From Tilda Swinton (White Witch) to the four children, Georgie Henley (Lucy: cutest girl in creation) Skander Keynes (Edmund) Anna Popplewell (Susan) and William Moseley (Peter: very handsome I may say!) All did a magical job and Liam Neeson (Aslan) surprised me with a very mystical voice job! All in all, I have to say that if you don't agree with me, try it again and make sure you don't like it. And if you do like, go see it again too, because in my opinion it was just that good!

title: Satisfying
review: After seeing this movie I talked about it with my elementary school age children. We all agreed that the movie had everything that we had envisioned in our head while reading the first book of the Narnia series. Aslan was magnificent, Lucy was adorable, the Witch was frighteningly evil, the scene at the Stone Table was heartbreaking. I'm a grown man who has read this book seven or eight times, twice aloud to my children, and I'm not embarrassed to admit that my eyes welled with tears. I loved the scenes with the professor. I do think that more time should have been spent showing Edmund's temptation and the effect that the Turkish delight has on him. He seems to cave in to the Witch's promises too easily. His siblings at this point in the story have done nothing except the most normal sort of bickering that any brothers or sisters would have done, but Edmund readily supplies the Witch with information that severely harms the forces of good. This is a very good movie, I would recommend it to anyone.

title: Like the book?...then you'll like this movie!
review:
Just like any other recent movie that originated from a popular book (Harry Potter and LOTRs both instantly jump to mind faster then you can say "the one ring" seven times fast!) - it is very hard to critique fairly and with an open mind. Most viewers already have images of what Narnia should look like, what Aslan should sound like, and of course what parts of the book were missed and what they should have edited. As a reader of all seven C.S. Lewis classics, I am no different. However, as a movie goer looking for a new way to indulge my over abundant imagination, I was very pleased with this picture! The casting felt remarkable! I felt that if they did well with casting the Lucy character, it had a good strong chance of succeeding. Lucy carries the entire movie. The White Witch is also very interesting to watch. I'm not sure how they made her eyes look as icy as they did, or if it was natural, either way - great intensity! The other three children are believable too. I thought Peter was very good as the eldest child, while I pictured Edmund to look a little different. Also - as far as all four of them being related, Peter didn't really look much like the other three, but he still made the perfect Peter so I can live with the slight difference.

The movie itself was a little slow at times, but if you read the book, the movie is very much in order and in context. I felt that while I was watching it, I was actually re-reading the book whereas in movies like Harry Potter- I have to piece certain parts together to figure out what is missing because the books are longer then any movie should ever be! And in their own way, they also succeed, but Narnia is as is well scripted.

As for other things I strongly enjoyed - the fawn, Mr. Tumnous was great and fascinating to watch. Liam Neison as the voice of Aslan really was the only major downer of the entire movie. It just wasn't as mystical or powerful as I expected and hoped for. I feel as though a no name actor with an amazing voice might have been better - especially since Aslan is suppose to take on many different faces and represent a wide range of possibilities. Recognizing the voice kind of ruined it for me personally.

Overall, I gave it a 9 out of 10. P.s. stay through the credits for a few extra minutes. You get the Alanis M. song and a bonus!

title: It's amazing!!!!
review: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe is an AMAZING movie. So far it's the best this year. Ever scene kept you in a trance. This movie was exactly like the book. There were only 2 minor parts that weren't in the book, but everything that was in the book, was in the movie. It's the closest I think a movie can get to the book. The actors and actresses that starred in the movie were excellent. They had amazing graphics, and the scenes containing the war being fought were wonderful. The movie flowed well, and wasn't choppy. You didn't get lost and they explained everything that you needed to know. This film included humor, suspense, and sadness. Pretty much everything. You'll laugh, gasp, and cry all at the same time. The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe is an AMAZING film, made for everyone of all ages.

title: A sample of something great.
review: Narnia has got to be one of the simplest movies that I have ever seen. And in saying this, I do not mean it in a derogatory way. Simple means it is clear cut...good versus evil...You know who the good and bad guys are. And so, you know who to cheer for in the theater. This is such a simple story...there is magic, creatures, and a proper villain...and as I have said before...the simplicity is a wonderful change from having to constantly sit and figure out who is really good and who is really bad. If I had wanted to think when I went to the movie I would have gone to see a drama. I believe that I loved Narnia most because of the pureness of the characters...they had real problems that they dealt with in just...real...old fashioned humility and courage. Narnia is a precious jewel that should be seen by all...adults and children alike. The story is fabulous and the characters are...well...simple to understand. So, walk through the wardrobe and maybe find a little magic in your life...I know that I certainly did.

title: Definitely worth watching!!
review: wow, i would just love to say, that knowing that these children were unexperienced actors and have immediately opened up to the big screen, they are definitely FANTASTIC!!!!!! i totally enjoyed each of their roles and the way they portrayed it. there couldn't have been a better Lucy, Edmund, Peter, or Susan. I encourage anyone of any age to watch this fun filled movie with great adventure and a great moral behind it. I hope you all get something good out of watching this film. I won't spoil it for anyone, but i would highly recommend it for any family who enjoys the books.(i know i do!) and its the perfect season to watch it. happy holidays!!

title: Out of the world
review:
This rare movie entertains people of all ages and who can say that these days. It stands on its merits alone, and is not competing with Lord of the Rings.

The wonderful achievement of a movie follows the author's intent with only minor changes is awesome. The tale's strength lies in the plot, the characters and the changes in them. Instead of merely entertaining, it provokes reactions from the viewer. Would they respond to challenges the way these children did? Viewers will have to see for themselves.

The thrill of seeing such realistic animation with centaurs, the lion and even the ugly creatures put the movie right up there with the superstar movies.

My favorite part is also seeing Lucy's delight at the magical kingdom, but also her response to Aslan.

This is a must see movie, and if you look closely you'll see a story of redemption that has only one allegory--Jesus.

title: Excellent!
review: This is the best film I've ever seen!! the actors are amazing and i could see it again and again and not get bored!! I'd definitely recommend it to anyone. Andrew Adamson has created an amazing film and it is exactly what i pictured when i read the books. It suits people of all ages from children to grow ups. I cant wait for the sequels to come out if they plan on making them and will be one of the first to see it if they do! The effects were amazing especially the way they made Aslam look almost as if he were an actually lion prowling around. I don't think there is a single thing in this movie that i can criticise. It is one of the best things I've done all Christmas .

title: Excellent
review: I've seen the movie twice. The first time, I was anticipating each event and the second time, I just relaxed and enjoyed the movie. The movie was very faithful to the book. The changes were to better express what Lewis wanted his reader to experience. There were some flaws, but overall, the movie was excellent! I recommend this movie for families to see together, but there are some frightening images/scenes that might scare young children. I also recommend that before seeing the movie to read/reread the book. Especially if you haven't read the book. The goods: The acting was wonderful. The beavers were great with their humor. The special effects, especially for the battle scene was amazing. Lucy's emotional scenes were very touching. The emotional baggage of the movie was very strong. Flaws: The White Witch should not have known that Edmund was a Son of Adam so quickly but Tilda's acting was great. Aslan should have been a tad bit bigger. Some CGI weren't as good as they could have been. I feel that the sacrifice scene should have been a bit longer. The farewell scene where Lucy and Susan walk with Aslan was somewhat short. People will be comparing Narnia to Lord of the Rings, but they should know that without Lewis, there might have never been a Lord of the Rings for the world to enjoy!

title: very very good, I'm definitely happy!
review: This movie was strikingly good, as a lover of the book, i was amazed at how well they made everything seem real, especially Aslan. When books are made into movies like harry potter, i like them to follow the book as well as possible, and that is probably why this movie made me so happy, only little thing weren't the exact same, and they were good changes, I have nothing bad to say about the movie except that the Santa Claus should have looked a little more like Santa Claus, but you could still tell who it was. All of the actors did a great job in bringing their characters to life, and the witch was scary, she might have been a little scarier, but then parents might not have taken their little kids to it. The end battle was my favorite part, it was intense and the leopards and tigers tackling each other looked really cool, the fighting was well done, EVERYTHING was just so well done so everyone needs to see this movie and i don't understand why the rating is only a seven when it should be an eleven!

title: A decent start; I have high hopes!
review:
The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrode, is a decent start to the Chronicles of Narnia movie franchise. I was sufficiently entertained that I will watch it again when it comes out on DVD, and I am looking forward to the next Narnia movie! This movie falls short of excellent because it tries too hard, and the strain shows. The film-makers were in the unfortunate position of having to convince the studio execs at Disney and Walden Media that they could do a good job making The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrode. The problem is, I am not a studio exec. I want an excellent movie, regardless of how much money it might make.

There are only a few changes made from the book. They shortened up the timeframe a little, showed things that are only hinted at in the book, and increased the tension and drama in a few scenes. None of these changes were bad decisions, but many of them weren't integrated into the plot very well. Rather than feeling the added tension and drama, all I was thinking about was that the screenwriters had made these changes purely to try to make the story better. On a micro level, the movie delivered excellent individual scenes and characters, but the elements didn't quite connect together to make a great movie.

The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrode hits one of it's most emotional notes before it even gets to Narnia. The movie opens with warplanes bombing the city of London, England, terrorizing its inhabitants. Fearing for the safety of the children, the citizens of England have implemented a program whereby children are sent out of the city to live where they will be safer. This dramatic scene introduces us to the four Pevensie children, played by four superb young actors.

In spite of great source material and a very handsome budget, the quality of the acting is the main strength of this movie. The children's performances are so very sincere and whole-hearted that I didn't even think about what an excellent job they were doing until after the movie was over. Peter is the perfect older brother left in charge: not quite sure of himself as a leader because of his youth and inexperience, but absolutely determined to follow in his father's footsteps and do his best to keep his younger brother and sisters safe. Edmund is the surly younger brother, chafing under Peter's authority and trying desperately to validate his own worth. Susan is the older sister, mothering the two younger ones the best a 15-year-old can, and cute Lucy, so adorable, yet brave and adventurous, is the youngest, for whom any one of her brothers and sisters (except perhaps Edmund) would lay down their life in an instant.

Another excellent performance is put on by the actress playing the White Witch/Queen of Narnia. When I saw previews for The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrode, I wasn't sure if I would like the way the White Witch was played. I thought she looked too much like an actress in glamorous make-up. But the full realization of her character, in the context of the movie, was completely satisfied convincing.

The Witch's general, a minotaur, and her captain of police, a wolf, were developed into more complete and satisfying characters than in the book. There is an added scene between Peter and the wolf captain that makes their second, climactic meeting more meaningful because of the relationship the two enemies have developed.

There was a lot of talk on internet discussion boards to the effect of "they'd better do a good job with Aslan's character." As with the rest of the movie, Aslan is good, but not excellent. He looks like a real lion, he is majestic and interacts with live actors well, but he doesn't feel quite as alive as he should. If he were a human actor, I would say that his make-up and costume are excellent, and his voice is good, but he's just not that great an actor. I applaud the film-maker's efforts though, and with this experience, I am sure they will do a better job with Prince Caspian.

Andrew Adamson and his fellow film-makers have showcased an impressive array of talent in making The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrode; now if they can learn to work together a little more fluidly, and the studios give them the opportunity, the big screen future is very bright for The Chronicles of Narnia.

title: The story does pertain to Jesus Christ.
review: I was pleased with this movie. I was able to understand the events that took place. I knew about the book since I was young and wished it would soon become a movie. And when I saw that it was, I said to myself you have got to see this one on the big screen. Every Christian should go see this movie in theaters. The graphics are great. A friend of mine took his ten year old son to it, and he loved it. I think that this movie is much more clean and suitable for children than The Passion of Christ. I was drawn to watch it because of my knowledge of who C.S. Lewis is. And because of the talk about the movie I heard on the radio. I am looking forward to seeing the other C.S. Lewis' books to be made into movies also.

title: Excellent
review:
I thought that this movie was an almost perfect realization of the book. It followed it almost to the word.

There were a few things I had a few problems with, though:

First of all, the music was a bit much. It was at times TOO "mystical" without having real substance. Also, the percussive scoring reminded me of Lion King.

The other thing I had trouble with was Peter. In the movie he was too reluctant to be a leader, and lacked the courage that he had in the book for battle.

Overall, though, an amazing movie. A keeper.

title: Not revealing any thing just telling you how much i enjoyed it!
review: I just loved it! It was so awesome! I can't get it out of my head! I've always loved Narina but now i love it as much as i possibly can! Narina can't get any more exiting than it is in this move! I will be anticipating the other 6! I just can't say how much i enjoyed this experience i will never forget the first time i saw it! I saw it two times,but can you blame me? Oh I LOVE NARNIA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I know this will definitely be something i will tell not just my kids but everyone who want's to hear! Narina just absolutely rocks! There is just something about this series that gets me so hyped up i don't think i shall ever be able to stop talking about Narnia! Of Course i also loved it for it's similarity to the bible! If you read it you will see that C.S. Lewis did intend for ti to be a Christian book1 just study the background of his life and see for yourself if he intended for it to be secular or Christian?

title: This is an EXCELLENT movie!
review: The actors and actresses are so believable and genuine.The scenery and special effects are absolutely breathtaking. This movie is refreshingly clean and true to the original story, which is unusual for Disney these days. I have seen the movie twice and will definitely go again! You can relate to all the emotions expressed by the characters. This movie is superior to anything Disney has produced in the past several years, thanks to Walden Media being involved. I highly recommend "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe". The story line is not hard to follow or understand if you are not familiar with the original book series by C.S.Lewis. And please do not write the movie off by presuming that it is a fantasy flick for children! It is incredible- the battle sequences are phenomenal.

title: Great!
review: The movie was perfect! It followed the book so well and yet it managed to get the point across so wonderfully! And it was perfect for Chrtistmas with all the analogies and snow! Most of the time if you read the book before you watch the movie you'll like the book more, and vice-versa. But Nania book and movie complement each other exactly. The acting, scenery, and special effects were all good. I can't wait for the rest to come out! I wonder if they will even do the 'Majician's nephew' because it's actually backup information. Maybe it will be done like star-wars where they wait till they finished all seven movies(if they're going to do that many movies or just combine them )and then do the real first one.

title: Thought provoking and Prophetic !!!
review:
There are no words to comment on this Majestic movie ! Brilliant and Prophetic in every sense of the Word.

In the vein of the Cecil B. Demille movies of long ago...Those who have read The Bible will understand what I mean, The Lion of Juda, the Armour of God, The Sword which is the Word of God, The Arrows to quench the enemy and The Blood of Jesus is depicted throughout this movie of Faith.

Not a surprise since C.S. Lewis is a Christian and depicts the Bible by making it into a Fantastic storyline accessible to children and adults alike.

It is a movie experience that must not only be seen with human eyes but also with a Spiritual Heart.

In a world amidst adversities and despair, this uplifting movie will give you energy, hope and courage. That things can change if only we give ourselves a chance.

The key to understanding the meaning of this movie is to have child-like faith and open your heart and you'll discover like I did the essential meaning of this simple story of Human Triumph that had me weeping throughout !

They should make more movies like this instead of the usual fare of sex, drugs and unrelenting violence.

We need to go back to the source, where there is morality as our senses have been desensitized by the medias. We no longer feel remorse or guilt because of that. We must take a stand for changes otherwise our future generations will suffer because of our errors.

Thank-you Disney for making wholesome movies that are accessible to everyone. Keep up the good work !!!

title: Wonderful adaptation of a classic story.
review:
This much anticipated telling of "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe" is a visual feast. Everyone of the beloved characters are there: Aslan, the children, Father Christmas and of course Mr. Tummus.

The audience at the 12:01 showing were completely enraptured in the breath taking scenery and action - again New Zealand shines! Unlike previous live action versions the creatures are photo-realistic,not cartoons or "stuffed" animals. The special effects houses that worked on this including WETA and ILM out did themselves. This is the world I imagined it when I read the book.

The scene at the Stone Table is moving, you weep with the girls over Aslan and the battle scene is spectacular, you really fear for Peter and Edmund as they go one-on-one with the White Witch.

There are a few changes in the plot, as with any movie. The telling of a tale in a book is much different than telling a tale in a movie. The changes are minor and add to the story and distract little from the plot for those familiar with the story.

Highly recommended for everyone!

title: Good Flick - I would say 50-70% like the book
review:
The special effects were terrific, and the basic story remains intact. Most of the differences are in details. Some of the changes seem to have been made merely to add more action to the story. From the time Edmund defects until the other three arrive with the beavers at Aslan's camp, the film bears little resemblance to the book. Most of the rest of the movie is much closer.

The movie version made by BBC in the late 1980s (aired on PBS and available on video) lacked the impressive special effects, but was much closer to the book in storyline. The differences between the book and movie versions as well as between the two live-action movie versions make form great English classes. There is a lot that can be compared and contrasted. :-)

title: As a 14 year lover of the story the movie was everything I could have hoped for.
review: I have read the entire Chronicles of Narnia series and have and have been around the story of The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe for the past 14 years. So needless to say I have been looking forward to this movie for a long time, and it did not disappoint. While certain moments of the book were changed in the movie the changes that were made actually made sense in the context of the novel. It wasn't like the last two Harry Potter movies in which pointless changes were made for no reason that did not advance the plot in any way. The actors were all perfect in this movie and fans of the series as a whole will be extremely pleased when they see references to the others books within this movie. Really I can't say enough good things about this movie, it was something that I have been waiting for the last 14 years and I couldn't be happier with the job the did. I was everything the novel is and more. Amazing.

title: OK but no great shakes
review:
Was slightly reticent about seeing this as had seen a few clips already and had not been very impressed. However it wasn't too bad. The opening sequence showing German bombers attacking London and the fear of the Pevensey family as they scrabble for the bomb shelter was for me the most powerful in the movie. Scary stuff.

The rest was fine but not outstanding. Peter Jackson has raised the bar so high that any fantasy film now is going to struggle. LWW is a very different fish form LotR: Narnia, even under the White Witch's rule is a polished clean and beautiful land not the magnificent, majestic and troubled Middle Earth. Even the battles happen on glorious sunny days! This is amazing as some of the locations seem to me to be identical.

The story itself is very chauvinistic (as was LotR). Girls don't fight (much) but instead look after the dead and heal wounds. Boys look after their sisters in a sturdily British way and good triumphs over evil. Totally.

Much has been made of the Christian allegory but to be honest it's only there if you look for it. It's not overwhelming so don't let the US religious right's enthusiasm for the movie put you off. They're just clutching at straws in a desperate attempt to bolster their sagging moral position and shaky faith. Perhaps.

In brief: CGI animals - very good. The Gryphon led air strike on the Ice Queens army is the stand-out for me Green screen - some dodgy moments. Wind effects - not enough hair blowing given the speed they were supposed to be going at (a perennial problem for film makers)

Performances: Tilda Swinton: excellent. Although her costumes just were not "Ice Queen" enough for me Georgie Henley (Lucy) - very good indeed. one to watch? Skandar Keynes (Edmund) - good. just the right level of slappable snottiness Anna Popplewell (Susan) - the standout of the juvenile cast. She has the best line in the movie ("We're not heroes. We're from Finchley") but even aside from this obvious advantage she is, in every other aspect, way WAY better than... William Moseley (Peter) - Far too poshly camp to be anywhere near a convincing reluctant-hero boy-king. Can't hold a sword. Can't fight. Can't talk without lisping. Makes Daniel Radcliffe look accomplished.

Give it a shot by all means. Don;t expect LotR or even Harry Potter but if you're bored, it's raining and TV is driving you mad then there are worse things you could be doing of an evening.

title: Blast from my past.
review:
Thought the movie was excellent. I read the books in 6th, 7th, and 8th grade and thought they were fun reads back then. Before I saw this movie, I had wished this movie would have been made/released when I was younger, so I might appreciate it more. Turns out it didn't matter. I had a great time and really thought the movie was worth the 7 bucks I dropped on it. I recommend it to anyone that has the smallest bit of imagination.

Take your kid, friend, girlfriend; all will enjoy the movie.

I can't wait for Prince Caspian. No doubt, more will be released based on the success of Lion, Witch, Wardrobe.

title: Narnian Delights
review:
I just saw the movie "Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" tonite. This is actually the third time I've seen it since it opened last weekend. I just thought this was superb.

Full disclosure first though: I've been a "fan" & admirer of C.S. Lewis for many years; and have read the whole Chronicles of Narnia many, many times. For those who don't know what the Chronicles of Narnia are: these are a collection of 7 children's books written by Lewis. Yes, children's books. And I'm 51 years old. And I love them. So what already ... ? ;- )

Anyway, I was already "biased in favor" when I saw the movie for the first time. But when I saw it I really had no idea how much it would pluck at my heart strings with so many themes like Desire, and Longing, Longing, and more Longing; for the Coming of Justice and Right. This movie was released during Advent Season: a few weeks before Christmas. Perfect timing given the themes.

The little girl who plays Lucy in this movie is just absolutely enchanting. And if you're like me and feel like you know Lucy ... and Peter and Susan and Edmund ... from the full Narnia series ... then you'll remember just how very, very special this little girl is in that series. This little girl Lucy in the movie really opens wide her child's eyes and my eyes looking at her eyes and her face. Her response and reaction to, well, everything, was so appealing that to me this little girl made every scene that she was in. And that's almost every scene of the movie.

All four of the children, though, were very well played by this young cast. Again, I almost feel I know these children from the books: and they come across with all the individuality and complementarity that they do in the books.

Character development is an interesting feature of this movie. Edmund's development is by far most profound; well acted, well scripted, satisfying. Peter has a strong character development as well. Susan has some character development. Lucy ... as far as I can see ... exhibits no character development at all ... and this is wholly welcome: one simply wants Lucy to change in no way at all!

Relationships ... among the four children; between the children and the Great Lion, Aslan; between the Children and the Narnians; were modulated in an ongoing appealing manner that was both complex and straightforward.

Speaking of the Narnians: McAvoy's Tumnus was perfect; Tilda Swinson's White Witch was simply perfect as well; the Beavers were wonderfully appealing and convincing. The Centaurs and Minotaurs and Wolves and Ogres were wonderful. The manner in which Dryads were depicted was quite imaginative and a successful adaptation from the books.

The scenery was beautiful, delightful ... and the music, which I thought at first I wouldn't like, actually turned out to be a wonderfully lush, well-integrated feature of the whole film.

Comparisons with The Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter movies are inevitable. I very much have enjoyed these series as well. And frankly I think all three contributions to this common imaginative/fantastic genre have unique features to commend them to us. I think other than that I'll pass on comparisons for the moment except to say: if you liked one of the three, you may find that, like me, you'll like all three.

Just a delightful, wonderful movie ... And just as LOTR and Harry Potter have developed multiple movie installments, I very much hope that cinematic celebration of the Narnian Chronicles continue!

title: Narnia better story than LOTR, LOTR better movie
review:
**A few spoilers but nothing new if you have read the book** I was disappointed with the CG in this movie, not nearly as good as Lord of the Rings. Almost looked like a made for TV movie in parts. Acting was just okay. The best performances were given by the white witch. She was my favorite character. For those of you who read the books, you may be a little disappointed. One of the most critical scenes in the movie is when Aslan heads up to the stone table to be sacrificed. There is supposed to be an emotion connection with the audience, but due to the fact that Aslan was only in the movie for a few scenes beforehand, you really don't' feel the impact. Then the children stay behind after Aslan's death and weep for a day or so. This again, after only meeting him a few minutes before in the film. Those were only some of the things that bothered my about the film.

Maybe Peter Jackson could have done better with the way the enviorments looked in the movie, they didn't seem to blend very well. The animals were actually done very well.

I give the movie a 7 in all, the book remains one of my favorites of all time. I liked it a lot more than LOTR although the LOTR movies are much better. I think maybe the lack of description compared to Tolkien in CS. Lewis's books came through on film. Who knows.

title: It was so real, the images came to life !
review: During the movie, I was so taken by the fact, this movie was so real. It was as if, this movie read my mind when it came to the images from the book I had created in my mind. It was really freaky! It was as if I had met and knew the kids. The story which I have not read these books in over 25 years. I found this movie to be a grand way to bring the words of great books to life. My sister and I love this movie, but we wished it had been longer. It went by so fast, maybe cause we were so over taken by it. But it did seem to have covered so much so fast. Also I was even taken with by the idea of the Biblical view of this movie. It was a great movie Good vs. Evil. I just flat out LOVED IT !!!!

title: More Texture Than Glitz
review:
I was touched by this movie not because of its flash but because of its humanness which is ironic because of the decidedly 'non-human' aspect of most of its characters. I guess that's the idea and I know that's why Lewis wrote it. As a children's story it obviously serves as a beautiful moral tool. The Christian allusions and the use of the movie as a Christian allegory have been mentioned many times here and I won't re-state them. Suffice it to say, Andrew Adamson and the writers have been content with letting the STORY remain pre-eminent and not giving in to making Narnia a multi-billion-dollar CG extravaganza.

The acting of the kids was good enough for a kids movie and that's about as much as I can say regarding THEM. Tilda Swinton, as the only other major HUMAN-like actor in the film, however, was OUT STANDING. The utter amorality and cold, callous cruelty of the White Witch exuded from Swinton and I think it is fair to say that she dominated every scene she was in. The ecstasy of the Witch's triumph at the Stone Table was written on her face and you could FEEL the loss of hope for Narnia. Her final demise, including her awestruck whisper: 'Impossible' when seeing Aslan back from the dead, was stupendous. I understand it is shown in the Trivia section for this movie that Swinton had not read the book prior to filming. I find this absolutely astounding. She did not act the Witch, she became the Witch!

I should perhaps mention Aslan himself. CGI he was but he was a 'user-friendly' CGI to be sure. He wasn't intended to be a 'super' lion or have super-powers in a special effects kind of way. He was a remarkable lion for sure but he was real enough for Lucy to entwine her fingers in his mane as the girls walked with him for a short way on his journey to the Stone Table. He was real enough to talk to the children yet still scare the bejeepers out of the Witch.

Images that will remain with me: -the WWII Blitz set-up at the beginning -the first sighting by Lucy of the wardrobe itself and her slow-motion pulling off of its dust cover -the first entry by Lucy into Narnia -Tumnus' lulling her to sleep with his flute next to the fireplace - sheer magic! -the temptation of Edmund by the White Witch with her vial and the turning of its magically conjured objects of delight into powdery snow once used - vividly foreshadowing her empty promises! -the Beavers - just like the book in every way -the frozen waterfall that was slowly thawing -the final battle - the dropping by the eagles and griffins of rocks and boulders on the Witch's army in great symbolism of the Blitz in London in the 'real world' outside the wardrobe -the stabbing of Edmund by the Witch -Aslan knocking the Witch down and finishing her at the end

An excellent movie to take your own kids to. There is no starkly graphic images.

title: Classical good vs. evil movie
review: I never heard of the Chronicles of Narnia before and I must admit, that my first thoughts were more than critical... Being a Disney movie, I thought it would be just another waste of time like the last ones. After I watched it, I realized that it's probably one of the best family/good vs. evil movies of the last years. The movie is using pretty much all of the stuff you need for a good classical Fairy tale: the good are surrounded by thousands of colors, nice creatures and above all the whatever-is-going-on, all understanding and wise king who always knows the right thing to do. On the other side is evil with it's cold and I'll kill-em-all ruler, all dark, ugly and bad creatures. And least but not last the kids who started as common boys and girls but grew up to save the world. As far as I remember I haven't seen a drop of blood throughout the whole movie. Way to go !!!

title: C.S Lewis in all its glory
review: I'm still reeling from the shock! It must be nearly fifteen years since I read the Narnia stories, and the images I saw today were so like my memories of them! The film is simply superb, with stunning imagery, and compelling acting by all, not to mention a brilliant score by Harry Gregson-Williams. Adamson and Peacock have truly succeeded in recreating the gripping and fantastical world of Lewis. The images are breath-taking. Films like this remind us that many of us have never grown up in our fantasies. I walked out of the cinema feeling like I could reach the sky by jumping, and my boyfriend had visions of riding across a field wielding a sword. If you want adventure, you will love this film!

title: A Childs Feast of Imagination.
review:
This wonderful movie will do for the Children of today what Star Wars did for a whole generation of kids back in the 70's. If you're an Adult, then Narnia could disappoint.

Primarily a Children's movie, this is not to be forgotten, that the story is based on the Children's classic: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe, taken from the series of books The Chronicles of Narnia by C. S. Lewis.

Transcending a storyline from a children's book into film doesn't seem that hard a task, concerning Narnia. Grown ups will love it all the same, but Children will be Astounded by it. The Magical Land that is Narnia will have them riveted to their seats in a Spellbound Wonder. Imaginations will be set lose and the desire of involvement shall be justifiably Magical.

On leaving the cinema, my wife and I, thought it a very good movie. The only negative criticism was that to the end of the movie, it was just a movie for Children, which we expected and knew.

This is no Lord of the Rings by any means. Standing proudly on it's own two feet, this very easy plot and what seems to be very simple character development is all to familiar with Children's adaptation's. For us, the movie started to wane a little after the crossing of the iced river.

The introduction of the characters, along with Lucy and her Kin was done very well, practically the humour of the Beavers, where have I seen "that" relationship before? Very funny, and will Children understand it, I wonder. They will, eventually. This is our point, after the snow had settled there was hardly any kind of stimulation, for us anyway. It continued onward on one level, even the battle scene was fair but harmless. I would not expect a bloody feast, as I have said before this is no Tolkien. This movie brings Children to the Fantasy and Magical Splendour that is C.S. Lewis. Both very Individual in their own right and both with exceptionally Intelligent writing Minds.

The young actress Georgie Henley was truly amazing, where did they find her? Please don't say Ilkley, West Yorkshire, England. It's a rhetorical question. Another Child star to look out for, as with other Child Actresses of her age, such as Shirley Temple, Dakota Fanning and the then young lady born in Jerusalem, Israel, Natalie Portman for example.

Well-done young Lady.

I hope that this movie will delight and entertain the young and the new generation of Cinema-goers, to be kick started by a movie that is visually captivating will be a memory to behold. You have to start somewhere, for me it was Star Wars. So lets hope that C.S. Lewis's work on the Big Screen will stir their growing imaginations, as his books will always do.

title: Amazing!
review:
The lion, the witch, and the wardrobe was the best movie I've seen since the Lord of the Rings. Though, it is for a bit younger audience, it is still very well done. The music is great! The acting was incredible. Especially the youngest actress in the film, who plays Lucy. The witch, played by Tilda Swinton was very very good as well. Everyone else was not far behind in their acting ability.

Anyone who does see the movie, do not compare it to the Lord of the Rings. They are completely different story's.

Just a hint to anyone who hasn't seen it yet. When the credits start rolling, the movie isn't over. So, just stay put, because there is another scene.

title: Beautiful Adaptation
review:
Since this was one of my favorite books from my childhood, I was both worried and excited to hear that the film was being made. Fortunately, the concern turned out to be unwarranted.

The film-makers did an excellent job with the adaptation. It remains true to both the spirit and plot of the original story. The casting was also excellent. Tilda Swinton's performance as the white witch was really a treat. Liam Neeson as Aslan was a little jarring at first, largely because his voice is so familiar, but this did not last. The children, especially the two youngest, really shone.

The only real flaw that I noticed was that the CGI was a little dodgy - uneven. But for once, it didn't bother me.

There has been some concern out there about the religious content of this movie. As someone of a different faith that CS Lewis, it is my opinion that this to be an excellent movie for children and adults of all creeds.

title: Beautiful!
review: This movie was amazingly breathtaking! It was just as I had always imagined when I read the books as a child. All religious hoopla aside, this story has universal appeal. A classic good versus evil plot for all time. I read the books to my children before we went to see the movie and my 5 year old sat awestruck through the entire film! Afterward, she told me that she couldn't believe her eyes, she had dreamed of that very lion the night before! Very true to the story, amazing casting, awe-inspiring scenery, and a spirit-shaking score demand an Oscar! I only hope that the next films will be as incredible as this one. Shrek was the springboard for this outstanding director, and he spared no expertise on this film. Powerful and energetic, this film never lost my attention nor that of my children. (An impressive feat at any turn) I am waiting expectantly for The Silver Chair, Prince Caspian, and a Horse and His Boy. Perhaps Disney should consider immortalizing Madeleine L'Engle's magical series of books, they could certainly do justice to it's mystical wonder.

title: ...He's not a tame lion.
review: I read all of these books very young. I have since reread LW&W a couple times since my teens. From reading them and the cartoon version that used to be shown on television every year before cable TV this story has always been a big thing with me. I saw the BBC version of this and I liked it because it really followed the story but it was like watching a play, with the silly costumes and the plywood sets.That version had two things going for it, a very neat and well sounded out Aslan and a wicked and convincing witch, this one over- acting to a perfection.So when I heard a long time back Disney was remaking this I thought, hmmm well have to see, I didn't think they would put out anything but cute fluff and I thought they would drown out Lewis' Christian allegory somehow. Well I was wrong.This movie is fantastic and a nearly perfect adaptation.The children were excellently directed and did not annoy me at all, which many child protagonists in film do.The little girl's expressions of wonder were actually believable.Edmund's treachery and the price he paid for it were right on, that kid that played him nailed some decent moments of complexity with the character.Peter and Susan were more shallow ,but those kids did them well, and I am sure we'll see more of both of those young actors as the grow. Aslan was a sight. The CGI made me think I was watching a real lion king.Neeson was totally perfect as his voice.Every time I've seen Liam in the last few years I've thought what a power he's become in acting, from silly crap in Next of Kin and Darkman to Rob Roy, Batman Begins, Kingdom of Heaven has been quite a career to watch.Now he has really nailed it for me, his voice giving the power and inflections that Aslan must have truly made the movie work.Only a few other actors could do the same and to have cast them would have almost seemed too cliché-ish,i.e James Earl Jones,Sean Connery. Now about Jadis.This woman that played her really gave her her own spin that as a whole did,in fact, work.The actress's stare alone was worthy of the white witch.In the BBC version the woman that played her over acted and was excellent in her attempts to cover her evil while trying to seduce Edmund.Well this Jadis was not over acted but was acted with a sinister style and a meanness that did give her over as the portrayal of evil to Aslan's good.Plus I liked her in her War Witch regalia. So In conclusion , well done Disney.This rivals LOTR in action and story if that what your looking for. Remember now, Tolkien's masterpiece was a thing in size and scope that is hard to comprehend, check out the Silmarillion for proof of this, he wrote Middle Earth's history from creation to LOTR, approx. 5000 years.Lewis work has no-where near the back story and history , I believe he meant to just get a out a good fantasy yarn with a Christ message.For deeper Lewis work read the Space Trilogy, the second book Perelandra could be made into a true horror film and it also is very Christian/Creationist based.Adam and Eve, Satan, and God are characters in this one.The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe is great viewing , see this now.

title: Excellent Movie
review: This movie was awesome. I love the Chronicles of Narnia and this movie stayed very true to the book. I went to a private screening and this movie and it was awesome. All of the performances were awesome, especially Tilda Swinton, the White Witch. She deserves an Academy Award for her performance. Georgie Henley was an excellent choice for Lucy. She's an excellent actress for her age, especially in a film like this. The special effects and CGI were the best I have ever seen. I couldn't tell most of the time if it was CGI or a live actor or animal. The only problem I found was that Edmund was too bratty. I know that in the book, Edmund was spiteful when he was mad, but he just seemed too bratty. I give this move 9 out of 10 stars.

title: Great example of book adaptation
review:
I went into the movie excited, having read all the Chronicles of Narnia, but cautious, after being disappointed by some of the HP movies. Fortunately, I was not disappointed.

For one, they stuck to their story. While I loved the LOTR movies and some of the improvements made, I felt the creative license was abused with some of the HP movies, so seeing how the filmmakers stayed true to C.S. Lewis was a relief. Some things need no improvement.

The first trip Lucy takes into Narnia is startling, awe inspiring and magical, recreating those feelings first felt while reading the book. I kept glancing at my children's faces to gauge their reactions, it was so cool! The four children were portrayed as I had imagined them, a hard feat to accomplish especially with such an established literary work, especially Lucy and Edmund. Edmund's character, which I believe to be the harder of the two could have been a little more fleshed out, a little more conveying of how he wasn't a mean or hateful brother, but just a kid looking for a way to be special in the ways he felt his brother and sisters were. His scenes of redemption seemed to lack the emotional weight I expected, but it's still a good portrayal.

The animal characters, which I feared would be cheesy, were excellent. The battle scenes were short of LOTR, but still intense and exciting. They definitely didn't sugarcoat the scary scenes with Aslan's death, the battle scenes or the stabbing of Edmund by the White Witch.

The visuals were impressive, the castles, the changing of the seasons, the scene at the stone tablet, all very vivid and enormous.

My favorite characters had to be Tumnus, the fawn and the White Witch. Superbly acted. Respectively, they both conveyed their characters as much with their body language and tone, not just relying on the dialog.

I was also pleased to see the scene, a brief break in the end credits where they set up more adventures with Lucy's scene with the Professor.

All in all, I loved this movie, it exceeded my expectations and I can't wait to see it again. I think the second time around it will be much better for I'll allow myself to be swept up in the movie rather than analyzing it for defects.

title: Hmmmm. Certaintley a must see, but... hmmmm
review:
Being a student, I had plenty of time to see the new big film on it's day of release. Narnia was a bit of a mixed bag, in that the best opinion I had heard was "Not Convincing". Despite my best rose-tinted glasses, I could not get past the fact that the film never had the Wow factor of a modern epic, until the simply superb Battle scene and the impossibly stunning graphics of the fully CG animals, even if some where a little charicatured in the design. Charicatured, hollow and sporadically ropey are actually a very good criticisms of the whole film. There is never a sense of excitement, enchantment or scale in the movie. The acting is often wooden or very melodramatic, exasperated by a lack of any depth in the characters beyond the basics for telling the story. And, just to top it off, I think that the idea that it is a fantasy version of Crucifixion theory is over-hyped, with the scale of Aslan's sacrifice in saving the whole of Narnia withered by the fact that Neeson never gives off the power of Aslan, as if a few snarls and soothing comments will win our admiration, and, as the script picks up pace, focusing the role of Peter and the inevitable fall of the Ice Queen, seems to be still alive by some loophole in the possibly magical laws of Narnia.

In summation, Adamson fails where Jackson succeeded in not breaking down the most fascinating aspects of a beloved and heavyweight cultural tome to a story in it's own right in favour of retelling the best bits. An unnoticeable soundtrack adds to a hollow feeling of melodrama rather than the drama the ideas presented should deserve

Actual Good Points? Lucy (although not the other children) being neither annoying or wooden (difficult for most kids- Maybe a UK Dakota Fanning in the making), and Tilda Swinton, Ray Winston and James MacAvoy being beautifully otherwordly and intelligent in their acting, very much single-handedly making their scenes work , and of course the awesome Animals. I will watch all the inevitable sequels in the franchise, but will probably not need the DVD's.

title: Lord Of The Rings+Harry Potter=Narnia.
review:
After having been to Warner cinema a few hours ago,i have to say that i think this is a really great,fun film. The plot: Peter,Susan,Edmund and Lucy are DE ported from London to the house of an eccentric professor in World War 2.One day when playing hide and seek,Lucy goes inside a wardrobe,and finds a strange,new world called Narnia.At first no one else believes her,but as they go into wardrobe,they change there minds.After finding out that animals can talk,and that there is a war going on between good and evil.They meet the leader of the force of god,a lion called Aslan (voiced by a great actor,who i will not give away plays him).The only thing some of them don't know is that one of them has betrayed them,and has joined forces with the evil White Queen,who wants to take over Narnia and kill Aslan. View on the film:

First for anyone wondering if any of the Christian images (two boys with the blood of Adam,two girls with the blood of Eve,a resurrection of someone who has died for our sins) ruin enjoy meant for the film.I have to say that i do not feel it hurts it at all.It mainly gives adults something to talk and think about after seeing the film(something most big films don't give you).The acting in the film is very good (with the White Which being a stand out).The voice acting in the film is really great (but why do some of the wolves sound American?). Anderson,for this being his non all-CGI film does a great job letting the story always stay as high as the FXs(by the great Lord Of The Rings Weta). Final view on the film: For anyone who wants to see the next Potter or Rings,you must see this.This is one of the best films i have seen this year.

title: Marvelous
review:
When this film was announced it was obvious that it would be compared to LOTR to no end. This review is not one to compare it to LOTR, because it is no Lord of the Rings. What is? In its own right, though, "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" is a fantastic film that should please both C.S. Lewis fans and fans of fantasy in general.

Let me start with the acting: WOW. I have never seen such an incredible cast of young actors. All of them are really amazing, especially the young boy who plays Edmond. His character is so complex, and it must have been really hard to develop. He did it flawlessly and really makes the transformation believable and dynamic. The little girl playing young Lucy also gives an incredibly wondrous and endearing performance. The other two actors are also astounding and pitch-perfect. I can honestly say that this is the best cast of kids ever assembled.

Tilda Swinton as the White Witch is a really cool and truly evil villain. She did incredibly at being both a seemingly kind yet cold-hearted (sorry) and fierce tyrant. Another perfect choice. Liam Neesan is fantastic as usual. What else can I say? The acting was perfect.

The story is handled very closely to that of the book and when it makes changes, they work. The opening scene is very focusing on the time-period in which they live, and the writers did a great job of filling in when C.S. Lewis would, for example, leave this to the readers' imagination.

Special effects on a whole was pretty well done. Tumnus' legs are pretty unbelievable, and the Beavers work amazingly well as living, breathing characters. However, I saw the credits listing several companies responsible, and sometimes it shows. There are a few moments when the effects look herky-jerky or cartoony, but overall they are pretty top-notch. Aslan, Tumnus, and the beavers alone make this film worth an effects nod at the Oscars, and the big-battle scene is pretty amazing to look at with the sheer multitude of creatures.

Now lets get to what you've all been waiting for: the battle. Yep, it's amazing. It was really great how they handled this. In the book, the battle is only described as it came to a close. The film stretches it out over 20 minutes, and every minute is spectacular.

I had a few gripes with the movie, though. I found the wolves to seem kind of out of place with their somewhat tough-guy accents. The score of the film is different and not half-bad, although some may not like its electronic blips and synth lines. It fits pretty well with the mood, though. Some won't like the part with Father Christmas, but it was in the book and HAS TO BE IN THE FILM! "LWW" is a great entry in the fantasy genre and one of the best films of the year. It's a movie that everyone can enjoy, and it will probably become a classic. Not only that, but it could possibly be the beginning of a promising new fantasy franchise.

title: An excellent film!
review: This was great. Jumping off the successes of The Lord of the Rings trilogy and the continuing Harry Potter series, it was inevitable that someone was going to get around to greenlighting C.S. Lewis' well-known collection of Narnia stories. It's fantastical tales of a magical land beset by the forces of evil and the struggles of the righteous have been popular reading for over 50 years; beloved by children and revered by Christian analysts for its parallels to another well-read collection of stories. I always wanted to read the books, buying nearly all of them at my grade school's annual book fair before the Pick-a-Path titles occupied my attention. I'm sure at that age I would have been as enraptured as the next child. My whimsy for childhood adventures still resides within and, admittedly, for a good portion of the film version I was along for the journey with eyes (mostly) open enjoying the exploits of Narnia the way most enact their hobbies  as passable time-killers. But the longer it went on, the less it satisfied my sense of wonder and eventually took on the more overt metaphors of one of my ongoing classes at Queen of the Rosary. Hint: It wasn't English or Reading.

title: Read the book before I've watched the movie and both are good!!!
review:
When i saw the book it kinda turned me off because of the pages that the book have (almost 800 pages) but when I started reading, I just could not to put the book down, it is such a good book and I totally had fun reading it.

Since I've enjoyed reading the book, I was so excited finding that it will be in the movies this December, I've gone out and watch it with my daughter who was kinda hesitating to come with me but ended up watching and enjoying the movie. I am so glad that we've went and watched it. We can't wait to see the upcoming films (if ever they decide to show it).

THIS IS A TOTALLY ENTERTAINING MOVIE AND BOOK!!!

title: Even when it almost takes itself too seriously to be fun, it still is an enjoyable experience
review:
Andrew Adamson, who gave us animated gems such as Shrek and Shrek 2, directs his first movie involving real actors with mixed results. The first entry in C. S. Lewis' The Chronicles of Narnia is certainly a good movie to watch, but somehow lacks the magic of movies that stay with you after the film is over.

It's not easy to adapt a famous book, but in that aspect Adamson and his team of scriptwriters manage to stay faithful to the novel although still the story has suffered a few minor changes. The plot is simple, four siblings travel to a magical world using an old wardrobe, they will have to free the land of Narnia from the eternal winter that Jadis, the White Witch has sent.

The acting is good for the most part; experienced actress Tilda Swinton dwells more into mainstream movies and give her usual great performance as the White Witch, giving power to a character that is always diminished by the majestic Aslan, who clearly is the star. Liam Neeson does a good job as his voice, giving him dignity, but at the same time it focuses in the messianic side of the character.

This would not be a bad thing if it not were by the fact that Adamson focuses more in those aspects of the story, leaving poor development for the children and the adventure aspect of it. Too much time is given to how great Aslan is, that there is few time to explore that sense of adventure every kid has in it.

The movie takes itself too serious as an epic to a point that it almost forgets is aimed for the fun of younger audiences. It feels as if they were trying to make the story a new "Lord of the Rings" epic when the story doesn't go that way. Fortunately, this never gets too serious to become a problem and the movie still manages to be entertaining.

The film is not a masterpiece, but it can be entertaining for younger audiences. Do not believe the hype, it's not a perfect movie, just go to the theaters with an open mind, and don't expect any more than entertainment. 7/10

title: Bring on Prince Caspian!
review:
A kid's Lord of the Rings. A kid's Bible. A kid's fantasy. Excuse me but here's an adult here who truly enjoyed every minute of this. Well, with the exception of the Santa intervention but that hiccup's in the book too.

I won't dwell too much on the special effects of this movie cos I'm sure other viewers will be as ecstatic about them as I am. I must mention however that fighting centaur. Absolutely fabulous stuff.

But the real strength of the movie is in the actors, which is rare for a movie of this genre. Tilda Swinton is an absolutely fantastic witch. Hopefully a nomination there. Many considered the kids as not up to scratch but I found them immensely expressive, and I've been training kid-actors for some years now.

Well done to the whole production team and bring forth the next CHRONICLE!

title: an amazing movie
review: What a great movie to see this holiday season, one for kids of all ages and very true to the book, the cgi was amazing, so good I've seen it twice already,The cast are really good and liam neeson really brings aslan to life,ray winstone and dawn french bring a little humour to the beavers,tilda swinton is really convincing as the white witch and all four of the children were pretty good too,the time goes by so quick u will hardly know you've been in the cinema for two and a half hours but when u come out I'm pretty sure u will feel as blown away as i did,this was my favourite book as a child and its the best movie I've seen this year...i cant wait for the next one.

title: If you liked the first Harry Potter, you'll love this
review:
I read the Narnia books as a kid, and my imagination took flights of fancy that I would have loved to have seen on celluloid back then. Now I'm an adult and the technology has finally arrived. The various mythical creatures are brought to life spectacularly, the scenery is fantastic, there's some understated humour, and the final battle scene is a worthy successor to the Minas Tirith battle in Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.

Indeed, this film both gains and loses by following LOTR. It gains because LOTR makes some of the mythical creatures in this film more believable. If you thought orcs, elves and hobbits were strange, wait till you see the magnificently rendered centaurs. But it loses some of its impact in the battle scenes because of its similarity to the LOTR battles ... though, in fairness, most mediaeval battles were pretty much like that, so it's hard to get much variation in.

As for the Harry Potter connection, the stars of the film are all kids -- except for the White Witch, played with commendable iciness by Tilda Swinton -- with the youngest child (Lucy Pevensie/Georgie Henley) likely to take home the most plaudits. Also, if this film has a weakness, it's that (like HP & the Philosopher's/Sorcerer's Stone), it stays a bit too close to the book from which it was derived. Don't get me wrong, the book is an excellent, heroic story -- but it's a children's book, and some of the 'this happened and then that happened' moments stretched credibility for me as an adult. Oh, and one or two shots were a bit obviously greenscreened with the characters superimposed on backgrounds.

N.B. Much has been made of the Christian analogy in the story -- it's there, of course, but it isn't overplayed.

In short, if you can see it through a child's eyes, or if you haven't seen Lord of the Rings, this is a must see. If you have ... well, it won't seem quite the franchise monster that LOTR was, but it's worth the night out just for the technical effects on the creatures, and the rest of it is pretty good as well.

title: Excellent
review: I just went to see the film in cinema and it was GREAT It Was So brilliant , the storyline special effects The Big War At The End, One Of the Best Films i have ever seen but i think king kong is gonna be the best :) Aslan, Great Big lion , with good courage The 3 children all played they're parts and the other child who is 18 was very good too The characters were good and detailed , the rhinos , the warriors the polar bears and more, of course animal lovers wouldn't of liked to have seen the war as many animals die or are injured but they are healed at the end by the youngest of the children as santa gives them a special potion to heal all wounds, and aslan has special breathe, because the white witch freezes them aslans breath melts it, so they don't die in a way

title: What Families Want to See
review:
I saw this film with my family: wife of 25 years, daughter (18) and son (15). We don't generally go out to the theatre as a group, but this was CS Lewis, so we made the exception. All were greatly pleased with the result. This is a wonderful film, wholesome and honest, childlike (rather than childish) and innocent, meant to edify and hearten the young of age as much as the young at heart. To me, this film helps support the contention that there is no need for filmmakers to shy away from this kind of family entertainment and that it can be done with rigor, skill and even artistic subtlety, just so long as the participants put their heart into the effort.

One wants to cheer everyone connected but let it be said that Tilda Swinton does especially well, bringing the White Witch to eerie and unsettling life. One is not surprised by the lengths to which the character will go but Ms. Swinton never reveals more about the character than she needs to and until she needs to.

Some have not been fully pleased by the special effects. I did not trouble myself about them, and found them quite satisfactory with rare exceptions.

See this film, please. You will be happier if you do, which is a nice state to be in this Christmas.

title: Superb Narnia
review: I thought it was an excellent film almost comparable with the Lord of the rings! I found it epic and most of all i liked the absolutely magnificent scenery,costumes and sets, especially the Ice palace. Its a movie i already proposed to my friends to see it. I loved Tilda Swinton in that role! Her 'frozen' eyes and 'icy' cheek bones can make you feel the evil and that makes her an excellent choice for the White Witch. Shes brilliant! I liked the little girl as well! Those huge wet blue eyes could take you back when you were kid and remember all that wild imagination you had and you thought you were a hero in a dream land with knights witches wizards and animals which talk! Who hasn't dreamt of that? Even if i haven't read the books i believe that is a good reason to start. I hope the next chronicles to be as good as that one!

title: Far exceeded all my expectations
review:
I grew up on Narnia and have enjoyed The Chronicles as a child and as an adult. I was thrilled to hear they were making a full length feature film. On my way to the theater, I worried that the film would not meet my expectations because they were very high, partly because of the film's hype and partly because I wanted this beloved tale to be told better than any movie has told its tale.

From the moment the film began, I was captivated. The cast was brilliantly chosen and delivered the story beautifully. The cinematic flow was perfectly paced and held the attention of all my children (ages 5-13)through the end and then some. We can't stop talking about it. As much as we enjoy the Harry Potter movies, this movie seems to have more depth and less fear. The music was great, too.

I highly recommend this movie to people of all ages except perhaps those under 5; it is a story that will keep everyone interested and have them thinking long afterward about courage, honor, and sacrifice. I can't wait to see it again.

title: A Dream Come True
review:
At the age of ten, I was given the first three books of "The Chronicles of Narnia", and it began for me a life time love affair with the magical world CS Lewis. To me, Narnia was the perfect fantasy world, and I wanted to go there to escape the horrors of my childhood. It helped me get through some of the worst times in my life, and to this day if any one asks me what my favorite book is I will always answer, "All of The Chronicles of Narnia".

Today, I am 40 years old, and I have waited some people's lifetimes for the perfect film version of the book. I have found it in my recent viewing of Mr. Adamson's wonderful film. Everything that I ever imagined unfolded before me on the screen.

This book is a nearly faithful rendition of the beloved story with only minor deviations here and there. These deviations, however, make no difference to me in my enjoyment of this work.

The CGI special effects were astounding. The illusions of James McAvoy as a faun and Shane Rangi as a centaur are incredible. The totally GCI characters are truly impressive. If there is any fault here it is that, like Gollum in LOTR, they are almost too perfect.

The young actors who played the Pevensie children, while they may be strangers to filming in a CGI environment, I never once felt that they were not playing as they should to the CGI characters. They give wonderful performances, particularly Skandar Keynes and Georgie Henley. They are everything I imagined Edmund and Lucy to be.

Tilda Swinton as the White Witch is the perfect combination of ice and evil. The design of her castle is extraordinary. The costumes she wears are impressive. Her minions are perfectly ugly and evil.

The true spirit of CS Lewis' wonderful tale is here. While Lewis may have put Christian themes into this story the ones that he chose have universal appeal. The ideas of sacrifice, spiritual renewal or rebirth, and love of your fellow man are not the private privilege of Christianity. I consider myself an agnostic and have never considered this book to be Christian Propaganda. The film does not present the story that way either.

You can imagine then that I look forward to the filming by the team that produced this one to anymore volumes of the "Chronicles" that they choose to make.

title: Wonderful!
review: I'm not one for long reviews, so let me just say that this was a truly magical film that engaged the child in me that first fell in love with these stories. It was a VERY faithful adaptation that was true to the heart of the story, while actually adding more depth to the characters and their interactions than there was in the book. The seamless effects and perfectly cast children really whisked me away to Narnia and made me forget I was watching a film. The young lady who played Lucy in particular was a wonderful actor through whose eyes you couldn't help but view the events that unfolded. A must-see for your whole family (except possibly for very young children due to a few dark and disturbing scenes).

title: I want my hour back
review:
that's about as long as I lasted in this utter piece of crap. I can't imagine the cast and crew sat at the screening and thought job well done. It was as if the director thought he was doing LOTR cliff notes. The dialog was horrible and full of current references. About 30 minutes in I started looking around as I was in a not so full theater full of adults, wondering if I was the only one reeling from this assault to art sense, let alone common sense.

Technically it wasn't doing so bad, and there were a few good touches of the animals running and whatnot. There were a few cheesy CGI shots but honestly this was the least of this films problems. As others have mentioned above there was no reason to care about the characters, the actors themselves were struggling with a poor and tritely written script. It makes sense that the Christian Right is responsible for this mess, being as simplistic as they are.

title: Biggest Disappointment In Theaters
review: Where the hell has Peter Jackson gone? The studio should have yanked him away from that giant pet project about some kind of gorilla and given the helm of this film to him. Instead the chose Andrew Adamson, whose credibility is due largely in part to a lovable ogre, whose presence would have benefited this film greatly, and would not have surprised me at all. Narnia is one part shrek, one part harry potter, one part lord of the rings, one part new testament, and all parts unoriginal. Major disappointment. I wish I had more to say about how terrible it was, but I'll leave it at this - reading Narnia helped defined my childhood, and instead of adding to said definition of my early years, this film defiled many of the memories that I have. Horrible. Save yourself.

title: This movie is complete garbage
review:
I just watched two controversial movies in the past week, one being The Chronicles of Narnia: lion/witch/wardrobe, and the other being The Golden Compass.

I'm sickened, shocked and horrified that moviegoers in the United States have rallied so firmly behind the former (Narnia) and against the latter (Compass).

Narnia is a shallow and predictable excuse for a movie, making no attempt to shroud its abusive and disgusting Christian imperialist message to the audience. It doesn't even attempt to get decent actors or a solid plot -- it just finds a Jesus/God character (the Lion, of course) and makes humans more important than all of the other animals, despite the shortcomings of the naive, lying and cheating humans. I understand the book was very short, but that doesn't make up for the gaping holes in the plot and complete lack of character development. The movie stutters from one scene to the next with no premonitions, no foreshadowing, nothing. Unless of course you know the story of the bible, but in that case you don't even need to watch this movie because all it does is chop up and regurgitate biblical tales to viewers in an attempt to further the Christian agenda. There is nothing new here, only some children and a bunch of animals who for some reason are willing to kill themselves to fulfill the prophecy of the return of the almighty humans.

The Golden Compass, on the other hand, was brilliantly dynamic, featured far better graphics and more diverse and unique characters and offered absolutely phenomenal acting. Daniel Craig was stern, Nicole Kidman was conniving and Dakota Blue Richards was gutsy, bold, unbelievably strong and tremendously courageous, to an extent that none of the children dreamed to achieve in Narnia. Simply put, Narnia was like a youth group adaptation of a biblical story in a church in the middle of rural Oklahoma and Compass was a stunning grade-A adaptation of the real history of the world by world-class actors.

Anyone who knows history can see the relevancy and importance of The Golden Compass. During the Dark Ages, organized religion WAS the Magesterium. They murdered and imprisoned people for speaking out against the church, they burned witches, they kidnapped children, they did almost everything that the Magesterium is accused of in Compass. This is a realistic and accurate portrayal of what has happened when religions and governments blend and imperialism and xenophobia take the front seat in foreign and domestic policy, today, eight hundred years ago or two thousand years ago. And it's the same thing that will happen in the future if we continue to escalate the war between Christianity and Islam.

The Magesterium also represents the attempt of *organized* religion to remove our souls from our bodies, which ironically are called "daemons" in the movie. This is a clear point that our inner demons, in real life, ARE our souls, as in that which makes us both good and bad is still what makes us. This movie is not a shot at faith and spirituality, but rather a shot at the blend of religion, power and government that so often convene when a church becomes involved in politics and thus gains power over society. We've seen this happen throughout history, so why people seem so shocked that Compass simply illustrates what has happened so frequently in the past 2-3000 years is truly beyond me.

Now look at Narnia. A delusional and unrealistic world where all you have to do is have "faith" in fairytale thoughts and everything ends up pretty in the end, with humans controlling everything and every other species of the earth obeying and abiding by the human agenda.
