To make the movie more marketable to children they make it so none of the good guys die in the end, they are only suspended by freezing them, there is no blood and while plenty of animals are killed and sacrificed, the children, who accomplish literally nothing throughout the entire film, are praised mindlessly by everyone.

Aside from the obvious fact that Compass had infinitely better actors and acting, better graphics and a much better plot, even the premise surpassed Narnia in historical accuracy, thoughtful foreshadowing of the future and its attempt to give a realistic impression of human nature when faced with an oppressive and all-powerful force.

Point being: Narnia is magical fairytale land, Compass is thoughtful, brilliant and historically accurate.

title: Beautiful and Involving Adaptation of a Classic
review:
The visual success of "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is made possible by the innovations in special effects that were developed for "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy. While some of the settings and monsters seem a bit recycled from that epic, the magical creations of the novel are recreated believably and beautifully.

The opening of the story marvelously retains the setting of war time Britain during the blitz, complete with an Andrews Sisters song and war reports on the radio, setting the film in a reality where good was clearly fighting evil and evil was ruthlessly attacking civilians (just a bit of imagination is needed to jolt us to contemporary comparisons on either perceived side of several current struggles). While most of today's audience will not know about the evacuation of London's children to the safer countryside and their knowledge of train stations is probably from "Harry Potter," the embarkation farewell is almost as much a tearjerker as Dumbo being separated from his mother.

Adding to the verisimilitude are the excellent child stars. Georgie Henley's "Lucy Pevensie" could be the granddaughter of "Scout" in "To Kill A Mockingbird" for capturing wide-eyed innocence and curiosity without any cloying sweetness. William Moseley would get my pre-teen heart beating faster and he seems destined to play Jude Law's son, though without seeing him play with toy soldiers I wonder how "Peter" suddenly gains expertise in military strategy and tactics other than instinctively rising to the white man's burden. Anna Popplewell's "Susan" is not faint of heart as she combines femininity and tomboy action quite fetchingly. "Skandar Keynes" as "Edmund" well captures the temptation of sibling rivalry. Too bad they will too quickly age out for the sequels.

As twinkly as James McAvoy is as "Mr. Tumnus" the faun, Tilda Swinton is is so charismatic as the White Witch self-declared Queen of Narnia, that not only does she immediately get my vote in the MTV Movie Awards as Villain of the Year, even over Palpatine in "Revenge of the Sith," but I thought she was more effective than bland, Liam Neeson-talking lion Aslan, even as she was very Saddam-like using informers, committing torture, imprisonment, habitat destruction and offering candy as bribery (good lesson here about not taking candy from pretty strangers, let alone tattling on your siblings). Too bad her costumes were a bit awkward, but her hair design was both regal and woman warrior.

Twenty years ago when I was first introduced to this book by reading it to my sons, I was completely oblivious to the Christian imagery, and could do so with this adaptation as well. Then as now I saw the gifts from Father Christmas as much a benign representation of the positive aspects of the Winter Solstice rather than eternal winter, as Christmas is at Hogwarts. Because the scene of Aslan's confrontation with the Witch is bloodless so as not to frighten children, it seemed more about emasculation to me than sacrifice, though having it take place in a Stonehenge setting seemed too specifically pagan (and that was constructed to celebrate summer any way). The battles are far less violent in clash and final results than in "The Rings" saga, which they otherwise imitate.

The talking animals are marvelously English, without any contemporarization or mugging that American animation inserts. Particularly fine are Ray Winstone as the voice of "Mr. Beaver" and Rupert Everett as the voice of "Fox." The wolves are quite the scariest things in the movie, as well as the exhilarating chase scenes, so much so that I don't know if the "wolf trainer" credit was literal or animatronic. A warning not to leave your seats immediately after the human participants are identified in the credits: the film continues to set up for the sequel. I didn't even recognize Jim Broadbent at first as "The Professor," while the housekeepers' accent seemed a bit out of place. The centaur wasn't particularly memorable.

The closing songs by Alanis Morrissette and Tim Finn were lovely. The score was fairly pedestrian action-adventure, coming to life during the chase scenes and too bombastic during the battles.

The dozen or so special effects teams listed in the credits demonstrated the globalization of the movie business these days -- from New Zealand to Guatamala to the Czech Republic and Poland to ILM and Los Angeles.

The film is long, but the small children in the audience were only restless during the early set up scenes and were quite involved once the thrilling action started.

title: Disappointed
review:
This doesn't really contain spoilers, but in case it hints too much for someone I've marked it as so.

I just got back from a midnight showing....

Overall I'd have to say I was disappointed. I'll admit I've never heard of The Chronicles of Narnia until I saw a preview for it, as I now know the books have been out forever. The movie felt like they were trying to capture LOTR and Harry Potter all-in-one, and they just didn't pull it off. I felt no attachment to the characters, and so many of the characters seemed so hyped to turn out so meaningless. I also think the PG rating hurt the film a bit. I can understand wanting to reach a wider audience, and maybe thats how the author would have liked it, but it just didn't feel right to see someone jabbed with a sword only for it to come out as if it had just been polished; perfectly clean. Also I think it's pretty violent for a PG movie, even without the blood and details. So if you have young children, I'd possibly reconsider. I'd say at least 10 would be a proper age.

I guess my advice is that if you read and enjoyed the books, it may be worthwhile, but if you're just an avid moviegoer/fantasy film enthusiast pass on this, or at least wait until you can rent it. I dished out $8.25 for this flick and can I fell shorted.

*side note: I'm extremely tired as its now 3:30, the movie started 15 min late, plus 20 min of previews, so excuse any bad grammatical errors etc.*

title: My Thoughts on HP, LOTR, and L,W & W
review:
I am a Christian, and I just wanted to say that I do agree that some people who claim to be Christians act very hypocritically sometimes.

It is really discouraging because as Christians, we are supposed to be consistent examples ( whether you take us seriously or not is beside the point; it's should just be our main goal )

There is controversy even among us Christians regarding The Lord of the Rings and now Narnia, but I would have to say ( without judgment or condemnation; I'm just voicing my honest thoughts and opinions ) that if anyone claims to be a Christian but does not feel uneasy about Harry Potter, there is something wrong.

I'm not trying to sound snobbish, but while those of you who are critical of us "hypocrites" lump The Lord of the Rings, Narnia, and Harry Potter together because they all contain "magic", there is a very distinct line separating Harry Potter from the other two.

I have not seen the Harry Potter movies, but watched part of "The Chamber of Secrets" for a while when it was on TV the other night. I'm sorry but there is something very evil there. I cannot explain the repulsion I felt in my soul... please bear with me.

The children are being taught to use witchcraft! And ( although I hear it is a little better in the newest movie ) it is treated rather lightly! The children don't seem to flinch at the presence of ghosts.

There are wizards in The Lord of the Rings, but "magic" is something which is treated with great care. There is no God in Middle Earth, so it seems that ( since some sort of "Higher Power" is needed to complete the story ) Tolkien chose to use "magic". Although some Christians are not in complete agreement as to whether or not this movie should have our approval, there is definitely not that evil feel to it.

I just read an article on the making of Narnia. C.S. Lewis said this when he wrote L,W & W: "I said to myself, 'Let us suppose that there were a land like Narnia and that the Son of God, as he became a Man in our world, became a Lion there, and then imagine what would happen'". L,W & W is definitely more directly related to Christianity than LOTR, but, like Tolkien, Lewis used a different land and a different form of a "Higher Power" to represent the deep truths of Christianity. It's some- times more effective than trying to use today's world and the "real God" when trying to witness. You guys would probably just dismiss it immediately! :)

Thanks for listening.

title: 4 kids live the adventure of a lifetime..NOT!
review: This is by far the most mind-numbing film I've ever had the dissatisfaction of seeing.Although it is said to be a family film, hence one whose main target is kids under 15, I sincerely doubt anyone could possibly endure the 140 most excruciating minutes in history, without shouting to the so-called scary villain-Queen of Narnia "Kill them all and get it over with!" So, if you happen to hit upon the idea of giving this movie the time of day, I recommend you consider doing something more useful,like taking out the garbage or socializing with the annoying neighbor next door, because you will undoubtedly enjoy yourself more!!!

title: What a shame ...
review:
I don't want to speak about CGI usage. Seems that a lot of people like it and get deeply impressed by it, otherwise these kind of movies wouldn't be such box-office hits. I find CGI is not a good way to transport emotions (exeptions: real comic movies like __The Incredibles (2004)__, which was amazing).

I don't want to speak about acting. Tilda Swinton is an outstanding actress, but a total waste here (she was great in "Constantine").I don't remember the rest of the staff (was there any?).

But what is the message of this movie? If you are on the "right" side of a war, then you win and you get back from death? Should this movies prepare our children's for the next "good" war? I didn't read the book, what I saw on the screen was a simple plot.

I like cruel movies when the cruelty is shown as what it is: cruel, heartless, merciless. But this should be a movie for kids, or am I wrong? Will they think war is a good thing, OR that a war always leaves two loosing parties (except the people who sell weapons)?

title: A huge disappointment
review: I was really looking forward to this film, being a massive fan of the books, however I thought the film was a huge disappointment - where do I start? Wooden acting, dialogue's that were so outdated as to belong in the last century, overlong, boring, special effects in todays sophisticated market were reminiscent of Dr Who in the 60's - OK perhaps thats a slight exaggeration! The makers forgot some very simple lessons, firstly not to try and replicate the books. The film has to stand up on its own and be adapted accordingly. Many of the scenes could have been cut and would not have detracted from the overall understanding. Good things - the wolves, Aslan (excellent and believable)ummm...I'm thinking...OK I give up! In fact the whole thing had me wishing that the Witch would kill off Lucy within five minutes which unfortunately she didn't!! Not all kids make good actors - come back Harry and Co!!! Actually thats not a bad idea..Harry Potter instead of Peter.....

title: Is this mass hysteria? Did I see the same movie?
review:
(if you have no knowledge of the story ahead of time this may be a tad confusing)

I really don't see where everyone is so sold on this film. Even Ebert has lost his mind. People are giving this the grades of Shawshank and Empire Strikes Back when it had sooooo little value. I refuse to believe people have them on the same curve, much less the same universe.

I'm curious to see where exactly this movie succeeded.

Visually? No! They saved all their cash for the obviously expensive CGI trip at towards the end and everything else was a soap opera sound stage, but with less humanity and realism. Terribly claustrophobic, I at no point got to see anything that made me think Narnia was more than a few feet and a football sized battlefield.

Directing? heck no! Would someone please tell the High King to stop holding his sword like a remote control? If you're going to try and make young actors cry .. you need to at least put some saline in their mouth or something .. I mean come on... what do you want? Lucy had to cry like 5-6 times not one of them made me feel anything but pity for the young actress forget the part she's playing.

Writing/story? Come on.. For those that have seen it, was there really much of a story at all? no .. straight up no. All the thought provoking visual dialog between the kids was cut out. Just about any device to make Narnia real was cheapened. To quote one critical review I read that is right on the money "I kept waiting to be transported right through the credits."

I'm not saying there weren't any good parts. They have interesting beats with the beavers and a fox. I really thought some magic was going to happen in an early exchange Lucy has with the Faun Mr. Tumnus. But, it didn't deliver and neither did this film Not by a long shot.

title: Honestly the only thing your even mildly interested in is the bloody lion and he was 100% cgi!
review: Oh dear, oh dear. And you thought Harry Potter had bad child actors in it. Go and see Narnia and marvel at how these youngsters take acting to an all time low. The visual juxtaposition between actors is incredible as well. Never have you seen professional actors try so so hard to drag a performance out of these empty shells calling themselves stars. Narnia sees the likes of James McAvoy, Tilda Swinton and even Liam Neeson battling valiantly to create a good film against poor cgi, an adequate score, a god-forsaken script and the worst performances given by children you have seen in your life. It is truly a terrible film and whilst your kids may enter the cinema shaking with glee rest assured they will exit shaking with sadness and confusion as to why Peter wore a crusaders outfit, why no one actually dies during war and how could someone have got such an easy formula so so wrong? Don't go and see Narnia, try medieval torture, you leave with the same effect. On the other hand Narnia makes a stomping good comedy movie, from the stupid boy's stupid dad's picture being broken to the little elf man catching an arrow in the chest. A laugh out loud feel good victim comedy that whole family can either cringe or snort derisively at with laughter. Honestly the only thing your even mildly interested in is the bloody lion and he was 100% cgi!

title: It's 100% Disney - Not more.
review: If you want to see this movie because you liked the trailer. Think again! If you want to watch it because it's Disney. Watch it! It's 100% Disney - and thats it. This movie is incomparable to "Lord of the rings" - i wish it would be. One important thing in a good story is to know why characters are acting like they do. What are their motives, their aims and why. Don't expect answers like these. Why is the White Which like this? - No answer! Why do children hide from the world war and fight to death? - I don't know, because this movie leaves most of your questions unanswered. The CGI Effects are sometimes really good but then in the next scene i could have done better than ILM. At least one good thing about this film are the imaginative inhabitants of Narnia. Tolkien was right, when he told Lewis his book is not worth the paper it is printed on. And that's it!

title: Don't waste your money - not for young children!
review: I went to see this movie, because I loved the Lord of the Rings trilogy and I knew that the same special effects people who worked on LofR worked on Narnia. Although it was visually inspiring and the creatures and animals were well done, the actual story was boring and the violence was appalling, given that it's rated PG and for children. I don't know of any children who need to see epic battle scenes or animals (lion, wolf, fox) being killed, plus watching other children do the killing. When the movie began with the fear surrounding living in London during WWII, I sensed that it was going to be inappropriate for children. It was a very scary, violent movie - for a child. I think that the people who rate movies need to change the rules. It's pathetic. I could go on and on, but in summary, don't waste your money.

title: Hey! You trod on my dreams!!, and the dreams of every child.
review:
I haven't written a spoiler - the entire movie is one big spoiler for anyone who respects the written words of CS (Jack) Lewis for the treasures they are, and who hopes that their child might learn a love of reading and develop their own imagination without being told what or how to think.

Problem one - Where is The Magician's Nephew? Without that before LW&W you are only getting Narnia Lite, despite what the theological purists say about the reading order.

Problem two - Jack Lewis wrote the stories to get children to think and imagine for themselves. Showing children what to imagine is like doing their homework for them, but on a much more soul-destroying and life-long scale.

Problem three - the voice-overs were chosen for pop-appeal rather than from serious quality actors. Comediennes and pop singers!!! A travesty wrapped in a farrago of misrepresentations.

Problem four - a wise person said that the Chronicles of Narnia should be read four times - as a child, as a young adult, in middle age and finally in old age, because the words of Jack Lewis will bring you a different kind of joy each time.

How can you do that with a movie? I can't think of a crueller thing to do to the memory and legacy of Jack Lewis or to your own children than to show them what and how to imagine rather than giving them the books and letting them imagine Narnia for themselves.

Except to show them the earlier 'muppet' version, but the crippling of the childhood imagination is the same unless they read the original words for themselves.

Truly great books were never meant to be recycled into celluloid, and this is one instance. Lewis wanted to teach children to think and imagine for themselves, and this film does neither and cripples both.

All in all, give your children the printed words of Lewis for the rest of their lives, not some flack's CGI imagination, editorial compromises and pop-culture voice-overs for a couple of hours of electronic babysitting.

This movie could debase the opportunity to imagine for one's self, for an entire generation of children who might have learned to love to read.

If you truly love your children, buy them the books and skip the fake film version - a cluster-bomb for a child's imagination and intellect.

title: How could they spoil so much Aslan???
review:
Well, Aslan is supposed to be the king of the universe of Narnia. In the book, He, is described to be big, almost as big as an elephant. Mayestic, wonderful, fear-inspiring. How many times did C.S. Lewis repeat: He is NOT a domesticated animal.

Aslan, in this movie, appears like a totally domesticated big-cat, a non-fear inspiring animal. When Aslan, the real Aslan roars, the whole cinema should shiver and try to cover their ears, for the voice of Aslan is the voice of the creation.

Now, leaving aside Aslan -what should be impossible- the movie is weak. Narnia seems to be a world inside a closet, not a universe biggest than ours that may be reached by some secret doors, one of which is a small closet. The battles are childish, the armors are feeble, the whole idea is lousy. Peter Jackson should have directed this movie, he has an open mind, and would be less concerned with making a movie for children.

title: Not my 'Beloved Masterpiece'
review:
Movies are never as good as the books, especially true for this movie. Perhaps I was spoiled by the Lord of the Rings which were done quite well, because this movie did not do the book justice. This had a more "Disney" feel that totally obliterated the wonderful atmosphere written by C.S Lewis. The only character that resembled the book was Lucy, who was also the only good actor in the whole movie. All the rest were annoying and unrecognizable.

Thank god I only paid 95 cents to see this movie. I still want my 140 minutes back so I can read the book instead and actually enjoy myself. I'll have to so as to remind myself what a powerful and memorable character Aslan is instead of that big CG animated pussy.

At least the sets were nice.

title: Bad Acting and mistake
review:
A good film, but terrible acting - 'Lucy' kept grinning stupidly the entire film and even when she was was meant to be crying it was v. unrealistic.

This film was intended to grab the Harry Potter audience - but has failed in part due to a terrible child cast. The BBC production was much better.

MISTAKE IN FILM: Mr. Beaver gives Lucy the handkerchief that she had given to Mr Tumnis. At the end of the film, Mr Tumnis gives the handkerchief back to Lucy (she already had it from Mr Beaver).

Very good and moving soundtrack.

title: A steady slope downhill from the beginning
review: The movie is a LotR wannabe Take a classic story, then remove the majority of the dialog, the character development, and hype it up with a lot of slow motion battle scenes and well there it is. The battle scenes were brutal. To make it suitable for the 5- age category the centaur who was quite obviously killed to protect Peter (which i can't remember from the books but seems like a good idea) magically comes back to life in time for the coronation. Considering the MASSIVE budget some scenes like the battle scene or the obviously fake bombers at the beginning could have been done up and the scenery seriously needed an improvement. I have the BBC version on VHS and though that film is embarrassing the graphics are so bad it is a lot better story-wise. I loved the Narnia books when i was younger and the whole Christian symbolism etc. The movie ignores most of that and plunges right into action scenes to keep younger children amused while if this movie was made a bit more violent it would be 13+ and there would be more story. Bad, bad movie and one to miss

title: Good scenes, poor characters and plot
review: The movie improves on the book in several respects -- visually powerful (especially for Aslan, battles, and fauns), more focused and coherent, with the seeming factual nature of film bolstering credibility. Aside from those, the movie is a junk shop of what are presumed to be children's desires -- to be powerful, good, admired and magical. However, the movie is a wicked witch, offering a few short-term pleasures in an attempt to seduce the young. Let me mention as an illustration the main plot assumption: all good-hearted creatures are unified by the desire to put four bickering children on thrones as co-rulers of a non-human world. There is never a hint of why this fantasy might be an undesirable reality, because anything undesirable can be removed with a potion, prophecy or an attitude adjustment.

title: Too much like Lord Of The Rings !
review:
I read lots of positive comments about this film but, as happened when I saw Donnie Darko, I do not agree with the other viewers.

First of all, the trailer was absolutely wrong because it pretended to be a sort of "Lord Of The Rings" production, but, watching the film, I realized that everything was represented in a childish way, much much much more than Harry Potter (and that doesn't pretend to be fantasy). The worst thing is that I didn't see any children at the theater maybe because of the "I do not tell the truth" trailer.

Here in Italy, the lion voice is really awful, irritating and difficult to understand clearly because they used Omar Sharif instead of a real Italian actor.

Some shots resemble too much the Lord Of The Rings, for example when the three brothers run away from the witch before meeting Santa Claus and they walk through the snow, just like the Fellowship of the Ring crossing the Misty Mountains. The only moments I liked were the battle and the lion killing the bad witch, but it was too "politically correct" because the good guys do not die and even frozen characters come to life again. I understand. Teenagers would have been disappointed by showing them a little bit of real life.

Maybe I would have enjoyed watching this film. If I was a teenager. But I'm 31 and I didn't.

title: Poor CGI and Acting
review: After having been treated for epics such as LOTR trilogy based on the creations of master Tolkien, I have expected producers of Chronicles of Narnia a much better depict of the tales created by another master of English Literature, C.S. Lewis. Although the film follows the works of C.S. Lewis, it seems effortless in the sense that actors are not up to the role they want to project with the children acting in an awful manner. CGI is also very poor and highly unrealistic and background and animations are of very poor quality, especially when compared to LOTR trilogy. I would have expected a film of much better quality and direction. Maybe that's because there is only one Peter Jackson unfortunately.

title: quite a disappointment
review:
This comment is meant for those who are mislead by the highly overrated score on IMDb and perhaps expect too much of this movie.

Having read a review that wasn't too enthusiastic about it, I went to see the film yesterday without any high expectations, by which I usually enjoy it more. Putting my brain at rest and eyes focused on pure enjoyment and entertainment, I was at least hoping that it could carry me away into this magic world of Narnia. However it didn't.

Regarding the history of the movie I couldn't help comparing it often with Lord of the Rings. Yet, everything that made LOTR so great, seemed to be lacking here, even if this story was probably meant for a much younger audience. The lack of tempo made it even boring at occasions. It took the children (or the movie) way too long to enter Narnia. Once there, the slow pace just went on, wasting time on silly and meaningless dialogs instead of explaining and revealing more of the history and background of this world. Santa??? The 4 children had to carry this film throughout the end but their wooden performances didn't succeed in this at any time. Not a bad word on the witch though, Tilda Swinton did a pretty good job. Together with Oreius they were the only two characters that stood above the ground.

About the credibility and predictability of the movie. There wasn't one moment where I thought something bad was about to happen, not the slightest sense of a threatening atmosphere at all. At a certain moment it even became funny or absurd (like telling such a bad joke you eventually have to laugh about it). I often call it 'Arnold Schwarzenegger'-humor. 'Are you with me' Peter asks Oreius. 'Till death' he answers. Sorry, but those lines just don't work if there's no bond or connection between the characters. We've seen them what, 5 or 10 seconds together? Enough said, I just don't agree with the general opinion about this movie and I usually do. Just to compare, this comes from sb who adored LOTR, enjoyed the 1st and liked the 3rd and 4th Harry Potter movies.

title: Mediocre
review:
I found the books very moving. I found the start of the movie promising. But the movie is paced very poorly: too much time is spent in setting up the children and the Narnia environment, and not nearly enough time is spent on the Aslan part of the story. I felt little investment in these characters; the pacing felt rushed and geared more toward chase and battle scenes than toward the material and scenes that should be so emotionally gripping. The big emotional scenes were far too rushed. And given that the movie has made the choice to go for the adventure aspect of things, the CGI effects were great...for 1982.

Inevitable comparisons will be made to Lord of the Rings. To some degree, these aren't quite fair: Tolkein's work is, from a literary standpoint, stronger. That aside, had Peter Jackson made this film, it would have been fantastic. And by that I don't only mean special effects (though there did seem to be a bunch of cast-off costumes from LotR): this director needs to learn about pacing.

On the good side, the faun, Mr Tumnus, is played very effectively, the children Lucy and Edmund are strong, and Tilda Swinton rocks as the White Witch--she's the best part of the movie, really.

Otherwise, it was rather disappointing. It wasn't awful. It just wasn't good. If you've read the books, as many on the forum have, you might be able to wring the emotion out of the film based on your memory of your reading. If you haven't read the books, this film will leave you wondering what all the fuss was about.

title: Terrible
review:
I can't believe there are so many people who actually find this a good movie. I would give it a 1 out of 10, but since it's a child movie i give it a little cut. There are a lot of child (/disney) movies that i like very much, both animated and real. However this one was just plain terrible.

The worst is the children. They are casted to be SO cute but they just can't act and they irritate the crap out of me. If this was the only failure i would maybe see through it, however there is really nothing good about this movie.

The beginning takes far too long and could easily have been cut 15 minutes, it seems like the director wanted to make the movie last for like 3 hours, to match the common image of "epic" fantasy movies. The story is very very simple and predictable but i guess you can't blame the director for this. The computer generated scenes also just not cut it. Sure it looks nice, but it all seems a little too rushed. CG Animals are not real enough and backgrounds look plain and dull.

Laughable i found the part where a battle is just about to begin, and the sound fades completely like in Gladiator. There is even a matrix-like moment.

Oh one light could be the music, it was very beautiful from time to time.

To sum things up: completely unlikable, unrealistic, bad-at-acting main characters ,bad CG, bad story, good music

just a terrible movie, don't waste your time and money.

title: Could they have ruined an incredible book even more?
review:
... probably not.

I read the book as a child and loved it, re read it as an adult and loved it, watched the film and I very nearly walked out.

How can you destroy such an epic book with such ease? The actors were horrible with screenplay and dialogue that made you cringe and almost burst into tears. From the start the Peter, Susan and Lucy (though to give the girl some credit did well for someone of her age) ruined it through shoddy acting, they played their roles poorly. Edmund was the saving grace of the four main characters but not by much. The only part of the film that did the book justice was the battle at the end with spectacular computer graphics.

All in all a thorough waste of money, you can't take an incredible story off to New Zealand and hope to turn it into a blockbuster: completely disappointing.

title: Zzzzzzzzzzzz...
review: My summary accurately captures my sentiments for this film. I must admit that I was not a huge fan of the book either, but the movie felt rushed and off balance. I could've cared less if any of the characters lived or died. I found it very bland, boring and clichéd. This might actually be one area where the case could be made that the movie should have been longer to better develop the characters and build the relationships between them and Narnia's inhabitants. Their interaction with Aslan was flat and emotionless. The only shining aspect of the film was the part of Lucy Pevensie, played by Georgie Henley. She was absolutely precious throughout the film.

title: Did I see the same movie as everyone else?
review:
Considering all the glowing reviews on this site, I'm beginning to wonder if I saw the same movie as everyone else. IMO, this movie was just bad. I am disappointed, but in a way not surprised, because I remember reading this book when I was younger and really enjoying it-- not surprised because the previews looked bad as well.

I'm going to say first off that the whole x-tian allegory thing didn't bother me in the slightest. Although I'm not x-tian per se, I do enjoy reading the bible on my free time and have no problem discussing x-tian issues with other people; in fact, I love doing so. That said, this movie was just too blatant. In fact, it was laughable. I recall the book being a lot subtler than the movie, and I get the impression that they made the movie this way intentionally (to attract the lucrative x-tian market). And what an allegory! If Aslan is supposed to be Jesus, what on earth was he doing fighting in a war and killing people? Wasn't Jesus the one who said, "turn the other cheek?" And Aslan's sacrifice wasn't exactly pure to say the least. It had a lot more to do with fulfilling the prophecy (ie, making the four humans survive) than actual charity. One wonders if he would have bothered had it been anybody else (probably not, since he was killing characters left, right and center in the movie). There are more.. but I won't bother. Needless to say, Santa handing out lethal weapons to children had me laughing out loud (much like the rest of the movie).

But terrible allegories aside (these are forgivable, and I'm sure justifiable, since almost anything is justifiable in religion), this movie was bad on many technical levels as well: 1) The acting was wooden. Lucy in particular was just terrible. The only bright spot, in terms of acting, was the Witch. She was actually quite convincing (minus her horrible wardrobe).

2.) The CGs were awful. The movie honestly felt like it was made in 1997 and not 2005. The green screens were poor (I'm being kind here). The cg characters were badly made (wooden) and lacked any kind of life. It's pretty bad when in almost every scene you think to yourself, "wow that looks pretty fake." And the wolves were particularly bad because they kept switching between real dogs and fake wolves. It was quite distracting "oh, real dogs again.. nope fake ones now". The one scene I was impressed by was the one where the two girls are walking with Aslan in the Forest. That was well made (although, my memory might be playing tricks on me).

3.) Many of characters came across as creepy.. but not in that acceptable kind of creepy, but in a pedophilic kind of way. Honestly, when Lucy meets Mr. Tumnus, I was really expecting him to jump on her (although, I knew he wasn't). The same can be said about the Witch, although to a lesser degree, in her first scene.

Had it not been for these problems, the movie might have been great (the story is actually pretty interesting).. but bad and sometimes creepy acting, bad effects, and blatantly exaggerated allegories (that are bad too), wreck this movie and make it terrible in that "showgirls" kind of way (although, I think showgirls was intentionally made as an ironic comedy). In fact, my friend and I were laughing so hard during this movie, that one person sitting next to us actually moved.

I mean come on, how can you not laugh at a movie that has Santa giving a bunch of kids totally lethal weapons, and tries to do so with a straight face?

title: Not Very Good!
review: This movie wasn't as good as critics were saying, first of all it had A lot of gore in it, it should of been rated pg-13 instead of just Pg. Also it was Christian based, I'm not saying anything is wrong with that because I'm a Christian but not everybody has that religion. So putting stuff like that in a movie is a bad idea because not everybody could see it because of their religion. So over all i didn't like it at all it was Very confusing you couldn't really follow the plot. I saw it with 3 of my other friends and we are all 13 and 14 years old and we could hardly follow it. It wasn't a children's movie or an adults movie, i don't know what it was! I just hated it so i don't recommend it.

title: Who Needs Lord Of The Rings!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
review: When i realised that this was going to be the first Christmas in 3 years without a Lord Of The Rings out at the cinema i was a little sad. I mean LOTR, all 3 of them, are AMAZING films and a Christmas without them didn't seem right. I then found out that The Chorincles Of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe would be coming out at Christmas, and being a fan of the book when i was younger i was intrigued by this multi-million pound blockbuster. Although i wanted to see it i was not all that excited about it. Over 2 hours later i walked out of the cinema blown away. The effects are outstanding, and the decision to have 4 unknown British actors play Lucy, Edmond, Susan and Peter Pevensie was a excellent idea. Aslan(voiced by Liam Neeson) was a perfect example of CGI at it's best. Although a Christmas without LOTR seemed daunting, The Chronicles Of Narnia filled it's shoes perfectly.

title: Pretty, but overall disappointing
review:
The special effects have been discussed at length by reviewers and viewers posting their opinions on this site, and they were certainly impressive.

Where I think this movie fails miserably is its character development. I've read the books, and know what care Lewis put into developing his characters personalities so that we can understand them.. but this movie doesn't even begin to scratch the surface. One minute, the kids are saying "we should really get out of Narnia", and then a minute later, "lets fight in the war and die for Narnia". The moral dilemma that Edmund faces is almost completely glossed over, and the viewer is left with only close-up reaction shots of the kids to substitute for actual exposition and character development.

I was also shocked at how they beat you over the head with the Christian message of the story. I know Lewis intended to copy the story of Christ, but I didn't expect the movie to attack so directly any characters that opposed the view of the "christian path".

Overall, I'd say that its worth seeing for the special effects and it's certainly entertaining. But as a movie that I'm expected to feel anything for beyond mindless entertainment, it fails, as I was unable to connect with any of the characters whom I felt were very relatable in the book.

title: An excellent children's movie--thank God they are believably English.
review:
I went into this movie not wanting to like it. I know the Narnia canon from front to back and, after seeing some disappointing changes made for The Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter, I didn't want my vision of Narnia to be tainted. But the reviews for this film were so strong that I gave in and paid my six dollars to see it. And it was excellent. For once the filmmakers (writers, really) have not taken license with the story but have instead just pared it down a little to make it fit into a timeframe. It was the CGI stuff that put me off in the previews but it didn't look too bad. I mean, occasionally it made me cringe (the fox) but on the whole it was not terribly distracting.

Tilda Swinton, as the witch, steals this movie. She is not a typical Disney villain--she is a bad-ass, and while watching I remembered that, after all, she is Jadis, the warrior goddess from another world, and it seems that the writers remembered that, too. The characters in this film have older memories of Narnia: memories that go beyond the Pevensies' experience. There are enough pointed looks and loaded answers to make sure that we, the audience, are aware of their significance. The costumes and makeup in this movie are outstanding--better than Lord of the Rings, I think. The only thing I found slightly amiss was that, as per Pauline Baynes's illustrations, I had always envisioned the witch as a brunette, but she looks so totally cool otherwise that I am not complaining.

title: Stunning
review: I had been looking forward to this movie for ages, and when I saw it this weekend I was not disappointed. The SFX were amazing, and the whole film really beautiful. They stayed very true to the book, and anything they changed made the movie more moving and interesting in my opinion. ABout the Christianity in the film, the book IS based on Christian beliefs, but thats just how the movie is. But overall, its not as if the whole movie was just trying to sell Christianity or put down other religions. So, If you want to see something I really do recommend this, Its never really boring, and its very touching, it also has great music that just flows right along with the scenes. Not to mention that the whole film is absolutely stunning. The only weird thing..the whole battle scene seemed like it would be very gory...but I never saw any blood? blood could not be much worse than some other parts. anyway, great movie! worth the money

title: A gorgeous treat for everyone!
review:
MILD SPOILERS AHEAD! It's as simple as this: young or old, see this film! The scenery, direction, actors, and, of course, the story are wonderful. The purity of the original book is upheld and the one or two added bits, such as the Blitz scene at the very beginning of the film, work extremely well. The child actors are all decent enough, all of them able to carry their scenes and successfully convey the courage and heartbreak of their characters. Georgie Henley and Skandar Keynes as Emdmund and Lucy are particularly convincing and when Lucy weeps for her fallen friends it melted even my cold cynical heart - so don't worry. As for the adult thespians, Tilda Swinton is positively glacial as the White Witch, James McAvoy is perfect as the sweet, tortured Mr Tumnus - and his chemistry with Henley is excellent - and Jim Broadbent makes good use of his limited screen time as the Professor. Liam Neeson as the voice of Aslan settles comfortably into his familiar role of kind mentor. New Zealand is apparently THE place to film one's fantasy epic these days and indeed, it's advantages are made very clear in this film. 'Narnia' (as most people are probably referring to it as) will thrill and it will delight and it should warm the hearts of everyone but the most bitter cynics. I went to see this film with eight friends of varying dispositions, some of whom adore the book and some of whom have never read it before and we all enjoyed it very much. Seeing a book so beloved by the nation brought to life on cinema is very satisfying and with Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings et al, it is becoming a regular occurrence. Let's make the most of this new so-called Age of the Fantasy Film and be thankful that we got to be here for its time on the big screen.

So, come on, indulge your children and your inner child and buy some hot chocolate and some Turkish delight and get down to the cinema now!

title: Sad - both reviews and the movie
review:
I don't know what's worse - the disappointment I felt after seeing the film, or some of the pathetic comments about its religious nature. I grew up a fan of Lewis and, having read his Narnia and other fiction (and non-fiction) books, I have to say the film is a huge let-down. No doubt, Peter Jackson should have done it. Unlike the books, it's just plain hollow. It's rushed and lacks the epic nature of the books. It should have been on par with LOTR, but comes nowhere close. What's worse are the scenes which are obviously trying to reach that level and which so blatantly fail.

As far as its religious nature, some of the reviewers here don't seem to realize that Lewis was a Christian who wrote - among other things - allegorical tales. This wasn't an alternative to Harry Potter, as some seem to think. It was an adaptation of some of the most loved and widely-read children's books in history.

If you don't understand why this had religious overtones, read the books. If you thought this movie would have made Lewis proud, read the books. If you want a great story in which you can get absorbed, read the books.

title: Disappointing
review: Some of the costumes in this movie were unforgivable, they looked like they were taken directly from the Xena Warrior Princess set. Seriously. I don't understand how the director allowed it to happen. The CGI was excellent, but I felt like the director couldn't make up his mind on which direction to go with the overall feel of the film. The casting was off as well, the children started to really irritate me with all their whining and crying, but again, that should get thrown on the director and not the actors. And I don't understand why the centaurs needed so much makeup. It didn't look good and didn't make a lot of sense since centaurs are half human/half horse, and not human/horse/elf ears. The whole thing felt very disjointed to me. There were just a lot of simple things that could've made this movie the classic that it deserved to be.

title: Over-hyped! Just Okay!
review:
Okay I admit, I took the bait due to all the coverage and church screenings of this movie and bought advance tickets for myself and my 12 year old son. He read the book and really didn't want to see it but I STILL got tickets. I should have listened to my son. I don't know why the Christian and church groups are really pumping this movie up. I don't get it. At any rate, here is my 2 cents worth.

First, this movie is really, really over-hyped. The clips shown make the movie appear more than it really is. I don't want to tell you any story lines but I will say this, see it at a matinée performance if you just have to see it and can't wait for HBO. But I will say this, the special effects and the animal characters are extraordinarily done. This movie should be a shoe in to receive an award for special effects. That was the best part of the movie.

Second, they hype this movie as being better than Harry Potter which I promptly paid to see for a second time after watching Narnia. There really is no comparison. Potter is far better movie and I haven't read that book either. Without having read Narnia, the plot was ALL TO PREDICTABLE from the very beginning. There really wasn't that much suspense involved. More than once I whispered to my son what was going to happen next and was right.

Last, I just wanted to say that it seems like there is going to be a tread to Potter like movies and if Narnia is indication of what is to come, then the Potter movies don't have a thing to worry about. Try to duplicate they might, but with Narnia it seems like all they did is a bad imitation. Go if you must, but don't expect very much.

title: Not as great as I hoped
review:
I was expecting a lot more from "The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe" because it is a great story and there has been a lot of hype about this picture. Unfortunately I felt after seeing it that there were parts of it that just didn't seem to be as quality as I hoped. For example, Mr Tumnus is not shown in full-body and close-up, it is always a legs shot or a face/upper torso shot, or shot from far away, so we can't really get a feel for how faun-like he really looks. Another example is where large backgrounds look a bit fake like a matte painting. I felt that the beavers were a bit over the top with comedy.

On the plus side though the voice acting of Aslan was wonderful, and the children were adorable. The story is well told.

title: So awful in made me register....
review:
I registered just to give this hyped, poor excuse of a movie a mark to take it down a bit... actually it is worth 5 stars just for trying to bing to life, Lewis' masterpiece, but I just have to take down that 7,2.

It has the worst special effects I have ever seen... reminiscent of Romanian 60's movies ( I think I could have done better in MS Paint, the scenario was pathetic and completely unoriginal, the acting was absolutely horrific (shame on you Neeson, but the most god-awful thing was the directing, it felt life a televised play from some indie theater.... Poor CS Lewis must be turning in his grave........ This tape should be burned on a stone table....

PS: The kids were cute though....;)

title: Worth walking out of
review:
Some producers were desperate to cash in on the success of The Lord of the Rings. "What we need," they said, "is epic battles between Good and Evil!"

So that's what you get. CS Lewis stole the Snow Queen from the brothers Grimm, so she's not exactly an original character, but Swinton does a good job, and is the only decent actor in the whole gig.

The oddest thing about the movie is that it ignores the fact that we, humans, exterminate species... And then bring them back to life "on the silver screen." Wheyhey! It's magic!

No, it stinks, this film. It's worth buying a ticket, just to puke some place in the cinema, and then get the heck out of there..

title: Is it possible to make the books even worse? Yes, it is.
review:
I have read all the Narnia books. I never liked them. When I saw the trailer, I had my suspicions -- and went to see the movie anyway, thinking "they might have turned bad fantasy into good fantasy." No such luck.

Visuals and performance: The acting is shallow throughout, with the exception of Tilda Swinton, who is the only one deserving of any stars here. There are so many talented, brilliant child actors in Britain; why did they choose what can only be the worst of the selection? The effects are ridiculously bad; only a third-rate computer game should get away with such a disaster without attracting much criticism. In the rare moments where you manage to get caught up in the set, a horrible CGI sequence will throw you off again. Speaking of the set: When I read "ILM" in the credits, I gasped with disbelief. Is there an ILM temp brigade, or something?

Content: Everything bad about the books was amplified, and where you could have overlooked it in the books, you can't escape it in the movie: the kids go from being victims of war to participating in a war themselves (even the visual parallel between air raid and air attacks in the battle is unmistakable); independent thought and criticism, especially from girls, is undesirable (anything Susan says, no matter how sensible, is met with ridicule); mercy is almost entirely unheard-of (whose head would Jesus bite off?). Finally, there is ONE extremely if involuntarily funny scene; in fact, most of the audience in the theatre where I saw the film started laughing -- the resurrected Aslan, back-lit in a kitschy stone arch, complete with flowing mane and all, is a lion equivalent of a blonde, blue-eyed Jesus painted on black velvet. The sappiness is so overwhelming it becomes ridiculous. In short, Tilda Swinton's performance is the only thing worth seeing, but even that is not enough to redeem the movie as a whole.

title: Just Don't Bother
review:
Well its hard to know where to start with this film. I don't want to give anything away if any of you decide that you want to waste the money going to see this film.

The storyline (looking beyond the magical world) is predictable and boring. There are several bits in the film that let you down and i almost walked out at one point.

I think for children this is an excellent film, however anyone over 18 will not like it. That is quite possibly why its marketed towards children.

The one saving grace of this film is the amazing acting by James McAvoy.

title: Garbage.
review:
This movie is terrible. The lion coming back is completely deus ex machina, there is 0 character development, Edward is a complete dick for no reason, the plot advances are meaningless and have no reason whatsoever, they do not build an ounce of sympathy for the people of Narnia, ETC. ETC. ETC. Please explain to me why so many people liked this piece of crap. The movie should stand on its own by the way, having to read the book to "get" the movie is just silly.

This entire movie was religious propaganda in shiny CG packaging. I am sad that I wasted 3 hours watching this utter piece of crap, hopefully someone will read this and not waste theirs.

title: Deathly boring
review: I don't even know why I went to go see this movie. I didn't really like the books; I was up to my nose in hobbits. This movie really didn't appeal to me, and as my friends sobbed over the death of Aslan, I was like, what's the big deal? He didn't even look real! None of the animals did! I could almost see through them! The writing was nearly word for word from the book. I'm not kidding. It shows that the writer cannot think for himself and therefore must copy words from the original source. The movie has no flow, and I don't think that it is any coincidence that the 'good guys' colours are the same of Rohan in Lord of the Rings. I also believe that watching the battle scene it 'battle of the Five armies' all over again. I would not suggest this film to anyone!

title: Sophisticated fur
review: Have you ever thought about how difficult it is to animate furred animals on the computer? This film gives us an impression how this is solved in these days: almost perfect I would say and I am that convinced now, because they showed us in very broad details, how good they are in doing so. Maybe they forgot to look at whats needed in addition to make up a convincing movie. Maybe the Lord of the Ring has "ruined" the scene of this kind of movies by being too perfect. OK, they tried to copy several elements, but constantly they succeeded in destroying their well done computer tricks by lots of nasty looking blue-box scenes. Few moments have some kind of "romantic touch". Additionally most of the real actors seem not to love their job. Sometimes I got the feeling that they are just clumsy reading some lines from a teleprompter while their animated counterparts are always more talented. From my point of view this film is absolutely childish and a waste of time for grown ups. Maybe my little kids like it - no blood at all and its black'n'white all over. No follow-ups please.

title: Should tank in the box office
review: I believe this movie has terrible flaws. It is pretentious and not particularly well acted; the visual effects are many times terrible, even some of the blue screens look like effects created with back projection. I'm guessing Disney's idea with this film is to compete with Harry Potter or with LOTR, I think they are failing miserably. If they are lucky enough they might recover the 150M they spend in this film, I just hope they don't decide to make the next books into films. As an investing tip, sell all your Disney stock or hope that Pixar's Cars will be as good as all the other Pixar films, if not, you are better off flushing your money down the toilet. Whatever happened to good screenplay writers in Disney? People wonder why the box office slump, well, it is easy, big studios spend 150M creating movies like Narnia. Avoid this movie, you have been warned, if you see it, it would be at your own risk.

title: Didn't Like...everything looked to be digital.
review:
CGI is boring, story line boring.

True to the book? Why would anyone care is beyond understanding.

Most Saturday morning cartoons are more entertaining. The DVD was not worth the money spend on it.

unsmiling
