NARNIA is a great film because even though it is one out of a million other fantasies aimed at kids, it stands out because it has such a whimsical quality to it. The colors, the lighting, the characters, it all adds up to a magical mix of atmosphere.

The score is perfect. The songs played during the battle sequence is beautifully moving. As well as the music during a citrine scene which I cant say too much about since it would be a major spoiler.

The mythology in NARNIA is also enjoying to watch. It seems like a mix of Greek, Roman and western European mythology. I must say every shot that includes a Griffin is marvelous. This mythology of creatures also insures some key characters being animals. And some of my favorites include two talking beavers who happen to be marries. Also the character of Mr. Tumnus is a very nice one who seems to contribute to the plot greatly although not too many people noticed that.

I would have mentioned Aslan in the previous paragraph since he is also a talking animal, but because he is the god of Narnia and an amazing character that has gone down in fantasy history, he deserves a paragraph for himself, although maybe only a book would be able to do him justice. Aslan is the god of Narnia and like the god that religious people believe in on earth, he is completely mysterious. Its not always clear why he does or doesn't do the things he does or doesn't do, but it does always seem to work in the end. Aslan, along with all the other Narnian creatures, is created amazingly by the film makers. There are so many incredible shots of him. He is also voices perfectly by Liam Neeson.

I think what makes me respect this film so much is the fact that there was so much love that went into making this film. And of course that is a very important ingredient in film making.

So I would definitely recommend this film to everyone, watch it, and buy the DVD. I got the 4-disc edition and its great, if you're a fan you should buy nothing less than the 4-dosc set. It includes more special features than the 1 and 2-disc editions plus it has a feature-length documentary on C.S. Luis, the author of the beloved NARNIA book series.

title: Heartbroken!
review:
I'm sorry everyone but I HATE this movie. The comments all seem to be positive. Does no one else see things the way I do? The first trailer I saw had me so excited that maybe they'd done gorgeous justice to my favourite books of all time.

Not so.

Yes it has lavish sets/costumes/props/pixels/unnecessary action... but it sure as hell cheaps out like any blockbuster does in telling the story.

Disney has been making me angry since I was a kid watching 'The Little Mermaid' and knowing she should turn into sea foam at the end. This is no different. It felt like this movie had been made to sell a video game. What's with the rushing across a breaking up river? What's with the battle scenes and DIALOG!? almost jokingly copied straight out of Lord of the Rings? This story is not a complicated mess of meanderings and secret meetings with underground (no pun intended) animals. This wasn't Narnia, it's a modern mockery. It is a movie for it's time when audiences want bigger and better CGI, millions of orcs/centaurs/whatevers fighting each other in clean digital fashion. DOES NO ONE HAVE IMAGINATION ANYMORE TO SEE THINGS FOR THEMSELVES? That was part of the point to the story in the first place. The books inspired my imagination like nothing else ever did. This movie leaves NOTHING to the imagination. Like so many movies these days, it hands everything out on a silver platter. Sometimes I yearn for the days of 2-d animation and creativity in solving problems without computers. Yet, 'Pan's Labyrinth' used CGI without overdoing it. Maybe this is what you get with the director of 'Shrek' at the helm. I have very little hope for 'Prince Caspian' being any better.

I'll just stick to my books and the badly animated, yet so much more entertaining, 1979 cartoon version that actually has some real feeling. -From a girl who used to look in everyone's closets.

title: One Remake that is on target! Not Many Remakes Are.
review: This film is a masterpiece, a wonderful film, an excellent film, a wonder to behold. Sure, they do change several things, but who's quibbling? Not me! I liked all the cast, except there was one problem with Lucy- that face she makes when she is upset. I could'nt stand it. It makes me sick every single time I watch it. Swinton was good, but the witch- no matter who she is played by, she is ugly. Kellerman (original BBC TV version) did animate everything way too much, and overdid it by a long shot. Swinton, however, was quite perfect as the witch. She will HAVE to come back for the Magician's Nephew, but as for Silver Chair, I know that witch was of the "same crew" and all that, but I think that if she tried to do that role too, she would basically be redoing her role from this, and therefore downplaying her role in this. Skandar did not have any facial expressions, except when he got wounded by the witch- his face was contorted beyond all reason. Jonathon Scott, from the BBC version, did not have any facial expressions at all, not even when he is being the unsatisfied brat. On the other hand, I thought the animators for the animated version of this did Edmund's facial expressions quite well. MOST AWESOME SCENES: when the two armies run at each other- there is dead silence, until the first sounds of hand-to-hand combat could be heard, and the second is when the centaur guy tries to attack the witch.

title: Wow. What a shame. Who has seen the original here?
review:
The reason I haven't seen this remake earlier is because I heard how bad it was. Now I know why. The first thing that got to me was the acting of all of the children. Unbelievably...bad! Come on guys this is Narnia, what I grew up with, I want to feel your emotions! But I got none.

The second is how all this CGI looks nice but in the end actually makes the original 1988 Narnia so much better. Firstly the acting was actually good, and secondly, there is something about seeing a physical, beautiful lion or seeing those two cheeky beavers (even though they were two actors in suits)..again physically being there instead of some CGI garbage, that added to "real-ness" of this fantasy land. Aslan had this presence that was shattered with pretty Computer Animation.

Also, with the characters, (because they actually acted in the '88 version), their relationships between themselves were so much more real, unlike here the attempted emotion about finding Edmund again..I don't feel it. I don't really believe they cared about finding Edmund again, yet, in the '88 version...I believed it all! I am rambling here and have made massive comparisons to something I originally watched on ABC , only because given current advances in movie making they could have made this so much more. What they have given us is something children will no doubt like, but more mature movie goers like myself have to shake my head in shame to imagine if the rest of the series will be filled in this empty-shell style.

The only reason this gets a 6 out of 10 is because it was a good trip back to the original Narnia, and I have not seen it in a while. I will probably watch it again tomorrow to remind myself of how good it is. Everyone else- get the original

title: Everything I could possibly want and so much more
review:
When I heard they were doing a motion picture of Narnia, I had a little checklist of things in my head that the movie absolutely had to do right for me to be happy coming out of the theatre. They had to show the interaction between Lucy and Tumnus well. I didn't want Tumnus to come across creepy and squicky, especially. I wanted to see the scene between the Queen and Edmund. I wanted to see the presents from Santa, even if we didn't see Santa. And they absolutely HAD to have grown-up Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy on a hunt at the end. I was not disappointed by any of those scenes. They were all there, and they were all wonderful.

Tumnus was perfect and timid and just wonderful to watch, and the costume and effects for his hooves were perfect. Even his scarf was lovely. The scene with him lulling Lucy to sleep by playing his pipe, and Aslan breaking the spell is absolutely gorgeous. And his horror at what he's been forced to do was well-played.

Tilda was lovely, if extremely understated. I'm still trying to decide if I would have wanted someone more over-the-top for the Queen. I love Tilda, but I was expecting more histrionics, I guess. On the other hand, she was gorgeous, and definitely coldly cruel. And the scene where she made a hot drink and Turkish Delight for Edmund was perfect.

The scene with Santa was almost exactly word-for-word from the book at the beginning, though I did miss him giving them the presents for Edmund as well, and apparently the beavers deserved nothing... I do understand why they cut that part of the scene, but still.

But my favorite scene was the Hunt. I was so worried they'd sell it short and keep them kids, but I desperately wanted to see the older versions of them, and the return to the "real world" as it were. It was so perfect, and the falling out of the wardrobe kids again was exactly how I'd hoped.

Now, I'm a long-time fan of the Narnia books. Read them several times over the years. And though I didn't see the Christian imagery when I was a kid, it's blatant to me now. And while I'm stridently anti-religion, and those sorts of things usually annoy the heck out of me, I can honestly say that the scriptwriter did an excellent job on transferring it all across. There was no new imagery to "suggest" further religious stuff, and I don't particularly think they toned down what CS Lewis actually had in the story itself. I thought it was actually quite well-handled, considering.

Other bits and pieces:

* Jim Broadbent as the Professor. Such an excellent casting choice. He really does the childlike surprise and interest well.

* Aslan. I would have liked a stronger voice, actually. I love Liam Neeson, but I don't think he was strong enough for the part when it came right down to it. I guess it felt to me like Aslan was holding back a bit.

* The Beavers were fabulous. The animation was perfect, and the interplay between the two of them was wonderful. And Dawn French was fabulous, as usual.

* I have heard others say that Edmund steals the movie, but really, aside from one scene at the beginning of the movie, everything I saw in the movie with him was stuff that was straight from the book. And the boy they got to play him did an excellent job.

* Peter--the young man they got to play him was excellent. He is how I have always seen Cedric Diggory in my head, if a touch younger than Cedric in GOF.

* I quite liked how they illustrated the realities of the children's situation before they got on the train, and also how much the kids really felt like siblings. Whoever was responsible for that did an excellent job.

* My husband was thrilled at "Aslan's on the move." Rather important line, and nicely done. Sent a thrill through me when I heard it. And another wonderful line that I'd totally forgotten about until it was said: "Ward Robe in the land of Spare Oom..." Which makes me think of Rock and Rule now, but it's an adorable line.

* The wardrobe itself was an absolutely gorgeous thing. WETA outdid themselves, and not just on that, either. The costumes after they arrive at Aslan's camp, and the weapons and crowns were all gorgeous.

* Tumnus's punishment. I was practically biting my nails waiting for Edmund to stumble across Tumnus in the Queen's courtyard, but when they showed him it was utterly perfect and so miserable. Poor Edmund...

* And OMG, the swordfighting. I kept snickering at Peter using his sword like a gun, keeping it trained on whoever he was fighting, but I love that in the final battle sequences they were actually swordfighting--meaning that they weren't fencing with the ruddy things or using them like clubs. Tilda especially shone in the battle sequences.

So, yes. Good movie. Watch. It's worth it.

title: Just about average
review: I grew up with the Lord of the Rings and the Narnia books. When they first announced the Lord of the Rings movies I just thought they were going to mess it all up, but they didn't. It's about time a real movie adaption of the Narnia books were made, and I can't say I'm too happy about it. I had high (probably too high) expectations. I must agree with all of you that state ''the acting sucked''. I didn't like the actor who played Lucy, and the others did a mediocre job. The story is great, but they didn't capture it too well. Visual effects...Yeah, they are doing their job. The musical score were fulfilling and well made. It's no Gladiator or Star Wars, but it's quite nice. Can't say it fulfilled by hopes of a great Narnia movie, but we can only hope the next will be better. Six stars out of ten.

title: A sober ,non annoying movie for children .
review: I remember that I read "The Lion ,the Witch and the Wardrobe " when I was a kid and I liked very much .I haven't seen yet the other TV-movies that were made before ,but I think that this one is a decent adaptation of the books of C.S.Lewis . Certainly one of the best aspects of the movie are the visuals , that look splendid without being excessive or ridiculous .Besides the lovely visuals ,the movie was pretty funny and enjoyable without being incredible . One of the weak points f the movie could be that at moments ,the movie is very slow and plain . The performances are fine but not so good as could (or should ) have been . The music is adequate for the tone of the story full of fantasy . "The Chronicles of Narnia " is over the horrid kid movies that are common in this days . The result is a decent movie for all the family .

title: A great movie
review:
I think that The Chronicles of Narnia is a great movie. I totally enjoyed this film.

The movie is translate from the comic series and the movie almost follow the guild lines so that I feel very understand when I was watching it. The Chronicles of Narnia talks about the four kids who travel through a wardrobe to the land of Narnia and learn of their destiny to free it with the guidance a mystical lion. The animations and the sound effect are great. In the film, it includes a lot of scope, depth, and wonder, so that it almost excited me in every minute. The characters are acting so great and I will choose Georgie Henley as my favorite character. She is Lucy Pevensie in Narnia and her performance is excellent. She can show me that the pretty and active of the real character and she can express her own feelings very truly. I am very touching after watching it and I think I learn a lot of things in the film. Although the film is based on a kid's book, but it is very suitable for anyone . I think all of you will be entertained by it and I want to present the film to all of you.

title: Narnia is sugar-coated "White-man's Burden"
review:
...First of all, Narnia is a world of animals. Being devoid of humans, it can be understood as the idealized realm of the natural, despite being nothing but fantasy. What is interesting, is that the natural is not conceived as mere existence, but rather presupposes a certain moral value-system. CS Lewis thus is able to take his morality and paint it onto the idea of nature. He therefore justifies his beliefs by embedding them into the firmament of existence in a fictionalized world. The animals of Narnia are therefore divided into good and badÂ—and this world is wrought by a moral battle between the good lion and the evil witch.

The entry of the four children is something like the "white man's burden". The four are somehow fated by the scripture of some manifest destiny in the prophecy to overthrow the evil witch and save the natural kingdom. What is even more perverse is the superimposition of British schemes of royalty and nobility onto the scene, echoing the arguments of "divine right" of old...

For more: themeasure.blogspot.com, Where I wrote this critique entitled Latent Ideology in Entertainment

title: films are not meant to be books, but neither are they meant to be so shallow and empty
review:
The tragic reality of our time is that people don't read books and don't like to be challenged. The greatness of Lewis's books were their commitment to hard realities and the strength of hope when it is not sugar-coated.

This film was made for modern Americans. No surprise there. But Lewis's books were written for a far wider audience.

As deviating as Peter Jackson's films were, at least they were entertaining in their own right. This was just boring fluff. The actors have a self-consciousness in their performance that is as bad as the self-consciousness that poisons modern American integrity. Mr. Tumnus was always one my favorite characters from the books. But here he is a weak fool with no convincing heart. I think many fans expected the professor to be more like Lewis himself. One good scene was when the Lucy is staring into the fire while listening to Tumnus's flute and she sees the figures dancing in the flames. They would have to make the whole film in that manner if they even wanted to come close to the spirit of Lewis's books. While in the theatre I sat next to a boy probably four years old. He was completely bored, jumping around, kicking the seat in front of him. During the fire scene, he suddenly became completely still and was utterly enthralled.

The child knew.

title: David in the Aisle- Chronicles of Narnia
review: What all started as a simple game of hide-n-seek developed into a remarkable adventure. During World War II, a family of four children are sent to live with professor, little do they know this was the beginning of a unforgettable event. Based on a book by C.S. Lewis the Chronicles of Narnia takes you in an astonishing venture with Lucy, Edmond, Susie and Peter Pevensie, staying in this new house must abide to many rules; not touching, no yelling and especially to leave the professor alone. With all these regulations instituted the Pevensies still find many loopholes, during one of there games Lucy the smallest girl saunters into the wardrobe and is whisked into a different world. A snowy paradise, upon meeting Mr. Tumnus, a half human faun, she is kidnapped, yet upon her escape she makes her way back home. Edmond the second youngest stumbles upon this wonderland and meets the cause of all the troubles, the white witch, she befriends Edmund using some of his favorite food and offers him the position of king if he were to bring back the rest of his family. Eventually all four children walk into the terrain of Narnia and hear the background story from a friendly beaver about a prophecy, a king named Aslan and an army that could defeat the white witch. With the help from many creatures and witty plays, the kids start to bring spring back to Narnia and weaken the powers of the white witch. With an army of mystical creatures, talking animals and magical weapons the two sons of Adam and two daughters of Eve go into battle to fulfill the prophecy, but do they succeed? I give this film 3 out of 4 'davids.' This is a movie to enjoy with everyone, the scenes were magnificent, the story line is amazing, plus the battle scenes are glorious and they didn't even use blood, this is a must see movie! If you enjoyed or are interested in this movie I would recommend; "Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events" ; "Harry Potter Series" and "Wizard of OZ."

title: Absolutely Phenomenal Movie
review:
This is one of the Best Movies I have ever seen. It rates up there with movies like The Lord Of The Rings. I am VERY MUCH LOOKING FORWARD to Prince Caspian. It is going to be awesome. Well I'm signing off. The Release Date for Prince Caspian is May.26th/08 and I am going to see it regardless of what I have up on the weeks it's in. And I hope Prince Caspian will be just as good. my rating is 10/10 for being excellent. I hope everyone who sees my post that it will help them with making a decision in seeing it if they haven't. Well as I was saying before I am signing off so bye

Ryan Voth

title: Bland and mediocre attempt at an epic
review: Fairly bland and sanitized attempt at an epic, which has some beautiful landscapes and interesting characters, but not much else. Some pretty terrible performances from the kid actors, and some truly crappy CGI for the various woodland creatures. Some scenes are kinda cool, but, for the most part, they're far too childish and boring. I mean, Santa Claus giving them weapons? You've gotta be kidding me. And the final battle scene is so poorly executed that's it's barely exciting or even interesting. Still, the production design is top-notch, and it never feels boring or overtly preachy (though I could clearly make out the thinly veiled Christian symbolism). Overall, simply mediocre.

title: Bad acting (directing?)
review: Apart from Lucy who tries to be expressive, those kids looked like they had been narcotized. And what's with this scene on the frozen river? They just stand there waiting for it to break under their feet, Peter holding his sword with two hands pointing it stupidly forward as if it was going to suddenly spit fire, paralyzed. Then a (too) brilliant idea emerges as he plants it in the ice as if in butter, foreseeing the coming surfing ride. Gosh it's so ludicrous.... The battle is a mess, the witch poses like in a shampoo commercial, and the plot is so thin... four children come up and suddenly become epic warriors and trained strategists overnight defeating a witch and monsters before sitting on a throne. Period. Looked pretty botched to me...

title: We need more movies like this, except even better ones.
review:
What begins as a cheesy Disney movie rich in terrible one-liners and bad CGI (the beavers were unforgivable) turns into a great spectacle of fantasy cinema some 30-40 minutes into the film. While everything after Lord of the Rings in terms of epic battles feels half-assed and, frankly inadequate, The Chronicles of Narnia does a good job at establishing a true 'heroic' feeling with our main characters toward the end and the recipe for fantasy is accurately followed. I think we need much more fantasy movies out there and now that the 21th century has opened with blockbusters of its nature, there will hopefully be more like this.

My only big problem with the film was the little girl playing Lucy Pevensie. For those of you who aren't familiar with the story, Lucy is the youngest in the foursome of siblings that the plot centres on. They are the ones to enter the wardrobe that takes them to the world of Narnia; they are the heroes in a quest for Aslan. Lucy is made into some kind of prodigal heroine who dominates the course of events; she is rude, snappy and badly acted. This little brat is the most annoying character I've seen since Jar-Jar Binks. She shouldn't have been in Narnia at all - they should have left her the wardrobe and locked her up. Anna Popplewell who plays her older sister Susan, on the other hand, is excellent. It may well be that she is just average and that the rest of the cast are really poor (they are just kids, after all) - but whatever the reason, she is the one thing that kept me watching Narnia at the beginning when it was at its worst.

Visually, everything except the beavers were handled nicely and for a children's movie, this wasn't bad. Charismatic actors like Tilda Swinton and Liam Neeson certainly helped things along the way, making this into a worthile adventure. 7/10

title: Personally I think this film was disaster.
review:
Having seen the BBC Dramatization, this was just disappointment. And maybe I was expecting more from this film with all that publicity it did have.

I disliked...well, almost everything. Personally I think this film was disaster. Awful screenplay, awful characters (except perhaps Mr. and Mrs. Beaver). Barbara Kellerman (BBC version) vs. Tilda Swinton as White Witch? It is like comparing Alien vs. Lassie.

Perhaps 140 minutes just wasn't enough. Things seemed to happen too fast but it is always problem when making books into films. Still I think that this could have been done much better. All warmth and emotion of the original story was gone. I am not looking forward for the next film.

Despite being cheap-looking, the old BBC version has that very important thing why it is superior to this film: feeling of magic.

And four stars? It is for the original story...

title: Diet "Lord Of The Rings" - 65%
review:
It has taken some time but finally, the right time and film came along to mark my 200th film review. I had bought this for my Better Half for her birthday in April but we hadn't watched it until today, when we shared a lazy Sunday morning in bed together. Having fond memories of the BBC TV adaptation in the Eighties, I had high hopes for this. It also seems determined to mimic another recent fantasy outing filmed in New Zealand and one that I enjoyed from start to finish. But while "The Lord Of The Rings" has a more adult feel to it, "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe" is strictly aimed at younger viewers and has a more kiddie-friendly feel than Peter Jackson's stunning trilogy.

The first "Chronicle Of Narnia" focuses on the four Pevensie children Lucy, Edmund, Susan and Peter (Georgie Henley, Skandar Keynes, Anna Popplewell and William Moseley respectively) who are evacuated during the Second World War to the home of a reclusive professor (Jim Broadbent). During a game of Hide And Seek, Lucy discovers a strange wardrobe which leads to the white wintry world of Narnia. Before long, they are all caught up in a titanic clash for the future of Narnia between the dark forces of the White Witch (Tilda Swinton) and the amassed armies of Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson). Can they all survive the battle ahead, especially when it appears that there is a traitor in their midst?

As if further proof were required, New Zealand is the place to go for shooting films with jaw-dropping scenes of snow-capped mountains and rich, lush forests. And, as "Lord Of The Rings" also proved, CG creatures have come a long way since Jar Jar Binks. From Aslan to Mr Tumnus (James McAvoy), each and every creature looks fantastic and believable. Sadly, there are moments when there are slight gaps in the CG sheen where it becomes apparent that characters are stood in front of a green screen instead of a beautiful sun-drenched valley. Make-up and costumes are also of an extremely high standard as are the performances of the four main actors. Henley is probably the best of the four, proving to be the equal of her older contemporaries.

The problem this film has is mainly one of pacing. Whereas "Lord Of The Rings" has the luxury of spreading itself out over three massive films (and still not get everything in), "The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe" has to cram everything in during its 140 minute duration and it sometimes feels rushed or like it doesn't have time to explain things - for example, it never explains that you don't find your way into Narnia if you're looking for it. It is also trying too hard to be "Lord Of The Rings" - thrown in Gandalf and you'd honestly never know the difference. And while I agree that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, director Andrew "Shrek" Adamson displays precious little imagination when it comes to telling this story which is a shame, given the vivid imagination of the original author, C.S. Lewis. But while this is basically Diet "Lord Of The Rings", this is still a fantastic film and one which tells this classic tale better than it ever has before. It's bright and thrilling and exactly what a children's adventure movie should be. Don't wait until you've hit 200 movies - go and get the special edition DVD and treat the kids.

title: Wonderful
review:
Simply wonderful. This is a child's fantasy wonderfully transfered to the big screen with big acting, directing, editing, production, costumes, and makeup. The cgi has come such a long way that the characters come to life... and let's not forget the voice actors who breath that life into those characters. It couldn't be done without them. All wonderful... simply wonderful family entertainment.

-LD

PS: It seems to me that finally Hollywood has caught on to the idea that good entertainment is good. It seemed to me that there was a time when one movie after another was made to depress and criticize everything ... as if there was an overall conspiracy of negativity that anything good is bad. And if you dared to make a movie that was about the good qualities in people, then you were ostracized by the industry.

It seems to me that now that time is over. With such wonderful entertainment going on in this past decade (Shrek, Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings - all three powerful solid movies each in their own right - etc etc) the movie industry has finally got it right. Make the movies you want - the ones that sell, the ones that don't - the ones that entertain the ones that don't. People will still flock to see them - b/c they are the movies.

title: Not bad, but not great.
review:
I was a big fan of the Narnia book series when I was a kid and it was not without some skepticism that I went into the theater to see this, the first big-screen incarnation, of the series. That said, I rather enjoyed this adaptation by director Andrew Adamson - who interestingly enough is a native New Zealander like Peter Jackson of "Lord of The Rings Fame" and considerable fortune;) Is there is something in the picturesque rolling landscapes of New Zealand that just imbues filmmakers with the passion and drive to see such large scale endeavors realized? Who can say. In any event, Adamson's previous co-directing credits for the wildly popular "Shrek" & "Shrek 2" and a strong background in visual effects were surely helped in landing him this gig on what has become (if I'm not mistaken, the most successful blockbuster of 2005). Young Georgie Henley sometimes stealing the show with her portrayal of little "Lucy Pevensie" and Skandar Keynes as her brother "Edmund" is also quite well cast and fills this the most dynamic role of the film quite convincingly. Anna Popplewell and William Moseley are adequately cast as "Lucy" and "Peter" respectively but are out-shined (and perhaps rightly so) by the performances of their afore-mentioned younger colleagues. Tilda Swinton as "The White Witch" is flawless: cold and menacing as I remember from the book. Indeed her introductory scene as she seduces young Edmund is quite a memorable moment in the film. Look for a good voice performance by Liam Neeson as the omnipresent "Aslam" as well.

The setting in the film are about as epic and sumptuous as you'd expect, shot in locations ranging from New Zealand to Poland, and the visual effects, while not flawless are generally satisfactory and the scale of the battle is certainly well realized. Of particular noteworthiness are some of the great creature designs by make-up artist Greg Nicotero (it's nice to see that Adamson had the good sense not go with CGI for everything).

On the flip side, though, the pacing for the flick lags a bit and in the end, though I enjoyed the film, it's tough for me to say whether it really captured Lewis' world and characters quite as I remembered it, but then it's been ages since I've read any of those books;) So get out there and give Disney more money why don't you? It's certainly a film that benefits from being seen on the big screen.

title: Brilliant Special Effects
review: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe is a great fantasy/family/action film, it is very flawed, mostly through the direction and performances of the four central children, the timing was also a little off. We already had several good fantasy action and even family films out this year such as, Batman Begins, Robots, War of the Worlds, King Kong, Star Wars 3, Harry Potter 4. That is simply too many of this kind of film in one year to fully appreciate them all. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe is second rate to most of these films, the effects to King Kong, and War of the Worlds, and all around to King Kong, and Batman Begins. Tilda Swintons performance is amazing and more than makes up for the others. She catches ever moment perfectly. She should have gotten an Oscar nomination. You should see Narnia because it is a very good film, but there are better one's out there.

title: For people who like clean violence with kids who like plain violence. 8 outta 10.
review: This movie is based off the books by C.S. Lewis. Unlike most (Narnia) movies it barley leaves anything out. In the books the white witch was suppose to be pretty. She was ugly! This is a breath taking heart pounding movie! No language and some violence. For people who like clean violence (no blood, guts, brains, organs, vital organs or anything else) with kids who like violence. I think it is a great movie and I'm sure you'll love it. I give it an 8 out of 10. I mean who could blame you! It was written in the 1700's. I mean C.S. Lewis's best bud did write lord of the rings. I think you'll love it! Try it and see!!!!!

title: Good, but Overrated.
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Warddrobe without a doubt is a stunning story with religious references, inspirational statements, and all-in-all an amazing resolution.

The movie, though extremely popular, in my mind, was not that spectacular and could've been much better. C.S. Lewis meant for an epic adventure filled with amazement and extraordinary visuals, which the film seems to deliver there, but it lacks in some respects.

The actors used for the main roles of the children were not impressive, and were rather lacking in various respects. As for the animation of the assortment of beasts, that was by far, spectacular. The storyline is very generic, and you can tell that it's meant for a wide array of viewers. With the storyline being so general, you miss out on the important details and the reasoning, and are pretty much blatantly told the how's and when's. The basics are definitely there, but it's not a "Lord of the Rings" when it comes to detail, which I think could've improved the overall outlook of the film.

The movie, though widely thought of as a biblical reference, is sparingly that. The book, however, definitely is a inspirational and reflective portrayal of various stories and ideals from the Bible. The movie is pretty easy to interpret and without the detail as mentioned above, you don't get the same feel when it comes to the metaphorical and representation that C.S. Lewis meant to have in it.

I enjoyed the movie, wasn't blown away, but I can definitely say it's worthy of owning in your own collection.

title: Most beautiful movie of 2005
review:
My entire family loved this movie. We saw it three different times in the movie theater, once on a huge digital screen, which was magnificent! Disney did a stunning job here. Don't listen to the anti-Christian naysayers on the IMDb. "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they write." The Christian lessons against sin, and the biblical doctrines of redemption and forgiveness were there too, the story of the prodigal son was there, the crucifixion and resurrection are there, and the battle of Armageddon is there. "It is finished." The suggestion of the return of Christ is very powerful and moving.

Disney should be commended for tying it all together in such an entertaining yet uplifting film. Aslan looked so real, this was the best use of CGI I've seen in years. All the child actors were perfect for their roles. The cinematography was gorgeous and the music very pretty. If you didn't like this film then you need a heart check.

10 out of 10.

title: Beautiful but useless
review:
I suppose this is what passes for epics these days. Perhaps I've grown too old and too cynical, but, I was never caught up by all the dramatic monologues that plague this film. Visually overwhelming just doesn't cut for me anymore. The story was common. Common as dirt. From the start you knew what was going to happen and how. Lucy cries when someone died yet you just wanted to pick her up and shake her for crying about 'death'. It seemed obvious to everyone that death in Narnia is not permanent and therefore not need be mourned. I kept waiting for the end.

This movie is not for anyone under 12 and not for anyone over 40. I hope others find it interesting.

S.

miles_to_go_before@yahoo.com

title: Stunning!
review:
Rich and compelling, a masterpiece for generations to come. A must-see! Beautifully written, stupendous! If there is one movie you need to see before you die, this one is it! A delicately crafted, whimsical, heart-warming tale of tragedy and triumph!

Based on the series by C. S. Lewis, this film depicts children who ultimately overcome their weaknesses and accomplish great endeavors. The children exude the matured gravitas inherent to their character, turning this film into a timely classic! Absolutely breathtaking!

The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a movie for all ages, completely brilliant! The director's precise judgement furthers the craft and execution of the medium infinitely!

title: Great Christian Movie
review: Loved it! Though it did not exactly follow the classic books of C.S. Lewis, it was still masterfully done and a real Christian classic! Everyone at my Church loved it! Though I think the BBC miniseries does a slightly better job capturing the values, Walden media really did a top notch job and they still shone through. The portrayal of Edmund by Skandar Keynes was really great, I think he did such a good job of capturing the wide scope of Edmunds emotions and how he changes. Aslan stood our like the Lion of Judah that he is, and this titanic struggle of good vs evil captured me! Great movie! I don't think enough movies today are good Christian movies and this one really shown through with good values - I can't wait for the sequel!

title: Mediocre.
review:
I don't know why so many people are comparing this movie with "Lord Of The Rings" trilogy. The stories haven't almost anything in common. Whereas "LOTR" was a herculean production at the service of a great fable, "Narnia" is a mediocre production with a pretty poor story (and with children on the main roles -SOS!!!-). As for the special effects, they're nothing to write home about. I guess the kids will enjoy the movie, but I do prefer other fantasy movies that are less pretentious and much more exciting (just like "Neverending story", "Willow").

The best things in "narnia" are the expresiveness of the girl who plays Lucy, and the talking animals (those effects are really something). Just an ordinary movie... all talk.

*My rate: 5/10

title: Best film this year.
review:
From someone who was born during the second world war in England, I loved it. I have never read the book, so can't comment on its adaptation to the big screen. But to me, the screenplay really was wonderful and magical. Can't wait for it to come out on DVD, because I will buy it.

I just felt the lion symbolized the British struggle against the Nazis. But a literature scholar said C.S.Lewis' original book was more involved in the negative effect of Christianity? I can't comment but besides the cinematography overall I felt I could watch it many times. Although I felt it would attract the young at heart just as well (possibly more) as a junior audience.

I am glad it was award an Oscar for Makeup, and would have liked it to have earned a few more nominations, etc.

I think it will become a classic. So I hope Walt Disney will release it on video/DVD a lot quicker than they did Mary Poppins.

Pat

title: The Lord of the Weak...
review:
To compare this to Lord Of The Rings would be wrong because as far as comparisons go this pales. Comparing this to Labyrinth or Krull would be fairer.

Where LOTR had strong characters and deep story threads we get some of the weakest child-actors ever in a movie perfectly suited to the least demanding 10 year old.

Where LOTR had a sense of dread and darkness, Narnia gives us no more menace than an overacting Tilda Swinton and some not very well realized cgi wolves.

Where LOTR gave us a world that seemed real and lived in Narnia gives us the castle from Walt Disney World and a land too perfectly groomed. Where LOTR gave us heroes to believe in, Narnia makes so many missteps that we care little about the fates of the characters before us.

I loved the Narnia books as a child, but I've come to a realization that they're children's books. They haven't grown with me as an adult unlike the Harry Potter series for instance which have cleverly grown darker with every new release as its dedicated audience gets older. The Narnia stories are simple stories, tho they do possess great moments of pathos which unfortunately weren't realized very well in the visualisation. Witness Aslans sacrifice as a huge missed opportunity for the viewer to connect with the journey. Because they are simple children's stories we know that the world won't be as gritty & dirty as the world of Middle Earth, but we're disappointed still when we see it.

While the books may still retain a sense of wonder, this movie does nothing to convey it. LOTR set the bar extremely high for fantasy movies, Narnia attempts to lower it back to where it was again.

In one word: Drivel.

title: Are they still allowed to make films like this?
review:
I have just seen this film long after the hype and having read almost nothing about it - I have to say that this is the most overwhelming experience I have ever had in the Cinema. I wouldn't have expected it to affect other people in the same way but apparently it does.

It got to me because I grew up in England in the sixties (actually living next door to Lucy Barfield, the dedicatee of the original novel and of course the one after whom the youngest character is named) and I saw the last of that England that the picture captures so well in the opening scenes. I can promise you that those sparky and plucky English children we are presented with really were like that. And as for the evocation in those early scenes  the London Station, the Country Railway, the Professor's House  one wants to applaud even the aging and distribution of the objects in the rooms. The Mother saying goodbye to them at the station was a proper mother from those times, the fleeting expression on the face of the guard seeing the evacuee children off was a gentle English expression of the type that Orwell wrote about  this sort of attention to detail amounts to genius.

James McAvoy's charming and ridiculously moving Tumnus makes a perfect introduction to the land of Narnia, and the interplay between him and the wonderful little actress who plays Lucy is a joy to behold. And then we are into this story of Good and Evil, and it is made absolutely clear, in the true spirit of Lewis, that Good and Evil underlies the Deeper Magic and that there can be no compromise between them. Which is why I think the film has been so successful. These pukka English protagonists, of the type now routinely portrayed in films as sneering, rapacious, bigoted, you name it  show a true spirit of courage, humour, honour, loyalty, and courtesy which I am sure international audiences from wherever respond to deep down, but have been deprived of for so long.

So congratulations to all involved  congratulations to William Moseley for being indeed Prince Peter the Magnificent. Congratulations to New Zealand Director Andrew Adamson for demonstrating true Cinematic Genius of the type that conceals the hand of the maker -as opposed to the officially acknowledged Genii who are known only by their surnames  Kubrick, Scorsese, Hitchcock  and whose identities are immediately obvious after one scene.

title: Tilda Swinton
review:
Tilda Swinton is brilliant in the role of the Queen of Narnia and her make-up artist and costume designer deserve Oscars at least.

She has just the right tone of seduction and unpleasantness in her dealings with Edmund and her voice and facial expression are just spot on all the time. She has by far the best role of course.

Lewis put this female figure with bare shoulders at the centre of the story and it is interesting that he tends to like seductive female characters as his villains. He lived in an all-male society and had a very ambiguous attitude towards women.

As a child (and this is the spoiler!) I was disappointed with the part of the book which was based on Christian mythology. I was impressed and saddened by Aslan's sacrifice for Edmund. This was not least because that sort of thing did not happen in children's' books very often. Then when it turns out he knew all along that deep magic would bring him back to life it seemed a cheat.

I wonder how many children locked themselves in wardrobes after watching this film! Overall a magnificent spectacle at the heart of which was Tilda Swinton's haunting performance - brilliant.

title: Weepie, manipulative, pro-war "kid's" movie.
review: When we first see Narnia, it's through the eyes of a cute little girl and a wondrous creature named Mr. Tumnus. I thought, this looks like a sweet kid's movie. But C.S. Lewis does not stop with providing an environment like Narnia where a child's mind is free to roam. No, instead children are thrust into a war movie that teaches about divisiveness, that diplomacy does not work, and likens Jesus to a magical lion. It was too much for me to swallow, and I would never expose my children to such drivel. And could they find a prettier, Aryan-looking boy to play the part of Peter? Good special effects though.

title: Great movie
review: Excellent movie! For all of you C.S. Lewis enthusiasts out there, this movie really portrays in large measure what one feels reading his book. I was afraid that certain themes or motifs wouldn't be conveyed correctly or respected, but the actors and production team did a wonderful job. You'll instantly love the characters and turn to the movie again and again! Can't wait for the new movie, Prince Caspian, to come out. If you liked this movie, check out Shadowlands with Anthony Hopkins as C.S. Lewis. I know it's not exactly like the play, but they still do a go job. Some of C.S. Lewis other books that are just brilliant are Mere Christianity, the Screwtape Letters, and the Great Divorce. The titles do not always give away what's inside, so make sure to check them out.

title: Best movie I've ever seen
review:
A wonderfully adapted movie for a good book. True it's not the same, but purists need to get over it. After all, not every book to film adaption can please everyone.

One of the major things that I loved was how much more alive Aslan was than he was in the BBC productions. He captured all the spender that he had in the book. The BBC's stiff puppet and monotone voice really disappointed me before.

The music and the acting were amazing! Except for the minor changes, the movie was the book. Just as I'd pictured it. Georgie makes the best Lucy, and William is the Peter that I imagined from the book.

Can't wait for the others!

title: Excellent
review:
the best since "The Passion", Also its suitable for children, Awesome battle sequences. We think the whole world needs movies like Narnia, everybody needs to know that Jesus died for every one of us, that there is the Evil who enjoy wars, sickness, envy, gay marries, child abuse, terrorism, and so on every bad thing we can imagine, but there is the mighty God (Lion) who will protect you if you trust your life to him, who is alive and who will come again for his people.The lion was incredible and all of the special effects were awesome.There is no movie like it.

Thank you for the opportunity to express ourselves Keep working on this direction God Bless you Andrew Adamson

title: A Let Down...
review:
I had my expectations high when I went to watch Narnia as I am a big fan of the Lord of the Rings and I enjoyed Harry Potter too equally. But Narnia was a total let down. Maybe it was my expectations, but I believe I wouldn't like it otherwise too.

The Chronicles of Narnia is the adaptation of the classic by C.S Lewis. T.C.O.N tells the story of four ordinary children, Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy Pevensie. They discover that a professor's wardrobe leads to the magical land of Narnia, and help to save it from the evil White Witch. They are helped in their quest by Aslan the Lion and several other creatures. The tale culminates in an epic battle against the forces of the witch.

The movie fails to keep the audience glued to their seats as the pace gets very slow in between. There are a lot of flaws in the direction and the dialogues are also sub-standard most of the time. But the directors have done an excellent job with the special effects and character make-up. The background score is excellent too, but played at the wrong time/scenes. A little more of editing would have probably helped the movie better.

Anna Popplewell & Georgie Henley have portrayed the characters of Susan & Lucy excellently. The boys have done a fair job too, especially Skandar Keynes who plays the role of Edmund Pevensie. I don't need to mention Tilda Swanton as she is already a great actress and she has done her job well.

Overall the movie would be probably enjoyed by children, but it fails to impress the adult audience unlike the Harry Potter series which is a children's movie but also equally enjoyed by all class of movie-goers.

title: Follows the book!!!
review: This movie followed the book so well. I fell in love with little Georgie Henley from the start, feeling that she did an excellent job of portraying Lewis' Lucy. Mr. Tumnus was a delight, his character pulling together the movie from beginning to end. Aslan was all that I had hoped for and more (still having been shell-shocked from the BBC puppet years earlier). The White Witch was satisfyingly chilling and majestic, and I disliked her through and through when the movie was done. The set was incredible, and the battle scene very well done. The sweeping panorama was breath-taking. Best of all, this movie was one that you could take even small children to see without having to lean over to cover their eyes and ears - no blood, no gore, excellent message, and not corny or cheesy like some other 'good message' movies. Well done!

title: This is an excellent movie.
review:
I'd recommend this movie to anybody who is looking for a good family type movie.

The actors in this were fabulous. I agree with Skander that the witch would give Voldemort a bad time. Aslan was great, the kids were all great actors and everything in the movie clicked. I've seen it 4 times and plan to see it many more. I was particularly taken with the excellent job done by "Mr. Tumnus" (can't remember his name now), and by all four of the kids.

I wonder how many people know that many children were sent out of the cities during the blitz and many of them were never reunited with their families. I knew one in Australia whose family were evidently killed and he stayed there.

The special effects in this movie were especially good, and I think some of the scenes are actually better than "The Lord Of The Rings".

Again, I'd advise you to take the time to see this great movie.

title: a flick that wants to be "The Lord of the Ring"
review: okay.. first off. I watched this film because it was Christmas. Regretfully, I have to say that this film is under everyone's expection The "everyone" is people who never read this book. I felt that this movie persistently tried to show what was written in the book not carefully considering the natural flow of the story. People who are fans of this book might have known every detail and backgrond story of every scence when they were watching. Even after the end of the film, i wasn't convinced to believe that Narnia had its unique style and story. Rather, I was convinced to know that this movie only aimed at its giant global gross with C.S Lewis in its back. very different from a mega-popular film, "the Lord Of the Ring"

title: wonderful story
review:
What a very entertaining story!!!!.It could really catch your attention and bring your self to relating the lessons that can be pick up from the story in the reality of life...

Yes, I have watched the movie but I was able to read it first in a novel form BY:LEWis....At the beginning of the story , I was really then excited to finished it...It's so nice and wonderful....And all of the character,(LUCY) was the one that I love!!!..She's great.She knows how to act as if it's true to life..Very fantastic!!!!!!..really!!!! Even the time I read the novel, I have just then imagined what was happening if it's in movie and I was definitely right. I've proved it when I watched its movie...Very nice!!!!!!

It's so creative with uniqueness!!!!!

title: Refreshing and unique. The conflicts of good and evil are there in all their glory. But this movie of Narnia gives them fascination, without complication!
review:
I am perplexed by all the hoopla about comparing the central figure in "Narnia" to Christ. Both Christians, and anti-Christians, seem to be 'Up in Arms'. Nonsense. Do they want to discredit "Tale of Two Cities", "Billy Bud", etc. too?

Christianity did not invent self-sacrifice any more than Virgin Birth (Confucius and Zoroaster are credited with virgin mothers) or a celebration around Dec. 25th (before Christ it was and still is to many, Winter Solstice). It would be wonderful if people would try to stop giving credit for good plots to some religion or another. Don't they think writers have any imaginations of their own?

title: A beautiful movie!
review: I am currently reading the Chronicles of Narnia and had to wait and finish The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe before I saw the movie. I was happily surprised to see how similar the movie is to the book. The writers, actors, and director stayed respectively true to the characters, settings and the story. I was not disappointed in the least by this film. I thought the casting was brilliant and the kids did a terrific job as the Pevensie's, (A.K.A. the kings and queens of Narnia). I would recommend this movie to everyone, (I am definitely going to see it again) and especially to those of you who always feel that a book is better than the movie it is made into, you will not be disappointed! I truly believe Mr. Lewis would be proud.

title: Booooring
review:
That movie was just boring and bad. Crappy acting, bad script, and average special effects i wasn't expecting a LoTR but something more intelligent.

My friends made me see this movie despite my opposition. I was bored during all the film. There are no depth of characters, almost no interrelations between them. There are no background stories that movie is telling other than main story. And why Aslan is so important we don't know (maybe it is explained in the book but it would be nice if they explained in movie yes there are some clues but they are simply not enough)

But there are some surprises for me which are seeing Turkish delights in movie and lion named Aslan (Aslan means lion in Turkish)

I dunno if i were 12 maybe i would like this movie but now it is just a piece of crap.

title: Fabulous
review: Fabulous, Excellent, best movie I've seen in ages. Imagination thru the eyes of a child. Can't wait to purchase it. Glad to see there were so many Scots played a part in this movie. I can't believe how cold the witch made me feel. The children were excellent, this movie just brings the book to life and should be seen not only by children but by people of all ages. The costumes and characters were wonderful. I can't make up my mind who my favorite was. The Lion was excellent but the Beavers were so funny!!! CS Lewis must be very happy about this one, just a shame he didn't live to see his book com to life. I really hope they do more from this series of books. I just really can't say enough wonderful things about this great movie!!!

title: A flat, tedious movie although visually beautiful.
review: Although the movie is visually beautiful and quite true to the book, it is also very flat--lacking excitement and timing. I found it very tedious and I had really looked forward to seeing it. There were too many sudden transitions (for instance, the children going to battle in medieval dress). Characters that might have been extremely interesting were barely presented (the professor, the housekeeper) and the animal characters were reminiscent of cartoon characters in their delivery (making their interaction with the actors very superficial. The children, on the other hand, gave delightful performances although they were not given much to work with dramatically. It is hard to know if the script was superficial or the direction was lacking tension and drama--perhaps the fault lies with both.

title: Fun ride, but not enough development to be very emotionally moving.
review:
This movie should have been longer, or perhaps a series. I simply didn't think there was enough development to justify the battle at the end. I understand that if you've read the book, you have a deeper understanding of what's going on and what the character's motivations are, but a film has to stand on its own, and not rely on previous knowledge of the viewer to work. In the world of the book, the children have reasons to stay in Narnia and contribute to events there, but in the world of the movie I think they would have left once they got Edmund back from the White Witch. Narnia and its citizens just didn't seem real enough or important enough for the children to want to stay and help at their own risk. Perhaps the inevitable sequels will help fill in gaps.

Also, we're not given much time to meet some of the important characters. People are just tossed onto the screen with no introduction, development, or motivation, which makes it hard to invest in them emotionally and pull for them in the battle.

The production quality was great, Aslan was very believable, which is a necessity for the film to be a success. All of the other special effects and sets were seamlessly executed, so the viewer can be drawn into the story instead of being distracted by thinking "how'd they do that and why didn't it look better?"

All of the actors do a good job, despite being given a few cheesy lines. Each of the children has the right character traits that define their roles. If I were about 10 years old I probably would have thought this movie was spectacular, but as an adult I just need a little more substance before we dive into the epic battle. Maybe I'm just not a member of the target audience.

title: Amazingly Accurate adaptation of C.S. Lewis's masterpiece
review:
When I saw Narnia, I was amazed by the movie's cinematography. Everyone who has read the book knows that C.S. Lewis was great friends with J.R.R. Tolkein of LOTR fame. Narnia is one of those family friendly films that looks at the struggle of good versus evil.

When the film opens, the Battle of Britain is in progress. A few scenes later, we meet the Pevensie children; Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy, who are portrayed marvelously by William Moseley, Anna Popplewell, Skandar Keynes, and Georgie Henley. By the order of prime Minister Winston Churchill, all children must be evacuated from London. While the credits roll, we see the Pevensie children board a train at King's Cross Station and taken away into the English Countryside. They are sent to the house of a professor who has strict rules for the Pevensie children.

One day while playing Hide and Seek, Lucy uncovers a wardrobe and wanders into a mystical land called Narnia. She soon discovers that there is a war between the armies of the white witch Jadis (Tilda Swinton) and the armies of the Narnain king, Aslan the lion (voiced by Liam Neeson). A few scenes later Edmund follows Lucy into the wardrobe and is confronted by Jadis. During the movie, Peter, Edmund, Susan, and Lucy are announced that they are the two sons of Adam and the two daughters of Eve. Peter becomes a leader in Aslan's army and Edmund is imprisoned by Jadis, the self proclaimed Queen of Narnia. He is later rescued by Aslan. Aslan forgives the sins of the children before he is put to death by Jadis. A battle between good and evil is about to take place to determine who will rule Narnia.

The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe is one of the best Disney Films ever. This movie deserves a perfect ********** stars.

title: Worth Seeing, With Some Reservations
review:
Narnia is exceptionally well filmed. The four Pevensies are arguably the most beautiful family of young children you'll see in any movie. Tilda Swinton is awesome as the Ice Queen. She combines stunning beauty with ferocious will in the role. Jim Broadbent has a small --very small-- role in the film.

The computer animation is head and shoulders above any I've seen before, especially the beaver husband and wife. The majestic lion Aslan is impressive as are the fauns, centaurs, trolls and ogres who swell the ranks of the armies of the Good and the Evil. Only the wolves' mouths when they speak don't quite make it.

Having praised the actors and computer actors, and adding that the sets are stunning and the climactic battle scene good, let me state what's wrong with the movie. It is faithful -- more faithful than I would have expected in a two-hour-plus movie, to C. S. Lewis's novel. And that's the problem, because Lewis's novel, no matter how revered as a children's "classic," is flawed both as fiction and as theology.

In the novel, you can skim past the pages where Santa Claus appears, with his flowing white locks and dressed in Victorian red-plush coat and boots, riding a sleigh with a full complement of reindeers in front, to give the Pevensie children their gifts, gifts which will prove crucial in confronting the dangers ahead of them. In the movie, you can't get away from how odd this scene looks juxtaposed with what goes on around it. It teeters on the brink of mawkish, and it strikes me as the type of scene an old-ladyish Oxford don might well have appreciated over fifty years ago.

More disturbing is the equation of the lion Aslam with Christ. It's bad theology. Aslam does not have the relation with his followers that Christ had with his: Aslam's are his subjects and like it or not, he's a warlord, at least until the Great Battle is fought and won. Aslam also does not have the relation with God that Christ had. He isn't God's son, he's a lion. He's the King of the Beasts, more in line with pagan wood gods of the Romans or Druids than with Christian deities or semi-deities.

But, oh my, are those children adorable and boy, do the animal scenes make it, and wow, is Tilda Swinton hot --and a good actress too. So, all in all, Chronicles is well worth seeing.

It's just not worth believing in.

title: Why Do People Find This Good?
review: I went to see Narnia today because of the positive comments i've heard from a lot of people i know.What a bad movie.Having read the book (and not really liking it)I didn't expect much but was still blown away at how awful it was.First of all characters come in and out of nowhere with no explanation of who they are and why they are there.Santa Claus gimme a break.How does someone not know what a wardrobe is but know what Christmas is (I'm speaking of course about the forn).Also the little girl cannot act.She smiles before she cries about Forn being a rock.The war which was what i looked forward to was far too short and the villains looked totally ridiculous.The story i found predictable and lame.The sword fight between Peter (who cannot hold a sword)and the witch was amateur at best and they weren't trying to hit each other but trying to hit each others swords.The ending explained almost nothing and left you completely oblivious to who the professor was.If there is going to be a sequel count me out.The only reason i don't give this a 1 is because of the absolutely beautiful cinematography and background scenery.

title: Very very good movie, even though it was number one for longer than GoF!
review:
*cries* Okay, I'm just getting over its longer stay at number one.

This movie is one of the most beautiful fantasies I've ever saw. It sort of surprises me though that it was PG. Near the end, there was a large battle riddled with mythical creatures and animals killing other mythical creatures and animals. In it, one of the siblings almost dies. There are many intense moments. The White Witch is the cruelest PG movie villain I've ever seen.

Some may argue it rips of LoTR but I say it's similar but different. So what if it was, like LotR, filmed in New Zealand and props were made by WETA? The acting was just marvelous, especially the four siblings, Imelda Stinton, and Liam Neeson as the voice of Aslan.

If you loved LotR, then you should definitely check this movie out.

title: Confusing
review: *There is a spoiler in this review* The best thing about the whole movie was the CG. It was extremely well done and looked great, actively drawing you into this fantasy world. Besides that though, I really did not enjoy this movie. At 2 1/2 hours it seemed to drag on too long, yet it also didn't seem to really give you the full context of the story. For instance, the children are told that they are part of a prophecy that declares they are to lead the people of Narnia to victory in a great battle. The children all hear this and prepare for battle, while barely even questioning if they should risk their lives for these people they don't know. I feel like there should have been more resistance to this proposition before they just marched into battle. Although this really doesn't say anything about the movie as a whole, the little girl who played Lucy (Georgie Henley) scared me a little. She looks quite odd with her big grin, and every time she was on screen, I felt someone annoyed. Anyways, overall Narnia is a great visual feet, but the story feels rushed, yet still long. I really don't know how this movie is getting above a 7 right now, because to me it was painful.

title: What an amazing movie!
review:
The CGI work done in this movie is uber-realistic. With the exception of a very few scenes, it is easy to see where someone could come out of the theater and think that this was filmed with real mythical creatures as actors. Yes, real mythical creatures is an oxymoron.

The movie was always moving forward and only had a few slow points. The battle scenes were pretty amazing for the CGI work that was put into them.

It was really a great great movie and, from what I can remember in grade school, this was an excellent adaptation of the novel by C.S. Lewis.

Cheers, Bob

title: Good
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is warmer than The lord of the Rings. (I like The lord of the Rings, too)

And, The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe talk more about the love between brothers and sisters. And, contain children's rebellious. Finally, we can see the four children grow up very much. Although it hasn't more fight, but its visual effect is very good. It's very agree family with children to watch. I am very expect the continuance, The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian.

If you take frame that want to see a fight, action and bloodily movie, you maybe disappoint.

title: An amazing film... a masterpiece
review:
It's been a while since I last read the book, so I can't say how true to the book it is... but I absolutely loved the old version of this, so when I watched it the first time, I was comparing it the whole time. Which is why I saw it again, and it just took me away! The film starts with the devastation of the Blitz in 1940. Very quickly it moves on into Narnia, and how all 4 children eventually come to enter that world. The children learn their purpose in Narnia, and although they have their doubts about it, they travel across the land to meet the great Aslan and defeat the White Witch.

Like I say, the film moves very quickly to begin with. There's not much (if any) unnecessary speech, or slow moving shots to fall asleep to. When the children are in Narnia, the story still moves fairly quickly, keeping you interested. Unlike the old version, I felt there was a constant chase from when they left the Beavers' house right up until they get to Aslan's camp. Being an action fan, this kept my eyes fixed on the screen! Aslan was portrayed very majestically, with a voice of someone who really cares, but with a roar so powerful that if you were really there you'd be shaking! The final battle made me think instantly of the likes of 'Braveheart', yet is was filmed in such a way that you can see how brutal battles are, but without showing any blood or gore, so that kids can enjoy the film as well.

To ignore the Christian themes in the book would do it injustice. The film showed these themes, neither making light work of them, nor pushing them 'in your face' as it were. Anyone who has a small understanding of who Jesus is will see these themes, and can ponder them in their own time, but kids can easily watch the film and take it purely as a great adventure story of good overcoming evil.

This film is far better than the old one (although the old one is still great!), and anyone can enjoy it. If you are not wanting to watch it because of the Christian themes in it, then watch it as an adventure film (like 'Willow'). This really is a masterpiece, with a fantastic soundtrack to accompany it!

title: Excellent rendition of the story
review: This movie is an accurate, loving portrayal of CS Lewis' book. It is a child's story, sweet, loving, not too complex and altogether charming. I found the production quality to be quite good, some very nice battle scenes and tense moments that worked well for dramatic contrast to the pretty basic good versus evil mythology, and I thought the White Witch was particularly well portrayed without being overwrought. She was quite chilling (no pun intended). Overall I highly recommend this movie for anyone, but especially those of us who have always loved CS Lewis's classic series. As a final note, I'm not Christian, was not raised Christian, and I didn't find any specific-only-to-Christianity jarring elements. The sacrifice and rebirth of the hero Aslan is a mythological theme that has been common to many fables and religions from all over the world. I believe anyone of any faith (and those of us who do not belong to any particular religion) would find this movie quite enjoyable for exactly what it is...a charming children's story.

title: A Chronicle of Mediocrity in the Making?
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia...

One of 2005's highly anticipated movies, Narnia chronicles the adventure of four siblings during wartime Britain who stumble through a wardrobe into the land of Narnia, where they end up fighting alongside Aslan the Lion against the evil doings of the White Witch.

There are two ways of seeing this film, from my perspective. Firstly, let me put it positively. I made a comment to my friend when I came out of the cinema, "When I came out of the cinema after watching Harry Potter and the Sorceror's Stone, I was vomiting blood due to watching a complete cinematic disaster. I came out of Narnia thinking, 'ok, not bad.'" It's not a bad film. But it's not a great film either. There is a certain barrier that Andrew Adamson seem to be unable to lift the film above it. Many of the cinematic sequence are deserving of wows and pows, like the build-up to the final battle, where the eagles soared and the animals charged. The animation of the beavers, and the other animals, were close to perfection.

But there was magic missing. Narnia felt very much like a frayed edge of a beautiful portrait. It just wasn't smooth enough, or great enough. It left me wanting more. A good example of the same feeling would be Bryan Singer's first installment of X-Men. The film made me want more, and unsatisfied. But X2 built up from it nicely and turned out to be one of my favorite movies.

So perhaps Narnia can build on this film. It's not a bad foundation, and if Harry Potter can slowly improve over the years (Goblet of Fire, the 4th installment, is pretty good), Narnia certainly has a greater potential to do even better.

6/10

(this show didn't deserve an Oscar nomination for Visual Effects)

title: Fantastic
review:
This film is excellent, but just so people who don't bother to read books don't sound ignorant to those of us who do, "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe" is actually the second book in the Narnia chronicles, so no there won't be seven movies made unless the directors decide a prequel "The Magician's Nephew" is in order.

I would have liked to see "The Magician's Nephew" made as it is the beginning of the series and explains why Aslan has such power in Narnia, how Narnia was created, why the Professor believes Lucy's story and why the wardrobe grants access to Narnia.

Otherwise, though, the film is excellent with a soundtrack which, although a little clichÃ© at times, is otherwise moving and fairly well placed throughout the action. The costumes, particularly for the White Witch, are fantastic and the special effects are well blended with reality, avoiding that unfortunate trend to add unnecessary effects.

I would recommend the movie for anyone who has read Narnia and loved it and even for those who haven't, since the script doesn't rely on prior knowledge of the book. For those who have seen it, it's worth the sweeties.

title: Is Lucy always crying...?
review: I have just seen this movie and wanted to comment on it. I think that it is a fairly good movie. Not a movie that I HAVE to see again, but still it was good. Narnia is very well made and also all creatures are very nice. I saw this movie with my brother and towards the end of it my brother looked at me and asked me how many times the little girl (Lucy) had been crying. I've given this some thoughts since then and he's actually right about Lucy crying all of the time. The last couple of times she cries in the movie we actually started laughing. Not that it is destroying the movie, but maybe if you see it again you'll notice that she starts to cry many times. Or maybe you have noticed this too...?

title: the best
review: This is the best movie i have seen in ages. the story line was great, the animation was great, and the actor's Who starred in it were perfect!!!!! William Moseley played the character of Peter Pevensie, and he did a fantastic job on it!!! the movie had everything i expected it to have! plus more!! the animation was terrific and had me on the edge of my seat. i haven't read the book yet, but i really want t0o after seeing the movie! the fact that the director didn't cut out any of the biblical meanings in the movie is fantastic, after all, the books are based around the bible. Aslan was just as magestic as he should be, the animators did a fantastic job with all the creatures, especially the ones they had to make without seeing the real things first!

title: awful
review:
have just seen this and hated it for one thing they did not use what new Zealand had to offer instead they used blue screen and made it look fake and only shot parts of the scenery for real i mean what was the point.

the costumes look like they had come from a TV show

and the fact that all of a sudden these 2 boys could use a sword and fight in a battle was stupid, i do fencing and know that it would take years to learn to fight that well

hopefully the next one will improve and maybe another director is needed

title: The Best Movie in the last 20 years!
review: I loved this movie! It was as good to me, a 37 yr old mother, as it was to my 6 (soon to be 7) yr old son. It also gave me hope that really good family movies are still being made with a passion. Some scenes were so good that I actually teared up. The newcomer child actors in the film were excellent & I see a bright future for them all. I don't recommend the film to children under 5/6 yrs of age due to the horrible villain creatures that were shown to on the side of the "White Witch". They were horrible looking & would probably cause nightmares to small children. I just hope the team that put this movie together do it again, because there is a real talent there. This was a beautifully made movie with such emotion that each person who sees it will not be able to help but be touched. I know you all will love it too! GO SEE IT!!!!

title: I was a bit disappointed actually
review:
Don't know what I was expecting exactly - I think perhaps I would have liked it more if I had read the book as a child as there would be an emotional connection to the story. As it is, I feel the story wasn't strong enough to sustain a full-length feature film. Maybe it is the Lord of the Rings effect...

I thought the children were very pretty, but not very likable - haven't read the book so don't know if they are like that on the page? The eldest children constantly wanting to dash and leave the poor talking critters to face their fate, Edward being horrible... Little Georgia is, of course, all cute and nice. But a whole lot of pointless pouting was taking place, I say.

On the positive side, my son loved it - it sure is a good film for the kiddies. The wardrobe transition scenes are excellent, as are most of the CGI characters and the Narnia landscape.

title: Highly overrated movie for kids
review:
Oh my gosh- this movie is really totally overrated. I haven't read the books so I can only talk about the movie. First of all it looks like a children's tale which tries to have a bit from Lord of the Rings. It naturally fails completely. The characters are very flat and don't have any substance. The plot itself seemed to be a fast forward version of its original story. That's the only thing I can think of. I really doubt the books are that flat and badly written. As the film is moving very fast to the final battle it looses any bit of atmosphere that might have been created in the beginning. To see these kids swing around swords and fighting in a life or death battle is very dull. I could go some steps further but this would spoil the film. If there is something to spoil at all...

What might be interesting?

Nicely animated fantasy figures A story which is more for kids than adults Beware that there still exist some fighting scenes which may not be suitable for small kids.

Result:

As a movie for children I would give it a 5 but as an adult which has certain expectations of a fantasy movie I can only give it 3/10 points. Very disappointing.

title: Excellent Movie - a Must see.
review: I thought the movie was fantastic. The animation and computer generated characters were awesome. The visual effects were wonderful. Kept ya on the edge of your seat - caught me off guard a couple of times and I jumped. Shed a few tears as well. Can hardly wait for the next one.The actors/actresses were well suited to the parts they played. Excellent comparative of the Bible. Hopefully it will help keep children focused on the good and not the evil. The wolf pack was very realistic. I loved the beaver couple they were delightful. I was taken aback when the evil queen slapped Edward. However, it did bring home the point that was being made. Evil has no patience its get it right the first time or watch out.
