Movies like this show that we have indeed come a long way since the days of Dragonslayer and Clash Of The Titans. With good acting, a solid story, and great effects, this is one of the greatest movies of 2005.

title: Excellent movie! Best of the Narnia bunch!
review: I thought that this was by far the best of any Narnia movie! To those of us who are fans of the book, we're relieved to finally have a movie that lives up to the imagination of C.S. Lewis. The children were perfectly cast. William Moseley as Peter carried the feeling of the eldest brother and gave depth to the character not felt in other versions. The computer animation was seamless and allowed us to see the animals with a liveliness never show before. Liam Neeson gave a spectacular performance as Aslan. I feel that the storyline was well adapted to the adventurousness of today's audience. I'm looking forward to further Narnia books coming to life in the same spirit as this one.

title: Great overall but acting was a letdown
review: This film is pretty good and kids will absolutely love it. Especially if they have read the Narnia books as I did ten years ago. Andrew Adamson did extremely well for his debut feature, but he did make a huge, huge mistake in casting chidren with no acting experience. The role of Lucy Pevinsey is really important to the film, so why would Adamson and co. not cast one of the thousands of child actors around who've been in front of cameras since they were in diapers? Georgie Henley is a cute kid, sure, but any kid can be a cute. The same can be said for William Moseley, he was a little too limp to really carry off a role like Peter. Tilda Swinton is absolutely perfect though. I'd have had nightmares about her if I'd seen this as a kid and thats the biggest compliment I can think of. There is some really good CGI going on here as well. Despite a whiff of unfulfilled potential, the first in the chronicles is definitely worth a trip to the theater.

title: And the point was?
review:
Don't get me wrong - I didn't think this was a bad film and enjoyed it more than Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire.

But... For me it added nothing to the book. I think this has a lot to do with the way C.S. Lewis describes everything/one so well, it's a doddle even for a 7 year old to imagine everything in a pretty 'realistic' fashion.

Fine, if you haven't read the book, it makes a good children's film. As an adult I think the thickly painted allegory is a bit too much with the story often feeling clumsy and made to fit.

Maybe it's just me.

title: The Most Magnificent Film of the Year
review:
The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe is a truly great film in every sense, and is without a doubt the best family film I have seen in a long time. I can't remember the last time I saw a movie that people actually applauded. Narnia is brought to life in amazing detail, and represents the novel in a way I doubt C.S. Louis could have ever imagined. It is sad he could not live to see his creation finally given the attention it deserved.

The performances of the four stars are amazing, with the young Georgie Henley as Lucy Pevensie stealing the show. Tilda Swinton is cold and ruthless (and amazing) as the White Witch. The performances of the CGI creations are also beyond expectations, achieving a level of excellence and realism I have not seen since Gollum of The Lord of the Rings. When Aslan first walks onto the screen, he does so with all the might and majesty of a real lion. As with all the other characters, the fact that they are CGI completely disappears, as every hair and muscle on their body moves with the grace of a living creature.

The story is as close to its source as I have ever seen, and never strays too far to flesh the story out. The climatic final battle outshines any other like it. Also, for those afraid of how Disney might handle a story with such obvious religious symbolism, do not fear. I will not spoil the details, but suffice it to say that NOTHING, religious or otherwise, has been changed from the original story. It is nice to see a movie with such high morals do so well. In the end, this is an amazing story with fantastic effects and brilliant actors but most importantly, it makes you feel good when you leave the theater. I wish there were more movies like this.

title: Die hard readers will love it, but parents be warned.
review:
I read The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe several times when I was younger, and later read the entire 6 book series. The movie is a faithful adaptation and likely the best live action version so far. Fans of the books have nothing to complain about.

---Spoilers--- The problem with this movie is that it misses the demographic a bit. It is too childish for anyone over 13 to really appreciate, and too violent for children who would.

When I saw this in the theatre, the children were delighted by the Mr. Tumnus, then horrified to see him frozen alive. They liked the talking cheetahs, but then cried as they tore out the throats of their wolven adversaries. Needless to say the pivotal sacrifice of Aslan had kids screaming and crying.

So be warned, it is a good movie, I liked it. But while there is no blood, there are themes that are far too graphic for young children. This movie should justify a PG-13 rating for this content, though a 13 year old would probably think it was stupid.

title: Brilliant film!
review: Just got back from seeing this film and thought it was bloody brilliant!!! the actors were perfectly cast, esp james mcavoy as mr.tumnus who i loved! Both the story and essence of the characters from the book were really paid attention to and i don't think they ruined it at all for me, i am a massive fan of the books and look forward to more films being made! All in all a major thumbs up! oh and the music was amazing too, actually don't think there was anything i didn't like about this film, which is quite unusual for me! Found it quite good that although it was filmed in new zealand there was still that essence of britishness about it that was present in the books, i love the 'but we're not heroes we're from finchley' line!!

title: I Loved it!!!! One of The Best versions Ever Made!!!!!
review:
Now, back when I was in the fifth grade I remember that we had to read the book of The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe. I Loved the book and thought it was awesome, I got 100% on my report and we got to watch the 1988 TV movie after everyone handed theirs in.

I've seen the TV version on Masterpiece theater, and I've rented it several times. I loved the attention to detail. Me and my friend had a marathon of the television series a while back and after it my friend turned to me and said "I would like to see this remade before the end of the millennium." well, sadly that didn't happen, but now it is 2005 and here we have the first version of this film put to the Silverscreen and.......

Now I am in University, and I was very excited to see this film. I saw it this evening with my friend who had said she wanted to see it remade, and I absolutely loved it!!!!! I appreciated the attention to detail, how they didn't skip on anything,I liked how nothing felt rushed, they took the time to see the statues in the witches castle. I liked all the actors, they did a wonderful job of fulfilling their roles. I liked Lucy especially she was far less whiny sounding in this version than in the TV one. I liked it when a great looking more traditional version of Jolly Old St. Nick leaves and she says to Susan "told you he was real." lol This film made me think to myself, I can believe in anything I wan't to believe and no one can tell me otherwise." If your still a child at heart, you can still believe that there is a sense of magic and wonder in this world and rightly so!! This film had such a mystical and fantastic sense of wonder. Roger Ebert was right when he said "This Movie has Charm of all things." It was wonderful to see. I was glad that none of the themes were watered down. The Costumes were beautiful, the Beavers looked a little like Capiveras, I liked the fox, and the river scene, it was an excellent for of suspense, I was extremely glad that Father Christmas was not cut out. ( although I thought he would ask where Edmund was, and I was hoping he would give his sword and shield to the beavers to take with them) Liam nesson's voice did the character of Aslan Honor!! The Battle scene was epic and astoundingly comes as close to greatness as Lord Of The Rings. I was also so glad to see the Polar Bears in this movie that I saw on the Poster, I was worried they would not show up. I thought it was really grand and interesting to see Polar Bears instead of Horses. I enjoyed seeing the Griffins and all the mystical, odd looking creatures that were summoned to fight for both sides. (I think I liked the Minotaurs and Centaurs Especially)

The only thing I was worried about was the white witch, I am very found of Barbara Keelermans version and I was wondering if Tilda Swinton could top it, looking at previews I didn't think so but now having seen the film I can breathe a sigh of relief, for Tilda swinton plays very well indeed, expressing just enough a charm in order to lure Edmund in to her trap, I remember the other one shouted at Edmund a lot! and I thought it was funny how she overplayed it quite a lot.!! I was thinking back to the scene when Edmund walks in on the white witch and she looked like she was yawning and then she goes "How Dare You!!" lol that was funny. I am really looking forward to seeing all the other films One thing is for sure, This Verson is definitely going in My Home Video collection.

title: Thoughts
review: I was highly impressed with the movie. After the first half hour of really getting into it, I never looked at my watch for the rest of the time. From the previews, the special effects looked great but I wasn't so certain of the acting. Lucy's character and range of facial expressions is amazing! Tilda Swintin as The White Witch can raise the hair on your arms with her lightning fast mood swings. The other children were well cast, too. As someone who's been reading the Narnia novels for over 15 years, I was glad to see they stayed pretty true to the story and brought it to life better than ever. I cried during the scene with Aslan, I'll admit. The music by Harry Gregson-Williams is beautiful. I've been listening to it since I saw the movie.

title: It is a very, very good Movie
review: But it is no "Lord of the Rings", more like "Harry Potter". I love the books and I think Disney did a good job but I feel they made a serious mistake in ballyhooing the "allegory thing". People who come to the movie particularly for that will be disappointed, it is so subtly done that If you hadn't been told about it in advance , you probably would't register on it Those people who stay away because of the ad stress on the allegory, miss a very good movie. Since this is a fantasy{ aimed toward children?} the battle scenes are clean, no gore. Exciting but not frightening. I hope they will continue with the rest of the books in the series. I don't recall any additional allegory in the rest of the books. Hopefully ,those children seeing the movie will be encouraged to read the books and see Narnia for themselves

title: Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe - amazing film!
review:
I go to see most films with a sceptical frame of mind, well most films based on my favourite childhood books anyway! Most of the time I feel that it's not just the film that adds to an overall opinion of it. It's environment, it's company, it's the experience! Seeing this film for the first time, was also a first time at the newly built multiplex cinema in town - without advertising i think we can all guess which one it is! The screen was huge, so that sold it for me straight away, the lighting was perfect, and the temperature was toasty-warm. Just right for the weather outside and on the screen! With the film starting as it did, a fictional scene from WW2, i was slightly taken aback as to where that fit into the book - but then i figured, it's Hollywood, we need to allow for some leeway! As the film progressed i was more and more impressed. The actors, i thought,were perfect for the parts, the house, and the professor exactly as i'd imagined it whilst reading it all those years ago.

As the film progressed, i thought the makers got everything down to a tee; the lamppost, Mr Tumnus, Narnia itself. The special effects were out of this world - Aslans legs wobbling slightly as he padded around the children, amazingly realistic. Even the soundtrack was spot on.

I left the cinema feeling refreshed, that finally Hollywood has got it just right - I don't have a bad word to say about this film...10 out of 10 and highly recommended!

title: Must see this movie!!
review: If you enjoyed watching Lord of the Rings, this is the next movie that must be seen. Truly a remarkable film bringing the book series to the big screen. C.S. Lewis may have hated the idea of making a movie of this back in his day, but I am sure he would have marveled at this show. For me, this raised the bar for entertainment. One exception would be the lack of fear coming from the White Witch. Perhaps this was done to prevent little kids from being too scared but as an adult I would have liked to see more than just utter cruelty. I would say it is worth every penny. A non stop action film that involves heart and spirit. This movie will bring out emotion like E.T. and keep you locked in your seat. While the actors are unknown by me, the little girl reminded me of a young Drew Barimore. Please bring your family and friends to this movie, they will all enjoy it!

title: Really great movie!
review:
I took my 12 year old daughter and a friend last night and I have to say... the movie was terrific! I really was not that interested in going and only went because the girls really wanted to go. I didn't know the movie was over 2 hours long until it was over. It had you from the first few minutes and was absolutely mesmerizing .

Everything about it was fabulous. The actors were great, the special effects were terrific and the storyline was so well done. I'm actually taking my 7 year old son back to see it at the movies versus waiting for it to come out on DVD. I haven't been back to see a movie a second time since I was a kid watching StarWars in the late 70's! Great, great Holiday movie.

title: A hit all around
review:
I am an 8th grade science teacher in Lakeland, Florida. We teach on teams, and the reading teachers on both 8th grade teams had the students read the book in class, either on their own or the teachers read it aloud. Our students were very hooked into the book. So we decided to take them on a field trip to see the movie on Friday the 9th when it came out. We had around 200 students attend a private showing - they had the theater to themselves - it was great.

The student's loved it!!! They laughed, they applauded, they cheered, some even cried! No one seemed unhappy with the movie.

I had never read the book, but I was impressed with the movie, and would love to see it again. I am now going to read the book, as well as the other Narnia books.

When are we getting movies on the other Narnia books?

title: Not at all let down
review: I was so excited to see Narnia coming to theaters, but I have to admit, I had my reservations about it, not sure it would come to par with the books. But, I was not let down at all. I loved it and saw it twice opening weekend. To bring to life C.S. Lewis' words and minds eye was amazing and done skillfully, sticking to the true story nearly word for word. Even knowing the story, I hung to the edge of my seat more than once. It is a beautiful film with rich, vibrant color and breathtaking landscaping. The characters and acting are priceless, fitting character to actor skillfully. Aslan is enchanting, frightingly awe-striking and good and gentle all at once. I was not disappointed in Narnia at all and I highly recommend it and can't wait for the second of the chronicles.

title: Connections
review:
This film is really really awesome. And remembering that C S Lewis was an Atheis before he wrote this book, there are some connections with Christ in this film,, >When Aslan resurrected, the stone table broke and 2 women were there >When Jesus resurrected, the stone cover broke and 2 women saw it

>After Aslan died, Peter took his place >After Jesus died, St Peter took his place / represent him

>The witch convinced Edmund with the candies *forgot the name* (material object) so that he tell everything >The evil convinced Judas with material object (money) so that he tell everything

title: Ignore the religious tub-thumping; this is one for the kids
review:
As an adaptation of a much-loved saga of mythical realms and fabulous beasts, largely filmed in New Zealand by a New Zealander, this first Narnian chronicle was always going to invite comparisons to Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings juggernaut. But where Middle Earth was shrouded in gloom, Adamson's Narnia is a more welcoming place; a winter wonderland that children would love to explore, White Witch or no.

The tale begins in dark times as the Pevensie children - Lucy, Edmund, Susan and Peter - are evacuated from blitzed London to the country mansion of twinkly Professor Kirke. During a game of hide-and-seek, Lucy (well-cast debutant Georgie Henley) stumbles into a room furnished only with a huge wardrobe, at the back of which she finds... a snowbound forest. And has tea with a faun called Tumnus.

Of course, Edmund poo-poohs her story until he follows her and is lured into doing the bidding of wily white witch Jadis (the spikily splendid Tilda Swinton). If he brings her his siblings, he'll get as much Turkish delight as he can eat. Now that's sweet-talk.

When the Pevensies arrive en masse, Tumnus is gone but a kindly Cockney beaver (voiced by Ray Winstone) tells them that only they can fulfil a prophecy to restore peace to Narnia by joining the righteous forces of the noble lion Aslan. But Edmund's treachery sets Jadis and her wolves on a relentless hunt to catch Peter, Susan and Lucy before they reach Aslan's army.

Much has been made of the book's Christian overtones, but while the movie retains the story's core elements it goes easy on the preaching to provide well-intentioned and wholesome entertainment - you know, for kids? Admittedly, the self-sacrifice and subsequent resurrection of Aslan is laid on a bit thick and 'Jadis' does sound like 'Judas'. But it's possible to overlook the biblical themes to enjoy a basic tale of good-versus-evil.

The pacing is brisk and the denizens of Narnia are nicely rendered (though the green-screen work is a bit shonky), from the earthly beavers and wolves to minotaurs, griffons, centaurs and cyclops(es?).

Grown-ups will appreciate it as a cynicism-free breath of nostalgia... but they may have to keep an eye on the kids when they next go shopping for bedroom furniture.

Just a few questions to ponder: where's Aslan been the last 100 years when he's needed? Why aren't the beavers afraid of humans wearing fur coats? How come Lucy's potion heals the most horrific wounds but not a cut lip? And why are all evil creatures - white witches excepted - ugly? Lord knows.

title: Very good!
review: This was an AMAZING movie! The story was very true to the book, and as someone who has read them since I was little, I know the story back and forth. Aslan's voice was wonderful, the White Witch was chillingly evil. And the Pevensie children were wonderful actors! Lucy was so convincing she had a natural talent for acting, Edmund grabbed your heart and you felt so sorry for him. Susan was very convincing as the older sister who thought everything out, and Peter did wonderfully as the older brother taking care of the younger siblings.There were only a few times when the matting for the movie was off, and it was noticeable. The added scenes went along with the story wonderfully, and did not break the rhythm at all. I really hope this is not the only Narnia movie to be made, it was so good!!!!!

title: Nothing like rodents acting!
review:
Chronicles of Narnia is a fantastic film. The children are very well cast, each has very distinctive and believable differences and characteristics (plus I couldn't help but adore little Lucy, her cuteness is lethal!) Narnia itself is very well done. Through great sets, locations and special effects it gives the strong feeling of an unearthly fantasy land.

My single favorite aspect of this film was this: animals giving realistic acting! When the children meet the beaver couple, the performance those beavers, and all the other animated animals is totally believable. Their facial expressions and body language are very natural and believable. After seeing this I can't help but feel a Redwall film is not far away.

The only problem I have with this film regards the lead-up to battle scene. I do not remember how it was done in the book, but I feel the film could have benefited from a few minuets of army-gathering and arming. Peter Jackson said the build up of armies adds tension and anticipation to the film and I have to agree, here it feels like "ok kids, heres your armies, have fun!" Other then this, I loved this film.

title: Way cool, well done and kicks LOTR butt . Can't wait for the next
review:
I went to see this movie on Friday and I was blown away! The acting was very very good and the white witch was amazing! All the CG was done so well that it tricks your eyes, really it does. The sets and locations where so cool that they took you breath away. The one thing a really liked about the movie was how close it stayed to the book. I've read all the books over and over, the movie was done just like i had pictured it in my mind. If any one here has seen the BBC version...forget it. When the next movie comes out i will be the first in line to see it.

Ryan

title: None
review: This movie is now the best movie I have ever seen. Aslan was done beautifully, the battle was AWESOME, and it was pretty true to the book. Some things were a bit off and some things were added. And that whole Christianity thing? Oh just clamp your jaws. I am a Christian and I didn't even think twice about the whole Jesus as Aslan dying on the cross/stone table thing. The book was more Christian-like to me. The movie was more about Edmund becoming a man, Peter becoming a leader, Lucy becoming grown up and realizing responsibility and Susan the same. I am a HARDCORE reader of the Narnia series and it is one of my favorites. I believe the director did an excellent job with re-doing it. My standards (which are pretty high, especially for this movie) have been reached. I can't wait for them to do the rest of the books. Disney is FINALLY redeeming themselves! Overall, my new favorite movie of all time.

title: Surprisingly good
review:
I was hoping that this would be good but somewhat dubious about it, but when i saw it i was relieved to discover that it actually was quite good. It stuck quite closely to the book, and when it deviated it did so in appropriate ways - none of the deviations seemed tacked on. I was impressed by the presentation of a particular icon of popular culture, who was presented in a way that harked back to how he was portrayed before commercialism got hold of him, and i wished he could become the new standard. The religious aspects of the film were neither under- nor overstated, and it worked fine on the level of an adventure film and as an allegory. I was very emotionally involved, partly because of having read the books as a child until they fell to bits, and i was actually moved to tears once. It was also so much better than the BBC TV version, and in that i'm talking about acting rather than special effects or scenery. However, the special effects did make me think that when they finally do 'His Dark Materials' in cinematic form, it will be able to do justice to those books too.

If they do decide to do the other books, i would certainly go to see them as well, and they would have the advantage of having good writing to back it up.

The only problem was that the climax of the film was too drawn out.

I'm amazed Disney could do a children's film that was actually good.

title: Everything I thought it would be...and more!
review:
Wow!! I have to say that Narnia is by far the best fantasy adventure movie I have seen in my entire life! I'm not A huge fan of Harry Potter like lots of people I know, However I really liked The Lord of the Rings...But not nearly as much as this movie. When I got to the theater on the day Narnia was released, it was already packed with people! Some who walked in slightly late even had to leave=) I thought that Georgie Henley, the little girl who played Lucy was adorable, and she did so well considering she has never acted before. This little girl played her part remarkably and I don't think there is another child actress out there that could have done better. Hopefully she'll be in more upcoming movies, because it's good to have a variety of children in movies instead of the same ones over and over, such as Dakota Fanning. Even though I love her amazing personality and acting abilities, she has been in so many recent movies! Dakota is so in demand right now that she doesn't even have to audition for her movies anymore! Anyways, to get back on topic, this little girl was just so amazing, and so cute. I loved her.

The other actors/actresses did great too! William Moseley, the guy who played Peter acted like a responsible older brother to his three siblings, looked after them and was brave enough to fight for Narnia. I think his acting abilities are pretty amazing, especially since he hasn't been in many movies besides Narnia. Skandar Keynes, who played Edmund did great in this movie too. His character was the second youngest of the four children, and he was the second to go through the wardrobe and into the magical world of Narnia. I thought he did really well. Last but not least, Anna Popplewell, who played Susan, the second oldest of the four. She did an awesome job as well. Her character was supposed to be friendly, but a little boring. At times she tries to act smart and superior to the rest of her siblings. Overall, I thought they all did an excellent job!

Another thing I loved about this movie was how close and precise it was to the original story. After seeing the movie, I came home and found The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe book in my closet. I started reading it, and it felt like I was watching the movie all over again. They did such a good job keeping it like the original, and I was so glad because I hate it when people take classics and ruin them by changing them too much.

All in all, this is such a wonderful, magical movie, and I loved it!! If you are thinking you won't like it because it seems like a kids movie, it's not. Narnia is a great movie for all ages, and C.S Lewis would be so proud. Definitely a 10/10.

title: Great for fans of the series
review:
I'm not exactly a "fan" of Narnia, but I read the book this movie was based on. And I gotta say, this movie is very faithful. I don't think there was anything missing from the book, and it changes some things to keep us interested.

The actors gave some solid performances throughout, and hearing Liam Neeson as Aslan was very entertaining. The visual effects weren't perfect, but they satisfy. And this movie doesn't fail to keep you interested for the whole time. You'll be on the edge of your seat for a majority of the time, particularly during the final battle. It was "Lord of the Rings" toned down, basically.

And the audience agreed with me. They cheered when it was necessary and when it wasn't necessary. They also booed whenever the White Witch came on screen. It was really fun in there.

Not that this movie has some faults. The beginning felt a bit unnecessary and out of place. But it is still recommended. 8/10.

title: Narnia mesmerises viewers of all ages
review:
This take on the Chronicles rivals even LOTR in its epic battle sequences. The characters are well-developed and well-acted. The scenery (filmed in New Zealand) is spectacular! All four main actors are new to the big screen (excepting Popplewell). Director Andrew Adamson's film is a wonderful success. He manages to keep humanity and childhood inside the mystical land of Narnia. The graphics in the film are also exceptional. Aslan, the Lion, King of Narnia is graphically breathtaking in all of his expressions and movements.

The Chronicles of Narnia is a must-see film!

Go to the Paly Voice and see a great review on The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe at http://voice.paly.net/view_story.php?id=3614

title: Four children walk through a wardrobe to find that they are in Narnia and have to fight the White Witch for their lives
review: This movie was very good, but a little violent. It makes me curious to see how they will create the creatures in a local production of Narnia.Lucy was very dramatic, Edmund was just mean, Susan was protective and Peter was brave. Aslan's name is impossible to pronounce (is it Az-lan or As-lin)? I jumped at a few periods in the movie. It was definitely worth the money I payed to see it. Pretty similar to what I've read in the book. Saddest part-When Aslan is sacrificed. Funniest part-When Father Christmas came and they thought is was the White Witch. Most intense part-the war(lasted for like 20 min.)I recommend this movie for adventure lovers. Enjoy it if you see it!

title: Through the wardrobe into the war :)
review:
I loved the film, although admittedly it was not as fantastic as I had hoped. The film remained true to the story although I was disappointed that Mrs Beaver did not try to take her sewing machine with her when they left the dam! The acting was generally great although Georgia's (who played Lucy)immaturity showed with some slight acting downsides. I was amazed at the reality of Aslan's character and felt he appeared very realistic except when he was running with Susan and Lucy on his back - that, I felt, was a slight flaw in an otherwise exceptional series of animations.

In my opinion, much better than the 1980s BBC version!

title: Too intense for younger viewers
review: I was planning to take my nine year old grandson to see Narnia but, after seeing it by myself last night, I have my doubts unless he has already read the book. I had never read the Narnia series, and so, although I knew that one of the characters was a Christ symbol, I did not know the details as to how things work themselves out. I found the CGI elements to be extremely well done. I thought the children were well portrayed, especially the oldest boy and the youngest girl. But I felt the suspense during the "death" of Aslan and the injury of the younger brother during the battle very keenly, and don't think it is appropriate for many children. A PG-13 might have been a better rating.

title: I was not disappointed
review: Being a big fan of the books, I went into this movie with no expectations, afraid that I would only be disappointed. But I could not have been more happily surprised. If you're a fan of the book you'll notice a few changes, but none of them seemed to detract from the story. They all fit and made the action move a bit faster and added a bit more tension, which was bound to happen. The only thing I didn't like was the appearance of the White Witch. Tilda Swinton did a fantastic job playing her, but I found her look distracting, it really didn't fit with the image I had in my head. Everyone else, though, was spot-on. When I first saw Lucy I thought she was too young, but twenty minutes into the film I couldn't imagine anyone else. Georgie Henly is quite the talented ten-year-old. I can't wait to see what they do with the other Chronicles.

title: Awesome Movie!
review: This movie is one that I could go back and see many a time. The first part was a bit slow but needed to set things up. The visual effects are top notch. My family and I could have stayed in the theater for another hour of this movie. We certainly hope that more of these are made. We watched a show called Beyond Narnia about C.S. Lewis prior to seeing the movie. That show really put things together for the movie. The settings for the movie and the acting are all fantastic. The beavers really draw you in as two ornery characters. The Ice Queen is about as scary a villain as you would ever want to see. She is the nice to your face and stab you in the back villain that we can all relate to all to well this day in age and obviously when the book was written. In this classic battle of good versus evil, it was very easy to find yourself on the good side and cheering them on! This will be a "must have" DVD when it comes out. Absolutely Top Notch! If you get the opportunity to go see this movie DO SO! You and your children will enjoy it.

title: Amazing better than the book
review:
I read the book The Lion The Witch and The Wardrobe over the Summer 05' and fell in love with it. When I found out they were bringing it to the big screen I was so excited.

I saw it last night and what can I say apart from GREAT!! From start till finish it had me on the edge of me seat. Great acting and special effects.

If you Like LOTR and HP you will love this.

Also you connect to the kids more so than in HP.

Also a tip stay seated through credits as there's a small scene to be watched which's links to the sequel.

The ending is spectacular. Can't wait for the sequel Prince Caspian.

title: Awesome
review: This was a great movie. I definitely recommend it for everyone except smaller children. There are a few scenes of violence where characters are killed, that could be scary for smaller children. There is plenty of action, and a big battle scene. The talking animals, especially the beavers are pretty funny. You actually get excited watching it. The scenes are beautiful, the music is perfect, and the children's acting is actually really good. The movie never gets dull and the ending is satisfying. I never read the book so I can't compare the too, but I am a huge Harry Potter fan and would have to say the movie was just as good as Harry Potter if not better!

title: A great holiday movie, and an epic in its own right
review:
FILM: THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE LION, THE WITCH, AND THE WARDROBE DISTRIBUTOR: Disney/WALDEN MEDIA DIRECTOR: ANDREW ADAMSON PRINCIPAL CAST: Georgie Henley, Skandar Keynes, William Mosely. Anna Popplewell, Tilda Swinton, Liam Neeson MPAA RATING: PG for Battle sequences and frightening moments RUNTIME:

Story: 4.5/5 Acting: 5/5 Sound: 5/5 Visuals: 4.5/5 Endorphin Factor: 4/5 Big Screen Experience: 5/5 Scoring system: Average: 4.6/5

MOVIES IT COULD BE COMPARED TO: Lord of the Rings Trilogy, Harry Potter films

DETAILS: So Thomas7g and I are talking, and we bring up the Yahoo IMVironment on chat for The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe. As we're talking, I tell him that although the first preview looked good, it really wasn't on my dradis for priority movies this holiday season. However, when I went to Narnia.com, and checked out the new trailer, my mind was immediately changed, and so off I went to take in what looked like a very promising movie.

I was not disappointed. The film really does stand out well, and even with only my vague memories of having read some of the C.S. Lewis classic (and seen the animated feature that was broadcast on CBS many years ago), I fully understood the story. The actors in the film were all perfectly cast, and played their roles to perfection. Liam Neeson, as the voice of Aslan, was easily recognizable.

The visual effects were damn good, but much of it could be easily discerned as CGI. The sound effects rocked, and I loved the soundtrack to this film. Might just have to pick it up.

There was an awful lot of crying in this movie...more than I remember seeing in previous incarnations.

There were good laughs, and much of them came from either the talking animals, or from Lucy, the youngest of the four siblings who is actually a little wise beyond her years.

The Witch, Jadis (Tilda Swenton) was ferocious in this movie. At first, when I saw her, I thought it was Alice Kriege (The Borg Queen from Star Trek: First Contact), but the accent told me otherwise. Nonetheless, Jadis was a bad ass...especially in battle.

Fantasy movies are really starting to see their heyday, with the overwhelming success of the Lord of the Rings Trilogy, and the Harry Potter movies. This film looks to continue that heyday with great success. In fact, it's actually made me get up the urge to give the LOTR movies another chance.

BOTTOM LINE: I'd still have to prefer the Harry Potter films over this, but The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe is a beautiful film in its own right, and will find its way into my DVD collection upon release.

Respectfully, Martok2112

title: Brought my Childhood to life
review: I grew up reading these books. They were my life's blood. I read it for the first time in the summer before 3rd grade and was captivated by it. I read it over, and over again. Those books were some of my favorite childhood memories. Sitting in the theater watching my favorite story unfold before my eyes was an amazing feat. They captured it ever so well and Liam Neeson was brilliant. The White Witch was terrifying yet so regal. Aslan himself was also an oxymoron almost. He seemed so dangerous, and yet in his eyes so gentle. The graphics on him were very detailed, from every hair on his head even to his eyebrows! There were moments of suspense that keep you on the edge of your seat even though you know what happens (if you have read the book). The children were genius, each of them showing maturity in some moments. You feel connected with them all. It is a great movie for any age. It is however a boarder line PG movie. There was no blood shown which is most likely the only thing keeping it from being a PG13. I highly recommend this film.

title: A wonderful movie!!
review:
We just got out of seeing this movie opening weekend and all I can say is Wow! What a great movie! I really wasn't familiar with CS Lewis's books before tonight, but now I will be reading them and recommending them to my family. My 10 yr old daughter really enjoyed this movie as well, it is enjoyable for the whole family.

This is one of those blockbuster movies...it sold out several of the performances this evening. My line for the Mega screen filled up the entire lobby of the theater. And after it was all said and done, the theater erupted with cheers and clapping when the credits finally ran, well done Disney and Walden Media, well done.

I will be going back to see this again to pick up on some of the finer points and symbolism of the story line and this will be one of the DVD's that I add to my collection.

Go see this movie, your whole family will enjoy it! The storyline and the underlying message are first class.

title: A very worthwhile film
review: In a family with more than one child, how can each child be made to feel special? C. S. Lewis solves this quandary by making it logical for a kingdom to have four thrones--one for each child in the four-child family who are the protagonists of this film. C. S. Lewis surely remembered his childhood and recreates a magical, wondrous world, the kind we all know before puberty clamps down on our imaginative powers. Everything about the film drew me in--the mythic creatures, the talking animals, the gorgeous scenery. And the White Witch! what an ice queen! I don't remember the actress's name, but she is the most memorable character of the film (certainly had me shivering in my skin). . . well, the youngest child (don't remember her name either) is pretty memorable, too. This is a very worthwhile film.

title: Jack Would Be Proud!
review: Adamson has done a faithful-to-the-original job! I read the book back in the early '70's and didn't understand some of the images, but this was a treat to watch. It does a much better job of representing Lewis's work then the earlier versions. I found myself relating scenes in this film to other works by Lewis (the scene where the children are walking in the grassy valley, on their way to meet Aslan, reminded me of a scene described in "The Great Divorce"). It's always a wonderful experience when the anticipation pays off in an excellently crafted film. Thank you Andrew Adamson & Douglas Gresham for a visually beautiful & esthetically faithful version of this classic. Jack would be proud!

title: Terrific Family Film (ages 3-11)
review:
Great family film. We took the kids (3, 6, 11), all of whom enjoyed it at some level. It held the attention of the three-year-old--no mean feat for a live-action movie. He talked about it all afternoon. The six-year-old loved it. The 11-year-old, the critic that read all seven books, liked it a lot.

No sex, double entendre or innuendo. No foul language at all. There's some violence, but nothing remotely graphic. We see no blood or gore of any kind. There are some scenes that are startling and a couple that are scary, but I don't think there are any nightmare-inducers (though ask me tomorrow morning).

The White Witch is a little intense, but it's good to see a villain who is just bad and not the helpless, misunderstood victim of some psychological tragedy that should excuse or mitigate her behavior. She does it because she's evil, pure and simple.

We'll buy this one for the collection, and watch it many, many times. It's a rare film that works for all the members of the family. To us, that's as good as gold.

title: Young Lucy Pevencie Travels through a wardrobe with her siblings only to encounter the adventure of a lifetime.
review: Wow, I can't believe it was that good. I have to say the war seen was really cool. Great acting!!! to. I recommend it to everybody i see. I have no Idea what to say. You guys just made a brilliant film pact with amazing adventure. The critics are right it is going to be a classic. I Hope it makes it to #1 on the box office chart. If you agree with me please E-mail me back. I want to know if everyone is saying the same thing. I hope. It was really good. Anyways As I said great film. You gotta see it. I saw the premier and was dying to tell everybody about it and compare my ideas with everybody else. Finally I Can!! Write back.

title: What can I say?
review: This is a magical movie. It's so beautiful that we want to watch it over and over again. It's very well directed, the cast is wonderful, the kids were a very good casting job, congratulations to the casting director, "Lucy" is just lovely, I hope to see her again in other movies, "Peter" has everything to be a star as his part was very important in the plot and he was very good in it. Liam Neeson's voice is breath-taking, it would be Aslan's voice if it was a real talking lion! The animals and other creatures seem real, they were there if we didn't know that they are CGI! Watch it, devour it... It's not "two thumbs up"... it's three thumbs up... My thanks and my congratulations to the film-makers, this is very well done, just like a very succulent stake!

title: Not as bad as some people make it out to be
review:
Almost everyone is in love with C.S. Lewis' Narnia series. I honestly was not sure if this movie would be too successful (Talking beavers? A villain whose sleigh is pulled by polar bears?) but when I saw it today the theater was packed with people of all ages.

It almost feels like the creators wanted to make another Lord of the Rings, but honestly I found myself cracking up during the battle scenes; I could only take the armies of polar bears and cheetahs so seriously. Sometimes I got the feeling that I should be enjoying the movie much more than I was. The sets and visual effects are spectacular, but then again what major movie *doesn't* have good effects with the technology and talent available in 2005? Aside from a few really fun and mesmerizing scenes, I never felt taken into Narnia.

title: I thought it was really good
review:
Just saw the movie today. MUCH better than I expected it would be. I was dreading 2-1/2 hours of Hollywood "fantasy" piffle. But it appears the director took his cues from LOTR and Harry Potter. The effects serve the story, not the other way around. And the story is what REALLY sells this picture combined with the great cinematography. It's a very faithful rendition of what I remember from reading the book so long ago. The acting is the only weak part, largely because of the kids being relatively new. Tilda is fantastic as the White Witch. And the talking animals do not seem overtly silly as I feared. Aslan is wonderful. Even Mr. Tummus is quite good. So the kids' acting abilities are more are more than made up for by experienced cast members.

And anyone who has it in their head that this is a "Christian" movie and fear being evangelized by it, not to worry. The brilliance of Narnia is that it doesn't preach and doesn't hit you in the head with a sledgehammer in order to point out the Christian parallels. And you can read as much Christian allegory into it as you want. It's not hard (speaking as a non-Christian) to approach this movie with a deep liking for Aslan's spiritual nature and the common themes of love, good, evil, betrayal, redemption, and forgiveness in this film. In fact if all that wasn't there, it would be a visually pretty but ultimately empty piece of Hollywood fluff. Of course people will compare it to "The Lord of the Rings" which is a much more mature work. But as an adaptation of a children's story, I think they did a fine job.

Treat yourself and go see it. Fair warning though. The theater I went to was packed with little kids, many under age 7. I don't think kids that young are going to get that much from the film. I often heard young voices piping up asking questions and parents working to shush them. Fortunately I was sitting far enough away from most of the kids, so it wasn't too distracting.

P.S. -- It pays to linger a little bit after the credits start rolling. There's a nice little end scene that suddenly cuts in about a minute or so after the credits start. Don't rush for the exit.

title: Narnia - magic comes true!
review: I just went back from the movie. It was so crowded...just like Star Wars EP3. The lion, the witch, and the wardrobe novels were my favorite when I was in elementary school. I remembered after reading all the series of novels, I wondered why there was no one making movies (not mini TV program) for Narnia. Until now, thanks for ILM and WETA's cooperation. At last, the magic comes true! The director Andrew Adamson and all other creative crews visualize the story in novels. Basically, I think the adaption of this movie from the novel is excellent. Such as the white witch, she is just like what was in my mind while I was reading the novel. I think most readers will not be disappointed. I find it is a Disney movie and it is for kids; thus there is no blood and much violence in this movie. (Unlike the lord of the ring trilogy, it is basically for adults and it is quite violent and bloody, but Istill love it, and it is very realistic) I think I can say it is "the lord of the ring - kid edition". The movie score composed by Harry Gregson-Williams is great and touching. Special effects and Visual effects are extraordinary. They are quite realistic. Most of the sequences are just like what they were in my mind while I was a child. After seeing it, I was moved. Finally, this classical stories are on the wild screen just like the lord of the ring, Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, and so on. I heard most other people saying that they love this movie when leaving the theater. I do really look forward to the next Narnia movies! Go see it! No matter you have read the novels or not.

title: A very faithful rendering of the book....
review:
Chronicles captures the book well, including many of the important nuances. The entire effect of the film, however, will be to render even to the most faithful reader a better, more complete understanding of the book. Just great....kids should see it, young adults, and the old folks, too!

For those who have read the entire Chronicles, something that really matters is how well the movie provides insight into the characters of the four children. The real mystery child is Susan, and viewers should pay special attention to her actions and reactions. Viewers should also note the time slippage between Narnia and England, for that is key to understanding the other books.

There are two ways to read the Chronicles...in the order they were written or in order of events in Narnia, as they are usually arranged now. If you are intrigued by Narnia after the film, the Magician's Nephew, the first volume in the beginning of Narnia to end of Narnia sequencing of the books, will answer some key questions---like why that Lamppost is there?...And where did the wardrobe come from?...And why Professor Kirke is likely to believe the children? My bet is that there is going to be a whole lot of reading of all seven volumes of the Chronicles in the next year....The 50th Anniversary edition with colored versions of the original Paula Baynes illustrations is worth its weight in gold.

See the movie, read Lion Witch Wardrobe, and then reading the other six. Unlike Lord of the Rings, most of the loose ends are tied by the end of the read. If Hollywood undertakes to produce the other six books, there are some great motion pictures ahead, but they are going to need special effects that go way beyond this first picture, for the full magic of Narnia is only hinted at in LWW. You simply don't stop reading once you start because the magic just gets better and better.

title: Like being ten years old again
review:
Wonderful way to spend an evening! I had my doubts going into the cinema (the early trailers reminded me more of a Series of Unfortunate Events than Narnia) but any fears I had proved unfounded. Although not a flawless work, it is an extremely well-crafted, entertaining one. The film opens amidst the London Blitz of WWII, which results in the Pevensie children (Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy) being evacuated to the countryside for safety (there's a compelling moment at the London station as Peter gazes at a soldier who's only a couple of years older than he is) where of course, the whole story kicks into high gear.

The early scenes, though necessary, are a touch slow (apart from one literally explosive bombing raid at the start) and are used mainly to serve as our introduction to the children. However, once the wardrobe is discovered, the magic moments come thick and fast - particular favourites are Lucy's first visit and meeting with Mr. Tumnus the faun, the appearance of Father Christmas, the charming Beavers, the whole waterfall sequence, and of course Aslan (a triumph of CGI - I swear you'll be dying to stroke him) and the climactic battle at the end of the story.

There are some genuinely dark moments amidst all this, balanced out by some wonderful humour from the talking animals. The negative aspects are few and far between - the ending felt a bit rushed, and the characterisation of the children was a bit overdone; half-way through the film you'll probably feel like saying "yes, Peter doubts himself but is ultimately a hero, Susan's the bossy one, Edmund the sulky one, we get it already!" But these are minor gripes when the entire spectacle can produce the wide-eyed wonder you'd thought you'd left behind with childhood - particular acting kudos goes to a deliciously malicious Tilda Swinton as Jadis the White Witch, Liam Neeson as Aslan, and Georgie Henley who makes a wonderfully appealing, brave Lucy. A wonderful Christmas treat for kids and grown-ups who still tap the back of the wardrobe ... just in case.

title: Awesome Movie
review: One of the best I've seen. Although not as good as LOTR. Although I was quite surprise why IMDb didn't list Liam Neeson as Aslan in the Crew list. but other than that I do recommend this movie. However there was too much Christian overtones. A lot of action which is a good thing. This movie will not bored you. Liam Neeson does a very good job, but i found the children to be average. I don't recommend the movie for younger children. There are a lot of scary scenes. If you love fantasy and action then this movie for you.It is similar to Lotr. There talking trees and animals. I particular like the beavers and the lion. I hope you found this recommendation useful

title: Excellent
review: Where to begin? This movie affected me in ways that are hard to describe. The best description I can think of is The Passion Of The Christ meets Lord Of The Rings, since so many of the central elements and themes from each of these movies are uniquely blended together in TCON:The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe. The insights of C.S. Lewis as someone of faith, which the movie is faithful to, are instructive, yet the fairy tale theme makes the mind attempt to object to the setting of the movie, since the central themes are not fairly tales. It has so many touching moments where the teachings of Christianity are hard to miss. When Aslan sacrifices himself, it is very moving, and the scene is made even more touching by Lucy's and Susan's reaction to those events before and after they occur. This movie has it all: wholesome and instructive themes, suspense and mystery, comedy, a bit of violence, good vs. evil conflict, convincing performances, and dazzling special effects. This movie is a must see, as it has something for both adults and children, with no profanity or nudity. The battle scenes at the end may upset very young children though, so parents with young children may want to see it first without the kids to determine it their kids can handle it. There are a couple of things about the movie though that I do take issue with, which is my reason for not giving it a perfect rating. First, when Walden Media have movie options on all seven books in TCON, why did they stray from the order in which C.S. Lewis intended for the books to be read. It seems to me that The Magician's Nephew should have been made into a movie first. It provides background information for The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe: The creation of Narnia, The origin of the White Witch, The origin of the lamppost out in the middle of the woods, "Professor Kirke's" true relationship to the story, and the origin of the wardrobe and how it came to be a link between Narnia and our world. All these points will be lost on those who haven't read the books. I also take issue with the made up scene when Mr. and Mrs. Beaver and the children are escaping from the White Witch. This scene is not true to the book.

title: A new favorite for me...a good reason for other parents to pause...
review:
I've been anticipating the arrival of this film since I first heard rumors it would be made. I became a great fan of the Lewis works as a teenager and have loved sharing them with my children as an adult. The film version was true to the novel - nothing seemed terribly watered down or removed as is so often the case with film versions of classic novels.

I was enthralled with the choices made for actors for all parts. Swinton (the White Witch) could not have been more aptly cast. The children all shouldered their roles with believability and grace.

The direction, art direction, score, and cgi were all first rate save two scenes in the film. There were two moments when my friend and I both agreed the combining of actors with background or scenery was less than seamless. There a few very minor details that are additions which are not in the book. But those add visually to the story and do not at all detract.

Lastly, I like to leave some information for parents trying to make a decision about letting children see this film. Spoilers will follow: There is one scene in this film in particular that I believe might be frightening to the point of worry for parents of very young or very sensitive children. The Stone Table scene where Aslan comes to the White Witch is imagined by Adamson in such a manner that the creatures loyal to the witch are quite grotesque and many may find them frightening. Some more conservative parents may find the battle scene between the armies of Aslan and the White Witch just a bit too realistic despite the absence of blood or gore. I personally have decided my children should wait for the small screen version (I think the large screen has a much more profound impact visually) and they are age 8, 7, 6, and 3 (I wouldn't let my 3 year old see it at all just yet). The Christian allegory is not altered or watered down by the film imagining. For non Christians the book and film version are amazing stories in their own right, and for the Christian the parallels between the story of Christ and this first of the Chronicles of Narnia are hard to miss (for those who do not know the story of how the Chronicles were first written, this allegory was intentional)

All in all, this film is magnificent. I absolutely loved it. It was so well done and well put together that I won't be surprised if we see Best Picture nods early next year. If you loved the book, you'll not be disappointed by this film. 9 out of 10 stars (with one deducted for 2 moments of less-than-seamless cinematography and cgi combination)

title: Our Hope Is Restored!!
review: This movie was superb. it brought hope to me. hope that there are still good movies out there and there still are good writers and director. and yes, i have been a fan of The Chronicles of Narnia since i was a little girl. i was so afraid that it was going to suck. because it it did i think i would have been very depressed. this movie was so much like the book. they only changed a few things, and what they did change was an improvement. i am not saying that the book needed improvement, but what they did was perfect. i have no complaints. this is a movie i can see many many times! thank you Andrew Adamson for not ruining my life! this movie saved my life...

title: Great Rendition for Children and Adults Alike
review:
Ever since the departure of Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy there has been a huge gap left in fantasy cinema since then. Now Disney is obviously trying to fill in the gap with a big screen rendition of CS Lewis' (Tolkien's college friend and fellow fantasy enthusiast) seven-part fantasy saga The Chronicles of Narnia. Though, in my mind, that LotR gap can never be filled, The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe does a damn good job at keeping our love of epic fantasy going.

Staying true to the book (with some extra added scenes to explain a little more depth of the story) and using a lot of the books dialogue this is an enjoyable treat for all the family. Though some of the performances are a little wooden, from the actors such as Liam Neeson for example and the kids especially. Even Tilda Swinton, who looked fantastic as Jadis, the White Witch, could have put a bit more malice and venomousness to the role. But this is the films only fault. The final battle is excellent (some bloody deaths could have been added, but that's just me) and the effects are satisfactory (I would have like to have seen some real animals used every now and then).

The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a great teat for the whole family leaving a sweet taste for the next installment, the Horse and His Boy. Just look out for some familiar props from Lord of the Rings like the circular sharpening stone, or, if you look carefully, the sword Narsil itself in the hands of a petrified Centaur.

title: A Good Yarn
review:
Although not in the same league with the already legendary Lord of the Rings pictures, director Andrew Adamson (of Shrek heritage) has brought C.S. Lewis' "The Chronicles of Narnia" to the silver-screen with unusual humanity and style. In a courageous attempt to capitalize on recent trends of audience infatuation with the fantasy genre Walden Media and Walt Disney Pictures brought us an expensive yet delightful holiday treat in the form of "The Lion with Witch and the Wardrobe".

A great many things about Adamson's adaptation of the Lewis books are very impressive. Interestingly though I did not feel startled by the quality of special effects. Perhaps LOTR/ WETA have ruined my view of effects for several years to come. But despite lacking a great many new thrills in the technology department Adamson has other tricks up his sleeve. I was especially impressed with the performances of the film's most integral parts, the Pevensie children. Despite risks of being overwhelmed by the abundance of CG characters, landscapes, and the resulting scenes, the four young actors who took on the lead roles of Lewis' valiant children proved themselves by excelling in almost every category. Skandar Keynes did well in producing the necessary audience feelings of disdain and eventual embrace of his surly but lovable Edmund. Anna Popplewell seemed like an old hand compared to her co-stars and handled her screen-time with grace and poise that is enviable for many of today's stars. William Moseley did justice to the character but he failed to make a resounding statement with his performance (I would be surprised if he is successful in turning his Narnia time into a long-term career). However, the most remarkable scenes in Narnia are not produced by the grandeur of special effects but instead by a tiny little girl named Georgie Henley. In the history of the cinema directors have shown sick fascination with hinging their films on the performances of children. While most people remember the positive moments in the history of film and children e.g. "Sixth Sense", "E.T.", "Oliver!" there have been a hundred times as many distinct failures (Brandon De Wilde's "Shane" is my personal favorite). And in other cases failure has not been outright and is instead replaced by mediocrity of child performers which has led to mediocrity of the film as well e.g. "The Road to Perdition". Although her performance is not what the film hinges upon for its overall effect it might as well have because 10 year-old Georgie Henley provides the deepest magic you find in Narnia. Henley completely pulled me into the story every instant in which she was the focus of a scene. Her on-screen communication does not even walk a fine line with overacting, it remains perfectly within the boundaries of subtlety and magnificently communicates the innocence and fiery spirit of her character. My favorite scenes of the film are played out between Henley's Lucy and James McAvoy's good-hearted faun Mr. Tumnus (McAvoy is particularly outstanding among the supporting players).

Tilda Swinton's turn as the white witch was a primary reason for my interest in the film. However, I was relatively unimpressed with how her performance played out. Certainly Swinton did an admirable job but she lacked anything extra that truly made her stand out amidst the quagmire of CG characters. This role could have kept Swinton in mainstream villainous or powerful female parts for life but I am afraid she did not do enough with her screen time to justify any special attention. She will likely never become a contemporary of Cate Blanchett as she, and her promoters, may want her to be. Jim Broadbent's precious few moments of screen-time are everything any Broadbent fan would want them to be. He handles himself as always with unequivocal dignity and produces a fantastic sense of mystery as the ancient and secretive professor.

The quality of voice acting is certainly good. Ray Winstone, Rupert Everett, Dawn French and many other talented individuals lent their professionalism to the project and they add to Narnia's mystical ambiance marvelously. Liam Neeson took on the difficult role of Aslan (Narnia's equivalent of the Messiah) and I am sad to report that he simply does not have the ability to voice a lion like James Earl Jones (Mufassa from Lion King). Neeson has proved himself time and again to be one of the great modern-day thespians but he just lacks the power Aslan needed (and could only be provided in my view by Jones).

As a whole Narnia presents itself as a very good children's fantasy epic. However, Lewis' high focus on child content will leave Narnia out of any serious consideration for awards and status in the history of movie-making. Peter Jackson's Lord of the Ring's will stand a test of time that Narnia cannot and will not. Still, Andrew Adamson's direction shows that he has the stuff to be a lasting directorial force in Hollywood (and with the success of the Shrek film's why not?). Not only does Adamson strut his technical stuff he also displays an uncanny understanding of what makes a movie humanistic and fantastic without exploiting or stretching an audience's collective imagination. He and his screen-writers cleverly expanded on Lewis' storyline (which lacked many necessary establishing factors) and did so without losing any of Lewis' charm or intent.

Overall, it is a Good Yarn that is worth seeing.

title: A captivating adventure that will leave you feeling fulfilled and intrigued
review:
I've read some of the books in the series. I remember enjoying them at the time...several years ago. I ended up going to see the film tonight on a whim and an invite from a few friends. I definitely do not regret it! Lewis' truly captivating story will let you escape from the stresses of your daily life and delve into the world of four curious and innocent children living with a mysterious professor in the British Countryside, escaping the constant bombardment of Luftwaffe bombers during the Second World War, who stumble across a mystery and an adventure far greater than anything they could ever imagine.

The film brings to life their incredible adventures, and the viewer feels like a part of the action, captivated by the fascinating story unfolding on screen.

Through a beautiful and moving soundtrack, excellent acting, incredible set and scene design, creatively designed costumes, and a very appropriate and well-implemented use of computer animation, the second episode in the Chronicles of Narnia: the Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe, creates a thoughtful and passionate reenactment of Lewis' original writing. I'm certain he would be proud of this amazing work of art, and I know that you will enjoy it just as I have.

title: The King, The Queen and everything else is in The Wardrobe - including excitement?
review:
Even in an age that includes such highly regarded fantasies as The Lord Of The Rings, C.S. Lewis's Chronicles Of Narnia are still beloved by many. Not that I would know, having read very little of the books (shame on me, I know), but I enjoy a good fantasy as much as the next person, and with Harry Potter and LotR successfully reinventing the fantasy genre in the 21st century, The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe seemed like an adaptation to look forward to.

Especially at Christmas. Last Christmas, we'd had the very entertaining Lemony Snicket's A Series Of Unfortunate Events. Alas, it has not lingered long in the memory, and I fear that this adaptation, despite being entertaining, will follow suit. Like Lemony Snicket, it wants to be a young children's fantasy, and succeeds on that level to a greater extent. After all, it has a higher pedigree. The problem only begins when director Andrew Adamson (of Shrek fame) starts trying to emulate Peter Jackson.

This, the first of the Chronicles Of Narnia (there should be many more to come) begins with the four Pevensie children - Peter (William Moseley), Susan (Anna Popplewell), Edmund (Skandar Keynes) and Lucy (Georgie Henley) sent to the house of Professor Kirke (Jim Broadbent) during World War II. While playing a game of hide and seek, Lucy decides to hide in the wardrobe, and while moving towards the back, finds herself in the kingdom of Narnia. Many surprises and adventures follow, not just for Lucy, but for all the Pevensie kids.

I think there are many treats in store for those who haven't read the book. Now I knew that Narnia was "in the wardrobe" (who didn't?) but I didn't anticipate the several interesting characters and remarkable visuals that were to be seen in Narnia. Not that they eclipse the young leads - all four are credible, and I'm sure they will go on to even bigger things. The biggest names in the cast - Jim Broadbent (in a cameo) and Tilda Swinton, don't disappoint, with Swinton being especially chilling as the White Witch. Recognisable voices are all over the place, from Ray Winstone to Dawn French to Liam Neeson.

Friends of mine have told me the film is very faithful to the book. That seems like another huge plus point, and in a way I suppose it is. But it's worth pointing out that what works so well on the page does not always work so well on the screen. I discovered this when watching Tim Burton's attempts to recreate classic moments from Charlie And The Chocolate Factory; however well he did them technically, they lacked a spark.

It seems that Adamson realises this, and it's at that point he enters LotR territory. Before long you will see (POSSIBLE SPOILER WARNING) birds soaring from overhead in a key battle, the "resurrections" of important characters, a "crowning" moment - it's all been done before, and done better, by Peter Jackson. Even the effects were better in LotR - just compare some of the computerised animals to Gollum and you will see what I mean. Additionally, there's some blatant blue screening on more than one occasion.

It's not that the battles are bad. They do have their effective moments, such as a memorable duel between Peter and the White Witch, but they sometimes border on tedium and confusion. And the film is not without its moments of unbearable cheese - just watch, for example, how some characters are "resurrected".

Despite the best efforts of Andrew Adamson and his crew, the order of things in the fantasy world hasn't changed. The Chronicles Of Narnia have got off to a satisfactory start, but Harry Potter and The Lord Of The Rings are still - clearly - in front.

Rating: 7/10

title: awesome!
review: this was incredible! it stuck close to the book, without being boring. there was all the magic of the big screen, without detracting from the message. the music and camera work was amazingly dramatic. also, the scenery was absolutely breathtaking. and while at some points, you have to laugh at the sheer absurdity (ie when you first see the head of the "secret police" at Cair Paravel), overall the fantasy is as realistic as possible :). the theme stands out clearly and leaves you feeling satisfied. the casting was well done and Lucy is beyond adorable. the action builds well, the progression of events is in no way drastically altered from the book, the actors do an incredible job of conveying earnesty and intensity, and Aslan shines. all in all? this movie is every bit as powerful and enjoyable as i'd expect from something based on a work of C.S.Lewis

title: Slavishly faithful to the source material, a little perfunctory but mostly pretty good
review:
Just to give you an idea of where I'm coming from, I adored these books when I was in the fourth grade. I am a good deal older and more cynical now, but I recall the books with a great deal of affection. I was wary about the film, both because it seemed like an attempt to cash in on the success of the Potter and LOTR films, and also because the books never seemed particularly cinematic to me (so much of it being things that only make sense from the point of view of a child).

The film opens with shots of German planes in the sky during the Battle of Britain. We're introduced to Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy as they go scrambling into the bomb shelter adjacent to their London home. It's a nice touch, a context that is only mentioned in passing in the book but which benefited from a more explicit showing now that WWII has faded from our collective memory. The film then proceeds with the events of the book, matching developments very closely. The four child actors play it all with a very English sort of reserve, which is a nice departure from the "needs their Ritalin" kids of many contemporary films, but it also mutes the sense of wonder sometimes. With the exception of a few moments between the very young Lucy and Tumnus the fawn, the kids accept what happens to them and how their lives are changed with relative nonchalance. They're good, and it's good to watch them as they endure and develop, but they're hard to relate to.

Turning to the ideological content of the film, the Christian metaphor becomes pretty explicit (perhaps even moreso than in the book). It didn't bother me per se, but I can see that becoming an issue for militant atheists. It IS a propaganda piece for the values that C.S. Lewis associated with Christianity at its best, but even as an agnostic I have respect for most of those values. I was bothered somewhat by the strident militancy of the last third of the film. There's a blend of childish awe and violence in the battle scenes that doesn't sit well with me, though to the filmmakers' credit they are just reproducing the tone of the book. But it's such a naive view of war, and it's so bizarre to set up these kids in a setting that plays like something out of Braveheart or Return of the King except with the miracle of no blood being shed. The mixing of violence and innocence, with religious overtones, is fundamentally disturbing to me.

Still, it's a good story well-told, and the filmmakers show a deep reverence for Lewis' writing and tremendous special effects know-how to bring it into motion.

title: Early Christmas Present!
review:
I've been looking forward to the release of Narnia for a long time and I'm happy to say I wasn't disappointed! The characters are wonderfully brought to life with every detail of the book shining through. I found at points the acting a little stilted but this does not detract from the overall brilliance of the film.

Conversion of such a loved book to film format would not have been an easy transition but the reason I feel it was so successful is that you can really see the love that the production team and cast members had while the film was in the making.

The film to me was every bit as fantastical and enchanting as the book was when I first read it. There is an emotional aspect to both the book and the film that I feel are quite unique and it is something that I have not found anywhere else.

I would highly recommend this film to people of all ages and especially if your a fan of the book! Enjoy

title: All it's cracked up to be...?
review: Just got back earlier from seeing Narnia. It was a good movie. It was not Lord of the Rings good, but then neither are the books. The books were made as children's stories, and thus so is the movie. However, the movie is very faithful to the books, with only minor and inconsequential changes. Narnia is very colorfully created and with the exception of a really cheesy effect at the end of the battle scene, the FX were really well done and believable. The actress who portrayed Lucy did a good job. The other children weren't quite as convincing, but all the wonderful and mystical scenery/eye candy drew attention away from this fact. The movie could have benefited from a PG-13 rating, as there was a sense in the battle scenes that the director was holding back in order to get the lower rating, and the battle was thus not as intense or convincing as it could have been. Also, the movie did seem rather rushed at parts and could probably get away with being another twenty minutes longer. I can't wait to see what they do with the rest of the series though and all in all it was an enjoyable and light hearted adventure. I did not leave the theater feeling disappointed and anyways, until PJ gets around to making the hobbit, this is the closest we'll get to the Lord of the Rings with the possible exception of the Potter series. Now on to King Kong...

title: Excellent rendering of the book, great effects!
review: The Lion, Witch and the Wardrobe does a great job of being faithful to the book, but is exciting enough by adding a few scenes and showing the back story of how the children got to the house in the country. Though the movie starts a little slowly, things really get exciting when they go through the wardrobe. Beautiful scenery, and wonderful characters. The battle scenes are intense, some animals are seemingly in danger, but its done well enough that you can take the kids and assure them that it will all be okay in the end. Kind of like "Lord of the Rings" for children. Fantastic CGI of creatures, action, costumes and detail. The Lion is magnificent, (stone table scene might be intense for children) but no blood shown, violence is somewhat off screen. The kids are just too cute and the sibling interaction is very realistic. After viewing the movie, you will want to read the book and really appreciate the writing and dialogs that did not make it to the movie. The beavers'conversations in the book are my favorite - "A lion? Is he safe?" "Of course he's not safe, but he's good! He's the King!"

title: A Classic for a New Generation!
review: I just saw an early screening of this movie with the church that my friend attends, and so I didn't have to pay for my ticket, but after seeing some of the garbage that has come out lately, I sure wish some of that money went to this movie! This film is truly mesmerizing! I went into this film after never reading any of the novels and not expecting much, other than the fact that it was getting some good early reviews and I have to admit, I was totally blown away. This film has great characters that are very enjoyable and easy to root for, and villains that you will hate. It's a grand tale that is placed together so well by the director Andrew Adamson, that I believe an Acadamy Award might not be too far off for him. He reminds me of Peter Jackson in the way that he weaves together this magnificent tale that i won't ruin for anyone here in my review. I recommend this movie to anyone who loves a great story with marvelous special effects and spetactular dialog that is smart and clever. I could watch this movie over and over again and i'll surely go and see this movie again. The best movie by far from this year!

title: Greatest movie of the year
review: I went to the New Zealand premiere of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe last night, and to describe this film in one word: amazing. Even the word amazing is not enough to describe it. I enjoyed every single moment of the movie, not one bit was boring. I highly recommend this movie to everyone. You don't have to have read the books before, I didn't, and I understood it perfectly. The Pevensie kids deliver awesome performances, and the talking animals are so realistic that you actually start believing it would be possible. It is a good mix of humour, drama, action, suspense, fantasy, etc. By far the best movie I've seen this year, and probably in a few years (even better than Harry Potter, and believe me, I'm a big fan). Don't hesitate to go see it, it's well worth the money, and you'll be caught up in the wonderful world of Narnia that Andrew Adamson has brought to the big screen.

title: A beautifully done and moving film
review: As a teacher I am always looking forward to seeing movies based on children's books, but I never know what to expect.
