Many screenplays are often lacking in their accurate portrayal of the book. However, this movie was beautifully done and very true to the original work by C.S. Lewis. The actors were well cast, the cinematography was wonderful, the soundtrack was very nicely done, and the special effects were exceptional. I was truly moved by this movie and very pleased with the final result. It is an excellent choice for older children especially those who have read the original book. There were a few scenes that were a little intense for my seven year old son, but he still loved the movie and hasn't stopped talking about all of the characters. Overall I give this movie a 10 and recommend it for anyone who would like to revisit a classic story or experience it for the first time.

title: This movie is amazing!
review:
I don't want to give out too much information on this movie but all I have to say is that it is AMAZING! It is really entertaining and though provoking for the entire family. As an adult, I was truly moved and my nieces were in awe throughout the movie. I remember reading this book as a child and this movie brought back memories. I strongly recommend this movie for anyone who would like to be entertained.

Although I have not yet heard of any of the actors in this picture (but I am sure they will be known soon enough!) The acting was as superb as the story. I can already foresee many awards and a place in the movie hall of fame for Narnia.

title: I Dare say the best movie of the Year!
review:
I didn't know what to think when I heard that one of my beloved childhood books was being turned into a movie. Anticipation was the first thought, but then fear came over me, what if they ruined it? My fears were blown away within the first five minutes of the movie. I was in Narnia! My biggest fear had been that because Disney was making the movie that the talking animals like Aslan, and other fairytale creatures were going to become animated. I mean when we're talking talking animals and Disney I think of the Lion King and the Little Mermaaid. With Narnia it was real, it didn't look fake like I thought it would have.

I can't say enough about this movie! I plan on going back and seeing it many times before it leaves theaters, to tide me over until it comes out on DVD. :-)

title: Narnia - impressive, but a little flat.
review:
Overall, I was really impressed with the first installment of the Narnia franchise. The CG and "groundbreaking photorealism" were truly stunning and a marvel that I enjoyed throughout the movie. However, I felt that the major themes of the book were not developed enough and consequently had little impact or emotional pay-off at the climax of the film. Obviously this is tailored for a much younger audience than myself, who I think will go nuts over the film, but for me I felt that there was nothing in Narnia that I hadn't already experienced from the trailer. My advice is take a kid along with you so that you can somewhat enjoy the film from their perspective too. Before I end this I will just say that I wanted to see more of Aslan going absolutely nuts and tearing the crap out of some of the weedy White Witch's minions. That would have earned the film an 8 on it's own. Andrew Adamson has already said though, "The story of Narnia doesn't call for brutality." That is the comment that I think even he doesn't quite agree with. I think overall the film is a little 'luke warm'. It is kind of brutal, just kind of soft-brutal. It is sort of scary, but not really. It is somewhat epic, but falls a little flat... which will make it a family box-office smash. The franchise is here to stay.

-Rich p.s. Georgie Henley (Lucy Pevensie) is a remarkable actress. She really delivers her character well and makes this film one worth watching.

title: Actually no LOTR but still quite good
review:
I just got out of the theatre, first day of Narnia and I am still thinking over and over about this movie. Well it is no LOTR at all but it is a quite good fantasy movie and if you are up for it you can really let go and fall into the story the movie is telling to you. I did not read the books, so I cannot tell if they are following the storyline 100% but who cares.. This story still lives on in my thoughts and I caught myself 2 times looking at the wardrobe and thinking about sneaking inside.

This movie got a great visual performance (for me though) and a fetching story.

I give a 9 out of 10 for catching me in for almost two hours

title: Exactly What It Claims To Be
review:
It could have been overblown, but it wasn't. It could have been "enhanced" or "inspired by", but it wasn't. It could have been excellent. And it is.

It's hard for me to separate the movie from the book, the two being so closely mated, and that makes it practically impossible for me to rate this movie, since the book is one of my favorites of all literature. That, and one of my earliest memories is my father lying in the hallway reading this book to me and my brother as we went to sleep. How do you objectively comment on something so close to one's heart?

I was deathly afraid that the movie would try to be something that the book isn't. The Chronicles of Narnia are not the Lord of the Rings trilogy. They are also not the Three Musketeers, or the Legends of King Arthur. They are stories for children, stories that happen to be about the most important thing that has ever occurred, but children's stories nonetheless. The movie preserves this. The animation is excellent but not flawless, and the CGI is good but not top-drawer. This is irrelevant. The story is all there, every bit of it, from Edmund's snottiness all the way to the mice on the Stone Table. The dialogue is not straight from the book, but it's organic to the movie.

I was also afraid that no movie in this day could possibly tell this tale and leave intact the mystery and power of Aslan, as representative of the Christ. No review of this movie could leave out this essential point, I don't believe, for this story is, in its essence, a story about the root of all Christianity. And my fears were not entirely unfounded. There is some skirting of the essential point, but the light touch on it is unlikely to obscure the truth from those who know, while refusing to hit over the head those who would rather not have to face it. In the end, it was dealt with about as well as could be expected.

And I was most afraid that I would leave the theater and find that my childhood memories were overlaid with some sticky Hollywood film that would affect my love for the book itself, that I would see in my head only those images that the movie projected, and that they would alter, perhaps even degrade my love for CS Lewis's immortal classic.

That didn't happen. For me, the movie was a fitting tribute to the book, preserving its character and power while allowing the characters to live and breathe for a new generation that might not be quite as much at home with the printed page.

For Narnia! Long Live the Lion!

title: this is my comment on the movie
review: it was a great movie i loved it it has very good special effects and was excellently acted the lion in the movie looked so real i was shocked to see that but in 1 case just my opinion was i don't think it compares to harry potter its good but i seen harry potter a few days before i seen this movie and i think it is better but try it out for yourself you will not be disappointed with the outcome and it is a great film i say it is the 2nd best movie this year and it lives up to the book expectations when you see this movie it will be every think you wished and more and it was well worked so go and see this movie thank you

title: Excellent film
review:
I was lucky enough to see this movie one week before the opening. Highly recommended. It is one of those rare films that actually sucked me in and had me fully focused on the film, as opposed to sitting there thinking about other things.

The special affects are stunning(you will believe that animals do talk!). The story line is as you would expect based on the books. The acting is very good. Not a drop of blood in any of the violence (good for kids).

There was quite a bit of violence, however, but my 7 year old daughter loved it and the violence wasn't too much for here. Will be a classic.

See it.

title: Are there any postings not written by Disney himself?
review:
Lets face it, the cgi effects are great as well as the score by H.G.W. (better be with that amount of money). The Story is predictable (even if you haven't read the book). The whole plot is childish.

Well, have you all really watched the same movie which I did? I also want to get paid for my comments.

Is there a chance of getting free entrance in Disney World if I say: "This is the best movie I have ever seen, much better than H.P. or LotRs!"

And what really makes me freak out is the idea of about 6 following stories. ("Please white witch, freeze me to death!")

title: A Cinematic Grab-Bag
review:
"J.R.R. Tolkien criticized Lewis's first Narnia book, The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. He thought that there were too many elements that clasheda Father Christmas and an evil witch, talking animals and children."

Tack on the blatant Christian overtones and you have the convoluted, pretentious, and self-righteous film that is "The Chronicles of Narnia".

If I was to pick a saving grace for Narnia, it would be the scenery, which, while lacking variety, was beautifully imagined and shot. Unfortunately you don't see much; the snowy woods were about the only set, until the epic concluding battle. Also, the visual-effects were extremely impressive, especially the photo-realistic animals, and creatures which inhabit Lewis' world. Although not on par with the Lord of the Rings (in part due to slightly weak voice-acting) the animals were vibrant, likable, and on occasion amusing. The effects are what truly shine in this movie, but not enough to carry it beyond mediocrity.

As for the acting (Despite a wonderful performance by the White Witch) well, it's difficult to criticize child-actors, as they are often way out of their league. Unfortunately, it must be done. The children were an abomination, the screen cutting away at every point any semblance of talent might be required, followed by shoddy voice-over crying. Susan, it seems, was purposely miss-cast, and her acting doesn't cover the void between literary character and on-screen heroine. There is no character development, aside from a ridiculous case of sibling rivalry. Apparently, a trivial argument between brothers is the basis for something far grander, grasping at straws in order to explain certain deeds, the writers fell short.

JRR Tolkien was correct in calling C.S. Lewis' story "a literary grab-bag" and that rings true with the film as well. Atrociously anti-climatic, with every single epic war cliché pulled from everything from the Lord of the Rings to Braveheart. How many hero's must we see wielding two swords before it stops eliciting the excitement of the first time?

Not having much to do with my overall review of the film, but something which must be mentioned, is the religious element to the film. The underlying Christian themes were overt and insulting to anyone of moderate intelligence. It's nothing more than religious propaganda, under the guise of a fanciful story.

Perhaps, if you loved the books as a child (and are a practicing Christian), or are a child yourself, you will find a worthwhile film in "Narnia". If not, I'd avoid this movie like the plague, go rent, or better yet read, Tolkiens work. A chop-shop fantasy tale such as Lewis', makes one truly appreciate the true genius of writers like Tolkien. Likewise, a chop-shop fantasy movie, helmed by the talented Andrew Adamson of Shrek fame (who, despite his best efforts, was unable to bring meaning to Narnia), makes you truly appreciate the efforts of someone like Peter Jackson. I hate to have to make so many Lord of the Rings references, but it was Narnia who made them so blatant in the first place. Frankly, and I'm being brutally honest, it comes off as a Rings-rip off, toting Christianity. Undoubtedly explaining the success it will see.

title: Reaaaly bad
review:
This is a really bad film in it's own right, but it's particularly terrible if you happen to have enjoyed the C.S Lewis books as a child.

I can guarantee the people who gave this film a good rating never read the books. If they did, then they shouldn't have bothered, because there is NOTHING of the books' sublime style and touching message left in this film's butchering of my favorite works of children's fiction.

The White Witch was ludicrous! She has dreadlocks / braids for goodness sake. She is supposed to be tall and beautiful, not thin and hippie.

I don't remember much of the rest of the film. I was so terribly upset from the moment Jadis appeared on set. I can't even recall if they stuck to the plot.

Don't waste your time watching this travesty.

title: F*cking weak man!!
review: This movie is F*CKING WEAK!!! This movies plot is tricky and kind of boring. They seem to have found a way to make you wonder if to much is happening in to little time or if to little is happening in to much time. I simply don't know!! But I do know what makes this movie the worst movie since Logans' Run. The acting. These people should never have tried to be actors!!!!! They make Michael York look like Max Von Sydow!!! I believe they harmed the world seriously when they made this movie!! Learn how to hold a sword like a normal person and learn how to act!!!!!!!!!!! Do not support Hollywood by purchasing this movie. F*ck NO man!!!

title: Overrated, annoying, a complete waste of time,
review:
Four English children are evacuated to an old country mansion during the second world war where they come across a wardrobe that leads to a fantasy world.

This was a huge disappointment for me, I loved the books as a child and expected this to bring back fond memories. Instead, I found it to be at best a cheap TV version not a high budget Disney affair. The acting was far below standard and the special effects where overall extremely poor and cheap looking. The story was not as remarkable and exciting as I remember, this may be because I am no longer a child, or because this version was just unimaginative and poorly made. Despite this being a 'children's film' it should still manage to appeal to both adults and children if it is an accomplished piece of work, as for example Harry Potter manages.

This is a badly made money-maker for Disney, they have brought a seminal children's book onto the big screen and it is a disaster from start to finish.

title: B-movie with a nice story ruined by incompetent directing, acting
review:
I don't really know what is more shocking for me: To see so many reviews here rating NARNIA 10 that I just can't resist to think that the studio/producer invested a considerable amount of money to write fake comments - or how it could happen that a major Hollywood studio proves itself again to be too amateurish to produce a decent movie with a solid story, fair acting, and competent directing.

Don't let many of this reviews here fool you: Narnia is dilettantish to the max. By no means it can compete with HARRY POTTER or the LORD OF THE RINGS - and I am not complaining about the shallow story. It is incredible bad directing (just one example: The two girls get ambushed by wolves. You'll see the wolf two meters away from them. Next scene: Both girls sit screaming on top of a tree. Question: HOW DID THEY GET THERE WITHOUT BEING SHREDDED TO UGLY PIECES IN THE FIRST PLACE?), it is bad acting, TV-budget special effects, but even worse: a simple, boring, predictable story. The only thing NOT predictable is the hair-rising illogicalness of, well, pretty much everything. How come the "good" warriors trust a boy with NO military skills AT ALL to lead them into battle? O god, the flaws of this movie are so countless, it makes movies like DUNGEONS & DRAGONS a Shakespearean masterpiece.

If you want to see a very, very simple fairy tale story suitable for your eight year old kids, go and watch it. If you don't like to get insulted by bad film-making - avoid it.

I can only shake my head. What a bad movie!

title: Less than the sum of its parts - Very slight spoilers
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia  The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe is the latest film adaptation of the C.S. Lewis book that kicked off the Chronicles of Narnia series. Set in World War Two, the story begins as four children are whisked away to a big old estate far away from where the Huns are raining bombs upon London. The Pevensie children, Lucy, Edmund, Peter and Susan discover a wardrobe that leads to a kingdom called Narnia clasped in the grip of a century long winter.

The frigid spell is the result of the usurped rule of the Witch, who has declared herself queen of Narnia, when in fact the true rulers are foretold to be two sons of Adam and two daughters of Eve. Local talking fauna are convinced that the quartet of Pevensie siblings are the prophesied revolutionaries who will be instrumental in restoring Narnia to it's former self, leading them all on an adventure revolting against the evil pretender to the throne.

Unlike Tolkien, Lewis's works are intentionally analogous to Christianity. Aslan, the lion found in the title, is a Christ figure. He is good and just, hated by the wicked and loved by the righteous. The book deals in themes of truth, honor, duty and sacrifice in barely disguised allegory to the Gospel. One wondered if Disney would leave those themes in place, or would the Witch Queen of Narnia be recast to represent George Bush, the Wolves his Texas Oil Buddies. Would Aslan become the heroic transgenderd heroin addict who rallies Narnia's bohemian community to wage peace against the forces of intolerance and corporate greed? To my joy, the Gospel themes are intact, and I daresay, quite forceful and explicit. The movie is at its strongest and most resonate in the scenes that depict Aslan's character doing what Christ did. The creators deserve credit and accolades from Christendom for resisting the temptation to water down a powerful story. Unfortunately, those same creators deserve a severe beating for chaining a gigantic steel ball to the leg of the movie. Great jumping catfish, just how long do you need to dwell on scenes of children traipsing through snow? I had loaded up with a big soda before the show, so I sat watching uncomfortably for fear of missing something big. I needn't have suffered so. The way the action has been paced, there were no small climaxes on the way to the big one. A good storyteller will traverse peaks and valleys on the way to the big mountaintop, but director Andrew Adamson makes the trip such a long slog that you are not excited by the big finish so much as relieved.

The child actors elucidate the famous British understatement, even the precocious Lucy. When a Limey from that era says "things are a bit sticky" he is likely armed with a teaspoon and surrounded by 100,000 angry Zulus. While I find that aspect of the classic English character charming, the surrounding action has to step up and provide a context that makes the understatement work. None of the main cast are particularly lively, with the exception of the animated ones who provide welcome relief along the grueling plot.

I will say that the animated creatures, particularly Mr. and Mrs. Beaver, are delightful, and the combination of Liam Neeson's voice and a fantastic animated lion make Aslan majestic and noble. When Mr. Tumnus and Lucy relate that Aslan is not tame, but is good, the description is well befitting the character we've watched on the big screen.

TCON was written before the hand-wringing era of Dr. Spock and Teletubbies (In my day an alien flying saucer would be surrounded by tanks and infantrymen, by gum!). The Pevensies are given arms, and prepare themselves for medieval combat. These lead to some intense scenes, and I could see where less mature children might be distressed by seeing peers on screen in peril. I don't recall any blood or flying parts, but the implication is there. People and anthropomorphic critters are being bludgeoned, slashed and impaled. For my own part, I think we have given children the false impression that there isn't evil in the world that seeks to destroy them, but parents who think otherwise are hereby duly cautioned.

Chronicles of Narnia  The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe seems to want to be Lord of the Rings but the story's shoulders are not broad enough to handle all the majestic shots and lingering views. While parts of the movie are wonderful and moving, the sum of those parts are plodding. As a Christian, I am grateful and encouraged that a major studio not known for being friendly to my faith made a faithful rendition of a cherished allegory. The movie lover in me knows that it's about 20 minutes of scene-eating too long, and is disappointed.

title: Completely crass in every way! Was an incredible strain to watch!
review: First let's start with the general feel. From the beginning of the movie it seems very American and not at all British; even the choice of music in the early part of the film is out of step. Then there's the unnecessary use of partial sepia or brown tones to indicate that it's the ordinary world, or possibly to show that it's the past. Now let's talk about the family dynamic ( or lack there of), no family is simultaneously that vicious to one another and yet (on-and- off) so loyal. Actually, the point of loyalty brings another thought to mind; the betrayal of Edmond was not believable at all. Edmond is willing to first betray his sister and her friend for a piece of candy and then, despite the heavy-handed movie-villain acting of the (not scary or impressive at all) witch, he still tries to do everything she demands while continuing to expect some kind of reward (isn't he a little to old for that kind of credulity?), only to be (very predictably) taken prisoner. After that the extremely poor actors, both voice and live action, go on portraying moronic, cold-hearted bastards leaving dozens of obvious questions in their wake, such as: why didn't Susan just shoot the witch with an arrow when she was about to kill Aslan? Why didn't Lucy just tell Susan to get stuffed and try the healing potion anyway? Why do the beavers walk on two feet? Why is it that Peter is brave but stupid, Lucy is smarter than anyone else but weak, and the other two are just useless scum that merely upset the others and get in the way until the very end when they suddenly redeem themselves in a way inconsistent to their actions in the rest of the movie? Why was the actor playing Mr. Tumnus more like a supermarket cashier than an otherworldly creature? Why does Susan joyfully hug Mr. Tumnus even know she's never met him before, especially since she doesn't seem like a very loving sort of person? Why didn't Aslan kill the witch when he had her in his tent? Why was the the dialog so weak and uninspired? Why was the battle scene not even as good as the wookie battle in Star Wars? Why was Aslan made so feeble when he's supposed to impart a sense of leadership and majestic awe? And finally, why did they cast such ugly actors/actresses? With the exception of Peter, all the humans looked more like something from the creature shop than the mythical characters.

title: Superficial and boring, disappointing and mediocre
review:
First of all, I've never read the book, and if it is as great as they say the movie falls way short.

The plot is flat: a prophecy indicates that 2 girls and 2 boys will end a 100 year winter, in a fantasy land inside a wardrobe.

I've read some comments on this movie, most of them with the "spoiler" warning. I don't see the need to warn anybody because there's nothing to warn. Unless of course you expect the prophecy to be false.

The problem with the movie is its predictability. You will find yourself no surprises or interesting twists, the movie takes you on a one-line story that ends where you would expect, even if you never read the book.

The visuals are stunning, but not distracting enough to forget that there's no depth, the few conflicts we see have very simple solutions. The main characters never really struggle as the sense of danger or pressure never kicks in.

All in all, it's a disappointing movie. Learn from my experience and don't go there expecting too much, you may probably enjoy it.

title: Good Effects, Boring Story, Preachy
review: I will admit I had never heard of "The Chronicles of Narnia" until I saw a preview for this movie. I had no idea that it was a series of books until a few months later, and with that said, I had no idea what to expect from this film. From the very beginning, I noticed that the movie seemed to borrow scenes from other films. When the children boarded the train and left for the countryside, it seemed very reminiscent of the train leaving for Hogwarts in the "Harry Potter" films. I know there are not too many ways to film a train leaving for the countryside, but it just seemed odd. The first hour of the film was good, especially pertaining to the development of the character Lucy. Lucy is by far the most interesting human character in the film, which is not saying much. Her siblings have rather flat personalities, and there is not much depth to them at all. Once the movie ventures into the land of Narnia, things begin to slowly progress downward. I was never blown away by the land of Narnia, the scope just did not awe me as Middle Earth in "Lord of the Rings" had. The White Witch is a decent enough villain, but her dialog is a bit spotty in parts, but that's tolerable for fantasy villains. The story is one of a prophecy being fulfilled, how original, and we learn this from two talking beavers. The movie cannot seem to decide if it wants to be a children's fantasy movie or an epic, and this hurts the film. The effects are hit and miss, but Asylin the lion looked absolutely stunning. The other animals were done fairly well, but some of the various mythological figures were not so good. I hate to break the news, but C.S. Lewis is not a creative writing genius. He just took the life of Jesus and put into the realm of fantasy, and I do not see the originality in that. The scene where Asylin is brought to the stone table, which is the Narnia form of a crucifixion, is way too much like the "The Passion of the Christ" but with animals and fantasy creatures as the stand in's for humans. And guess what? Asylin comes back to life after being sacrificed, at that point, I proceeded to yell "Jesus Christ" and got a few laughs. The morals in the movie are very disturbing, especially when Asylin pretty much orders Peter to kill a wolf, and Peter never even offered the Wolf a chance to surrender. Overall, I never really connected or bonded with the characters and the story is very lacking in excitement and originality. I do not mind a movie with a message, or even a Christian one for that matter, but when you take a line directly out of the Bible, when Asylin says "It is finished", you are now pretty much making a propaganda film. The film was watchable, but it will not become an instant classic for me. I will stick to "Lord of the Rings" and "Harry Potter" for my British fantasy fixes.

title: The first Narnia film is a droll, humourless affair...
review:
The long-awaited "other New Zealand movie" finally hits the screens. Will it live up to it's hype and it's $180m budget? Andrew Adamson has big shoes to fill; the Chronicles of Narnia encompass an imaginary world in the Tolkien mould, albeit at a less detailed and more child-friendly level. Thus children, not 300 yr-old wizards and rangers are the heroes here and Adamson has taken a gamble in picking unknown's for his characters; a ploy that worked somewhat for Harry Potter...but this isn't Hogwarts.

The film opens to a scene of WWII bombings in London a 5 minute sequence covering the first 5 lines of the book....we also have some character setting here; Peter is the stuffy, bossy one, whilst Edmund is the bad apple boy. After a Potter -style train ride they arrive at The Professor's house, their safe haven whilst the bombs are falling. It's all very gloomy and sad, which brings me to my first gripe. The situation portrayed in the book is one of excitement and wonder, not doom and gloom. Obviously Adamson was trying to contrast the boring world of Earth with the wondrous world of Narnia; but considering that they go there to fight a war anyway...where's the contrast? It makes for some tough viewing. The kids mope around and fight with each other, before Lucy, the youngest, finds her way into Narnia through the wardrobe. There she meets Mr Tumnus, half-human, half...something. He's charming enough, but his nervous manner indicates immediately that perhaps he's up to no good. Taking Lucy home and drugging her (not in the book) really doesn't help the situation. It ruins one of the best characters of the Narnia realm. Edmund's encounter with the white witch is interesting, if forgettable. Tilda Swinton has the cold complexion of an ice queen but "proud, stern and beautiful"? It's simply not there. There's more moping and more kid-fighting before the whole sorry lot end up in snow-land.

After this it's all Aslan and war. The CGI Aslan is very stately and lionish, but is largely expressionless throughout - a far cry from the joy and sorrow he expresses in the book.. The movie drags on and on - we simply don't care enough about the characters to be interested in their fate - and eventually we get to the big battle scene. It's all pretty simple. (King) Peter's army is animals and half-animals; the Witch's army is men in monster suits. The good guys win of course and everyone lives happily ever after.

The first Narnia film is a droll, humourless affair. It says something when the first and only laugh is from Susan shooting the Witches' servant dead with an arrow (?!?) So where did it go wrong? From someone who knows the books well, there's an awful lot of interesting characters and dialogue left out. The book is only 200 pages but it seems Adamson was more intent on providing battles and set pieces than humour and magic.

title: Don't waste your time...
review: Disney Studios put The Lord of The Rings and Harry Potter in the same package to make this trash. The Train on the beginning reminds me The Hogwarts Express, as the lady of the house reminds me Minerva McGonagall. The Lion, Gandalf.Anna is a pathetic Legolas. The battle makes me sleep, and how can you explain the way that the lion surrender himself ? He Knew everything about the stone table, and the Witch, Nothing ??? The four brothers passed years in Narnia While even a second passed in our world ? Forget it! Walt Disney must be crying in heavens. I wanna 140 minutes of my life back and let the other books only on the libraries. Put it on bottom !! 0/10

title: Boring. save your money for king kong
review: This was totally a kids movie and stayed well within the limitations of its PG rating. Whenever someone was stabbed and killed, there was no blood on the sword, and at the end of the movie just about everyone who was 'killed' came back to life. there were some really big gaps in the plot.. and the main character went from being a 10 year old wimp to a warrior in about ten minutes. I also found the story boring for the most part with only about 15 minutes of excitement (during the battle scenes). The battle scenes were awesome and paralleled those of Lord of the Rings, however much of the story and etc i found to be extremely slow moving. I give this movie a 5/10 simply for the cool creatures, fantastic CGI, and the battle scene at the end.

title: The worst film i have ever seen!
review:
I've seen this in cinema with couple of friends. Believe or not we could no longer take this, since we were sitting in the middle we had no chance to get out, so we had to watch till the end.

Year 2005, come on now, you can make way better graphics than that.

Acting was almost good, but not enough. The only thing in the film was the performance of the little girl, she was stunning and very natural.

I haven't read the novel, and not willing to after this film, but hopefully its not as bad as the film. I think they have really spoiled the book.

I wish i would have never seen this film, but it happened.

and good luck to everyone who is willing to watch this!

title: This movie sucked. I just saved you 10 bucks and 2 hours of your life.
review:
This has to be the worst movie I've seen all year. I don't know how all you people could stand to sit through it. Actually, I don't know how all you people could have stood to sit through it and then call it a good movie.

The only good part about the movie was Aslan. Not joking at all. Aslan was captured magnificently. Other than that, nothing about the movie brought the book to life. Peter was a blotch on the radar who didn't even know which end of a sword was up; Susan was more like Boromir with that horn of hers; Edmund was the one you wanted to punch throughout the whole movie (and not just for selling out his family - that boy was a truly terrible actor); and Lucy was nothing more than an annoying little girl.

All over the movie I could see scenes copied shamelessly from The Lord of the Rings Trilogy. The scene on the river, for instance, when Peter fights off (hahahahahahahahahahaha yeah right) the wolves - a straight imitation of the scene in The Fellowship of the Ring where Arwen brings the river down on the Nazgul.

I don't see how anyone over the age of 1 could enjoy this hopeless rendition of The Chronicles. Better luck next time.

title: Maybe the book was good but this is an awful movie
review:
First, I would like to point out that this is not a critique of the book as as I am apparently one of the handful of people who have never read it. I was actually looking forward to watching Narnia as it was recommended to me by a few people. Also, knowing that WETA was on board gave me the impression that it was going to be a quality production. Unfortunately, this movie seemed to rely primarily on special effects as it fails terribly when it comes to acting, storytelling, and direction.

One big problem was that there was no epic scope conveyed at all and everything felt like it happened in a week once the kids passed into Narnia. I found it ridiculous that a land that had been suffering for a hundred years of oppression from a tyrannical witch (who is quite possibly the best thing about the movie) is saved by bickering siblings who had absolutely no idea how to use a weapon or run an army a few days earlier. Actually, I'm not really sure why they needed the kids in the first place. From what I saw, Aslan would have done a much better job leading the army and it was he who finally defeated the witch in the end. I hope the book does a much better job conveying the kids' importance to the plot as they seem to be more like tourists in this movie.

Pacing was another problem. Considering how long this movie ran, I was stunned at the lack of character development or substance in the plot. They could have probably cut the running time in half or less and delivered the same message. You never really know why the witch does what she does, where Aslan comes from, why the kids are so important, or anyone else for that matter. Everything just seems to happen because it was "prophesized" or just plain convenient. If this is how it is in the book and they wanted to remain faithful, that's fine, but it definitely makes for a very shallow and unsatisfying movie experience.

I wish I could say more positive things about this movie but nothing unsaid comes to mind. There are plenty of people who liked this movie more than I did and I wish I could say why that was. I actually thought about walking out of the theater at some point but kept telling myself that it was going to get better. Considering the large following that this book has, it either deserves much better treatment or it just does not translate very well to the big screen.

title: Trix Are For Kids
review:
Having seen (and enjoyed) the Harry Potter movies, and to a lesser extent, the overlong Lord of the Rings movies, I decided to join some friends for this bit of fantasy.

I do think it plays well as a kids movie, but as an adult, it's just a bit too slow-paced and cutesy for my taste. The characters were thin and underdeveloped and the action scenes tended to fall short for the most part, at least in comparison to other films in the genre. I'd recommend you check out Potter and his Goblet of Fire instead.

The ending, in my mind, unfairly rewards the youngsters. Thousands strived long and hard for this particular goal over the centuries and died trying, while the kids reap the rewards simply because they are fulfilling some arcane prophecy. The message seems to be, "no need to work long and hard, kids!"

title: This is how kids movies SHOULD be made...
review:
There's a real sense of wonder and magic in the air throughout this film. It has something for everyone: Fun, adventure and a deeper meaning than you'll find in most children's movies. It has an innocence about it, but does in no way talk down to kids. It's a genuinely enjoyable film that delivers in all areas.

For someone like myself (who is usually unimpressed with kids movies and annoyed by the child actors who populate them), I can - in all honesty - say that I was in no way annoyed by the four young lead actors in this movie. The standout is obviously Georgie Henley, as the youngest Pevensie (Lucy). I assure you that seeing her reactions - which are *so* genuine - to everything around her will take you back to what it was like when you were a kid and still had that sense of child-like wonder. The friendship she immediately strikes up with the goat-legged Mr. Tumnus (James McAvoy) shows what it's like to be a true friend and accept someone who's different (which is a message kids need to learn). Lucy's youngest brother, Edmund (Skandar Keynes), is almost the total opposite. He's the angry one, who's always getting into trouble and making bad decisions. Even though I found him to be the least likable of the four siblings (and the actor over-emoted on occasion), he *does* prove his worth by redeeming himself at the end.

The two older actors (William Moseley as Peter and Anna Popplewell as Susan) both give solid performances. While Peter does come close to being the typical angst-ridden teen (and Susan the bossy know-it-all), they thankfully manage to keep their characters likable and don't overact too often. Tilda Swinton - who literally plays an ice queen by the name of Jadis - imbues her character with a real sense of malice, but - at the same time - keeps her performance dialed down (opting for an eerie calm instead of over-the-top yelling). She is cold as ice, in all senses of the word, and this is what makes her White Witch so formidable (well...that and when she's kicking butt with twin swords).

Of course, it wouldn't be Narnia without the many magical creatures who populate it. They are brilliantly brought to life by a mix of impressive CGI (except for that one dodgy-looking rhino) and well-cast voice actors. Liam Neeson is marvelous as the mighty Aslan (the way the animators manage to convey so much emotion on his face is truly amazing). Mr. and Mrs. Beaver (Ray Winstone and Dawn French) are a likable pair and aren't the usual annoying variety of talking animal that you find in kids' movies. Michael Madsen is suitably menacing as Maugrim, the White Witch's head wolf. Rupert Everett even gets a memorable cameo as the helpful Fox. There are also many other extraordinary creatures throughout - most of which are on display in the epic final.

The scenery is quite breathtaking. When you see the meticulous effort that has gone into designing Narnia, you'll no doubt be overcome with the same feeling of awe as young Lucy. The movie benefits immensely from a very fitting and memorable score (and make sure you don't walk out as soon as the end credits begin to roll. There's something extra only a little ways into the closing credits - proving that good things do indeed come to those who wait). The creatures, the scenery, the music - all of it combines to bring alive this truly magical land that you will never want to leave.

As far as family films go, this one is - in a word - perfect. It will appeal to kids and adults alike. Before you know it, you'll be searching the back of your wardrobe for a magical land. And should you not find one there...you'll be taking a sledgehammer to the back of your wardrobe and knocking holes in it until you find such a wondrous place as Narnia.

title: A movie that took me by surprise.
review:
You have to thank the Harry Potter franchise for starting the fantasy- books-into-movie-transition-hype because ever since 2001 when the boy wizard made it's movie debut, other fantasy novels such as The Lord of the Rings decided to rule the movie box office where no longer did action movies pumped up with hardcore violence and blood or mindless plots grabbed audience members but literary heroes with good hearts.

The Chronicals of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe tells the story of four children who go off to live with their eccentric uncle (Jim Broadbent) while World War II is breaking out all over Europe, including England where the children used to live. Lucy (Georgina Henley), Susan (Anna Popplewell), Edmand (Skandar Keynes) and Peter (William Moseley) try to make the best out of living at their uncle's mansion where they are not allowed to make any kind of noise until one day when the kids are playing a game of hide and seek that young Lucy discovers that a coated closet takes her to another world of magical creatures including a half faun/man by the name of Mr. Tumnus (Scottish Actor James McAvoy) who is forbidden to make contact with humans along mentioning that The White Witch (Tilda Swinton) will punish those who break law in Narnia.

The older kids don't believe Lucy until the following day they discover for themselves that their closet their younger sister hided one time leads them to Narnia where it seems strange to be talking to creatures who can talk back. They meet with Mr. Beaver and his wife where they tell the kids that they're meant to be heroes and save Narnia from the White Witch just before Edmund betrays them.

(Note: I have never read the books just like Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings, but I do follow with the characters and plot through Internet) I did wanted to see The Chronicals of Narnia back in theaters, but I was glad that I got to see the film on DVD where everything looks beautiful just like the film itself. Apart from the acting, I thought that each of the four child actors did a good job in convincing me that they could take charge when put into peril. Another thing about the film that took me by surprise was the voice credits from tough guys Ray Winstone (The Departed) doing the voice of Mr. Beaver along with Michael Madsen (Kill Bill) as Grimel, the head wolf of the White Witch. Liam Neeson is the voice of Aslen, protector of the creatures of Narnia which surprised me since he played both a hero and a villain that same year with him being the villain in Batman Begins and a good guy in this movie.

This is a good movie to all ages!

title: A new epic for the kids
review:
I read The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe in the 6th grade, it seriously was my favorite book that I could just read over and over again. When I first saw the trailer a few years ago for the film, I was scared to see it because I wasn't sure if it would ever compare to the book. But you know what? It's a film, that's a book, I don't like to compare the book to the movie because I think that's how people end up hating a movie is if it's not faithful to the book. A film is bound not to be like the book, some things have to be changed for entertainment or because there is no way to adapt a scene from a book onto film. So finally decided to just go ahead and give The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe the movie a chance and see what it was like. I watched it a couple days ago and really enjoyed how everything was presented and I felt like it was very faithful to the book after all.

Lucy, Edmund, Peter, and Susan are all brothers and sisters, set in WWII in England, for safety's sake, their mother sends them to a friend's house. When they are playing hide and go seek, Lucy finds a closet, she goes in to discover a whole new world. A world called Narnia, she meets a faun(who is half man, half goat), Mr. Tumnus, who warns her to go back, that the White Witch will come after her. She goes back, but tells her brothers and sister, who eventually follow her into Narnia. But Edmund has been bribed by the evil White Witch to betray his brother and sisters. But they must work together to bring peace back into Narnia and are to be the future kings and queens.

The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a wonderful film, to me it was kind of a new epic for the kids, like how Lord of the Rings isn't meant for kids, this was a film they could get into. I still prefer the book, things just lead up to your own expectations and imagination. But still the acting, the special effects, the story is just lovely and I'm sure that this is a film that you will definitely enjoy. It's a great family film, worth the watch.

8/10

title: Read It then Watch
review:
"The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" was an action packed movie about four kids, Lucy, Susan, Peter, and Edmond, who were forced to move to the country side of England to escape the bombings of WWII. They moved in with there Uncle, who was a professor and lived in a huge mansion. While staying there the youngest of the four children, Lucy, came across a wardrobe in an empty room during a game of competitive Hide-n-Seek. While hiding in there, she just happened to come across another world called Narnia.

In a lot of ways I like this movie more then the book, but over all I would have to say the book is my favorite. I'd rate this movie a 8 out of 10, mostly because I don't think they did the best job with some of the effects in the scenes. Also I love reading, and I liked that I could picture the characters and scenes the way I wanted too.

I think all of the characters did a great job and played their roles perfectly. The scenes in this movie were put together well, and the seasons gave an effect of the differences between the worlds. The Witch and Aslan matched the seasons, and it helped show their personalities.

My advice to you would be to read the book first then watch the movie.

title: Awesome adaptation of C.S. Lewis' classic series
review:
There had been a few adaptations of C.S. Lewis' classic series; But those adaptations over the years, are an animated TV special, and a live-action TV mini-series from BBC. So Narnia hasn't made it to the silver screen, until Disney and Walden Media decided to adapt Narnia to the big screen, with today's visual effects and excellent soundtrack too boot.

Now that "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe" is a movie, I'm excited; I wanted to see it. And so I did, and it was awesome! with a top-notch cast. Though I never like Mrs. McReady and the Beavers display quite humor. And also, the film has awesome effects, and music too. As I said, I am not one to take sides which adaptation of "Narnia" I love. So I love BOTH this film and the animated TV special.

title: Amazing Film!
review: This film was one of the best movies I have ever seen in my life! After I saw this movie I read all of the books and they were all great. The actors do a fantastic job and the special effects are great. The last battle scene is also really good and the white witch is so cruel but Tilda Swinton did the part perfectly along with most of the other actors. The part where the children were all standing on the ice and then it broke was not included in the book but it was a great addition to this movie. I think all the actors should be very proud of the fantastic job they all did. The kids did exceptionally well especially in this film and if anyone hasn't seen the film I suggest you see it as soon as possible, you will not be disappointed

title: Great Movie for our kids but for parents first
review:
One of the best message given to kids other then the adults. Actually other than the kids more adults should watch and learn out of the this movie. It has many message in it for us as being parents.

I also have to respect the special effects creators as being 3d and cinema4d user. more than respect it was perfect I have watch the movie several times to catch any mistake on animal effects it's perfect, magnificent. I have enjoyed every second of the picture.

Too many good messages given who are trying to be human.

As we have an very old saying who do not love animals can not be human. Even most fearful animal do not harm anyone who do not tread herself.

For who would be interested Aslan means Lion in Turkish.

As many other quotes comes out in the movie which leads me that the writers has spend enough time in Turkey and study history of ancient Anatolia.

title: Beautifully done
review:
Very rarely do you find a good film with such wisdom and depth that leaves you with a triumphant feeling. The Chronicles of Narnia is one of those films.

Based on C.S. Lewis' timeless story, Andrew Adamson brings the story to the silver screen and breathes life into it like you've never seen. The direction is majestic and powerful, with amazing special effects and dazzling shots. The screenplay is written with such intensity and fire that it brings epic moments to the film. The actors do a marvelous job in believability and pull off all types of acting in the film.

Enhancements include a brilliant musical score and a spectacular battle scene. What else can I say? This was a great movie, and a family one too.

The only things that I wasn't satisfied with was the opening. While still good, it still wasn't the best opening for such an awesome film, and is really just a device to get the characters to the next location. Another is seeing the kids as adults. For some reason, the characters did not match up with the younger versions of themselves, so it was an awkward moment. Also, the film is watered-down because its supposed to be a family film. But its still a magical one.

But those minor flaws do not hinder the greatness of this film. Tilda Swinton is the best witch around, and the sacrifice scene is so well-written (some cheesy lines but overall good). I can't really explain just how well the film works with itself AND the book. Faithful to the book, faithful to the family, and faithful to what makes a great film. 8.0/10.

title: An excellent entertainment, A lovely story.
review: Not having seen any of the previous incarnations of this story, I was not certain of what I would see, but I was totally delighted with this film. The four young actors playing the children were perfect. Liam Neeson as the voice of Aslan was Majestic, and Tilda Swinton was very impressive as Jadis, the white witch. The film's locations were also a real treat. Finally, I enjoyed the small part that Jim Broadbent brought to the story as Professor Digory Kirke. The musical score was also very appropriate and majestic. All in all one of the finest fantasies to come to the screen. I would imagine this will rank with Lord of The Rings, both films based on stories by good friends and rival professors, C.S. Lewis and J.R.R. Tolkien.

title: Chronicles of Narnia in 3-D!
review: This is one of the ultimate fantasy classics. I was impressed with the amount of CGI that went into this, especially how well they integrated the half-human creatures, like the centaurs and fauns, with their human actors. Aslan was awesome, truly majestic, humane yet at the same time very much a lion. I got to see my DVD in 3-D due to a pair of TV Eyes glasses I got off eBay. They turn any movie 3-D! The inside of Mr. Tumnis's house was beautiful rendered in 3-D, I wanted to live there. The scenery was wonderful, from snowbound vistas to springtime forests, to the plains of battle. All of the creatures looked so much more real and solid, more fully integrated into the movie than they were in 2-D. The moral story is still there but it's not heavy handed. And I just loved how bratty Edmond was and how well the kid actor played him, especially after he had his change of heart and was trying to atone. I haven't read the book in a long time but I think the movie captured it very well, certainly better than most.

title: Too violent for kids, too immature for adults
review:
I watched this DVD because I'm a fan of the LOTR films and CS Lewis apparently wrote similar content to Tolkien. I've never read any of these books though. As a film, this movie fails. It starts of well, the initial scenes with Lucy and the Fawn are delightful and magical. In fact there are probably 3 good performances in this film, Lucy who's acting is a joy to behold, the Fawn guy who does a decent job and Orlando or rather the White Witch who plays the part of an evil witch - just right.

Special effects were not extraordinary by any means. LOTR - FOTR, had better effects by far, while the battles in Narnia were, I think too violent for the target audience. The film is just not serious enough for a mature audience but too violent for little kids, I'd say. There isn't enough substance to this film and it seems to lack spirit, except for a few moments (like Lucy and the Fawn).

I don't think this film teaches anything about Christianity, and I personally think Sailor Moon is more Christian than the pagan celebrations depicted here but then again I never read the book so maybe it's just a fault of this film. Overall - OK for kids, if you don't mind them having to put up with violence like little Lucy having a dagger (to kill orcs with). Fantasy fans should rather watch LOTR, I guess. This film is superficial kitsch, but then again, it's Disney so what can one expect?

title: Synthy and Fake
review: I can't believe anyone saying that this movie is good. This is such a money-making movie. They spent loads of money, not on acting or the story but only on the graphics. And, i admit they look stunning. Though the storyline is worse then 50 cent's movie. Then the fighting...can you imagine kids from London, sword-fight like noble knights and kill creatures i/e Minotaurs. And then there's the worst part of all: the music, compared to music composed by Klaus Badelt, Howard Shore, John Williams and James Horner this sounds like a composition of a bunch of mentally challenged people. All these freaky synthesizer noises don't fit in the fantasy image this movie wants to create. Plz people, don't support this awful production.

title: A Rather Unenchanted Magical World: Embark Upon A Pacier Adventure Somewhere Else.
review:
Oh, the disappointment! To walk into the cinema expecting something with the verve of Lord of the Rings, or at least with a comparably good mise-en-scene, and instead to be treated to this lacklustre matinée! The film's greatest flaw is its laboured pace: the fault of casting on the basis of looks, poor acting direction, and flabby dialogue editing.

The young actress Georgie Henley (Lucy) really shines, but her three siblings get progressively more wooden with age. The White Witch (Tilda Swinton) and her sidekick Ginarrbrik (Kiran Shah) turn in the worst performances of the lot. Swinton is as enchanting as a doleful catwalk bitch; her jarring seduction of Edmund never convinces, and thereby makes nonsense of most of the plot. Shah delivers his few lines in the fashion of a Hong Kong schlock overdubber. Liam Neeson turns in a journeyman's performance that is just too portentous to suit this fantasy, whilst Tumnus (James McAvoy), although possessed of a lively face, also belabours his lines.

I don't believe, however, that the actors are entirely to blame: delivering one's dialogue at Sesame Street pace is a problem which inflicts most of the cast; it is the director, therefore, that must be charged with the crime. Narnia is Adamson's first live action feature, and it is all too apparent.

Having to deliver their lines in little snippets, and through many repetitions, actors depend on a director to orient them within the film, and to choose the right take! Adamson either failed to coax the necessary stuff from his cast, or else failed to hear that their performances were dragging. A third, worse, alternative, is that he positively encouraged a ponderous acting style.

Less than brisk editing is the other half of Narnia's pace problem; crisper cutting would have significantly improved this film. All those half second pauses  between lines, between shots, between actions  accumulate to drain it of life.

Performances and pace, however, aren't Narnia's only woes. Generally workmanlike effects are badly let down in a few instances that just can't be forgotten. The waterfall and its ice flows loudly declare their artificiality; they put one in mind of a shopping centre display. And when it came to equipping Aslan's soldiers with leathern jerkins, Peter in particular, how did the costumiers come to settle on fabric so fake you could smell the vinyl from the cinema's back row.

The film can't entirely undo Lewis' magic: with those grievous exceptions above, most things are competently done, and the beavers are entertaining. However, the Narnia experience is decidedly pedestrian; there just isn't enough levity, enough lustre, in this film. I never really felt like I was on an adventure; I often, sadly, felt rather bored.

The cinephile will find this film slow-going. Even those who read the book along time ago will find it so well signposted most of the surprises won't be surprises at all.

title: How I felt...
review:
First, I like get two facts clear before writing the review: (a) I am a Christian from both the Anglican and Catholic denominations, so there will be no surprise that I have something in for this film (b) And I also began reading C.S. Lewis' adult work (i.e. his science fiction trilogy, "The Screwtape Letters," and his theology) before reading his work for children.

I first saw this film in Hobart, Tasmania with my Dad and two friends from the Anglican church as a type of treat. I was interested in seeing it because I admire the work of C.S. Lewis and also I wanted to see this film out of interest. I confess that my only "Narnia" experiences were the cartoon and BBC versions, and, so I started reading all of the books, and I got the invite by the time I was halfway through "The Silver Chair." Anyway, onto the film...

The film goes along a good pace and does an okay realization of Lewis' Narnia, the New Zealand backdrop does as well for this film as it did for Middle-earth (I was most impressed with the portrayal of Father Christmas). As for the computer graphics, they may not be as well done, as say "Lord of the Rings," but they added perfectly to the creation of Narnia (indeed they much better than the BBC which had F/X no different than the original "Doctor Who," so that I couldn't tell the difference between a werewolf and a normal wolf). As for the acting it was okay, the children were all right and being connected by a desire to go home. Although he merely provided the voice, Liam Neeson was a perfect choice for the voice of Aslan because in the book he has a "golden voice," while Tilda Swinton was a perfect choice for Jadis, making her evil witch first ambiguous than going revealing some more evil. This was better then the other versions that tend to show the witch as a screeching crone. Ray Winstone and Dawn French were good as the beavers, provided some good humour.

My only complaints with it, are some shots that feel cheaply as if shot on hand-held camera, the camp fox and the ending. Those shots felt artificial and seemed to clash with the rest of the film, as did the portrayal of the fox by Rupert Everett. His line about being one of the good guys seems to be more Hollywood then Lewis, and he seem to be doing this out of a favour for the director for his work on the second "Shrek" film. As for the ending, I know it is a film and different from the book, but to it felt a bit too quick, especially the chase of the white stag, and when the children came out of the wardrobe, it felt too Hollywood as well. The only ending worked was with Lucy and Professor Kirke looking at the wardrobe and talking their Narnia experiences, unfortunately this was set a bit after the end credits when people were just heading out of the cinema! Otherwise it was all right adaptation of a work, while not being able to set the house on fire, it did perfectly to entertain for a whole evening.

title: disappointing
review:
*MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS* * MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS* * MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS*

I have read the book far too long ago to make any comment if this one a good adaptation or not. I do remember that the book was full of magic and at time I have read the book several times. I can only say that I didn't like the film as I was missing the magic. Something was missing and I found myself cold and detached when watching this film and it came as a surprise because the trailer was quite promising(a proof that one should watch trailers very cautiously).

The technical aspect of the film is also not perfect. In some of the scenes you can see that it has been filmed with blue screen(and for a film which relay on special effects, that is a big miss). Some of the performances are not apt for the task. Especially William Moseley & Anna Popplewell ( respectively: Peter & Susan Pevensie). Their acting is dead wooden and do not bring the characters to live. If any thing save the film from a total disaster it is the performances of Skandar Keynes(Edmund Pevensie) & Georgie Henley(Lucy Pevensie). Their characters are well played and are convincing. The best performance comes from Tilda Swinton(White Which), who give a new meaning for the say: "you are as cold as ice". When ever she is on screen the chill and icy tone made me feel freezing(and in need of a cup of warm chocolate).

I am sure children will love the film. Adults who have fond memories from the book may be much more disappointed. Shame we have to endure another 6 adaptation of these books.

title: poor and pitiful
review: I think this film was a cheep cut off of the book. And is defiantly not worth seeing. It wasn't much like the book to be onset it just destroyed the whole story. The only descent part is towards the end when the goodness of the warmth fought the evilness of the cold in one big battle. This film is a no see. I was expecting a lot from this epic tale but all i found was Borden. All i was thinking is when will this film end cause it just seemed to drag on and on and on. I walked out the cinema highly disappointed and tired. If u want to see a good film see Just friends. yeah don't see Narnia anyway and if you bring your children they will get really board and possibly fall asleep.

title: An excellent adaptation with superb effects. Very entertaining.
review:
When going to see this movie there were two things that were with me as baggage walking through that darkened doorway, thankfully I managed to leave both right there allowing me to enjoy the movie. One was the animated film I saw when I was a child, and the other was the hype and associated comparisons to Lord of the Rings both by Author association and Hollywoods new found love of the trilogy.

Neither affected the viewing of the movie and I was drawn into the film from the opening scenes. I can quite honestly say that even if I had been affected by those pieces of baggage, or indeed carried some of the religious argument into the cinema, I would still have been pulled into the movie just the same.

The story grabs you from the opening scenes of the Blitz and the performances of the children pull you right in. Immediately you understand the group dynamics and personalities of the children. That's one of the amazing strengths of this movie that carries from beginning to end, the storytelling.

Despite the huge effects and locations the real power is the story itself, pulling the classic book down into a manageable movie and yet keeping the moralistic tale filled with believable and identifiable characters. The movie does this amazingly well.

The acting is superb too, which helps the audience succumb to the tale. In particular the children are the shining stars of the film, with Georgie Henley as Lucy shining the brightest. There's a fine line between a young child star overacting and pulling off a strong performance of a childs' naivety, and she walks that fine line perfectly.

Skandar Keynes as Edmund is another character who is very ably acted, he portrays the petulant child well. Through this performance you can actually understand how he comes to his betrayal and you empathise with the range of emotions as he realises what he has done and how his young family have been affected.

Liam Neeson as Aslan was an interesting choice. Originally I had heard that this was to be voiced by Brian Blessed and that due to, allegedly, changes in his voice from dieting he was swapped for Neesom. Now this choice seemed poor for me, the voice of Blessed is strong and commanding and I didn't feel that Neesom carried the gravitas that could carry the role. How wrong I was. Neesoms voice was perfect for the part of Aslan, projecting warmth and strength wonderfully well.

The acting across the board is really good with Tilda Swinton proving to be a very strong and foreboding White Witch. Other roles, such as James McAvoy as Mr. Tumnus and voices like that of Ray Winstone as Mr Beaver, are very well acted and totally immersive.

The effects are stunning in this movie, although there are a few moments where the green screen effect is apparent. What makes the larger creature effects so good is that they are combining CGI with costume and make up, combining reality with make believe. The only slight stumbling block of these effects is during the full scale battle scenes when CGI takes over totally and some of the more natural textures and movements are lost. However its not a huge setback and your eye is only distracted by it if you are watching very carefully, while you're absorbed by the movie you're likely not to notice.

The battle scenes are choreographed very well be they live action or CGI. Flowing and fantastically detailed, the larger battle scenes do not end up as a mess of creatures and body parts. I was reminded of the battle scenes from The Last Samurai which were almost graceful in the way they played out.

There are obvious comparisons with Lord of the Rings during the battle scenes, the sheer scale and epic feel of them as well as the multitude of mythical creatures, but that's where it ends. Sure there are many connections and similarities, but these are two altogether different tales and hugely different movies.

Something else I noticed on this movie - and usually when this aspect of a film is so noticeable it's a bad thing - was the music. Music should compliment the story, said the composer of The Crimson Rivers soundtrack, it should not try to overtake and retell the story. Likewise it should not disappear into the audio track and not have some form of impact.

The music for this movie hits these statements firmly on the head. It matches the movie perfectly and every scene it touches, it helps to build emotions and heighten tension, and bring the audience back down when the pace slows.

I have to say I was surprised at the ending. The temptation to create it in an overly romanticised manner or dwell upon the successions to the throne is avoided and instead we are treated as adults and the conclusion moves on more to setup the second movie. Oh, and a spot of advice, stay to watch the credits.

This movie belongs alongside The Lord of the Rings and holds great hope for the remainder of the trilogy.

title: Good Movie.
review: Best movie i have seen in quite a while. i cant wait for the other ones to come out. Great Job. I liked it so much I'm reading all the books now too. I think it was better than anything that has come out this year. I think this kind of movie is way better than other kinds. My Favourite characters are Aslan and the professor. Favourite part in the movie was the battle scene. Even If Liam Neeson isn't I think is still really good. I thought the people who played the 4 kids were good. I like this movie way better than those Harry Potter movies. I'm From Canada and I'm 17 listen to metal music but still loved this movie. Man What A good movie.

title: All praise to JEEESUS, ahem, AAAASLAN! ...
review:
Had a bit of a special cinema-experience the other day; as a European visiting the US - Georgia, to be precise...

With two kids (6 and 11 yrs) of the people we were visiting, we went to see Narnia So, there I am, sitting in the Deep South, where a man is a man, and the Bible and a gun are both to be found next to the bed.

Ra-ra-ra, movie starts, at first very nice, but I was very disappointed by Narnia itself; I found it to be less than magical; very clean, and extremely dull-witted play by all kids except the smallest girl. The good guys look as if they are made out of clean plastic Lego or Playmobil parts put together by a toy-company, and the castles have the 'just out of factory - no people actually LIVE in them'-look that only big multi-nationals such as "Castles-R-Us" (a.k.a. Disney) can come up with. Where are the latrines that splatter-painted the walls of real castles in warm, earth-brown tones?

The most realistic things in Narnia were the bad guys; the minotaurs and the winged demons and orc-like creatures that actually were sweating and wearing stuff that looked real, and not like fancy-pancy plastic armour. Go Evil!! Speaking of Good vs Evil; the lowest of low points came when Aslan was resurrected; appearing with the sun-halo behind him, and music majestic and epic enough to tell even the dim-wittest person in the audience that "Go(o)d was back to kick ass!" - at this precise moment, arms shot up, hands were clapping, the word "YES!" was repeatedly yelled out with gospel-choir-like fervour, and I the word "Jeeeeeesus!" was heard yelled above it all. I should've brought my big paper bag after all.

After the movie, slowly filing out of the cinema, we passed a small guy with slick hair and a neatly ironed, white shirt. He was smiling a most benign smile, with a level of facial expression not unlike that of a playmobil figurine. He was handing out little pamphlets and postcards, with a mighty, roaring Aslan on one side, and text on the other side extolling all the Great Lion's virtues and how these were more or less analogous to those of our lord Jeeeeesus (with proper referencing to bible-passages, of course).

So, there; religion in the US today. I hope every kid in Europe will be able to watch Narnia and only marvel at the magic of it all, without having some more or less hidden religious message stuffed down their throats. Or - even better! - go and see Harry Potter and his adventures in a less-than-perfect but infinitely more interesting world instead :-)

I give it two stars; one for the best scene in the whole film: The Blitz over London in the beginning; and one for the Evil Queen desperately trying to make it more than a complete failure.

title: Over-hyped
review:
I'm fresh back from having seen Narnia on the biggest possible screen. I knew better than to have great expectations, so I was only slightly disappointed. The story is very straightforward - you know where it's going, and it just keeps on going there and going there. The book is too compressed here; events happen too fast and there's no real time for developing the characters.

In the final analysis this Narnia movie is just a run-of-the-mill Hollywood production of a story that was and is a far better fit for the small screen as a TV series. Also, a big-budget production like this pretty much had carte blanche with the creation of the fantasy world of Narnia, and still they couldn't come up with anything particularly imaginative. This movie reads far too much like what it is, but shouldn't exclusively be: a kids' movie.

4 out of 10.

title: Another Film Failure
review:
How eagerly I awaited my viewing of this movie! I was excited that this story, which was so nicely crafted and developed my eager young mind. The chronicles of Narnia are a fantastic story. That being said, this movie is another example of how these horrible film writers have ruined every descent story there is.

First, the movie, being released after Thanksgiving, was clearly more concerned with Marketing for the Christmas season, what with the appearance of Santa Claus and the addition of Narnia having not had a Christmas in over 100 years. If Santa Claus had more to do with the plot (he does give the weapons) then perhaps this cameo would have been more productive, but once he leaves, there is no mention of Christmas or Santa for the rest of the movie. It seems as if this was just a last minute addition just to satisfy the whim of the producer.

Second, the characters were hardly developed at all. I suppose the viewer is supposed to pick-up on the tired motifs of (1) the child who always tells the truth but is never believed (2) the antagonizing, self-serving older brother (3) the bitchy (pardon the language) older sister and (4) the indecisive oldest sibling. Aside from all of these, we learn nothing about the characters that makes them unique to the story of Narnia. Honestly, this movie made me sick of British children all around. The gap-ridden smiles, the freckles (grr... ginger kids), and the terrible naivete of these children grates on every nerve as they stumble through fairly tame obstacles. And by the time you get to the end of the movie, all you know about the characters is the motifs, and as Aslan crowns each of the children, he assigns titles that are the complete opposite of what little we know about the children: the self-serving older brother is "the Just", the bitchy older sister (who just wants to go home the whole time) is "the Courageous", the indecisive Oldest sibling is "the Great".

Third, the special effects are clearly the only thing in the movie meant to capture your attention, and in that, I feel the movie is successful. The Lion is amazingly real-looking, the white witch really looks mean, and the centaur is really cool. Too bad the costumes suck, and the plot suffers because of all the graphics they try to add.

This movie was a let down. I'd prefer to watch the TV version because at least that version had half-way descent writing. When will the filmmakers learn that computer graphics cannot make-up for the lack of a good story and certainly shouldn't be exchanged for basic story tools (e.g. Characterization, mood, setting etc.).

title: uninspired bore of a movie
review:
I can't possibly believe that anyone would rate this movie over 5/10 ... and that would only be for the effort of making it.

I have to be honest and say that I had my mind made up about the film even before my friend dragged me to the theatre to see it.

The opening shot was promising, I didn't expect the movie to start with a war scene, but that was about the only unexpected thing about it. From the point the kids leave their mother behind and travel to far off places it all turns to bloody sh*te.

The casting agency did a dreadful job and chose 4 of the most annoying actors éver! With one of them even surpassing Home Alone's Macaulay Culkin! At one point of the film I was actually rooting for the Witch to actually kill him, or at least torture him or something.

The visuals are lacking in imagination and are plain dull with a laughable final act that has no suspense whatsoever. And someone should inform Adamson that night scenes need to be lit too ... they were pitch black!

(minor spoiler) And for God's sake, if you're going to kill off a character, LET IT STAY DEAD! Don't create a boring weepy scene only to magically revive the corpse 5 seconds later.

The only good thing (and that's still arguable) about this film was Tilda Swinton. She is and always will be a good actress. But even good actresses can suck in lousy movies ... and she came very close to sucking in this one.

Perhaps all is not lost for the other possible book adaptations. But Walden Media may want to find another director, actors, CGI department if they ever want to compete with the Harry Potter series.

title: By far the most over rated movie I have encountered this far on IMDb
review:
This movie is really a good example of a bad Disney movie. OK, it is obviously made for children only, but that's no excuse for lacking all kinds of depth and emotion. I watched the movie in a cinema ranked as one of Swedens best, so the film makers really had a great opportunity to stun me, if not with a touching screen play so with spectacular special effects and nice filming. But no, nothing. In the cinema I could follow the reactions of my fellow watchers and the audience as a whole. The best words I can find to describe the reactions of the audience is flat and numb. Some clever lines were dropped that delivered some laughter but that was it. A movie that leaves a huge part of the audience untouched is in my eyes not a good movie.

To summarize: This film can probably give a thrill to really young ones, but if you're over 13 I would really recommend another movie, if you like movies that deliver so to say. But yet, for me this movie was a must as I read all the books when I was young so I don't regret spending 80 Swedish crowns (approx. 10USD) to watch it.

title: I don't remember the book being this bad
review:
I read this book about 20 years ago, liked it, but wasn't crazed. Shortly into the movie, I cringed, and tried to remember if the book really was this bad.

Let's start with Tilda. She carried on, and did wonders with what she was given. Unfortunately, she wasn't given very much. The White Witch really wasn't that scary. Villains these days are much more complex and at least somewhat sympathetic. The White Witch was just a bitchy dictator. Not scary. Voldemort would rip her to pieces, and any Sauron or even Saruman would turn her inside out.

The special effects: OK, Aslan was good. Everything else--not good. There's one scene where the three kids are standing on a hill looking out across Narnia, and the background looks horrible, like a blurry, hastily-painted backdrop, or a bad green screen drop-in. The rest of the effects are sub-par for 2005 to say the least.

Lastly, the whole sacrifice/resurrection bit. Was this how the book was written? Halfway through the story, CS realized he hadn't come up with a way to get a sacrifice and resurrection, so he just dropped in the whole "deep magic" rules and whatnot? Then why did I (or anyone else) actually like the book?

Unsympathetic characters, one-dimensional villain, amateurish plot device(s)--this movie just is nowhere near the hype. Go see King Kong again.

title: Powerfully disappointing
review:
I expected so much more from a movie with as tried-and-true a storyline as The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe. Apparently, so much effort was spent perfecting the computer animation that all the other aspects of film-making fell by the wayside.
