True, the inhabitants of Narnia are diverse and fantastical enough to warrant some digital effort. But the life- lessons of Narnia are not conveyed through the flashy mythical animals, no matter how realistic.

The screenplay was lame - contrived and trite. The cinematography was inconsistent. Scenes that were heavily computer animated were pretty standard, but those that were actually filmed - earlier, pre-Narnia shots and narrow, humans-only shots - were distractingly awkward at times. And lastly, much of the acting was seriously sub-par. Unexpected islands of talent within the cast are provided by the performances of nine-year-old Georgie Henley as Lucy Pevency and James McAvoy as Mr. Tumnus.

Overall, though, I'd say skip it - unless you are a die-hard Narnia fan. Then wait for the DVD and rent it, but don't spend $8.50 and a three-hour excursion to the theater like I did.

title: Average
review: I saw this film yesterday with my children aged 8 and 5, both girls. They both really enjoyed it. I thought it was average. The character of Lucy was well portrayed by the young actress. However, Edmund, Susan and Peter were way off the mark. Bad casting? I don't know but I found that I didn't care one jot what happened to these three. I was actually hoping that the White Witch would turn Edmund to stone when she captured him. I also felt the same with Aslan. When he was sacrificed, I didn't care. I don't think the screenwriters were able to convey any meaningful relationships between character and character or characters and audience.The White Witch was excellently cast and played, mind you. She was very convincing. The worst part of the film was the beginning. The relationships between the siblings was very weak. It seemed like the writers were rushing it along to get into the main body of the story. Even when Lucy had gone 'through the wardrobe' for the first time, there was a part where her brothers and sisters were disbelieving of her. I was thinking 'Just get on with it!' Once they'd all gone into Narnia, the film picked up a bit. The scenery was breathtaking and the special effects were great. I think these were the only things that saved the film from being awful. I read all the books when I was younger and enjoyed them immensely. Wish I'd seen the film then as I think I would have enjoyed it more! Children will love it but adults? Be prepared for 2 hours of mediocrity.

title: Enjoyable but not memorable
review:
In my opinion the movie is quite well done, well acted and visually impressive. It was a good diversion that did successfully get me into this fantastical world.

The primary thing I found unsatisfying was with the four protagonists as I can't remember any movie where the main characters do so little and are so unimportant to the unfolding of the story. In my opinion, they are present but not much more.

C.S. Lewis and J.R.R. Tolkein were apparently friends and both LoTR and Narnia were written about the same time. In LoTR the characters constantly make difficult decisions that determine their future, they make significant sacrifices and their strength of character and body are tested from start to finish.

In Narnia, with one significant exception, the characters are lead around from the start to the finish. The meet other characters by chance and each linearly gets them where they need to be next. They are destined for prestige in Narnia before doing anything beyond showing up.

Each of the four kids have interesting personalities but in my opinion at the end of the movie they are all the same undeveloped stereotypes as they were at the film's opening. Having not read the books, I don't know if I would have the same concern there or if the film version sacrifices so much that it is lost. My hope would be that the book does far more in this area.

For such a large budget and classic story I was very surprised that it would lack something so basic to story telling. At least that was my experience with the film.

title: What!
review: I looked forward to this film so much as it was so enjoyable as a child. However, I would like to find out who cast the children in the film because I thought all bar the little girl they were absolutely terrible. Everything about their acting was annoying and in places embarrassing. Does anyone share my views on this or is it just me. The oldest boy in it was by far the worst and I just felt like grabbing him from the screen and telling him to wake up. Very disappointed as I loved the book so much. I hope that something is done about this in the follow up films otherwise I think they might have a few less viewers. All that to one side the CGI was amazing and the well known actors like Ray Winston were extremely good.

title: A visual feast ruined by terrible acting
review:
Here's what I suggest, WAIT for the DVD to come out. No point spending money for this movie unless you have kids 14 and below who want to have some fun.

Visually the movie is fantastic, but then again, in this day and age you've come to expect that from every movie. It's not enough sorry to say. The kids acting are terrible. There is little that makes you want to keep watching or keeps you on the edge. The story moves along so fast with so little content that you lose all interest in it. It's simplistic, boring, terrible editing...and more.

If its Friday night and you have nothing else to do, go enjoy the graphics but other than that...its not something people above a certain age group will find enjoyable. If anyone tells you that fantasy and long books are supposed to be like this...tell them Lord of the Rings is what its supposed to be like..not this.

title: Nice for kids
review:
LOTR for kiddies. Most kids from about 6 to 15 will be able to associate with one of the characters, its a fairy tale for any adult who watches it. Dialogue is lame, the main characters are all overacted, which would be OK I guess for kids under 12 or so who may need it to follow the story.

While I know Tolkien and Lewis were friends, the stories are definitely aimed at different aged audiences and no Narnia film will IMPO ever match any of the LOTR.

I'll not watch the rest of the Narnia films, which I'm certain are in pre-production by now...

title: Child actors beware....
review:
I went to see this film a few days ago, and to be honest I was a little bit disappointed. The cinematography was amazing, and if you enjoyed Lord of the Rings style action then this film does deliver.

However, I am one of those people that think that the only good child actor to have existed is Macualay Caulkin in Home Alone, so I found it very hard to see beyond the 'hammy' acting of the Pevensie children.

The film was visually exciting, and thankfully stayed loyal to the book, it was just the little actors and actresses that ruined it for me. I mean how seriously can you take a very camp Peter, who's meant to be 'The Magnificent'...

title: Masterpiece!!
review:
What an experience!! One of the BEST fantasy films I've ever seen!! To sum up what I feel about it: Things I didn't really like (but didn't hinder my enjoyment of): Some of the CGI was just shoddy, and being made by WETA and for the money they spent, there's something amiss to that.*ponders* It was TOO SHORT!!! I felt like it needed At least another hour to finish what it started, and GAWD we could have used it considering how good it actually was. I mean I loved these characters and I wanted to get more out of them. What's worse is I feel they used the fact that it was so short to skimp on a few things, and that's just a shame. And I'm not necessarily talking about things straight from the book, I'm just talking about character development and interaction...because you could TELL these characters adored each other so much they just LONGED to have more time together.

The cinematography could have been better, and the editing could have been tighter.

Again these things didn't interfere with my love of the film, I just think these things could have made a really good movie--GREAT! One last gripe...there seemed to be an almost lackluster inattentiveness to detail, and that bothers me again since this comes from WETA...WETA can and HAS done better! And I think Disney was really pressing them for time, and that's a shame, because what they COULD squeeze in was MAGNIFICENT!! Things I bloody ADORED!!: Ummmm ALL OF IT??? REALLY, some of it was impossibly beautiful and had the potential to be...transcendent.

TUMNUS TUMNUS TUMNUS TUMNUS TUMNUS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Okies I could have withstood another 4 thousand hours of Tumnus FOREVER!! He was the GOD of Narnia (to me) and I can't speak my praises of him anymore. He was charming, haunting, charismatic, eerie, simple, complicated, angsty, sweet, humble, loving...so many other adjectives. He really is my favorite character, and to be honest I think he was better in the film than Lewis even wrote him.*adores* EDMUND!!!! GUH! He was everything I'd hoped, but perhaps not as nasty as in the books. He was truly a lonely and hurt little boy who just missed his Father very much, and children often misbehave when they are hurting. I think the film truly allowed us to extend great sympathy for his character and I think that's grand!! Jadis/Aslan-I'm putting them together because I think they both sort of blend together what Narnia is about. There was something more ancient and powerful and archetypal than even Lewis himself ever realized in their characters. I'm not discrediting that it's a Christian fairytale, that was made clear enough...But Christianity is based on older religions, and whether Lewis tried to or not, the truth and power of those ancient religions come through the strongest from these two characters. I loved Jadis's fire, as frozen-hearted as she was, her need to win went beyond desire...It was all that really mattered to her, because that was the way it was meant to be, and she could not escape herself. Aslan's sacrifice was the same. He couldn't escape that older innate truth anymore than Jadis could, and that truth is What must be MUST be. It's the oldest truth there is, and in the end it's the only one that really matters...The King/God/Savior MUST die, and there must be ONE to kill him. No matter the reason and no matter the myth, it is just the way the universe works, and Lewis just happened to understand this. That said Tilda was ASTOUNDING and she radiated her own kind of beauty, a cold and isolated loveliness that was truly magical, she was as tender as she was cruel, and as ruthless as she was apprehensive...It was a privilege just to see her act. Liam as Aslan was JUST as astounding and his voice just resonated wisdom, so much so that had Aslan spoken to me I could not help but respect him utterly, and he truly did look like REAL lion! The rest of the Penvesies: GUH these kids were so great! Peter was lacking for the first half of the film...but when Edmund fell, you could SEE the ferocity in his eyes, and THAT's what I wanted to see in Peter-wonderful! Susan was just a lovely lovely girl and had such a knowingness to her, plus she's pretty darn good with a bow and arrow! Lucy was Lucy, and that's a good thing, and she was such a pure spirit of all girlhood, and I felt like I was experiencing through her those feelings I had as a little girl, something I had desired to feel for such a long time.

The Ending...Awesome stuff!! The crowning was good, but Aslan leaving and that little "talk" between Lucy and Tumnus was BETTER!! Then the stag hunt with the four adult Penvesies was TO DIE FOR!! When I buy the DVD I'm going to have that on instant replay for weeks, it was just the most wondrous thing in creation. It wasn't even that they were beautiful and perfect, THEY WERE THEMSELVES!! I could totally believe they were those same four actors all grown up! I wanted that scene to last forever, and I didn't ever want them to go home.*worships Adult!Penvesies* To say the least I can totally and honestly admit that it was MORE than I'd ever hoped for, and that some of it was SOOOO right, that I could disregard most of it's failures. Bad CGI?? Who cares! It was the story Lewis wrote, and what else matters??? I truly feel I've been to Narnia and back!

title: Very good, sorta Oz but strongly religious in places.....
review:
.....you know, Aslan being brought back from the dead and all. Who would have thought a movie about a talking lion, beavers, rhinos, cheetahs, etc centaurs, satyrs, etc-would be so moving and involving? I never read the books, but respecting the writer CS Lewis very much, I more than wanted to give this a chance.

It's well worth your time. Sure there are Lord of the Rings type backgrounds and imagery, sure you have to suspend disbelief(talking beavers?), and you wanna swat the second boy a lot, but still-this works and works well.

Tilda Swinton as the White Queen was great, scary, believable. I liked all four of the kids, esp. the youngest-Lucy. Good jobs by them. You will enjoy the battle-harpy eagles dropping rocks, a bombing run anyone? and root for the good guys.

Weaknesses? Well--you don't get to know who is who all that well amongst the menagerie of animals; esp. the centaur, rhino, etc that show up towards the battle, the kids sorta accept their fates/roles quicker than you would imagine, and the ending sure seems odd. Tacked on, etc. They were inside Narnia literally for Years, then whap! back on the floor as they were at the start, mere minutes after they'd left.

But that's just carping. Best parts involve a thawing out waterfall, the big battle, and of course, Aslan's sacrifice.

***1/2 good stuff.

title: A magical film but.......
review: Filming a book is never easy because a director has no way of knowing what is in your mind's eye. Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings is hailed as a great piece of work because although he may have imagined it differently than from you or I he did managed to bring Middle Earth to life and you could believe it exists. So it was with some degree of expectation that the magical land of Narnia would also shine on the screen. Shine it does but not as wonderful as you may hope. The sets are fantastic, the CGI is god-smackingly good and the battle scene is superb. Where the film falls down are on the things you cannot quite your finger on. For starters, Narnia does not seem cold enough during the evil white winter, Tilda Swinton (as Jardis, the White Witch) doesn't seem evil enough , Aslan (although superbly CGI) doesn't seem majestic enough and the film does not seem magical enough if say compared to Harry Potter. The children actors are at times are a little wooden but do a good job. Regardless if you can get over the nit picking it is great film for kids and adults who know the story. Also it was the first film I have seen that added material to the book in a beneficial way without taking too many liberties. More of B+ than a A-. There is cartoon version made in '78 and I would recommend watching that as well if not just for the music which is so perfect for the story and a real shame that this film did not have that cracking soundtrack.

title: Spellbinding!
review: The Chronicles of Narnia has been on my "to read" list for years, but I've never quite got round to it. There was always something else to read first. So I went to the movie with no preconceptions and only a vague idea as to what the storyline was. Visually, the film is absolutely enchanting. From the lavish landscapes to the amazing fantasy creatures, it all works. The audience I was with was silently spellbound thru most of the picture. We were sitting in the back row and we didn't even see very many people getting up for restroom breaks! Storywise, things move right along (as you would expect in such a hefty novel translated to a single film) but it never feels rushed. The actors all do a superb job and casting Liam Neeson as the voice of Aslan was simply inspired. The only thing I would have done differently would be to have cast a different actress in the role of the Witch. Tilda Swinton does a creditable job and is suitably menacing when she needs to be - and she looks good in the combat sequences - but I think if an actress who was a bit more overtly feminine had been in the role, the aura of menace would have been enhanced. As it was, you know the Witch is up to no good from the first moment you lay eyes on her, and you wonder how Edmund could fall for her BS. But this is a minor quibble. Overall, an amazing movie that leaves you wanting the next installment. You have to hope that the production team returns more or less intact for the next one, they did such a good job here.

title: True to the book
review: PERFECT! wonderful film, impeccable casting, well-paced, and nearly flawless special effects. I am looking forward to all its sequels. Am planning to see it again in the theater. I was very pleased with the beavers; their personalities were funny and serious and homey. Little Lucy was a remarkable actress; she drew me into the film immediately. The Aslan was powerful but kind; the development of Peter into a real King made sense to me. The young actor seemed born to the role. The castles were gorgeous. Mr Tumnus the faun was exactly right. I noticed at several points that the movie theater was absolutely quiet, almost breathless. All the chase scenes were cliff-hangers and had me clutching my date's hand till I noticed my fingers aching. (His too probably.) I missed a couple of great scenes that had been in the trailer -- hopefully they'll be in the DVD. The children and animals were taken seriously, a refreshing change from the sitcom silliness of most children/animal movies these days. Highly recommended.

title: Excellent Book Adaptation!
review: The acting is top notch, most notably Tilda Swinton as the White Witch and all the Pevensie children are brilliantly casted. The effects are some of the best I have ever seen, I was skeptical at first at the idea of a world of walking, talking animals coming to screen, but Adamson knocked the vision out of the ball park. The story of this movie reflects Lewis's tale so well I would have to say that it is one of the best book adaptations that I have ever seen. But not only does it stay true Lewis, it exceeds some of his descriptions! A two page battle sequence in the novel turns into a beautiful 25 minute action experience. If you are atheist, Christian, catholic, whatever, this is a must see film. The story is simply stupendous regardless of age, race, or religion. Although some people are calling it Lord of the Rings Jr., it never felt like a kids movie. It is a story about four children and their adventures through a mystical land, that is age appropriate from anyone from 8-108! Big ups to Disney, Walden, Adamson, and of course CS Lewis, go see this film!

title: O.K. for my 6 year old
review: I have read other peoples comments and I did not read the story as a child, however I did see the animated t.v. movie as a child and was excited to see if this live version, with the C.G.I. would be all that I remembered. Well, it was! There were times you could actually see that the actors were in front of a C.G.I. background, but then again Narnia only exsists in the imagination. I was very pleased to see that the movie followed the story pretty much scene for scene. I was especially excited to see if they would complete the story with the Kings and Queens chasing the white stag (like in the t.v. movie) and returning to their world. It was all there! Just like I remembered. The actors were brilliant! My six year old went and he was a little scared when Aslan went to the White Witch but he was fine with the battle scenes. Go see this film!

title: A Magnificent Piece of Cinema
review: I was so worried that this film would disappoint after all the hype surrounding it but I really was mistaken in my fears. A combination of solid acting, superb graphics and a classic story came together perfectly to provide what I believe to be the film of the year. There was no attempt to avoid the comedic value of the story which only added to the enjoyment factor but the fear was present as well. The acting was sensational on certain parts and the big names were not a disappointment- Dawn French particularly was superb. There is always a worry with child actors that they will fail to draw you into the story after their years of trained acting but this was not the case. There is no doubt that there is a hint of 'Lord of the Rings' throughout the film, despite the Director's protests, but the two original stories come from such similar backgrounds and genres this comparison is inevitable. Truly a film for all the family- adventure, comedy, romance, deceit, love and friendship all in one film.

title: Go see it...
review:
Just go. Now. Stop reading and GO!!!!

OK fine. Listen, I have had this vision of what the story should be. Call me evil, but I think CS Lewis wrote a great children's version of a much larger tale.

And this movie was it.

Virtually everything I've imagined from the story was in this movie. The warrior Centaurs. Peter a strong young man needing to find that strength. Father Christmas as anything but Jolly Ol' Saint Nick.

This movie was absolutely brilliant in every respect

.....alright fine. In a couple of places the computer animation could have been better. BUT THAT WAS IT!!!

title: Disappointing.
review:
I was hoping for really good things from this movie, but it left me feeling somewhat disappointed.

All the ingredients are there to produce a really good film, a good book, stunning scenery and ILM on special effects duty ...but, the screenplay is a little bland, as are the performances of the children. The director has failed to make them sparkle in their roles, just as he failed to excite with his inconsistent pacing through the movie. There seemed to be a lack of excitement throughout, with scenes building and then not moving to the next level to really excite the audience.

It made me jump in a few places (hence the PG rating) and there are good things in this film, Aslan looks terrific, costumes and locations are wonderful but ultimately I found it all uninspiring.

It should have provoked some real emotion within me, but didn't (the book did!) They need to tighten things up if the remaining stories are to be turned into great movies.

title: Review from someone who hasn't read the books
review: I didn't have any expectations regarding this movie but still it managed to disappoint me. The special effects are fantastic and are sadly the best part of the movie. Aslan looks amazing! My main problem was that the movie wastes a lot of time in some scenes like the War in London, Pevensies taking the train, going to the new home, Lucy meeting Tumnus... The Witch is far from being scary and her castle or evil deeds are unimpressive. The Beavers look great and are believable. Aslan is great. The rest of the characters in the movie are given ZERO depth. Are we supposed to feel sorry when they die in the war? I didn't even remember their names. There is little if any character depth in this movie... even the Pevensies. Geographically the movie gives us little or no indications as to where the characters are or where they are going. People just show up like it's a 20 minute ride. In the frozen lake bit the kids are half way through but they manage to outrun a sled in a couple of minutes. Suddenly there is some ancient prophecy that we don't know and now the kid has to die. Then there is a war and the kids know how to fight and to lead a medieval style battle. Everyone who read the book will probably hate my comment but this is MY OPINION. I didn't read the books and honestly I don't have any intention on doing so. If you want to give something for your kids to read get some Enid Blyton. There are no mythological creatures but the adventures are far more interesting.

title: Excellent Realization
review:
I read the Chronicles of Narnia when I was little and remember distinctly being very moved by the story, in particular when Azlan's story unfolded. So many years later, the movie that I created in my head has come to the screen in all its glory.

Thanks to the visual effects of WETA and excellent acting by the young cast, Narnia lives if only on screen. Little time is wasted getting the audience into the story and once the action starts, it doesn't stop. It's difficult to tell where the effects start and stop which is what contributes to its believability.

This is fantasy of the highest order, suitable for children of all ages - including the older ones like myself. It's not often that the audience breaks into appplause at the end of a movie but that was the case here, and it's well deserved. You are cheating yourself if you wait for the inevitable DVD: this one is truly majestic on the silver screen, and should be seen that way.

title: A Visual Feast... Mesmerizing
review:
Having not read any of C.S. Lewis's fantasy novels, I was wondering what sort of magical world I would be entering upon viewing The Chronicles of Narnia, The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe. Like the world of Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings, Narnia is a fantastical place, where animals speak, centaurs and satyrs roam the lands but is divided by good and evil. Four London children escape the wrath of World War II and go to live in the countryside estate of an eccentric professor (Jim Broadbent). There, while playing hide and seek, they find a wardrobe chest that leads to the snowy land of Narnia. The evil ice queen (Tilda Swinton) has a hold on the land of Narnia and turns anything and anyone into stone that tries to up rise against her. The land is a never ending white Winter. The children join forces with the creatures of Narnia, led by the leader of the pack, the lion Aslan, to defeat the evil White Witch and her quest for ruling the land.

The Chronicles of Narnia is a visually impressive feat of Winter Wonderlands, Ice Castles, talking animals, mystical creatures, and a battle between good and evil but one of the most magical effects is that of Lucy, the youngest of the four children, who first enters the land of Narnia. Emotion as such cannot be created by any CGI. Disney's reported $150 million gamble hits the right notes for a successful franchise from the 55-year old book. To some, the story could be an allegory of the story of Christ but I didn't find that the film was arching for too many Christian themes. There are some bloodless, but violent scenes but as most children stories go, good always overthrows evil. Not only will children be thrilled by The Chronicles... adults, too, will be mesmerized.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
review: Everyone was looking forward to a big screen adaptation of the classic children's book by C.S. Lewis, and director Andrew Adamson (Shrek) has done a good job making that happen. Basically the four Pevensie children, Lucy (Georgie Henley), Edmund (Skandar Keynes), Peter (William Moseley) and Susan Pevensie (Anna Popplewell), are evacuated to the country after war has broken out, staying with Professor Kirke (Jim Broadbent). One day, when playing a game of hide and seek, Susan hides in a large wardrobe of an empty room, and goes through a magical porthole leading to the land of Narnia, where she meets faun Mr. Tumnus (James McAvoy). She quickly returns when he warns her of the evil White Witch (Tilda Swinton), and next to enter the land through the wardrobe is Edmund, who meets the witch, calling herself the Queen, and she wants to meet the other children too. Soon enough, all four children are in Narnia, and it is only when Edmund is kidnapped he knows the "Queen" is evil, and it is up to Susan, Peter and Lucy to find him and get him back. When they are all brought back together, Mr. and Mrs. Beaver (Ray Winstone and Dawn French) take them to the true king of Narnia, Aslan (Liam Neeson) the lion, who ends the winter, and tells them of the prophecy they are part of. Now they are set to go into battle with the Witch's army, with all the other good guys, to bring peace and harmony to the land, and become the new leaders. Also starring Rupert Everett as Fox and Michael Madsen as Maugrim the white wolf. The performances, especially by the nasty Swinton and the majestic Neeson, are good, the special effects are well done, and the action is as good as you'd expect, it may not be amazingly good, but it a great family fantasy adventure. Filled with marvellous effects and made in Britain, this is a very good adventure story. It won the Oscar for Best Makeup, and it was nominated for Best Sound Mixing and Best Visual Effects, it won the BAFTA for Best Make Up/Hair, and it was nominated for Best Special Visual Effects and Best Costume Design, and it was nominated the Golden Globes for Best Original Score and Best Song for "Wunderkind". Good!

title: this movie sucked!! here are a few reasons
review:
• bad casting. how can those children be anymore annoying? - bad special effects. although the lion looks good, often you see the actors stand before a blue screen. it's just too obvious.


  • bad screenplay. "sons of Adam, daughters of Eve" cut the Christ iancrap!


  • big part of the movie is one of the boys being a traitor. he isn't! he's just walked into a fairytale world, what does he know?!


  • And what the ^%&$ was Santa doing in this movie?! "here have some weapons!" damn


I HOPE THERE'LL BE NO SEQUEL Thank you...

title: I Just don't know
review:
What was his movie about?? *semi-spilorers ahead* so abunch of kids are in a house after being orphaned. they are with this old man thats just really happy all the time. They talk about believing your family all the time no matter what they say (which I think is a terrible message I don't trust 95% of the people i know family or otherwise.. lotsa bad people out there.) Anyway then they go upstairs and fall through a closet into "narnia". Once there a guy gets frozen and killed but then magically comes back to life later on. No one seems to really ever fight. Talking beavers.. I couldn't make out what they were saying but it didn't make any sense. They ran to abunch of other animals and eventually for some reason the oldest is made king and each kid comes ridiculously close to dying (with zoom ups of each kids face during each instance) but coming out alive in the end.

At the end they fall out of the closet and the old man pops in (which to me clearly speaks of drug use)smiling and says something like " I KNOW " ..and smiles.

Half way through the film some old fat man said something like "it will end" and I just thought I hope this "movie" will end.

title: A big disappointment!
review: This movie really disappointed me! I have never read the books and did not see the television series as a child. So I watched this film with an open mind, not really knowing what to expect, just that it was a children's movie, and in the adventure/fantasy genre. For me the movie had really bad special effects, the creatures were OK, but the blue screen scenes are really, really bad, and some of them are used in very unnecessary places. The story does not manage to introduce the land of Narnia properly, and the white witch is just a one-dimensional villain, lacking depths and motives. So the story stumbles along, showing us mythical creatures by the numbers, not knowing why some of them are good or bad, not letting us know how anything came to be. The climax of the film is over before it has begun, and I found myself wanting the witch to win, cause everything was so tacky and annoying. I understand that the concept was kept simple, because it's mainly for children. However, the great movies for children, manages to work on more than one level, making it entertaining for people of all ages, because it has a heart and a soul. This movie is missing both.

title: just boring
review:
Well Disney exactly knew which scenes they had to show in the previews; the mouth-watering final battle to allure those people who did not read the books. But one after another:

My girlfriend and me went to cinema to watch this movie, at the end she did enjoy it and I was bored to death. Here are some reasons why this film was...unconvincing...for me:

The characters weren't worked out properly, they remain flat until the end, so it was hard to feel with them. Same with the story; if you haven't read the books some questions are intruding; why is Peter able to fight like a maniac in the final battle when he killed a single wolf just by luck a couple of scenes ago ? Why are the humans so important for Narnia ? What does the professor give to the kids at the end ?

The CGI were nice sometimes to look at ( panning shots ), but most of the time they remained at B-Movie -level. ( Read some other comments because of that )

The famous final battle was very disappointing. It was neither coordinated nor thrilling, I thought "Well, at least It'll be over soon". Battle characters and animals weren't introduced, they hopped around thats it. What about the Minotaurs for example ? And didn't I saw the scene with the sword-pointing Minotaur on the rock somewhere else ? ( Yes I remember, Battle of Helms Deep in LotR II, change the minotaur with the orkchief )

Its a miracle how they keep characters shallow because shortage of time and make you feel like it never will end, I constantly watched my clock in desperate mood.

No no, shame at you Disney. It is possible, look at LotR! But that requires more than a couple of CGI's and well done advertising. Maybe good for kids but boring else.

Rent the DVD at your video shop if you are a fan of the books, don't waste money for the ticket.

title: BORING
review:
Characters - The child actors are pretty bad. The characters are poorly written, and most of them are really dumb.

Plot - This story could have been entertaining, but its way too long and boring. The story focuses on everything that is dumb and boring and glosses over any elements that could've been entertaining.

Sights and Sounds - This movie had no continuity department. Some of the effects are good, but the overall look of this movie is pretty bad. I thought that this movie was made years before the actual date due to the poor quality.

Overall, this movie is very boring and I wouldn't recommend it.

title: Beautiful, but far from classic.
review:
I must admit, from the first shot that took you up into the cockpit of the German Bombers over the London rooftops, I had high hopes for the this film. Beautiful opening, I thought, emotional, and set up the relationships between the characters quite well while maintaining good pacing. Unfortunately, as the film continued, it started to drag in its attempt to fit all the characters and the plot elements into what turned out to be at times a tedious experience.

Admittedly, this is well crafted film, and it's meticulous workmanship can be seen in every shot and transition. The actors and CG characters all do a wonderful job of maintaining the fantasy that is Narnia. You won't be seeing any swaying cardboard cutouts and badly rendered crowd effects in this film. But perhaps I have been spoiled by the likes of Peter Jackson and even Chris Nolan with his recent take on the Batman franchise, but this version in all its loyalty to the work of C.S. Lewis somehow missed an element of magic which comes from a directors authorship.

In other words, this is not an enduring creative masterpiece, but rather palatable adaptation An adult vision of a children's story. It never creates that distinction between Narnia and the real world, and by creating a Narnia that is as believable as that London Flat, it actually took away some of the wonder that could have made this film as enduring as the original work by C.S. Lewis. The director did not choose to show this world as it would have appeared in the eyes of a child. . .the over bearing whiteness of winter snow in contrast to a damp musty country estate, the incredible and unbending evil of the manipulative white witch that distorts her beautiful features to one of animal like menace.

Remember how in the Wizard of Oz, Dorothy's world suddenly went from black and white to technicolor in the turn of a tornado. Ah. . .there's the authorship that transitions a classic work of literature into a classic film. So in the way that every shot was predictably framed, in the same way that every cut was just the right length, and every costume just as it would have been in C.S. Lewis's world, it became a technical affair which for someone like me who already knows the plot quite well became. . .well. . . boring.

But then again. . .this is a well made film. Few would call it a blasphemy of the original version laid on paper and not celluloid. But this version is like a well made suit. Beautiful, but a suit never the less. Perhaps I went the the theater seeking not a suit, but rather, a pair of wings. . . not quite proper dress etiquette but that's what makes it magical.

title: Good for kids under the age of 12 , bad for everyone else.....
review:
This Movie , i must say was a huuuge letdown...

First of all any movie can have great special effects and scenery now a days , so we start judging the movies on the different aspects instead , like acting. The acting in this movie was very poorly done , the four kids were understandably inexperienced to be in such a movie , but then the casting director should have done a better job at trying to find the right set of kids to act in it... The dialogs between the kids , were as annoying as nails to a chalkboard.

The only character i enjoyed watching was aslan himself , but since aslan was made up of special effects , he had no mistakes to make... Another thing which annoyed me was that in a scene u could clearly see that peters sword , was bending to the wind...O.o

All in all this movie was a huuge letdown , i expected more from the director and the crew to at least get better actors , and better directing... but i guess they made this movie for the money rather then for the story....

title: Like Lord of the Rings without the good parts.
review:
'I don't want to fight, I want to go home.' 'Okay, let me just take you to see the talking lion.' *Five minutes later* 'I AM WILLING TO COMMAND AN ARMY FOR THIS STRANGE LAND WHICH I ONLY DISCOVERED AN HOUR AGO!'

The child actors were appalling, and it was clear this movie was only made for the lord-of-the- rings-imitation battle scene. The entire plot was skimmed over at lightning speed, made even worse by the unbelievably bad acting of the children (who were also repulsively ugly). Ugh... I've already wasted my time watching this time, I can't bear to waste any more on this review. All I can say is, avoid this movie. Go and watch Lord of the rings instead, because that's all this movie is: a miserable failed attempt to copy the success of lord of the rings.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia: My View
review:
My analysis is solely based on the movie and NOT on the books!!

I have four major qualms with this movie: a) the simplistic way in which four main human struggles are presented b) the simplistic/inaccurate way in which human tendencies are presented c) overall fake way the movie is filmed in general d) the simplicity of its conclusion

a) While watching this movie, four main human struggles were presented (though feebly): i. old vs. young- The classic struggle of young children versus the mean, old guardian-like figure seems to creeps its way into the film. It seems as though there are two sub-groups of old vs. age presented in this film, one being the children against the new, old guardians (the "professor" and the "housekeeper") and one internal struggle between the eldest children versus the youngest. The mean, old "housekeeper" is in part the reason that all four children discover the secrets in the wardrobe, for they fear that they will be chastised for breaking a window. The film also presents the struggle between the eldest children and the younger ones for they do not believe they have found a magical land in the back of a wardrobe. ii. woman vs. man- The film presents an aspect of women versus men. For example, the youngest child is a girl while the eldest is a boy, and it seems as though they find it difficult trying to identify with each other. Also, the lion is presented as a man and the evil witch is obviously a woman. iii. good vs. evil- Obviously the film is all about good vs. evil, and of course is solved by a wonderfully happy ending. (the bad witch vs. the good lion) iv) brother vs. brother- Another struggle simplistically represented in the film, the competition between an older, wiser, more handsome brother versus a younger, less wise, less handsome brother who is driven to betrayal. The movie tries to present the difficulties two brothers have with internal, family competition and is of course solved at the end of the film. *All aspects are seemingly solved at the end.

b) There are three human tendencies seemingly represented throughout the film: i. females are always compassionate, sympathetic- Three scenes seem to represent this aspect best: the two sisters watching the execution of the lion, the witch killing the lion, and the sisters weeping over the lion's dead body. As the witch is about to kill the lion, it almost seems as if there is a tear in her eye, for girls should be compassionate (of course!) and not evil. The sisters cry as the lion is being executed also signifying the fact that females tend to be tender and sympathetic. The scene in which the sisters stay next to the dead lion as the two brothers prepare for battle also signifies the aspect that females should always be tender (weak?). ii. females can be conniving- The witch is presented as a seemingly nice 'ruler of Narnia' when the youngest brother meets her. Then, of course, the witch is found to be conniving and truly evil. This almost seems to convey the notion that females can be outwardly kind but can become vicious, conniving individuals. iii. men are always ready to fight- The scene in which the sisters are crying as the men are fighting also represents the aspect that men are always prepared to fight. This simplistic realization is sometimes downplayed by the individual acts of the youngest girl. She seems to be presented as a brave, young, daring girl when she persists on saying that they must fight the war that they caused.

c) I found the filming utterly unbelievable. The battle scenes were very much like the ones seen in Lord of the Rings, and it seems that the director spared no expense in making them. Yet, there are individual scenes in which you can tell that the children do not see animals. Perhaps its due to bad acting, but it sometimes seemed that the animals were not there (obviously they are not).

d) The conclusion seems to bring every struggle to a sickening, unbelievable, simplistic conclusion. The children are all crowned "Kings and Queens of Narnia" bringing the whole aspect of old vs. young to a close since the old lion will no longer rule Narnia. Also, as the children roll out of the wardrobe, the professor asks where they have been and the children do not respond for fear that he won't believe them. Yet, the professor surprisingly says to "try me" (me- meaning him) perhaps settling the issue between the whimsical, young children versus the old, wise professor. The conclusion also seems to solve the whole issue of women versus men in that each child is crowned (not only the men), the witch is no longer living (for she is killed by the lion), and the fact that the brothers now accept the youngest, female child's whimsical story. The death of the witch, the 'resurrection' of the lion, and the crowning of the children all signify that good has beaten evil. Of course the two brothers are now pals as they each equally rule over Narnia, and the brother versus brother competition seems to be over. The film's simplistic representation of the basic human struggles, tendencies and its overall fake/copy-cat-like filming undermines the overall message. The movie almost belittles humans and signifies the fact that humans will inevitably have war. The beginning of the movie presents four young children trying to escape a war, but in the end they are each faced with a different, magical war. They become passionate about the cause, and it seems as though the movie presents the fact that humans will fight for a cause they feel deeply about. Maybe I am just an idealist, but I don't think that way. Perhaps this movie is only to be considered children's entertainment.

title: Beautiful to look at, but not great
review:
First off, a little background: I am an avid reader, lover of good stories and films (classic and new). I adore the LotR books and films, and I love the HP books and the last two HP films. Therefore, I came into Narnia really hoping to love it, predisposed to love it. Boy, was I disappointed!

Spoilers>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

I haven't read the Narnia books. All I know of them is that they are supposedly Christian metaphor. Though I am an atheist, I adored LotR, which comes from a similar background. My mother, a devout Christian, watched Narnia with me.

The film is beautiful to look at, with amazing winter settings, and wonderfully rendered characters. Aslan is magnificent. In addition to being visually stunning, the cast is great. James McAvoy is a darling Tumnus, Ray Winstone is a hilarious Beaver, Tilda is a ferocious witch, and Liam Neeson is regal as Aslan. Of the children, only Lucy and Edmund were truly interesting (the other two weren't explored enough- I mean, Peter is supposed to be this compelling King in the Making, but the film never justifies this). Narnia looks like a perfectly real world, and it would be easy to lose yourself in it if it weren't for the plot clichés.

Now the bad: As previously stated, the other two children weren't really explored. Susan's only purpose in life is to stand beside her more interesting siblings. Peter is destined for greatness, but all he really does is rally the armies to battle (though I will admit he had a great moment with the witch at the end). Lucy is a lovely picture of faith and love. These three children have only a little depth: they do not want to do battle, but they are unquestionably good. The only truly interesting one is Edmund, who betrays his family because of his inferiority complex. Since I haven't read the books, I don't know if this lack of depth is due to the source material or the director. One of the complaints that Christian groups have against Harry Potter is that he is a rule breaker and occasional liar with questionable ethics; this is precisely what makes him interesting- his faults!! Every great literary character- from Scarlett O'Hara to Bruce Wayne- is flawed, but these children (Edmund excepted) are perfect.

People in Narnia keep dying left and right, but getting magically resurrected. Now, being a fantasy fan, I am used to magical resurrections, usually involving a very powerful magical character, like Gandalf, Voldemort, even Buffy (twice, no less). Therefore, it is easy to accept Aslan's return, but it is really tedious when EVERYONE is resurrected. Only bad guys stay dead. If there is no death, then there is no peril, and therefore there is no drama.

Finally, the film moves very quickly from one thing to the next. One second, the children are discovering the magic of talking beavers, the next second, they are throwing themselves off a cliff to escape the witch while struggling with a prophecy that declares them to be royalty. Narnia is great and it is beautiful, full of interesting characters- why don't we linger with them for a little while. When the big battle (which is not really big) begins, we cheer the good guys because that is what we're supposed to do, but we really don't care about them. We love the children because we've followed them, but can we really say we care about anyone in their army? In LotR, we cared about secondary characters, like Theoden or Treebeard, because we were allowed time to grow to care for them. In essence, this film's greatest problem was its brevity. ain't it cool news (website) said it best: that extra hour is the difference between a film like this and a film like LotR.

Was the film awful? No. Is is preachy? Almost annoyingly so; my mother hated it (and she's a Christian). I would take young children to see it, but I would not pay to see again myself. If it's adventure you want, hop over to King Kong, or better yet, watch Harry Potter before it leaves theaters.

title: Disappointed in Narnia
review:
I really enjoyed the first half an hour of this movie! I enjoyed the portrayal of Lucy and Mr. Tumnus. But overall I rather disappointed in the movie.

I agree that it was probably difficult to adapt a screenplay from the book, however, I did not think that changing around events and adding scenes was necessary or respectful to the readers of the book. I think the changes unnecessarily changed the movie into a less intelligent film. If nothing else they could have used some narration in this book. Perhaps they could've even begun with the children falling out of the wardrobe and narrating the story to the professor.

Was it really necessary to make the chase more dramatic in the fact that the witch appeared to be right on their heels rather than a few hours behind as in the book? Would it have been difficult to show the changes that the being in Narnia had on the children, couldn't they have somehow appeared stronger, braver, and more skilled. Rather than them literally stating that they are going to "practice" and making it appear that a few hours of "practice" could make them skilled defenders?

Could the witch have just acted out her disbelief at Aslan's return rather than her stony faced statement "impossible!" I missed the scene where Aslan is so delighted to be reborn that he throws the children in the air. I think Aslan throws someone up in the air in every book! It would've been nice to see this dimension of Aslan as well.

I hope that at some point in the future another producer gives this book a better life on the screen.

title: This movie SUCKS !!!
review:
This movie SUCKS ! One of the worst movies I've seen this year, right after F4.

The kid actors are just horrible, the acting on all parts in this movie is crap actually.

Had some very nice CGI, but you can't build a movie on that + I found it boring as hell.

King Kong is WAAAAY better than this sugar sweat, cheesy, Hollywood propaganda crap. I feel like I've been tricked, the trailer does not make the movie justice. If you've seen the trailer, leave it that way, cause it's much better than the whole movie itself.

4 of 10, and I'm being generous...

title: Very Disappointing
review: This movie was nothing like the books. They are a great series, and unfortunately this movie did not do the story justice. The acting was pretty bad, the kids were adorable..but adorable does not equal good acting. Also, they attempted to make it a little too kid friendly, while the books have a more grow up feel about them. I'm guessing their budget was also much smaller than LoTR, since the special effects were nothing special...LoTR was upsetting only in the fact that they doctored the ending to give Liv Tyler a bigger part, however the rest of the plot was just like the books, and the director did an amazing job of making a fantasy movie that felt real. Unfortunately, Narnia did nothing of the sort, and like I previously stated, the actors did not make you feel anything really. The Witch looked at best bored and in need of some makeup, the kids kind of like they were along for a joy ride instead of in a real war and the CGs were poor. Overall it was very disappointing..the best part being the Pirates of the Caribbean 2 trailer.

title: The Chronicles of Money-a: Jesus, Lilith and the drobe full of War
review:
It isn't so much what the Narnia says that is disturbing as the things that it is really saying and how that bodes for sequels and other popular entertainments.

One of the first lessons learned by one of the Pevensie children is that it's okay to go home with strangers. Especially if they offer you tea. If they offer you tea then you are just ill-mannered if you don't come home with them. Mr. Tumnus has been cast much younger than in the book, and the film is chock full of very weird close up shots of peoples' faces as they change expression. This combined with the borderline coquettish way the little girl playing Lucy has been directed to act, the lulling of her to sleep and the anguished "I'm kidnapping you," made this scene more harrowing than anything in the recent crazy-guy-with-child-in-peril film "Keane." Is it really possible that people don't see how freaking creepy this sequence is? Another lesson: if you have an imagination you are a sissy boy-liar-traitor and probably have dark hair. You will betray your own family to their deaths.

Another lesson: Women should shut the heck up when a man (especially one with blonde hair and blue eyes) is making a decision. They keep telling Susan not to be so smart and she keeps shrewing it up with the wrong decisions, countermanding and undermining her man/brother (did I mention that's creepy too) at the worst possible times with the worst possible decisions. When will she ever learn? As I hear there is more punishment in store for women who think they want to have ideas, or be unashamed of their strength and (gasp) sexuality. Stay tuned! And if you are a strong woman, then you are heartless, asexual andwell, ultimate evil really. Why not end it all now and save Aslan the trouble of biting your head off? Thank any lion god that in movies it doesn't matter how cool you make the good guys: evil is always cooler. Tilda Swinton walks away with it to the point where there should soon be an epidemic of cross-dressing elementary school boys trying to be as tough as she is.

Another lesson: Christmas is all about presents and has bugger-all to do with Christ. As a moonbat I can't really argue with this lesson.

Know ye this: Lion Christ was shaved for our sins. Yea, upon his haunches he sat, taunted by Jew and Orc alike. Verily would he have been smote and struck from the book of life by the evil Smart Woman, save that Lion Christ knew the secret to tricking her: women can't read! Huzzah! With this gnosis he laid his fuzzy head upon the pagan altar bearing the very instructions of how he would rise again on the morrow. O for a muse of fur!

'Tis a rare film where the talking beavers are more realistic than the humans. Oh, and the new age music is simply awful.

Is this really what you want your children to be learning?

title: Yawn...
review:
The lion the witch and the wardrobe is in my opinion, one of the worst of the seven books in the narnia series, but still a great book overall. However, I cant help but disagree completely with the length of this movie. If I recall correctly, the book was barely a novel, weighing in at a minimal 100 pages or so. Strech those 100 pages out into a two hour movie with unbelievably horrible green screens and blatant groan-able analogies, and any movie would end up with a less than 5 rating from me. Two hours! really! I'm not joking! Where did they get all that extra footage? Well, mostly views of the countryside, and long close-ups of the actors faces.

Almost every scene and character in this movie was ripped straight from the Bible, or from Lord of the Rings, and it shows. Names have been changed to protect the innocent (in most cases).

The Santa Claus scene was the worst. Why is Santa Claus in narnia? isn't it kind of another world? I think presents could have come from somewhere else just as easily, and that passage could have stayed on paper and out of the movie theater...

In defense of the movie, I understand completely that this was a movie based on a very Christian children's book and the analogies were meant to be understood by children, however, a little more subtlety could have made an okay movie into a decent movie in my opinion.

The Santa Claus scene was the worst. Why is Santa Claus in narnia? isn't it kind of another world? I think presents could have come from somewhere else just as easily, and that passage could have stayed on paper and out of the movie theater...

Even though I didn't care for this movie that much, if you haven't seen this movie yet, I do suggest watching it, because the later books in the series are much better and will make much better movies... and it would be a shame to have missed the first one.

title: Falls short of a better film, but good
review: A decent film, 'The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe' is at times captivating, but, it falls short of delivering a better film. I haven't read the book since I was about 10, and I saw the cartoon on television -which I really enjoyed- before that. However, this review is not to look at the film adaption of the book and to say what was done wrong and what was removed; it's been too long ago for me to really remember the story to go into that detail! I am rating this as a film. Design, pacing, and acting and the three main areas that I'll cover in this review; each had varying levels of success. Although some of the film design was done very well, I did have some problem with some of the CGI and realism. Some of the design was done exceptionally well, and some of it wasn't. For example, the scenes of the children crossing the river, the lion, and the creatures turning to (or from) stone were quite well done, but I had some problems with the CGI beavers and some of the other critters. The beavers did not look realistic, but it looked as if they were made to be realistic without facial expressions (or limited expressions). The lion was done well, and CGI in other films is also done well, but it seemed to me as if the beaver got the short end of the stick (no pun intended) when it came to CGI. The battle scenes also involved some less-than stunning CGI compared to what I've seen in other films. Costume design and set design was generally very good from the castle to the beaver's home. There were some very good shots; in particular, the shot of the curtain falling down from the wardrobe while Lucy pulls on it is very good. The film did have some trouble with brining the camera into the scene; it seemed difficult to really get involved in the film in some places because the characters seemed distant while better camera use could have brought the audience more into the story instead of making them feel like outsiders. Pacing was another unfortunate drawback of the film. There was often a sense that some events were slow while the action scenes got less time. Not related to pacing, but I did notice consistency issues. Lucy provides one of the characters with a hankerhief, which is later retrived from another character and then by the same character at the end of the film. In principle, the character who presented this at the end should not have had the item anymore. Acting was done well throughout except for a couple of instances involving CGI, including the character who becomes alive again after being turned to stone. Overall, it's a good film for children, and it reminded me of Disney's older children's films. It also reminded me of Lemony Snicket -- I guess it goes to show that children enjoy films where children are in unfortunate circumstances and become the heroes. I hope more films like this continue to get made. It's certainly not a perfect film, but it is not too bad. I give it a 6/10.

title: Fun film amazing design, let down by some truly horrible special effects.
review: Just got back from seeing this film and I have to say, overall, I enjoyed it. Some of the imagery was exactly as I imagined it when I read the books, the White Witch and her castle, Mr. Tumnis and the Beavers. It's a very well made film, not sure if Andrew Adamson should direct real people, but this was his first time, so we'll see what he does in the future. As for the design, Weta has again created amazing creatures, armor and weapons and some of the effects are beautiful, such as the Beavers, but, some of the effects are appalling. The wolves, seen better animals on the PS2, Aslan, the one creature who should have been top notch, so-so, no life, no character, too much facial animation...real lions don't have that kind of muscle structure. Next time, go to Weta, ILM just can't cut it anymore. Anyway, no more complaining, fun movie, take the kids. they will love it.

title: Mediocre children's film
review:
Let's get one thing straight - this is not the next Lord Of The Rings. That trilogy set the bar so high for fantasy films that it would take something pretty amazing to even equal it. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe is not that film.

Amazing (but sometimes a bit wonky) effects sequences, wonderfully animated talking creatures, beautiful sweeping New Zealand scenery and odd flashes of humour can't stop this being very clearly an old school children's' film with a simplistic story, cheesy bits (like the appearance of Father Christmas to hand out the 'magic weapons') and two-dimensional characters.

It also doesn't help that the four central child actors are very annoying - lacking the charisma, talent or maturity of, say, the stars of the Harry Potter series.

Thankfully the Christian subtext is subtle and Liam Neeson turns in a warm vocal performance as Aslan, but it's the CGI Beavers and wolves that will really stick in the mind. A mild distraction, Narnia is a pleasant piece of gore-free fluff that will - eventually - become a Saturday afternoon television staple to distract the wee kiddies from their Playstations once ITV's copy of the Railway Children has worn out.

title: Peter Jackson watch your back
review:
Straight away i've compared this film to Lord of the Rings which to be honest i probably shouldn't have done but there is no doubt about it that there are so many similarities between The Lion, the Witch and the wardrobe and Peter Jackson's Masterpiece trilogy that it would have been acknowledged eventually. A war raging in a world of magic and good vs evil that is inspired by a timeless novel, and filmed in New Zealand by a native director. It's too obvious for anyone not to compare. However, The Chronicles of Narnia should be given its own space in the world of cinema that will allow it to stand up against such a huge movie franchise such as Lord of the Rings because, put quite simply, its the most enchanting motion picture in years.

The story follows four siblings in their journey through a magical wardrobe and into the world of Narnia. Whilst there they learn of their destiny to lead an army against the evil White Witch who has kept Narnia in an endless Winter for 100 years. With guidance from the Lion messiah, Aslan, the four young heroes must find the strength to overcome the odds in the great battle of good vs evil.

Director Andrew Adamson has had great cinema success with his beloved Dreamworks creation of Shrek. But, this being first time behind a feature film, and a really big one at that, he had his work cut out for him immensely. Luckily he was clearly up for the challenge because with this spellbinding family epic Andrew Adamson has done the job perfectly. He made it so much better than i imagined it would be and the film genuinely has something for absolutely everybody's taste. As far as i'm concerned Adamson has himself a really good chance at an Academy Award because he has truly met the standard head on.

Visually, the film matches that of Harry Potter and all the special effect are so stunning and realistic that it will draw you into the magic even more.

The performances are excellent form the four leading youngsters and Tilda Swinton shows her evil side as the White Witch that could easily be her best spell yet. James McAvoy plays Mr. Tumnus with great emotion and captures the character on stunning form (I specifically felt a need to mention him because i think he's a brilliant actor and i'm an ever growing fan).

Its obvious that they would have had to cut some of it out from the original portrayal in the novel for various reasons. They kept the runtime to 2hrs 20mins and i, for one, am beyond impressed, nothing important was missed and everything was explained better than previous adaptations that i have seen of the novel. It was also good to see a film that didn't seem to last half as long as it did and that you didn't want to finish, the time went by quickly and i loved every single moment.

If you have any doubts about seeing this film for any reason, don't. Its a film for everybody that will capture and hold you until the very end.

From the beloved masterpiece by C.S Lewis another form of masterpiece has been created on the big screen, it is a must see and that is a fact that i must insist you pay attention to.

I know for a fact that Walden Media has optioned all seven of the Narnia books for film development and i really do hope that they make the rest of them because if they are half as good as this on screen then we will have a masterful saga.

If you really want to see a film thats worth yours family's money make it 'The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the wardrobe'. You will not be disappointed.

title: boring
review: This movie was pure garbage, a pure waste of money to go and see this film, a pure, utter, bore fest, not often i would say this but the book is better! OK the start of the film was OK, that's as good as it gets, i would've been better watching "on her Majesty's secret service" (another film i dislike greatly) at least it made me giggle, not like this excuse for a film! overall i absolutely hated this film so much, i will definitely not be going to see the sequel (why are they wasting money to make it anyway?!) and why waste £5 or whatever it is on a ticket, i'd rather watch paint dry!!! I will never Ever, EVER watch it garbage again as long as i live!

title: Corny, pretentious, boring and stupid
review:
I went to see this movie with some friends of mine and we had quite a debate was it just us having too big expectations, or the movie was really that bad:

The first hour you watch kids jumping in and out a closet and making a 5 meters walk in the woods, waiting for something to happen. Then an episode with an awfully casted Faun and a heavily over-polite British chit-chat over a cup of tea hogs the next 15 minutes, making a feeling inside a viewer that something really cheesy and boring is about to be happening the rest of the time. And the feeling is right -- lame references to Christianity, forced references to various mythologies with a menagerie of poorly animated and incoherent CGI characters that look like gathered from every fairy tale, myth, horror movie and Disney cartoon ever made... Then Father Christmas comes out of the blue riding a sleigh and arming the kids up to their teeth, turning them instantly from toddlers to warriors just by giving them 50 pounds of steel! All of that is garnished by a complete lack of imagination and creativity (a beaver called Mr. Beaver -- give me a break!!!), generic directing, pathetic music, corny landscapes and poor acting. The result is a killing boredom with a total lack of interest in the characters or that Narnia place where Turkish delights are a national treat (how the hell do they now for Turkey?!?).

The only highlight is the appearance (I deliberately don't say "performance") of Tilda Swinton. She is so weird that she just doesn't have to do anything special to look creepy. And still, it was all so corny! Little Georgie Henley (Lucy) is perhaps about to be going places too, but with some other movies.

To me there was nothing "heart-warming" in this movie, nothing "moving" (except for my bowl, however) and absolutely nothing worth seeing. Just 140 minutes that made me more aware of the fact how difficult is to make a decent movie, even if you have a good template and loads of money. I wonder where all that money went to!

P.S. Any comparison with LOTR is an utter blasphemy! I don't want to see this movie or any of its sequels EVER again!

title: Wouldn't actually watch it again... Well, maybe for the cool lion
review: Maybe it's just me, but the plot seems kind of too worn out. Or perhaps, it would be better to re-phrase - the realization wasn't good enough. Throughput the whole movie I couldn't stop wondering "Why the h**l am I thinking of a weird combination between "Heroes of M&M", "Willow" & "The Ice Queen"?!?!? Too brutal one might say, but acting of the four majesties didn't feel as "real" as the artificial characters per se. (Take the gryphon or the cute fox for example - let's not even start with Aslan.) And as NOT modest at all of me to say - I tend to "catch & feel" a good movie when I see one - but this one wasn't exactly the right kind. So personal or not, a message to people about to see "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe": Your children will love it, make sure you've had enough sleep before it (otherwise you might turn into Mr/Mrs Snoooreee) and even if you try to shed a tear at some point - don't even think about it. Believe me, it won't come out.

title: Dull, Dreary & Dreadful & that is being kind.
review:
This film is from the Walt Disney Studios, who used to make fantasy films by the multi dozens.

I have realized that the magic of Mr Disney has been slipping since his death. This piece of cinematic garbage as to be the worst film ever released by The Disney Co.

There is no magic or wonderment shown here, about 110 minutes of boredom followed by computer generated effect scenes, killing all the bad people, There is supposed to be a religious parable involved. Its there all right, but almost laughable/

If you want to see a film with a religious parable rent WELCOME BACK, MISS MARY , this minor B movie says more about the love of God, Jesus & man, than one frame of this one.

Tilda Swintion is the major names actor this, she is the White Witch.

a mean rotten witch (spell it with a b) She shows not one bit of menace just over/under acting. Liam Neeson does the voice of Aslan the Lion (supposedly---Jesus------sorry he did not convince me). There are 4 children in this well of different ages, the youngest lassie smiled & was sort of cute, The 2 older were typical English lads of the period, (suprised that they were not caned as boys of that period were often caned or slippered), the other sister is typical mid-teen.

The kids in both the Harry Potter films & the Lord of the Rings films were much much better, . The special effects were typical CGI.. The director did the 2 SHREK films, they were animated & much better, maybe this too should have been animated.

Do NOT wast time or money on this.

Rating * )out of 4),25 points (out of 100) IMDb 1 (out of 10)

BTW if over 65 years of rating films I have rated under 100 films this low. this is definitely one of the WORST OF ALL TIME

boring, pointless and ruined an amazing book!!!! the first and most ANNOYING THING about this film was the main child actors... the main child actor (William Moseley)who played Peter, was a total tool and couldn't act. the way he POINTED his sword at the enemy instead of using it as it is intended and thrusting it into them was so annoying i near cried.

the female child actors, like always, were uninteresting and added nothing to the story.

the only redeeming features of this film was that James McAvoy and Liam Neeson was in it. these actors did not deserve to be exposed to such novice and disgusting screenplay writing and directing

title: In a nutshell, I would say the movie was... Just OK'ish.
review:
In a nutshell, I would say the movie was... Just OK'ish. As a huge fan of "The Lord of the Rings" and the "Potter" films, an epic fantasy movie such as this should have blown my socks off, but it just didn't seem to have any heart.

The movie starts in World War II England. Four kids are sent out in to the countryside to live away from the main brunt of the German bombing campaign. The children are quite bored, and they decide to play a game of hide and seek. When the youngest attempts to hide in an old wardrobe, she enters a mystic wintry world of Narnia. A land full of half animal, as well as fully animal creatures who can chat it up, as well as cyclops, and other various creatures we expect to find in such tales of fantasy.

Tilda Swinton does a quite competent job as the wicked white witch. Well, lets face it, just watching her beautiful face would be enough entertainment to half carry a movie. In fact, all of the acting is quite solid in my opinion. Also, the effects of the show are quite masterful, a job well done by all on that front. Where the movie comes up missing is how it uses all of the wonderful attributes it has. These are wonderful and magical images, yet we never really care that much about either the children or the entire world of Narnia. Sure, they seem nice enough, and the White Witch seems quite evil, but we never seem to get into the characters outside of rather shallow characterizations of good and bad. Its as if Disney tried to make a Lord of the Rings film. They kept all of the imagery and the structure, but they forgot the heart.

Now, I must confess. I nave never read the books myself, but even if they also never really let the reader get into the characters, I still blame the film makers, whose job it is to go beyond the source material and make a truly entertaining film for its viewers. I am unsure if the writers and directors were just not competent to this task, or if they truly felt like all they had to do is give us a few funny and cute lines of dialogue for us to understand why these human children decide to risk all to help them, or conversely why all of the "good" creatures of Narnia are willing to die in combat under the leadership of some seemingly random humans.

Another sadly missed opportunity was the final somewhat anti-climatic battle. While the first half of the movie is unforgivably slow to build towards some action scenes, the war itself involves a good idea of creatures running at each other, but rarely do we get to see any actual combat, or even contact between combatants! My mind was a wonder at the thought of a cheetah, rhino and centaur good guys duping it out with various half bull, cyclops or bat people. But, none of this is actually seen. Instead we get to see a lot of heroic poses and grunts from a multitude of admittedly wonderful looking mythical creatures. But, as I said, without gaining an investment in any of the actual beings we are watching, these poses come off as images some CGI technician thought would look good.

The ultimate realization of image over substance and hopefully not a hint of things to come in fantasy film. With that being said, I am sure it will make tons and tons of money considering the marketing megamachinery behind it connecting it to the recently very popular "Christianity in film" trend. But, it will never truly take the place of our beloved Lord of the Rings franchise.

title: Thelionthewitchandthewardrobe....
review:
Chronicles Of Narnia Shane Gannaway One of the most daunting tasks a director can possibly try to tackle, has to be that of a movie that was based on a book. It's not just the regular movie goers he has to please, it's the thousands upon thousands of fans that he also has to satisfy. I can't say whether Andrew Adamson did a quality job of putting the book's magic on charm on to the big screen. I've never read the book. He did put something on there though. And while however beautiful it is, it has its flaws.

The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe, is as a good friend of mine put "a visual feast." The movie is amazingly stunning in visuals and CGI. This helps bring some magic to this movie. The animals are amazingly done, looking extremely lifelike. The faun, or as some might know him, Mr. Tumnus is also very well handled. The way they added goats legs onto the second half of James McAvory is flawless. This movie doesn't lack on the visuals. It's got plenty of eye candy and many people probably won't mind watching it muted.

If the movie is not muted, then you have to sit through what seems like could have a solid story. Instead you are rushed through an adventure that was seemed to be squeezed into two hours for no apparent reason. The obvious Christian allusions are all still there, but there is a sense of rushed-ness as we fly through this film. There are times when you may watch certain scenes and wonder why they are in the movie at all. Basically, besides the rushed story it's the small things that start to grate. The fact the at a little girl no older then 10 can make a bulls-eye with a knife. The never convincing fake snow that the audience sees so much of. The feeling that Narnia was toned down a little, just for the kiddies. This movie is rated PG, so I don't know what I expected when I went to see it. It is though, a very violent movie. And the only reason it keeps this PG rating is by taking out in what would have been some very gory scenes, all blood. I hate it when this happens. When a movie is toned down, when the artistic value of film is compromised, just for more ticket sales, I get angry. And a kitten dies. It's a horrible thing. Anyway, that's what Narnia does. They tone it down and speed through all the while impressing you with some pretty sights and sounds. Like I said, I haven't read the book. It's my belief though, this book should have been made for the people who first enjoyed it, and not the little kids Disney usually shoots towards.

title: Hollywood cardboard!! *SPOILERS*
review:
I am a fan of the Chronicles of Narnia (the books), I read them when I was a little kid. I just watched the movie on DVD and was appalled at the way the makers of this film turned the books into Hollywood cardboard.

For one thing you don't like/empathise/sympathise with the characters, because it is all just too easy. There is no going hungry in the woods, or anything that makes you feel as if getting through this adventure is a struggle. Or that shows the characters actually growing... in the book, this was not the case. By the time they are crowned or whatever, I was thinking to myself that this was totally stupid, they had not really done anything in the movie to deserve being crowned. Without the struggle & growth that is presented int he books, you wonder to yourself, "what is the point???".

The logic was much better in the novels as well - for example, in escaping from the beavers' damn they don't go down a tunnel or cross a river. They leave before the wolves get there, and because of heavy snows their tracks and scent are hidden from the wolves. They hide in the woods overnight, cold and hungry, while the wolves move on.

In my opinion the character Aslan should have been narrated by someone like Ian McKellan, because Neeson had way too high a voice and no 'presence'. You just didn't believe that Aslan was this all-important being who was around way back when the "deep magic was written".

The special effects were good. And I liked the way Mr. Tumnus was portrayed. That's just about the only aspects of the movie I liked.

Sure, it could be mildly entertaining if you hadn't read the books... but if you have I don't understand how you could enjoy this film. THUMBS DOWN.

I could go on and on for another hour about the different ways I was disappointed with this film. But I think you get the idea.
