review: i loved this movie.it has just about everything you want in a movie.there's action,drama,mystery with an air of evil.it also looks great,with a beautiful pallet of colours.kids will like it for its sense of wonderment and magic,as well as its rich collection of larger than life characters.there's also a breath taking battle scene which is quite well done.but this is not just a kids movie.i think many adults will also enjoy it.Tilda Swinton Plays the evil white witch and is mesmerizing.she oozes insincerity,sarcasm and evil,while also holding a seductive charm over both the audience and the characters,especially the children.this is the first movie based on the beloved series of books by C.S.Lewis.as far as i can recall,it stays fairly true to its source material.a warning to parents.this movie might be a bit too intense for young children,due to the battle scene, and the white witch might also be a bit too scary.there are also many mature themes running throughout.for me,this movie is brilliant.i give "The Chronicles of Narnia:The Lion,the Witch and the Wardrobe a solid 10/10

title: Wow!
review:
There are many reasons why I love the movie "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe."

1. Mythical Creatures: I love stories about mythical creatures. "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" has centaurs, fauns, unicorns, and talking beavers, horses, and lions. There were also a few mermaids who didn't have any part in the story, but they were my favorite kind of mythical creature. But, if I had to choose my favorite mythical creature that actually had a part in the movie, I would choose the centaur. I love horses, and it's amazing how there is a mythical creature that is a mix of a horse and a human.

2. Tilda Swinton: Although I have never seen Tilda Swinton in anything else before I watched the movie, I could tell that she has had a lot of experience as an actress since she was so good. Then, when I looked at her resume on IMDb, I saw that she was in so many movies and TV shows that it was hard to count. She has a fabulous performance as the White Witch in "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe."

3. William Moseley: William Moseley may not be the best actor ever to live, but he was still good. I thought that he was really cute, and I liked the character he developed. He seemed to be a nice older brother who wasn't too grown up and acted like a dad. I just finished reading "The Outsiders" for school, and I didn't like the character of Darry because he seemed too grown up because he had to take care of his two younger brothers since his parents died. But Peter's parents didn't die, so when William Moseley had to act like an older brother, he didn't have to look too grown up. The part that I feel shows that Peter was still like a child was at the beginning of the movie when he was at the train station and he started looking at the soldiers, and Susan had to act like an older person and make him stop day dreaming to hand the woman the paper.

4.Overall story: The overall story was a good idea by C.S. Lewis. I read the book before I saw the movie, and when I found out that they were going to make a new movie for it, I was really worried that the filmmakers might ruin the story, because I saw a different movie of "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe," and it seemed really fake and the acting was terrible. Although I was worried that the filmmakers would ruin the story, I was excited, because it looked like a good movie, so I was hoping that the story wouldn't be ruined. I was pleased after I saw the movie, because it was true to the book, and the production was excellent.

title: A good adaption, but did not quite capture the spirit of Narnia.
review:
I have been a fan of Narnia ever since I first read the books at the age of six, so needless to say I was quite thrilled when I learned that a movie adaption was in the works.

I went to watch Narnia opening weekend, and was overall quite impressed. The actors were all great, but Lucy and Edmund particularly stood out to me. The special effects were excellent most of the time, but there were a few moments where the effects were not as good as they should have been for a movie with such a large budget.

The movie followed the book fairly closely, but there were a couple scenes that were added for more drama at the expense of some scenes that were in the book. But, I think my biggest complaint would have to be that Narnia in the movie did not feel like the Narnia in the books. It seemed to me that the spirit of the book was lost in the adaption somewhere.

But overall, I'd say it is a great movie, and if you have not seen it, you definitely should.

title: I've been spoiled.
review: "The Chronicles of Narnia  The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe": I've been spoiled. I've seen "Lord of the Rings", and you, Narnia, aren't a Lord of the Rings. However, I WILL say it's WAY better than those flat "Harry Potter" things, and has a made-for-kids fantasy akin to the for-adults grandeur of "Excalibur". The special effects are pretty darned good here, and the story is well, VERY reflective of a number of things: 1) World War II in Europe, 2) the biblical story of Jesus, and, yes, 3) Lord of the Rings. C. S. Lewis, who wrote this story, went to school with J. R. Tolkien, who wrote "Rings". In fact, they shared ideas, and it shows. Good guys, bad guys (and gals  played by Tilda Swinton), twisted biological creatures who serve as the Righteous or Evil masses, sweeping landscapes, and in THIS case, a huge battle scene without one drop of blood (again, this one IS for kids). My wife and I enjoyed this one very much, and you will too, as long as you allow for it to be less than a fully adult story. Older kids would ADORE this. It gives kids all the power and glory they dream of having.

title: 'Narnia' is LOTR for the junior high crowd.
review: A film with that is a special effects palooza, in strange fantasy world, with a core group of height challenged heroes; it is 'Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring' right? Well 'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe' share more then a title that is so wordy neither cannot fit on any marquee. The film starts out in London during a WWII bombing. Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy are sent off to live in the country stately mansion of Professor Kirke. During an exuberant game of hide and seek, Lucy (the youngest) hides in an ornate wardrobe. Lucy discovers the world of Narnia and befriends Mr. Tumnus, a Faun (a man with a goat's anatomy below the waist). Narnia is in a 100 year winter by the designs of the evil White Witch that has crowned herself queen of all Narnia. Lucy ends up bringing back her siblings and they learn of a prophecy that has four humans (two sons of Adam and two daughters of Eve) that are to topple the Queen. The Queen must kill the four-some to continue her reign. The Queen mobilizes her army (that looks not-so-surprisingly like the legions of the Orcs from LotR). The last 45 minutes recreates the battle in 'LotR; The Return of the King', but with almost no blood (Narnia is PG, Return of the King was PG-13). Both films find a 'lost and forgotten' army to save the day. The picture's special-effects blend animal bodies and humans torsos on numerous occasions and seamlessly. Additionally there are talking animals all over the two and half hour movie. There are a couple of blue-screen backgrounds that were notably not up to par but all in all a top quality show.

title: Slow to start, boring in the middle
review:
Slow to start, boring in the middle, painful to end.

Big news everyone! CS Lewis was a friend of Tolkien and this film shows clearly that friendship does not affect writing skills for one, that marketing does not trick everybody in seeing a film or buying merchandise, and that when you want to express your religious opinions too strongly it does not make good fiction books.

The books have the same flaw as the film: story is boring. Have you seen the film? No? Don't and be sure you don't miss much.

Special effects are million dollar apiece, same quality in fact as LOTR, the cast did their best, really, they did, the story was simply too symbolic to be interesting any more, like a joke they explain to you is no longer funny.

CS Lewis expressed his renewed religious feelings in a fervent way and wrote plain uninteresting books, whose symbols are too close to propaganda to be attracting anymore. Adapting them to the cinema could only lead to a result where every moment is lasting too long.

title: Good, but LOTR is still better...
review: Narnia was a very good film in terms of all-round quality. It had the epic feel, the big budget CG and a screenplay that remained loyal to the text, creating the most epic realisation of Narnia that has yet been seen. While the world of Narnia has lots of spirit and is beautifully made, I couldn't help feeling that New Zealand's beautiful landscapes could have been used more. It is evident that a lot of the sets were either CG or studio-created, and while it did look good, it just didn't possess the natural beauty of Peter Jackson's Middle Earth. And the battles weren't quite as epic or intense as in LOTR, though to be honest, this is aimed at younger people than LOTR, although I'm sure everybody has heard of The Chronicles of Narnia and will delight in seeing this epic film that brings it to the screen once again. It has the emotion and the grandeur, but Narnia needs more natural beauty - it could have quite possibly been done in the UK, and let's be honest, NZ has far more in the way of scenery to offer. But aside from that, Narnia was another great adaptation of C.S Lewis's work - and one that definitely had me checking inside my wardrobe back home (you may be surprised to hear that there wasn't a fantasy world in sight...) 9/10

title: This was a good movie, but it could have been a great one.
review:
Although I am glad that this movie was made, and I certainly think the result is a more than adequate family film, I can't help but feel disappointed by the result. In making the transition from book to film, it feels like the filmmakers jettisoned what they thought were minor details of C.S. Lewis' original work, and replaced them with typical Hollywood-style action sequences.

While none of this was bad in itself, many of those "minor details" were, in fact, central to the themes and ideas of the book. It's not that things were changed that bothers me. Some of the additions made to the story were quite good. What bothers me is that certain things were changed or deleted that shouldn't have been.

For example, the initial encounter between Aslan and the Witch was meant to demonstrate Aslan's absolute superiority over the Witch, and her fear of him. She was terrified of him, mirroring the way that, in C.S. Lewis' world-view, evil is absolutely inferior to good.

The film, however, was interested in making the Witch seem like a "credible" villain, and took away much of her fear in that scene. It's a mistake. C.S. Lewis' point- that evil is much weaker than good- gets lost, and very little is gained from the change.

Similarly, in the book, the Beaver specifically states that Aslan is neither tame nor safe. Lewis put this in to mirror his ideas about God. The movie, in the interest of keeping Aslan's status as a Lion as a surprise, drops this element, opting instead for a few seconds of surprise for anybody who, say, didn't read the title of the film (are we really supposed to be surprised that Aslan is a lion when "The Lion" is right in the title?).

There are numerous other instances of this. Please don't misunderstand- I'm not some mad purist who can't stand it when the slightest change is made transitioning to the screen. I don't mind changes per se, it's just that C.S. Lewis was a very talented writer exploring some very complex themes, and he didn't include small details randomly or without thought. In a nutshell, I feel that excellent elements have been removed and replaced with merely adequate ones.

This is not to say that this isn't a good movie. It's an excellent family film, and certainly ranks head and shoulders above most the the garbage people take their children to see. It's a rousing adventure story, the visuals are magnificent, and Lewis' works shines through despite the misguided changes. This movie is entertaining to both children and adults.

This is a very good film. That's too bad, though, because it could have been a great one.

title: Disappointing interpretation of a classic
review:
The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe was a classic fantasy book before the current Harry Potter mania and remains one today. I have fond memories of immersing myself in the world of Narnia benevolently looked over by the all powerful lion king Aslan. I had previously seen an animated interpretation of the story which was admirably done and enjoyable so was looking forward to seeing what could be done with the wonders of modern CGI.

Unfortunately I was disappointed by the end result. The 4 key child actors were very wooden and seemed more intent on getting their proper British accents right than on making their characters believable. The CGI distracted from the story rather than added to it and looked very tacked on in a number of places, most noticeably the fox.

Compared to other recent interpretations of classic books, LOTR and the Harry Potter series, this movie falls far short and does not do justice to the wonderful source material. I'm not sure if there are plans to develop this into a series but, on this showing, I hope the producers decide to leave the other Narnia classics to live in our imagination rather than drag them kicking-and-screaming to the screen.

title: Decent attempt but must try harder
review:
I came to The Lion The Witch and The Wardrobe with some trepidation as I adore the BBC series that was done some years ago and did not think it could easily be topped by simply introducing some CGI. I was right.

However, in it's defence, it was better than I was led to believe it would be by other peoples responses to it. I think that if I had come to it fresh or just from reading the book I would have got on with it a bit better.

One of the main problems I had with the film was the children themselves. Now I always found Peter and Susan vaguely annoying in the book/TV series for being too 'goody-goody' so I wasn't surprised at my dislike for them. But Edmund had always been my favourite character by far and I found him detestable in this. And not simply in the way you are supposed as he is a traitor etc because, as I said, I liked his character in the book. Lucy I found a little too wide-eyed and vacant but she grew on me throughout the film. I think I just found her a little too young for the role, it made it a little unbelievable.

Now to the other characters. Good job with the beavers, they were spot on. Mr Tumnus seems to have been transformed from a likable if initially misguided character into a creepy slightly paedophilic figure which disturbed me somewhat. The wolves I found too 'cute', nowhere near as scary as in the TV series (yes, OK, they were more realistic (especially since some real!) but not terrifying like they should be). Dwarfs, ghouls, fawns etc all OK, didn't stand out as particularly good or bad.

Tilda Swinton spot on as the white witch. Could not have thought of anyone better to cast in this role. She always has a menacing, slightly psychotic air which is perfect. Not convinced on Liam Neeson as Aslan, I thought a deeper, more authoritative voice would have been better but I got used to it.

Now I don't know how long the TV series was but this film felt far too condensed  it's a long time since I read the book but I got the feeling there was a lot missing, I just can't quite place what.

I also disliked the battle scenes, they seem to have fallen into the CGI trap of 'lets show what we can do and how impressive it can be' rather than showing specific parts of the battle with key characters in detail. There was a little bit of close-up but nowhere near enough to show the true intensity of a battle.

One thing I did like is that I found that they kept the whole Christian thing quite low key (I know others didn't think this from the posts on the message boards but I did). I never spotted this in the books as a child and when I learnt it as an adult it disappointed me greatly as I am not Christian and do not agree with Christianity. It ruined the books for me to a degree when I thought back over them and I thought they did a good job stopping it from taking over the film.

Here's hoping they manage to improve on what they've done so far and make Prince Caspian better  hopefully the children will have grown into their roles more improving that side and I'm praying (excuse the irony!) that they avoid the 'just throw CGI at them' approach for the battles.

Overall, well worth watching if you haven't seen the TV series, otherwise you may want to avoid if that lies close to your heart!

title: Narnia Rocks!!!!!!
review: Like Harry Potter, this is one of those movies that I wanted to see ever since it hit the theaters but wasn't able to for a long time. In the meantime, my excitement continued to build to see this movie. Of course I have read the book a dozen times over again! The wait was well worth it, however! I wasn't disappointed. The reason for my rating score of 9 is because it took so long before we finally got to Aslan, who happens to be my favorite character of the book series and the movies, old and new. My favorite scene is the scene where the saintly and magnificent Aslan pounces upon the White Witch and tears her throat out, damning her world to damnation!! Let's not forget that this is a Walt Disney produced film and not the film of The Ghost and the Darkness staring Val Kilmer and Michael Douglas. So there is no film footage of graphic blood to show nor view. It took me forever to convince my mother to sit and see The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe along with me. I knew that she would adore it if I could only persuade her to watch it. And Aslan? Why, she absolutely fell in love with him!! My mother didn't know about the Christian/Jesus keynote of the story and she vowed that if Aslan died (and stayed dead), that she would no longer continue to watch the movie. I must also make it clear that a great justice was done for all of the CGI animal characters. They looked so beautiful and so real!!! Not to mention their voices!! Very well done!!!

title: no wonder children are getting dumber nowadays
review:
This movie was supposed to great. All my friends had read this apparently brilliant book as children. I never read books coz i cant read! I love great movies even if they are intended to entertain children.

This movie was so bad i left the theater half way through it. I should have spent the ticket money on fine grass. The amount of animal cruelty featured in this film was shocking. To make it worse, they made dead lions come back to life to cater the concept of a children's story which was pathetic.

I think i am going to watch Tokyo drift to try and forget i ever saw this movie.

title: Basically just a waste of time
review:
First of all, I've seen the original Narnia movies/series, and I couldn't believe how much greater they were, than this re-make.

The goods things with this movie: great special effects great scenery the story is still kept alive very lifelike

The bad things about this movie: It doesn't live up to its potential. The fighting is just stupid. Susan gets a bow, but she only use it once, or twice. In the fighting scenes, good and evil doesn't have any character, so you wouldn't know which one to cheer at. I mean, it's just a lot of creatures that punches each other, and so on. The movie is long, but much of it happens too fast.

Conclusion: This is one of the better fantasy movies for kids, but if you're looking for something darker, yet not a violent movie, this is definitely the wrong choice. From the day the Lord of the Rings-movies were published, every other movie have to be compared to it, and this movie isn't even close.

title: pretty good but...
review:
well, this isn't really a comment. i just wanted to write this cause i don't know how to write on the goofs. The show is pretty cool for kids about 7-11 yrs. old cause it kinda relates to them and how they feel in a new world they know nothing about. OK so let me just go on to my goof.

Well, in the scene on their first night on prof. Kirke's house, when Lucy said "sheet's still scratchy" Susan and peter comforted her and peter said tomorrow would be a great day or something like that, then it turned out to be raining so Susan was doing this DEAD BORING game about words like gastro-vascular then Lucy wanted to play hide and seek. as you could see outside the window, it was raining and it was all dark, right? but then when they started playing, the rooms were lit and when Lucy came out of the wardrobe and called them, they went to the spare room. then when they were talking and Edmund said "i believe her" Lucy said "you do?" ed said "yeah, didn't i tell you about the something field in the bathroom cupboard?" (sorry i don't remember everything) then they got mad (peter & ed) at each other and when ed left the room, you could see the window which was looking pretty light to me, as though the sun was shining beautifully.

what a huge no-no in the movie business for Adam i forgot his last name. i wanna be a director when i grow up so ill make sure my movies don't have these mistakes. but ill make sure there are some easter eggs in the movie so watch out for them!

see ya

title: wow.. most amazing
review: This is a most amazing production. I cannot even imagine the huge amount of work that went in to preparing this film. So many incredible people were involved in the making of this movie and I would just love to commend them all on their great work and how they so closely made the movie along the books guides! C.S. Lewis - an obviously incredible author and imaginative man - would be very pleased (at least, I believe he really should be!) The cinematography of this film is amazing. Never have I ever experienced such an excitement as when I discovered the beautiful artwork of this movie. The many camera angles, work put in to the different characters, combination of animation and true film, and the work with the young actors was .. well, what can I say ... amazing. I can only hope and dream that someday I will be given the great opportunity to be involved in such a beautiful film production!! --By far my favourite film ever created! (If you would ever want to involve me in a film, let me know!! :) -- cami_5911@hotmail.com )

title: awful, dog gone awful
review: to say the movie was bad would be an understatement:it was terrible. I read the lion and the witch when i was in first grade. It was my favorite book for years. Obviously i was excited when i heard they where taking it to the big screen. I can't even start to describe my disappointment. Everything about this movie turned me off:editing (you could see the green screen miles away), special effects, original score. But what really killed it for me the script. they butchered it. How could they do this to one of the best kids tales of all times? The dialogue was poor and character development was obviously not the scriptwriters' main priority. I was not glued to my seat. I couldn't wait to get out of there. The only remotely good thing about the film was the acting. And although Tilda Swinton was plain (can't think of a better word), the child actors where promising. I hope to see their craft has improved in the sequel.

title: Chronicles "for all ages"
review: Seriously, who can you say this movie is for all ages. I looked at the ratings and people my age give it a 7. It's a children's film, and a poor one in that. The story starts very slow and gives you a look at 4 children who discover a magical world. I only decided to see this movie because of all the positive things I heard about it. But by the time they're going to enter the Witches' castle, I couldn't take it anymore and stopped watching. There's nothing else to say. It's a total waste of time, only music is good. Nothing actually happens, and no, I'm not the guy who only enjoys action flicks. I love slow movies like the Hours for instant. But this is just completely useless. Book = good, for me it's the only reason to believe people actually watched and enjoyed it.

title: great
review: out of all the Disney movies i have seen this is the best! even though i think this movie was targeted towards children i think it would be a favourite for adults who have also read and loved the books.i think the casting directors did a great job in choosing the children that brought Narnia to life,Goergie Henley who played Lucy did a great job same as Skandar Keynes, Anna Poppelwell and William Moseley also Tilda Swinton was a great choice for the evil queen that had put the residence of Narnia through a long and cold winter, i had made a big mistake in not going to the cinemas and watching this film i hope you didn't because after watching the movie i was like ''wow! that was amazing i'm so stupid for not going to the cinema and watching it!'' your children (if you have any) and also you (even if you weren't a big fan of the books) will love this film!

title: magical fantasy
review:
I don't want to tell too much, but this is definitely a FANTASY that grabs your heart and takes you into their world.. a movie that allows you to live the real fantasy that it tells you about.. a must see for all ages, If you believe in fantasies, this is a must see for you. I would suggest it to be rated highly.. it takes you away like a harry potter movie and keeps you highly interested,there are few movies that give me the anxiety I feel, like I am really there and part of the story. This movie is one of the few on my list. The creations of the creatures that were in this movie like aslan were so realistic. I am always looking for perfection, The pegasus was incredibly realistic for a movie.

Jen

title: Superb adaptation of C.S. Lewis's classic first book!
review:
During WWII four children named Peter (William Moseley), Lucy (Georgie Henley), Susan (Anna Popplewell) and Edmund (Skander Keynes) are sent to live with a professor until the war is over. One day while being bored, Lucy while playing hide and seeks hides into the wardrobe that leads her into another world called Narnia inhabited by magical creatures especially a goat-like being named Mr. Tumnus (James Avery) where it's leader whom is a powerful Lion named Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson). Later as the children go into the wardrobe with Lucy they find themselves on the adventure of a lifetime as they join with Aslan and his rebels against the White Witch (Tilda Swanton) to free Narnia.

An elaborately well done adaptation of the classic C.S. Lewis fantasy novel which was actually the second of the book series will lead into a new cinematic fantasy franchise like "Lord of the Rings", "Pirates of the Caribbean" or "Harry Potter". The kids acted quite well unlike some kid actors and the effects were masterfully done by Weta and ILM with make-up by Robert Kurtzman, like the book and animated movie that came before this it has a religious allegory to the film even on the theme of death and resurrection.

The Director Andrew Adamson ("Shrek") accomplished everything to bring the beloved fantasy novel to the big screen in a successful way, i'd say thank you Adamson and team for making a great movie for the fans of the genre and can't wait for the sequel "Prince Caspien" in 2008.

A must see!

title: Good Adaptation Of The Classic C.S Lewis Book, But Although It May Not Be The Best Adptation Of A Novel, It Is Still Entertaining And A Fun Family Film(SPOILERS)
review:
SPOILERS

I was very excited to see this movie. It looked like it had cool special effects, a solid score, and some really cool moments, and there were, but this film is not the best. It is great, but there were some moments in the film I wish they had left out. I am glad, though, they extended the war between the White Witch and her army and Aslan and Peter and their army. The war was a fantastic moment in this film.

Here is the plot. Like the title says, a group of children find a magical wardrobe the takes them to a land called Narnia. Unfortuanley, there is a war in Narnia with the White Witch, who can freeze people. The ruler of Narnia named Aslan, who is a giant lion, is going to fight it. Then he is killed by the White Witch. Peter, who is one of the children, leads the war. Then it turns out Aslan is alive. He kills the Witch. Then the children become the Queens and Kings of Narnia. A few years go by, then they accidentally go out of the wardrobe and are back in the real world.

Overall, this is a huge movie, that is also very good and has some very fantastic aspects about it. This is definitely not the best movie in the world, but it is a spectacular movie based on the fantastic novel by C.S Lewis. What is odd, though, is that I have a Narnia collection and the first book is the Magician's Nephew and this one is the second is my collection. It is odd that they made this one first, but I am truly glad they did. I guess they wanted to do the Narnia film with the Pevensies.

8/10

Recommended Films: Lord of the Rings.

title: The movie was disappointing...
review:
Hi. I had always loved the books of Narnia. I've read all the books,many times...

But the movie had some changes in comparison to the book. And the very important ones.

In the book "The lion the witch and the wardrobe" the readers are told how much the kids (all of them but mostly Susan and Lucy) loved Aslan (the Lion). They didn't even dare touching him, because they knew he was a wonderful, proud creature. They loved him but at the same time were afraid of him.

Well, in the movie the creator hadn't showed that love which was very, very important. In the movie it just seemed they didn't respect Aslan and thought of him as just an animal - not the Talking King of the land of Narnia.

If you read the book and liked it you will be disappointed by the movie as I was.

-by Daria,11 yrs old.

title: Truly Remarkable! Great Music! Great Effects! Great Acting! Great Battle Scenes! GREAT!!
review:
Probably one of the greatest fantasy movies I have ever seen! I wasn't really impressed by the old movie and book, but the movie was truly better even though they took out a little. Some lines still make me laugh. Like

Peter: Yes, but I am sure the professor wouldn't mind us using these. (Peter passes some fur jackets) Edmund: But this is a girl's coat! Peter: I know.

That one still gets me!

I didn't expect much from it. But when I first saw it, I really had to pee over and over. And it was the day of Christmas. It was, like, 10:00 at the time and I was exhausted. But when I watched it the second time, I really loved it. The music makes me nearly cry because of it's beauty. One day, I am dreaming to become a producer, director, and writer, etc. And I hope to have great composers like the composer in this movie.

It was also very intense, and the witch creeps you out even though she is supposed to be beautiful. The acting makes the intensity! The music does it! The actors' and actress' reactions make the movie. But most of all... ASLAN MADE THIS MOVIE! I LOVED HIS VOICE! AND HE ALSO KILLED THE WHITE WITCH, Jadas.

If you have not seen this yet, you are missing out on 100 tons of a great fantasy! You need to see this movie!

title: Probably great for 8 yr olds
review:
But for adults, perhaps not.

The acting of the children is key for this story (as is the script) I think and what I saw I characterize as the producer directing the director to direct the kids to appear as (unknown adjective) as possible. The result was goofy & wooden characters. The acting was so uneven all around.

I'll blame the director.

Then there's the story and script. I can't believe the book I read back in grade 5 or 6 was this inane. I don't want to think it was though I can't remember it at all.

I'll blame the screenwriter.

Special effects were fine.

Huge disappointment for me.

title: very well done...
review: this movie was very well done, playing close attention to the book. CJ lewis would be proud of this movie. I was quite delighted to see the children play the roles with passion and commitment, well done. only thing i wasn't happy about the lofted cover drive edmund hit to break the glass, i mean he should have come more on his front foot and gone for a powerful drive, oh well, perhaps in the next movie. Anyways, i think i will actually go and purchase this DVD for my collection. i cant believe that i waited this long to see this movie. oh well, damn my boss for making me work over time, i highly recommend this movie to all people that loved the book.

title: "The Chronicles of Narnia", A Perfect Fantasy
review: "The Chronicles of Narnia:/The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is a perfect fantasy. It satisfies the adult thirst for entertainment just as well as that of the older child. It involves the adventures of four young siblings who enter a fantastic world of elves and witches and animated animals that engulfs our imagination. Georgie Henley plays the youngest of the troupe, Lucy Pevensie, who first witnesses the magical land of Narnia. Her initial adventure eventually ensnares the others. Skandar Keynes plays Edmund Pevensie the younger of the brothers, and he actually cinches the attraction for the older two. William Moseley plays Peter Pevensie, the eventual leader of this group of adventurers. And Anna Popplewell plays Susan Pevensie, the older and most attractive sister who is more like an assistant to Peter in their fantastic story. The music is essential and awe inspiring. The computer graphic generated animals were enough to fool me. Liam Neeson is the voice of the lion, Aslan, and he was the perfect choice for this entertaining piece. Tilda Swinton plays the White Witch and her piercing eyes and gripping expressions make her the most outstanding source of evil seen in cinema in years. Don't miss this movie.

title: Lion,Witch&Wardrobe-Better to Keep in Closet **
review:
Tale of children sent away to avoid the bombings of World War 11 England only to find utter mayhem in an enchanted land.

Coincidentally, the children are supposed to be the ultimate liberators from The White Queen. The latter, played by Tilda Swinton, is as eerie as my high school chemistry teacher. She holds a sword like a true clod.

Jim Broadbent, a fine actor, is utterly wasted here as the man whose house they have gone to only to find a rear closet whose back door reveals this land in turmoil.

It's almost like a David and Goliath tale with modern Hollywood technical achievements.

title: i love this movie!
review: oh my god! this was an awesome movie! i didn't even read the book and i understood it completely! that's one of the great things about it! a lot of movies based on books are made to where you almost have to have read the book to understand the film. or if you've read the book, the movie pales in comparison. but narnia is in a class by itself. the casting is another of this film's fine qualities. the casting director must've gone through the candidates for each part with a fine tooth comb! my favorite character in the film is mr. tumnus. he's so sweet! exactly like i thought he would be! James mcavoy did a wonderful job bringing the character of c.s. lewis's sensitive faun to life. it's just a wonderful movie, and i recommend it to anybody who enjoys harry potter, king arthur, lord of the rings, or any sort of medieval movie. in fact, c.s. lewis was actually a friend of j.r.r. tolkien's. but enough about tolkien. narnia is just a beautiful movie built around an amazing story.

title: Bad decors, effects and acting
review: What a pity-full movie... The decors and landscape look like plastic and fake during the whole movie, and the acting is quite excessive (it reminds me of the first Harry Potter movie, but the special effects were great at that time). Quite too long, and too childish for me maybe, I am really happy that such movies like LOTR does exist, because it should be a good objective for studios! But Disney is doing another theme park again instead of telling us a good story with good pictures. It's a shame when we think that POTC where inspired of a Disney attraction and was done quite better (special effects, filming, acting and a good and simple story, just what we need of adventure to have a good time!) I don't think I will see the next installment...

title: Truly sickly
review: I loved reading the lion the Witch and the Wardrobe as a child and I thoroughly enjoyed the BBC TV series however I have to say that this film was one of the most sickly and insipid things it has ever been my misfortune to see. The CGI graphics for the creatures were years out of date and they just did'nt look real and in parts like when the children are standing on the mountain you can clearly see their standing in front of scenery which has been projected behind them.Indeed unlike the Lord of the Rings the whole thing looks completely studio bound. There's absolutely no sense of dramatic tension. Your never at any point scared of the White Witch (I know its a kids film but there should still be a few harmless fright) and scenes which should be emotional are instead laughable. When Aslan was sacrificed all I could think about was how good he'd look stuffed and sitting in my living room. I also hated the fawn Mister Tumlin. If I was King Peter my first royal decree would be to tell him to wear a shirt and keep away from my little sister on pain of death. All in a all a rotten film and a terrible waste of good source material.

title: The violence, both emotional and physical, made this at least a PG-13 movie
review:
I read the book to my 7 year old daughter and she really liked it. The book does not focus on the violence and she was able to gloss over that and enjoy the magic and adventure of the fantasy world. The movie, however, makes all too explicit the violence implied by the book. So much so that when my daughter's first grade teacher proposed to show the movie to her class, we and several other parents objected (and prevailed). While some children may be able to handle it, parents should not simply assume this movie is o.k. for kids under 10 simply because it is rated PG.

First, the London bombing scene is pretty scary. Lots of flash/boom and tension about whether the characters will be hurt.

Second, the first time Edumnd meets the White witch, the dwarf flies out of the sledge and holds a wicked-looking knife to his throat. It's very unexpected and very threatening.

Third, the death of Aslan is very emotionally violent as hordes of hideous creatures do really nasty things to a beloved character while the little girls in the movie watch without being able to help. Not only is the physical violence of the killing itself potentially disturbing to the young mind, but the emotional violence of cruelty is also hard to take. Any movie that has such a serious killing scene in it should be PG-13. I find it hugely ironic that Prairie Home Companion got a PG-13 rating for "risque humor." The idea that humor is somehow more worthy of parental concern than is cruel violence reflects, to me, a deep confusion of values.

Fourth, the battle scene is pretty scary. Again, the forces of evil are represented by really nasty looking creatures, just waiting to inhabit a small child's nightmares. And the fighting and killing is strong stuff.

These are all the longish parts that are likely to stick in a child's mind. There are also other flashes of horror that could also disturb a young child: the 'death' of Tummus, whose face contorts into an awful expression of pain; the encounter on the ice floe, where the wolf is very scary---heck, my daughter cried during "Piglet's Big Movie" because she imagined the awful things that would happen to the friends IF they fell into the river---and here the ice damn falls and the children plunge into the raging river; the voice of the wolf fighting Peter.

I'm just saying you need to really know your child on this movie, much more than the innocuous "PG" rating would lead you to believe.

Aside from the mis-rating, I found Aslan's character terribly disappointing. The jaw and mouth were way unbelievable for me; it made Asland look too much like Tony the Tiger.

title: Lost magic
review: I'd like the TV series better than the movie itself. Even though the effects were thousand times better than the TV-series, I think the TV-series got a whole a lot of charm than the Hollywood production. The effects were too overwhelming and a little too much, to actually care about them all. The characters are simply drowning in all the visual effects. I just lost interest in what was going on and I just couldn't keep up to the end 'cause I just didn't care about what was going to happen to them. The kids could get eaten by the bad wolf for that matter. I just couldn't believe their characters. I don't exactly what's wrong with the movie, basically everything. It's trying to be Lord of the Ring like but it just don't work. It just fit better in smaller production. But this is my opinion. It was just nothing that I expected it to be. The magic was gone.

title: William Moseley
review: This movie was awesome!! All because of William Moseley!! he is soo hott!! and cute..i love him soo much!! yea so this was an awesome movie..i can't wait till the next one comes out..so that i can see william Moseley or ((Peter)) again! i can't wait!! i hope i will one day get to meet u william Moseley..so i hope u are reading this and let me meet u...well anyway this comment has to be at least 10 lines or i can't post it so i am just going to type some dumb stuff...................I LOVE WILLIAM MOSELEY..........................I LOVE WILLIAM MOSELEY.......................I OVE WILLIAM MOSELEY...GOOD BYE

title: The Wrong Director, The Wrong Producer
review: I watched the movie twice, first at a multiplex and next at a economic single screen theatre. May be I didn't notice how good the movie was the first time, but no,I found more faults and wished Peter'King Kong' Jackson had directed the film. Were it were not for the 10 minute war sequence, Narnia would have been one of the major disappointments of 2005. Especiallly when the plan is to bring out six more movies.Irrespective of the box- office collections it garnered, Narnia is below par . Andrew Adamson doesn't get the characterization right. It takes a while for Aslan to appear, and therefore, not much time remains for the character of the king and not a mere jungle lion to encompass the audience. When Aslan and the White Witch go inside a tent for a meeting , there is an awkardness, as we see a Lion and not Aslan. Similar thoughts occur in the war sequence, the children would be believably dead than so unbelievably skilled to fight war. A little bit of practice and they are ready to battle! Unfortunately Disney hasbagged the rights for the movies, as a result there will be no blood where blood should be, and mild violence. The dilemma for the producerswas the question of doing away with the christain influences of the story or retain it. The result is a ambiguous reference to religion. The father Christmas scene is a drag and could have been crisp. It seems a scene out of a TV series. The air - raids, and the following scenes, in the opening sequence, takes up precious time of story teling. It is a while before all the children walk through the wardrobe. When they do, screen time is running out for the other characters to come. The final scenes of the crowning and " Long Live" cries is again awkward, and unintentionally ironic. Although Narnia... like the Harry Potter series, will be popular, but not everlasting cinema. Prince Caspian(2008), the next movie in the sequel, is been directed by Adamson again, hope he realises where he went wrong last time. Of course there is always Shrek.

title: disappointing
review: I have to say that this was a disappointing movie. In complete contrast to the excellent Lord of the Rings series which I thought had nailed the visual imagery, a lot of this Narnia movie seemed off. I feel that the people making this movie must not really have been lovers of the books, were lacking in vital imagination, or both. The movie was soulless. It was not that the individual actors were especially bad (I enjoyed Lucy for example), but the casting and computer-imagery seemed to be seriously off. The Great Witch, the Beavers, most of the Penvesies, the Professor, even Aslan, these were not how this book lover at least (and I think others too) had imagined them. The tempo of the movie and execution of plot was also lacking in the necessary spark to get the viewer involved in the movie. I was looking forward to this movie, but it was a serious disappointment.

title: If God is out there, somewhere, Andrew Adamson will never direct a movie, EVER.
review:
I'll put this plain and simple: This movie is miserable. The characters: Square as the wardrobe. No depth, no nothing. The story: i didn't read the books(Jizuz there are 7 of 'em???), but it has no depth, just like the characters. Everything is fast and unexplained. The visual effects: They're OK. The Directing: Awful. Is it just me, or that guy copied some of the LOTR shots? Some of the scenes just run really fast, without causing an impact.

That's bout it.. Oh, no it isn't. That comic relief dwarf, that guy is a disgrace, i really hated the bast@rd. If God is out there, somewhere, Andrew Adamson will never direct a movie, EVER. This movie is suited for children, ONLY for children. Oh, and junkies. This might be a hell of a trip.

title: Harry Potter The Previous Generation
review:
The Chronicles Of Narnia was a revelation when it was released in book form, and none more so than The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe, and the transition from book to screen was always going to be a difficult job, and when announced there was tales of people both excited and worried. Thankfully, any worries there was are easily disbanded. It is not a film that would be in the Top 10 movies of all time, but if you want a movie to watch with the Family on a Saturday or Friday night, this is a beautiful movie.

The Witch is brilliant, and will easily creep out any young child, while the animations of Aslan are brilliant, with Liam Neeson getting a home-run, as his voice easily replicates the power that Aslan is meant to represent. The children are well chosen, with the uneasy mix of youth, bravery and actual acting ability.

A good comparison to The Lord Of The Rings, but will never exceed the Lord Of The Rings, but you can be confidant in the fact that, should you be missing the Lord Of The Rings, you can turn to The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe. Well done, Andrew Adamson.

title: Nice Lion... Shame About The Dreadful Children
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia is the best advertisement yet for birth control. Lucy, Edmund, Peter and Susan are perhaps the most annoying child characters in the history of cinema. All the Pevensie clan seem capable of doing in the first half of the film is to bitch, moan and bicker. The director doesn't help by insisting on repeated close-ups of their sullen faces. I wonder if Andrew Adamson made them drink lemon juice between takes in order to obtain those grim facial expressions. Someone should have called that damned Super Nanny to sort them out.

As unappealing as the children are, they can not be blamed entirely for the film's lack of excitement, imagination and heart. Make no mistake that this is nothing more than a poor man's "Lord of the Rings". CS Lewis' classic novel deserved far better than this lazy adaptation. I am one of the few people on earth who finds Peter Jackson's trilogy trite and boring. Nevertheless, it is hard to deny that those films (well at least the first one) had a sense of grandeur and majesty. These are qualities that are sorely missing in Narnia. The set design feels one dimensional and the use of blue/green screen technology is painfully obvious. Worst of all, the story feels rushed and forced. The sense of wonder that permeates each page of Lewis' book is nowhere to be seen here. A couple of poorly rendered CGI unicorns just don't cut it. Even the much hyped final battle scene looks like Peter Jackson's leftover footage from "The Two Towers".

The film does have good moments, they are just sadly infrequent. The film's greatest asset is Tilda Swinton's fantastic portrayal of the white witch. The Chronicles of Narnia picks up noticeably every time Tilda graces the screen. Her interpretation of the white witch is wonderfully evil without ever becoming a parody. A lesser actress would not have shown such restraint. It says a lot about a film, when one of the best performances comes from a computer generated lion. Aslan is a magnificent creation. If only the animators had been so meticulous with the cheap looking beavers and eagles. James McAvoy's turn as Mr Tumnus also deserves praise. His character's impact far exceeds his screen time.

It speaks volumes for our empty society that this film has been interpreted by some as having religious value. CS Lewis' book was a well concealed biblical allegory. This is just a tawdry attempt to cash in on the success of the "Lord of the Rings" at the expense of a literary classic. If you are looking for enlightenment hire "The Last Temptation of Christ" or even (I can't believe I'm writing this) "The Passion of the Christ". Those films might be as much fun as a car crash, but at least they were made with a more noble intention than to simply create a new movie franchise.

title: absolutely delicious
review: This movie was fabulous! The best way to convince you is to tell you that my daughter didn't want to see it. She went along under protest. She is 6 and about 2/3 of the way through the movie, she leaned over and whispered in my ear: 'when they start to sell this, you NEED to buy it!' I wholeheartedly agreed. We have watched it an additional 8 times since purchasing it. WOW!! I will be watching for it to play again on a big screen. It deserves to be shown in all it's glory on a widescreen with epic sound. I loved the fact that the children were so natural and unaffected. I am so glad they didn't make this movie with little pixie American children!

title: great story, bad pacing, uneven acting
review:
Georgia Henley and Skandar Keynes were outstanding as Lucy and Edmund Pevensie respectively; if anything Georgia carried the rest of the cast, who acted as if their source material was commonplace rather than one of the most beloved children's fables in twentieth century English literature.

Tilda Swanton exuded some evil as the witch, but not enough to make me afraid, particularly during the Stone Table sequence. Her portrayal was not nearly as fearsome as other evil villains we have come to expect from this genre (like Sauron in Lord of the Rings).

The CG characters (particularly Beaver) were awesome though Liam Neeson, from whom we routinely expect brilliance, was flat as the messianic Aslan. James McAvoy put in a fantastic part-CG performance as the nervous Mr. Tumnus.

All that to say that the momentum waned a bit at the 110 minute mark; it did not have the breathless pacing and richly veined detail of Peter Jackson's rendering of the Tolkien epic, much more tedious material. And from the director of Shrek we expect a bit more pop and a bit of humour along the way as well. "Lion..." was very serious indeed.

Let's hope the actors and Director Adam Adamson kick it up a notch in the next one (Prince Caspian); the Narnia chronicles have so much more depth than the Harry Potter books, but the Potter movies have excelled in the book-to-screen transition. The first Narnia movie was only good, not excellent. There is a large fan base out there expecting a higher standard.

title: Very, very lightweight.
review:
Well, this kind of light weight fantasy adventure is gonna become more and more common now. It's really a shame. Could someone, at least once, create a fantasy epic with raw brutality, pitch black story and with no concern for the budget (aka. "we need to make it for a larger focus group, hence the mild violence and language and easy-to-melt-characters").

I hate (yes HATE) the kids. The actors who plays them really suck, and I am usually very, very tolerant (always looking for positive upsides to a performance), but this just is to much crap. The director does not make any kind of statement in his "work", and is pretty much non-present throughout the entire film. The Oscar-nominated special effects is not really that good, not "A-Sound-of-Thunder-bad" but not very special at all, with the small exception of Aslan who actually looks like a real lion whenever he does not speak. The voice of Aslan by Liam Neeson is not good (Liam is a great actor, but the voice does not fit... or maybe the audio-mix is just crappy). The one thing that makes it worth watching is Tilda Swinton as the Queen, and also some the set-designs.

All in all, two and a half hours of: "When is the suspense ever gonna start!?", and; "When will the four disturbing children die already!"

title: Solid, but unremarkable
review:
Finally got to watch this last night and, while I enjoyed it, I was underwhelmed. I will admit, right off the top, that I enjoy the LOTR and Harry Potter books more than Narnia. Narnia is aimed at a younger audience, which I am no longer a part of, and are much preachier, which is to be expected.

The story was presented quite well, from what I remember from the book. The talking animals work well, although I felt that the beavers looked a bit cartoonish. The wolves were excellent.

Overall I was surprised at the lack of a WOW factor. There were no scenes that I looked back on as visually impressive. The CGI'd creatures were beautiful, and the flying ones I liked particularly, but good CGI is now a basic expectation of a big budget movie.

The characters are very two dimensional, although well played by the actors. Lucy's grin was annoying at times, but many 6 year olds are annoying at times, in real life. The Snow Queen was striking, the dwarfs were cool, but, in the end, I was left wanting more.

I will watch this again, I am sure, and I will go to the sequel(s), but this will never be a movie that I put into the DVD player myself. If I am in the mood for some epic fantasy, it will be The Two Towers. If I am in the mood for a fantasy aimed at children, I will put in Harry Potter.

title: A Cold War allegory for children of all ages
review: The despicable Russians turned a giant swath of this here earth into a squalid slum. They called it the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. How poetically tuneful. It was a daytime nightmare. It destroyed the life of Alexandr Solshenitsyn and killed the 40 million others who endured its sociopathy, and died. They died because the USSR was run by a psychopathic fraud, Joseph Stalin, who ran a psychotic government. It was a fraud. The 20th century was a disgrace which will live in the hearts of reasonable men as a great mistake. The little men and women, children of the blitzkrieg in London, faced a Leviathan of evil proportions: The Cold War. Into this scenario come the four children Peter, Edmund, Susan and Lucy, shipped off to rural England to escape the blitzkrieg of the Nazis- The Other Psychotic Dirtbags. Now, we begin. The cosseted innocents of the Blitzkrieg stumble into the New World Order of the icy thought-controlled world of Narnia. They are the descendants of Adam=Christians and Jews. The heroic struggle of the children and the animals of "magic Narnia" "thaws" the cold war, The Icy eternal winter of Narnia ends, and the new Jerusalem ensues. (Except for the Jews of course-since they are anathema.For some reason).Can't figure out why the Jews are treated so bad in this world.Too bad the Soviets didn't thaw out until 1989. Until their bankrupt economy gave out.

title: Engaging adventure film
review: Fine adventure film based on C. S. Lewis novel about two brothers and two sisters who magically enter a land where they must join forces with a lion king to fight an evil queen. The unknown actors who play the children are all quite capable without trying to be too cute. Swinton is perfect as the cold-blooded ice queen. The director keeps the story moving along at a good pace, as we are introduced to strange characters such as talking beavers and creatures that are half-horse/half-man. There may be some theological undertones but the movie, to its credit, does not dwell on them. Ultimately, however, the story gets pretty absurd, specially with the events concerning the lion.

title: WOW I'm almost speechless
review: I missed seeing this movie in theatres (i could kick myself really) but i bought it on DVD and wow! i was just shivering the whole time because i was just amazed by everything! the adaption took the book and really made a movie out of it by rearranging and adding bits without losing the magic that is narnia (opening scene was perfect whoever decided to add that is a genius)...the soundtrack was as stunning (from "go johnny" to the song for the ending credits) as the sets/cinematography (the beavers look great!)...all the actors were amazing too! i just could goon... i really truly recommend this movie whether you've read the book or not... my mom LOVED it (shes fallen asleep in all HP and LOTR movies lol BUT NOT narnia... don't get me wrong I'm a huge fan of all three fantasy series but that just says something...)

title: Leave it to the Beavers
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe is a fantastic movie. Worthy of a few awards? I would say so. Worthy of global praise? Well, it's not that great. Pretty much, C.S. Lewis's first children's novel has been made into a children's action movie. Adults all across the nation are saying that they would "prefer watching Fellowship of the Ring". Well, frankly, I found the entire LotR trilogy quite boring and too drawn out, and would much rather watch this one.

It follows the story of Pevensie children inside a large mansion while their father is away at war. They are playing hide-and-seek one day when the youngest, Susan, stumbles upon a wardrobe leading to the snowy land of Narnia. It starts out quite entertaining, and it stays that way for the longest of times. You see the White Witch, Mr. Tumnus, and Professor Kirke. And then...you meet the Beavers. Sadly, these horribly-animated creatures were not only annoying and slowed down the mood of the children's adventure, but they're also the reason many people consider this to be a child's movie.

Once the children arrive in Aslan's camp, however, the speed picks up again and the movie is A+ from then on. The most amazing part of this movie is the final battle. In my opinion, the Battle for Mordor looks like Mario Party compared to this epic conclusion. The most realistic CGI yet. Many people will say that they didn't like the ending, but it stayed true to Lewis's novel, so it's all fine in my book.

All in all, Narnia is a fantastic movie that will keep kids and adults entertained as long as they look more at the story and not the special effects.

title: Great movie with amazing visuals and good acting.
review:
The chronicles of Narnia is a book written by the late C.S. Lewis.The movie recently came on DVD.I went and purchased it.

The first ten minutes were very exciting, and I enjoyed them.After that, the movie started getting really slow, especially when they went into the professors house.When they got into Narnia things changed...

The visuals were spectacular, it was amazing how they took the many creatures of Narnia and made them look so realistic.The music was amazing!It was composed by Harry Gregson-Williams, the man who's music is in Metal Gear Solid series and also Kingdom of Heaven.The acting was amazing, Skandar Keynes and William Moseley did a great job acting.

Overall, the movie is 2 hours and 15 minutes long, but it was really well-done.I'd definitely recommend you to buy it.

title: Brilliant Film
review:
A really thrilling and moving picture. When I first saw it, I decided it was one of my favourite movies-it just was so great overall- the special effects, the actors, the setting- it was all so convincing.

At first I really wasn't happy since the BBC version had the witch as a brunette and in this version had a blonde; Tilda Swinton, so I thought it could drag down the originality, but when I watched the film, she was so convincing and set the character perfectly, and I didn't think there was a better actress.

In a way, it represents Christianity; I mean Aslan knew he was going to die, and he was crucified and then he rose again; that sort of represents when Jesus was crucified and then rose again.

I was convinced to read the book after watching the BBC version, and thought it was very good, but was disappointed because as I read the book, I pictured the scenes, the setting and the type of film in my head, and was annoyed that the original wasn't anything like what I wanted, but then when this one came out,it was thrilling and was exactly what I pictured and imagined it would be. To me it wasn't just a perfect Christmas film to watch with your family; it actually had an impact on me...it just moved me.

title: A film that judges critics
review: I am sure by now that most people know the story. I would suggest that our views of this motion picture are, far more than is the usual case, predicated not upon the movie as upon ourselves. This has been the case with other pictures as well, most notably Mel Gibson's "The Passion of the Christ". To rate "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" depends on what one brings to the film. For a Christian who loves Lewis, it is a 10. For a Christian who does not know or does not like Lewis, it is a 7. For a non-Christian who likes Lewis (and I have known at least one orthodox Jewish woman who loved Lewis) it is an 8 or 9. For a non-Christian who does not like Lewis, it is a 6. For a non-Christian who does not know Lewis, it is a 7. For an insecure post-Christian, it is a solid 1. For a mythical dispassionate viewer, for anyone who remembers his or her own best childhood hopes, it is 9. Better than the TV version because of the advances in special effects, this is a fil crammed with small and beautiful touches. But it does help if one likes cats!

title: Excellent and a great teacher of values!!
review:
This movie is superb! The messages that it delivers are moral, timely and most certainly of a strong Christian value. C.S.Lewis was an apologist for the Catholic faith and his story is filled with Christian symbolism especially the scene where Aslan is persecuted and humiliated by the minions of the White Witch and finally executed by her.

What more of a parallel can be drawn to the Passion of the Christ and his execution? When the stone table breaks that is the symbolism reflecting the destruction of the Temple at Christ's death and it goes without saying that Aslan's "rebirth is the Resurrection of Jesus all over again.

Peter's reluctant heroism is a message to us all. Hold fast to the truth regardless of the popular train of thought and fight for what you believe to be right with every ounce of your conviction.

Edmond's greed and his manipulation by the White Witch shows us that when we seek after personal satisfaction and gain, there is always a hidden price involved that we, unfortunately, discover far too late.

This movie has stunning visual effects and is suitable for young children BUT I feel it is important that a parent watch it with the child(ren) and take time to explain the parallels between the scenes and their moral equivalent.

title: Splendid adaptation of a childhood favourite
review: When I heard that Chronicles Of Narnia was coming to the screen as a big budget epic, I was ecstatic to say the least. Although I had never heard of the director before, he seemed in interviews to be really trying to stay true to the heart of the book. Finally, the first clips began to hit and I knew then that he had succeeded. Upon release of the film, I am proud to say that this is a near perfect adaptation of the first novel in the series The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe. From the period setting to the special effects that are full of wonder to the epic grandeur of the tale, Narnia delivers in every respect. All the children, though unknowns, turn in fine performances and Liam Neeson as the voice of Aslan is inspired casting. His rich tones give a sense of greatness to the lion king. The best performance of the film is that of Tilda Swinton as Jadis. She is just purely evil. The only real complaint that I have about the film is that the cyclops and a few other background creatures look incredibly fake. After wowing with so many other things in the movie, was there not enough budget left to create a makeup that didn't look like a Halloween mask? In the end, however, I am left hoping that this series will do well and get to carry on with further installments.

title: Great!
review: Oh my gosh! I love this movie so much! It's my favorite movie, then Pirates Of The Caribbean of course. (Johnny Depp;)) anyway. The creatures and stuff in here is so awesome. It's amazing how u guys can do that. The actors were all super. Lucy is so cute. Edmund is my favorite, cause well...I don't no. I just like him. Susan is pretty and smart. Peter is hot. Such good actors here. I can't wait to see Prince Caspain. I'm looking forward to it so much. Please don't wait until like A LONG TIME until it comes out. I really want to see it! Anyway i love this movie. It made me laugh, cry, and be happy. It's so magical and thats what i love about it. I wish I could enter a world like that. So cool. Better go now. again, great movie. Bye! P.S. I love u Will and Skandar!

title: Solid children's fantasy epic
review: This major theatrical adaptation by Disney of THE LION, THE WITCH and THE WARDROBE is not only faithful to the book, but an entertaining adventure film in its own right. It stands right up there with LORD OF THE RINGS and the HARRY POTTER films. Four siblings are shipped off during wartime to a distant relative in the country, and quickly discover a wardrobe that opens onto an alternate world, called Narnia, populated by talking animals and mythical creatures like griffins, centaurs and mermaids. The ruler of Narnia, a wise and compassionate lion named Aslan and voiced by Liam Neeson, is being challenged by the evil White Witch, played by veteran British actress Tilda Swinton, who may be a new face to many viewers here. After various adventures involving a helpful faun, fox and beaver family, a pack of extremely vicious wolves and Old St. Nick himself, the children join Aslan's army and do battle with the witch and her gruesome minions. The final battle may remind you of the final battle in LORD, but keep in mind LION was written before LORD. The actors playing the children are adorable and believable as siblings, the actors voicing the animals are for the most part OK, the special effects are seamless, and the music works 90 percent of the time. My only real complaint is the night scenes were much too dark, to the point I literally could not see what was going on in some scenes. I wonder what the director could have been thinking. Anyhow, see LION. This big-budget version (there are two previous TV adaptations and a wonderful cartoon) would not exist if it were not for HARRY POTTER, but LION is head and shoulders above the Potter films.

title: Fantastic
review: I went to see this movie a few days after it had come out with a friend of mine, without knowing anything about it. I was amazed! This film was gorgeous. I ended up seeing it 4 times in theaters. First of all, it follows the book very closely, something few directors bother to consider doing anymore(Harry Potter, anyone?). The characters, especially the four Pevensie children, were cast wonderfully. They truly acted as a family and I hope we'll see more from them in the future. Mr. Tumnus was great, as was the White Witch- perfectly true to both C.S. Lewis' and my imagination. Aslan was magnificent- I never doubted for a second that those children weren't talking to a real lion. It was shot beautifully, in New Zealand and the Czech Republic. The special effects were wonderful- all sorts of wide and beautiful shots. And of course, each one was accompanied by Harry Gregson-Williams' haunting and beautiful musical scores, perfect for the tone and feel of the film. It was really a treat, and each time I left the theater satisfied. I encourage everyone- children who love the books, adults, even grandparents- to go see this movie. It was a perfect realization of Lewis' magical world.

title: Best movie in the universe!
review:
This movie is the best movie I've ever seen in my life!!!!! It's fab-u-lous! I recommend you to see this movie right now. If you haven't seen it, you missed out on it. But on Tuesday, April 4th it's going to come out. I'm so totally going to buy it and you should, too. And, just to let you know, you're not waisting your time watching it. And if anybody tells you that you are, don't believe them (well, you can, but I wouldn't b/c it's great) b/c it's wonderful. And it's great for parents and kids.

"Once a King or Queen in Narnia, always a King or Queen in Narnia"-Aslan- The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the witch, and the Wardrobe

title: Best Movie EVER.
review:
Homigawd this movie is SO good.

I know this wont help much people, but for serious... I saw this 5 times in the theater.. and I can't wait until April 4th when it comes out on DVD.

The special effects are awesome, the makeup won a Grammy. The music IS SUPERB. The actors are very nice looking *coughWilliamMoseleycough* It's great!

The whole scene with the battle makes me shiver, the music is climactic, and its a perfect example of how something as in going to another world can change you.

title: An Excellent Tribute to CS Lewis's Classic
review:
If anyone tries to tell you that this movie is boring, unconvincing, and has crappy special effects, don't listen to them. After reading a few of the user comments about this movie here on IMDb, one major trend I saw was that people thought that A, it was boring, B, it had bad special effects, and C, it was not a good adaptation. All 3 of these are completely wrong.

First of all, this film is anything but boring. The child actors chosen for the parts are the best choice in the world. These children play their parts to perfection, and they are completely believable as the Pevensie family. They are talented, believable, emotional, and they gel unbelievably well as brothers and sisters. I never once questioned their bond as siblings. They just....fit. Lucy's wide-eyed wonder when she first enters Narnia is magical...in fact Andrew Adamson specifically did not show the actress the set until that day...she was brought in blindfolded so that her expression of joy when the blindfold was taken off could be fully captured on camera. People's accusations for the boringness of the film are only due to the fact that the children take awhile to get to Narnia. If you are looking for a slam-bang movie with nonstop action, Narnia is not for you. It is a sweet, loving, tale with some mighty fine action in there, but with a core of four young kids in a foreign land, forced to become heroes by living up to the prophecy about them. I greatly respected the filmmakers choice to not try force the children into Narnia right away, without any back-story. The whole set up of the bombing in London, then the train trip to the house, then the hide and go seek game...it all worked perfectly to give the audience time to absorb, learn, and understand the characters of these children. Without this set-up...they wouldn't really be anything else than excuses to have action. The way the film works, with about an hour before any major action, is excellent.

As for the bad special effects accusation...this is simply absurd. The Chronicles of Narnia had some of the best special effects of the year, and the only picture that out-did it, I believe, was King Kong, whose special effects were mind-boggling. Nevertheless, Narnia's fx are a wonder to behold. They are so seamlessly integrated throughout the the film that everything seems incredibly real. The beavers, especially, are two of the most cute and believable CGI creations I have ever seen, including Gollum from the Lord of the Rings trilogy. The wolves are also really well done. The final battle scene is perfect - the special effects pound at you for a good ten or fifteen minutes at the great clash between good and evil. Of course, the scale is nothing like Lord of the Rings, but Narnia is not meant to be a replacement for Lord of the Rings. It is meant as a tale in its own right....don't put comparisons on it that aren't meant or needed. For itself, it is a good action epic, and the special fx rival Lord of the Rings, even though the scale is not as grand. The greatest special fx creature in the movie, though, would be Aslan. Aslan is the most beautiful CGI creation I have ever seen on screen. Neither Kong nor Gollum, are beautiful, but Aslan is just that. He has just the ethereal, not quite real touch to make him believable as the Savior figure he is. His anger is mighty to behold, and his mane flows like the waves of the ocean.

Now for C - the accusation that the movie is a bad adaptation of a book. Making a movie out of a book is always tricky. You are never going to satisfy everybody, and you are never going to displease everybody. There are always some people out there who seem to think that a book is easy to translate into a movie. Well, here's news: It's not. Good movies made from books are few and far between, and for good reason: it's not easy making the transition. The screenplay writer/director has to make cuts, he has to NOT include everything. If everything in The Lion, the Witch, and the Wadrobe had been included, we'd be staring at a five hour movie. The director's and screenplay writer's ability to translate the book into a two and a half hour movie is admirable. And they did it while still maintaining the heart and soul of CS Lewis's classic. Some things had to be cut, and also - the movie is a movie, and should be judged as one. Movies are a completely different genre than books - there are things you can do in books which you can never do in movies, and there are things you can do in movies that you could never do in books. Narnia does an excellent job of taking a classic and making a perfectly admirable movie.

In closing, Narnia is one of the best films of the year. I highly recommend it - and don't listen to anyone who tries to tell you that it's a bad movie.

title: Good!!, As Expected.
review:
I have never read the book before but i heard this is million times better. Anyway from my experience this is without doubt one very satisfying movie to watch. As of expected, just like in the trailer.

The movie is very constance in pace and is always something in the movie. I say the movie have been done pretty well. Especially the casting of the kids, it is marvelous. But despite all the goodness, i still feel the movie is lacking of something, and the story is a little too brief and concentrate on the younger audience. The CGI is very well done.

Final Words: This is one very entertaining movie to watch no matter how old you are. But more on the kid side. And it sure make a great Saturday night movie to watch with family.

Rating: 8/10 (Grade: A-)

Please Rate Yes/No After Reading, Thanks!!!

title: Not what I expected
review: This movie will suffer heavy criticism because of the enormity of the Lord of The Rings masterpiece. It is hard not to compare the two. Going into the film I fully expected a full force 2005 high-tech fantasy epic. This is what was promoted by the movie company. What I got was a kids movie. The movie itself was watchable but a huge disappointment. Zero character development. Zero thrills. The movie lacked everything needed for a good fantasy. The writers tried to cram too many events into a short time. What you get is an annoying stream of plot important events that all happen to quickly with no back-story. This movie is not for adults and barely for fantasy fans. Its too bad that the awesome Narnia books had to come to the screen as this lame kid flick.

title: awesome movie
review:
Caution, man, this review has a spoiler of the best part of the movie.

dude, bro, the best part of this whole movie was when the kids were talking about something with the old guy professor, and while they were talking about something he totally just busted out his big pipe and started smokin' a bowl. that was awesome. Me and my buddies went and saw this all together and we all agreed this was the best part. In conclusion, this is a movie that really met me where I'm at, and spoke to my heart. huh?? I need to have 10 lines to post a comment?!?! What? 10 Linez? What else do I need to tell you about this awesome movie, with the pipe smoking guy. Talk about Chronic-cles! Oh yeah! You know what I mean! Go watch this movie, and then go see "Slasher in the House", ever since I saw that one I don't offer people beer on the side of the road anymore.

title: A nice addition to the fantasy movie family
review:
There are two fantasy movie series which Narnia can be compared to and they are, of course, Harry Potter and Lord Of the Rings. Of those two I'd go a bit more towards Potter than LOTR, as the film clearly was aimed towards younger audience than LOTR. But what comes to over all appearance of the film it goes heavily towards LOTR.

My opening babbling doesn't mean, that Chornicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe would be a clear copy and mix of the two. The story elements are there: the growth of children to become heroes of Narnia, the fears of children in war. But the execution of the film differs, as Narnia relies on Christian thematics and morals in its story line.

I recently read the book before seeing the film, and I can say, that the book is more blatantly religious than the film, tough the main elements are present: daughters of Eve, sons of Adam, Aslan, the Judas theme etc., but they aren't so heavily underlined as they were in the book.

The story has gone under some changes, even tough it's pretty faithful to the book in general. It's just the fact, that the book is rather short and some things aren't explained. Lewis had the knack of just skipping some elements and going somewhere else. Now the film begins with raid over Britain, where we see the reason why the kids are sent away from London and the bombings of the German troops. There are some adventurous scenes added in the middle of the story, but other than that the film is pretty accurate display of the book.

The most thrilling thing in the film is magnificently made Aslan, voice by Liam Neeson. It's both real and surreal at the same time, just like the other animal characters of the film. But it's the Aslan who stands out the crowd.

I was pleasantly surprised with the film, as I didn't expect to like it very much, but I did.
