The battle was a spectacular sequence, with all the creatures doing battle. The acting was one of the weaker elements of the film. The four lead children while doing good jobs, didn't reach a performance that emotionally grabbed you. Though Georgie Henley as Lucy really takes your heart, she has so much talent for such a young girl. Tilda Swinton was really cold hearted as the White Witch, though i felt she could have gone further and brought an even more menacing performance, where ever word she said was just tainted with coldness. The voice talent of the creatures was also great. Ray Winstone and Dawn French do great jobs as Mr. and Mrs. Beaver.

The Chronicles of Naria: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe does fall short on the epic grandeur that it was aiming for, yet it doesn't fall short of a wonderful family movie that will captivate your imagination and bring that inner child back to life.

title: If you're a fan of the books, go see the film while it's in theaters!!!
review:
Acting: Knowing that they spent several years looking for the right children for the main characters, it doesn't really come as a surprise that they're all amazing actors although in most of the cases if not all, this is the first thing they've ever done. Wonderful performances from all of them. As Lucy is the character that first leads us into Narnia though, it is the part they just had to get right for the movie to work. Georgie Henley does a great job of portraying the sense of magic this story is all about and you really see it in her eyes as she stumbles into the land of a 100 years of winter. All the voice actors also do truly remarkable things with their roles and Liam Neason did a surprisingly effective job with Aslan. It's a sad thing we never get to hear Brian Cox do the voice, but Neason is such a professional and as it turns out he is perfect for the role. I have to mention James Mcavoy as Tumnus also as he gives life to some of the most memorable scenes in the film. Tilda Swinton, doing the white witch Jadis as only she could have done, is now rightfully circling around in "for your consideration" ads. Give her an Oscar will you!?

Directing: SomehowAndrew Adamson was always the right way to go with this one as he's just as big a fan of the books as everyone reading this review. He really pulled it off, and made this into one of the best films of all time, one that will be remembered for years to come.

Digital Effects: I'm running out of superlatives here. This is some of the best, if not THE best work in visual effects history to this date. You just can't get a higher grade when you're making the audience watching the animals talk, not only believe that they're real, but also not thinking about that they're computer generated characters. This way, instead of concentrating on how lifelike the characters look, you can concentrate on what the character says and thus experience the full performance of the actor doing the voice. The voices, combined with the state of the art VFX makes these creatures, through the books already loved by hundreds of millions of people around the world, REALLY come to life. Watching Aslan walk among his people is like going to the Zoo looking at a real life animal. It looks that realistic. This is the movie upon people will be judging all future work done in visual effects.

Music: Being a fan of the 80's BBC TV series it made me a bit nervous the first time i was about to hear Harry Gregson Williams score. I mean, Geoffry Burgon's main theme for the TV series had since my childhood always been close to my heart. I was not to be disappointed though as the score for this film is so much more epic in scale than even Howard Shore's Lord of The Rings outings. It is every bit as magical as Narnia itself. This score shines in it's full glory in the most important of scenes. From entering the Wardrobe, meeting Tumnus and playing the Narnian lullaby to going into full battle with the white witch this is an epic score to be remembered. It is also already nominated for a golden globe together with one for best song.

Adaptation: The changes made for adapting the book into a film all come off natural and nothing ever seem out of place or order, they enhance the value of the film. The most notable scenes added being the conversation between Edmund and Tumnus in the dungeon and being attacked by Maugrim and friends on the frozen river. These are both so great and so well directed that they seem like they were written by the hand of C.S. Lewis himself. As for adding a touching opening of war-struck London and making the end battle longer and more exciting than in the book (and in your imagination) well that's something i think no one would argue with. Of course it had to be done. It is as natural as making the girls more active in the battle scenes. Some of the dialog in the scenes with Tumnus seemed a bit too modern the first time i saw it though, but i kind of liked it the second and third time i saw it.

Costumes: From the 40'ish clothes worn by the kids to all the armor worn i battle this film has it all. It really shows that they spent just as much time and effort on detail for this to come alive as they did in the lord of the rings productions. But it's done by the same people at Weta, so that is a given.

Makeup/Prosthetics: KNB FX? Ever ever heard of these guys? Of course you have, these guys are legends. The makeup and prosthetics for this film is every bit as groundbreaking as the visual effects. Howard and co. i know you wanted the centaurs in this film to be the centaurs upon all centaurs will be judged. Well you've done it! The same goes with all the other creatures.

End grade for this film is 10 out of 10 as it is the best film i have ever seen, and i would like to say that i hope the academy recognizes this as such, but as they generally go for drama in the best picture category it feels like kind of a stretch. However Return of the king got nominated and i think it's only true to say that The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe has every bit as much drama as that film.

title: Does not compare to Lord Of the Rings or Harry Potter
review:
Andrew Adamson, the director (Shrek) should stick to animated films. The Chronicles of Narnia is a very limp film in his hands. The first hour of the film crawls at a snail's pace. The four children have to carry the film but they aren't interesting enough to do it. One plot point of the book is that the younger boy, Edmund, becomes bound to the White Witch and has to redeem himself in the end, but in this film all he does is accept some Turkish delight (candy) from the witch. Big deal. I thought the four kids were very unappealing.

The second part of the film is a battle after we meet Aslan, the lion, voiced by Liam Neeson who sounds exactly like Liam Neeson and to my ears I could never get past that.

It's fair to compare this film to other movies in the genre, namely the Lord of the Rings and the Harry Potter films. Narnia lacks the magical touches of Potter and the epic vision of LOTR.

title: The most violent Disney movie I've seen
review: The movie adaptation of the cult classic book The Chornicles of Narnia: The Lion the Witch and the Wardorbe arrives in theaters on December 9, 2005 (San Diego). Just six days before the release date of its competition King Kong. Families from all walks of life will come to an agreement that CNLWW is the best way of ending 2005 with a bang. The parental guidance rating is almost deceitful because of the action content this movie radiates. It is some what controversial when the question is asked, is this movie too much for my child to see? CNLWW is the most violent Disney film I've seen. In the end, CNLWW is a well rounded film that deserves what it will get ... praise.

title: beautiful, great acting, soulless
review:
I'm a Narnia fan (have re-read all the books every 2 years or so for fifteen years now) and went to the movie excitedly and open-mindedly. It's hard to satisfy fans who know the stories so well and love them as they are: but Peter Jackson completely satisfied me with Lord of the Rings, despite the changes he'd made. So I was hopeful.

I was very struck, as others have posted, by how beautifully-made the film was. The acting and voices, too, were superb, as were all the effects and props. Yet I am completely dissatisfied.

Why? It seems the "soul" has been excised from the story. Why did the director (or screenwriter) make so many bloody changes that seemed to contribute nothing to the story, or even detract? For instance, why was Aslan's "children why are you following me" line changed to "shouldn't you be in bed"? That seems a definite unimprovement, and was echoed by many other changes. Was Disney's PC squad on the loose, cutting out anything that seemed too religious? Regardless of the cause, all the deep spirituality and gravitas--the things which made the books spellbinding (and I'm not even a Christian, but rather a Baha'i)--have been removed or changed. Meanwhile, much angst was added that wasn't in the original story, such as Peter's repeated squeamishness, and all the too-dwelled-upon sibling stuff. And then the gorgeous Narnia that was created, including special new touches such as the phoenix, was flashed too briefly before our eyes.

I think this movie sapped the soul out of Narnia, despite the brilliant work done by nearly everyone involved. The culprits seem to have been story-monkeying, and a failure to allow us to experience what is truly enthralling about the Narnia story, including a failure to allow us to dwell long enough in what of Narnia had been brilliantly created.

Alas, with a salute to the acting, cinematography, and rendering, I sigh and go back to the books. The door is still open for someone to capture Narnia. I hope that by "The Voyage of the Dawn-Treader" and "The Last Battle" someone gets it right. Put the soul back in. It's not Christian, it's spiritual, and please leave it that way, gravitas intact.

title: Dianna
review: I thought the movie was awesome. I have read the books and am a fan. The movie followed the book really well. It is really great movie. I think even if you haven't read the books before you will still find the movie to be good, and you may even want to start reading the books. I hope that all of C. S. Lewis's books will be made into movies because I'm looking forward to them and sure they will be a great hit. The movie has a really good plot. It gets you really interested in it. It is very adventurous and exciting. Once you start watching you wont want to get up and leave for anything. It shows you how fairy tales and magic lands aren't childish and boring and how fun and exciting they can really be. The movie is awesome and i recommend everyone to see it.

title: Better than King Kong
review: This movie was amazing. I recommend this to anyone. The story takes place around the time of WWII. Showing the Germans bombing of England. Parent heartbreakingly having to send their children into the country to keep them safe. The scene at the train station was done very well. I heard many of the women weeping in the audience. The children arriving in the country really showed the difference between the bombed out imagery & the quiet countryside. Very well done. The imagery in Narnia was breathtaking, the acting was superb & the plot made sense. My family saw this & King Kong. We all decided unanimously that this was a much better film. The little girl was spectacular. Her eyes were so expressive many times they told the story. The Queen was evil but beautiful a perfect casting. Azlan really took your breath away. The detail on all the animals was done to such detail you weren't sure which was really & which were not. I would not miss this beautifully done drama. Take your family & watch with amazement.

title: Narnia, for who?
review:
The special effects were great. The talking animals were the most real I've ever seen on the screen. Their facial features were fluid even when they talked--without being "over-animated." By far the best role in the movie was the White Witch (Swinton was a near perfect match for Jadis).

HOWEVER

WHAT audience is this movie for?! Certainly not for children due situations like the uncannily LOTR-like "orks" fighting on behalf of the White Witch. Anyone with a child under the age of nine or ten could not possible watch this movie comfortably as a result of the child's burying his or her head into their lap or asking to leave because its "so scary." Those "orks" are pretty damn scary and considering that 3/4 of the theater I was sitting in was filled with families of this nature got to be really annoying. Should they know better? How can they not?! We have come to be a slightly leery of Disney productions due to its more mature pieces such as Pirates of the Caribbean and what not and so that was not the issue. The issue is when McDonalds starts making happy meal toys out of it. Promotions such as these are what makes little kids come see the movie and get the crap scared out of them. However, once again, WHO were these people supposed to market for? There is no blood, the fight scenes exist but they are cheesed up so as not to scare a younger audience. This detracts from any sort of realistic experience of Narnia that a reader and rather avid fan of the book such as myself would hope to achieve through seeing this movie. Obviously it is exclusively for readers of Lewis' actual Chronicals. Anyone who has not read the book has no idea what they are in for and essentially sits through a movie of the little rascals meets LOTR and wind in the willows. Granted, anyone who knows Lewis' Christian motives understands that the events and characters all have deep and heavy symbolism attached to them. However, even for fans of the books,there were too many loose ends not covered in the film. A prime example is when Aslan is "sacrificed" on the stone altar. Obviously a crucifixion reference. However, he just gets up and changes the rules without there being the slightest hint or reference that there were so many intricate "rules" of Narnia that could be changed or reinterpreted to begin with. There were some glossings over but no one, especially as an outsider to the book would really know what was going on.

As I said before the best part in the entire movie was done by the White Witch. The children themselves were not marketable in acting skills or in looks. Bravo on the voice of Aslan, Liam Neeson was a perfect choice. The set, of course, was beautiful and the costumes were superb as well. I loved the faun. McAvoy was perfect for the role. I do not recommend going to the theater to see this movie. At best, I can see myself one day showing it to by ten year old when he or she is sick in bed with the flu and slightly too delirious off of Nyquil to piece all of the film together anyhow. That is quite possibly the only audience who could gain full satisfaction from this work.

title: Our Comments
review: We liked it. Go see it. Mr. Tumnus and the Witch were hot. We know we're not being helpful, but we don't want to spoil things. Go see it, now. We cried ... a lot ... in the beginning of the movie. Bring tissues. Lucie was so cute. We need to have ten lines of text in order to submit this, so we're going to continue being unhelpful. The credits are long and fun to watch. Don't leave immediately when they start, because the movie is not over. I repeat, NOT OVER. You'll miss something ... yes, something, so stay. Okay, how many more lines? 3? 4? What else can we say? You may not know this, but Narnia is a Christian metaphor. It's really very allegorical and metaphorical, it's practically unrecognizable. That was sarcasm. Lots of sarcasm. Bye bye. P.S. The Witch and Mr. Tumnus are really hot.

title: i love the movie i want to try to meat Skandar and William PLEASE! HELP!
review: o my god i loved this movie i thought it was the best movie ever i really liked peter and Edmund's parts in it cause peter was so brave for his family and Edmund came back to his family i thought it was great and i also like the scene with Lucy and Mr Thomas it was so cool i loved it IT WAS MAgnificent i just really would give it extra bonus points i loved the special features i thought it was better than lord of the rings um it was just great i hope they come out with a second one HOPING! please contact me at317-272-2283 to give me info on how to meet the cast i'll pay i'm a huge fan i love it Andrew Adamson your the best!i loved it your my greatest people and i'm your greatest fan

title: "If it's a war Aslan wants, it's a war he shall get." - White Witch
review:
There really couldn't have been a worse time for 'The Chronicles of Narnia ' to be released in theaters in my opinion. It was released right on the tale of the much more elaborate 'King Kong' which will no doubt beat the hell out of it with box-office numbers. I really didn't know what to expect from 'Chronicles of Narnia'. In my mind it could have either been a really great action-packed, visually stunning film or it could have been a childish sappy-as-hell flop. Well, my thoughts after leaving the movie theater playing 'Chronicles of Narnia' were somewhere in between, but closer to the positive. 'Chronicles of Narnia' has real excellent special effects and action, but in a way the film takes itself way too seriously. There are parts so sappy they make you feel almost embarrassed to be in the theater, but there are parts so amazing from a visual effects stance that you can't take your eyes away from the screen. Although there are parts of 'Narnia' I didn't really get into it, I enjoyed it for the most part.

'The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' takes place during WWII. Four children, Peter (William Moseley), Susan (Anna Popplewell), Edmund (Skander Keyes) and Lucy (Georgie Henley), are transported out of England to safety to live with their Uncle the professor (Academy Award Winner Jim Broadbent - Iris). While staying with their Uncle, the kids discover a passage way to another ice-covered fantasy world (Narnia) in a old wardrobe closet. In the land the it is up to the four to save the good guys led by a gigantic, fierce yet wise and lovable lion, Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson) from the evil White Witch who calls herself the Queen (Tilda Swinton - The War Zone, Broken Flowers). The film also features a lovable beaver who helps the kids (voiced by Ray Winstone - The War Zone, Sexy Beast), Father Christmas or Santa Claus who also helps the kids (James Cosmo - Trainspotting) and Mr. Tumnus, a half-man/half-goat (played by James McAvory).

Like I had mentioned previously the action and effects in Narnia are amazing to say the least, but the story kind of drags. I felt in my heart that the beloved children's story could have been adapted to film better script-wise. The acting is kind of a mixed bags. The adult actors are all fantastic - Jim Broadbent, Tilda Swinton, Liam Neeson, Ray Winstone and James McAvory, but the kids kind of split. Skander Keyes and Georgie Henley are the two-standouts of the kids who both give great performances, while the two older kids William Moseley and Anna Popplewell are to put it nicely "less impressive". Andrew Adamson's direction is surprisingly very good, with a lot of neat camera tricks and cinematography.

If you are into the action / fantasy films I can recommend 'Chronicles of Narnia', but only after you've seen the modern-day masterpiece King Kong (also in theaters). 'Narnia' is a film to take the little ones to and I don't find anything wrong with it that wouldn't be appropriate for kids 5 and up. Grade: B- (screened at Harkins Arrowhead 18, Glendale, Arizona, 12/19/05)

title: Excellent Film
review:
This truly was one of the most phenomenal movies of 2005. The acting, story, and special effects were GREAT. I saw it twice in the theaters, and hope to get the DVD, as soon as it comes out. There is also a video game, which I hope to get for Christmas.

First of all, I think the story was just unbelievable. The book isn't very descriptive, and the director and producers did a fabulous job illustrating the story and highlighting the main events. The color was unbelievable, and the length was perfect. The bombing scene at the beginning really gave the film a strong starting point. The story could have suited to be a bit more gory, but hey, how much blood and guts can you fill a PG movie with? Even for teenagers, the story was great.

The costumes and music were also great. The orchestra was wonderful, and the Narnia Lullaby was so pretty. The dresses and suits of armor that the Pevensie children wore was great. The cast selection was perfect. This was really a great movie.

title: Disappointing
review:
I am a die hard Narnia fan so I am bound to be a little critical, but I went to see this film with an open mind as possible.

Let me start by saying that the film doesn't even come close to the brilliant BBC series of some years ago, so if you watched and loved those you may be better off giving this film a miss and see if you can pick up a copy of the BBC version on DVD instead.

Positive points are the performances. I often find child actors a little too cutesy or unnatural, but there wasn't a moment I felt that during this film. Lucy Pevensie in particular was brilliant. Any stars I've given this are down to the cast.

Now the downers. This may not bother everyone, but the CGI effects were shoddy and inconsistent - as if the artists working on it had been comprised of a team of people who never met during the entire production. This was not quite as bad as the green/blue screen moments, however, which had all the artistry and subtlety of Peter Kay's Amarillo video. How on earth those scenes made the final cut, I'll never know. One particular scene has a painted backdrop which is similarly poorly finished, so it seems there were problems in many areas of production. It was like watching an unpolished version for a test audience - only it wasn't and we weren't.

Overall, I would not recommend this if clumsy continuity errors (of which there are too many to list here), poor attention to detail and bad computer work bother you. If not then the children's performances, Tumnus and Aslan will impress you and you may enjoy yourself. If you just adore the book and would love to see an on screen adaptation, try to get your mits on the BBC version.

title: Okay but not great (spoiler)
review:
I thought the ambiance was great, both before the children arrive in Narnia and after they get there; the casting of the children and other characters, looks-wise, was also excellent. Tilda Swinton as the White Witch was the best thing about the movie.

The efforts to provide psychological credibility were not convincing--perhaps the screenwriters should have focused on the plot and the pleasures Narnia offers, such as great food, more, as the books do. Peter and Susan were a bit wooden; Edmund and Lucy better. (May not be their fault--Edmund and Lucy have better parts.) Although much has been made about the decision to "allow" Susan to fight in the battle as an advance toward gender equality, I was bothered by the pervasively dismissive attitude toward women and the "lesson" that patriarchal order must be maintained at all costs. Mrs. Macready is needlessly bitchy; Susan is depicted as a whiner and a nag; Mrs. Beaver is insulted by her husband repeatedly and not acknowledged as the wonderful motherly and capable personality she is in the book--the books did not betray their misogyny so openly. Some of the things added to the plot, such as the direct pursuit of the children and the beavers by the WW and the entirely gratuitous icy river scene didn't do much for me; I wish, though, that more had been done connecting the beginning in London during the Blitz with the events in Narnia.

The conclusion was a bit choppy and too much time was spent on the battle, for my taste. Also too many echoes of Lord of the Rings (movie) there for it to feel original and independent.

title: Great for kids But...
review:
I watched this movie with great expectations which were only partly fulfilled. This movie has way too much pathos, kitsch, stereotypes and odd twits. I found some scenes embarrassing for their mannerism. Resemblances with "Lord of the Rings" are also striking. There are several scenes I found quite irritating: First, the children get weapons from Santa Claus as Christmas presents. Secondly, in the Battle air raid is being applied as in "real life" - the Second World War.

Maybe this film is more suitable for kids and the American audience.

Acting was overall good. Visual effects with some exceptions are great. Especially at the beginning moods are described very well.

Watch it with your kids they will have an awful lot of fun and enjoy nice visual effects!

title: WHat's the right age to enjoy this movie?
review:
I went to see this movie without my 4 years old, as I watched the trailer and contained too many scary characters. I'm glad I did as I'm sure it's able to scare small (minor than 8) children, but I also found the movie to be not as attractive to adult audience as was Lord of the Rings or to a teenager as Harry Potter is.

I'm also kind of disappointed as I saw too many edited scenes and cuts in the sequence, several questions raised how did they...? what happened to..? MMM...I still don't know if it was so great as I think it was going to be.

I think the director hurried up to have this movie ready and in order to gain timing they missed up some very important development in the story, we will have to wait to see if the following parts will be better than this one.

title: bah... below my age group
review:
This movie is totally for kids. In my opinion, this movie wasn't that bad, but didn't fit me because it was out of my age group. Though I never read the book before, I was hungry for a fantasy movie.

The storyline was okay. But as i said, childish.

The music was okay. If there was anything good about this film, it was the music, went pretty good with the movie.

The acting was okay. Nothing over the top, except for the queen, which it felt weird watching her fight.

The effects was okay. Nothing over the top, I expected more from W.E.T.A workshop. But its not like the details would of been noticed anyway, the camera quickly glimpses the actors, you don't even notice the wardrobes and weapons and all that stuff.

In general, this movie was okay, just that it was a little childish, despite having a huge battle scene at the end which did nothing for me. A great movie should have a ending that I should remember for a while, but this movie just ended in a plain way.

title: Nicely done
review:
MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS (for the tiny minority who haven't actually read the books)

Even after seeing the impressive trailers for The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe over the past month or so, I still wasn't quite sure what to expect.

Were the kids going to be any good? Was New Zealand really going to be able to double up as Middle Earth AND Narnia? And could they really manage to stretch out a rather thin book into a two hour plus film? Thankfully, Andrew Adamson and the magicians with WETA have produced one of the best movies I've seen this year. And it's absolutely gorgeous. Although it lacks some of the grandeur of Peter Jacksons LOTR trilogy, the results are actually much better at times - with Narnia becoming a more sumptuous, understated landscape than some of Tolkien's over-the-top world.

And, thankfully, the wonder of the book has been captured perfectly. The early scenes of the Pevensie children being evacuated from Blitz-hit London are heart-wrenching, while Lucy's first discovery of the world inside the wardrobe fills you with as much delight as you got when reading the book as a child. Then when the rest of the family discover Narnia as well....it just gets better and better.

Tilda Swinton is very good as the White Witch - displaying the right kind of frosty malevolence that the role deserves. Inspired casting has seen Ray Winstone and Dawn French provide the perfect voices for the beavers, while Liam Neeson lends more than enough gravitas to Aslan. And, thankfully, the kids are perfect choices for the roles. Instead of their slightly two dimensional counterparts on the Harry Potter series, the Pevensie clan are actually believable as unwilling visitors in Narnia. Peter and Susan are great as the elder siblings on the lookout for the younger sister and brother, while Lucy practically steals the movie at times. And it's nice to see that they managed to pick a suitably moody, sulky Edmund too.

A few minor quibbles aside (an American Maugrim for one, and the lack of real emotion during Aslan's sacrifice at the hands of the Witch), it's the kind of epic fantasy that was sorely missing last Christmas. At times emotional, beautiful and comical it's likely to delight young and old fans alike. Go and watch it.

title: I love this movie.
review: This is one of the best movies I have ever seen. I loved it so much because it was action packed and had a great plot and story line. Also, the older brother in the movie (Actor: William Moseley) named Peter was so Hot. I advise everyone to go see this movie. It is great for all ages. I also suggest everyone to buy it when it comes out on DVD. This is my favorite movie in the whole world now. I think the director did a very good job of directing this film. Also the actors were perfect for their parts. This movie was very enjoyable. I have seen this movie twice now and will probably go to see it many more times. Again, if you have not yet seen this movie you should go see it. You will not be disappointed.

title: An eighties child through and through
review: A very poor attempt at improvement for those of us old enough to enjoy the BBC version. My advice is read the book - the "special" effects aren't "special" (remember Blue Peter riding on Aslan?!?), and as with so many films they try to cram so much into such a short space of time that it becomes disjointed, loses all semblance of a story and becomes a producer's excuse to show off - which in this case pays off poorly. I can understand why it has received higher ratings: it is harmless, has morals and stirs up the warm glow inside all of us, but at the end of the day, it has been done better before (just not for cinema or DVD). Sometimes the beauty in the story is the understanding of the plot, of the weekly wait for the next installment, and the development of the characters; this film had none of these and I feel for all those people who rated it highly, as they had obviously missed out on the regular weekend episodes which chronicled Narnia when I was a child (And no, it wasn't that long ago, and yes, I didn't think I'd be catching myself writing those "In my days...." comments yet!).

title: Pretty Good
review: I have not yet read the books, but my husband really wanted to see the movie so we went last night. I thought the movie was pretty OK. It seemed to drag a bit in the beginning, but once the kids arrived in Narnia, the action picked up over the last half or so of the movie. I thought the boy who played Peter was very good, and has the look of a young Heath Ledger. All the actors where very good, with the White Witch being super. I thought that the animation was good, although I had seen a "Making of" special on TV, so I knew where the animation was. I have purchased the complete Chronicles of Narnia and am looking forward to reading them all before the next movie, hinted at, comes out.

title: Judas Redemption
review:
"The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" based on the C.S. Lewis novel has a long title, and is a great movie. It is one of the year's best. Director Andrew Adamson and screenwriters Ann Peacock, Adamson, Christopher Markus, and Stephen McFeely bring to life Lewis's story of four children's journey to the fantastical kingdom of Narnia. This maybe Disney's "Lord of the Ring"-- a wise selection. Director Adamson creates a visually stunning live action tale seamlessly incorporating state-of-the art CGI, and classic compelling storytelling. Adamson also keeps our focus on this story thread despite such distractions as talking animals and mythical creatures which are an integral part of the context.

During the beginning of World War II, Peter (William Moseley), Susan (Anna Popplewell), Edmund (Skandar Keynes), and Lucy (Georgia Henley), are sent to live with an eccentric relative Professor Kirke (Jim Broadbent) somewhere in the English countryside. Away from their mother, the children make the best of their situation. While playing their favorite game of hide-and-seek, the youngest Lucy enters the upstairs wardrobe, and finds herself in another world, Narnia. Lucy befriends Mr. Tumnus (James McAvoy), a faun or half-man creature. From Mr. Tumnus, Lucy discovers that Narnia is ruled by the evil White Witch (the amazing Tilda Swinton) where it has been winter for 100 years without Christmas. Upon returning through the wardrobe, Lucy tells Peter, Susan, and Edmund. They do not believe her story. However, Edmund happens upon Narnia through the wardrobe, and aligns with the White Witch. The White Witch is aware of the prophesy involving the sons and daughters of Adam. Eventually Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy all enter Narnia. They learn from Mr. and Mrs. Beaver that the White Witch's reign will soon end with the return of the legendary lion leader Asland (perfectly voiced by Liam Neeson).

Alsand is literally and metaphorically the messiah in C.S. Lewis's story. Edmund (Keynes), forced into loyalty to the White Witch, is the story's Judas. He betrays Peter, Susan, Lucy and ultimately Asland, unknowingly becoming the White Witch's pawn. The courageous and noble Asland gives his word to the malevolent White Witch in this epic battle of good and evil. Perhaps the difference in this parable, Adamson and Lewis offer the possibility of redemption for this story's Judas-- Edmund.

Andrew Adamson is the great storyteller in "The Chronicles of Narnia." "Narnia" is an epic tale of sacrifice and redemption that beautifully captures the wonder and awe of children embodied in Lucy. Georgia Henley gives Lucy a great soul, innocence and courage. Her touching bond to the charismatic Asland (Neeson) is the heart of "Narnia". Tilda Swinton is a powerful dark presence as the White Witch. Swinton as the Witch is such a threatening force. Liam Neeson perfectly voices Asland. Neeson too is an amazing presence. His Asland is wise and noble, also hinting at great anger and great power. The clash of wills between Asland and the White Witch is compelling. Adamson's "The Chronicles of Narnia" is classic storytelling of a timeless story, well worth watching.

title: Pretty Cool, Needs more Centaurs, though
review: This was a pretty awesome movie. They definitely should have put more Centaurs in it, though. It was cool to see a centaur fight a minotaur, but that was just at the big battle at the end. The whole movie should have been centaurs and minotaurs fighting. Centaurs are way cooler than little English kids. The lion, Azzlan, he was cool. The goat boy, portrayed by Justin Timberlake, was okay. The Ice Queen lady should take a shower, and use Pert Plus. This just proves that White Women with dreads are evil. Anyway, lots of "blahhh" stuff in this movie, with a few incredible fight scenes and tons of cool centaurs. "King Kong" is about 40,000 times better, so go see that instead. Then, after you've seen Kong, and you're bored, go see this.

title: Maybe I'm not 8 years old any more ... totally lacks quality feel of LOTR
review:
Very hard not to compare to LOTR and this just doesn't stand up to the comparison. Firstly in any medium this is much more of a child's tale than LOTR so perhaps the Disney treatment is more justified. But the translation to the big screen lacks a quality feel and Peter Jackson's direction, his dedication to the story in LOTR and to a quality product are nowhere to be seen. He really deserved the knighthood! So sadly we have wooden acting, 1 dimensional characterization, cheap special effects.

Looks like they did it for the money. Very sad.

C.S. Lewis must be spinning in his grave.

title: Well done special FX+CGI but children's fantasy story...
review:
Copied this from another comment because it's a perfect summary: "might be o.k. for small children, but definitely not for the sophisticated child or adult."

Honestly, I feel such fantasy crap like Beastmaster or Masters of the Universe actually has a better story background than Narnia.

As a movie Narnia is well done, actually it is only the garbage fantasy mix from the original story that makes it suck for anyone beyond 12. Maybe we have a better understanding now why J.R.R. Tolkiens and C.S. Lewis friendship broke up on this. It takes some time to compare two books, but two movies based on books can be compared within one day.

Comparing LOTR with Narnia is like comparing Dracula to Count Von Count.

title: Something just wasn't Right
review:
I was so bummed when I finally saw this film. I had read the book as a child and absolutely was enthralled with it. I had wrongfully assumed that the movie would have that same kind of excitement and adventure for me.

The CGI was well done (Kong producers should have asked these guys for help!), the story was alright, the acting was exactly what I expected.

Story: My first question for the film would be...what in the world takes so LONG to get the story really moving? This IS the Chronicles of NARNIA right? Well I was afraid the actors would age on screen before my very eyes at the pace the first act was going. There was TOO MUCH (I know you don't hear that often) character development. I didn't ever think they were all going to get through the wardrobe.

Once they did the story picked up a little and it felt a little better from there. However it never had that adrenaline rush of excitement one usually gets from movies of this style.

As for the acting, hey they are kids, they did pretty darn good for kids. Not all kids are Dakota Fanning.

I would recommend this film only for families with children and for those who have not read the book. Why? Kids won't care that the acting is mediocre or that the first act moves like molasses. They will be happy with pictures of snow and hide and seek games. Why people who haven't read the book? Because if you have read the book you will be disappointed (assuming you have a pretty decent imagination) and if you haven't read the book and you are of adult age, you probably aren't going to read it now so you might as well see the movie.

title: A great movie for all ages!
review: With box office attendance falling, Hollywood has finally caught on. The "Chonicles of Narnia" is a movie in the traditional style. For those of you tired of fractured fairy tales, anti-heroes, slang, dumbed-down dialogue and pop cultural references, flatulence gags, and other such staples of current family-geared movies, this is the movie you have been waiting for. Great visuals, lots of suspense, and a message of hope and sacrifice that is faithful to the book. The cast, writers, producers and director have taken C. S. Lewis' simple, almost wispy allegory and turned it into a vibrant, convincing adventure story.

title: Georgie, the witch's hair, subtext and snowballs
review:
When I saw Corpse Bride I thought that was the best movie I'd seen all year (besides Madagascar and Robots). However I may need to rethink that. This was such an awesome movie. I read the book over Thanksgiving weekend to gear myself up. There were some differences from the book, which is expected. But it was still amazing.

Georgie Henley is a great actress. She brought a lot to her role and gave convincing crying scenes that were quite touching.

Tilda Swinton is another great actress. She clearly brought the White Witch to life. I loved her scenes with Edmund and how she was so deceiving. I also liked her hair. At a certain distance it looks like dreadlocks. I thought that was interesting.

There's a great spiritual subtext within the plot. I loved that the most. I loved the representations of Gethsemane and dying on the cross. That's all I'll say for those who haven't seen it.

And finally one more thing. This is something that puzzled me. If you're an 8-year-old girl and you get hit in the face with a hard-pack snowball, I'm sure the last thing you'd do is laugh, especially if you're the sensitive type.

If you haven't seen this movie, I highly recommend it.

title: Peter Pan remake
review:
All children in a London family are transported magically to a distant land. Here they find a conflict between the evil ruler and the outcasts. There is combat. There are magical weapons. There is a favorable outcome. The children return home and are welcomed.

Is it Neverland? Or Narnia? Captain Hook has morphed into the wicked white witch. Is it the crocodile or the lion that the antagonist fears? The Indians of Neverland are replaced by talking animals. Like the movie of Peter Pan, the combat is bloodless and is not likely to scare children.

But don't let the similarity to Peter Pan keep you away. The acting is very good. Georgie Henley (Lucy) is a delight. The special effects are very good. The plot is simple and dialog is easy to follow, very unlike Lord of the Rings. It is good entertainment for all ages.

title: Enjoyable but not worth the hype
review: After hearing my friends rave about this movie, i had to watch it for myself. Sadly though... the movie was reasonably enjoyable, but some what disappointing in my opinion. Firstly, the beginning of the film was far to lengthy and boring. How the kids happen to stumble upon the wardrobe is tedious to say the least. Over elaboration of the stupid games played, and how they all FINALLY end up in the closet can really bore people. Thankfully, the movie picks up pace and the cute animals are humorous and realistic. However, my major qualm about the film is it fails to remain sensible or logical in its own right. Even though The Matrix and The LOTR were far fetched stories, the plot was logical and believable.... On the other hand, this story is just basically random. The 4 "heros" actually didn't do much in the entire story. It was Aslan who gathered the troops, it was aslan who killed the ice queen, and all they were, were props! The girl only shot ONE arrow in the battle... Them being called kings and queens really doesn't make sense. Neo could do anything, frodo the ring bearer.... but these 4... nothing! Well, all was not lost considering that the final battle was rather enjoyable but still abit short. LOTR like CG for the final battle. One thing that i found astounding was that Aslan could just resurrected just because the ice queen didn't read the fine print..... overall, moderately enjoyable, but somewhat lacking in many ways.....

title: Wow!!!!!!!!!!!!!
review: You know I have read all the Narnia books and I have to confess that I was afraid of this movie, the books are greater than Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings, son I thought that the movie was to complicated to do, but I was luckily wrong the movie was terrific, i don't have the words I just can't wait for the Horse and his Boy And I just wan to say to people that doesn't know or understand thing of the movie that read Magician Nephew sou you understand all the thing you don't know and to read all the other books so you can see all the wonders of this magical world and see all the beauty of CS Lewis creation NARNIA its incredible!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

title: In a Nutshell...A Good Movie
review: Disney has proved time and time again that they can make the best children's movies. Over the past couple of years they have began to make adult movies (Pirates of the Caribbean, National Treasure) and now finally they have made a movie that children and adults can both watch together and both truly enjoy watching. The movie is rated PG and was obviouslly meant to be so, it could've easily been made a PG-13, but the books were written for children so the correct decision was made to make the movies for children as well. This movie could easily be "The Lord of the Rings for Kids". Both authors (C.S. Lewis and J.R.R. Tolkien) were very good friends so it seems fitting that both of them would write two of the greatest stories ever, with one directed toward kids and the other toward adults. Being that this movie was PG, only the main evil character was developed, unlike Lord of the Rings where the extreme "evilness" of the orcs were brought out as well as Sauruman and Sauron's. The battle was done very well with enough action included to make fans of action movies happy, there were very few scenes, if any, where any one character gets completely destroyed, as there were in the epic Lord of the Rings' battles. All in all, the story was done nicely there was not, however, any attempt to explain how the wardrobe could do what it did or how it came into the professor's possession. I am told that the book does explain this. Overall a good movie for people of all ages to enjoy.

title: Well done efforts pay off, I hope the next one is better
review:
Briefly, this is a good film, and a film that should do well with the audience and the box office. And, for more detailed reviews, please read the many others written by users here at IMDM.

Up front, I do recommend this movie, and I think it's well worth seeing, but it's not without its flaws.

And I think the flaws have to do with two things: Direction, and animation. The animation is of course superb, life changing, record setting, and all that, like so many reviewers are writing - but being truly critical, there are places here and there where it just doesn't work for me. Maybe I'm asking too much, and maybe if this film had been delayed a few years the problems for the animators would not have existed. To the point, in many scenes, just as I was relaxing into the scene, and really "suspending disbelief" and buying the scene, some character would move funny, and unnaturally, and that made the experience less than perfect - Sort of like trying to relax on a long drive, but every few hundred yards there's the unsettling feel and sound of another pothole, followed by easing back into relaxation until....wham ! another pothole. I started to look for flaws, which really isn't my nature, but it's what happened.

As for direction....for one, Andrew Adamson is a superb talent, but I have to report what I saw, and how I felt. And I'll do this by comparing the human acting in this film to that of Shadowlands, a film I admire greatly.

In Shadowlands, it all felt so real. Of course having Debra Winger and Tony Hopkins as centerpieces didn't hurt any. The Warnie character was superb as well. Compare that acting to some in this film - the Professor, the little ogre that was always around the white witch, Mrs. MacReady.....just a little overdone, I think, and unconvincing. Each time they were on the screen, I kept thinking their makeup etc. looked more like Little Theater than major Film. In Shadowlands, I felt drawn into the characters, and I especially admired the sensitivity, mannerisms, and believability of the Douglas Gresham character.

Funny enough, each of the four children characters in this film (Narnia) also, at times did this for me, especially the Lucy character, but in many cases when most or all of them were together, it just felt staged. And of course it was staged - this is film and they were acting. I just wish it hadn't been so obvious.

And I think all this added up to one feeling overall for me....the movie dragged rather than flowed in many parts, and that alone takes away from this being a top notch film in its own right. It will succeed with many people, and at the box office, and it was a very admirable job at bringing the book to film, but if this is to succeed as a franchise and live up to its potential, I think it needs to be viewed with the criticisms that I and several others have pointed out.

title: Lord of the Rings (Childrens version
review: I thought this movie was a children's version of the epic Lord of the rings. This movie well exceeded my expectations with seamless graphics and a stringent script which stayed directly with the novel version. I was amazed by the unknown acting talent scrounged up from our English and Irish neighbors. The movie is paced well, if a bit dodgy in the beginning. Having read the story previously you find yourself already familiar with the characters which might throw off a newcomer to the tale. I think that anyone of any age can take great pleasure from the movie. I can only hope and dream that this stays a success which will lead to the making of the other terrific tales written by C. Lewis.

title: The Mouse does the Lion
review:
Some suits at the House of the Mouse had this idea of bringing to film this fantasy epic on a mystical world, based on a well-known book series and have it done by a Kiwi director. That's great, but the problem is, this idea has been done already. Even though "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe" is actually a good movie, the concept is lacking in freshness.

There's not a second in the movie we can't shake off the sensation that we have seen something like this before, and better executed. It's also hard to forget Disney's marketing has more influence in this movie than its artistic merits.

The Jehovah's Witness-y side of the story is also a marketing element well implemented. People tired of getting hardcore Christan culture constantly shoved down are not going to be bothered by it, and Bible-Belt families will be delighted.

Again, this is a good picture. A great live-action debut by the director and a bankable new franchise for Disney to milk. Until the public gets tired of the literary-fantasy-epic trend, (which could be not that far in the horizon).

title: Lacking a little something!
review:
Don't get me wrong I liked this film tremendously but I feel that it is possibly the only book in the series, except maybe for The Last Battle, that is actually epic enough to be made into a movie.

As for "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe." There was something about the film as a whole that was lacking. It just didn't seem as epic as films that have proceeded it. I didn't fear for the lives of the main characters like I did in the LOTR trilogy. The musical score didn't uplift me during the battle scenes, nor soothe during the more tender moments, ie the death and resurrection of Aslan.

The rest of the series, although good, for me just seems to hum along on auto pilot until the last book in the saga. I for one don't think they'll make the others unless this one does exceptionally well.

What think you?

title: Not perfect, but....
review: Don't go looking for perfection! This is an excellent movie with very little deviation from the book. My wife, two daughters and I went to see this on Saturday. I thought Mr Tumnus was incredible. His facial expressions conveyed his emotions so well going from fear when he first meets Lucy, to nervous determination at what he must do, to sadness and regret at what he was trying to do. The witch was also very well acted. There were a few scenes where I could tell that there was a blue screen. I also thought there should have been more of a build up to when the stone table cracks. HOWEVER, none of this took away from me enjoying the movie!

title: children's fantasy
review:
A solid movie for kids. I have not read the books but I figure from the length of the movie that it stayed somewhat true to the book.

I was impressed with the casting of the Ice Queen. The rest of the casting didn't matter to much to me. Everybody else did a descent job of acting. The scenes and the special effects were great.

Some of the fighting scenes near the end were good. There could have been more fighting, You show 100,000 soldiers before the battle but there is only 10 minutes of fighting?

Some points of the film annoyed me. A beaver that is named mr. Beaver (I might change my name to mr. human). The death of the lion: Girls are crying over a creature who they had just met and he comes back to life. I know the Christian elements of the story but the sacrifice itself and left dead would have been more effective to the story (I thought the whole table thing was a bit lame). The rescue of the youngest boy took thirty seconds. The end of the story annoyed me too.

Every time I try to complain about something about the story I just think that the story is for children 10 and under. The above complaints are more personal complaints. If I was 10 I probably wouldn't have these complaints.

title: Narnia is a rarity to be cherished
review:
Ah yes... Narnia.

A dazzling display of color and richness fills the screen as you are immersed in the wonderful world of Narnia. Groundbreaking special effects, CGI, and film quality throw you back in your seat as the story unfolds before your eyes. As if that isn't enough, wait till Aslan grazes the big screen mid-way through the movie.

William Moseley, Anna Popplewell, Skandar Keynes, and Georgie Henley all put forth an exceptional performance. Their true emotion will leave your face moist from the salty tears that escaped your eyes throughout the film. In fact, Henley's performance was so brilliant for her first film that she deserves nothing less than Breakout Performance of the Year. James McAvoy was lovable and fun as Tumnus and served as a delight to the screen. Tilda Swinton served as a perfect White Witch who balanced evil and charm perfectly, how the 45 year-old woman swung the swords around in the big battle was an immense credit to her versatility.

Lavish sets from all over the world are wonderfully portrayed in this film. The snow is mildly fake and takes away from some the glory of the scenes, but it is still adequate.

Improved dialogue, added humor, intense fantasy/realism, a glorious battle, all are present and accounted for.

All in all, The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe is a visual masterpiece that will take a place in your heart forever. One can only hope that the next 6 will live up to their predecessor.

title: Like "The Lord of the Rings," this movie is a good tribute to the Narnia Series
review:
There are many things in life that are risky. It could be argued there are few things more risky than to take a classic novel and turn it into a screenplay. We saw this with Lord of the Rings. There was a lot of excitement surrounding the news of not one, but three movies being made for this trilogy, but it was coupled with apprehension. Questions were being asked. Are these movies going to stand up to the novel? Are the changes that were made going to adversely affect the story? If you can't fit the whole novel in the movie, what are they going to leave out? All fears were gone after The Fellowship of the Ring was released. Peter Jackson did a superb job and gave a fine example on how a classic novel should be translated to film.

Fans of the Chronicles of Narnia went through the same experience and should find themselves with the same result. The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe, the first book of the series, sets the bar for the other six. And it can be said with confidence, the bar is set pretty high.

Like LOTR, there is some license taken in the screenplay, which is by Ann Peacock, some of which, was needed to add to the story. For example, the first 10 minutes of the film aren't even in the book, but could be extrapolated from the first few pages of the novel. And, it was needed to give us the reason why the four children were being shipped off to the countryside to live with a recluse professor and a housekeeper desperately in need of anger management classes.

The story is about four children who discover a magical world hidden by a wardrobe that seems to be forgotten in a spare room. This land has been taken over by an evil witch and they find out their destiny involves the liberation of this fantastic country. We meet all sorts of fantasy creatures; fauns, talking beavers, minotaurs, centaurs, etc., as the story unfolds.

There is only one actor I could really recognize. That was Liam Neeson, who voiced Aslan, the true king of Narnia and a very large, hardly safe, but good lion. All of the others were relatively unknown, but did a very good job. The four children felt like siblings. The White Witch was great. She was evil, cruel, treacherous. Mr. Tumnus, the dwarfs, all of the human actors were very believable.

The animals, both natural, like the beavers and the wolves, along with the imaginary (fauns, griffins, minotaurs, etc.) were all CGI. To sum up how they looked in a word, especially Aslan, would have to be "wow." There was maybe one spot in the entire film where the CGI betrayed itself, and that was only for a half second. The human voices, mixed with the animals natural growls, barks, chirps, etc, were as important as the CGI itself. Both elements were a great mix to bring life and believability to each character. I believe there was a collaborative work between ILM and Weta Workshop on the creation of these characters, especially the centaurs, minotaurs, etc.

As most of those who "read" this know, this is an allegory. C.S. Lewis, the writer of the The Chronicles series, wore his faith on his shirt sleeve and it influenced all of his writings from the point of his conversion on. However, those who don't consider themselves Christians would still enjoy this film because, as with any good allegory, the parallels are left unsaid. But more importantly, it is a good movie. Cinematography, acting, plot, special affects, all elements of movie making are used to tell the story and it is told well.

From what I can tell, this is the first live action movie directed by Andrew Adamson. He has two funny movies under his belt, Shrek and Shrek 2, but this is his debut in a serious, live-action movie. And he did a very impressive job. If the rest of the book series is supposed to be made into movies, he has set a very impressive precedent. And, given how he did on this one, I hope he will be brought on board for the rest.

If one were to scale this, I think it would be fair to rate it a 9 out of 10. I found myself getting impatient with the story only once while I was waiting for Aslan to first appear. But a good story was made into a good movie that could be viewed more than once without risking boredom.

title: Pretty good, minus the Passion of the Lion.
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia - Based on the classic novel by CS Lewis. Four London children are sent to a professor (Jim Broadbent)s country home in order for protection during World War II. There they find a magic wardrobe which leads to a mystical land called Narnia, which is being ruled by an evil witch (Tilda Swinton). To defeat the Witch, they must join forces with Aslan (voiced by Liam Neeson), the lion God of Narnia, and the great battle between good and evil.

Good things first. The film is well directed for the most part, though it could've been made more touching. It, in the wake of numerous Harry Potter films, Lord of the Rings, and a slew of mediocre epic wanna-bes, manages to keep the ideas of magic and grand scale battles interesting. The music and locales offer a different sort of character and charm from other movies. Swinton is drippingly evil as the Witch. Though she looks like Galadrial without eyebrows and dilated pupils, her character is radically different and deserves appreciation. The children are all earnest and cute and British, though they all have some points where I just wanted to reach into the screen and slap one or two of them. There are some adorable critters in the mix of everything. I loved the adorable little Beavers (voiced by Ray Winstone and Dawn French, one of my beloved British actresses) and the Fox (voiced by the charming Rupert Everett). Liam Neeson voices Aslan (Why is he always typecast as mentor figures?) with earnestly and authority. The final battle is pleasing to the eyes and the adrenaline of all, and manages to be satisfying in spite of it's PG rating. (On a minor note, why are all these experienced warriors so willing to be commanded by a couple of teen boys? Silly.)

Now on to the mediocre stuff. I found myself grimacing at the absurdity and spectacle of the sacrificing of Aslan. Really, what the hell is this? The Passion of the Lion? Disney already killed a Lion in one of their films, and they did it better that way. I haven't read the books, but I don't care if it IS in the book. The scene is just silly. I get the allegory. On the third hour the mice nibbled at the Lion's ropes, and he became alive again. Dumb. Another thing that concerns me, for a film that takes place during World War II and strives to show us the importance of sacrifice, Narnia is pretty lenient on letting ANYONE die unless they're bad. Good people don't die. And that's where the boys are separated from the men, and Lord of the Rings is placed a notch (well. several notches) above Narnia. War involves sacrifice. It involves pain, and Narnia glides over that like it's the glacier lake. Oh, and having a scene that shows Santa giving a 6 year old girl a dagger is just plain wrong. Excellent to take a child to, and alright for everyone else, Narnia gets a B.

title: Narnia - Very Good, Could It Be Better?
review:
First, the overall rating of the movie is good to very good. Narnia is true to the original story and well done. The production values are good and so is the acting. So there aren't any clinkers to trip up the audience as the story progresses. I do recommend it. I want to make this clear up front before I begin to criticize it since most of my disappointment stems from expectations. I don't expect others to have the same expectations that I had for the film.

However, Narnia has been on the horizon for some time, as has been the new Harry Potter film, Goblet of Fire. The difference is that with Potter I already knew what to expect  super design and production values, good to very good acting, and somewhat trying adolescent themes :^). With Narnia there was the hope that it might be entertainment of epic proportion. After all, the story lends itself to that end. It didn't seem to me to achieve that goal.

In the inevitable comparison between the Potter film and Narnia, Narnia comes up short. While there are equally stunning scenes in both films, the impact of Narnia is less. It is in the wonderment department that Narnia falls down. Watching the film, one has the thought that director is no Peter Jackson. The action flows, all the elements are there but the magnitude of the impact is not as great. The casting is good and I have no complaint there. The director has a good eye for faces and uses it in his film.

I was going to say originally that the film did not have enough inspiration or creativity in it. But upon additional thought it was clear that there is much to admire in the film. A lot of the sets, costumes, and makeup designs are superb. The integration of computer graphics and actors is well nigh seamless. Any inspiration that is missing seems to come in framing the shots or the storyline. In fact, if it was possible to have Jackson re-cut the film, he might make it twice as good. All the elements are there after all. It just seems to progress from event to event in a way that sometimes makes the story plod a bit.

It will be interesting to see if Narnia does well and, if it does, where Disney will go with the series. One thing about the Potter franchise is that the films have been consistently good - something that moviegoers know happens but rarely.

There is the issue of whether the film is suitable for children. Although the gore is not excessive, there are lots of battle scenes. And the makeup/design of the monsters is quite good, certainly good enough to scare young children. I am guessing 8 and up would probably be fine. Anyone younger and the violence or monsters could be a bit much or the quiet parts may make them fidget rather than stare properly. Children vary, of course, but I saw one Dad with his 3-year-old there. This film is just too much for a child of that age.

All of this commentary is from the perspective of someone who has read the books. I know the significance of Aslan to the series and the import of the allegories. I find I can't guess the reactions of people who are not familiar with the series and it will be intriguing to read some of those reviews.

title: Exhillorating Adventure that Fits in a Room
review:
After having seen the preview of The Chronicles of Narnia, I was left wide-eyed and brimming with excitement at the anticipation of a sequel.

Narnia is a well-cut, well-rounded film adaptation of C.S. Lewis' classic set of Chronicles. One of the many appeals of the film is that it is entertaining for all ages. It captures the imagination of both those who are young, and those who are still young at heart.

Lucy was exceedingly well-played by the very engaging Georgie Henley who shows ability far beyond her years.

The CGI in this film is nothing short of a modern marvel. The seamless Lion is truly unbelievable. The single best CGI animal I have seen to date. (Better than Jackson's King Kong.) Tilda Swinton plays an average White Witch. Nothing out of the realm of what was expected. William Moseley and Anna Popplewell playing Peter and Susan respectively, also did apt jobs. Nothing outstanding. I feel that James McEvoy's "Mr. Tumnus" was a far more entertaining and engaging character than that of Peter, Susan or Edwin. But then, it may just have been written that way by Lewis...

I think most would agree with me when I say that the Lion and Lucy stole the show.

title: A+ Book-to-Film movie (for once)
review:
I must say that, as a huge fan of C.S. Lewis' books, I was a little weary when I heard the news of his most treasured book being made into a movie. Despite that fact, I eased up slightly when I heard that WETA (the people who made the CGI, armor, miniature effects for Lord of the Rings) was doing most of the work on it.

Watching the movie, I was surprised at how closely the movie followed the book. I mean, sure, there were moments when you thought "I don't remember this", but, hey, besides that, the movie was excellent.

This is one of the few Disney movies that I will actually want to watch again and and again. Great job!

title: Everything I'd Hoped It Would Be
review:
I have been a fan of the Chronicles of Narnia since I was seven years old. Of course, at that age, I had no idea of the symbolic significance of the stories. At 40, and a practicing Christian, these stories have grown with me. I had high hopes for this movie, as well as some apprehension upon going to the theater. Could anything measure up to the magic of Lewis' written words.

The answer? Absolutely. Aslan was portrayed with all the power, might and mystery that could possibly be conveyed in the two-dimensional world of film. I believe it says something when a person can enter a theater already knowing the story and still be awed.

In ways, it was better than Lord of the Rings. Not one element of the story was missing. Nor was anything added. The film adaptation of this classic is as true to the original story as a film can get. I highly recommend seeing this in the theater. I am sure it will transfer beautifully to DVD, but the big screen has a spectacular impact. Especially the sound.

I'm not usually a fan of child actors, but the children chose to portray the Pevensie children could not have done better. Liam Neeson as Aslan was just perfect. Some (very few) of the CG elements were obvious to the point of mild distraction, but that was truly the films only "weakness." If you are a fan of the series, this will not disappoint. If you are unfamiliar with the story, this will be a treat beyond your greatest imaginings.

Finally, the story's Christian subcontext is a reassurance to believers, a message to non-believers and yet it, like the books, avoids the trap of being too didactic or preachy. This is an amazing movie.

title: Fantastic
review: I went in expecting a good but child orientated movie what I saw must rank as one of the most wonderful films ever made. There is only two things that I had negative thoughts about 1) Some of the animation was a little unpolished; the wolves in certain scenes, and 2) The children were obviously new to it all and didn't have the presence of say Dakota Fanning BUT they were so full of zest, especially the youngest, you couldn't help but love them. Otherwise it was pretty much unfaultable! That being said It wasn't quite made in the scope of The Lord of the Rings BUT it was quite similar in parts and if you loved the lord of the rings (who doesn't?) then this is definitely worth seeing.

title: Good fantasy, but not really an epic.
review:
Four children are taken away from war-torn London to the house of an eccentric professor in the English country side. There, during a rainy day playing hide and seek the youngest girl Lucy (Georgie Henley) finds a portal to a fantasy land, Narnia, in the back of a wardrobe.

What happens after that is a fantasy epic. The coming of the children marks the end of a long winter and the birth of a new age in the land. The White Witch (Tilda Swinton) has brought winter (but not Christmas) to the land and runs Narnia with the aid of her secret police.

I'll get the comparisons out the way first. This isn't as grand feeling as LoTR. Filmed in New Zealand using some of the same epic countryside the film feels like a huge set, it doesn't feel like any of it was set outside in the beautiful country. It's clear that the characters are mostly filmed against blue/green screen and that these days is a disappointment.

The acting from the four children is uniformly great. The voice acting from the animals is good and the CG effects bringing them to life is well done. Liam Neeson playing the father of Aslan does okay, but I felt most Hollywood leading men could have done the job just as well. Tilda Swinton starts off fantastically in her chilling seduction of Edmund (Skandar Keynes), but becomes dull in the middle. A little hamming as the villain can be forgiven, even giving the role a panto feel. She pulls it back for the Stone Table scene only to lose it again in the final battle.

To make the film rating lower (PG in the UK) the film is very sterile. The massive closing battle is relatively 'clean', little blood being spilt. Big as it is you never feel lost, you always know what's going on. Griffons spiral in beautifully, monsters clash with each other with bone crunching speed. The end, again is clean and comes with an abrupt speed leaving me feeling let down.

Andrew Adamson does well. There are a few lighter moments but his tone is too uneven and I found myself glancing at my watch to see how much longer there was until the action picked up again.

A good children's film (maybe a bit dark for younger children in places) and a good starting place for any further films, but could have done so much more.

title: Pulls through despite wooden acting...
review:
I must say, this film delivers as much as can be expected in this day and age. Most blockbusters are horribly contrived action-fests that try to excite us with their fancy special effects. This is a little different, but before I get to the good parts, the cons:

The acting is terrible and the script isn't great. If you don't like hearing action film-esquire one-liners, then try to block the twenty of them or so out of your hearing. If you are going to see four no-name actors delight you with their unexpected Oscar-worthiness, you will be SORELY disappointed. I think the best acting was done by Liam Neeson as Aslan, but as such you don't even see him.

Now, what pulls this through to an 8.

It actually follows the story to a T...some of the lines were right from the book, and that made me very happy. The special effects, despite some poor blue-screen, were unbelievable. Aslan was perfect...there were times were I thought it was a real lion (I know, I know...that is the dumbest thing I could ever say...I know). Also, just the feelings that the audience feels (if they are into the movie) are phenomenal. The scene containing Aslan's walk to sacrifice carries a power and emotion that I have been waiting to see in an adaptation of this book. (Those who haven't read it will be in great suspense at this point...the looks on some of the faces in the theatre were pretty amusing).

So, yes...as is often the case these days, ignore the wooden characters and enjoy the overall story and the beauty of Narnia and its inhabitants (and take the kids).

title: Awesome, Awesome, Awesome
review:
This movie was simply awesome. It can be a great date flick, children's getaway or it can allow you to rekindle lost youth. I don't always comment on films because I am so cynical, but this movie just melted me away. The computer graphics were breath taking and the storyline just kept you in suspense. The only weird out of place part was the World-War II scene at the beginning. But, I guess it needed to be done to link why the children were sent to the professor's mansion. I am definitely looking forward to another Narnia adventure. Unfortunately, I will most likely need to wait 2 years.

This is just simply worth watching!!!

title: Had me sold until the battle scene...
review:
I truly enjoyed Narnia for the first two hours of the movie. The casting of the children was perfect. The special effects, though spotty at times, were effective. I was drawn into the world of the book through the artistic medium of film. However, the illusion of belief was shattered during the final battle scene. In short, I thought I was looking at cut scenes from a new Xbox 360 game.

This would be fantastic if the scene was produced for a video game, but not for a big-budget holiday film. The polar bears dragging the ice queen's sleigh didn't look a far-cry (no pun intended) from the cgi Coca-Cola bears. Some scenes with the centaurs looked like a first-generation Xbox or PS2 title. Very young children will--most likely--not be distracted by these details. But everyone else, from teens to adults, will see it as a cheapening of the film.

Will I see it again? Most likely. Will I buy it on DVD? Probably not. I'm hoping that, if future films are produced in the series, the effects will be improved. The expectation of the average movie-goer has been raised dramatically (ala Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, etc.). If future Narnia movies do not meet (or raise) the bar previous films have set, they will not stand the test of time, nor the patience of the audience.

title: the message was clear, but too much cheese
review:
Like everyone else, I had very high hopes for this movie. The movie stuck fairly close to Lewis's story. The stone table part was magnificent, and I think Lewis would've been very happy. Nuances such as Lucy and Susan's bewilderment of touching Aslan's mane were clearly there. However, cheese sank in from the very beginning as soon as the musical score came into focus. Contemporary music ruined the movies epic theme for me. As soon as I heard the Enya-esquire tribal sound coming out of the Cinerama's speaker system, I thought, "Great. Disney's gone the route of other film makers... cutting a deal for that one pop star." And I'm sure that their will be a number of other artists that will gain some monetary gain from all of this. Nothing but opportunistic BS. So, yeah, I thought the musical score stank to high heaven.

The children got a little annoying, and by the end, you really want to knock some sense into these characters. I think the director really settled for less with some of the scenes. It seemed as if the musical score (which already sucked to begin with) had to make up for the wretched bad acting; a combination which almost made me laugh out loud.

But I'm sure you're kids will like it. The animals were truly amazing. They were actually the best part of the film, I thought. The beavers rocked. I could watch a whole movie devoted just to them. Cute, cute, cute! Overall assessment: C- to D+

title: Just one little gripe
review: Narnia is far better than I ever hoped it would be due to the amazing effects and the wonderful Tilda Swinton, but here is my one problem with the film. I never new fully appreciated Daniel Radcliffe and his fellow Hogwarts classmates until today. Strangely enough I liked this better than any of the Potter movies (haven't seen Goblet yet), but I had a big problem with the male children and a lesser problem with the females. They simply were not up to the task. The boy who played Edward made me feel that I was watching a school play. He was quite awful. I have only read the Magician's Nephew which had a different set of children in the story. I hope the other 6 books are the same way. Let's put it this way. Dakota Fanning doesn't have to worry about losing any future roles to any of these kids. I found the Christian elements of the film were handled quite well also. This was a rendering of Lewis's vision and to downplay it too much would not be faithful to the story to overdo it would have made the film play like a Sunday School special. It was a difficult task and the filmmakers are to be applauded. Certain to make gobs of money. Would not recommend it to the very little ones. My daughter is a very bright 6 year old. she loved it, but she held on tight and looked away several times. Don't go any younger than a bright 6 year old. And if you don't have any kids go anyway. You're bound to enjoy.

title: Decent movie from a mediocre book
review: The realization of Narnia is fairly impressive. Landscapes are portrayed nicely, and the scope of the world is felt. However certain areas (mostly the witches castle and dungeon) are so obviously artificial you want them to hurry up to the next scene, before you're pulled out of the fantasy world completely. The best moments in the film, come from Lucy's first venture into Narnia. Her encounter with Mr. Tumnus is well done and when he enchants her with his flute, the scene is fairly creepy. His turnaround is nicely portrayed and he stands out as one of the better actors in the movie. Despite the wonder of disappearing in and out of the wardrobe, you start to wish they'd go in for good and start the adventure. Mostly because it's tough to watch Peter and Susan act without any wolves or lions to distract you from their melodramatic expressions. Once in Narnia, the film begins to take off and is only slowed down in a few scenes that are unnecessary. THese scenes are not in the book and are the filmmaker's attempt to try to flesh out more story. However there are already places in the book that shouldn't be there, so adding more scenes doesn't help. The adventure is fairly face paced. Once meeting some well rendered beavers, they are attacked by fiersome wolves. THe wolf captain proves to be the scariest villain of the movie and offers some of the best CGI in the movie. (The witch might have been scarier if her hair wasn't gelled back like she was just riding a motorcycle, and she didn't have to cope with that stupid crown.) Anyhow the story goes along with the children meeting Aslan. Probably the best computer generated character since Gollum.
