Aslan gets a nice chunk of screen time and he seems more than capable of defeating any witch. I guess thats kind of the whole problem. Aslan was gone and now he's back. He brings with him spring, a huge army and brings back animals that were turned into stone. So who needs the kids? All they do is mess things up enough to get Aslan killed. (But that doesn't matter because he is reincarnated.And yes that is kind of like Jesus)Peter really doesn't do much. Sure he fights the witch, (with swordfighting abilities we never knew he had) but it's Aslan who get her in the end.

title: What Might Have Been....and What May Yet Be.
review:
I went into this afternoon's matinée with mild expectations. After having recently finished the seven book CS Lewis series, I wondered-often aloud-whether or not it would be possible to truly capture the magic of Narnia on the big screen. Overall, I believe this film is a stunning attempt at relaying all of the wonder of Lewis' magical world, but it falls short of satisfying those of us who were completely entranced by the literary version of the story.

Down to the very last creature, every bit of acting was superb, particularly Lucy and the White Witch. Peter was not quite as regal as I had expected, but then again, what young boy who has been thrown into a mythical world by walking into a wardrobe really is regal? I was disappointed that he was never referred to as the High King, elevating his status above that of Edmund-although Edmund does acquiesce to his leadership after Aslan's "death." I had hoped to be captured by real visual majesty ala the LOTR Trilogy. I was disappointed. But there was enough magic present in this opening volley that I will return on opening day for any sequels-and I have a sense that whatever nitpicking concerns I have for this first film will be long forgotten as the series moves forward. I continue to anticipate great things.

title: The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe
review: The Chronicles Of Narnia: The Lion, The With And The Wardrobe is based on the novel of the same name by C.S. Lewis. The film takes place in England during World War 2 and is about four siblings. There names are Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy. To keep them safe from the war they are sent away to live with a professor. One day while playing in the big house Lucy discovers that if you enter the wardrobe you will enter a winter land called Narnia. Her siblings do not believe her, but finally they look for themselves and see that Lucy was not lying. The siblings make friends with the local creatures who tell them that the land is cursed by the evil witch Jadis who has cursed the land to always be winter time. The animals protect the siblings from Jadis and they are introduced to a lion named Aslan who shows them that they are the only ones who will be able to save Narnia from the evil queen. The end results in a battle between good and evil and the fate of Narnia rests on their shoulders. The film has good direction, good performances by the entire cast, good cinematography, good art direction and good set decoration. The film started out really promising and I thought I would quite like it, but by the end I was quite disappointed. I thought the film was well made and it is a good looking film, but mainly I had trouble with the film's pacing. As I mentioned before, when the film started out I found it quite interesting, but as it went along I felt it dragged and soon it became slower and slower to the point where I was getting bored with the film. I feel that if perhaps the film had been trimmed and edited a little better that this may not be the case. I felt the end (especially the battle scenes) just went on for far too long and I just lost my interest. The book that this film is based on is quite popular and I'm sure that many people will really enjoy this film. I say this because I' am personally very picky when it comes to adventure/fantasy films. Really popular films such as The Lord Of The Rings just do not interest me and I think that this is a film that falls in the same category. I 'am sure that many adventure and fantasy film fans will enjoy this movie and me not really being a fan of the genre will stick with my opinion that I did not like it. However I do feel that I could have liked this movie with a little better pacing and editing. But as it stands I can appreciate the direction and the way the film looks, but other than that this film was just not for me.

title: Great effects but awfully tame on the action
review: I must give this movie a great deal of credit for the effort on special effects. They took the time to make the non-existent appear totally real. This was a definite strong point! Unfortunately, the action level in this movie was severely debilitated. Word and phrases like, "to the death," were brandished (perhaps to build up the feeling and the intensity), but when all was said and done, the actual portrayal of the whole book through this movie was rather like my describing the American Revolutionary War process as, "the colonists dumped some tea, England got mad; then the colonists wrote a Constitution and the US became a country." If you're expecting a dynamic and powerful movie, this isn't it! If, on the other hand, you want something lightly entertaining, but not terribly moving, you're right on track here.

title: A fine movie, but a let down. Definitely not as good as I had hoped.
review:
I've been waiting for "Narnia" to come out for about a month now. So naturally, I went to see it the first chance I got. It was sold out. So I went to a later showing (which was also sold out) and waited in line for a half hour to get in. I was disappointed by the movie. Probably not worth the $7 I paid to get into it. Sure it's nice to finally have a big screen adaptation of CS Lewis's book, but it could have been done so much better. Not to say this is a bad movie. (The amount of people gushing about how wonderful it is should cancel out that thought) But it's not an amazing movie. It's just a fine movie. An okay one. Allow me to explain.

The number one biggest flaw in "Narnia" is the casting. 3 of the leads should never have been cast in this movie because I can guarantee you that there are better people out there. Characters in point: Lucy, Aslan and the White Witch. Lucy is played by newcomer Georgie Henley. Yes she is very young, but that is no excuse for her to be a bad actor. Throughout the movie, she had this air about her that seemed to say, "Oh! I'm doing this because Andrew Adamson told me to and I'm looking like he told me to look." Chalk it up to inexperience, but that is no excuse. I was so sad to find out that Liam Neeson was doing the voice for Aslan. That was an AWFUL decision. Granted, Neeson is a very good actor. But he is not acting in this movie, he is giving the VOICE for a character. Everyone who has seen a Neeson movie or heard him talk knows that he has a very, calm, gentle and smooth voice that never really changes despite what's going on around him. It isn't the fierce or proud voice that was needed for Aslan. In my opinion, the voice over would have been better if given by someone who had a deeper, richer voice. James Earl Jones, perhaps? They need not have necessarily re-cast the role of the White Witch, but they definitely could have had Tilda Swinton show some more emotion. Yes I understand that her character is cold, but she is most certainly not devoid of emotion. In my opinion, Swinton's performance was very bland. This is not to say that ALL of the performances/voice overs were badly executed - because they weren't. Rupert Everett as the voice of the Fox and Ray Winstone and Dawn French as the voices of Mr. and Mrs. Beaver were quite good. As was James McAvoy as Mr. Tumnus. But it is Skandar Keynes, William Moseley and Anna Popplewell as the eldest Pevensie children that really shine. Skandar is quite believable as Edmund, beginning as a sulky young boy and ending as a quiet young man. Anna does a good job of playing the logical Susan. But it is William who doesn't let down at any point and in my mind, is the best actor in the entire movie. All of their performance's make this movie worth while.

My second, and last, problem with "Narnia" is that it lacks the spice of other book adaptations. ESPECIALLY those of recent years that are adaptations of other beloved series. Namely, the Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter. Both of these series do a magnificent job of staying loyal to the books without being boring and they also do a good job of drawing you into the story. Yes we know that Harry doesn't get killed by Voldemort, but we are still on the edge of our seat, scared that something will happen. This NEVER happened in "Narnia". Andrew Adamson seemed to be saying, "I loved this book as a child and I will not change any of this. Even if it would make my movie better." There are many scenes that could have been cut out or sped up, but they were not and I actually began to grow BORED during the movie. Yes there are the clever moments (okay, clever MOMENT) like at the beginning, with the movie starting with the bombing of London. This drew you in, but you didn't really STAY IN.

All in all, this movie is a fine movie. Nothing special. And yes, there ARE religious undertones in this movie. GET OVER IT. Lewis made it that way and if you don't like the content, don't complain about it. No one is making you watch this movies and if you won't appreciate it, don't bother.

title: Not "that" good
review:
Well before I went to see this movie the hype was that it's the next LOTR...Now that I have seen it I can tell you that it is far from it. It was really disappointing on how I actually got bored through the first part of the movie (more then half of the movie was actually super super slow, no action what so ever) The only thing I liked in this movie was the visual effects. The movie wasn't very entertaining all the way till the battle which occurs near the end.

But as I said earlier the visual effects were superb! Coming from a graphic design background I really enjoyed that part of the movie. Very nicely done!

Now lets see what Peter Jackson has to offer with King Kong next week :)

title: Obvious Symbolism
review:
The Chronicles of Narnia which follows four siblings in an amazing journey through a magical world is an instant classic.

If any one goes to see this movie there is no way you can miss the obvious symbolism of a Christian and Jesus. It show in the lion how Jesus sacrificed his life. It shows you another view of it all. FOr any Christians to see this it will be an unforgettable movie.

Even if you and your family are not religious, this movie is a must see. It is a brilliant re-make of the book that holds true to C.S. Lewis's classic. The movies to come and follow "The Lion, Witch, and The Wardrobe" are a waited for event!

title: Has bite but lacks charm.
review:
I saw this at a special midnight preview screening. The place was packed to the rafters with not a child in sight.

The film is shot on an epic and majestic scale of 2:35 and every inch of the wide framing is packed with rabid detail. It looks gorgeous and the lighting is splendid, the costumes are colourful, the landscapes reveal wonder upon wonder, the creatures are stunningly created and the script moves along at a cracking pace. The Walpurgisnacht-esquire scene will creep out most people and I recommend any parents to be vigilant when it starts. This is a fairly provocative and terrifying orgy of violence that could well disturb many kids.

The major flaw is the uninspired score and the lack of escapist magic and charm. The four kids in the film are anemic and devoid of any real emotion. This hampers any connection or engagement with their characters.

I still prefer the old animation from the 1980's over this multi-million dollar venture.

Still, it's not all bad and there is much to enjoy and savour. There's even a sly reference to KING KONG and many nods to THE LORD OF THE RINGS. Take your kids and spend a couple of hours in the world of the Wardrobe.

Above Average.

title: Not a bad movie, but not amazing either.
review: I suppose I allowed myself to build too much anticipation for this film. I believed it would be as good a movie as I had seen all year. Well, it wasn't. That's not to say it was bad, per se, but there was nothing truly excellent in this film save the effects. As an adaptation from a novel, the film is, for the most part, very faithful. There are only a couple of changes made that I had a problem with, and these were tiny and did not distract. But at the end of the day, this film is just average. This review isn't all doom and gloom, there are some nice positives. As I stated earlier, the effects are top notch and I don't ever remember explicitly recognizing them. There is a lot of very funny humor. Tilda Swinton is magnificent as Jadis, the White Witch. And parents should not be afraid of taking smaller children to see it as the film is not scary or bloody to any great degree. Go see it, it will entertain mildly....just don't expect to be blown away.

title: CS Lewis would have had mixed views of this film
review: Cs lewis would have approved of the wartime beginning and period feel and it is a very English film. However he may not have liked some of the departing from the plot, but some of this provided necessary drama. Great performances from Liam Neeson as Aslan and James McAvoy as Tumnus. The White Witch is never really frightening and the children aren't convincing. Seems very like lord of the Rings at times, especially the scenery and battle sequences. A well directed film that doesn't hide the dark side and religious connotations. great for children and some humour for adults. best performance must go to the animated wolf Maugrim, very frightening

title: Story setting nice but characters did not endear
review:
Saw the movie preview screening on 6 Dec 2005.

Some quick bites:

This is a personal view : I never read the book so perhaps the characters would have been more endearing on the silver screen. Kids will probably love this movie but it didn't seem well-tailored for the adults (or perhaps adults who haven't read any of the books before). From the perspective of a clueless viewer such as I myself, I couldn't help but feel nothing of the plight of the foursome (in truth, Lucy was not too bad and was acceptable) and couldn't find much redeeming factors even at the very end. Perhaps with the hindsight of prior reading, I my change my views.

CGI's were top-notch especially Aslan who looked uncannily life-like.

I've always had a soft spot for fantasy-based movies and this was no exception. It had a fairly solid storyline although I must admit that some scenes could do with more brevity and moved the movie at a quicker pace.

Special mention must go to Swinton's portrayal as the White Witch - she was totally in her element, fleshed out her character superbly and was truly a piece of excellent casting by the directors. Though suspiciously a bit like Kate Blanchett in style in LOTR, Swinton played the evil role superbly and was easily the star of this movie.

My kids will love it for sure. But just a 6/10 from me.
